description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for year-ago periods are restated for an accounting change, which also resulted in gains in the latest periods; second quarter and 6 months gains from the change were $4,200,000 and $8,400,000, respectively, compared with $4,451,000 for the year- earlier quarter and $8,902,000 for the year-earlier 6-month.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on July 24 about the Zenith Electronics Corporation inaccurately described the production of Magnavox color television sets. Most are still made in the United States.

title: Colleges Set Up Scholarships For Eastern Brooklyn Youths
description: To encourage greater achievement among students at five high schools in poor neighborhoods in eastern Brooklyn, five private colleges have offered 65 scholarships to students from the schools.

title:
Patents;
Improving Diagnosis Of AIDS
description: LEAD: PROCESSES patented this week for the Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company in Emeryville, Calif., are regarded as strongly improving the diagnosis of specific diseases such as AIDS. Kits to be used for disease detection are to be produced.

title: Regan Continues: Protecting the President Over Arms for Hostages
description: In his second day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington, Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, was questioned by members of Congress on his knowledge of the Iran-contra affair. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony.

title: TRASH DISPUTE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: The shoulder-high garbage, maggots and rotten fruit are gone and the city's Italian Market is breathing easier.

title: Hungry City Unions Beginning the Hunt
description: IT'S called the Easter Egg Hunt, and it happens every three years. The term was coined by Robert W. Linn, director of the Office of Municipal Labor Relations, to describe the search for the money the city hides in its budget for municipal wage increases - this year perhaps as much as $450 million.

title: 2d Justice for Fifth Circuit
description: The Supreme Court, in an unusual move, has assigned two members to handle emergency matters from Louisiana, Texas and Mississippi, an area that has had many appeals of death sentences.

title: Nuclear Plant Is Shut Down
description: A leak of radioactive water in its cooling system forced a shutdown early Friday of the Detroit Edison Company's Fermi II nuclear power plant, officials said. An alert was declared at 2:20 A.M. after ''water with slight radioactivity'' leaked in a feed water check valve that was being repaired, a company spokesman said. The plant was shut down at 3:17 A.M., and the alert was ended at 4:04 A.M.

title: Johnson Not Mets' Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: French Air-Traffic Controllers Sign Accord Ending Dispute
description: French air-traffic controllers have signed an accord with the Transport Ministry, ending 15 weeks of job actions over a pension dispute.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
AT HOME ABROAD
description: LEAD: CYRIL OTHENIN-GIRARD was surprised to find ''so many old cars on the highway'' in America. Laurence Reynard gets a kick out of the ''big refrigrators.'' Jean-Francois Blachaere finds it intriguing that even teen-agers who don't need the money often choose to work in the summer.

title: Beyond Fried Clams and French Fries
description: If you go to Cape Cod in search of fine dining spots, those that meet the test by big city standards can be counted on the fingers of both hands. The Cape is better known for its clam shacks and fish houses, and that is as it should be.

title: Plot Thickens On Home Runs
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Parks as Retreats
description: Those thousands of us who live below Merrick Road and share the South Shore have a great privilege. Only a few minutes' walk for some, or a short drive for others, and we look out on a scene far removed from the shopping mall, commuter-railroad, flea-market aspects of Nassau County.

title: 'Teen Wolf' Stunt Kills Youth
description: A teen-ager performing a handstand on the hood of a moving pickup truck here died after falling to the pavement, the police said. The 17-year-old, Kelly David Draper, lost his balance as the truck moved at 15 miles an hour, Sgt. Joe Owens said. He said a movie, ''Teen Wolf,'' spawned a handstand-on-moving-vehicle fad.

title: Majors Lean To Business Track
description: AS THIRD-YEAR college students formally declare their majors this fall, they will continue to forgo courses in the humanities and social sciences in favor of vocationally oriented university majors, such as accounting, marketing and health services, according to many experts.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SANDS OF SORROW: Israel's Journey From Independence. By Milton Viorst. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) Some Israelis remember the Six-Day War as their finest moment, others as a victory that contained the seeds of despair. If it rescued the Jewish state from possible annihilation, it also marked the beginning of an occupation that continues to sap the nation's strength. These contradictions are woven into the fabric of Israel, creating patterns that are not readily apparent. Milton Viorst, a political journalist, takes a long look at Israel's four decades, capitalizing on the growing library of memoirs in Washington as well as in Jerusalem, on interviews with some of the principal players and on his own rich experiences. His is a valuable examination of the competing values of religious and secular Jews, of rival Ashkenazi and Sephardic interests and of a mainstream Zionism whose struggle with revisionists remains a factor. ''Sands of Sorrow'' is valuable not only for the linear examination that carries us from the 1948 War of Independence to the debilitating invasion of Lebanon, but for the study of rival domestic forces that continue to bear on Israel's relations with Washington and with its neighbors. Mr. Viorst cites a growing belief in Israel that the Jewish colonization of the West Bank has become irreversible, but he argues that creation of an independent Arab state there remains possible and desirable.

title: Bush, in Iowa, Speaks Softly on Farming
description: Vice President Bush, the Connecticut Yankee, Texas oilman, American diplomat and Presidential candidate, says this to the crowds of Iowa farmers: ''I'm not running for Secretary of Agriculture. You know more about the specifics of farm programs than I do.''

title: A Nigerian City Whose Past Is Cast in Bronze
description: Down on Igun Street, a few steps from the palm-wine bar and across from Dr. Eze's Herbal Medicine clinic, Nigeria's bronze age is flourishing - 600 years after it began.

title: A LAUREL BY ANY OTHER NAME
description: Re ''Laurel: Sacred Shrub, Seasons' Celebrant,'' Opinion Page, June 28: Jerry Cimisi should have taken the trouble to learn the proper name of the laurel, which is Kalmia latifolia. The laurel of ancient times is Lauris nobilis and no relation at all.

title: Curfew Keeps Children Home in Maine Town
description: Precisely at 9 o'clock each evening the siren at Town Hall on Easy Street sends out a deep whistle that sounds through the homes and streets of this central Maine town.

title: A DRAMA-FILLED LANDING IN GROTON
description: FRANCIS MOHR'S hobby was flying, and for years one of his favorite trips was a short flight from Republic Airport in Farmingdale, L.I., near his home in Baldwin, across Long Island Sound to Groton.

title: Author Chronicles Shreds of Lives
description: WE might meet the people in Marian Thurm's books, both her 1984 story collection, ''Floating,'' and her recently published first novel, ''Walking Distance,'' eating an egg roll or a Twinkie in the supermarket, or getting excited about a trip to Disneyland at age 50.

title: LISA B. ASKENASE, A BUYER, TO WED MITCHELL KONSKER
description: Lisa B. Askenase and Mitchell L. Konsker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Konsker of Merrick, L.I., will be married Sept. 3, the mother of the future bride, Mrs. Irwin Askenase of New York, has announced.

title: Officials Cite 23 Food Outlets
description: The New York City Health Department last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: CONGRESS AWASH WITH IDEAS TO EXPAND THE WELFARE STATE
description: IN his memoirs, David A. Stockman, President Reagan's first budget director, recalls his attack on ''the bloated budget of the welfare state,'' with its accumulation of ''40 years' worth of promises, subventions, entitlements, and safety nets.''

title: Learning to Love Woods Hole
description: Joseph Story Fay came to Woods Hole in the 1850's for the same reason most people come to this misty, sea-sprayed Cape Cod village today: to catch a boat to Martha's Vineyard. And like the thousands of tourists who pass through town each summer, Mr. Fay and his family found themselves with time to kill before the boat arrived.

title: MUSIC
description: Billy Joel: The Video Album - Volumes 1 and 2. CBS/Fox. Vol. 1: 40 minutes. $19.98. Vol. 2: 50 minutes. $19.98.

title: EMPTYING A CITY, KIDNAPPING A COUNTRY
description: TO DESTROY YOU IS NO LOSS The Odyssey of a Cambodian Family. By Joan D. Criddle and Teeda Butt Mam. 289 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: Fishermen, Too, Strike At Strange Bait
description: It was near the end of a visit to the Gladding International Sport Fishing Museum in South Otselic, N.Y., when I stumbled upon a display in the dank basement that, for me, caught the essence of the sport. It purported to show each step in the making of the famous Oreno bass plug: the simple cigar-shaped plug with the red head, white body, menacing green and yellow eyes and three treble hooks that is the archetype of a fishing lure.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Pasadena, Calif.; An Office Glut On the Horizon?
description: AFTER a two-year building lull, a new surge of office construction has begun in this suburban city, threatening a new glut.

title: RECORDINGS: ROUNDUP OF NOTABLE RECENT RELEASES
description: Roger Sessions: Symphonies Nos. 4 and 5; Rhapsody for Orchestra. Columbus Symphony Orchestra, Christian Badea, conductor. New World Records CD NW 345-2.

title: FATHER PANIK VILLAGE: HIGH HOPES ARE NOW DESPAIR L>By PEGGY McCARTHY
description: IT began on Dec. 23, 1939, as Yellow Mill Village, an alternative for more than 1,000 families to the rundown tenements they lived in on the east side of Bridgeport. Politicians of the time predicted that the clean, sunny apartments in the new complex would put an end to juvenile deliquency, disease and crime.

title: Recent Sales
description: Fanwood $172,000 390 North Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old colonial; patio, basement, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes, $2,980. Florham Park $203,900 5 Keyes Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, screened porch, 1-car garage, new roof; taxes, $1,673. Hanover Township $216,500 59 Locust Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old split-level; eat-in kitchen, central A/C, fireplace, patio; taxes, $1,727. Maplewood $190,500 83 Oak View Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, formal dining room; taxes, $3,505. Randolph $150,000 852 Route 10 West 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old ranch; basement, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes, $1,975. South Orange $265,000 471 Center Street, 9-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; 4 fireplaces, wraparound porch, den, 4-car garage; taxes, $4,364. OTHER AREAS Port Chester, N.Y. $240,000 99 Robert Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 bath, 52-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman, den, 3-car garage, 0.73-acre; taxes $2,341. Orange, Conn. $210,000 725 Racebrook Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; remodeled, 2-car garage, 150- by 160-foot lot; taxes $1,285. Lindenhurst, L.I. $126,000 255 Lido Promenade West 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000.

title: French Only on New TV Show
description: IT IS springtime in Paris.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: Mortal Choices: Bioethics in Today's World. By Ruth Macklin. (Pantheon, $19.95.) What does a metaphysician do in the world of physicians? Ruth Macklin, a professor of bioethics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, uses many compelling case histories drawn from the ethical problems of modern medicine to answer this question.

title: A New Era for Brooklyn's South Shore
description: IN New York City where most new construction begins with a wrecking ball, vacant land - that rare local resource -is helping to spur development on Brooklyn's southern shorefront.

title: Hot Song, Cool Message
description: ''Cuando Estemos Juntos'' (''When We're Together'') is sexy, suggestive and sung by a boy and a girl who look as if they have a mattress in mind. But its message is abstinence (''I don't want us to regret / Having lived an encounter. / You'll see I'm right / When I say no'') and it has been heard all over Mexico. Not only did ''Cuando Estemos Juntos'' sell 500,000 copies last year, but it provoked a remarkable increase in phone calls and visits to family planning centers - just as its producers hoped.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
College Leaders Read 'How To'
description: LEAD: MACHIAVELLI'S ''Prince'' outlined the tactics that heads of state should employ to stay in power. And according to a survey, the book also offers helpful hints for university and college presidents.

title: DOUGLASS, WITH 134, SHARES LEAD IN SENIOR EVENT
description: Dale Douglass, who has finished second four times this year but never first, matched his opening-day 67 in the second round of the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative golf tournament today and earned a share of the lead with Roland Stafford.

title: Q and A
description: Martinique Question: We want to rent a three-bedroom house in Martinique for a family vacation at Christmas. How can we get the names of house agencies there? - D. G., San Francisco Answer: Families planning to rent houses should be aware that renting in the French West Indies is not as advisable as in some of the other islands, notably the United States Virgin Islands. The standard of facilities, including bathrooms, are often below what many Americans expect, a tourist official on Martinique said. Some guests have complained of inefficient plumbing and limited hot water. But the island has a villa rental service run by the government tourist office that provides information and arranges rentals. The service can be reached by writing to the Martinique Tourist Office, Boulevard Alfassa, Fort-de-France, 97206 Martinique, French West Indies. The telephone number, including international and country codes, is 011-596-63.79.60.

title: THE LIGHTS OF FIREFLIES ARE DIMMING
description: WHEN I was growing up, some 70 years ago, in the town where I still live, one of my joys on a summer night was to watch the fireflies' pulsating lights across the lawn -thousands of them, like stars come close to earth. So many twinkled at once, near and far, that they gave depth-perspective to the darkness.

title: China Says Tornado Killed 16 And Injured 442 in Northeast
description: A tornado swept through three counties in northeastern China on Friday, killing 16 people, seriously injuring 442 and leaving 13 others missing, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: UNCONVENTIONAL TALENT ''New Wave/New Haven'' is the title of the New Haven Artists' Theater presentations by performers who have been seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, P.S. 122, the Kitchen, Franklin Furnace and other New York showcases for what's new in unconventional talent.

title: MAJOR CONFLICTS SEEN IN TESTIMONY OVER IRAN AFFAIR
description: When the Iran-contra committees finish their public hearings next week and begin to prepare a final report, they will confront a hearing record riddled with conflicting and contradictory testimony.

title: William Rau's Scene Was the Railroad
description: WILLIAM H. RAU (1855-1920), whose turn-of-the-century landscape views of Pennsylvania and New York are on view at the Museum of Modern Art through Sept. 29, has the perfect qualifications for canonization by the museum's Department of Photography. Like Eugene Atget and Jacques-Henri Lartigue -two photographers whose work the museum first brought to wide public attention - -Rau is a master of what might be called the vernacular sublime. His pictures are filled with esthetic delights, despite being taken for mundane purposes having nothing to do with art. They seem to have sprung whole from eyes innocent of self-consciousness or guile. They are fresh and exciting in a way that photographs taken in our less ingenuous times no longer can be.

title:
FOCUS: SAN JUAN;
Beachside Condos Increasing
description: LEAD: A SCORE of new condominiums that have sprouted along San Juan's most attractive beaches attest to what economists and developers describe as a boom in construction. About 1,000 apartments are being built or have been finished in the last year, with the bulk of them costing between $100,000 and $300,000.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Piero Frescoes Closed to Public For Restoration

title: HARBOR GUARDIAN BECOMING AUTOMATED
description: IT IS a dark day for lighthouse keepers in New Jersey. The crew of the last manned maritime beacon associated with the state is about to be replaced by a computer.

title: Justine Wise Polier Is Dead; A Judge and Child Advocate
description: Justine Wise Polier, a retired New York City Family Court judge and a leader and recognized authority in the field of juvenile justice and children's rights, died Friday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mayor in a Drug Case Says He Won't Resign
description: Mayor Mike Roark, charged with distributing cocaine and with obstructing justice, has issued a statement denying the allegations and saying he will not resign.

title: Condo And Co-op Rates Drop
description: RESIDENTS of cooperatives and condominiums are finding, to their pleasant surprise, that the cost of insurance coverage for their complexes has started to drop this summer. This follows a two-year period in which premiums became almost prohibitively expensive and directors' liability policies were difficult to obtain.

title: Rome's Mischievous Architect
description: To chance upon one of Rome's many beautiful fountains or hidden piazzas is a common pleasure, but I was not prepared for the array of fanciful buildings designed by a single architect in one of the city's subdued residential quarters. Walking from the Villa Ada in the Parioli district to the Villa Borghese recently, I wandered a few blocks too far east and found myself confronted by a massive arch that connected two apartment buildings. Struck by the oddness of an iron chandelier hanging from the middle of the arch, I stepped closer, only to discover other unusual ornaments on two facing apartment buildings: giant bees, lions' heads and standing figures perched above windows and under balconies. Fading frescoes and Latin inscriptions added to the abundant decoration.

title: FEATURES THE IMPROVE AUTOMATIC CAMERAS
description: In the last six weeks a half dozen friends have asked me to give them advice about buying a point-and-shoot camera. My mother, whose lifelong photography experience has consisted of posing for my father, now owns a Pentax IQ Zoom, the first point-and-shoot model to have a zoom lens. Clearly point-and-shoot mania is upon us.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Middletown, R.I.; A Developer Saves a Farm
description: A DEVELOPER with roots in this town of rolling farmland that touches the sea has planned a subdivision of single-family homes with a special feature. The project, Wyndham Hill, has been designed to preserve a 14-acre strawberry farm.

title: Extreme Measures
description: ON the face of it, Iran seems to be holding the world by the throat. Its strident calls for Islamic revolution have unsettled Moslem neighbors and Arabs of every political persuasion. Last week, during the annual pilgrimage to the Moslem shrine at Mecca, Iranian activists began chanting ''death to America, death to the Soviet Union, death to Israel'' in defiance of rules against political acts at the shrine. Saudi Arabian police, moving to disperse them, opened fire and, according to Iranian reports, scores, perhaps hundreds, of Iranians were killed in a stampede and rioting, shaking the Moslem world. Inflamed crowds in Teheran attacked the embassies of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and France, which has broken relations with Iran in a dispute over suspicions of Iranian involvement in international terrorism. Iranian officials promptly blamed the deaths in Mecca on ''a U.S.-designed plot'' and proclaimed today as ''a day of hatred'' against the United States.

title: Child Development Center Is Set Up
description: LEAD: A NEW Child Development Institute has been established at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. It is described by one of its co-directors, Dr. Margery Franklin, as ''a way of coordinating, consolidating and expanding various activities related to child development already on campus.''

title: HORSESHOES, ANYONE?
description: For years it overshadowed even baseball as the ''summer game'' in many rural communities in Connecticut, particularly at picnics and other large outings.

title: Report Describes Contra Violations
description: When Congress approved $100 million in aid for the contras last year, an important string was attached: $3 million would have to be used to insure that the Nicaraguan rebels showed a more enlightened attitude toward human rights. To comply with this condition, the Reagan Administration asked the Association for Human Rights, which consists of exiles from the Sandinista Government, to monitor the contras.

title: Prospects
description: Executive Economics

title: MARY I. BUDD IS WED TO MARK S. LOGAN
description: Mary Innes Budd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Budd of Winchester, Mass., and Silver Creek, Minn., was married yesterday to Mark Skelton Logan, the son of Carol S. Logan of New Fairfield, Conn., and C. Wayne Logan of Santa Clara, Calif. The ceremony was performed at the Parish of the Epiphany in Winchester, where the bride's uncle, the Rev. Eugene A. Monick, and the Rev. John J. Bishop, both Episcopal priests, officiated.

title: THE OLD NEW WAVE
description: USUALLY, I'M NOT TOO fond of trends. The very word sounds more like the length of a hemline than something good to eat. However, the current interest in traditional foods is one that hits just where my taste buds are happiest. The only problem with many of these richly flavored concoctions is that they have always taken too long to make.

title: Next Week; What Kind Of Pennant Races Do You Expect?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are turn unpublished letters.

title: A Performer, Teacher and Wit
description: JOAN PANETTI will go to great lengths to get a point across to her students or, in this case, an audience.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: KNUTE, AND KNUTE AGAIN. By William Warner. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $14.95.) Two-thirds into this lackluster third-person narrative of an American boyhood, William Warner cuts in to describe at length its genesis: his attempt at a short story (needless to say, autobiographical), written while living in the Upper West Side apartment of an absent stranger whose daughter a friend of his was exploiting for sex and free rent.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BLUES, BARBECUE, ART Soul food is on the menu and the blues are onstage at the Hudson River Museum Thursday evening. Robert Jr. Lockwood, the 72-year-old blues singer-guitarist from Arkansas, will perform at 8 P.M. in the courtyard, drawing on a repertoire enriched by years in Memphis and Chicago playing with Robert Johnson, Muddy Waters and Sonny Boy Williamson. Tickets are $5 at the door, or $1 for children younger than 12.

title: When Mail Order Isn't Up to the Mark
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: Teens' Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
HOBOKEN: A PLACE FOR EVERY TASTE
description: LEAD: FROM Tex-Mex to trattoria to grazing fare, there is a place for just about every taste in Hoboken. In fact, so many new dining spots are popping up there that the locals ought to form a Restaurant of the Month Club.

title: P. B. PERETZMAN MARRIED TO ANN ELIZABETH MAGEE
description: The wedding of Ann Elizabeth Magee to Peter Bruce Peretzman took place yesterday at the Aquinas Institute in Princeton, N.J. George Szalony, a Roman Catholic deacon, and Rabbi Alfred Landsberg jointly performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
FENDING OFF SUMMERTIME DISEASES
description: LEAD: THE arrival of hot midsummer brings with it certain predictable problems for gardeners. Knowing what to look for, along with close observation, can help identify and treat some of those problems.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Tax Cap Overcome In Massachusetts

title: The Pope and Waldheim: Time Enough to Think
description: It is more than five weeks since Pope John Paul II received the President of Austria; time enough.

title: Girls and Math: Is Biology Really Destiny?
description: IN A WORLD WHERE test scores translate into scholarships and admission to college, and college in turn leads to high-paying jobs, the failure of high school girls to score as well as boys on college- entrance examinations has led to widespread concern. As critics of the tests demand a remedy for what they charge is a serious bias, researchers are making intense scientific efforts to understand just why the scores are so skewed. On the Scholastic

title: COLLEGE DOESN'T INSURE RECEPTIVITY TO IDEAS
description: Prof. Anthony DiFranco [ ''Don't Lose Sight of the Real Purpose of College,'' Opinion Page, June 22 ] has recalled to all us the real purpose of college: promoting the life of the mind.

title: 10 Saved as Press Boat At Swim Sinks in Sound
description: A press boat accompanying a charity swim across Long Island Sound sank today, but the 10 people aboard were rescued and uninjured, authorities said.

title: Mosque Has Violent Past
description: The Grand Mosque of Mecca was the scene of a bloody two-week siege in November 1979. An armed takeover fired by religious fanaticism, it posed the gravest challenge to the Saudi royal house, with political overtones and lasting implications for the country's internal security.

title: Taking Tape's Measure
description: PICKING A BLANK CAS-sette can be more puzzling than picking any other audio component. After all, amplifiers, tuners or tape decks have clearly discernible features and stated specifications to set them apart from others of their kind. But when it comes to the cassettes themselves, they all look alike except for the window dressing. They may not sound alike, but in making a choice the buyer has little to go on except contradictory advertising claims.

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Between Two Women'' is a lovely little television movie - no car chase, no missiles, no mayhem, not even an extraneous scene. It might be satisfying for this alone, but a delicate joy goes further than that: ''Between Two Women'' is about an adult relationship.

title: FOOTPRINTS OF THE ANCESTORS
description: THE SONGLINES By Bruce Chatwin. 293 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $18.95.

title: GETTING READY FOR FALL
description: RASPBERRY canes that fruited this summer should be cut to the ground. Check lawns for chinch bugs and control, if found. Before mowing, use clippers to trim under fences, by mail boxes and around tree trunks. Never water a lawn with a hand-held hose; it does more harm than good by encouraging shallow roots; allow the lawn to turn strawlike (go dormant) in hot weather. Deeply soak 'mums and asters so they have a strong root system to support early fall bloom. Last call to start seed indoors of broccoli, cauliflower and Chinese cabbage for fall crops. A Gentian

title: Stop the Ruinous Turf Wars Over Foreign Policy
description: Rogers and Kissinger. Vance and Brzezinski. Muskie and Brzezinski. Haig and Allen. Haig and Clark.

title: COMMERCIAL PHOTOGRAPHER MARRIES INGRID L. JOHNSON
description: Ingrid Louise Johnson, a daughter of Albert O. Johnson of Windsor, Conn., and the late Gertrude Johnson, was married yesterday to Waring Abbott, a son of Billie Abbott of Brooksville, Fla., and the late Marvin Abbott, at the bridegroom's home in New York by the Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Lessons in Picking Software to Learn By
description: LAST YEAR, parents spent about six times as much as schools -more than $200 million - on educational software, according to a survey by Future Computing Inc., a Dallas-based market research concern.

title: WILL TAYLOR'S DRUG STORY HURT THE GIANTS?
description: No, I do not believe Taylor's drug story will hurt the Giants. Once again, the credibility of drug testing is questionable. Taylor has hurt his image as a sportsman. His arrogance and deceit are an insult to sports fans. PHYLLIS KING New York, N.Y.

title: THE STORY UNFOLDS
description: AS the Iran-contra hearings draw to a close, current and former members of President Reagan's inner circle described how they and the President were deceived and betrayed over the sale of arms to Iran. Highlights of the week's events follow.

title: Suddenly, Business Schools Tackle Ethics
description: FROM IVAN BOESKY and Martin A. Siegel, lately two of the better-known names in the financial community, to a handful of callow young Wall Street traders whose alleged conspiracy was derided as ''Yuppiescam,'' insider-trading scandals in the last year have badly tarnished the reputations of some of the nation's most prominent financial institutions. Nor has Wall Street been the only area engulfed in scandal; manufacturers of products from contraceptives to military weapons have all come under public scrutiny recently for questionable - if not actionable - behavior. With each new scandal, attention had been focused on business ethics - and, in turn, on what is being taught young men and women in business schools these days.

title: LOYAL TO THEIR EXCESSES
description: THE LAMBERTS George, Constant & Kit. By Andrew Motion. Illustrated. 388 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: Jazz: Bop And Swing At the Y
description: DICK HYMAN called the sixth and final program in the 92d Street Y's Jazz in July series, for which he was artistic director, ''The Kingdom of Swing and the Republic of Oop Bop Sh'Bam.'' As it happened, the ''Oop Bop Sh'Bam,'' referring to modern jazz or be-bop, was in short supply, represented primarily by a performance of Dizzy Gillespie's ''Night in Tunisia.'' But there was plenty of swing, performed by an instrumental octet and, in the second half of the program, the vocalist Joe Williams.

title: RAIL UNION RE-ELECTS LEADER
description: Richard I. Kilroy has been re-elected international president of the 200,000-member Railway Employees, the union has announced. Mr Kilroy, of Potomac, Md., ws elected by acclamation Wednesday to a second four-year term as head of the largest transportation union in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: SUSANNAH WURGLER AND RUSSELL MURPHY JR. MARRY
description: Susannah Marie Wurgler, who will begin a doctoral program in biochemistry at Harvard University in September, and Russell Davis Murphy Jr., an associate with Temple, Barker & Sloane, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Russell Davis, a great-uncle of the bridegroom, at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass., assisted by the Rev. Austin H. Armitstead, a Methodist minister.

title: PROGRAMS TO TREAT ALCOHOLISM INCREASE
description: LEAD: ''TEN years ago,'' said Dr. Eugene Aronowitz, commissioner of the Department of Community Mental Health, ''Westchester County had one center for the treatment of alcoholism. The most it could offer its clients was basic outpatient services. Inpatient treatment was virtually nonexistent.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A RELUCTANT HERO. By Francoise Sagan. Translated by Christine Donougher. (Dutton, $16.95.) France, May 1942. Beautiful, troubled Alice and her resolute Resistance lover, Jerome, descend on the peaceful country estate of Jerome's boyhood best friend, the happy industrialist Charles Sambrat. Their intention: to persuade Charles to let them use his property in the unoccupied Dauphine as a way station for Jews being smuggled out of France. If this sounds interesting, let's take another look at Francoise Sagan's characters. Alice likes ''nothing so much as a wood fire in the summer, open French windows in the winter, and long swims'' in the rain. Jerome is a ''man of intellect,'' a man ''born lame . . . disappointed, anguished''; whereas Charles is ''a very fine-looking, healthy animal,'' ''a skirt chaser'' who gives ''women the desire to lie down and men the desire to get up'' (and one woman the desire to lay the book down and get up). Jerome is dedicated to saving Jews (no Jewish character appears, though Alice visits a sort of nest of ''them'' . . . ''There were eight of them, no, ten, no, twelve . . .''). Charles is dedicated to pleasure. And Alice - well, Alice is troubled and beautiful: Swim in the rain, anyone? How to persuade apolitical Charles to risk all for the Resistance? But of course: Alice will seduce him. Certain she would never feel ''that'' again, she is suddenly reawakened by the virile industrialist. Et voila! Le triangle. They reel, they gaze, they moan. Don't blame the cliches on the translation. It's Mlle. Sagan who has failed this time to invent a cast of grown-ups and a vocabulary equal to her theme - the conflict between personal desire and moral responsibility.

title: DEBATES TO PLAY BIGGER ROLE IN '88
description: The process of choosing the Democratic and Republican Presidential nominees is going public and national in 1988 as never before.

title: CASSY SPERRY PLANS TO WED IN SEPTEMBER
description: The engagement of Cassandra Campbell Sperry and Philip Wyman Ordway has been announced by her mother, Arden B. Sperry of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Chatham, Mass. The bridegroom is the son of John G. Ordway Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla, and White Bier Lake, Minn. A September wedding is planned. Miss Sperry, who is known as Cassy, is also the daughter of the late Corydon Stillman Sperry, who was a general partner in the investment firm of Stillman Maynard & Company, New Yorl. The future bride graduated from the Ethel Walker School and in 1985 from the University of Vermont, from which her fiance graduated in 1983. She is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Mark L. Sperry of Middlebury, Conn., and of the late Mrs. Julian Humphrys, and the late Richard C. Bondy, both of Goldens Bridge, N.Y.

title: Hopefuls Seek to Make PAC's an Issue in '88 Race
description: Several Presidential candidates, shunning contributions from political action committees, are seeking to make the committees an issue in the 1988 campaign even though they have never played a consequential role in financing Presidential elections.

title: WILL TAYLOR'S DRUG STORY HURT THE GIANTS?
description: If the Giants are hurt by L. T.'s drug story it will not be because of the revelations included in his book ''LT: Living on the Edge.'' It will be because of the media's insistence on making an issue about what is basically old news. Everyone knew about L. T.'s problem with drugs and everyone knew that L. T. had licked the problem as shown by his past season's most-valuable-player performance. The story has been told. The Giants had a nice, quiet off season. The news media are the only ones who could hurt the Giants, by repeatedly asking if the Giants will be hurt instead of focusing on the team's chances of accomplishing the difficult task of winning yet another N.F.L. championship. PAUL GENZBURG New York, N.Y.

title: How a Teacher Became a Tortilla Tycoon
description: CAN a former political activist and history teacher come home again and find happiness making tortillas? Joel Cavazos says he has done just that, taking a ma-and-pa tortilla factory that was grossing $45,000 a year and turning it into a near-$10 million-a-year operation that supplies two hamburger chains and a Mexican fast-food chain.

title: THORLEIF ORNDAHL AND MISS MCCREA WED IN HONOLULu
description: At St. Clement's Episcopal Church in Honolulu, Anne Barrows McCrea, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Michael Dacey of Honolulu and the late Stanley Barrows McCrea of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Thorleif Axel Ake Orndahl, the son of C. Ake Orndahl of New York and Montauk, L.I., and Gerda Konig Orndahl of New Canaan, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Hollinshead Taylor Knight, Dean of St. Andrew's Episcopal Cathedral in Honolulu.

title: 'Talkaholic' Finds Her Spot in Life
description: LEAD: DEBBIE NIGRO, media personality, woman-around-Westchester and self-described ''talkaholic,'' is the host of a new television show. The program, ''Center Stage,'' is broadcast on the CNN Headline News Network through UA Columbia and Cablevision; it runs six minutes and is on the air 10 times a day, Monday through Friday.

title: How They're Wooing the Potential Dropout
description: LEAD: I WANTED A HIGH school where the kids were bad, one where there weren't any smart people hanging around being superior,'' said 18-year-old Edward Mulraine, recalling his freshman year in 1984 at the Theodore Roosevelt High School in New York City. ''But now I see myself as different, as someone who is ready to learn and wants to become more than just a street sleeper.

title: CRAZY QUILTING REVIVED IN EAST HADDAM
description: THE art of crazy quilting, so popular in the Victorian era, has been revived in East Haddam for the benefit of the East Haddam Historical Society.

title: Exploring Cape Cod's North Side
description: The North Side of Cape Cod, an elongated crescent that swings for 33 miles along Cape Cod Bay from Sandwich to the eastern end of Brewster, is one of the oldest continuously inhabited segments of North America. In 1620, the Mayflower Pilgrims, before they even set foot on that rock at Plymouth, probed the entire length of the North Side's superb beaches by boat looking for a safe anchorage. Because a thick fog shrouded the coastline while they searched, they missed Paine's Creek in Brewster, Sesuit Harbor in Dennis, Barnstable Harbor and the inlet at Sandwich.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE NEW-PARENT BUSINESS;
Buying Carriages Through Catalogues
description: LEAD: WITH items as small as booties and as big as twin baby carriages, catalogue companies say that babies are big business - and becoming more so.

title: LIFTING FARM CREDITS SYSTEM OUT OF MIRE
description: EVEN as many farmers are cautiously forecasting a more profitable harvest season than they have seen in years -in large part because of Federal aid -the vast and intricate system that holds a third of all farm debts is calling for one of the costliest Federal bailouts ever.

title: MISS FETTER WED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The wedding of Anne Lindsay Wilkinson Head Fetter and Thomas O'Farrell Sandy took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown, Mass. The Rev. Susan Crampton, a godmother of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Cash for Cleveland Pupils: Easy as A, B or C
description: Good grades will be rewarded in dollars under a privately financed plan that, the city's Superintendent of Schools says, will drive home a point: education means money.

title: Tax Gap at Gucci Gulch
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Battle In Mount Vernon
description: LEAD: ON a corner ledge in the Gramatan Avenue campaign headquarters of Carmella R. Iaboni, who is challenging Ronald A. Blackwood, the incumbent, for this city's Democratic mayoral designation, stand two identical painted plaster statues.

title: KATHLEEN MARIE BIFFERATO IS THE BRIDE OF ARTHUR CONNOLLY 3D, A LAW STUDENT
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anthony of Padua in Wilmington, Del., Kathleen Marie Bifferato, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Vincent A. Bifferato of Wilmington, and Arthur Guild Connolly 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Connolly Jr. of Wilmington, were married yesterday. The Rev. Roberto Balducelli performed the ceremony.

title: NEW HAVEN SET FOR MUNSONS' VISIT
description: LEAD: THE Munsons are coming to New Haven next weekend and organizers of the three-day event say it will be one of the largest family reunions ever held in this country.

title: Q&A: Woo Sang Ho; A 'MODERATE TELLS WHY STUDENTS IN KOREA FIGHT
description: SOUTH KOREAN university students were the principal force in the protests that culminated in June with street fighting in Seoul. Partly because of these protests, the Government accepted most opposition demands, notably for direct presidential elections. Yet many students say they will continue to demonstrate. They say they mistrust almost everyone - the Government, opposition politicians, the domestic and foreign press.

title: LEIGH ANN REYNOLDS, A TEACHER, WEDS
description: At St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., Leigh Ann Reynolds, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Clinton Reynolds of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Arthur Williams 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams 3d of Summit, N.J.

title: LAND PLAN STIFLES PHILIPPINE ISLAND
description: The first effects of a new land redistribution plan are being felt here on the sugar-growing island of Negros, where banks have halted agricultural loans and planters have begun withdrawing their deposits in protest.

title: Investigators Find 'Appalling' Facts In Harlem Fire
description: Releasing a report that laid out what Mayor Koch called ''an appalling set of facts,'' the head of an inquiry board said last week that the sprinkler system in the Harlem apartment tower where seven people died in a fire last March had not been working for months and possibly years. The board also found serious construction flaws in the garbage chute, where the fire began.

title: Let Them Rent Whole Tankers, Not Just Flags
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COCKROACH CHRONICLES
description: LEAD: FORCED ENTRIES The Downtown Diaries 1971-1973. By Jim Carroll. 184 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: A Raft of Plans That Try To Dispel Math Anxieties
description: ''So many girls in my math class moan and groan that it's just too hard,'' said Susie Casente, a high school senior in Morgan City, La., and a past participant in the Summermath program at Mount Holyoke College. ''Girls are expected to be dainty and not work hard. And because math is hard work, a lot of them consider it unfeminine.''

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I suggest that history will say he was a giant, not only in a physical sense, but in the esteem of all those with whom he came in contact.''

title: Jazz: Roccisano, Brookmeyer
description: JOE ROCCISANO, a jazz saxophonist, composer and arranger who led a big band on the West Coast for several years, brought his recently organized 15-piece New York version of the band to Fat Tuesdays, 190 Third Avenue at 17th Street, on Thursday evening for an introductory four-day run through today, with the valve trombonist Bob Brookmeyer as guest soloist.

title: Suspect Speaks at War Crimes Trial
description: John Demjanjuk, the retired Cleveland auto worker who is accused of being ''Ivan the Terrible,'' at the Treblinka death camp during World War II, took the witness stand for the first time last week and denied that he was the Nazi ''hangman or henchman'' who operated the gas chambers in which 850,000 Jews were killed.

title: An Earlier Rialto
description: To the Editor:

title: Earthquake in California
description: A strong earthquake rattled houses and frightened residents along the northern California coast Friday, but there was little damage, the authorities said.

title: U.S. WALKING ON EGGSHELLS IN PANAMA CRISIS
description: THE crisis that has shaken the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega since early June intensified on several fronts last week. General Noriega sent troops and helicopters to storm the home of his former second-in-command, Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, shut down three newspapers and stepped up his attacks on the United States. Meanwhile, business activity ground to a halt as the opposition called a general strike aimed at ending 19 years of military rule.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: CARNIVAL OF SPIES. By Robert Moss. (Villard, $18.95.) Bagging Russians is the daydream of every armchair spy, and this novel by the author of ''Moscow Rules'' provides many targets richly deserving such a fate. The main character, a German Communist from Hamburg, improbably named Johnny, begins his career in the 1920's by rebelliously dropping out of school at age 14, going to sea, joining the party and working his way up in the apparat.

title: BROWN TIDE BLUES
description: FOR decades, scientists and environmentalists have wondered how long the coastal waters of the region could successfully withstand the constant flood of man-made nutrients.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: Roger Tory Peterson;
'I WORRY ABOUT THE BUTTERFLIES'
description: LEAD: ROGER TORY PETERSON, the author and illustrator of ''A Field Guide to the Birds,'' has been described as the nation's foremost birder, and many naturalists consider him the greatest wildlife illustrator since Audubon. Dr. Peterson, 78 years old, has been dividing his time between traveling and working on ''A Field Guide to Western Birds'' at his home in Old Lyme.

title: 'No Illusions' as U.S. Talks With Vietnamese Start
description: A long-sought meeting between President Reagan's special envoy on Americans missing in action in Vietnam and newly installed Vietnamese leaders began here today, but with scant hopes of real progress on either side.

title: Developers Find Benefits in Offshore Construction
description: USING technology from the flagging offshore oil industry, and inspiration from the development of property along the water's edge, entrepreneurs are tapping the potential of floating structures.

title: U.S. to Seek Pakistani Aid in Atom Case
description: The United States will ask Pakistan to crack down on a private procurement network that is believed to obtain material for the development of nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: MARY POLLARD IS MARRIED
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass., Mary Markley Pollard, a daughter of Mrs. Max Markley of Bluffton, Ind., and Winter Haven, Fla., and the late Mr. Markley, was married yesterday to Allerton Delano Marshall, a son of Mrs. Lawrence Clark Marshall of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Marshall. The Rev. Stephen M. Price officiated. The bride, a pianist and the director of the Nine O'Clock Sunday Morning Service at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, is a graduate of Northwestern University and received a master's degree in music from Columbia University. The bridegroom, a graduate of Princeton University, is the business manager of St. Bartholomew's. The bride and bridegroom were previously married and divorced.

title: AUDIENCE HAS A ROLE IN OUTDOOR 'ROMEO'
description: IF you favor the Montagues, wear the orange sticker. Rooting for the Capulets? Choose blue.

title: BROADWAY 'SCOOPED' BY RUTGERS
description: WHEN Kevin Patterson was writing what he calls a ''biographical play about a mathematical genius and avowed homosexual who was instrumental in inventing the computer and in winning World War II,'' he hardly expected another play about the same subject to pop up right away.

title: Activists Meeting to Plan a New U.S. Agenda
description: Grassroots political activists from across the country, asserting that ''there is a new progressive opening in American politics,'' are gathering here this weekend to lay plans for advancing their cause in the 1988 Presidential election and beyond.

title: Q. & A.: ALIGNING A DOOR LATCH BOLT
description: Q. Ever since we did some remodeling on the first floor of our home, the door to our bedroom, which is on the second floor, will not stay closed when we shut it. The door closes all right and doesn't rub or stick, but the lock doesn't seem to engage - in other words, the latch bolt doesn't seem to snap into the opening in the metal plate on the door frame. As a result, we have to place a book on the floor on the inside of the door to keep it from opening by itself during the night. Can you suggest what could be wrong and what I can do to correct this problem?

title: DOLE SUMMER DRIVE TAKES AIM AT BUSH
description: Senator Bob Dole took his August campaign schedule off the desk in his Capitol office Friday and held it up. It listed trips almost every day that will take him around the nation in his quest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: To Moslems, Kaaba Shrine Is Most Holy Place on Earth
description: The Kaaba Shrine in the Grand Mosque of Mecca is, for Islam, the most sacred place on earth, and making the pilgrimage there at least once in one's life is one of the basic obligations of devout Moslems.

title: PORT AUTHORITY POWERHOUSE: Stephen Berger; Revving Up the 'Economic Engine'
description: FROM crisis to recovery, Stephen Berger has been a man at the center of New York City's economy, deftly pulling strings in business and government alike. Now, as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, one of the world's largest transportation agencies, he is emerging as the power broker for the region.

title: HITLER'S BUDDIES
description: THE COLLAPSE OF THE WEIMAR REPUBLIC Political Economy and Crisis. By David Abraham. Second Edition. 352 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. Cloth, $45. Paper, $17.50.

title: BET TWICE EDGES ALYSHEBA
description: Bet Twice held off Alysheba's late charge by just a neck today to win the $500,000 Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park. It was an exhilarating chapter in their continuing rivalry and one that set the stage for yet another rematch in their duel for the 3-year-old championship.

title: Despite Protections, Landmarks Decay
description: AT Broadway and 20th Street in Manhattan, a mansard-roofed building from the 19th century looks to be a breath away from the scrap heap.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE RIDDLE OF THE DINOSAUR, by John Noble Wilford. (Vintage, $8.95.) The Times science reporter John Noble Wilford offers up ''a lively introduction to many of the fascinating characters who have pursued and studied dinosaur bones, and a survey of two centuries of scientific thought on evolution,'' Alan Ternes said in The Book Review in 1986. ''Mr. Wilford shows how fossils . . . became the hard evidence that enabled scientists to brave religious orthodoxy, which in its most extreme statement . . . had the earth created at 9 A.M. on Oct. 23, 4004 B.C.'' HEAT AND DUST, by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $6.95.) The heroine of this novel of India past and present, winner of Britain's prestigious Booker Prize, is an Englishwoman who travels to the subcontinent to learn more about her grandmother, who as a bored colonial wife of the 1920's had deserted her husband for an Indian prince.

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Susan Sherman to Philip Morgan Smith misidentified the church where the ceremony took place. The couple were married at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: A Weapon for Grocery-Shelf Wars
description: IT isn't often one sees the president of a computer company mud-wrestling with a sheep. Yet that's what David Grooters, head of Fastech Inc., found himself doing during a visit to our farm to show me a sales information system for laptop computers.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: WOLFING DOWN THE CITY Nobody, not even Walt Whitman, ever saw New York City in a more romantic light than Thomas Wolfe. Anyone would want to live in this city, if it existed. This is from ''The Train and the City'' in ''The Complete Short Stories of Thomas Wolfe'' (Scribners), edited by Francis E. Skipp.

title: THE LAW OF INVERSE FITNESS
description: I AM off the hook for today. No Tuesday-Thursday lunchtime basketball game. But as I look around my office, I feel like I've been transferred to a M.A.S.H. unit. The inventory of office injuries is seemingly endless.

title: Big Event With Disney Touch
description: THE 10th Pan American Games, an every-four-year Olympic-type competition for Western Hemisphere nations, will begin Saturday in Indianapolis and run for 16 days with an all-star cast.

title: THE DOG DAYS OF SUMMER PRODUCE HEATED QUESTION
description: NOW that the dog days of summer are upon us, it's time for the serious sports fan to come to grips with questions that are as hot as the August sun and that beat down on us just as relentlessly. I intend to take a torrid breath and to ask 10 of these questions that have been gathering momentum since June, questions that just won't leave us alone. I will also answer them since the author of a summer sports quiz has the privilege of being as foolish as anyone else; indeed, he has the responsibility. I won't, however, answer the final or wrap-up question; it's an item that professional testmakers call open-ended. I won't answer it for reasons that iwill become incredibly obvious.

title: IT'S COLD AND DARK INDOORS
description: LEAD: SCENES FROM THE HOMEFRONT By Sara Vogan. 133 pp. Chicago: University of Illinois Press. $11.95.

title: E. M. MCDONOUGH JR. MARRIES MAGGIE R. FAY
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Westport, Conn., Maggie Reynolds Fay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fay of Westport, was married yesterday to E. Merritt McDonough Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McDonough of West Hartford, Conn.

title: 2 Die Climbing Matterhorn
description: Two foreign climbers fell to their deaths today trying to scale the 14,780-foot Matterhorn, the Air Zermatt rescue service reported. The identities of the climbers were not immediately determined.

title: High AIDS Rate Spurring Efforts For Minorities
description: The disproportionate impact of AIDS among blacks and Hispanic people is leading civil rights groups and the Federal Government to shift resources to deal more directly with the threat the disease poses to minorities.

title: UNRULY NATURE, UNRULY LIFE
description: Edwin Dobb's article, ''Battling With Unruly Nature'' [ Opinion Page, July 14 ] , is brilliant. I especially like the paragraph about theorizing on ''getting rid of everything but the grass,'' and the ones following it, ''Isn't life just the reverse - messy and unruly?'' and ''What, then, are these reposeful places we fashion for ourselves?'' and then the punch line, ''All the earth tangos as we prepare for sleep.'' Terrific! JANE SEIP Setauket The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and daytime telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Long Island Weekly Section, The New York Times, 229 W. 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
Finding the Fury
description: LEAD: THERE WERE 10 MINUTES to kill before I had to leave for the Police Athletic League baseball game. I sat on the side of my bed to look through Popular Mechanics magazine. When I reached the article on the new 1956 Plymouth Fury, my heart started to pound. It would be years before I defined the experience as a coup de foudre; later on, I would meet a woman and fall in love at first sight.

title: Cancer Found on Reagan's Nose
description: A new spot of skin cancer, the third found on President Reagan's nose in the last two years, was removed last week in a two-hour surgical procedure at Bethesda Naval Hospital. The operation was performed under a local anesthetic, and Mr. Reagan returned to the White House ''in great spirits.''

title: OLD MASTERS FOR HARTFORD, NORFOLK AND MADISON CONCERTS
description: IT'S a good week for the old masters, as Chamber Music Plus and the Norfolk Festival prepare to wrap up their summer seasons, while the music of even older masters helps inaugurate the Chestnut Hill Series.

title: My Cellar: A Nice Place To Visit, if Not Live
description: I GREW up in a house, but I lived in apartments after graduating from college, so until I bought a home a few years ago I had no cellar in my life, no cellar of my own. ''So what,'' you who have lived over cellars for years are thinking, ''big deal.'' Big for me is that my cellar has brought a different dimension to my life, given it a new foundation, so to speak.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FIRST CONTACT. By Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson. (Viking, $19.95.) The Australians Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson have followed their successful documentary film ''First Contact'' (nominated for an Academy Award in 1984), with a richly detailed history of the exploration of interior Papua New Guinea by white prospectors in the early 1930's.

title: Creationism: A Text Based on Faith
description: Textbooks and teaching aids promoting creationism - the biblical version of man's origins - continue to roll off the presses despite a Supreme Court decision in June that said states could not require it to be taught alongside the scientific theory of evolution in public schools.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE NEW-PARENT BUSINESS;
A Little Bundle - of Coupons
description: LEAD: SOON after Karen LaBarbera of Brooklyn gave birth to her third child at Beth Israel Hospital recently, she was handed another bundle -a plastic-wrapped packet that included diapers, a magazine for new parents and coupons good toward the purchase of infant products made by a variety of manufacturers.

title: SHE TOOK THE AIDS TEST
description: Dena Kleiman and other extremely low-risk individuals should stop obsessing and donate a unit of blood. The testing is free, confidential, accurate and will be repeated every eight weeks, with each donation. This would help replenish the donor pool depleted by an ill-informed public, as a result of AIDS panic.

title: WE LIVE IN A SOCIETY OF EXCESS - WHY?
description: OUR society is laden with excess. We have abundant wealth and too much poverty, excessive military and nuclear arms and on and on. I see the excess in our society in its emphasis on success, achievement, thinness, grades, athletic prowess, sexual extravagance, alcohol and drugs - on exaggeration.

title: Moscow Says Zaire Expelled Envoy and 2 Embassy Aides
description: A Soviet diplomat and two technical services employees at the embassy in Zaire have been expelled, the press agency Tass reported today.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
MERCHANT ADDS ACTING TO INVENTORY
description: LEAD: SIX days a week, shoppers in the market for an organ or a piano find Nelson Varon holding forth in his Jericho Turnpike store, Nelson Varon Organ Studios. Monday evenings, however, the avuncular Northport resident becames Garrison Oliver Dietrich, the beleaguered studio head in ''Illusions of Death,'' a comic sendup of just about every old movie melodrama ever seen on late-night television.

title: WHERE HE DIDN'T FAIL
description: THE WORLD AND RICHARD NIXON By C. L. Sulzberger. 269 pp. New York: Prentice Hall Press. $18.95.

title: Natural Healing Substance Found
description: During experiments last summer, when Dr. Michael Zasloff was making incisions in frogs, he noticed that the wounds healed in a manner that was quick, clean and altogether unexpected. Swimming in a tank, the laboratory animals were surrounded by bacteria but somehow showed strong resistance to infection.

title: HEAT WAVE YIELDS TO FAIR IN SUSSEX
description: THIS Sussex County community will have both plusses and minuses to record before the summer, with its unusually high temperatures and humidity, draws to a close.

title: PATRICIA C. MOSSER IS MARRIED TO M. CARY LEAHEY
description: Patricia C. Mosser, an assistant professor of economics at Columbia University, and M. Cary Leahey, a vice president and senior economist for Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia. The Rev. James F. Karpen, the United Methodist chaplain of the university, officiated.

title: RECORDINGS: ROUNDUP OF NOTABLE RECENT RELEASES
description: Villa-Lobos: Five Preludes, 12 Etudes.

title: JODY A. SEANOR IS MARRIED TO PAUL MARTIN STAPLETON
description: Jody Anne Seanor, a daughter of Mrs. H. Eugene Seanor of Milford, Conn., and the late Dr. Seanor, was married yesterday to Paul Martin Stapleton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Stapleton of Fairfield, Conn. The ceremony in Loyola Chapel at Fairfield University was performed by the Rev. William Cullen and the Rev. James Bowler, both Roman Catholic priests.

title: 'A POET IN THE TRUEST SENSE'
description: Saint Patrick's Day is a time when Irish Catholics (and would-be Irish Catholics) around the world raise their voices in song, lift a pint to good old St. Patty and proudly ''strut the green.'' It is a day when smiles seem more frequent and man's humanity to man shows its gentle face.

title: CHILDREN
description: The Steadfast Tin Soldier Narrated by Jeremy Irons. Music by Mark Isham. Illustrated by David Jorgensen. 1986. Color. Random House Home Video. 30 minutes. $14.95.

title: Correction
description: The Pop View column today in the Arts and Leisure section misidentifies the leader of the studio band on ''Late Night With David Letterman.''

title: Africa Goes Private
description: A depressing sight on Africa's landscape is the litter of abandoned factories, legacies of a socialist god that failed. Once it seemed to make sense for newly independent Africa to rely on the state to run cocoa plantations, banks, breweries, hotels, insurance companies, steel mills, oil refineries, plastics factories and textile mills. But what looked good in theory to some was disastrous in practice - as even avowedly Marxist states like Angola and Benin are creditably acknowledging.

title: MORE FREE COURSES OPEN TO PARENTS
description: ''Parents Deserve Credit Too!'' -so reads the title of a brochure published by Elizabeth Seton College in August of last year. The July 5 Westchester Journal item, ''Back to School,'' refers to Mercy College's upcoming program for parents of scholastically elite students. Seton College in nearby Yonkers has been offering parents up to three credits free of charge under criteria that simply state that their child be enrolled at Seton full time (minimum of 12 credits).

title: Outdoors; Drought Threatens Salmon in Canada
description: A DROUGHT in eastern Canada - in some locations, there has been little rain since late May - is threatening the survival and spawning success of salmon in rivers in the Atlantic provinces.

title: PALMER WATSON MARRIES LAWYER
description: Mary Palmer Watson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Watson 3d of New York, and S. Richard Gard Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Richard Gard of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., were married yesterday at the Second-Ponce de Leon Baptist Church in Atlanta by the Rev. Dr. Monroe F. Swilley Jr. The bride, who is known as Palmer, is a commercial-loan officer at the First National Bank of Atlanta. She is a graduate of Pace Academy and Salem College in Winston-Salem, N.C. The bride, a member of the Junior League of Atlanta, was presented at the Atlanta Debutante Club. Her father, formerly an investment banker in Atlanta, is president of the National Security Traders Association in New York.

title: BARBARA LEACH WED TO FREDRIK BLOEMERS
description: Barbara Ellen Leach, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ferguson Leach of Bronxville, N.Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Fredrik Bloemers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Derk Jan Bloemers of Winterswijk, the Netherlands, were marrried yesterday. The Rev. Robert W. Bedingfield performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: There Is Much to Learn From the Titanic
description: To the Editor:

title: Single-Family Home Market Prospering
description: EVEN though two out of three new dwellings in Westchester today are condominiums, the market for single-family houses - each on its own plot of land - is thriving, and the houses are bigger and more expensive than ever.

title: HONORING A CHEROKEE
description: South from Knoxville, Tenn., toward Chattanooga on the Georgia border, Interstate 75 passes through rolling hills and pastures, well-tended farms and woodlands laced with water of the Tennessee River system.

title: WHERE DANDELIONS GET RESPECT
description: Michiko Itoh is probably correct that, in general, Americans do not like dandelions and regard them as unwelcome weeds [ ''A Weed to Many Is Others' Idea of Joy,'' June 28 ] .

title: Demolitions Anger Queens Homeowners
description: THE residents of Bayside, a tight community of homeowners in northeastern Queens, have gone on a bulldozer alert.

title: Cable TV
description: It's easy to dial past good movies with cryptic titles, and cable this week is chock-full of such plums - like ''The Family Way'' (1984) and ''Cluny Brown'' (1946). The first, Yoshimitsu Morita's import, is a deadpan, wickedly funny look at Japan's newly affluent, utterly aimless middle class. It's due Sunday at midnight on Bravo. The rarely shown ''Cluny Brown,'' from Margery Sharpe's story, is a slyly delicious spoof of British caste snobbery - and catnip for director Ernst Lubitsch and a fine, sporting cast headed by Jennifer Jones (as a plucky young plumber) and Charles Boyer. Catch this lark Saturday afternoon at 2 on WHT.

title: Rangel Seeks Wider Inquiry on Fire
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel called yesterday for a wider investigation of a fire that killed seven people in a high-rise apartment building in Harlem last spring, saying that Federal, state and city officials should work together ''to make certain that tragedies like this don't happen again.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: GORBACHEV'S PLAN;
An Experiment in Chaos?
description: LEAD: NO one can accuse Mikhail Gorbachev of timidity. From his boldness in arms control to his intent to upend economic planning, he has attacked long-sacred Soviet values and institutions with a fervor seldom equaled. Ronald Reagan's and Margaret Thatcher's efforts to reshape their societies pale by comparison.

title: Music
description: As the dean of American summer music festivals, Tanglewood has encountered its share of criticism for offering mostly standard crowd-pleasers that will attract large audiences and bring in revenue. In fact, the Lenox, Mass., festival, more than most others, has demonstrated a commitment to new music, despite its box-office drawbacks. Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, now run by the composer Oliver Knussen and the pianist Leon Fleisher, presents concerts throughout this week in the Theater-Concert Hall, near the shed on the Tanglewood grounds. This year's composer-in-residence is George Perle; on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings at 7:30 P.M., there will be short, pre-concert programs of electronic music. Most performances are given by fellows of the Tanglewood Music Center. Sunday morning at 10 A.M., there will be a concert of works by Stravinsky, Copland, Carter, Louise Talma, Arthur Berger and Harold Shapero. Sunday night's performance, which begins at 8:30, is conducted by John Oliver and includes works by Mr. Knussen, Bruce Saylor, Lutoslawski and Mr. Perle. Works by Boulez, Rorem, Miriam Gideon and Alexander Goehr are to be performed Monday evening at 8:30. On Tuesday evening, the Boston Symphony Chamber Players, made up of principal players from the Boston Symphony, presents works by Copland, Mr. Perle and Mr. Knussen. Wednesday's concert offering at 8:30, conducted by Mr. Knussen, highlights the compositions of Jay Alan Yim, Stravinsky, Goehr, Michael Gandolfi and Gerald Levinson. And on Thursday evening at 8:30, the seemingly omnipresent Kronos Quartet takes the stage for the festival's final concert. For information, call 413-637-1940.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE HAUNTED MESA. By Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $18.95.) The newest best-selling novel by Louis L'Amour, who is especially noted for his Sackett family series of westerns, is a combination of western and occult adventure, with the former given a decided edge. Mike Raglan, the hero, is an investigator of occult phenomena, but he is also a tough loner who knows how to use a six-gun. When he travels to a remote Southwest mesa to investigate the mystery of the Anasazi - a race of vanished cliff-dwellers - he manages to cross over to the Other Side, a fourth dimension that turns out to be very much another western frontier, replete with hidden gold, treacherous landscapes and plenty of Indians to shoot down. (The latter, a military clique called the Varanel, may sound exotic, but they attack at dawn.) When ghostly invaders cross from the Other Side to make trouble, Raglan neatly dispatches them with fisticuffs. The expansionist ideology of westerns remains thoroughly intact: ''No barrier will stop my people,'' says Raglan to a dismayed Keeper of the Archives. ''No doubt your land has minerals we could exploit.'' As always, Mr. L'Amour is adept at tight plotting, meticulous research and authoritative sense of place. But the writing here is tired and lacking the crusty energy of his better westerns. Nor does he apply any suggestiveness needed for a supernatural chiller, often resorting to long series of questions and cliches. At one point we are told that Raglan ''did not want there to be another dimension. . . . He was having trouble enough dealing with the three he had.'' This seems a reasonable complaint; perhaps Mr. L'Amour should heed it and stick to writing westerns.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE NEW-PARENT BUSINESS
description: LEAD: DURING a baby's first year, parents spend, on average, about $520 on disposable diapers, $550 on commercial baby food and, if the child is a first-born, another $800 on nursery furniture and equipment, according to American Baby magazine. In New York City, an upwardly mobile family spends even more - close to $2,000 just on nursery furniture, Baby Talk magazine reports.

description: The National Football League is devising a program to broaden the hiring of minority-group members. It expects to come up with a plan by the time the regular season opens on Sept. 13.

description: The older you get, Gary Gabrielle, who is 33 years old, was saying the other evening, ''the more you have to be creative to beat the competition in the romance department.''

title: Strong Fears Remain Over New Immigration Law
description: It seemed like a traditional revival meeting, with a lot of singing, swaying, handshakes and hallelujahs in a large green tent on a vacant lot in Brooklyn.

title: Breton Crepes, Savory Or Sweet
description: The sign outside a creperie called Le P'tit in Dinan announces, ''Fast Food: Crepes.'' Their crepes are the same as those served all over Brittany, cooked to order and available with dozens of fillings. It's just that this creperie has recognized that the Breton crepe suits the modern style of life as well as it represents a longstanding local tradition.

title: But Why Call It 'Don Giovanni'?
description: THE TERM OPERA HAS BECOME THE RECEP-tacle for disposable works of all sorts, a black plastic bag where otherwise unclassifiable refuse may be deposited and immediately forgotten. There is hardly a theatrical notion or whim, no matter how creatively barren, antimusical, muddle-headed or inane, that may not attract a subsidy, pass itself off as an opera production and find place fleetingly on some stage somewhere. Though born dead, each unfortunate creature serves its purpose: awards, academic honors, publicity and commissions are pressed on the director, who is then encouraged to attack other operas. Theoretically, this might be a good thing, since a piece of durable art could result, just as it is mathematically certain that a thousand monkeys jumping on the keys of a thousand typewriters would eventually write all the books in the British Museum. Eventually, however, could mean light years, at least, and most of us do not have that much time.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
HOW TO EASE THE COMMUTERS' LIFE
description: LEAD: ITEM: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has increased the Hudson River tolls and received permission to spend 90 percent of the extra money raised on projects that will do nothing to alleviate cross-Hudson traffic congestion.

title: Music: New Leads In 'Sweeney Todd'
description: THE New York City Opera's current run of ''Sweeney Todd'' changed casts on Thursday night and offered a new pair of well-matched principals. Stanley Wexler gave the title role a blunt, emphatic, full-voiced approach that was never terribly sinister in its implications but was still very pleasant to listen to. Next to him was Marcia Mitzman as Mrs. Lovett. Miss Mitzman has a clear, cutting voice, alloyed liberally with brass. It does very well in penetrating Jonathan Tunick's powerful orchestrations of the Stephen Sondheim music.

title: Dana Ivey's Penchant for the Persnickety
description: WITH NOTICEABLE CONSIS-tency, Dana Ivey has played antagonists or less than commendable characters -snobs, manipulators or loners. Her willingness to take on unlikable characters and to refrain, in the process, from seeking audience affection, partially explains why she was the unanimous choice for the title role in ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' , which reopened last week at the John Houseman Theater. , Miss Ivey portrays Daisy Werthan, a difficult Southern Jewish widow who, at 72 when the play begins, is nearly twice the actress's age, and is another 25 years older by the time the story ends.

title: BETH GROSSMAN TO WED MARK SHUSTER
description: Beth R. Grossman, the meetings manager of the United States Trademark Association, and Mark W. Shuster, the director of marketing for Faberge USA Inc., both in New York, plan to be married in September.

title: Paper in Britain Defies Ban on Spy Memoirs
description: The Guardian defied a legal ban today and reported about the Government's battle in an Australian appeals court to stop the publication of a former British spy's memoirs in Australia.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Cambridge, Mass.;
Condos Spurt On the Charles
description: LEAD: THE sale of condominiums on a scenic bend of the Charles River in Cambridge is the culmination of a development plan that has created a new residential neighborhood.

title: KATHLEEN LAMB PLANS TO WED DR. DANIEL TS'O
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Lamb of Hingham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Elaine Lamb to Dr. Daniel Ts'o, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Ts'o of Ellicott City, Md.

title: When the U.S. and Hungary Behave the Same Foolish Way
description: LEAD: Thirteen prominent American intellectuals signed a letter last month sharply criticizing Hungary's refusal to allow Janos Kis, a distinguished young philosopher, the right to visit the United States and teach for one year at the New School in New York City. Hungarian authorities said the visit would not ''further Hungarian cultural and scientific relations with the outside world.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: DEGAS IN WILLIAMSTOWN

description: Leonora Mary Cravotta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Cravotta Jr. of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to Louis Joseph Betti Jr., the son of Gloria Betti of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Mr. Betti. The Rev. Edgar da Cunha performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church in Palisades Park, N.J.

title: Beaver Statue a Symbol at Fresh Air Fund Camp
description: From now on, when the bus from New York City rounds the bend into the Fresh Air Fund's camp at the Sharpe Reservation here, the youngsters will be greeted by a 4-foot-tall bronze beaver.

title: EASTON SCULPTOR CREATES ART FOR LARGE SPACES
description: LEAD: IN the big front room of her Victorian house in Easton, Dolly Curtis weaves fiber sculptures that fill huge spaces in museums, galleries and the lobbies of corporate headquarters in the East and Midwest.

title: Error Razes Ancient Village
description: A bulldozer operator unknowingly destroyed an unmarked 800-year-old Indian village that archeologists had hoped would provide a rare glimpse into pre-Columbian American culture.

title: Four Killed in Crash of Plane in Jersey Resort Area
description: Four people were killed yesterday afternoon when their single-engine Cessna airplane hit a power line and crashed into a wooded area near a small lake in Sparta, N.J.

title: Woman Takes a Chance as a Young Father Seeks a Handout
description: AS I wove through the crowds in Grand Central Terminal on my way home from work one day, I saw a man carrying a child and pushing her stroller. The little girl was plump and her white shirt stuck out below a red jacket. A tiny face peeked out below a fringe of curly bangs.
