title: EMPTY SEATS ON LOCAL BOARDS VEX TOWNS
description: THE Willimantic Housing Authority was recently in a situation where it couldn't meet because, after a string of resignations, it no longer had enough members to put together a quorum.

title: BROOKHAVEN'S SWEEPING PLAN MAY END RETAIL DEVELOPMENT
description: IN an attempt to halt development of shopping centers along its main roads, the Town of Brookhaven appears ready to enact one of the most sweeping rezonings of retail property in its history.

title: Plans End for 2d Panel on New York Charter
description: A coalition of politicians and civic leaders, which announced last month that it would seek to create a second commission to review the city charter, has dropped its plans because of a lack of support.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis from Washington on July 26 on the struggle between the executive and legislative branches for influence over American foreign policy gave an incorrect first name for President John Tyler.

title: China Wages War Against Illicit Journals
description: A young factory worker from Changchun, a city in northeast China, turned hooligan after reading ''obscene and bawdy'' books, the Chinese press reported recently.

title: State Senator Held in Smuggling Scheme
description: A State Senator from New York City was arrested by the F.B.I. in an elegant, wood-paneled dining room at the Plaza Hotel yesterday after an agent posing as a shady international financier gave him $150,000 to smuggle out of the country in violation of currency laws.

title: THE BABER'S FATE
description: LEAD: IN SIBERIA IT IS VERY COLD By Lester Goldberg. 221 pp. New York: Dembner Books. $14.95.

title: MINNA JOYCE TOWBIN IS WED
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Minna Joyce Towbin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Robert Towbin of New York, and Edward B. Pinger Jr., the son of Jean Schaupp of San Francisco and the late Edward B. Pinger. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer and the Rev. David Forbes officiated. Mrs. Pinger, a cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College, was formerly a research editor at Elle magazine. Her father, a former vice chairman of L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towban and a former vice chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, is a managing director of Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. Her mother is Irene K. Towbin, a painter.

title: MY NEIGHBOR, MY ENEMY
description: Reading Thomas Friedman's article while on a concert tour in the United States, I found it difficult to recognize the fear-striken, hostility-ridden, violence-prone city of his story as the Jerusalem I live in. For the past few weeks Israeli and Palestinian craftsmen and workers have been renovating our apartment there. They work with mutual respect, comradery and friendship. It is a scene duplicated everywhere in the country.

title: DENVER
description: Every day this summer, scores of vacationers will pass through Denver without stopping for so much as a tank of gas. They are hungry for the West, and for most of them, the West is somewhere high in the Rocky Mountains, not down in the glass and steel canyons of Denver.

title: DAWSON SMACKS 3 HOMERS
description: Andre Dawson hit three home runs and drove in five runs, leading the Chicago Cubs to a 5-3 victory today and breaking the Philadelphia Phillies' five-game winning streak. The Cubs had lost three in a row.

title: ANTIQUES LOFF TO NEW HOPE FOR VINTAGE CARS
description: LEAD: AN ESTIMATED 1,500 to 1,700 vintage vehicles will undoubtedly cause traffic tie-ups Saturday and next Sunday as they make their way to the grounds of New Hope-Solebury High School here and remain on display for the annual midsummer presentation of the New Hope Automobile Show.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE HAUNTING MEMORY OF A DESPERATE JOURNEY
description: LEAD: Modern Israel's birth in 1948 was accompanied by considerable anguish and tumult. A newly issued Israel government medal commemorates one of those birth pangs: the frustrating voyage of a steamship called the Exodus 47.

title: A Composer Sets Midlife Blues to Music
description: A FATHER and son struggle to communicate. A wife feels trapped in a dead-end marriage. ''Life is choking me,'' cries a husband unable to get his life together.

title: STEWART FANS 14 IN BEATING TWINS
description: Carney Lansford led off the ninth inning with a home run off Frank Viola, giving the Oakland Athletics and Dave Stewart a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MARSALIS IN POMONA Wynton Marsalis, the 25-year-old virtuoso trumpeter who is a master of both jazz and classical music, will appear in Pomona Friday evening.

title: ELISE NAGLER MARRIES
description: Elise Gallaudet Nagler, the daughter of Elizabeth G. Nagler of Valley Stream, L.I., and Lawrence Nagler of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Ronald Wayne Barrett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Barrett of San Jose, Calif. The Rev. Donald Williams performed the ceremony at the Mount Soledad Presbyterian Church in La Jolla, Calif. Mr. Barrett is a technician for the Integrated Software Systems Corporation in San Diego. He and his wife are graduates of the University of California at San Diego.

title: LYNN APRUZZESE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass., Lynn Marie Apruzzese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent John Apruzzese of Mendham, N.J., and North Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to James Fenelon DesMarais, the son of Mrs. Harold R. Somerset of Orinda, Calif., and Richard DesMarais of Englewood, Fla. The Rev. Herbert C. Skelly performed the ceremony.

title: From New York Lawyers, Advice for Aliens
description: At the New York City Bar Association the other evening, an immigration lawyer, Marjorie Siegel, heard the cases of a live-in housekeeper from Singapore, a student from Trinidad, two English nannies and several other illegal aliens.

title: DATABANK: August 2, 1987
IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: SO WE walked down the rutted, cinder drive toward Jane's house. I'll call her Jane because that's her real name.

title: INSTRUCTOR IS WED TO MIA KJELDSEN
description: Annemarie Kjeldsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christen Kjeldsen of Aarhus, Denmark, and Douglas Weisberger, the son of Mrs. Elton Nachman of Somers, N.Y., and the late Monroe J. Weisberger of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married last evening at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale by Rabbi Jack Stern Jr., who was assisted by Cantor Joseph Boardman.

title: COLLEGE ERRED IN SUSPENSIONS, A COURT RULES
description: Students who were suspended after conducting a three-day sit-in at Hamilton College to protest what they described as racial and sex discrimination were entitled to a hearing under the due process clause of the Constitution, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: KIMONOS AND LONELY VIOLETS
description: THE OLD CAPITAL tr,br1By Yasunari Kawabata. Translated by J. Martin Holman. 164 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: North Point Press. $15.95.

title: HENDERSON PLACED ON DISABLED LIST
description: Rickey Henderson, whose sore right hamstring has kept him out of nearly one-third of the Yankees' games this season, went on the disabled list for the second time after he experienced swelling and more soreness yesterday morning.

title: WILL TAYLOR'S DRUG STORY HURT THE GIANTS?
description: I don't think there will be a problem at all. There are 44 other Giants on the team. I believe they all have sympathy for L. T.'s problems. They won't let it affect the caliber of their play. The way they played defense all last season, they could have won with Andy Headen at right linebacker. It's a team game and one player, no matter how high he rises to the occasion, cannot carry his team to a championship by himself. I think Lawrence Taylor has learned a lesson the hard way. And I am sure his nightmare has made him a stronger individual and a better human being. Hang in there, 56. BRIAN CORRIGAN Hawthorne, N.J.

title: Hollywood Streak
description: THERE'S something about the notion of a rag-tag bunch of passed-over baseball players coming together to make sports history that appeals to the movie mentality. At any rate, since the Salt Lake City Trappers of the Pioneer League set a professional baseball record last week by winning 29 straight games, the team, which has no major-league affiliation, has been flooded with inquiries from Hollywood types seeking to turn the historic streak into box office cash.

title: CHILDREN OF DIVORCE
description: Having shared Karin Spencer's experience as the daughter of a divorced and remarried father, I understand exactly what she is saying when she tells her father, ''I don't feel comfortable living here (''A Curfew for Karin,'' by Duncan G. Spencer, About Men, July 5). And Mr. Spencer is correct when he assumes that she is also saying, ''You left my mother, and now I'll show you how it feels.''

title: ANNE LIEBERMAN WEDS DAVID FLINT
description: Anne Judith Lieberman, an associate producer of the weekly science series ''Innovation'' on Channel 13, and David Randall Flint, who will enter the New York University Graduate School of Social Work next month, were married yesterday. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated at a loft at 126 Fifth Avenue.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE RULES OF LIFE. By Fay Weldon. Illustrated by Amanda Faulkner. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Attuned to the latest spiritual and electronic fads, Fay Weldon, the English author of many novels, begins this tale in the year 2004, in the British Museum, now a Temple of the Great New Fictional Religion, or GNFR, which has replaced Christianity.

title: Consumers League: A Spry 87
description: LEAD: FOR 87 years, the Consumers League of New Jersey has been involved in major social and economic issues, among them child labor, minimum wage, workmen's compensation, migrant farm workers, the metric system, occupational diseases, recycling, pure food and drugs and the elimination of sweat shops.

title: A Personal Message
description: After 48 years as a reporter on The New York Times, writing a column two or three times a week for more than 30 years, I concluded a little while ago that a man can stick in the trench too long.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
They Welcome Campus 'Graying'
description: LEAD: IMAGINE discussing the Holocaust in a college history course and learning that one of your classmates was among the soldiers who liberated a concentration camp.

title: HEALTH-POLICY AID AVAILABLE TO ELDERLY
description: LEAD: AFTER having surgery to remove a cyst on her shoulder, Marcelle DelGaudio found herself with a fistful of medical bills, receipts and forms.

title: MT. SINAI CONSIDERS SCHOOL OPTIONS
description: LEAD: AS requested by the Mount Sinai School District, a study is being conducted on the feasibility of the district's operating its own high school, merging with the adjacent Port Jefferson School District or maintaining the status quo, under which Mount Sinai teen-agers attend Vandermeulen High School in Port

title: Drama Finds a Leading Role In Britain's Opera Houses
description: DAME JOAN SUTHERLAND was once quoted as saying that ''it's the sound of singing that people want when they come to the opera.'' And she added, ''If they want a good dramatic performance, they should go to a straight play.'' All too often, a good dramatic performance has been the last thing audiences get when they go to the opera: glorious voices declaiming in fixed positions in front of fine scenery was for a long time the norm, and theatrical values came very low down on the list of operatic priorities.

title: 'Very Little Pain' for President After Surgery
description: President Reagan was ''feeling fine'' today after surgery Friday to remove a small skin cancer from the tip of his nose, the White House said.

title: NICKI LAZARE HAS WEDDING
description: Nicki Kalmine Lazare, the daughter of Paul L. Lazare of New York and the late Janet Kalmine Lazare, was married yesterday to David Gray McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Etchison McDonald of Baltimore. The Rev. Lawrence A. M. LaPointe, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the home of the bride's father.

title: Corrections
description: An article July 19 about the Scillies, off Cornwall, England, misidentified the current that warms the islands. It is an arm of the Gulf Stream.

title: Met's Garden: Where Views Enhance Art
description: The public got its first look at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's new rooftop sculpture garden yesterday and found a bonus for art lovers.

title: My Son Is Having A Bad Year in 2d Grade
description: THE CALLS started early in the school year, before cool weather set in.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a trip to Tuscany, I would like to add a note to Beth Archer Brombert's excellent article ''Exploring the Hill Towns of Tuscany'' (Travel, July 12).

title: Bus Drivers' Rules of The Road
description: AFTER four years of driving a school bus, Gerry Marcus of the Lakeland school district in Westchester County, N.Y., learned that the finger he had been pointing at students on his bus was an invitation to aggressive behavior.

title: Star Cub Benched
description: IT was just a 30-second television commercial, but by the time Jody Davis, the Cubs' $1-million-a-year catcher, was finished with the taping on Friday, he was late for batting practice. His manager, Gene Michael, was not amused. He scratched Davis from the lineup and said he would be benched indefinitely. ''Baseball is going to be No. 1, not commercials or doing other things,'' Michael said.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
She Forgot Her Baby in School
description: LEAD: MORE than half of America's teen-agers engage in sexual intercourse by the time they are 17, according to a national poll published by Planned Parenthood. And in 1984, more than a million American teen-agers became pregnant.

title: For Art's Sake
description: Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, who has been successful in attracting public support for a cultural institution, is about to learn whether she can also dish it out. Dr. Campbell, the director of the Studio Museum in Harlem for the last decade, was named last week to succeed Bess Myerson as New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. As director of the Studio Museum, which she is credited with having built into perhaps the finest black fine-arts museum in America, Dr. Campbell headed one of the many museums, theater groups, dance companies and other organizations that rely on the Cultural Affairs agency for much of their sustenance. That experience, plus an academic grounding in the fine arts, led many in the arts community to praise her appointment to the agency, which dispenses more than $130 million a year.

title: A SOBER PAUSE IN SUPERCONDUCTOR RACE
description: THE experimentalists are as frenetic as ever, and the rhetoric is no less inflamed, but the development of superconductivity has entered a new, more sober phase.

title: Swedish Bone China In Whites and Golds
description: When it comes to dinner services Gustavsberg is a name to reckon with in Sweden, where the best tables in private homes, royal palaces and fine restaurants are set with bone china and stoneware made by the 162-year-old company.

title: ALL OF HER PLEASURES ARE FUN

title: A Long Trial in Spain on Fatal Tainted Food
description: When the trial of 40 merchants accused of importing and selling tainted cooking oil that killed more than 600 people opened here in late March, it was expected to last six months. Court officials now estimate the trial will continue the rest of the year.

title: MISS WOOLVERTON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The Chocorua Island Chapel on Squam Lake in Holderness, N.H., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Susan Cate Woolverton, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John Frederick Woolverton of Portland, Me., and Center Sandwich, N.H., and Frederick Chase Rozelle 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rozelle of Center Sandwich. The Rev. T. Gutherie Speers Jr., a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

description: Nancy Friedman, a lawyer on the staff of Peter F. Vallone, majority leader and vice chairman of the New York City Council, is planning to marry Steve Posner next May. He is vice presidetion of operations for the New York advertising concern f Newmark, Posner & Mitchell. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harold K. Friedman of New York and Mr.s and Mrs. Sidney Posner of Cedarhurst, L.I.

title:
ART;
FRIEDEL DZUBAS REFINES HIS MASTERY AS AN ABSTRACT COLORIST
description: LEAD: AMONG the American painters for whom color is the primary vehicle of expression, Friedel Dzubas is an acknowledged master. Although several other colorists of his generation - Morris Louis, Helen Frankenthaler, Sam Francis and Kenneth Noland - are more widely known, few would dispute his position in the vanguard that succeeded the Abstract

title: Dolly? Barbara? Tammy?
description: SOMETHING terrible happened while Virgil was on holiday. Somebody stole Dolly Parton.

title: Hispanic People Attack English-Language Bills
description: Hispanic residents in the New York metropolitan region have mounted aggressive campaigns to kill legislative proposals to declare English the official language in the three states.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Presses Pakistan The United States will ask Pakistan to crack down on a private network thought to be getting material for the development of that country's nuclear arms program, Administration officials said. Page 3. Violence in Family Courts Amid eruptions of violence, family courts step up security and try to defuse the tensions of divorce, custody and other cases. Page 22. State Senator Arrested In a sting operation, the F.B.I. arrested a state senator from Queens who it said agreed to carry $150,000 out of the country illegally. Page 34.

title:
GARDENING;
FENDING OFF SUMMERTIME DISEASES
description: LEAD: THE arrival of hot midsummer brings with it certain predictable problems for gardeners. Knowing what to look for, along with close observation, can help identify and treat some of those problems.

title: A SUMMER VACATION INTO THE PAST
description: IF Joshua D. Scalora expected only mystery and excitement during a field school in archeology on the Pequot reservation in Ledyard this summer, he was quickly disillusioned.

title: Massachusetts, Angered by Terrorism, Raises Tuition for Foreign Students
description: Foreigners studying at public colleges and universities in Massachusetts face huge tuition increases this fall as a result of legislation signed last month by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. The measure, which moved through the Legislature with little attention and no debate, requires foreign students at the state's 29 academic institutions to pay the ''true cost'' of their education. University officials said the law would require them to charge foreigners almost twice as much as the tuition paid by American students from outside the state.

title: A RIGID BUILDING CODE PRESERVES NANTUCKET
description: THIS GENTLE, FIRM ISLAND IS not the place of exquisite tranquility it was a generation ago. In the last decade Nantucket, like virtually every other desirable piece of shoreline on the East Coast, has been put under development pressures that seem more fitting for Madison Avenue than a rural community. Vast numbers of new houses, stores and commercial buildings have gone up, and the roads that were once country byways have become choked with traffic.

title: Article 740787 -- No Title
description: VOTERS would consider the costliest referendum in county history if, as expected, legislators approve the plans for a 530-bed jail facility that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke submitted to them last week.

title: Authors Seek Muse In a Room
description: Carl Solberg slouched over an old typewriter, pounding out notes for his work-in-progress on the China lobby, while in a nearby carrel, John Demaray, a medieval scholar, put the finishing touches on his most recent opus, ''Dante and the Book of the Cosmos.''

title: A Scholar Who Made Education a Best Seller
description: THE BRASS PLATE ON the enormous dark wooden door of Allan Bloom's apartment, in a 1920's building near the University of Chicago campus, might read 221b Baker Street. Mr. Bloom, beaming a greeting, seems Holmes and Watson rolled into one - tall, slender, angular, massively domed. He is an inventory of energetic, hospitable moves as he juggles a cup of espresso while lighting a cigarette. His words tumble over each other, like a magician's distracting patter, and his observant eyes glow as if catching the flame of a Victorian gas jet.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
BROWN IN LOVE
description: LEAD: YOU'RE IN LOVE, CHARLIE BROWN Directed by Bill Melendez. Written by Charles M. Schulz. Kartes Video Communications. 26 minutes. $14.95.

title: Bolivians Say It's Their Right to Grow Coca
description: Alberto Vargas and Julio Rocha grow coca, the raw material of cocaine, and they are fighting for their lawful right to continue.

title: HEATHER KNIGHT BECOMES BRIDE
description: Heather Atwood Knight, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Knight of New Canaan, Conn., and Stowe, Vt., and Capt. Colin Mitchell Pech, U.S.A.F., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry L. Pech of Hamburg, N.Y., were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in New Canaan by the Rev. Charles Smith.

title: Her Serendipity Was Writing About Biology With Elegance and Wit
description: In the late 1960's Helena Curtis was working part time for the Rockefeller Institute as a freelance writer and also raising two children. Because she had written a book on viruses and another on protozoa, a budding textbook publisher offered her $1,000 a month to write an introductory college book on biology. ''That was a lot of money then,'' Mrs. Curtis recalled recently, ''so I dropped everything and did it.''

title: THE ITALIANS
description: THE ITALIANS HAVE A WORD FOR IT - garbo - that elusive combination of decorum and grace that characterizes the most disparate accomplishments: a finely turned phrase, a virtuoso recital or, for that matter, a deft piece of tailoring. ''Garbo,'' wrote the social commentator Luigi Barzini, in his book, ''The Italians,'' ''keeps everything within the boundaries of credibility and taste.''

title: Correction
description: A dispatch from the United Nations on July 26 about that organization's approach to fighting the world drug trade incorrectly characterized a statement by Ann Wrobleski, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, as defending the opium trade in Afghanistan.

title: Foreign Film Makers Look to American Actors
description: ALTHOUGH THERE IS nothing new about American actors starring in foreign directors' films -from Marlon Brando in Bernardo Bertolucci's ''Last Tango in Paris'' to William Hurt in Hector Babenco's ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' - the phenomenon is assuming ever-larger proportions. For economic as well as artistic reasons, directors from abroad making English-language movies want to work with American performers; similarly, actors from the United States are attracted to the challenging projects that Hollywood doesn't seem to be offering. Perhaps Mr. Hurt's Academy Award (and Cannes Film Festival prize) for best actor sent an important signal to his colleagues, namely that a South American director could shape brilliant characterization as skillfully as an American.

title: G.O.P. PONDERS AN APPEAL TO MINORITIES
description: WHEN Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, stared down at an audience of young Republicans the other day, he was struck not so much by what he saw as what he did not. ''I'd like to see 50 wheelchairs in this audience,'' he said, ''I'd like to see 50 black faces, 50 Hispanics, 50 Asian-Americans.'' The problem with the Republicans, he said, is that ''we're sort of a hard-hearted party, the upper crust.''

title:
INVESTING;
Waiting for the Japanese Cash
description: LEAD: Investors hoping for higher prices often invoke the imminent arrival of a new wave of buyers, to push quotes upward. ''Wait until the public starts buying,'' is one standby. Now some analysts - covering the United States stock market and international gold markets - say, ''Wait till the Japanese buy.

title: Music: Piano and Voice On Mostly Mozart Bill
description: LEOPOLD HAGER did not produce a fully satisfying concert with the Mostly Mozart orchestra Friday night, but he did enough to leave one interested in hearing more of the conductor's work. He led two symphonies - Haydn's 69th and Schubert's third - with a sense of purpose and a feeling for the drama of symphonic development that did not wilt even when the playing became uneven.

title: FIRST-TIME WINNERS
description: The final of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Baltimore a week ago was remarkable in two ways: It featured some unusual and interesting personalities, and it was one of the most exciting finals in the 64-year history of the event.

title: Student Program Trains the Hispanic to Lead
description: The game is called ''Power Play,'' and it can get dirty. An ''emperor'' and his ministers rule ''the masses,'' who team up to gain influence any way they can.

title: Italian Prime Minister Wins His First Vote of Confidence
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria's new Government overcame its first parliamentary hurdle today, comfortably winning a vote of confidence in the Senate.

title: Behind the Saudi-Iranian Tumult, Political and Religious Frictions
description: The crisis that has erupted between Saudi Arabia and Iran after violent clashes Friday in the holy city of Mecca is a consequence of considerable political and religious frictions between the two largest countries on the Persian Gulf.

title: Surviving Tragedy On the Farm
description: ANNABEL HILL has coped with the suicide of her husband and a debt-laden farm that twice was put up on the auction block for nonpayment of loans. But she calls herself ''blessed.''

title: Cabaret: John Wallowitch's Nostalgia Trip
description: ''THE World of Wallowitch,'' a cabaret revue featuring John Wallowitch, a composer-lyricist, and the singers Melissa Eddy and Betsy Ann Leadbetter, is steeped in nostalgia for a genteel, Manhattan style of life that has all but vanished.

title: Caudill Injured
description: Bill Caudill of the Oakland Athletics suffered a broken right hand when he punched a man who was said to try to assault the reliever's wife in the parking lot of a hotel today, a team official said. Caudill, who has pitched in six games with one save, was placed on the 21-day disabled list and outfielder Dwayne Murphy was reactivated.

title: Music: The Taneyev String Quartet
description: THE air of peacefulness that seems to be hanging over Soviet-American relations these days settled tangibly over the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Friday night. The instigators were the members of the Taneyev String Quartet, a venerable group formed at the end of World War II in Leningrad. This was their American debut and their presence counterbalances similar tours of the Soviet Union made a year ago by the Manhattan String Quartet.

title: 'CAMPUS SCHOOL'
description: Seventy-five students from five school districts in the county are participating in a summer program designed to enhance their motivation for learning and their enjoyment of school.

title: POSTGRADUATE PIONEERS OF THE MAMET METHOD
description: IT IS SUNDAY AFTERNOON, AND members of the Atlantic Theater Company are gathered for a game of softball on a field surrounded by cascading green hills. In the cheering section sits Gregory Mosher, artistic director of the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse theaters at Lincoln Center, who has a summer house nearby. And in the offing is a barbeque at actor/director W. H. Macy's log cabin in the woods, just outside of town. The playwright David Mamet is flying in from a movie meeting on the West Coast to be there.

title: McMahon to Start
description: EIGHT months after he underwent shoulder surgery, Jim McMahon, the quarterback who led the Chicago Bears to victory in the 1986 Super Bowl but missed most of last season, will be getting a chance to show just how well he has recovered. Mike Ditka, the coach, announced that McMahon would be starting the team's first exhibition game in two weeks.

title: 'COME ON, BIG BOY - LET ME SEE YOUR MANUSCRIPT'
description: THE BOYS OF WINTER By Wilfrid Sheed. 280 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: LEARNING BY HEART. By Margot Livesey. (Penguin, Paper, $6.95.) Margot Livesey is a Scottish immigrant to Canada and the stories in her first collection, which are set in the British Isles, are rich with understanding of people cut off from their roots and from one another. An elderly woman is surprised to discover that her sister, with whom she lives, is virtually blind.

title: SHE TOOK THE AIDS TEST
description: Dena Kleiman may have understated how the possibility of a false positive result may affect a person who was not counseled to the extent that she was. A friend of mine, someone, like Ms. Kleiman, who had no reason to think she had been infected, was plunged into a profound depression when her first test result came back positive and she was warned never to have children and to inform previous sexual partners of the result. My friend didn't dare believe the second AIDS test result, which was negative. She has taken the AIDS test a third and fourth time (with both results negative) yet has become convinced -neurotically, she admits, but also helplessly - that she still may be infected with the virus.

title: A Cow Is a Cow Is a Cow - Maybe
description: IT didn't seem like a Federal case to the owners of a small motel in Stowe, Vt.: five plywood cows grazing in a field next to the motel.

title: Iran-Contra Hearings Leave Fundamental Issues Unexamined; Who Is the Enemy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Planning Treatment of Terminally Ill Is Urged
description: Severely or terminally ill patients are often left out of decisions on whether to keep them alive through respirators, feeding tubes or other treatments, according to a Congressional study.

title: Dance
description: The city's streets seem to be spilling over these days with outdoor summer arts festivals. But the Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival is one of the granddaddies of them all. It opens on Tuesday with a dazzling variety of free performances. Things get off to a giddy start at 11 A.M. with a parade featuring a 50-foot dragon, clowns, puppets and performances by the Heavenly Hummingbirds and the Acrobrats. Harold Nicholas will star in a performance by Dance Ellington at 12:30, with a repeat performance next Monday, and he is just as dazzling and dapper an acrobatic dancer today as he was as one of the Nicholas Brothers in those 1940's film musicals and revues. And Jacques d'Amboise's National Dance Institute will celebrate literature at the same performance and at 7:30.

title: Forsaking Decorum
description: Moscow concert-goers were in a Billy Joel state of mind last week. In highly unusual outbursts, fans mobbed the stage and danced in the aisles at Olympic Stadium while the singer performed. Some observers linked the rare discarding of decorum to the Government's drive for ''glasnost,'' or openness. But Mr. Joel also played a role, encouraging the audience to dance and approach the stage. At one show, the singer upbraided people who sat stonily in the first few rows.

title: Is OSHA Falling Down on the Job?
description: In the office of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration that covers Travis County, Tex., there is a file that reads like a roadmap to laborer Victor Nazario's death. For more than a year, the file shows, OSHA inspectors visited worksites of the Austin-based Bland Construction Company. Almost every time, they found workers deep in trenches that were not shored up or sloped to protect them from the cave-in accidents that kill scores of construction workers every year, about 10 annually in Texas alone.

title: WILL TAYLOR'S DRUG STORY HURT THE GIANTS?
description: If we can believe that Taylor is telling the truth when hefan can - then L. T. will have yet another great year at the expense of opposing quarterbacks. His fellow Giants have overcome greater obstacles than the revelation of a drug story two years old, and their primary concern will not be Taylor's book or the backlash.

title: Is It Prime Time for Vietnam?
description: IT'S BACK - NAPALM, FIREFIGHTS, BODY BAGS, Hueys, rice paddies, Victor Charlie, search-and-destroy, the quagmire, the Living Room War.

title: On Campus, the Look Is, Well, Studied
description: IN THE OLD DAYS, when a pungence in the air signaled the start of another academic year, young college women donned tweed Bermuda shorts and Shetland sweaters, while men stepped out in khakis and dirty white bucks. ''It was not a preppy look,'' insists Ellin Saltzman, senior vice president and fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue. ''It was simply what you wore.''

title: Aloft in Rheims, The City Of Champagne
description: The balloon ride over the 13th-century Cathedral of Notre Dame came in the early evening, just before we devoured a plate of sweetbreads in a truffle crust at one of the best restaurants in France. A great black shadow decorated with colored stripes, the balloon soared upward from the spacious back lawn of Boyer Les Crayeres, Rheims's most celebrated place for eating and sleeping - and where the sweetbreads, among other things, were already on the fire. It lifted over a line of trees and drifted noiselessly through the glittering air toward the center of town, whose streets and houses took on the appearance of a Roman mosaic in faded orange and brown.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MENUDO ON TOUR Menudo, the young musical group that originated in Puerto Rico a decade ago and now wanders the international concert circuit, comes to the Island today. Lately, the ensemble and its newest member, 12-year-old Ruben Gomez of New York, have been on a ''Summer in the Streets Tour,'' and although there aren't too many ''streets'' surrounding the Westbury Music Fair, that's where Menudo plays at 3 P.M. For ticket information call 333-0533. 'PRIME TIME' JAZZ Ornette Coleman and the Prime Time Band make their Long Island debut tonight at Eisenhower Park. The alto saxophonist, who has fused jazz with such genres as rural blues and classical idioms and met with remarkable critical acclaim (most recently at the JVC Jazz Festival in New York), and his trail-blazing band perform at 8 P.M. at the Lakeside Theater of the East Meadow park. The concert, courtesy of the Nassau County Office of Cultural Development and Meet the Composer, is free. PUBLIC ARTISTS With the current talk about art in public places, Arthur Byron Phillips, an East Hampton artist, decided it might be fun and illuminating to get some of the artists involved in the Great Depression's Public Works Arts Program, performing and literary, as well as visual, together. So through word of mouth and combing the archives, he's come up with more than a dozen veterans of the program from all over Long Island.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
VOLUNTEERS IN PARKS
description: LEAD: ''I NEVER thought I'd be comfortable picking up a slug,'' Bernice Levine, a retired social worker, said recently. ''But now I feel quite comfortable about it. I've also become an expert on earthworms.''

title: OTHER ANIMALS JOIN MOST-UNWANTED LIST
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH deer have been seen in Westchester as far south as Bronxville, residents in the southern part of the county have had more problems this year and last keeping raccoons at bay. Skunks and squirrels are also frequently unwanted guests.

title: CRIME IN EVERY HAMLET
description: BACK in 1929, in ''Red Harvest,'' Dashiell Hammett sent his San Francisco shamus, the Continental Op, to a town in Montana called Personville. (Among the locals, ''Poisonville.'') In this adventure - considered to be the first of the so-called ''rotten town'' novels of the period - the detective describes the place as ''an ugly city of forty thousand people, set in an ugly notch between two ugly mountains that had been dirtied up by mining.'' Even his client feels compelled to apologize for her unprepossessing city. ''You'll find it a dreary place,'' she says. ''I suppose all mining towns are like this.''

title: RECORDINGS: ROUNDUP OF NOTABLE RECENT RELEASES
description: LEAD: Holst: The Planets Orchestre symphonique de Montreal, Charles Dutoit, conductor. London 417 553-2

title: Dollars Abroad
description: To the Editor: Travelers should be aware of the difficulty of securing United States dollars through a credit card cash advance in many third world countries in the area of the Indian Ocean and the Arabian and Red Seas.

title: Vermont Forest Plan Draws Praise
description: In Washington offices far removed from Vermont's Green Mountains, the United States Forest Service drew up a plan for how the national forest system should be used over the next 50 years.

title: Catching Up
description: NOBODY'S saying that Syd Thrift doesn't know his baseball, but in a game where the importance of pitching is universally recognized, it's just possible that the Pirate general manager may have gotten his baseball maxims mixed up. That possibility emerged after the Pirates, who have a lock on the cellar of the National League East, traded the pitcher, Don Robinson, the last remaining player from the Pirates' 1979 world championship team, to the San Francisco Giants for a minor league catcher, Mackey Sasser. When it was pointed out that the Pirates already had two catchers on the roster, Mike LaValliere and Junior Ortiz, Thrift had a ready reply. ''You can never have enough catching,'' he said.

title: 3 Charged in a Pyramid Scheme
description: Three men with Hollywood entertainment connections have been accused of trying to snare show-business people in New York for an illegal, high-stakes pyramid scheme, according to the State Attorney General's office.

title: MY NEIGHBOR, MY ENEMY
description: Thomas L. Friedman's deeply moving report on contemporary Israel is at the same time deeply flawed (''My Neighbor, My Enemy,'' July 5). For while his article probingly demonstrates a parity of psychological and even historical claims to the land, the piece is curiously neglectful of policy and political considerations.

title: Nova Scotia: Coves Attract The Lawless
description: For centuries, Nova Scotia's rocky shoreline has invited most kinds of misfortune and skulduggery associated with the sea.

title: RECORDINGS: ROUNDUP OF NOTABLE RECENT RELEASES
description: Weill: Johnny Johnson Lyrics and libretto by Paul Green. With Burgess Meredith, Evelyn Lear, Lotte Lenya and Jean Sanders. Conducted by Samuel Matlowsky. Polydor 831 384-2 Y-1.

title: Recent Sales
description: Irvington, N.Y. $328,000 4 Riverview Terrace 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old frame ranch, eat-in kitchen, basement workshop, river views;taxes $4,679. Peekskill, N.Y. $377,500 30 Pamela Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; family room, den, 35-foot deck, master bedroom suite, 0.75-acre; taxes $4,777. Port Chester, N.Y. $240,000 99 Robert Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 bath, 52-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman, den, 3-car garage, 0.73-acre; taxes $2,341. Orange, Conn. $210,000 725 Racebrook Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; remodeled, 2-car garage, 150- by 160-foot lot; taxes $1,285. Sherman, Conn. $169,000 Candlewood Lake Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, 0.5 acre; taxes $907. West Haven, Conn. $235,000 295 Country Hill Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; fireplace in family room, central A/C; taxes $3,115. OTHER AREAS Fanwood, N.J. $172,000 390 North Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old colonial; patio, basement, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes, $2,980. Florham Park, N.J. $203,900 5 Keyes Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, screened porch, 1-car garage, new roof; taxes, $1,673. Lindenhurst, L.I. $126,000 255 Lido Promenade West 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000.

title: WHY BRADLEY ISN'T RUNNING
description: SPOTTING THE BIG GUY STANDING unceremoniously outside the visitors' center at the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area in northwestern New Jersey, the two sixth-grade teachers make their move - would he address their students? Of course.

title: Pirate Radio Walks the Plank
description: An unlicensed rock radio station that had been broadcasting from a ship four and a half miles off Long Island for five days had its timbers shivered by the Federal Government last week.

title: JAPANESE STYLE
description: JAPAN IS A COUNTRY that has long had appeal to foreigners, and modernists in the West have been greatly influenced by the traditional Japanese way of life. Simplicity, functionalism and minimalism -three of the most important elements of Japanese design - have been appreciated, since the 19th century, and reinterpreted by Western designers and architects.

title: Beyond Principles
description: THE BREAKDOWN at first was hardly noticeable except to the trained eye. The Ivan Boesky scandal, for instance, did not seem especially alarming, nor did the discovery that Wall Street was swarming with chiselers and finaglers of the Boesky type. It was only Wall Street, after all. The chance to get filthy rich had always brought out the worst in people.

title: COMMUTERS SHARE THE RIDE TO WORK
description: LEAD: WHEN Barbara M. Shea of Stratford drives to her job in New Haven as information systems specialist for the Southern New England Telephone Company, she makes the trip with 14 co-workers she picks up at the company's Stratford parking lot.

title: GROWING COMPLAINTS CITE DAMAGE BY DEER TO SHRUBS AND CROPS
description: LEAD: DEER, raccoons, geese and coyotes have been causing an increasing number of problems in the county in the last two years, according to Federal and state officials, local animal nuisance-control agents and residents. And, they say, efforts to cope with the problems are only short-term at best - because, first, there is no general firearms hunting season in the county and, second, most county residents don't want to harm wild animals.

title: CRIME
description: The Anna Lee mysteries by Liza Cody have maintained a consistently high level beginning with the appearance of the first one, ''Dupe,'' in 1981. Lee is a private investigator working for Brierly Security in London. The fifth in the series, UNDER CONTRACT (Scribners, $16.95), carries on the good work.

title: In Kenya, Man and Beast Compete for Free Land
description: Every morning, soon after the sun breaks through the vast African sky, herds of foreign tourists trundle through Kenya's game parks in search of bold tapestries of wildlife.

title: ARRIVING AT FUNK FROM TWO DIRECTIONS
description: RHYTHM IS WHAT FUNK IS ALL about. Funk is stripping the music down and getting rid of everything that isn't hard rhythmic muscle. Bass and drums, stuttering in tandem, are no longer simply the foundation of the music - they are the music. And the music is the beat. The bass player plucks and pulls at his strings, making them pop like a drumstick ricocheting off the head of a snare. The guitarist chokes his strings against the instrument's neck while strumming percussively, getting a rapidly percolating, double-time rhythmic pattern, something like a jazz drummer might play on his ride cymbal. Electric keyboards sputter staccato responses, and even the horns hit hard and hollow punctuations: every instrument a drum. That's funk. And while it's a long way from James Brown's original mid-sixties funk manifesto, ''Papa's Got A Brand New Bag,'' to the latest rap, go-go and street-funk hits, with their new technology of electronic sequencers, turntable scratching and synthetic rhythm sections, the fundamentals remain the same. Rhythm. Muscle. The beat.

title: MY NEIGHBOR, MY ENEMY
description: Thomas Friedman's evenhandedness in characterizing the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians surely represents an improvement over most United States accounts. Unfortunately, the two communities are not exactly symmetrical. One already has a home; the other is uprooted and desperate. One is among the most militarized states on the planet; the other must resort to throwing stones. Whatever value one may assign in the abstract to each party's claim to the land, the moral equation is radically changed by the fact that Israelis are wearing the boot and Palestinians are under it. ALFIE KOHN Cambridge, Mass.

title: Jazz: The Mulgrew Miller Quintet
description: MULGREW MILLER, a young pianist who has been impressing his fellow musicians with accomplished, inventive and increasingly individual playing and composing, has been heard in a variety of contexts, from solo and trio work to hard-bop combos. But he has seldom been showcased so effectively as with his new quintet, which is playing at the Village Vanguard through today.

title: In Texas, Book Salesman's Life Is Mostly a Road Show
description: RAYMOND WARD didn't set out to spend his days in a white Caprice Classic full of textbooks, barreling across west Texas from the suburbs ringing Fort Worth to tiny, isolated towns like Marfa and Alpine. But he switched from teaching to selling schoolbooks three and a half years ago, a career path shared by most of his peers in the business. Since then he has endured 14-hour days, lugged 40 pounds of books through countless schools and become immersed in the odd mix of lonely road show and frantic sales rush that puts about $1.6 billion worth of new textbooks into American elementary and secondary schools every year.

title: STEAKHOUSE LIVES UP TO THE IMAGE
description: P.G.'S on Jericho Turnpike in Huntington is a classic steakhouse. You know the formula: steaks can be ordered for one, two or three people ($19.75, $39.25, $58.75), come sliced from the kitchen and are perched on an overturned saucer so that the juices congregate at one end of the platter.

title: THE CROWD IN THE WILDERNESS
description: THE LEGACY OF CONQUEST The Unbroken Past of the American West. By Patricia Nelson Limerick. Illustrated. 396 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: Black Holes May Underlie Process Of Galactic Birth
description: Of all the astronomical oddities, none are weirder than black holes and quasars. A black hole - as massive as millions of suns - is believed to exert so strong a gravitational pull that nothing, not even light, escapes it. A quasar, on the other hand, emits an overwhelming amount of radiation.

title: New Milford
description: THE stately brick building, with the words ''Town Hall of New Milford'' in gold lettering, overlooks an old-fashioned bandshell on a historic town green surrounded by dozens of boutiques.

title: Week of Tribute To Baldrige
description: The Reagan Administration eulogized Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige last week, making it clear that he would be missed not only for his tough-minded trade policies and negotiating skills, but also for his ''simple, strong and decent values.''

title: DEMOCRATS' BALLOT BLUNDER
description: ONE measure of Democratic prospects in the critical Nassau County and town elections this year is that the candidate some Democratic leaders consider their strongest may owe his place on the ballot to Republicans.

title: PLEASE, DEAR GOD, PLEASE...
description: THE FIRST sign of senile dementia has appeared. At 6:15 the other morning, I brushed my teeth with Clearasil. What's even worse news is that I didn't notice what I had done until I read the tube, which was lying deceptively, like toothpaste, next to the sink. The good news is that at least I can still see to read. But what fuddleheaded distortion will tommorow bring?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE HUSSAR. By David R. Slavitt. (Louisiana State University, $16.95.) David Slavitt, the author of nearly 30 books, calls his intriguing new novel ''a literary parlor game'' and gives credit for the plot to Theodor Fontane's 19th-century German novel ''A Man of Honor,'' a description of which he read in a book review five years ago.

title: DATA UPDATE: August 2, 1987
description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars)

title: Matters of Sense and Opacity
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Borough Park Conversion; 22 Walk-Up Condos
description: On Dahill Road at 17th Avenue, a quiet corner in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, two adjoining apartment buildings, erected in 1928 with 31 rental apartments, are being transformed into 22 condominiums with entirely new layouts.

title: Dealers at Jersey Casino Spurn Unionization
description: After an intense campaign by management, dealers at the Claridge Casino Hotel in Atlantic City have rejected unionization, delivering a blow to labor's efforts to organize the city's casino workers.

title: TRAINING WOMEN FOR TECHNICAL JOBS
description: LEAD: A PROGRAM recently begun in the Hartford area aims to fill the state's growing need for workers in technical fields with women who are seeking more challenging, better-paying jobs.

title: FOXED BY A BIBLE-BANGING MAORI
description: LEAD: SEASON OF THE JEW By Maurice Shadbolt. 384 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: Jay Tarsas: 'I Don't Do Sitcoms'
description: AS FAR AS MOST OF THE television establishment is concerned, Jay Tarses operates in uncharted territory. For instance, to get to the set of ''Slap Maxwell,'' the comedy Mr. Tarses is currently producing, and sometimes writing and directing, for ABC, a visitor must strike out into the smoggy vastness of the San Fernando Valley. On a scruffy commercial boulevard, miles from the nearest soundstage, you drive past cut-rate body shops, evangelical churches and used-furniture emporiums. You cross over a flood-control channel, turn left at a 24-hour donut shop and park in front of a store called Tile World. Next door is a small one-story building that looks, from the outside, as if it might house a printing shop or a temporary employment agency. Ensconced happily inside, in a modest office, is perhaps the most innovative - and controversial - purveyor of television comedy today.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
SEX MYSTERIES OF THE OVIPAROUS
description: LEAD: What unfolds in this book is a drama of competition, sexuality, predation and evolution in which the egg is cast as hero. Most of the animal population delivers its offspring in some sort of shell, but we don't quickly think of dragonfly eggs or the eggs of the Roman snail. EGGS: Nature's Perfect Package (Facts on File, $22.95) shows the making, laying and hatching of the eggs of insects, fish, and reptiles, as well as chickens.

title: There Is Much to Learn From the Titanic
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Home Buyers Find Quieter Pleasures On the Back Roads
description: LEAD: IN the rolling, unspoiled farm country north of Montauk Highway in Bridgehampton, Alexander Kaufman, a Roslyn developer, is building 13 traditional-style houses on fields once planted with potatoes and corn.

title: THE ENEMY OF THE AGENCY
description: ON THE RUN By Philip Agee. Illustrated. 400 pp. Secaucus, N.J.: Lyle Stuart. $19.95.

title: KIM STALLER IS MARRIED TO J. A. MACARI ON L.I.
description: Kim Staller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin P. Staller of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Joseph A. Macari, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Macari Jr. of Stamford, Conn. George V. O'Haire, a Lloyd Harbor village justice, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Nashua, N.H., Looking Askance at a Compliment
description: Shirley Santerre, a real estate agent here, says Nashua is ''too expensive.''

title: MCGWIRE IS UNFAZED BY ALL THE ATTENTION
description: Kathy McGwire's baby is due on Sept. 30. That means her husband, Mark, the first baseman for the Oakland Athletics, could face a difficult choice - miss one of the last games of the season to attend the birth of his first child or stay in the lineup in hopes of breaking the season home run record set by Roger Maris in 1961.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl vs. Gilbert: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl stopped third-seeded Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 7-6, last night to join Brad Gilbert today in the finals of the $232,000 D.C. Classic in Washington. Gilbert, who was seeded fourth, advanced earlier in the day by winning 10 of the final 11 games to surprise second-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany, 3-6, 6-3, 6-0. (AP) U.S. in Final: Pam Shriver and Chris Evert won their singles matches yesterday to propel the United States past Bulgaria and into the finals of the Federation Cup competition in Vancouver, British Columbia. Shriver defeated Katerina Maleeva, 6-3, 7-6. Evert beat Manuela Maleeva, 6-2, 2-6, 6-4. The top-seeded Americans will face West Germany, who defeated Czechoslovakia. Shriver will play Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, and Evert will play Steffi Graf.(AP) Horse Racing Disqualification Benefits Theatrical: Theatrical was declared the winner of the $221,800 Sword Dancer Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday after the first-place finisher, Dance of Life, was disqualified for interference. Dance of Life finished three lengths ahead of Theatrical but was placed second after track officials ruled that he impeded Theatrical entering the stretch. The win was the fourth in a row for Theatrical, a 5-year-old Irish-bred horse. He covered the mile-and-a-half turf course in 2 minutes 26 seconds to earn $133,080 for his owners, Bertram Firestone and Alan Paulson. Theatrical, ridden by Pat Day and carrying 124 pounds, returned $2.80 and $2.10, while Dance of Life returned $2.40.(AP) Golf Spencer-Devlin Leads in Britain: Muffin Spencer-Devlin of the United States had only two birdies and shot a 75 yesterday, but took a one-stroke lead with a 222 after the third round of the $165,000 British Ladies Golf Open in Saint Mellion, England. Sally Little of the United States and Alison Nicholas of Britain were tied for second. The defending champion, Laura Davies of Britain, winner of the United States Women's Open last Tuesday, dropped into a fourth-place tie at 224. (AP) Strange and Dillard in Tie: Curtis Strange and Andy Dillard both birdied the final hole yesterday to share a one-stroke lead after the third round of the $724,043 St. Jude Classic in Memphis. Strange and Dillard had totals of 10-under-par 206 in the PGA Tour event. (AP) Johnson Maintains Lead: Chris Johnson survived a bogey on the final hole for a two-under-par 70 yesterday and a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the $250,000 Columbia Savings Ladies Professional Golf Association National Pro-Am tournament in Englewood, Colo. Johnson's 54-hole score of 207 left her one shot ahead of Sally Quinlan.(AP) Auto Racing Unser Edges Waltrip: Al Unser Jr. passed Darrell Waltrip on the last turn of the last lap yesterday to win the third round of the Budweiser International Race of Champions series at Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, Mich. Unser beat Waltrip by three-hundredths of a second, the closest finish in the history of the series, in the 50-lap, 100-mile race. Unser averaged 155.63 miles an hour. (AP) Diving A Second Gold for Louganis: Greg Louganis collected his second gold medal in the United States outdoor championships at Bartlesville, Okla., yesterday, winning the 10-meter platform competition and a spot on the United States Pan American team. Louganis, who had a score of 657.12 points in the 10-meter competition, will be defending his titles in that event and in the 3-meter at the Pan American Games, which begin Friday in Indianapolis.(AP) Empire State Games Double Dash Victory: Wyndell Dickinson, a 22-year-old from Bayshore, L.I., swept the 100-and 200-meter dashes in the open men's division at the Empire State Games yesterday in Syracuse, N.Y. He took the 200-meter with a time of 21.73 seconds to beat Nigel Gabriel of Brooklyn. He beat Gabriel again in the 100-meter with a time of 10.98.(AP)

title: To Waste Not, We Must Want Not Incineration, but Planning
description: THE only waves that Islip's vagabond garbage barge, Mobro, now appears to be making are political - waves of recrimination between state and local officials.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Let me say right off that Brian Herbert, author of PRISONERS OF ARIONN (Arbor House, $17.95), is the son of the late Frank Herbert, author of the massively popular Dune series. I mention this not to draw invidious comparisons but to underscore the fact that he has written a quirky science fiction novel that takes a fresh approach to one of science fiction's classic themes - the invasion of Earth by technologically superior aliens.

title: In the Heat of Summer, The Market Is Sizzling
description: The bull market just won't quit, despite the heat of summer and an economy that is merely plodding ahead. The Dow Jones industrial average has been leading its less-visible siblings into record territory again and again, surprising those analysts who had been predicting that the unprecedented five-year rally would end any day now. The Dow, in eight consecutive advances, , has gained 86.74 points, finishing the week at a record 2,572.07. The Amex, Nasdaq and other indicators have also hit records, a sign that investors are looking outside the usual blue chips.

title: OLD SAYBROOK BOATBUILDER FEATURED IN MUSEUM EXHIBIT
description: FOR 40 years, Earle Brockway's sturdy boats have traveled along the Connecticut River and Long Island Sound. Now, the no-nonsense products and techniques of the Old Saybrook boatbuilder are featured in an exhibition at the Connecticut River Museum in Essex.

title: TYSON UNDISPUTED AND UNANIMOUS TITLIST
description: Boxing has an undisputed heavyweight champion, and he is Mike Tyson.

title: 'GIN GAME': ALL IN THE CARDS
description: IN ''The Gin Game,'' a pair of lonely elderly people - Weller Martin and Fonsia Dorsey, the play's sole characters - come upon each other in a nursing home and, momentarily, make contact.

title: RECORDING AN AMERICAN DREAM FROM A GENTLER ERA
description: LEAD: GROWING up in Old Westbury at the turn of the century, surrounded by ''servants who used to stay 40 years''; playing with little girls in Irish lace dresses and little boys in suits made in London; spending winters in Palm Beach, via private train, and summers in England and Scotland, Peggie Phipps Boegner never really considered herself ''privileged.

title: Corrections
description: A box accompanying an article last Sunday on smoked fish in Maine omitted mentioning the retail store of one smokehouse. The Ducktrap River Fish Farm has a store on Pitcher Pond Road in Lincolnville, Me. (207-763-3960).

title: RECORDINGS: ROUNDUP OF NOTABLE RECENT RELEASES
description: Tchaikovsky: Piano Concerto No. 1. Barry Douglas, piano, London Symphony Orchestra conducted by Leonard Slatkin (RCA CD 5708-2-RC). Mussorgsky: Pictures at an Exhibition; Liszt: Dante Sonata; Wagner/Liszt: Isolde's Liebestod. Barry Douglas, piano. RCA CD 5931-2-RC.

title: Rock: Bonnie Raitt And a Five-Man Band
description: WEEKS, months and years on the road, singing soulful songs and playing the blues, are subtly transforming Bonnie Raitt, remolding her more and more in the image of the barnstorming rhythm-and-blues perennials whose ethos so decisively influenced her own.

title: LOOSE ON THE CONTINENT
description: ALBANY PARK An Autobiography. By Patrice Chaplin. 192 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: Handling Death at Home: Lessons in Experience
description: The moment Lisa Carlson pulled open the door of the pickup truck one March night in 1981, she knew her husband was dead. Back then, she was Lisa Brackett, wife of John Brackett, a schoolteacher, and mother of two young children. That night she became the widow of a suicide.

title: D.W.I. Facility Treats the Problem
description: ARRESTED five times for driving while intoxicated, Sean, a married 29-year-old hospital chef from Medford, received what he considered the break of his life in April when a Suffolk County judge sentenced him to four months of treatment at the new D.W.I. Alternative Facility in Yaphank and five years of probation, instead of one year or more in the county jail.

title: Dim Forecast on Health Care
description: Seven hundred American hospitals, or one in 10 nationwide, will probably close by 1995, according to a study by one of the nation's largest accounting firms.

title: PITCHING PROWESS CAN'T DO IT ALL FOR DODGERS AND THE ROYALS
description: THE answer is the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Kansas City Royals. The question is which teams are living proof that whoever said pitching is 75 percent or 90 percent of the game wasn't necessarily correct.

title:
INVESTING;
Junk Bonds: Performance, Plus Stability!
description: LEAD: LIKE the stock market, the junk bond market has confounded both its fans and critics in 1987. For the first half of the year these high-yielding, lower-quality bonds outpaced higher quality corporate and government issues.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The gravity of the disease has reached a point where the minority community is now moving faster than the majority community to mobilize, to do something about it.'' - John E. Jacob, president of the National Urban League, discussing AIDS. [ 1:1. ]

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
For the Executive, Chester Has Cachet
description: LEAD: AS the inventory of buildable land continues to dwindle in the northeastern part of New Jersey, residential development has moved west, reaching to the wide-open fields of Chester Township in Morris County.

title: ELLEN McVICKAR BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Norbert in Paoli, Pa., Ellen Ludlow McVickar, a daughter of the late C. Virginia Bogert Brown of Millbrook, N.Y., and the late Grenville Kane McVickar of Warwick, N.Y., was married yesterday to Earle Morrison Layman Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Layman of St. Louis. The Rev. Walter J. Burke performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;
FIGURATIVE SCULPTURE MAKES IMPACT AT STORM KING CENTER
description: LEAD: THE 400 acres of the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y., are commonly regarded as the domain of large abstract sculptures, often boldly colored, that contrast with the green of the huge, rolling lawn. Here and there one has found figurative sculpture but, in the main, figuration is a kind of grace note to the outsized geometry.

title: A Painting Landmark In Focus
description: IT HAS BEEN NEARLY NINE YEARS SINCE THE exhibition ''New Image Painting'' opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art in December 1978. In its own quiet way the show, which included the work of 10 painters then between the ages of 30 and 43, was a landmark. Organized by Richard Marshall, an associate curator who had at that time been at the Whitney for only three years, it was the first official recognition on the part of a major New York museum of the important esthetic changes underway in the art of the 1970's.

title: O. ROBIN SWEET WEDS
description: The Battell Chapel at Yale University was the setting yesterday for the wedding of O. Robin Sweet, a daughter of Ottilie Sweet of Avon, Conn., and Stephen Sweet of New Haven, to Dr. Thomas A. Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Angsten of Waupacka, Wis. The Rev. Kate Lattimer, an Episcopal chaplain at Yale, performed the ceremony. The bride is the founder and president of the Nanny Connection Inc., a placement agency in New Haven. Her husband, formerly vice president of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., will join the California Polytechnic State University in Pomona in September as the director of the Center for Hospitality Management. The previous marriages of both the bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
GUEST WEEKEND: RELAX, THAT'S AN ORDER
description: LEAD: I'M spending weekends in the Hamptons this summer. And Fire Island and upstate New York. And I'm not paying 1 cent for a mortgage or rent. How? My husband and I are invited - try begged - to be guests by our friends every week.

title: WHEN BUYING HEALTH CARE IS LIKE BUYING BREAD
description: YOU may remember Jack Riley. He played the paranoid hypochondriac Eliot Carlin on the old ''Bob Newhart Show.'' When the ConnectiCare Health Plan needed a new spokesman, what better example of a medically afflicted layman would there be than Mr. Carlin?

title: SHE TOOK THE AIDS TEST
description: I would like to thank Dena Kleiman for sharing her AIDS-testing experience with the public. I admire her candor and courage at revealing deeply personal thoughts and feelings, which will certainly help others who are facing similar issues to feel less alone. KATHLEEN WARDACH, R.N. New York, N.Y.

title: WESTON, SPLENDID ATMOSPHERE
description: IF restaurants were graded for settings alone, Cobb's Mill Inn in Weston would deserve a valedictorian A. After all, what could be more restful, scenic or romantic than dining in a 200-year-old gristmill-turned-inn, overlooking a tranquil stream replete with showoff swans and ducklings?

title: Jersey Man Charged In Rattlesnake Attack
description: A Wallington man has been charged with attempted assault on a neighbor by arranging to have three rattlesnakes slipped under her door, according to authorities.

title: SUNDAY CHURCH MEANS SUNDAY BEST
description: ON summer Sundays, it sometimes seems that the uniform of the city's population consists entirely of jeans, shorts and T-shirts. But there is an older, more formal, more gentle tradition that late risers might suspect had vanished - that of dressing up in one's best for church services.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Mixed-Use on Rittenhouse Sq.
description: LEAD: AFTER nearly a generation, the saga of one of Philadelphia's premier properties appears to be ending.

title: Dance: By Daniel Stein
description: DANIEL STEIN creates a world that is at once magical and terrifying in ''Inclined to Agree,'' presented on Friday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street. The full-evening mime piece, which will be performed through Aug. 8, opens the 10th anniversary of the workshop's summer Out-of-Towners series. Mr. Stein, based in Paris and Milwaukee, here pays a return visit to the series. It is hard to think of a better way to celebrate the anniversary.

title:
ART;
OCEANVILLE: SHEDDING A BIT OF LIGHT ON LIGHT ITSELF
description: LEAD: ''STALKING THE LIGHT'' at the Noyes Museum here is a lightweight exhibition, but this is not a defect.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Mixed-Use on Rittenhouse Sq.
description: LEAD: AFTER nearly a generation, the saga of one of Philadelphia's premier properties appears to be ending.

title: More Violence In South Africa
description: Eric Mxolise Mntonga, a senior official of an anti-apartheid group that sponsored a recent discussion between white South Africans and leaders of the outlawed African National Congress, was found dead in his car last Sunday, bludgeoned and stabbed. Alec Boraine, director of the same group, called the murder a ''political execution.''

title: Video Head Cleaners Clean Up Their Act
description: THE HOARY ADAGE about cleanliness being next to godliness holds true for video. Plain dust, along with particles of cigarette smoke, cat and dog sheddings and other airborne household debris, take their toll of VCR's.

title: DELI DOLDRUMS
description: BECAUSE I live in Brookhaven Town, my life is filled with fresh air, trees and delicatessens. I suffer no commuter stress because I live only six miles and two traffic lights away from my job, with no rush-hour jams if I avoid Nesconset Highway and travel the slightly longer scenic North Country Road route.

title: CHESS WHEN A TOUGH METHOD OF DEFENSE IS NECESSARY
description: ONE of the measures of the quality of a defense is the extremity of some of the methods used to combat it.

title: Serious Theater Is The Cause Celebre At a 40-Year-Old Summer Festival
description: THERE WAS A QUIZ on French radio the other day, and the question asked of one contestant was whether the Avignon Festival, France's annual carnival of theater, was celebrating its 100th anniversary this year or its 40th. The contestant responded, incorrectly, that it was the 100th anniversary, provoking the radio announcer to a howl of outrage. ''How could you not have known that it's the 40th anniversary,'' he groaned. ''All of France has been talking of nothing but that.''

title: VOICES FROM THE BARBIE TRIAL
description: IT WAS LESS A CRIMINAL TRIAL in the usual sense than a morality play in which Everyman meets the Devil and survives. For once, the Devil did not have the best lines.

title: Books in Britain
description: To the Editor: The article on antiquarian booksellers in London (Travel, June 21) reminded me that many booklovers have extended the experience of browsing through bookstores in the United Kingdom by purchasing the Sheppard Press publication: ''A Directory of Dealers in Second-Hand and Antiquarian Books in the British Isles,'' which costs about $15 and can be purchased by mail or phone from Hatchards in London, Blackwell's in Oxford and most booksellers in England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales.

title: Business Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: Partisan Blasts, Private Deals On Capitol Hill
description: In Congress, it was a week of public partisanship and behind-the-scenes compromise, both with an eye to next year's elections.

title: LOUISA PARKINSON IS MARRIED ON L.I. TO ROBERT EVANS
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Louisa Dyer Parkinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dexter Parkinson of Laurel Hollow, L.I., to Robert Dow Evans, the son of Mrs. E. Cuyler Hammond of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Paul G. Evans of West Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: SUSAN RIORDAN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. George N. Riordan of San Marino, Calif., and Quogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Milligan Riordan, to Donald Christopher Lisowy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Lisowy of Little Ferry, N.J. An August wedding is planned. Miss Riordan is an architect with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in New York. Mr. Lisowy is a member of the education department of the New York Zoological Society.

title: Finance Ministry Is Staying Put in the Louvre
description: Always attentive to changes in the center of their capital city, the French have been observing virtually inch by inch the rise of a great glass pyramid in the vast courtyard of the Louvre.

title: NEW AWARDS SET ARTS COUNCIL MARK
description: LEAD: THE State Council on the Arts has announced fiscal 1988 awards totaling $16.4 million, the largest such dispersement in its history.

title: . . .And Now for Outside Tests
description: NEXT spring, several hundred currently unsuspecting seniors at 18 colleges scattered across the nation will take an extra set of final examinations, created and administered by professors they have never seen before.

title: HONORING WILLIAM FAULKNER
description: American novelist and short story writer William Faulkner will be honored tomorrow with the release of a 22-cent United States commemorative in his hometown of Oxford, Miss. The stamp, which is part of the Literary Arts series, will go on sale at local post offices this Tuesday (Aug. 4).

title: A LIST OF THE BEST
description: Following is a list of college textbooks that are considered classics in their fields. Sales figures were provided by publishers. Titles are listed in order of copyright dates. Engineering Drawing and Graphic Technology, by Thomas E. French. 13 editions. Published by McGraw-Hill in 1911 as ''A Manual of Engineering Drawing for Students and Draftsmen.''

title: Maine Man Survives Copter
description: A sailor who survived a helicopter crash three years ago was among the five crewmen rescued after a chopper crashed Thursday while trying to land on a Navy ship in the Persian Gulf, his mother said here today. Rosemary Winslow said she had been told that her 27-year-old son, Robert, was one of the crewmen rescued and that he was doing well. ''This is his second time in the drink,'' Mrs. Winslow said. ''How many lives do you have?''

title: JAMIE HEANEY, COPYWRITER, MARRIED TO MARK STEVENS
description: Jamie Marie Heaney, the daughter of Bernard J. Heaney of New York and the late Mary E. Heaney, was married yesterday to Mark Stevens, a son of Mrs. George M. Stevens of Quogue, L.I., and the late Mr. Stevens. Msgr. William J. McMahon officiated at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Uneasy West Germans: Yearnings Despite Plenty
description: On the prosperous side of a sundered Germany, in a nation that still lowers its voice because of the Nazi crimes, that is reluctant to translate its economic might into political clout and that is geographically and psychologically vulnerable to blandishments from the Communist East, a search for an acceptable homeland goes on.

title: HEART CENTER RETHINKS PLANS
description: ST. FRANCIS HOSPITAL, Long Island's only state-designated heart center, is reconsidering a major building project that includes a new wing and a multilevel parking garage. Neighbors in the Village of Flower Hill, which borders portions of Manhasset, Roslyn and Port Washington, objected and retained a lawyer to fight the expansion as planned.

title: MOVIES
description: Destry Rides Again With James Stewart, Marlene Dietrich, Brian Donlevy, Una Merkel, Charles Winninger, Mischa Auer, Irene Hervey, Billy Gilbert and Jack Carson. Produced by Joe Pasternak. Directed by George Marshall. 1939. MCA Home Video 94 minutes. $29.95.

title: RECORDINGS: ROUNDUP OF NOTABLE RECENT RELEASES
description: Falla: El corregidor y la molinera. Seven Popular Spanish Songs. Teresa Berganza, mezzo-soprano; Lausanne Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Jesus Lopez-Cobos, Juan Antonio Alvarez-Parejo, piano (in songs). Claves CD 50-8405. De Falla: The Three-Cornered Hat (Complete). Homenajes. Interlude and Dance from La vida breve. Florence Quivar, mezzo-soprano; Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra conducted by Jesus Lopez-Cobos. Telarc CD-80149.

title: WILL TAYLOR'S DRUG STORY HURT THE GIANTS?
description: Lawrence Taylor's actions and arrogance will affect the next Giant season negatively, but, more important, his drug story will cause tremendous damage to the lives of untold numbers of young people.

title: A Guessing Game: Giuliani's Future
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, who has spearheaded the investigations of the New York City corruption scandals, may signal soon whether he will become a candidate for elective office.

title: Haitian Soldiers Shoot Protesters
description: The election of a civilian Government, tentatively scheduled for Nov. 27, is supposed to mark the beginning of democracy in Haiti. But the bitter residue of resentment and anger after two generations of Duvalier dictatorship has lately threatened to explode in the streets before it can be expressed at the polls.

title: 35-STORE SHOPPING MALL IS MAJOR RETAIL ADDITION FOR YONKERS
description: A 250,000-square-foot shopping mall opened yesterday in Yonkers, nestled between the 30-year-old Cross County Shopping Center that surrounds it on three sides and Central Park Avenue on the fourth.

title: Syria Shields Swiss in Beirut
description: Syrian soldiers were deployed around the Swiss Embassy in West Beirut today to reinforce security after telephoned threats. Callers link the threats to the arrest of a Lebanese Shiite Moslem who hijacked an Air Afrique airliner July 24 in Geneva and was seized by the Swiss police.

title: As Tensions Grow in Divorce Proceedings, Attacks on Court Officers Mount
description: Eruptions of violence in divorce, alimony and child custody cases are leading family courts to increase security and try other measures to defuse the tensions of proceedings packed with the explosive emotions of a marriage breaking apart.

title: Justices on the Constitution: What Children Should Know
description: For the Justices of the Supreme Court, the Constitution, now in its 200th year, is a working document, subject to daily interpretation. The New York Times asked each what they thought children, America's youngest citizens, should know about the Constitution by the time they finished high school. Responding, Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Byron R. White, William J. Brennan Jr. and Harry A. Blackmun wrote as follows: SANDRA DAY O'CONNOR

title: THE PRIVATE GREENING OF CENTRAL PARK
description: WITH negotiations in progress after a years-long hunt for a concessionaire to rebuild Central Park's 110th Street Boathouse, the park these days wears a celebratory air.

title: KARIN KISTER WED TO C. L. HOWARD
description: The wedding of Karin Kister, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sven J. Kister of Palisades, N.Y., to Christopher Lippitt Howard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Harris Howard 3d of Providence, R.I., took place there yesterday. The Rev. Daniel Burke performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. Martin's Episcopal Church.

title: Lilco Basks In Warm Praise For Hot Spell
description: LEAD: THE success of the Long Island Lighting Company in meeting record electric demand during days of sweltering weather last month without plant breakdowns or power reductions has earned the company a measure of praise from even some of its strongest critics.

title: Iran-Contra Hearings Leave Fundamental Issues Unexamined; A Positive Step
description: To the Editor:

title: JEAN HESSELMAN ENGAGED TO MARRY DR. JAKOB BOHR
description: The engagement of Dorothy Jean Hesselman to Dr. Jakob Bohr, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest David Bohr of Copenhagen, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leo W. Hesselman Jr. of Sea Cliff, L.I. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned.

title: FREE CONCERTS OFFER BROAD VARIETY
description: THE roster of free county concerts continues to grow, so whether your musical tastes run to chamber music, show tunes or jazz, listening can become a family affair without any strains on the budget. In the case of the ''Listen 'n' Lunch'' series, a bit of living history is also involved, because the recitals are given on the grounds of the Bill of Rights Museum in Eastchester. The museum itself can be visited before or after the music.

title: Mob-Style Killing Of Traffic Judge
description: IT was described as a gangland type of slaying - five fast shots that pierced the head and body of George M. Aronwald on March 20 in a laundry shop in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Special Draft Argued
description: SINCE he lost his collegiate eligibility by signing a representation agreement with a sports agent and accepting money in the deal, Cris Carter, the Ohio State receiver, has indicated that he may ask for a special supplemental draft so he can join the National Football League a year early. Among those who think that would be a bad idea is Bo Schembechler, the coach of rival Michigan. ''I hope the N.F.L. doesn't open a can of worms by holding a special draft in that line,'' Schembechler said at a Big Ten coaches meeting in Chicago.

title: India Gets a Beachhead in Sri Lanka
