description: WITH bitter humor, one Sri Lankan family has pasted to a living room wall a portrait of the Indian Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi. ''Our leader,'' the host tells a visitor, with an uncomfortable smile. The scene tells more about Sri Lankan attitudes than political realities.

title: McEnroe Fails As Ambassador
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DANNY'S DAYDREAMS
description: THE SECRET LIFE OF WALTER MITTY With Danny Kaye, Virgina Mayo, Boris Karloff and Fay Bainter, 1947. Embassy Home Entertainment. 110 minutes. $19,95.

title: PARAGUAY RIVALS BATTLE AT PARLEY
description: Rival factions of the ruling Colorado Party began fighting today on the first day of its convention, with a group calling itself the militants apparently gaining the upper hand.

title: Navy Planes to Test Anticollision System That Could Affect Airlines
description: In a decision that could have important implications for civilian aviation, the Navy has ordered flight tests of a new anticollision system for training planes.

title: Curbing Funds for Abortion Advice
description: Throughout his Administration, President Reagan has made it clear that he believes abortion is wrong. While members of the anti-abortion movement have been heartened to have an ally in the White House, they have been frustrated that there is still no ''Human Life Amendment'' extending Constitutional protection to the unborn.

title: SHE TOOK THE AIDS TEST
description: Although Dena Kleiman's article, ''She Took the Aids Test'' (July 5), was an interesting piece of reporting, it left me cold and disheartened. Is passing the AIDS test yet another commodity to flaunt - along with a co-op on the West Side and a house in the Hamptons? That Ms. Kleiman views AIDS as a problem of the individual and not as a crisis of the community is sad but not surprising.

title: Circus Camp Lures Vermont Youths
description: When Nicholas Ponzio applied to summer camp, he received a list of things to pack: rugged clothes and poncho, insect repellent, bathing suit, clown costume and juggling balls. For good measure, Nicholas packed his unicycle, too. No need to worry about red bulbous noses, spinning plates and juggling clubs, however. Those were supplied by the camp.

title: Rialto Screams
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowie Creates a Spectacle
description: ''ROCK HAS BEEN SO ASSIMI-lated in the culture now that it doesn't have the kind of muscle it used to have,''

title: WHITE KNIGHT, GREEN VILLIANS
description: PATRIOT GAMES By Tom Clancy. 540 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: A Perfect Match
description: To the Editor:

title: In Today's Issue: Education Life
description: Part 2 of The Times Magazine today is Education Life, including these special reports:

title: Foster Care Woes in Baltimore
description: Serious deficiencies in the foster care system here are exposing children to the risk of permanent damage, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: CHILDREN
description: Too Smart for Strangers With Winnie the Pooh. Walt Disney Home Video. 40 minutes. $29.95.

title: TWO LUNCHES FEATURING FRESH PRODUCE
description: SOMETIMES the idea is not to be original or creative in the kitchen, but merely to be expedient and to satisfy. The goal is easier to accomplish in summer, when fresh produce is at its peak and the hot weather requires bright refreshment instead of hearty sustenance.

title: For Italy's Sake
description: Call it politics Italian style. After months of squabbling, during which Italy functioned without the benefit of a fully constituted government, the five parties that have ruled the country since 1981 agreed last week to go along with a new coalition government led by Giovanni Goria, a Christian Democrat, as Prime Minister. Mr. Goria, a 44-year-old economist who has served as Treasury Minister for five years, is the country's youngest Prime Minister in the postwar era. The coalition partners agreed on a broad outline of policy goals that did not differ significantly from the programs pursued by former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, a Socialist whose resignation in March precipitated the political crisis.

title: The Push For Smarter Schoolbooks
description: CALIFORNIA'S 11-member State Board of Education sent a shock wave through the textbook publishing industry last fall by rejecting every mathematics textbook submitted by some 14 publishing houses. The publishers, who were out millions of dollars, accused Louis (Bill) Honig, the state Superintendent of Public Instruction, of political grandstanding. He in turn accused them of trying to fob off warmed-over texts from other states instead of developing ones that met California's tough new math curriculum standards.

title: NEW LYNDHURST DIRECTOR
description: Following a three-month nationwide search, Lyndhurst, the national trust property in Tarrytown, has named a new property director. Taking the new position is Susanne Brendel-Pandich, the former curator and manager of the Biltmore House, in Ashville, N.C., which is considered the largest private house in the country.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DRAMA
description: LEAD: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court Starring Richard Basehart, Roscoe Lee Browne, Paul Rudd. Color. MasterVision. 60 minutes. $64.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE BANKER'S LIFE. By George S. Moore. (Norton, $19.95.) A banker for 60 years and the retired chairman of what is now known as Citibank, George S. Moore presents a unique perspective on the nation's banking system. His career began in 1927 and, although he retired from Citibank in 1970, he remains active as a consultant.

title: WHERE IS YURI GRIGOROVICH LEADING THE BOLSHOI?
description: DISPLAYING ITS CHARACTERIS-tic sense of commitment, the Bolshoi Ballet excited audiences in New York with sheer dance power generated by young newcomers. ''They're different,'' says Natalya Bessmertnova - the senior ballerina on the current American tour -during an interview in a BBC-TV documentary that was broadcast in the United States this spring. ''They 'feel' the world differently,'' she says, adding graciously, ''Our future lies with them. They will take our ballet forward.''

title: Ayckbourn in Texas
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran-Contra Hearings Leave Fundamental Issues Unexamined
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL TAYLOR'S DRUG STORY HURT THE GIANTS?
description: No is the answer to the question for three reasons: 1. Coach Bill Parcells is too dominant a force and a master motivator to let this happen. 2. L. T., barring injury, will be with the team right from the start, unlike Dwight Gooden, whose enforced hiatus for more than a month contributed mightily to the Mets' mediocre early-season record. 3. When the game's premier linebacker shows he hasn't lost his disposition to savage opposing quarterbacks, there is no way his teammates won't respond with the same intensity that won them the championship last season.

title: LEITH ANN COLTON TO MARRY WALTER DERISH IN OCTOBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Colton of Hartsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leith Ann Colton to Walter Scott Derish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Derish of Babylon, L.I. The couple plan to marry Oct. 4.

title: U.S. Rejects Iranian Charges of Complicity in Riot
description: The State Department issued a statement today that said Iran had sought to use the violence in Mecca as part of a continuing effort to destabilize the region for political purposes.

title: Denver Takes Title, First in Arena League
description: Whit Taylor passed for four touchdowns, including three to Gary Mullen, as the Denver Dynamite defeated the Pittsburgh Gladiators, 45-16, to win the first Arena Football League championship tonight. The game drew a crowd of 13,232 to the 15,089-seat Civic Arena.

title: A High-Stakes Dream
description: ''THIS IS A VERY EXPENSIVE colt,'' says Woody Stephens of Look To The Top, the 2-year-old he's training now at Belmont Park in New York, and with whom he hopes to win racing's Triple Crown next spring. ''So you're trying to give him every chance in the world to be a good horse.''

title: Don't Forget Ace Parker
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A. C. KLEIN WED TO NICKI KALISH
description: The marriage of Nita Jane Kalish, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Kalish of New York and Remsenburg, L.I., to Allen Chapman Klein, the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Elmer Klein, took place yesterday at the Westhampton Yacht Squadron in Remsenburg. Judge Bruce Kaplan of the Family Court in Manhattan officiated at the ceremony.

title: Report on Senator Sets Off an Uproar
description: The Republican Senate campaign committee routinely sends research on Democratic Senators to their prospective opponents. But the 72-page report that it sent to two Ohio Republicans was far from routine.

title: Holograms: Popping Up All Over
description: LEAD: FOR years, the International Banknote Company, a financial printer in New York, has been grinding out stock and bond certificates, stamps and foreign currency. Now it believes that the technology of holography can make more money for its shareholders than its traditional products, and the company has invested its future in holograms - three-dimensional images created by laser technology.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article about textbooks in some copies of Education Life, section 12 of today's paper, include a garbled sentence on page 20. The sentence should read: ''Virginia's state board of education was shocked two years ago to find texts in which the word 'inalienable' was deleted from the Declaration of Independence because it was deemed too hard for students.''

title: LIEUT. JENNIFER SPERRY WED TO FELLOW OFFICER
description: Second Lieut. Jennifer Kay Sperry, U.S.A.F., a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger P. Sperry of Bedford, Tex., and First Lieut. Robert C. Dooley, U.S.A.F., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Dooley of Mountainside, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford. The ceremony was performed by the Revs. Joseph Schumacher, Roger Pierre and Edward Wilert.

title: HIGH-TECH NAVY AT RISK IN AN IRANIAN LAKE
description: IN some ways, the hot and shallow waters of the Persian Gulf are coming to resemble, in military minds, the rice paddies and river deltas of Vietnam.

title: A Readiness to Let Poindexter Take the Fall
description: IT was the week of the old bulls - senior figures, past and present, in the Reagan Administration - sitting at the witness table and telling the Iran-contra committees that they had done their best, that they had been deceived, that the whole wretched affair was the fault of John M. Poindexter.

title: AIRPORT NOISE DISPUTE PERSISTS
description: LEAD: CONTROVERSY continues to simmer as to the proper approach that transportation authorities should take in seeking a reduction in the amount of noise generated by jet aircraft using Newark International Airport.

title: ANDREA GOODMAN WED IN MICHIGAN
description: Andrea Eve Goodman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. David Goodman of Delmar, N.Y., and James Harris Hansell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Hansell of Washington, were married last evening at the Campus Inn in Ann Arbor, Mich., by Rabbi Yoel Kahn.

title: Robert Benton Goes Back To Texas for a Little Fun
description: ROBERT BENTON WAS being emphatic about his new film, ''Nadine'' - which is to say that he was speaking calmly, gently, in his self-effacing but mesmerizingly insistent way. '' 'Nadine' is not 'Places in the Heart,' '' he was saying, referring to the 1984 movie that won him a third Academy Award. ''But because 'Nadine' comes after 'Places in the Heart,' and because it's also set in Texas, and because the same director's name is on it - as if people really ever notice such a thing -well, people may be expecting it to be 'Places.' ''

title: POSTINGS: Fourth in Queens; All of a Pattern
description: ''Basically, we follow the same pattern in all our projects,'' explained Stephen Shalom, a Manhattan developer, who with Arthur G. Cohen, also of Manhattan, is spending $3 million to co-op a sagging apartment complex in the Briarwood section of Queens - his fourth conversion in the borough. ''We take a sound, but old building that has not been properly maintained over the years and do a lot of modifications.'' In their current project, Briarwood Gardens, on Burden Crescent at 84th Drive, three identical adjoining six-story buildings, as well as another across the street, are receiving new roofs, plumbing, electrical systems, windows, lobbies and sidewalks. Of the 234 apartments, 63 were bought by existing tenants at a discount, while 118 have remained rent-stabilized for those opting not to buy. Through buyouts, departures and deaths, 53 apartments were vacated and subsequently refurbished and 30 of them - mostly one-bedrooms and a few studios, ranging from 450 to 700 square feet - are on the market for $53,000 to $84,688. Occupancy will begin in September. A small, enclosed park on the three-acre site is being relandscaped for exclusive use by residents.

title: SHOULD IT BE HARDER TO CASH IN ON OUR PUBLIC SERVICE?
description: AS the number of American lobbyists listing themselves with the Justice Department under the Foreign Agent Registration Act has grown, to close to 1,OOO by last year, so has concern that for many high officials and their top aides, service in the United States Government has become no more than a way station for the acquisition of expertise and contacts to put at the disposal of foreign clients.

title: Sports of The Times; The Runs of August
description: IN the National League East, the race began Thursday night when Dwight Gooden started for the Mets against the Cardinals with only three days' rest. He had originally been scheduled to start Friday night in Montreal with his usual four days' rest.

title: ANDERSON ADJUSTS AS RESERVE
description: You can call him Ottis or you can call him O. J. You can ask him for his autograph or ask him if he's anybody when he leaves the practice field. Whatever happens, O. J. Anderson has been in the spotlight and out of the spotlight and he's come to grips with his new role in the supporting cast of the defending Super Bowl champion Giants.

title: We Can Weave a New Safety Net
description: AFTER years of regressive national policies, America's social safety net has come to resemble the contents of Ollie North's shredder.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: An Olympic Bid Nothing New
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lubbock, Tex.;
Channeling Tax Increases
description: LEAD: FACED with a deteriorating downtown business district and a shortage of Federal redevelopment dollars, city officials in this West Texas city are trying a novel approach to that time-honored method of raising money through property taxes.

title: MARIN'S NEGLECTED OILS
description: LEAD: AT one time John Marin (1870-1953) was among our most celebrated painters. His reputation was confirmed by major retrospectives at the Museum of Modern Art in 1936, the Institute of Modern Art, Boston (presented also in Washington and Minneapolis), in 1947, and the Venice Biennale in 1950.

title: Education
description: To the Editor:

title: LIZ CRONIN WEDS MICHAEL D. URBAN IN COLLEGE CHAPEL
description: At St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Chapel at Dartmouth College yesterday Elizabeth Anne Cronin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Cronin of Kennebunk, Me., and Michael David Urban, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Urban of Abingdon, Va., were married. Msgr. William L. Nolan, chaplain emeritus of Aquinas House at Dartmouth, performed the ceremony.

title: THE THIRD WORLD IS SOFTENING ITS VOICE
description: BUFFETED by years of global economic slowdown and adamant rejection from Washington and much of Europe, representatives of the world's poorer countries are quietly jettisoning their harsh rhetoric and most radical demands for aid, trade and third world development. Last weekend, many of their spokesmen took a conciliatory tack at the close of the month-long forum at which the world's rich industrial northern countries hold a dialogue with the poorer southern nations.

title: Real Reform Is Nowhere in Sight
description: SUDDENLY, everyone is talking about a historic national consensus on welfare reform. It all seems too good to be true.

title:
DINING OUT;
Off-the-Taconic Spot in Hawthorne
description: LEAD: NIGHTINGALES' is certainly convenient for hungry travelers on the Taconic Parkway in Hawthorne. This nifty little restaurant offers American food: hefty snacks at the capacious bar or a complete meal in the pretty dining room.

title: U.N. Parley Deadlocked Over Third World Debt
description: A huge United Nations economic conference, attended by most of the world's countries, was deadlocked tonight by a dispute over steps to ease the developing-world's debt burden, now approaching $1 trillion.

title: 'REVOLUTION' SEEN AT TURNING POINT
description: ''THE REVOLUTION of art fabric that began in the late 50's now seems to be at a turning point,'' Jack Lenor Larsen - a renowned textile artist and designer, collector, curator, author and long-term president of the American Crafts Council -speculated recently.

title: DAWKINS MEETING FUND-RAISING TEST
description: WHETHER former Brig.

title: 'WE'RE SPEEDING DOWN A PATH OF DESTRUCTION'
description: RECENTLY, a woman exclaimed: ''Thank God for my microwave oven!''

title: NEW EDITOR AT DIGEST'S CONDENSED BOOKS
description: THE literary cognoscenti may blanch at the thought of making cuts to condense a book, but the facts are that the more than 1.5 million people who buy about 10 million copies of Reader's Digest Condensed Books every year have made the Digest book-publishing program one of the most successful in the country.

title: JOHN MUTCH WED TO SUSAN COENE
description: At the Church of the Nativity in Fair Haven, N.J. Susan Leslie Coene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Theodore Coene of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to John Mutch, a son of Edith Mutch of Bloomfield, N.J., and John Mutch of Middletown, N.J. Jay Harbeck, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: Bad Marriage
description: Margaret Thatcher won applause from free marketeers for selling the state-run British Airways to private shareholders. Now the airline's managers are attempting to defeat the intent of privatization by proposing it merge with British Caledonian, its only serious British-flag rival.

title: BEST SELLERS: AUGUST 2, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles international terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 2 1 6 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 3 2 9 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 4 3 5 WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) BECOMING A DOCTOR, by Melvin Konner. (Elisabeth Sifton/ Viking, $19.95.) To understand them, join them; Mr. (now Dr.) Konner, an anthropologist, went through medical school and produced this engaging account of the long, difficult, sometimes painful initiation that turns ordinary young people into physicians. SARTRE: A Life, by Annie Cohen-Solal. (Pantheon, $24.95.) Published two years ago in France, this modest, industrious biography is full of suggestive detail about Sartre's odd, unhappy life but steers clear of psychological reductionism. SPILLVILLE, by Patricia Hampl. Illustrated by Steven Sorman. (Milkweed, Cloth, $25; Paper, $9.95.) A collection of intelligent meditations, in words and pictures, on the little Iowa town where the composer Anton Dvorak lived for a while in the 1890's. ELLEN TERRY: Player in Her Time, by Nina Auerbach. (Norton, $22.50.) Ms. Auerbach portrays the immensely popular English actress as an angry subversive, paralyzed in her emotional life by the humiliating patriarchy that governed her public existence. ORPHANS: Real and Imaginary, by Eileen Simpson. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $16.95.) The author, a novelist and psychotherapist, joins her own history (orphaned before age 7) to an exploration of the painful fate of orphans in history, literature and the imagination. HEMINGWAY, by Kenneth S. Lynn. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A sympathetic and detailed biography that sees Hemingway as a valiant and moral man and writer of his own time and place, not the macho freak of his posthumous publicity. THE HOTTENTOT ROOM, by Christopher Hope. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.95.) Mr. Hope's protagonist in his passionate third novel is a South African secret agent in London; his thesis is that the world is turning brutal, mad and claustrophobic.

title: Verbatim; Recovering Intent
description: 'Attorney General Meese has expressed the notion that judges, in interpreting the Constitution, should be close to the original intent of those who wrote it. . . . But to try to recover original intent from records that are nonexistent or not faithful to actual proceedings may be an impossible hermeneutic assignment.' James C. Hutson

title: Why College Classics Stay That Way
description: THE AGE OF FLIGHT had just dawned and World War I was still some years in the future when Thomas E. French's ''Engineering Drawing and Graphic Technology'' was published in 1911. But the book is still taught at many colleges and universities. So are at least a dozen other textbooks published in the 1920's and 30's, some of which not only hold their own against the newcomers on the block but actually dominate the field.

title: A Turn-of-the-Century Vestige Threatened on the 'West End'
description: UP to a year ago it looked as if the 1904 Progress Club building, at 88th Street and Central Park West, would survive as the neo-classical base for a 25-story apartment tower. But now, after protests by neighbors and a stalled development plan, a new developer has proposed demolishing it.

title: The Never-Ending Dissertation
description: LEAD: CAROL BRADOF HAS been waking up in the middle of the night, unable to sleep because a project begun 12 years ago remains unfinished. Mrs. Bradof started a Ph.D. program in medieval literature at Columbia University before her first child was born. Now a proud mother of two children, ages 8 and 9, she is a not-so-proud member of an as yet barely acknowledged fraternity of doctoral students known as A.B.D.

title: HOT DOGS AND HAVE A NICE DAY
description: While many more people in the subcontinent speak English regularly than the 2 or 3 percent Steven Weisman indicates, it is clear that it is not the first language of the vast majority. English serves as a bridge across the multitude of India's languages, and it serves very well. The idiosyncrasies of diction and tense he observes are excellent links not only between traditional and modern concepts and cultures but also language structures. In short, they do exactly what bridging languages are supposed to do.

title: A Call to Workable Arms
description: No administration in peacetime has funded defense as generously as has President Reagan's. Yet the performance of the armed services when called to action has too often fallen below the high standards the services expect of themselves. In Lebanon, Grenada, Libya and now the Persian Gulf, the military execution of civilian policy has been flawed by failures of command, training and equipment.

title: MUSIC
description: Andrea Chenier By Umberto Giordano. Sung in Italian with English subtitles. With Jose Carreras, Eva Marton and Piero Cappuccilli. La Scala Opera of Milan, conducted by Riccardo Chailly. 1985. Home Vision. 130 minutes. $39.95.

title: HOT DOGS AND HAVE A NICE DAY
description: As an Indian who has just immigrated to the United States after a four-year stopover in England, I found Steven R. Weisman's article, ''Doing the Needful'' (On Language, July 12), rather amusing.

title: LOSING DECADES WISTFULLY
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL TAYLOR'S DRUG STORY HURT THE GIANTS?
description: Taylor's drug story will do two things: hurt the Giants and help to sell his book. The real question is: Which is more important to Mr. L. T., a ball game or a best seller? HERBERT CONNER New York, N.Y.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Nipping Disease in the Bud

title: 'Star Wars' Report Sees Launching Cost Of Up to $1 Trillion
description: Launching ''Star Wars'' antimissile defenses into orbit could cost as much as $1 trillion, depending on countermeasures taken by the Soviet Union, according to a new Congressional study.

title: U.S.-Escorted Tanker Starts Trip Down Gulf
description: The tanker Gas Prince slipped quietly out of Kuwait today without the mine-damaged supertanker Bridgeton and sailed under United States Navy escort through Persian Gulf waters thought rife with Iranian mines.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
DUSKY SHARK
description: LEAD: Carcharhinus obscurus Size: To 12 feet; averages 10.

title: A Team Is Formed to Fight Bias in New York
description: In an effort to head off racial violence, New York City has formed a new unit to keep a close watch on brewing tension in its neighborhoods.

title: VILLAGE'S NEEDS THREATEN PAST
description: LEAD: PLANS by the Village of Southampton to find new municipal office space have worried some longtime residents, who fear that old structures will be recycled for administrative use without regard to their historical significance. Village officials contend that Southampton, like many other municipalities on the East

title: Home Sales Falter In the Suburbs
description: No one could predict how long the trend might last, or even say for sure that it was a trend, but a look at home buying in New York City's suburbs last week - which should have been the peak of the season - detected a lull. In communities where real-estate prices have more than doubled since 1980, sellers were lowering their prices and still waiting for buyers.

title: TORRIJOS'S LEGACY LINGERS IN PANAMA
description: Six years after Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera died in a mysterious plane crash, his legacy continues to dominate Panamanian politics.

title: Agency to Mark Anniversary
description: Trail Blazers, a New York-based social service agency for disadvantaged children, will celebrate its 100th anniversary at noon tomorrow by erecting a teepee near the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park. At 2 P.M., Mayor Koch is to speak and be declared an honorary Trail Blazer. Formerly known as Life Camps, Trail Blazers each year serves more than 250 disadvantaged children between the ages of 8 and 17 from the New York-New Jersey region. They attend a one-month summer camp in Sussex, N.J., and meet during the rest of the year for weekend educational events.

title: Indian Troops Take Up Positions in Sri Lanka
description: Indian and Sri Lankan troops moved today to take up new positions in separate attempts to quell resistance in the north and south of the country, Sri Lankan officials said.

title: Poll Finds About Half of Judges Think Bork Should Be Confirmed
description: About half of the nation's judges think Judge Robert H. Bork should be confirmed as a Supreme Court Justice, according to a poll.

title: FLOWERING TREES CAN GLADDEN SUMMER
description: WHETHER grown in the front yard, a secluded patio garden or in a container on a roof terrace, a small flowering tree can be a superb addition to the landscape.

title: CRULLERS, FOLLOWED BY TRAGEDY
description: LEAD: THE IDEAL BAKERY By Donald Hall. 138 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $14.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Fending Off Summertime Diseases
description: LEAD: THE arrival of hot midsummer brings with it certain predictable problems for gardeners. Knowing what to look for, along with close observation, can help identify and treat some of those problems.

title: Social Security Reduces The Budget Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: YEAR ONE: A Record. By John Tittensor. (Penguin, Paper, $4.95.) Part diary entries and part narrative, this brief, sad book is the record of the first year of John Tittensor's grief following the accidental death of his two children. On June 9, 1982, the house where Mr. Tittensor's estranged wife lived with his children, Emmy and Jonathan, ages 7 and 9, burned down.

title: Live, From Tin Pan Alley: Rock on Cue
description: ANYONE WHO WATCHES the ''Late Night With David Letterman'' television show with any regularity - live, a RE-run (as Mr. Letterman chooses to accent it) or, as recently, impaired by a technicians' strike - must be impressed by the show's house band. True, the personality of its leader, Paul Schaffer, as created or reinforced by Mr. Letterman and the writers, is a peculiar piece of work, a sort of hip nerd. But Mr. Schaffer's skills as a keyboard player and band leader are never in doubt.

title: Q and A
description: Tax on a Swapped Co-op Question: My husband and I would like to swap our co-op apartment for a residence in Italy for about six months beginning next May. We plan to sell it shortly after we return. However, we are concerned that this swap might be construed as a sublet for the purpose of the 1 percent New York City real-estate transfer tax. Would we be liable for the tax even if no money changed hands during the exchange? . . . N. G., the Bronx Answer: You may be. A year ago the city expanded the rules for transfer tax on the sale of residences to include co-ops whose owners had, in the two years preceding a sale, sublet them or used part of them as home offices.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: New Sunglass Varieties Offered by Opti-Tint Opti-Tint has provided services to manufacturers of quality optical lenses for five years in the county and now in Mamaroneck has added a designer and fashion-frame sunglass outlet at the factory during the week and half a day Saturday. Varieties include solid-colored lenses, gradiant shadings and polarized and mirror coatings primarily on plastic lenses with metal or plastic frames.

title: MISTAKEN IN THE SHORT TERM
description: FORMATIVE WRITINGS #1929-1941. By Simone Weil. Edited and translated by Dorothy Tuck McFarland and Wilhelmina Van Ness. 289 pp. Amherst: The University of Massachusetts Press. $30.

title: When TV Takes on the Role of Moral Guardian
description: LAST WEEK, CBS RAN A SERIES OF public-service messages in prime time. Entertainment and sports stars warned us to ''stop the madness'' on drugs, ''just say no'' to alcohol and also seek guidance on AIDS. An increasing number of dramas and even comedy series is saying much the same. On television, it is a time to think about substance abuse and the need to wear a condom. Soon to come, apparently, will be messages about seat belts; at the request of the television industry, a coalition of prominent writers, producers and directors will tell us to buckle up. Applaud all the good intentions at work here, but remember which road it is that good intentions pave. When television embraces a public morality or advocates rules of behavior, we ought to be just a shade disturbed.

title: LYME DISEASE PANEL EXAMINES RESEARCH
description: LEAD: AS Lyme disease continues to spread in the county, medical experts and researchers are struggling to understand how to combat the tick-borne illness.

title: SHE TOOK THE AIDS TEST
description: In recent weeks, the news media has been bombarding us with ''fear of AIDS'' articles, written from the perspective of people in the lowest risk groups. Now The New York Times Magazine joins the chorus with ''She Took the AIDS Test.''

title: MASERATI BITURBO: ECONOMICAL SPEED
description: OVER the years, I have been lucky enough to have driven most of the cars there are. Weird things like Lancia Zagatos, the Thomas Flyer that won the New York-to-Paris race in 1908. Morris Minors whose valves I burned with mega-octane aviation fuel in a far time and a long-ago place. Studebakers and Hudsons.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: AUGUST 2, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 2 3 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 3 5 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 4 2 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $5.95.) Four hundred years of history in fictional form. 5 6 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 6 4 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Pocket, $4.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 7 6 MURDER IN GEORGETOWN, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.50.) The mystery surrounding the death of a senator's daughter. 8 9 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $4.95.) An American submarine's pursuit of Russian underwater nuclear weaponry. 14 4 NOBODY LIVES FOREVER, by John Gardner. (Charter, $3.95.) James Bond on the trail of the kidnapper of his devoted housekeeper. 15 15 THE WITCHES OF EASTWICK, by John Updike. (Fawcett, $4.50.) Three women and a devilish stranger concoct a curse that haunts a small New England town. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 6 MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle Barrows with William Novak. Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them in order to grow. 4 14 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star and father of five. 5 39 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's experiences flying in East Africa and across the Atlantic in the 1930's. 6 10 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. (Berkley, $4.50.) Television journalism as experienced by a veteran correspondent. 7 14 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 3 8 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $4.50.) How to cope with overbearing men. 4 16 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 5 28 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) The 1987 edition. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 2, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21 More than 400 Moslems died when clashes erupted Friday in Mecca, Islam's holiest site, Saudi Arabia announced. Upon hearing reports of the deaths, Iranian mobs stormed the Saudi and Kuwaiti embassies in Teheran. Page 1

title: Comings and Goings
description: HE had been expected to make a comeback in the Coors International Bicycle Classic, which begins Wednesday, but Greg LeMond, a two-time Coors winner who missed the recent Tour de France after being wounded in a shooting accident in April, had to withdraw from the Coors race because of a recent appendectomy. . . Leroy Irvin, the Los Angeles Rams' cornerback who had been boycotting training camp because of dissatisfaction with his contract, finally showed up yesterday. . . Thomas Rooks, the former Illinois running back who set a school career rushing record before being drafted by the Vikings last year, was one of 14 free agents cut by the Cardinals. . . . Jim Copeland Jr., a former Virginia football player, was named the school's athletic director, replacing Dick Schultz, who left to take over as executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: CHICAGO BEARS, UNHAPPY HEIRS, AND A STOCK DISPUTE
description: LEAD: WHEN the Chicago Bears won the Super Bowl two years ago, members of the majority shareholding McCaskey family gathered in the locker room to congratulate the players and coaches. It was the first championship that the descendants of the Bears' founder, George S. Halas Sr., engineered since assuming control of the team in 1983.

title: Philadelphia's Capital Crafts
description: WHILE THE NA-tion's statesmen and politicians drafted the Constitution here 200 years ago, Philadelphia's cabinetmakers and silversmiths were hard at work providing sophisticated furnishings for these and other dynamic personalities who lived and worked in the first capital of the young Republic.

title: JET DEFENSIVE LINE STARTS IN A RUSH
description: It was almost dreamlike: The Jets unveiled a pass rush today along with an impressive-looking outside linebacker.

title: Help for Schools - With Strings
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation last week offered the New York City Board of Education $600 million to help build new schools -on condition that the board undergo a little remedial training.

title: Teachers Are Trained to Use Arts as Bridge to Other Areas
description: WHAT better time than summer for teachers to become students?

title: POSTINGS: Cedar-Sided Condos; Entering A Market
description: Even the developer of the tallest office tower in Paris, a World Trade Center in Miami and a hotel in Moscow exercises a bit of restraint when attempting a new kind of construction. In the Fairways in Teaneck, N.J. - his first town-house project in the United States - Jacques Teze decided to start off small, with 28 condominiums on four acres.

title: Tigers Unnerve Yankees
description: The afternoon had already begun to drag when Charles Hudson stepped to the mound in the seventh inning at Yankee Stadium yesterday. The sun was finally poking through the haze, but the Yankees were losing and the crowd of 55,103 had grown disinterested.

title: HOW BEAUTIFUL WAS ALICE?
description: To the Editor:

title: In-Home Help: Matching Needs
description: LEAD: AFTER Joanne Kobar launched her business, TGIF, in 1982, she realized that ''I had done what every entrepreneur should do first: find out what there is a market for.''

title: A Step Toward The Summit and A Missile Accord
description: The Reagan Administration has been pushing to complete an agreement on arms control in time for the President to meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and sign it this winter. Last week, Mr. Reagan said he was ''heartened'' by the prospects.

title: DANCE
description: An Evening with the Bolshoi Recorded live at Battersea Park, London. Home Vision. 117 minutes. $39.95. The Golden Age Home Vision. 112 minutes. $39.95.

title: Rubbermaid
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Space for 16 Galleries; SoHo Spruce-Up
description: As art galleries continue their exodus from the East Village into SoHo, where space is generally more affordable, developers are busy sprucing up old manufacturing buildings.

title: Steering Clear Of Street Scams
description: In June the Florence area jewelers' guild sent a letter to the United States Consul General in that city deploring operations in which guides steer tourist groups into shops offering only overpriced wares. The English translation provided by the Florentine artisans was not perfect, but the import was clear:

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has published its long-awaited proposed regulations for controlling a major source of smog: evaporated gasoline emissions from automobiles.

title: City's Economy Seen Booming
description: On the heels of some good economic news last week - employment in New York City surged to a 16-year high - Mayor Koch signed a series of bills designed to keep the good news coming.

title: THANK YOU, COLONEL NORTH, FOR THE 'OLLIE'
description: THE Oliver L. North craze that has swept the country has swept me along with it in a way you will never believe.

title: WILY DIRECTOR OF EXPO TURNAROUND
description: Something has come between the Mets and the St. Louis Cardinals in their bruising battle in the National League East: Buck Rodgers and the Montreal Expos.

title: ANDREA BAUMANN ENGAGED TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philippe E. Baumann of New York and Clinton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Raymond Baumann to Ivan Laurence Lustig, a son of Barbara L. Lustig of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, and the late Neil M. Lustig. A September wedding is planned. Miss Baumann, an associate with Booz, Allen & Hamilton, management consultants in New York, graduated from the Institut Le Rosey in Rolle, Switzerland, and Princeton University, where she received a joint bachelor's and master's degree from the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. She also received a master's degree in public and private management from Yale University. Her father is the executive vice president of Stralem & Company, investment advisers in New York.

title:
GARDENING;
FENDING OFF SUMMERTIME DISEASES
description: LEAD: THE arrival of hot midsummer brings with it certain predictable problems for gardeners. Knowing what to look for, along with close observation, can help identify and treat some of those problems.

title: JONATHAN FISK MANDEVILLE IS MARRIED TO ANNE TIFFANY ROBBINS, A DESIGNER
description: Anne Tiffany Robbins, a daughter of Mr.and Mrs. Walter spalding Robbins of Fairfield, Conn. and Onancock, Va., and Jonathan Fisk Mandeville,a son of Ann Adams Mandeville of Fairfield and Robert Turner Mandeville of New York were married yesterday.

title: EMBASSIES SMASHED IN TEHERAN
description: More than 400 Moslems died when clashes broke out Friday between Iranian Shiite Moslem pilgrims and Saudi riot policemen in Mecca, Islam's holiest site, Saudi Arabia announced Saturday.

title: THE SUNSHINE GIRL, THE SILENCED DAUGHTER
description: WHEN my mother died last summer, she left me a new life. I try to wear it well (in good health, as she would say) because the old one wore me down - weighing heavily as space and time on my spine.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE NEW-PARENT BUSINESS;
The All-New Rock-a-Bye Baby
description: LEAD: CHILDREN'S music is a tiny part of the recording business, accounting for less than 3 percent of its $4.6 billion in revenues. But this is one baby in the midst of a growth spurt, industry spokesmen say.

title: Summer Serves Up Its Sleepers
description: THIS SUMMER'S TWO MAIN SLEEPERS TURN out to be ''Robocop,'' which has already attracted a sizable action audience, and ''La Bamba,'' which should draw a smaller but no less attentive music-loving crowd. On the surface, a violent, futuristic police fantasy and a sweetly nostalgic rock-and-roll biography would appear to have nothing in common, but in a way these films have similar appeal. Each offers slight but distinct variations on a formula that is comfortingly familiar. Each creates its own little universe, a world that is enveloping and complete.

title: LIABILITY FEARS, INSURANCE COSTS CHALLENGE DAY CAMPS
description: LEAD: AT the Pierce Day Camp in Roslyn, the trampolines have been stashed away in a garage, and fire extinguishers and smoke detectors installed in camp buildings. At Twin Oaks in Freeport, a wooden playground area (with rope ladders and sand underneath) replaces steel climbing bars and a carousel.

title: SOCCER CAREER HIS GOAL
description: WITH the demise of professional soccer in North America, Michael Savarese Jr. of this Middlesex County community will have to realize his dream overseas.

title: LISA SEARL VETTER WED TO JULES KORTENHORST
description: Lisa Searl Vetter and Jules T.H.M. Kortenhorst were married yesterday at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence, R.I., by the Rev. Daniel Burke. Holly Becker was the maid of honor. Sandro Van Hellenberg Hubar was best man.

title: METS' TURN TO ROMP AS LEACH GOES 9-0
description: The Mets, who were decked by 13-3 in the opening game of their series here, cast aside their red faces tonight, rebounded with a vengeance and decked the Montreal Expos, 12-4.

title: The Ring of Untruth
description: TRUTH FLOATS. PEOPLE'S literal words rise or fall in a sea of unconscious intent and body language. Consider this summer's Iran-contra hearings. Only one American in three thinks President Reagan has been telling the truth about aid to the contras. By contrast, uniformed Oliver L. North, firm and facile in the witness chair, persuaded three-quarters of the public that he's telling the truth.

title: UNIVERSITY TO REPLY TO FINDINGS ON BIAS
description: LEAD: THE affirmative-action plan of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has ''major deficiencies in design, communication and implementation'' and should be totally overhauled, according to a controversial report released at the university's campus here last month.

title: DEVELOPERS GAIN D.E.P. SUPPORT IN PIER DISPUTE
description: LEAD: THE latest skirmish in the war between environmental groups and developers is taking place along the Hudson River waterfront, where developers want to erect high-rise buildings on piers.

title: 18 Reported Injured in Violence on Rikers Island
description: Eleven guards and seven prisoners were injured in a flare-up of violence at a solitary-confinement section of Rikers Island last weekend, a New York City Department of Correction spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: A Shorter Leash for Pit Bulls
description: Are pit bull terriers so dangerous they should be banned? Alarmed by horrifying accounts of pit bull attacks, local governments including New York City's are considering restrictive laws. While all-out bans are difficult to enforce, there is ample reason to discourage pit bull ownership.

title: IN THE CHASE, PROTECTIONIST URGES ARISE
description: SO far, the race to make superconductivity a force that could reshape everyday life has known few national boundaries. The major discoveries have been shared by scientists in the United States, Japan and Europe, and barely a day goes by when researchers fail to keep tabs on their overseas competitors.

title: Canada Tornado Death Toll 27; Search Goes On
description: Hundreds of rescue workers dug through mounds of twisted rubble at a trailer park and an industrial area today that had been devastated by tornadoes that killed at least 27 people and injured more than 200.

title: MOVIES
description: A Sunday in the Country Starring Louis Ducreux, Sabine Azema, Michel Aumont. Directed by Bertrand Tavernier. 1984. MGM/UA Home Video. 95 minutes. $79.95.

title: Honoring the Classics of Jazz
description: ''Classical Jazz at Lincoln Center,'' a series of three concerts that is taking place tonight through Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall, finds Lincoln Center paying tribute to women in jazz and to two other outstanding composers and players, Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker. Lincoln Center has been the site of many jazz concerts but never sponsored a jazz event until this week.

title: PANNILL KNITTING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NANOMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CUMBERLAND FEDERAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $260,000. c-After tax credits of $1,603,000 for the quarter and $2,666,000 for the 6 months. The latest periods' nets include an after-tax writeoff of $696,000 in connection with the Federal Savings & Loan Insurance Corp.'s secondary reserve. The year-ago periods are pro forma. The company went public in May 1987.

title: FIRST MUTUAL SAVINGS ASSN OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Confirmed Nondrivers: Resisting the Open Road
description: Some of them never had that urge to get behind the wheel of a car that overcomes teen-agers. They did not count the days till they became eligible for a learner's permit, and later as they progressed from school to work and through adulthood, they felt no lure of the open road or, for that matter, of the crowded one. They are the nondrivers of the country, and they constitute a sizable minority.

title: Boxing; Tyson Crowned Amid Trumpet Fanfare
description: Earlier on Saturday evening, Chuck Hull, dressed in a tuxedo, stood at center ring and pronounced Mike Tyson as the undisputed world heavyweight champion after Tyson hammered out a 12-round decision over Tony Tucker.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 3, 1987
description: International A2-8

title: REFEREES WHO CALL THE SHOTS AFLOAT
description: The first tremors of an upheaval in yachting shook the sport almost imperceptibly in June when officials tested a new system that would settle a racing dispute on the water instead of the usual way, in a protest room hours after the race is finished.

title: NORTH AMERICAN COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Panama Says Dissident Withdrew His Charges
description: The retired colonel who plunged Panama into turmoil two months ago with accusations that the military high command was guilty of corruption and political murder has reportedly withdrawn the charges.

title: Investors Fear New Inflation
description: The outlook for inflation has re-emerged as a crucial issue in the credit markets, as investors worry that recent increases in consumer prices will lead to higher wage settlements and a new cycle of higher costs and more inflation.

title: Federal Phone Plan Is Disputed
description: The bidding for a $4.5 billion contract to build a telephone network for the Federal Government is being threatened by a sharp dispute about the dwindling number of qualified competitors.

title: Advertising; Lewis Galoob Toys To Fallon, McElligott
description: Fallon, McElligott of Minneapolis - the hot one - has become an agency for Lewis Galoob Toys of San Francisco. Billings could be around $8 million. The company also uses Towne, Silverstein, Rotter of New York.

title: The Iran-Contra Thicket; Mysteries Remain in the Affair, Even as It Has Raised Vital Issues on Abuse of Power
description: Fifteen years ago this summer, a night watchman found a piece of tape left by burglars on a door latch at the Watergate office building where the Democratic National Committee had its headquarters. Two years of intense

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: TV Review; 'CIRCUS,' ONE-HOUR DRAMA ON ABC
description: ''CIRCUS'' is a wisp, a one-hour movie without beginning, middle or end. Actors appear, identify their characters and vanish without a trace. Maybe it's a new kind of drama. Most likely, though, the ABC special, on Channel 7 at 8 tonight, is just one of those things that turn up on television to kill time in midsummer.

title: Two Girls Killed in Van Fire
description: Two children died early Saturday when the van in which they were sleeping was destroyed by a fire. The victims were identified as Anna Hollek, 7 years old, and her sister Alyssia, 5, of Doyle in Lassen County. Bill Heafey, the Nevada County Sheriff, said the girls' father, Gerald Frank Hollek, 33, was being sought for questioning.

title: A Family Grieves As Many Search For Missing Girl
description: Twice a day, every day since July 9, friends, relatives and strangers have joined Karen and Kenneth Schweiger as they search the mosquito-infested swamps and woods of Staten Island for their 12-year-old handicapped daughter.

title: C-Span Erases No More
description: For years, C-Span, the nonprofit cable television cooperative for public affairs programming, has been broadcasting hour upon interminable hour of Congressional hearings and floor debates. But to save money the network did not save the videotapes.

title: AMNESTY PROGRAM FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS GAINING MOMENTUM
description: After a slow start three months ago, the nation's amnesty program for illegal aliens is gaining momentum with more than 40,000 applications being filed each week, according to immigration and counseling officials around the nation.

title: PROTECTIVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment gains of $3,582,000 for the quarter and $4,708,000 for the 6 months. c-After investment gains of $117,000 for the quarter and $737,000 for the 6 months.

title: Wiebelskirchen Journal; Awaiting a Homecoming of a Different Drummer
description: The modest pale-green house on Kuchenbergerstrasse, where Erich Honecker grew up in the 1920's, was freshly painted three years ago when it looked like the Communist leader of the German Democratic Republic would be making a visit to West Germany.

title: LAWTER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Offer for Stake In Dome Mines
description: Giant Yellowknife Mines Ltd., an Australian-controlled mining concern, has offered $417 million ($313 million United States) for nearly all of Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s stake in Dome Mines Ltd., a big Canadian gold producer.

title: REGINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January 1987.

title: Israeli Officer Reported Slain By Guerrillas in Gaza Strip
description: Palestinian guerrillas shot and killed an Israeli Army officer today in the occupied Gaza Strip, a military spokesman said.

title: Lawmaking and Politicking: Reagan's Veto Strategy Is Not Getting Rave Reviews in Congress
description: The relationship between the White House and Congress is starting to sound like a bad marriage. Both sides seem to have an increasing propensity for grating on each other's nerves and questioning the other's motives.

title: PACIFIC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
N.F.L. Camps; Jets See Hope for Front Line
description: This is the state of the Jets on Day 1 of a full training camp: Three regulars on the offensive line are missing because of last year's injuries, and Coach Joe Walton believes the unit will be better than in 1986.

title: PRUDENTIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Union Square Traffic Detoured to Fix Main
description: Traffic around much of Union Square will be detoured today and possibly until later in the week because of repair work on a water main that collapsed Friday and flooded much of the area.

title: Suburbs Straining to Build Services for AIDS Victims
description: Just outside New York City, suburban doctors and social workers are struggling not only to treat their AIDS patients, but also to find places for them to live, buses to take them on errands, and neighborhoods to welcome them home.

title: Sports World Specials; Computer Crew
description: Crossing the Atlantic Ocean alone in a sailboat would seem to be dangerous enough for sailors who can see where they're going. Jim Dickson, a 41-year-old yachtsman from Washington, plans to do it the hard way. Dickson, who is in the final stages of planning a solo voyage, is blind.

title: Yanks Outslug Tigers, 8-5; Mets stop Expos, 7-4; Mood Upbeat After 5-1 Trip
description: The Mets ended a revival road trip today by beating the Montreal Expos, 7-4, and headed home with five victories in six games against the two teams in front of them in the National League's East.

title: Citicorp Executive Takes Fidelity Post
description: Glen R. Moreno, a key executive of Citicorp Investment Bank, resigned last week to become chairman of Fidelity International Management Holdings Ltd., which is affiliated with the huge Boston-based Fidelity group of mutual funds.

title: Dr. Brustein, Pathologist, Marries Glenn H. Corwin
description: Dr. Sheryl N. Brustein, an attending pathologist at the State University Hospital and the Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Glenn H. Corwin, the assistant principal and special education teacher at the Lorge School in Manhattan. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg officiated at the Sands Point, L.I., home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin R. Corwin.

title: Death in Mecca: In a Time of Prayer, Tensions Explode and Yield Violence
description: From out of the desert, from uncounted towns and cities across the Middle East and around the world, they had trekked for weeks, Islamic pilgrims in white robes and turbans, women in chadors, thronging the roads to Mecca on the most sacred mission of their lives.

title: 5-Year Stock Rally: The Far-Reaching Impact
description: The bull market in stocks, which five years ago began a climb that is still breaking records, has changed the face of corporate America.

title: Life of Plants In the Bronx: Not So Secret
description: Down in Rhododendron Valley and up on Daffodil Hill, on Azalea Way and along the wooded shores of the Bronx River, an unusual census is under way at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Jenifer Jean Saydah Weds John Klein at St. Patrick's
description: St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jenifer Jean Saydah, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore M. Saydah of Closter, N.J., and John David Klein, the son of Eileen Klein of Orlando, Fla., and Clarence W. Klein of Wichita, Kan. The Rev. John Clairmont performed the ceremony.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: The Nicaraguan Democrats Need Help
description: The debate about assisting the Nicaraguan contras will soon begin again. Let's hope that this time, in contrast to so much of the past debate, the policy options are broadened beyond a simple choice between the contra and Sandinista extremes.

title: MANUFACTURERS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: When Men Confront Infertility
description: WHEN William Stern and his wife, Elizabeth, made the decision that led to the birth of Baby M, he was partly motivated, he said, by a desire to continue his bloodline. But the man who is infertile does not have the option of hiring a surrogate mother. His choices are childlessness or adoption.

title: 2 HOTEL HOLDUPS IN MIDTOWN TIED TO A TEAM OF 4
description: Robbers at two mid-Manhattan hotels took more than $29,000 in cash and jewelry Saturday night, and the same team of four well-dressed thieves is suspected in both cases, the police said yesterday.

title: INVESTORS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

DOFASCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Chile Is Said to Bar Author From Entering the Country
description: The Chilean author Ariel Dorfman was prevented from entering the country today when he arrived at Santiago Airport on a flight from the United States, members of his family said.

title: Fire Is Still Burning In Ruins of Factory
description: Pockets of fire continued to burn amid the ruins of a five-building factory complex here yesterday, hampering firefighters' efforts to raze the structures.

title: Networks Take Turns In Covering Hearings
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair will be televised live beginning at 9 A.M. on the CBS television network under the network rotation system. The hearings will also be televised on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on some local affiliates of PBS, the Public Broadcasting Service, including Channel 13 in New York.

title: U.S. WON'T CHANGE ITS POLICY IN GULF
description: While the violence involving Iranians and the Saudi police in Mecca has considerably raised already high tensions in the Persian Gulf, Reagan Administration officials said today that they plan no policy changes for the region.

title: Going Out Guide
description: American Classics

title: FOR LESTER LANIN, 50 YEARS OF MUSIC
description: He stood to one side of the bandstand, wearing a dinner jacket and turning occasionally to direct his musicians with a hand movement or two. As they struck up a current Paul Simon hit, ''You Can Call Me Al,'' he tapped a cowbell with a stick to keep time.

title: 16 Years After a Transplant, Man Dies of a Heart Ailment
description: A 53-year-old man who lived for 16 years with a transplanted heart died Saturday of a heart-related illness.

title: Member of Aquino Cabinet Is Assassinated by Gunmen
description: Three gunmen today killed Jaime Ferrer, a member of President Corazon C. Aquino's Cabinet, on a busy street near his home in a Manila suburb.

title: Moscow to Consider Compromise In Dispute With Bonn on Missiles
description: A senior Soviet arms negotiator said today that Moscow would consider a compromise to resolve differences over West Germany's short-range Pershing 1A missiles.

title: London Seeks Part Of A.D.R. Market
description: In recent years, London has watched with alarm as much of the equity trading in Britain's flagship companies has crossed the Atlantic to Wall Street, where non-American shares are bought and sold in the convenient, dollar-denominated form of American depositary receipts.

title: Riverfront Offering Best Hope of Revival for City in Shadow of St. Louis
description: In this desperately poor city, the best chance for economic turnaround seems to lie in the weedy, abandoned lots along the Mississippi River.

title: THE STAGE: ANN MAGNUSON
description: IN THE satirical world of Ann Magnuson, commercial television is portrayed as more than just a popular communications medium. It is the church of an American Babylon, a malignant spiritual force that fosters envy, rage and ignorance. Its blasphemous iconography confuses sex with religion, fame with holiness. And according to the lilting country waltz with which Miss Magnuson opened her show ''Transmissions'' on Friday, its underlying message is that ''misery loves misery.''

title: Books of the Times
description: WILLIAM FAULKNER: The Man and the Artist. By Stephen B. Oates. Illustrated. 363 pages. Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: TEKELEC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest periods' losses include a pre-tax charge of $635,000 from the discontinuance of two product lines.

title: Harness Racing; Campell Seeking Hard-To-Get Victory
description: He has earned more money in harness racing purses than any other driver and he is a premier figure in the sport. His notable victories are numerous. But the most prestigious one has eluded John Campbell.

title: JIFFY LUBE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quieter Subs Make All of Us Sleep Better
description: To the Editor:

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Decade After Strip Mine Law: Successes and Some Setbacks
description: The 10th anniversary of the Federal law to curb strip mining's environmental abuses will be observed Monday, after a decade in which hundreds of thousands of acres have been returned to productive use while many other tracts have been left ravaged.

title: Sports World Specials; A Partial Admission
description: Critics have long claimed that student athletes, especially football and basketball players, are far more likely than other students to be enrolled in college under so-called ''special admissions'' procedures; that their high school grades and entrance test scores are lower than those of other students, and that their graduation rates are lower, too.

title: BALDWIN & LYONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $4,627 and $18,058 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the sale of stock; and gains of $3,532 for the quarter and $1,569,631 for the 6 months on investments. c-Includes gains of $27,351 for the quarter and $36,004 for the 6 months on the sale of stock; and gains on investments of $823,119 and $2,595,775 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Amy Zarkin Wed To Neal J. Reiner
description: Amy Lynn Zarkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Zarkin of Sudbury, Mass., and South Laguna, Calif., was married last night to Neal Jeffrey Reiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Reiner of Deerfield, Ill. Rabbi Les Bronstein performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

title: C O M B CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted. The company said results for the latest periods include pretax income of $1,069,000 for the second quarter and $1,991,000 for the 6 months, representing the company's 50 percent equity in the earnings of its unconsolidated joint venture, Cable Value Network.

title: WILMINGTON TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Insider-Trading Cases Entering Crucial Phase
description: A little more than a year after the insider trading scandal burst into the open, Government prosecutors are preparing for what could be the most decisive phase of this wrenching episode: trying their cases in court.

title: Market Place; The Recovery At Caterpillar
description: ''CAT is healthy again,'' a Wall Street analyst declared last week. He referred to Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of earth-moving machinery - and a frequent disappointment to shareholders during the 1980's. It often lost money because of industry overcapacity, fierce price competition and a strong dollar. And, like other capital goods producers in recent years, it suffered in the depressed economic conditions worldwide.

title: CARMELITA MARACCI, A BALLET INSTRUCTOR AND CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Carmelita Maracci, a leading American ballet teacher and noted performer, died at her home in Hollywood on July 26 after a long illness. She was 75 years old.

title: Golf; Littler Wins With Up-And-Down Style
description: Gene Littler had a rather tumultuous final round in winning the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative golf tournament today by one stroke from Dale Douglass.

title: COWLEY LOST HIS CONFIDENCE AND HIS SEASON, TOO
description: JOE COWLEY has not lost his sense of humor. He was standing in front of a stall in a $1 million barn on the Buckman Oak horse farm here one day last week when, sticking his left hand through the gate to pat the nose of Rare Topaze, the stall's majestic resident, he noted, ''One chomp and your fingers are gone.'' Whereupon he pulled his left hand out, put his right hand in, wiggled his fingers and said, smiling, ''Here, I don't need these anymore.''

title: FARE-BEATERS COST OTHER NEW YORKERS A NICKEL ON EVERY TOKEN
description: To the Editor:

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Diana F. Hausman Weds A Fellow Medical Student
description: Diana Felice Hausman, a medical student, and Daniel Eliot Sabath, a medical student and Ph.D. candidate, both at the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday in a loft at 24 Fifth Avenue. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated.

title: Sports World Specials; Time Catches Up
description: It was one of those crystal moments of baseball history, when time itself stood still: the day in 1939 when the aging Roy Hobbs, making a comeback in a career he never had, stood at the plate for the New York Knights in the second game of a doubleheader against the Dodgers in Brooklyn and bashed the first pitch into the clock on the right-field wall.

title: Special Olympics Opens
description: Thousands of mentally handicapped athletes, bearing the flags of 72 nations and a message of courage, marched into the University of Notre Dame stadium today to open the 1987 International Summer Special Olympics.

title: PULLMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $972,000 for the quarter and $3,087,000 for the 9 months. The results for the year-ago periods have been restated for the fiscsal 1986 sale of an equipment leasing company, which was accounted for as a discontinued operation.

title: Pay for Teachers Rises by 7.1%
description: The average starting salary for schoolteachers rose 7.1 percent for the past year to $17,800, with six states offering more than $19,000 to beginners, according to the American Federation of Teachers.

title: Connally Plan After Filing
description: John B. Connally, the former Treasury Secretary and three-term Governor of Texas who filed for bankruptcy on Friday, said he might return to legal work or assisting others wanting to ''put deals together.''

title: Surf's, Well, Barely Up, on Maligned L.I. Sound
description: The tan factor was a searing seven today at Hammonasset Beach State Park. Lifeguards dabbed on a little extra zinc oxide, the older crowd took refuge under umbrellas and legions of sun-worshipping teen-agers basted themselves with cocoa butter as they broiled on the hot sand.

title: Vietnam More Optimistic About U.S. Talks
description: United States and Vietnamese negotiators looking for ways to resolve the issue of 1,776 Americans still listed as missing in this country met briefly twice today.

title: Strong July Seen by Purchasers
description: The nation's economy continued to expand in July, and at a much faster rate than in June, according to a report to be released today by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income of $314,000 for the quarter and a charge of $623,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Dr. Jody Lewinter Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Jody Riva Lewinter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Lewinter of Westfield, N.J., and Dr. David Kruger, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sam Kruger of Highland Park, Ill., were married yesterday at the Summit (N.J.) Hotel by Rabbi Charles Kroloff.

title: Bank Bill's Narrower Provisions
description: While much of the debate over the banking bill has centered on such broad policy issues as the separation of commerce and banking, and the rescue of the thrift system, a host of smaller provisions that affect millions of individuals and thousands of banks and thrift units have found a place in the legislation. The bill is expected to pass both the House and Senate this week.

title: 3,100 MINERS ON STRIKE ARE DISMISSED IN NAMBIA
description: A copper-mining company in South-West Africa partly owned by a United States corporation has dismissed 3,100 black workers who were on strike for better pay and working conditions.

title: Voodoo Banking for Farmers
description: The Farm Credit System: to urbanites, it sounds like the answer to one of the more esoteric questions in Trivial Pursuit. It is, in fact, a sprawling collection of cooperative banks whose imminent collapse is anything but trivial for thousands of rural borrowers and Wall Street lenders.

title: Outdoors; Step to Solitary Angling
description: A LETTER from David Lilly of Manhattan informs me that one of these columns has inspired him to resume fishing after a hiatus of nearly 30 years.

title: NATURE'S SUNSHINE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Auctions Set Only for Shorter Issues
description: The Treasury plans to auction a full array of bills this week, but the outlook for note and bond financings remains cloudy.

title: Letters to Congress: Amend the Constitution? Let Us Count the Ways
description: One citizen suggested abolishing the Presidency. Another wanted to eradicate the Senate. And still another proposed that the United States of America be known instead as the United States of the Earth.

title: OPERA: 'LOGENGRIN' STAGED BY HERZOG
description: For two acts, the Bayreuth Festival's new ''Lohengrin'' appeared to be a handsome but conventional affair, staged in the austere Wieland Wagner style that prevailed in the decades immediately after World War II.

title: Food-Poisoning Toll Rises to 3 at Hospital
description: A second and third patient have died at the Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home after an outbreak of food poisoning was traced to salmonella, a hospital spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: INSITUFORM GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DANCE: JOSE LIMON COMPANY AT SUMMERFARE
description: THERE are times when it is a pleasant thing to sink into a familiar dance and savor its comfortable pleasures. The dance need not be the best of the choreographer's oeuvre. ''A Choreographic Offering'' is hardly a masterwork of Jose Limon's career in American modern dance. But a performance of the piece tonight Saturday night at the Pepsico Summerfare festival, at the State University College at Purchase offered a vision of the warmth and seriousness of his dance at its best, and of the gifts of the current Limon Dance Company.

title: Milk Industry In New York Is in Upheaval
description: At 3:30 in the morning, next to a vast, dark graveyard, what is at once a decades-old routine and a fierce new battle for survival unfolds at the Tuscan Dairy Farms processing plant in Woodside, Queens.

title: Pravda Reports 2 Accidents And Gives Warning on Safety
description: Two separate chemical accidents on the same day injured 42 people, five critically, in Soviet Central Asia, Pravda said today.

title: Advertising; AIDS Contract Goes to O.&M.
description: Ogilvy & Mather will be handling both the advertising and public relations programs for the national AIDS campaign of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. The year-long contract is for $4.5 million, and there is a one-year option to renew.

title: When Doctors Refuse to Treat AIDS
description: Fear of AIDS has produced its most painful symptom yet: doctors and dentists who refuse to treat patients they believe to be infected with the AIDS virus.

title: OIL PRICE RISE EXPECTED
description: The price of oil in the futures market is expected to rise sharply this week on fears that Iran will retaliate against Kuwait or Saudi Arabia for last week's violence in Mecca, and that such confrontations will limit the flow of crude supplies from the Middle East.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $51,000 for the quarter and $73,000 for the 6 months.

title: ECONOMIC PARLEY TERMED A SUCCESS
description: A 141-nation conference wound up a monthlong debate tonight with agreement on a joint strategy for tackling some of the third world's most pressing economic difficulties, including an offer of more flexible treatment for heavily indebted developing nations.

description: The company said there are no share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company didn't go public until October 1986.

title: Pan Am Games; For Cubans, Politics Are All in the Game
description: THIS is not a good moment for the United States and Cuba.
