title: Eastern Discounts
description: Eastern Airlines will offer reduced rates to travelers on certain flights this fall, the Miami-based carrier said. The fares, based on mileage, will be available for purchase until Aug. 18 for midweek round-trip travel from Sept. 9 through Oct. 28. The fares apply to flights to and from the cities Eastern serves east of the Mississippi River, as well as Kansas City, Mo., and Omaha. Travelers must depart on a Tuesday or Wednesday and return the next Tuesday or Wednesday. If the distance is less than 750 miles each way, the fare will be $49 each way. It will cost $59 each way for a destination 750 to 1,200 miles away and $69 for a trip of more than 1,200 miles.

title: Oil Prices Decline on Gulf Calm
description: A surprising buildup in gasoline supplies in the United States and the momentary calm in the Persian Gulf sent prices of crude oil slumping yesterday.

title: HORIZON GOLD SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $80,200 and $15,800 for the latest quarter and year- ago period, respectively. The company said its revenue and net income increased because its Buffalo Valley Mine operated for all of the latest quarter. The mine began production in June 1986 and only operated for one month in the year-ago quarter.

title: Talks on Howe
description: Eddie Chiles, owner of the Texas Rangers, and Mike Stone, the team president, met with Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, yesterday about the possibility of returning Steve Howe to the major leagues.

title: COMMODORE ENVIRONMENTAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a credit of $300,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: That Dog Won't Hunt
description: If Ronald Reagan is serious about his new ''peace plan'' for Nicaragua, he must think its Sandinista Government can be intimidated into giving up its independence, its power and its Marxist world view.

title: Seabrook Utility Says It Needs 15% Rate Increase
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, drained by its $2 billion investment in the dormant Seabrook nuclear plant, asked for permission today to raise rates as a last resort to avert bankruptcy.

title: TECHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $43,000 and $84,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Cauthen, the American jockey, earned his 1,000th victory in Britain yesterday when he rode the favorite, Picnicing, in the Hassocks Graduation Stakes. Cauthen, 27 years old, arrived in Britain eight years ago after beginning his riding career in the United States. . . . The Winnipeg Jets signed Bob Essensa, a goaltender, to a multiyear contract. . . . Team Canada has added two more defensemen to its training camp roster: Rob Ramage and Brad McCrimmon. The roster, now at 38, will be cut to 23 by the time the six-team tournament begins Aug. 28. . . . Ralph McFillen, who served three years as commissioner of the Gulf South Conference, has been named commissioner of the Metro Conference. McFillen, who also spent 12 years as the N.C.A.A.'s assistant director of championship events, succeeds Steve Hatchell, who resigned to become executive director of the Orange Bowl.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in some editions yesterday of a science education professor at Lehman College misidentified him. He was Theodore D. Benjamin.

title: ENEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NIEKRO IS SUSPENDED FOR 10 DAYS
description: Joe Niekro, the Minnesota knuckleball pitcher who was caught with an emery board in his uniform pocket earlier this week, was suspended yesterday for 10 days. The action was the first by a league president in a season that has been punctuated by controversy over scuffed baseballs and corked bats.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $800,000 and $1,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: INDEPENDENT BANKGROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: Violence in California Has Spread to the Sky
description: A law that would imprison highway gunslingers for at least three years was proposed today as violence spread from southern California's freeways to the sky, where one pilot reported that another had drawn a gun on him.

title: REPRESENTED NASSAU IN CONGRESS 17 YEARS
description: John W. Wydler, a former Representative from Nassau County, died, apparently from a heart attack, Tuesday at Capitol Hill Hospital in Washington. A resident of Garden City, L.I., he was 63 years old.

title: Marietta Threatens to End Phone Bid
description: A dispute over the Federal Government's multibillion-dollar telephone contract escalated yesterday when the Martin Marietta Corporation, one of two remaining bidders, threatened to withdraw.

title: CERPROBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: INTEGRATED GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: MARINES TRAIN FOR SWIFT RAIDS AND HOSTAGE RESCUES
description: Over the last two years, the Marine Corps has quietly trained amphibious battalions that can be deployed overseas to mount commando raids, to evacuate American diplomats from besieged embassies and to help rescue hostages captured by terrorists.

title: DAVID MARTIN
description: David Martin, a bass guitarist for the 1960's rock group Sam the Sham and the Pharaohs, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 50 years old.

title: Safeway's Defense on Boycott Charges
description: Commerce Department charges that Safeway Stores Inc. complied with the Arab boycott of Israel are based in part on an untested area of the United States anti-boycott law, according to the attorney representing Safeway.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Campeau Corp., a developer and owner of commercial income-producing properties, appointed Benjamin F. Riggs president.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRITISH AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS). Results are in U.S. dollars; American dollar equivalent amounts are translated at the exchange rate at June 30, 1987, of 1.60 to one against the pound sterling.

title: PAKISTAN REJECTS ATOMIC INSPECTION
description: Pakistan has rebuffed renewed suggestions that it allow inspection of its nuclear sites to demonstrate that it is not making nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-After charges totaling $7,494,000 from cost of litigation and abandoned power plant costs.

title: Beyond the Expulsion of Dr. Smith
description: The ouster of Frank L. Smith Jr., after only a year as head of New York City's high schools, appropriately follows his division's failure to carry out programs linking schools to jobs. But the schools' problems of leadership and sclerotic bureaucracy far exceed Dr. Smith's responsibility.

title: 'The Living Daylights' First in Ticket Sales
description: ''The Living Daylights,'' the latest James Bond adventure, with Timothy Dalton making his debut as the film series' fourth Agent 007, took in $11 million in its opening weekend to set a James Bond box-office record and handily won the No. 1 spot.

title: COMMONWEALTH BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Companies

title: SUIT IN BROOKLYN SEEKS TO BLOCK OFFICE COMPLEX
description: A group of Brooklyn residents and business owners sued yesterday to try to halt construction of Metrotech, a $770 million office and research complex proposed on 17 acres in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Do as Madison Does
description: To the Editor:

title: BUFFETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VTX ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shares oustanding are net of repurchase of 25 percent of the outstanding shares in April 1986.

title: NAC RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized losses of $105,000 for the quarter and a realized gain of $645,000 for the 6 months, on investments; the 6 months also includes a tax loss carryforward of $188,000. c-After realized gains on investments of $2,083,000 for the quarter and $2,078,000 for the 6 months.

title: SUFFOLK BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The per share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend in May 1987.

title: On a Tenement Roof, Tropical Dreams
description: MANY New Yorkers dream about escaping to a cool island paradise where the wind rushes through the palm trees. Others take action. Who needs the Hamptons, one might argue, when there are people like Jane Stonehouse, an artist who can create an island paradise - complete with a thatched beach cabana - on the rooftop of an East Village tenement?

title: MOORE MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION/ INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Metro-North Train Kills Man Near a South Bronx Station
description: An unidentified Hispanic man was struck and killed by a Metro-North commuter train yesterday evening just south of the Melrose station in the Bronx, a police spokesman said.

title: VALMONT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Great Gatsby
description: President Reagan's chief speech writer, Anthony R. Dolan, wrote an Op-Ed piece for The New York Times last month in praise of his boss. Ordinarily, not much can be expected from such worshipful efforts, but this one was memorable.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $9,253,000 and $51,225,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $30,795,000 for the quarter and $66,202,000 for the 6 months.

title: Canadian Talks For Helicopters
description: A British-Italian consortium has won the right to negotiate with the Canadian Government for the potential sale of 28 to 51 EH101 military helicopters, a spokesman for the British manufacturer Westland P.L.C. said today. Westland and its partner, Agusta S.p.A., had been competing against a group led by France's Aerospatiale.

title: West Germany Top Exporter
description: West Germany has overtaken the United States as the world's top exporting nation, and Japan is close behind, according to figures compiled by the International Monetary Fund.

title: Employment Agency Niche
description: MOST analysts continue to give high marks to the temporary-help business - a niche industry that sprang into the Wall Street spotlight this week on the strength of a surprise takeover bid from abroad.

title: ESTATE FIGHT TO BRING EXHUMATION
description: A Cook County Circuit Court today approved a request from several family members to exhume the body of George Halas Jr., whose estate is at the center of a court battle over control of the Chicago Bears professional football team.

title: 50 Superseding Counts Filed in Wedtech Case
description: A superseding indictment, dropping eight counts, was filed yesterday in the Wedtech racketeering case against Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx; the former Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon, and five others.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stage: 'Las Bacantes,' at Festival Latino
description: THE fearsome central image of ''Las Bacantes,'' Salvador Tavora's powerfully austere flamenco interpretation of Euripides' ''The Bacchae,'' is a giant wooden wheel that sits at the rear center stage of the Newman Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival. As the compressed fury of Euripides' tragedy is unleashed by a gaunt, pony-tailed Dionysus (Juan Romero) with Charles Manson eyes, the device is mounted by his five worshipping Bacchae who use it as a murderous tool of pleasure and pain.

title: DIMENSIONAL MEDICINE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Museums to Share Their Masterpieces
description: A remarkable series of international art loans between the Metropolitan Museum, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Hermitage in Leningrad is now in the final planning stage.

title: Fox Film Posts Net
description: The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation said today that it earned $15.7 million on $319 million in revenues in its fourth quarter, results buoyed by the box-office success of the Arnold Schwarzenegger film ''Predator'' and the international release of ''Crocodile Dundee.''

title: Some Welfare Reform Beats No Welfare Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Yehuda Rosenman, 69, Jewish Program Leader
description: Yehuda Rosenman, the director of the Department of Jewish Communal Affairs of the American Jewish Committee for two decades, died of brain cancer Tuesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Vietnam's Issues May Be Next for Talks
description: Vietnamese officials expect to open talks with the United States before the end of this month that will for the first time address Vietnamese problems arising from the war, a high-ranking Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest 9-month includes a charge of $74,000 related to the planned relocation of corporate offices.

title: Manhattan Roulette
description: To the Editor:

title: DOMINION SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: F.C.C. Struggled With Itself Six Years Before Reversing a Policy It Opposed
description: From the moment President Reagan appointed Mark S. Fowler chairman of the Federal Communications Commission in 1981, the activist, deregulation-minded commission vowed opposition to the fairness doctrine.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dome in Default On Most Loans
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it had defaulted on nearly all of its loans because some of its lenders were unwilling to extend an interim borrowing arrangement on terms acceptable to the company. Dome said that the default would not affect its daily operations and that it intended to continue making payments to lenders based on the provisions of an interim plan that is no longer in effect.

title: BRASCAN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bill Is Signed by Cuomo To Control Gypsy Cabs
description: Governor Cuomo has signed a bill that gives New York City officials a new weapon to keep gypsy cabs and other unlicensed cars for hire off the streets.

title: Truthful Depictions
description: To The Home Section:

title: VIKONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $52,000 and $60,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Will Charles Use the 'Veto' At St. Paul's?
description: Plans to redevelop the setting of an English institution, St. Paul's Cathedral, are reportedly running into trouble from another institution, Prince Charles, whose continuing outspoken criticism of modern architecture has endowed him with what many Britons have called a ''royal veto'' over building designs.

title: Nicaraguan Peace Plan, or Ploy?
description: What might be called the Arias-Wright-Shultz-Baker-Reagan peace plan for Central America represents progress, inside the Administration at least. It offers a gleam of hope that President Reagan and his aides realize the need for negotiations, and perhaps even for compromises, to end a bitter conflict within and with Nicaragua. The pity is the taint of coming so late in the Reagan Presidency - and so soon before a showdown vote in Congress on aiding the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: GIANT GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,08,000, or 6 cents a share, for both the quarter and 6 months. The company paid no prefered stock dividend in the latest quarter and 6-month; it paid preferred stock dividends of $133,000 and $304,000 in the year-ago second quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Canadian Is Hopeful Of Visit by Sakharov
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet rights campaigner and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has accepted an invitation to visit Canada in October, according to a research foundation in Winnipeg that has named him winner of its humanitarian award.

title: Dallas Project Is Refinanced
description: The Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Company, Japan's second-largest life insurer, and the Equitable Financial Companies of New York said today that they provided equal portions of a $450 million refinancing of the Dallas Market Center, the world's largest wholesale merchandise mart.

title: Europe, U.S. Agree on Pasta Subsidy
description: The United States and the European Community said today that they had tentatively agreed on a plan to end the six-year-old dispute over the community's exports of subsidized pasta to the United States.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $792,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: Rainbow Room: Re-creating the Glamour
description: On July 26, 1938, a consignment of fresh Gaspe salmon headed upstream in the elevators of the RCA Building at Rockefeller Center toward the elegant tables of the Rainbow Room. It was one of many firsts for the supper club - the first time salmon was caught, shipped and served in a New York restaurant the same day.

title: NATIONAL PIZZA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No More Free Opinions
description: The latest victim of the Federal budget-balancing law is the complimentary copies of Federal appeals court opinions that the Washington press corps used to receive. The clerk's office of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has told news organizations that they will now have to pay for the opinions at the usual subscription rate charged private law firms. That rate, also increased because of the budget-balancing law, is $225 a year, up from $160. How much will the court's new policy save the Government? A court official said she was not sure there would be any savings, for early signs point to a falloff in paid circulation because of the increased subscription rate.

title: 201 Rebels in Uganda Said to Die in Assault
description: An army officer said today that 201 rebels had been killed in an attack on an army outpost here.

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest 6 months.

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment losses of $26,971,000 for the quarter and $11,571,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes investment gains of $60,823,000 for the quarter and $121,464,000 for the 6 months.

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net of $1,335,000 for the quarter and a loss of $814,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary gain of $955,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4,992,000 and $5,458,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $22,300,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company also said net earnings for the first half of 1986 benefited significantly from favorable refined product margins and were reduced by $26,987,000 due to a writedown of Charter's interest in an oil producing concession.

title: LIPOSOME CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Figure in Insider Case Might Return to Kidder
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has asked Richard B. Wigton, who was indicted in the Wall Street insider trading scandal, to rejoin the firm, people close to Kidder said yesterday.

title: UNION VALLEY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $281,000, or 8 cents a share, related to the termination of a pension program.

title: Congressman Leads in Race To Be Mayor of Nashville
description: Representative Bill Boner and Phil Bredesen landed in a runoff, leading six other mayoral candidates in a non-partisan election today.

title: Dining Out Guide; Hot and Spicy
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AKBAR, #475 Park Avenue, near 58th Street (838-1717) - **(June 27, 1986) For those who crave some hot and spicy food no matter what the outside temperature - or the cuisine - several interesting options are available. This aristocratic restaurant offers some beguiling Indian food: the vindaloos are appropriately hot, condiments are cool and curries are complex. The lamb vindaloo, for example, a smoldering dish from southwestern India, excels here because it has much more than mere B.T.U.'s going for it; the pulpy sauce is stratified with sensations of cumin, garlic, ginger and cinnamon. Another good choice is the tandoor chicken, mildly hot outside from a coating of mixed spices and succulent within. Entrees $7.50 to $19.95. Fridays and Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 2:45 P.M. and 5:30 to 10:45; Sundays, 5:30 to 10:45 P.M. CAFE MARIMBA, #1115 Third Avenue, entrance on 65th Street (935-1161) -

title: Man in 1946 Escape Found in California
description: A man who escaped from a Virginia chain gang 41 years ago and had a career as an electrician in the movie business was arrested after his past was discovered in a chance check of records.

title: Magazine Publishers' New Chief
description: DONALD D. KUMMERFELD, who worked for seven years in the Federal Bureau of the Budget, served as Deputy Mayor of New York and was an associate of Rupert Murdoch, has agreed to take over the presidency of the Magazine Publishers Association on Sept. 1.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
WAINOCO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $606,000 from tax credits. c-Net loss

title: Pitchers Pounded, Bat Impounded
description: Six home runs and numerous accusations flew round Shea Stadium last night as the great war of the corked bats broke out again, and Howard Johnson's bat was held hostage for the second time in a week. And for a time, the Mets even played the game under protest, complaining that the umpires were picking on them.

title: Mozambique and Pretoria Revive Nonaggression Pact
description: Mozambique and South Africa have decided to re-establish a joint security committee and have agreed that a nonaggression pact signed three years ago should be reactivated, officials said today.

title: NEECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CHORAL CARAMOOR

title: Why New York City Is Not Yet, Thank Goodness, Like Calcutta
description: To the Editor:

title: Atari's Net Up 39.2% in Period
description: The Atari Corporation, which makes personal computers and home video games, said today that its profit rose 39.2 percent, to $13.5 million, or 23 cents a share, from $9.7 million, or 22 cents a share on fewer outstanding shares, a year earlier.

title: COAST SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects an after-tax charge of $3.9 million for the writeoff of the company's investment in the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp.'s secondary reserve.

title: Bobby Wadkins Leads P.G.A.
description: Bobby Wadkins overcame poor putting conditions and intense heat today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the 69th P.G.A. Championship. ''The fairways are perfect, the rough unplayable and the greens just so-so,'' said Bobby Wadkins after shooting four-under-par 68 on the P.G.A. National Champion course of 7,002 steamy yards.

title: Cabbie in East Harlem Shot Dead by Gunman
description: A cabdriver was fatally shot yesterday by one of two gunmen who accosted him as he drove on a service road near the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 111th Street, the police said.

title: Indianapolis Ready for Prime Time
description: All over town, brightly colored banners hang from street lamps, fences, buildings and store windows. Billboards at the airport say ''IBienvenido!'' Downtown, the walk-don't walk signs have been changed to the international signs of an upheld hand and a figure in stride. Mayor William H. Hudnut 3d - El Jefe - recently completed a 12-hour course in Spanish, and delivering one speech not long ago, he wore a sombrero.

title: Motorola Seeks Toshiba Chips
description: Motorola Inc., the American communications and electronics company, has asked Japan's Toshiba Corporation to supply it with microchips, a Toshiba spokesman said. American manufacturers are facing a shortage of some key semiconductors as a result of the Japanese trade ministry's moves to curb Japan's output of chips because of American charges of dumping. The United States accused Japan earlier this year of selling chips below cost in third markets.

title: ISOMEDIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'Protocols of Zion' Originated in Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Islanders Name Lane
description: Gord Lane, a former Islander defenseman, has been named head coach of the Springfield Indians, the Islanders' American Hockey League farm team. Lane, 34 years old, served as a player and assistant coach for Springfield last season. He replaces Fred Creighton, who announced his retirement after two disappointing seasons as coach of the Indians. Lane, a native of Brandon, Manitoba, spent 10 seasons in the National Hockey League, the last 7 with the Islanders.

title: U.S. AND MANAGUA OPENLY DISAGREE ON A PEACE PLAN
description: President Reagan's new peace initiative for Central America immediately ran into trouble today, as the Administration and the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua openly differed on procedures for a negotiated settlement.

title: Matthew Broderick Injured in Car Crash
description: The actor Matthew Broderick was in stable condition today after a car crash near Enniskillen in which two women were killed.

Individual tickets are $4.50, or $3.50 on orders of eight or more. Box-office hours are Monday to Saturday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Information: 362-1911. title: Hansen Campaign
description: The jingle is set to the tune of ''The Mousketeers'' song from the 1950's Walt Disney television series: ''Who's the jailer of our land, who won't set Hansen free? M-I-C-K-E-Y, M-E-E-S-E.''

title: A Helping Hand for the Panamanians
description: LEAD: Although the outcome of events unfolding in Panama's crisis of political legitimacy is still uncertain, the way it is resolved has serious implications for human rights in that country.

title: ESTIMATE IS RAISED BY ADMINISTRATION ON 1987 INFLATION
description: The Reagan Administration today raised its estimate of the 1987 inflation rate to 4.8 percent, a full point higher than the 3.8 percent it estimated in January.

title: U.S. and Soviet Scientists Begin Conference on Space
description: Soviet and American scientists sharing information on research in space have begun a six-day meeting, Tass, the Soviet Government press agency, reported.

title: Con Edison Agrees to Freeze Rates for Gas Customers for Two Years
description: Rates for Consolidated Edison gas customers in New York City and Westchester County will be frozen at existing levels for at least two years, under an agreement announced today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Sports People; N.B.A. Salary Increase
description: The salary cap for National Basketball Association teams will increase to more than $6 million next season, an increase of 25 percent over the previous year. As a result, the average player's salary is expected to increase from $440,000 to $510,000 a year. Each team will be allowed to spend a maximum of $6,164,000 on player salaries in 1987-88, compared with $4,945,000 last season. The salary cap is being increased because of soaring N.B.A. revenues. Under the collective bargaining agreement between the league and the Players Association, players must receive at least 53 percent of the league's revenues. ''Since the implementation of the salary cap four years ago, N.B.A. revenues have almost doubled,'' said Russ Granik, the league's executive vice president.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,883,836 for the quarter and $8,990,301 for the 6 months, and the 6-month also includes a tax credit of $315,000. c-Includes capital gains of $4,149,618 and $5,685,541 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6-month also includes a tax credit of $13,772,501. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split for holders of record April 10, 1987.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE gem - which weighs between four and five ounces -could have been mailed without wrapping it, for $1.10. But few people would paste stamps on a diamond that, large as it is, has no room for the mailing address.

title: Wary of AIDS, New York to Cut Fewer Hospital Beds Than Proposed
description: Faced with a projected surge in the number of AIDS patients needing hospital care, state health authorities agreed yesterday to reduce New York City's hospital beds by 2,000, a much smaller reduction than had been recommended.

title: Shopping for Big Names and Fees
description: Trailed by security men, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d swept into a cocktail reception at the Metropolitan Club.

title: STUDY SEES WAGE BIAS AT CITY HALL
description: Women and minority-group members employed by New York City suffer pay discrimination, have been virtually shut out of certain jobs and lack promotion opportunities, a study commissioned by a labor union charged yesterday.

title: NEW YORK PANEL TO URGE ALTERATIONS IN ETHICS BILL
description: The commission appointed by Governor Cuomo to investigate government ethics will recommend that key provisions of the ethics bill passed this year by the State Legislature be changed, the commission's chairman said yesterday.

title: OCCUPATIONAL-URGENT CARE HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $150,000 for the quarter and $220,068 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $208,900 and $306,200 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $66,863 for the quarter and $61,358 for the 6 months.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MS CARRIERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE PANEL CUTS AID FUNDS
description: A key House committee today approved a $13.2-billion appropriations bill for 1988 foreign assistance that slashed President Reagan's request by $2.7 billion.

title: ARTS, CRAFTS AND POLKA FROM CENTRAL EUROPE
description: The 10th annual polka festival started yesterday at Hunter Mountain in the northern Catskills and will continue through Sunday, featuring music, dancing, food, drink, and the arts and crafts of Poland and other countries of Central Europe.

title: MPSI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ford Matches G.M. Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company today matched the buyer incentives offered yesterday by the General Motors Corporation, including the lowest financing rate ever offered by the Big Three auto makers.

title: Unisys President Quits In Reshuffling at Top
description: A year after it was created in the merger of the Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation, the Unisys Corporation announced a realignment of its senior executives yesterday. The reshuffling included the resignation of Paul G. Stern as president and a director, effective Dec. 31. He had held the same positions at Burroughs.

title: MONTY ALEXANDER
description: Tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592), Monty Alexander, a pianist is to lead ''Ivory and Steel Jamboree,'' a group including a steel drummer, on a double bill with Brazilian Express, which includes Claudio Roditi on trumpet and Slide Hampton on trombone. Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: Judge Blocks Stravinsky Biography
description: A new biography of the composer Igor Stravinsky was blocked yesterday in an unusual ruling by a Federal judge, who said the book took too much material from previously published works.

title: HELEN DOWLING
description: Helen Dowling, a violinist and music teacher, died of lung cancer at her home in London on July 12. She was 71 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Engineer Is Charged With Making Drugs

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects a tax provision at an effective rate of 40 percent for the latest quarter, and year-ago quarter net benefited from a tax credit. c-Net loss and includes an after-tax writedown of assets of $34,036,000 and excludes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,095,000.

title: ATARI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split as of June 1987. The company said results for year- ago second quarter and 6-month includes net income of 2 cents a share resulting from satisfaction of interest expense by issuance of common shares to Warner Communications Inc.

title: Rights Group Assails States on College Bias Plans
description: Five Southern states have failed to obey a court order to desegregate their higher education systems, the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund said in a report today. The rights group said the Department of Education had refused to begin enforcement proceedings against them.

title: Auto Sales in Japan
description: Foreign car sales in Japan rose 59 percent from last year's levels to a record 9,597 in July, a spokesman for the Japan Automobile Importers Association said.

title: MYLES J. LANE, RETIRED JUDGE AND EX-PROSECUTOR, IS DEAD
description: Myles J. Lane, a former United States Attorney in Manhattan and a retired State Supreme Court justice, died of Alzheimer's disease at the Mary Manning Walsh nursing home in Manhattan yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: Liberal Lawyers' Group Says Bork Favored Business in Court Rulings
description: A liberal lawyers' group said today that a study of Judge Robert H. Bork's record contradicted his contention that he is a politically neutral practitioner of judicial restraint and showed pervasive bias for business and against individual rights claims.

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: IE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $4,547,000 from an accounting change.

title: AIDS Hospital in Houston Falls Victim to High Costs
description: The nation's first hospital solely for AIDS patients is planning to close, a victim of internal problems and the devastating costs of treating the fatal disease.

title: AFTER 8-YEAR WAIT, SOVIET PIANIST FLIES WEST
description: Vladimir O. Feltsman, the Soviet pianist whose soaring musical star was abruptly stalled eight years ago when he applied to emigrate, finally came out today, certain that the long delay had only made his music better.

title: Record Corn Yield Seen
description: A survey of nine Middle West states released today suggests that the 1987 corn crop could produce record yields this autumn. Agrivisor Services Inc., an arm of the Illinois Farm Bureau, predicted an average American corn yield of 120 bushels an acre. That would break last year's record of 119 bushels an acre, Jim Quinton, grain market analyst with Agrivisor, said.

It also includes a $25 million writedown of notes receivable.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lasting Effects Unlikely in Attack Like Koch Had
description: A transient ischemic attack, Mayor Koch's problem according to his doctors, usually has no lasting effects. But it can be a forerunner of a stroke. The brief episodes, known to doctors as T.I.A.'s, result from the temporary reduction of blood flow to a part of the brain.

title: Article 003987 -- No Title
description: The Tenneco Credit Corporation is offering $250 million of notes due in 1994 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 390 money market mutual funds fell $508.1 million, to $241.40 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 100 institutional funds were down $1.27 billion, to $66.39 billion. Assets of the 200 general purpose funds were up $838.1 million, to $69.07 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds posted a decrease in assets of $80.4 million, to $105.93 billion.

title: MEI DIVERSIFIED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SKAH SHAH AT S.O.B.'S
description: Skah Shah, a Haitian band, performs tonight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M., 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $15 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Panamanians Rally To Call for Removal Of Nation's Leader
description: Tens of thousands of Panamanians filled the streets of the financial district today, waving white flags in defiance of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader.

title: Poll Indicates Decline In Support for Contras
description: The flurry of support for military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels that followed the testimony of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North before the Iran-contra hearings appears to have dissipated, according to an ABC News/Washington Post poll made public last night.

title: Southern Progress Shift
description: Don Logan, already president of the Southern Progress Corporation, a Time Inc. subsidiary, got the chief executive's title as well on Monday, when it was relinquished by Emory Cunningham, the 66-year-old founder of Southern Living magazine, the flagship publication of his company. Mr. Logan, 43, and like his predecessor an alumnus of Auburn University, joined Southern Progress in 1970 as a data-processing manager.

title: LINEAR INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $37,937 for the quarter and $57,387 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The name is corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: INSIDE
description: Allies May Help on Mines

title: Art: 'The Tables,' At the Modern
description: ANY day when it's not actually raining, you will find an interested and inquisitive crowd of people taking stock of an installation by Tom Otterness called ''The Tables'' that can be seen in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art. First seen earlier this season at the Brooke Alexander Gallery in SoHo, ''The Tables'' deserved a larger space, a larger and more general public and an open-air location. This is a transfer that justified the museum's ''Projects'' series many times over.

title: 27.58 Rise Puts Dow Near 2,600
description: The stock market again surged into record territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 2,594.23, up 27.58 points.

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the distribution on April 30, 1986, to stockholders of record on April 3, 1986, of one share of the company's limited duration class B common stock forn each share of common stock outstanding. Revenue represents commissions and fees.

description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $298,000 and $647,572 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $58,000 and $109,504 for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $3,232,000 and $3,537,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $49,000 and $69,000 for the same periods, respectively. The company said the large realized investment gain in the year-ago second quarter reflects a change in the company's investment policy from taxable to tax-exempt investments. The shift was due to the expected change in the tax position of the company.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sondrio Journal; In Italy's Valley of Death, the Terror Still Hovers
description: The Alps of the Valtellina seem high and mighty, giant things incapable of change at least during one man's lifetime. But this summer the mountains did change, and now they are dangerously fragile.

title: Adjustable Plans Gain As Mortgage Rates Fall
description: Mortgage rates fell slightly in July, two reports show, indicating that fears about rising inflation have lessened and that rates are stabilizing after soaring in the spring.

description: b-Includes investment gains of $19,540,580 for the quarter and $36,825,230 for the 6 months. c-Includes investment gains of $31,943,499 and $47,548,047 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Children's Dining Booms in Borscht Belt
description: The good news about being a children's waiter at a Catskills hotel is that ''you know if the kids don't like what's on the menu, you give them peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, they'll be happy,'' said Roger Breton. He had just finished balancing seven steaming plates of baked chicken as he raced across the children's dining room of the Raleigh Hotel.

title: British Stocks In Record Fall
description: A sudden hefty rise in interest rates engineered by the British authorities sent prices reeling today to a record one-day loss in points on the leading stock index.

title: AIMEE WALSH
description: Aimee Walsh, vice president of merchandising and design for Calvin Klein Underwear and Sleepwear, died of an aneurysm of the brain July 31 in North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. A resident of Manhattan and Westport, Conn., she was 38 years old.

title: Ruder Is Approved As S.E.C. Chairman
description: David S. Ruder won Senate approval yesterday to become chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. But the endorsement of the Northwestern University professor was not without opposition: The vote was 81 to 17.

title: Italian, in Chelsea and midtown.
description: I HAVE to admit that my relentless search for quality food in Chelsea is not entirely motivated by high journalistic ideals. I just need a good place for lunch, and Chelsea happens to be a short blast on the subway from Times Square.

title: Deere Splits The Analysts
description: ALTHOUGH Deere & Company, the beleaguered giant of the farm equipment business, is not expected to show a profit until its fiscal year ending in October 1988, the stock yesterday reached its loftiest price in three years.

description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Robert L. Crandall, chairman and president of American Airlines Inc., before the Aviation Safety Commission July 23:

title: STEEL BANDS AND SALSA IN PLAZAS AND PARKS
description: IN the winter, they are forlorn structures - roofs above empty air, stages without spectators. But in summertime, just about any outdoor shelter and public space in New York can turn into a bandstand. In parks, on street corners, even in bank plazas, from afternoons (mornings and musicians don't mix) into the night, New York's musicians come up from underground during the summer. On furlough from the confinement of clubs and theaters, their music glides happily into the city's soundscape.

title: BRIGGS & STRATTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Soviet and Israel Plan To Make Film Together
description: Israeli and Soviet film producers have signed an agreement to co-produce a comedy-spy thriller to be shot in both countries.

title: KOCH AIDE RESIGNS POST OVER INQUIRY
description: The official in charge of commercial real estate for New York City submitted his resignation yesterday, saying he would suffer a ''severe financial loss'' if forced to give up private real-estate interests that have prompted a city inquiry into his official conduct.

title: Edwards Enlists Campanis's Help
description: Al Campanis, who resigned from the Dodger organization last April following nationally televised remarks concerning the ability of blacks to hold baseball managerial jobs, will be working with Dr. Harry Edwards, who is seeking to create a job bank of minority-group members for baseball front offices.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Odd Couple: A Marxist Soviet and an Islamic Iran
description: As an avowedly atheist state that sells arms to Iraq and is engaged in a war against Islamic guerrillas in Afghanistan, the Soviet Union hardly seems a promising partner for the Islamic revolutionary leaders of Iran. But the Iranians appear to have put aside their differences with the Russians to forge a friendship of sorts in recent weeks that challenges American interests in the Persian Gulf and gives the Soviet Union an advantage, at least temporarily, in an intricate competition in the gulf region.

title: About Real Estate; Condominiums in Brooklyn for $45,000
description: Can families that have only about $45,000 for an apartment find what they need in New York City? They can, with the city's help, if they act together, buy a vacant building, hire a contractor and become, in effect, both developers and customers.

title: Robert Gilman Morris Weds Sara Fortunoff
description: Sara Marion Fortunoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Fortunoff of Somers, N.Y., and Robert Gilman Morris, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Shep Morris of Manhasset Hills, L.I., were married yesterday. Cantor Richard Berman performed the ceremony at the Tappan Hill Restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: IN ILLINOIS, TOPIC IS THE WEATHER
description: When Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified at the Iran-contra hearings in Washington last month, he was the talk of Oregon, Ill., and Anniston, Ala. Two correspondents returned to those towns and took their pulse again.

title: Whose Pershing Missiles Are They Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Whitney to Preview Some 3-Year-Olds
description: The ranks of the older horses are so thin this summer that the women and children of the local equine population had to be recruited for the Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track Saturday.

title: Sandinistas and Rebels Differ Sharply on Proposal
description: While expressing strong interest in a Central American peace plan offered by President Reagan, Nicaraguan Government and rebel officials differed sharply today over the form the negotiations should take and what should be discussed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe that my real motherland - and the real motherland for any artist, if you've got a gift from God - my real motherland would be a concert hall.'' - Vladimir O. Feltsman, the Soviet pianist,on arriving in Vienna. [ A5:2. ]

title: Warehouse Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Health Service Dispenses Banned Contraceptive Drug to 35
description: The Indian Health Service said today that it was continuing to prescribe Depo-Provera as a contraceptive for American Indian women even though the Federal Government rejected the drug for contraceptive use almost a decade ago.

title: Jate Lobell Suffers 3d Straight Loss
description: Jate Lobell, considered the top pacer as recently as three weeks ago, suffered his third consecutive defeat tonight in the first elimination of the $287,000 Oliver Wendell Holmes pace for 3-year-old colts and geldings.

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Unfit for British Print
description: When America publicly washes its dirty covert linen the whole world laughs, according to Richard Secord, the former arms salesman to Iran. If the Secord thesis were correct, nobody would laugh in or at Britain, where an Official Secrets Act makes it a criminal offense to disclose anything the Government calls an official secret. And there are never public inquiries into two secret services, M.I.5 and M.I.6. In fact, the system is more effective in denying to the British people what everybody else - including the Soviet Union - already knows.

title: Soviet Says Pershing Missiles Are Main Impediment to Pact
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union said today that West Germany's insistence on keeping American warheads on its missiles was the main obstacle to an agreement eliminating short- and medium-range nuclear arms.

title: IRENE H. WATTS
description: Irene H. Watts, a onetime ballerina of the New York stage and a patron of music in New Jersey for many years, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday at Evergreen Hospital in Kirkland, Wash. A resident of Mountain Lakes, N.J., she had been visiting in Seattle. She was 88 years old. Mrs. Watts was the daughter of Gustave Hinrichs, a conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra and of the Metropolitan Opera Company at the turn of the century, and of Katherine Fleming, a contralto who sang at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: U.S.-Japan Tensions Over Trade Said to Imperil Security
description: Economic tensions between the United States and Japan are threatening to undermine their security relationship, a study issued today by the Council on Foreign Relations says.

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $685,000 and $152,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: A Different View Of 'Cosmo Woman'
description: Hearst's gold mine, Cosmopolitan, is looking to attract manufacturers of things other than beauty and fashion products. It hopes to achieve that goal through a campaign addressed to the advertising community.

title: Cannon Group Reports Loss
description: The financially troubled Cannon Group Inc. confirmed in a delayed report today that it had not alleviated its cash crisis in the first quarter of its fiscal year, which ended April 4.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: August in the nation's capital.

title: Sports People; Auburn Decision
description: An academic honesty committee at Auburn University recommended last night that Jeff Burger, the senior quarterback, be suspended for two quarters and receive an ''F'' for plagiarism, knocking him out of his final year of eligibility. The committee, made up of four professors and three students, earlier recommended that Burger be suspended for three quarters based on allegations of plagiarism in a psychology class paper at the university. Burger said he would appeal the recommendation to higher university officials. Burger's attorney, Robert Sasser of Montgomery, Ala., said the quarterback did not attend the initial meeting in which the suspension was recommended and that the plagiarism charge was unfounded. Burger, a 22-year-old from Cedartown, Ga., led Auburn to a 10-2 record last season.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $2,129,000 and $2,313,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Britain Is Investigating Arms Sales to the Gulf
description: Customs authorities said today that they were questioning dozens of British companies suspected of having violated the Government's embargo on arms sales to Iran and Iraq.

title: Film: Basinger and Bridges in 'Nadine'
description: NADINE and Vernon Hightower are Splitsville. The time is the early 1950's, but theirs is not a separation that would interest Walter Winchell. It's not even news in Austin, Tex., where Nadine is a hairdresser in the Alamo Beauty Shop and Vernon runs a losing proposition called the Bluebonnet Lounge, the sort of roadhouse that does six dollars and change on a busy night.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Steps Forward and Back; Dog Days
description: The pooper-scooper law: despite uniform cynical predictions, New Yorkers responded to this 1978 ordinance with astonishing compliance. All over the city, dog walkers promptly produced little shovels, Baggies and old newspapers and picked up their dogs' droppings. Strollers found that they could raise their sights.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Martin No Longer in a Rush to Retire
description: In years past, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants would sit down with George Martin at the end of a season and persuade him to play pro football one more year. Last February, only days after the Giants won Super Bowl XXI, the tables were turned.

title: Sports of the Times; Fighting Crime on the Mound
description: Justice was swift, if a bit lenient.

title: Charges About Drugs and Other Crimes by the Police Shake Rockland Town
description: Some residents of Clarkstown, a cluster of hamlets and villages in southern Rockland County, still remember it as a small postwar town - before the expansion of the Palisades Interstate Parkway and before the construction of the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Meeting Urged At Allegheny
description: The New York-based brokerage Spear Leeds & Kellogg, which holds a large stake of Allegheny International Inc. preferred shares, has requested that the Pittsburgh-based manufacturer hold a special meeting of preferred shareholders.

title: ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: More Belgian Jobless
description: Belgium's unemployment rate rose to 12.2 percent in July, from 11.1 percent the previous month, the National Labor Office said today. Last month, 515,037 people were out of work, up from 466,106 in June.

title: NASH FINCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing McGirt Stops Brown: James (Buddy) McGirt, a junior welterweight ranked No. 2 by the World Boxing Council and the International Boxing Federation, knocked out Roger Brown at 1:05 of the fifth round of a scheduled 10-round fight at the Felt Forum last night. McGirt, who is from Brentwood, L.I., dominated from the opening round. He repeatedly hurt Brown with left hooks to the body. But it was a right hand to the jaw that got Brown in trouble.

title: CONFEREES PRESS FOR DEFICIT PLAN
description: House and Senate negotiators, hoping to begin their summer recess at the end of the week, struggled today to reach a compromise on a method of making automatic cuts in Government spending when the deficit is too high.

title: Dream Boats
description: The northeast corner of Central Park inspires many daydreams. Shining through the decay and pollution are all the elements of an elegant water concourse in Central Park. Visions come naturally of rowing on the lake, strolls by the shore, meeting friends in an open-air cafe.

title: U.S., Japan in Supercomputer Accord
description: Japan and the United States have resolved most of their dispute over the Japanese Government's unwillingness to purchase American-made supercomputers, officials said today.

title: MESABA AVIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Fed Approves Bank Ventures
description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved applications by J. P. Morgan & Company and the Security Pacific National Bank for investment advisory and brokerage services.

title: Disputed Alzheimer's Drug Faces New Tests
description: A clinical trial of an experimental drug that has shown some promise of reducing memory loss in victims of Alzheimer's disease, but whose value has been sharply questioned by many experts, was announced today by top Federal health officials.

title: FERRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KRUG INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: New World Tender For Kenner Parker
description: New World Entertainment Ltd., heating up its takeover battle with Kenner Parker Toys Inc., said today that it would begin a $41-a-share tender offer for the nation's third-largest toy maker.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AFTER nearly a year of delays, David Bouley, who garnered a large following as the first chef at Montrachet in TriBeCa, opened his own restaurant last night. Called Bouley, at 165 Duane Street, it is rustically elegant in the French Provencal-style, featuring a 14-foot-high barrel-vaulted ceiling, whitewashed walls and antique carved doors from France.

title: Mercantile House Gets Rival Bids
description: Quadrex Holdings, a London-based Eurobond and brokerage house run by the American financier Gary Klesch, announced an offer of $:530 million ($832 million) for Mercantile House Holdings P.L.C. The British financial services company is already the subject of a bid of $:490 million ($770 million) by British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C., a British holding company with wide-ranging interests.

title: Ingersoll to Buy New Jersey Paper
description: The Ingersoll Publications Company, a rapidly expanding newspaper chain, announced an agreement yesterday to acquire The Morristown Daily Record in New Jersey from the Tomlinson family, which has owned the paper since it was founded in 1900.

title: KEY RATES
PERRY ROBINSON
description: Perry Robinson, a clarinetist, leads a quartet Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 9 and 10 P.M.; there is a $10 Cover and a $7.50 minimun.

title: Baseball; Tudor Gains First Victory in 3 1/2 Months
description: John Tudor pitched four-hit ball over five and two-thirds innings tonight for his first victory after more than three months on the disabled list with a broken leg as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-2.

title: Film: 'Care Bears' Adventure'
description: I'VE seen many drawings of the Mad Hatter, from Tenniel's classic to Disney's cartoon, but never dreamed he resembled a gnome and was the exact color of Pepto-Bismol. That's how he looks, though, in ''The Care Bears' Adventure in Wonderland,'' the third feature film starring characters who started out as toys and became sincere cutesy-poo cartoons.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $558,000 for the quarter and $959,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $574,000 for the quarter and $435,000 for the year. The company said about $3,266,000, or $1.01 a share, of the prior year's net income is attributable to the receipt of life insurance proceeds, net of provision for retirement and related settlements and applicable income tax benefits.

SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

TAP-DANCING AND CALYPSO AT LINCOL CENTER
description: IN 1971, a brief ''street theater festival'' made its debut at Lincoln Center. This grab bag of the arts was an idealistic effort to broaden the constituency of America's largest performing-arts center. Over the years, the al fresco festival - which was renamed Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors in 1974 - has grown from a seat-of-the-pants production to a nearly half-million-dollar, populist extravaganza that includes 27 days and nights of entertainment in Damrosch Park and the other plazas of Lincoln Center.

title: Farm Credit Bill Advances
description: The House Agriculture Committee has approved a sweeping restructuring of the farm lending system in what could ultimately be a huge Federal bailout.

title: Bonds Drop in Light Trading
description: Government bond prices ended slightly lower yesterday as dealers and investors remained on the sidelines awaiting word from the Treasury on the August refunding schedule.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports People; Hearns Gives Up Title
description: Thomas Hearns wants to be the World Boxing Council's middleweight champion and, according to his manager-trainer, no longer considers himself the W.B.C. light heavyweight titleholder. Responding to a W.B.C. ultimatum, Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager and trainer, said in a telephone interview with The Associated Press yesterday that ''Tommy has definitely given up the light-heavyweight title. We already assumed it was known.'' It had already been announced that Hearns would try to become the first man to win four titles by fighting Juan Domingo Roldan for the vacant W.B.C. middleweight championship Oct. 29 in Las Vegas, Nev. On Wednesday, the W.B.C. announced in Mexico City that a Hearns-Roldan match would not be sanctioned unless Hearns relinquished the light-heavyweight title. ''The only thing he's interested in is going for that fourth title,'' Steward said, adding he would send a telegram to the W.B.C. Hearns, a former World Boxing Association welterweight and former W.B.C. superwelterweight champion, won the W.B.C. light heavyweight title by stopping Dennis Andries of Britain in the 10th round March 7 in Detroit. The W.B.C. middleweight title became vacant when Sugar Ray Leonard retired after upsetting Marvelous Marvin Hagler on a 12-round split decision April 6 in Las Vegas.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Sun Rhythm Section, the Lone Star Cafe, Fifth Avenue and 13th Street (242-1664). Rockabilly fans, and knowledgeable rock-and-rollers, know these musicians individually as names on dozens of classic recording sessions, from the Johnny Burnette Trio's ''Tear It Up'' to Billy Lee Riley's ''Flying Saucers Rock-and-Roll.'' One of the group's guitarists, Sonny Burgess, flamed through the 50's singing ''Red Headed Woman'' with his hair dyed fire-engine red to match his clothes and his guitar. Stan Kesler, a Fender bassist, wrote songs for Elvis and produced Sam the Sham and the Pharaohs' ''Woolly Bully.'' One could go on forever, but history is almost superfluous here; this band is playing inspired, incendiary rock-and-roll right now. The show is tomorrow at around 9:30 P.M.; there is a $10 cover charge.

title: 10,000 Come to Times Square To See Madonna at Premiere
description: When she arrived in New York in the summer of 1978, a dancer named Madonna Louise Veronica Ciccone told a cabdriver to drop her off ''in the middle of everything.'' The driver, she said, took her to Times Square.

title: SAUL, B F REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $200,000. c-Net income and includes a $357,000 tax credit for both periods.

title: Film: 'Girl,' A Swedish Melodrama
description: THE devil is a woman, still.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Telegrams Are on the Wane
description: During the Iran-contra hearings on Capitol Hill, the telegrams stacked in front of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified to his fame. But aside from major national and international events that inspire members of the public to wire messages, the business of sending telegrams is declining.

title: PACIFICORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
British Publisher Has Elsevier Stake
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell said he wants to discuss cooperation, or even a merger, with Elsevier N.V., the second biggest publisher in the Netherlands. Mr. Maxwell said his company, the British Printing and Communication Corporation, had bought an 8.5 percent stake in Elsevier, which recently lost a battle to acquire a rival publishing company in the Netherlands.

title: Air Merger Is Delayed In Britain
description: British Airways said today that it would pursue its planned merger with British Caledonian Airways, although the deal will be delayed by the Government's decision to refer the agreement to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission.

title: Iran-Contra Figure Besieged by Debt
description: The once-thriving conservative fund-raising network operated by Carl R. Channell, who is awaiting sentencing for conspiracy in the Iran-contra affair, is plagued by severe financial troubles.

title: Bush's 'Main Event'
description: The George Bush Presidential campaign may appear to be in full swing, but the Vice President has been keeping his public waiting for ''the main event,'' his formal announcement.

title: Different Games, New Heroes Where Rockne Once Reigned
description: No longer on the sidelines, they stood in their own kind of winner's circle today, in the land of Rockne and the Gipper and the Four Horsemen, listening to the roar of the crowd.

title: Shultz Says European Allies Are Weighing Aid on Mines
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that European allies are considering ways of cooperating in American minesweeping efforts in the Persian Gulf, an apparent shift in the allies' previous rejections of requests for such assistance.

title: Outdoors, Confines of Stage Are Lifted
description: Performances out of doors and in unusual concert spaces offer audiences a chance to savor the weather and enjoy a rare feeling of relaxation that sets in on summer weekends in the city. Such events can also give performers and producers a new or renewed sense of their art.

title: Black Doctors Endorse Mandatory AIDS Tests
description: The nation's oldest organization of black doctors has endorsed mandatory AIDS testing for donors of blood, organs and tissue, and for military personnel and immigrants, but not for all hospital patients and marriage applicants.

title: ON WEST 89TH ST., LIVES REFLECT UPHEAVAL
description: Nowhere is the recent transformation of upper Broadway more visible, and more deeply felt, than along the two block stretch between 88th and 90th Streets.

title: Bank Board Bond Plans
description: A funding corporation set up by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board will begin issuing long-term bonds to the public and use the proceeds to shut or sell off insolvent thrift institutions in late September, the new chairman of the agency, M. Danny Wall, said today.

title: Iran's 'Spasm' And Oil Prices
description: HOW serious are the risks of a war in the Middle East that would close the Persian Gulf and send oil prices spiraling upward? The Iranian leaders have been making threats that have caused the oil market to shiver and shake.

title: Statue of Truman in Athens, Bombed in 1986, Is Restored
description: A statue of President Harry S. Truman was restored to its original site today by the Socialist Government, a year and a half after the statue was bombed by a group protesting what it called American imperialism in Greece.

title: CHRIS ISAAK
description: Chris Isaak leads his rockabilly band tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, near Broadway (228-7880). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $12.50.

title: Continental's Pact at Newark
description: Continental Airlines signed a 25-year agreement today with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to complete and operate Terminal C at Newark International Airport.

title: CANNON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: The company said first quarter revenue was more than double the revenue in the year-ago quarter and included revenue from assets acquired in the purchase of the screen entertainment division of Thorn EMI in May 1986. The company declined to provide comparative results for the year-ago period; it was determined that it is impracticable to restate its financial statements for the period due to constraints of time, costs and availability of accounting records.

title: Conyers v. Abrams
description: Representative John Conyers Jr. plans to introduce a resolution of impeachment against Elliott Abrams, asserting that the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs violated the law by deceiving Congressional committees about aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: Faulting the Iran-Contra Committees
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North has become a hero to many Americans. Polls even have shown strong support for a Presidential pardon. All this is apparently due to Colonel North's performance under fire. But things might have been far different if the House and Senate committees investigating the Iran-contra affair had been tougher and more thorough.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 7, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Rock Buccaneers Roll to Stamp Out Stagnant Radio
description: Let's face it, the world loves a nice pirate. Ever since the F.C.C. boarded an old tanker anchored four miles off Long Island last week and shut down Radio Newyork International, the young rock 'n' roll pirates have been having the time of their lives. Talk show requests; an MTV appearance this Sunday afternoon; interviews coming out of their ears.

title: New Blood and Continuity at the Fed
description: Alan Greenspan, about to take over at the Federal Reserve, will quickly be tested - to squeeze or ease credit, to react to higher oil prices, to rule on the Piggy Bank & Trust Co. merger. Urgent as his response will be, he has the chair well into the next Presidency. The Greenspan mark will be made on long-term issues, where he must focus early.

description: In the circle of energy lenders, the Hibernia Corporation stands out as the exception of 1987.

description: A new exhibition center for contemporary art is to open Oct. 8 in a renovated building at 548 West 22d Street. The center is a project of the Dia Foundation, a private organization that sponsors venturesome artists' works. The foundation was established in 1974 by Philippa de Menil Friedrich, the daughter of the art patron Dominique de Menil and Heiner Friedrich, a former art dealer.

title: Boss Rings Only Once
description: Lou Piniella says George Steinbrenner isn't talking to him. But when Steinbrenner called the other day in Cleveland, Piniella wasn't there to answer his phone. His failure to be in his hotel room cost him a catcher he had been seeking for three weeks.

title: Queens Man Slain Near Shooting Rampage Site
description: A 29-year-old man was fatally wounded yesterday afternoon when four gunmen in a brown Cadillac opened fire on him in the South Jamaica section of Queens, the police said.

title: Walsh Talks With Israel Stall; Court Action Is Considered
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and the Israeli Government have failed to reach an out-of-court resolution of a dispute over whether Israeli citizens may be required to answer questions about their involvement in the Iran arms sales, officials close to the investigation said today.

title: Grumman Wins Fighter Contract
description: The Air Force has selected the Grumman Corporation as the prime contractor for a previously announced deal with China to upgrade that country's aging F-8 jet fighters with new electronic equipment. The company, based in Bethpage, L.I., was awarded two contracts totaling $245 million, calling for new avionics and weapons-control equipment for the Chinese-built F-8's.

title: TRENWICK GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Britain's Social Democrats Vote To Merge With the Liberal
description: The rank and file of the Social Democratic Party, begun six years ago as a moderate ''fresh start'' in British politics, has voted to merge with the Liberal Party, its electoral partner.

title: CAROLE P. BANNETT
description: Carole P. Bannett, a housewares retailer and an associate of Lee Bailey, the designer and author, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 59 years old. A prominent figure in the New York housewares business for many years, Mrs. Bannett also was active in several civic organizations, including the 79th Street Block Association.

title: LEINER, P NUTRITIONAL PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Give Peace A Chance
description: In the last couple of days, this important political message has been delivered to those Americans paying attention:

title: House Panel Hears From Experts on AIDS
description: Experts at a House subcommittee hearing today recommended several steps to stem the AIDS epidemic, including voluntary testing and isolation of victims. One doctor said an AIDS victim seated next to him should be quarantined.

title: Indian Player Overcame Obstacles to Win U.S. Title
description: If a young player arrives at an American national championship from abroad, his chance of making his mark in a major team championship is small. If he has no partner and no team and does not know any leading American players, that chance goes down virtually to zero.

title: Tough Odds for Hambletonian Defender
description: Ulf Thoresen of Norway had never attended a Hambletonian before he drove Nuclear Kosmos to victory at the Meadowlands last year in the most prestigious event in harness racing.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Broadway
description: Sophocles Per Pound

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 7, 1987
description: International A2-11

title: President's Nose 'Terrific'
description: President Reagan may have surgical stitches removed from his nose on Friday, his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today. ''The Presidential nose is terrific,'' Mr. Fitzwater said after an assessment by Col. John Hutton, Mr. Reagan's personal physician. Doctors cut a nearly half-inch skin cancer from Mr. Reagan's nose last Friday and closed the wound with 20 stiches.

title: GUILTY PLEA FILED IN WEDTECH CASE
description: A former United States postal inspector agreed to plead guilty yesterday to charges of accepting $20,000 in bribes from the Wedtech Corporation in connection with two contracts the company obtained to manufacture mail containers.

title: Sports People; Soto Starts Back
description: Mario Soto made his first minor league start Wednesday night in Florida as part of an injury rehabilitation assignment aimed at getting him back to the Cincinnati Reds. Soto pitched five innings for the Reds' Sarasota farm club in the Gulf Coast rookie league, allowing two hits and one unearned run against the Dodgers' Sarasota team. He walked none and struck out two. Soto is on a 20-day medical rehabilitation program. He had surgery last August to remove bone spurs from his right shoulder, and started this season on the disabled list. He was activated April 20 and made six starts, going 3-2 with a 5.12 earned run average. Soto complained of shoulder soreness and was put back on the disabled list.

title: Article 875987 -- No Title
description: A gift of $10 million has been pledged to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Milton J. Petrie, chairman of the Petrie Stores Corporation, a chain of retail stores specializing in women's apparel.

title: Behind Issue of Soviet Compliance
description: With President Reagan in need of a political lift, White House officials have been savoring the prospect of a new arms treaty and a summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: In Alabama, Talk of President's Men Yields to the Intrigue of Soap Operas
description: When Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified at the Iran-contra hearings in Washington last month, two correspondents of The New York Times visited Oregon, Ill, and Anniston, Ala., to see how people in two towns reacted to him. The reporters returned to those towns this week and took their pulse again.

title: Del E. Webb
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation said that it had held talks with two major stockholders who were considering seeking control of the company, but that no agreements were reached and no further meetings are scheduled. Webb, a developer of retirement communities, real estate and gambling properties, last month said it was considering a restructuring or the sale of assets because of a looming write-down of $60 million on its casinos.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''The World of John Wallowitch,''

title: A&E OFFERS 'LEADING LADIES OF ENTERTAINMENT
description: LOOKING for a packaging gimmick to get through the summer doldrums, cable's Arts & Entertainment network has come up with a salute to the ''Leading Ladies of Entertainment.'' Included is everyone from Marlene Dietrich in ''Knight Without Armor'' to Phyllis Diller as the host of ''A Night at the Improv.'' This evening at 8 o'clock, the spotlight is on Faye Dunaway.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Howe Called Up by Rangers
description: Steve Howe, who had been suspended in the past from both the major and minor leagues for cocaine use, was called up by the Texas Rangers today. The move came without a public statement by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, who had discussed the move Wednesday with team officials.

title: 'The Presidential Mind'
description: What was President Reagan thinking when his Administration took the actions that exploded into the Iran-contra affair? That's not the same question as whether he ''knew'' about the diversion of Iran arms sale profits to the Nicaraguan rebels, but it's a critical question nonetheless.

title: Koch Suffers Spasm in an Artery, Enters Hospital and Is Called Well
description: Mayor Koch was hospitalized yesterday morning, suffering from nausea, dizziness and slightly slurred speech. After a full day of tests, doctors said he appeared to have suffered a mild spasm of an artery in his brain and had made a complete recovery.

title: CAVORTING ON THE GREAT URBAN STAIRCASES
description: THERE are few things in architecture as wonderful as monumental staircases, and they are as much a thing of the past as gas lamps. They are simply not made anymore, and probably never will be again, despite the growing interest in the Beaux-Arts, in classicism and in all the architectural ideas that the kind of buildings that do have great stairs represent.

title: Governor of Vermont To Shun Senate Race
description: Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin announced today that she would seek a third two-year term next year instead of running for the United States Senate, saying, ''I am not ready to move on.''

title: LIPOSOME TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Iran said today that it had extended its naval manuevers in strategic areas of the Persian Gulf.

title: FILM FESTIVAL FAVORITES: FIRST 24 YEARS
description: Film addicts being as passionate about their favorites as any opera-house claque, there will probably be as many cavils as ticket buyers during the New York Film Festival retrospective that begins tonight at Alice Tully Hall. But the 47 films to be shown until Aug. 25 are an impressive representation - ''sort of a Chinese menu,'' said the program director of Lincoln Center, William W. Lockwood Jr. - of the festival's first 24 years.

title: Step by Step Toward Welfare Reform
description: LEAD: For two decades, welfare reform - chiefly the overhaul of the Aid for Families with Dependent Children program - has been the Mount Everest of domestic public policy. Several Presidents have failed to reach the summit, and now Congress is preparing a new expedition.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $26,899,000 for the quarter and $53,458,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized capital gains of $8,245,000 and $20,647,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.
