The company also said the latest second quarter includes a ''fresh start'' tax benefit which reduced the provision for income taxes by about $27,000,000, or 16 cents a share.

description: Voters in this island state have voted decisively to drop their antinuclear status in exchange for what their President calls economic survival.

Film: 'Happy New Year'
description: HAPPY NEW YEAR'' didn't look very original or very funny back in 1973, when the original French film, written and directed by Claude Lelouch, opened in New York. The curious thing about the American remake, opening today at the Quad and New Carnegie Cinemas, is that although it's no better, it's certainly not worse.

title: Iran-Contra Panels Are Continuing Their Inquiry, Official Says
description: The chairman of the House committee on the Iran-contra affair said today that the staffs of the select committees had not finished their investigation and would continue to pursue leads in the weeks before a final report in October.

title: Art: Public Sculpture as City Companion
description: AS much as any public art project in recent memory, the fine-arts program of the Battery Park City Authority has been perceived as a model. Announced in 1983 for the new 92-acre development in lower Manhattan, it has an advisory committee of distinguished art professionals. Scott Burton and Siah Armajani are two sculptors who have been involved in the planning and design of the World Financial Plaza. Ned Smyth, Richard Artschwager, Mary Miss, R. M. Fischer and Jennifer Bartlett, artists, have been commissioned to make large-scale works for sites alongside the Hudson River.

The latest quarter quarter includes $2,282,000, or 47 cents a share, as a result of a previously announced modification of the payment schedule of the agreement coverning the January 1984 sale of Curtiss-Wright's rotary engine business to Deere & Co. Year-ago 6-month includes gains of $1,120,000, or 23 cents a share, as a result of two unrelated real estate transactions.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

title: Steelworkers Back LTV Pact
description: Steelworkers at the LTV Corporation approved a contract yesterday that restores supplemental pension benefits to about 8,000 employees who retired early. The vote averted a threatened strike but intensified a struggle with the Federal agency that pays LTV's regular pensions.

title: Police Go to Baltimore To Interview Suspect
description: Two New York City police detectives left for Baltimore yesterday to interview a woman sought in connection with the abduction of a 20-day-old infant from Harlem Hospital Tuesday, a police spokesman said.

title: Simon: Trying to Update Party's Ideal of Concern
description: The older man with the bow tie and horn-rimmed glasses seemed out of place at the waterfront bistro, with its dusty peach walls and heavy beamed ceilings, where the crowd leaned toward the young, the affluent and the trendy.

title: U.S. Accuses 2 Of Tampering With Witnesses
description: A Federal complaint filed yesterday in Brooklyn charged a Queens lawyer and his son with attempting to influence witnesses called before a Federal grand jury that was investigating aspects of New York City's municipal corruption scandal.

title: Folks in Tokyo Want Their Share of the Miracle
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Eagle Returns,' A Documentary on 13
description: The bald eagle is doing reasonably well in Florida; it may not prevail but it seems to endure. ''The Eagle Returns'' offers a reason why: injured, sick or even lost and lonely eagles are befriended by people. The respectably done half-hour documentary can be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tomorrow night.

title: Farm Pact in Midwest Portends Industry Shift
description: A migrant farm workers union, 20 Ohio growers and Vlasic Foods Inc. today signed the latest in a series of novel labor contracts that could reshape the Middle West's vegetable industries and cause repercussions in supermarkets and other farm states.

title: Ex-Principal Guilty of Molesting 6 Teen-Age Boys
description: The former principal of a private high school in Montgomery County, Md., who faked his own death while under investigation 17 years ago and fled the country under child abuse charges earlier this year, has pleaded guilty to molesting six teen-age boys he met through the Big Brother program.

title: Soviet Scientist Is Said to Request Asylum in U.S. After Leaving Ship
description: A Soviet citizen has sought asylum here and has been turned over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service pending an investigation, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: EMPI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a one-time expense of $40,000 associated with staff reduction.

title: McCallum Wants Out
description: Napoleon McCallum, eager to continue his career with the Los Angeles Raiders, is considering making a request that the Navy allow him to resign from full-time duty and place him on reserve status, his agent said today.

title: The Insurers and the Trustbusters
description: Senator Howard Metzenbaum thinks insurance should be subject to the Federal antitrust laws, and cites the recent explosion in liability premiums as evidence of the need to end the industry's exemption from Federal regulation. He's right to call for a critical look at the unique exemption provided by the McCarran-Ferguson Act. But the liability insurance crisis won't be ended - or even greatly mitigated - by the law's repeal. That requires a basic change in liability awards by the courts. A more realistic goal is to bring the modest, long-term benefits of more aggressive marketing of insurance to states now burdened by anti-competitive regulation.

title: In Marine's Spy Case, A Plea of Not Guilty
description: Marine Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree pleaded not guilty today to charges he funneled United States secrets to the Soviet Union, and prosecutors said they plan to introduce evidence they said will show the former Moscow Embassy guard is anti-American.

title: Crimean Tatars Unjustly Accused
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE CENTRAL AMERICAN PRESIDENTS AGREE ON A TENTATIVE PEACE PLAN
description: The presidents of five Central American countries today signed a preliminary accord intended to resolve conflicts in the region.

title: U.S., Japan Finish Trade Pact
description: The United States and Japan, seeking to head off an escalating high-technology trade war, exchanged letters today formally acknowledging an agreement intended to make it easier for American manufacturers to sell supercomputer in Japan.

title:
PATENTS;
Apparatus For Brain Diagnosis
description: LEAD: STAFF members at the HZI Research Center in Tarrytown, N.Y., were granted a patent this week for a method and apparatus to conduct brain function diagnostic tests. The patent covers operation of the headset that the company manufactures for medical use.

title: KRELITZ INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net loss Comparable periods reflect the change in the company's fiscal year- end to April from December.

title: Manville Fails in Suit of U.S.
description: The Manville Corporation, now in bankruptcy proceedings, has lost its bid to get the Government to reimburse it for damages the company paid to individuals exposed to asbestos in Government shipyards during World War II.

title: INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EARTHWORM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company changed its name to Earthworm Inc. from Earthworm Tractor Co.

title: Camille Nimer Chamoun, 87; A Lebanese Leader 43 Years
description: Camille Nimer Chamoun, former President of Lebanon, a prominent Christian leader who survived four attempts to kill him in a political career over five decades, died in a hospital today of a heart attack. He was 87 years old.

title: Donation in Japan
description: Bob Horner, slugging for a Japanese team, has marked his 30th birthday with a donation to a Japanese medical research foundation. Horner, a former Atlanta Braves star, donated $33,300 to the Japan Intractable Diseases Research Foundation in a ceremony at the clubhouse of the Yakult Swallows, his team in Japan.

title: NORTHEASTERN MORTGAGE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax net gain of $2,002,217 on the sale of loan servicing rights. Share earnings reflect a 10-percent stock dividend paid in February 1987.

title: CORRECTION
description: A schedule in Weekend yesterday with an article on the New York Film Festival's 25th-anniversary retrospective at Alice Tully Hall gave incorrect ticket prices. Tickets are $5, or $4 each with an order of eight or more. For members of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and Lincoln Center associates, tickets are $4.50, or $3.50 each with an order of eight or more.

title: Soviet Is Reported to Deploy a Rail-Mobile Missile
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said on the floor of the Senate today that the Soviet Union had begun to deploy the new SS-24 intercontinental nuclear missile, the first that can be moved on and fired from rail cars.

title: Surely Not Cigar-Shaped!
description: They'll never get the world right.

title: CDC LIFE SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: At Four New Boutiques, A Fresh View of Classics
description: Fashions come and fashions go. One season it's androgyny and the next it's bustiers. Keeping up with these vicissitudes is difficult for designers and merchants alike, except for those who choose to stay out of the fray by sticking with the classics. The classics go on year after year, virtually unchanged, and always seem to find an audience.

title: MANUFACTURED HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kenner Bid Halted
description: A Massachusetts Superior Court judge has temporarily blocked New World Entertainment Ltd. from making a $401.8 million tender offer for Kenner Parker Toys Inc., based in Beverly, Mass. The judge also blocked Los Angeles-based New World from acquiring more Kenner Parker stock and from taking any other action to gain control of Kenner Parker. The rule was based on a decade-old Massachusetts law that prohibits a suitor from seeking control of a company for a year if it acquires more than 5 percent of the target's stock before indicating it plans to make a tender offer.

title: VENEZUELA FREES CUBAN EMIGRE
description: Orlando Bosch, a Cuban emigre leader who served nearly 11 years in prison on charges of planning the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner despite repeated acquittals, was released tonight.

title: Yanks: From Bad to Worse to 2d
description: For three days, the Yankees teetered. Finally, they fell.

title: Matsushita's U.S. Plan
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company is considering making color television tubes in the United States, a company spokesman said today.

title: ENERGY FACTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: New York Still Needs Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Begin Marks 74th Birthday
description: Israel's former Prime Minister, Menachem Begin, celebrated his 74th birthday by receiving Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today but gave no sign of ending his four years of seclusion. ''He is fine, thank God,'' said Mr. Begin's personal secretary, Yechiel Kadishai, adding that he had no idea if Mr. Begin, Israel's Prime Minister from 1977 to 1983, would ever return to public life. Mr. Kadishai said Mr. Shamir visited for an hour.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Mets, Darling Keep Surging
description: His season has been a capsule version of what has happened to the Mets, adversity leading to frustration, but never silencing the expectation that things would get much better before the National League East pennant was decided. Now, Ron Darling and the Mets are enjoying a resurgence that has seen them enter the race, not just with tough talk, but with deeds, too.

description: President Reagan announced new procedures today that he said he would follow for informing Congress about covert operations, including a commitment to notify legislators within 48 hours in most cases after a new operation is started.

description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, warmly embraced the five-nation peace agreement for Central America today. His action could increase the pressure on the Reagan Administration to support a plan that differs significantly from its own peace proposal.

description: Former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, who was once accused by the United States of being a war criminal and later fought for the treaty that governs American-Japanese security relations, died today in a Tokyo hospital after months of illness. He was 90 years old.

title: Advances in Salvaging Raise New Legal Issue
description: A dispute over the salvaging of a historic shipwreck 160 miles off North Carolina may become the vehicle for deciding a novel legal issue, created by technological advances, that could be of increasing importance in coming years.

description: A public relations consultant was found guilty yesterday of collaborating with Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, in soliciting a $250,000 bribe for the awarding of a cable-television franchise in Queens.

title: How to Cork a Bat: The Inside Story
description: In recent years in baseball, doctored bats have not been as prominent as doctored balls. Perhaps that's because it's harder to detect something that is inside a bat than something that is on the outside of a ball. Doctoring a bat is also more difficult than doctoring a ball.

description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $41,804,708 for the quarter and $65,919,137 for the 6 months. The company said it sold all of its operations on Dec. 31, 1986. Thus, its only revenue for 1987, totaling $644,305, was interest on short-term investments.

Soviet-Chinese Border Talks
description: A Soviet delegation arrived here today for a second round of talks on resolving disputes over the 4,650-mile Chinese-Soviet border. The first round was held in Moscow in February.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a former postal employee who agreed to plead guilty to charges of accepting a bribe from the Wedtech Corporation misstated his former job with the Postal Service. The employee, Jerrydoe E. Smith, had been a contract specialist in the Postal Operations Procurement Division.

title:
PATENTS;
Chinese Characters Encoded for Computers
description: LEAD: A system for encoding Chinese characters and a keyboard for such use were patented this week by Wang Yong-Min of the Computation Center in Henan province, China. According to patent 4,684,926, Chinese characters and phrases can be stored in computers of any size as well as in systems for Chinese information processing and communications.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect Empire's investment in Deltona Corp. using the equity method of accounting.

title: Terrorists Kill 25 in Punjab; Curfew in Sikh City
description: Terror ists have killed at least 25 people in the Punjab in the last two days, the authorities said, and a curfew was ordered today at the Sikh holy city of Amritsar after Hindu relatives of the victims rioted.

title: Stanford Files Order
description: Stanford University has filed for a temporary restraining order against the National Collegiate Athletic Association drug-testing program.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 8, 1987
description: International 2-5,28 Information on intelligence matters will be shared with Congress through new procedures, including a commitment to notify legislators within 48 hours after a new operation is started, President Reagan said. Page 1 A preliminary Latin peace accord was agreed upon and signed by the Presidents of the five major Central American countries. The proposal requires follow-up negotiations. 1 Jim Wright embraced the accord, raising pressure on the Administration to support a plan that differs from its own peace proposal. Mr. Wright, the Speaker of the House, termed the tentative pact ''a very positive step.'' 4 U.S. consultations on a resolution at the United Nations Security Council have begun, officials said. The resolution would seek to impose an arms embargo on Iran for the continuation of the Iran-Iraq war. 3 Sri Lanka will ask India to withdraw its forces before the end of the month if the situation in the country remains stable, President J. R. Jayewardene said in an interview. 2 A divestment from South Africa was announced by Standard Chartered P.L.C. of Britain. The sale for the equivalent of $254 million is the largest ever by a foreign corporation. 33 U.S. and Soviet arms negotiators will step up their work in an effort to narrow differences on reducing nuclear missiles before the planned meeting between their foreign ministers in Washington, officials said. 28 Moslems returning from Mecca to Cairo said that Iranian demonstrators who rioted there carried knives and Molotov cocktails and that hundreds of people were killed in a stampede as the Iranians attacked the Saudi police. 3 In India, terrorists killed at least 25 people in the Punjab in the last two days, and the authorities ordered a curfew at the Sikh holy city of Amritsar after Hindu relatives of the victims rioted. 2 The scarcest single ticket in England is for an opera seat at the converted Glyndebourne estate house and, more particularly, at the acclaimed production of ''Porgy and Bess'' that reopened for eight performances. 5 Runaway Soviet locomotive crashes into passenger train 2 Syria tries to calm Saudis and Iran on Mecca riot 3 Managua journal 4 Marine in spy case pleas not guilty 5 National 6-9 The nation's jobless rate fell in July below 6 percent for the first time since 1979, Government figures showed. Analysts said the array of monthly statistics were encouraging and pointed to a quickened pace of economic expansion. 1 Labor economists continue to worry that despite the landmark dip in unemployment, most new jobs tend to pay lower wages, carry fewer benefits and create a more unstable labor environment. 9 A definition of insider trading was offered by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which asked Congress to outlaw the use of confidential corporate information to buy and sell stocks and other securities. 1 A dispute over salvage efforts on a wreck 160 miles off Cape Fear, N.C., may become the vehicle for deciding a legal issue: jurisdiction over wrecks in international waters. 6 The House and the Senate delayed the effort to reach a compromise on a proposal to reinvigorate the budget-balancing law and prepared to leave for the four week-summer recess. 8 The television evangelist Jim Bakker and his top associate refused to defend themselves at proceedings that led to their ouster as ministers of the denomination, the chief officer of the Assemblies of God said. 6 College tuition this fall will rise faster than the inflation rate for the seventh straight year, according to a survey that found the total annual cost at one elite school reaching more than $19,000 a year. 6 Pennsylvania Avenue's rebuilding will be completed with a 3-million-square-foot, $370-million trade and cultural center and Federal office building that is to be the crowning jewel of the Federal Triangle. 6 Dole urges AIDS issue to be kept out of 1988 race 8 Soviet scientist said to ask asylum 8 Nuclear plant evacuation plan called inadequate 8 Congressman resist cutting census queries 9 Ceremonies mark dam's 50th year 9 Regional 29-31 Mayor Koch suffered a 'tiny' stroke on Thursday, his doctors concluded after administering new tests requested because he had re-experienced the symptoms that led to his hospitalization Thursday morning. 1 The type of stroke the Mayor had is generally regarded by doctors as having a prognosis of complete recovery, but it could be followed by another stroke. The type of stroke is often called a lacunar. 31 In the Queens cable-television case, a public relations consultant was found guilty of collaborating with Donald R. Manes, the late Queens Borough President, in soliciting a bribe for the awarding of the cable franchise. 1 The collapse of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in April could have been avoided had the New York State Thruway Authority properly inspected and maintained the structure. a new report shows. 1 The X-rays of Howard Johnson's bat were negative. Baseball entered the era of the random bat test as X-rays of the bat used by Johnson to hit his 27th home run of the season did not reveal any foreign substance. 1 An appraisal: Broadway's boom in construction has added sleek glass to the brick and limestone of old Broad way. More important, it has brought large masses of buildings to the uneven skyline of the street. 29 A debate on instituting zoning is being waged in North Canaan, Conn., a commercial and farming town on the Massachusetts border. The issue could end 129 years of unfettered building in the town. 29 An epidemic of salmonella poisoning at Coler Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island has left four patients dead. As many as 70 patients have been placed in intensive care and about 60 staff members have been infected with the bacteria. 29 New York employment rate rises 9 Rockland police chief rejects call to step down 30 City delays Chinatown rent rise 31

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Victory for McEnroe: John McEnroe, seeking his first tournament title since October, convincingly defeated Brad Gilbert, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Volvo International at Stratton Mountain, Vt.

title: Opera: Shostakovich's 'Nose' in Santa Fe
description: ''The Nose,'' Shostakovich's 1930 dramatization of the classic Gogol satire, is hardly contemporary music, but a company steeped only in the traditional repertory would have to stretch to encompass it. The Santa Fe Opera - steeped in Henze, Stravinsky, Eaton and Britten - took it comfortably in stride Wednesday night.

PATENTS;
A Process to Assist In Teaching of English
description: LEAD: Grace Marie Raynor, a retired school teacher who lives in Newhall, Calif., has invented a communications process described as useful in teaching English as a second language and in overcoming illiteracy.

title: U.S. Revokes License of Pilot Whose Jet Plunged
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today revoked the certificate of a Delta Air Lines pilot who was captain of a jet that lost power shortly after takeoff and plunged to 500 feet above the Pacific Ocean in June.

title: 'The Black Bottle' That Halted Pryor
description: A year ago, Aaron Pryor, the former junior welterweight champion, admitted publicly that the rumors he had been addicted to cocaine were true.

title: Blind Sailor Has to Turn Back
description: Jim Dickson, the man seeking become the first blind person to cross the Atlantic Ocean alone, was forced to head for Nantucket, Mass., today for repairs to his sloop.

title: Brain's Resilience a Key To Mayor's Prognosis
description: Doctors regard the type of small stroke Mayor Koch suffered Thursday as generally having a prognosis of complete recovery, but it could be followed by another stroke.

title: Court Overturns McLain Conviction
description: The racketeering conviction of Denny McLain, the last 30-game winner in the major leagues, was overturned today by a Federal appeals court.

title: Food Poisoning Crisis Still Rages at Roosevelt I. Hospital
description: When nurses at Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital began to report that dozens of elderly patients were suffering from nausea, abdominal cramps and high fevers one night last week, it was clear that a major crisis was developing. Dr. Phillipe Tassy, the night-duty physician, quickly suspected an outbreak of food poisoning.

description: b-Includes a loss of $123,700 from discontinued operations and a gain of $224,500 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $51,400 from discontinued operations. The company did not report sales figures for the first quarter of the prior year. All of the company's sales for the year-ago first quarter were from its semiconductor business, which it sold May 4. Last August, the company acquired Adamas Carbide Corp., which is now its primary business.

title: Unexpected Guests Fill Pan Am Rooms
description: With opening ceremonies of the 10th Pan American Games a day away, members of the games' organizing committee wrestled today with the problem of what to do with several hundred athletes and officials they had not expected.

BAKKER'S CHURCH TELLS OF REFUSAL
description: The chief officer of the Assemblies of God said today that the television evangelist Jim Bakker and his top associate refused to defend themselves at proceedings that led to their ouster as ministers of the denomination.

title: Two About Elvis
description: ELVIS WORLD. By Jane and Michael Stern. 210 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $35. THE ELVIS CATALOG. By Lee Cotten. 255 pages. Dolphin/Doubleday & Company. Paperback $17.95, hardcover $35.

title: E.D.S. Unit Wins Big Navy Job
description: The Electronic Data Systems Federal Corporation, a unit of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, has been awarded a military contract estimated by the Navy to be worth $544 million over the 12-year life of the project.

title: Europe Backs Pasta Pact
description: The governments of the 12-nation European Community ratified the pasta settlement with the United States today, an official said. The accord, which eliminates subsidies on half of the pasta the community's member countries export to the United States and reduces subsidies on the remaining half by 27.5 percent, was reached Wednesday. The agreement ended a six-year-old dispute and may have averted a trade war.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: REPORT ON COLLAPSE OF THRUWAY BRIDGE ASSAILS EARLIER STUDY
description: Taking issue with an earlier state report, the New York State Commission of Investigation said today that the collapse of a bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that claimed 10 lives could have been avoided with proper inspections and maintenance.

title: Film: He-Man Seeks Key
description: Off the toy counter and onto the big screen flies He-Man, biceps rippling, pecs glistening, to do battle with evil Skeletor, colored waves flashing from every perverse pore, over who will be master of the universe. Specifically at stake in ''Masters of the Universe,'' which can be found at the Warner and other theaters, is possession of the Cosmic Key, invented by the cute dwarf Gwildor, which can transport you anywhere in any galaxy. He-Man and his allies, Man-at-Arms and Teela, whose close-fitting battle suit reveals almost as much as He-Man's, find themselves in Colby, Calif., where they get involved with a couple of teen-agers and are pursued by Skeletor's minions and a local cop. If you liked the toy, you'll love the movie.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: A Bird? A Plane? Flying Art!
description: A floppy yellow moon, a giant, multicolored sea urchin and a 12-story black cone are expected to glide briefly through the skies above New York Harbor on Tuesday, then vanish as suddenly as they appeared.

title: SYRIA TRIES TO CALM SAUDIS AND IRAN ON MECCA RIOT
description: Syria has begun a mediation effort to ease tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia over the hundreds of deaths in Mecca a week ago. But it reportedly told Teheran that it would side with the Saudis in the event of fighting.

title: Pickens Is Considering A Big Stake in Singer
description: Reaching again for a large military supplier, the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens announced today that his Mesa Limited Partnership owns the equivalent of 4.4 percent of the Singer Company and may buy up to 15 percent of the aerospace and electronics manufacturer.

title: IN DATA THAT APPEAR GOOD SOME DETECT A NEW POVERTY
description: Despite July's landmark dip in unemployment to below 6 percent, some labor economists continue to express concern that most jobs being created, largely in the service sector, tend to pay lower wages and provide fewer benefits than the manufacturing jobs that have been lost in the 1980's.

title: Kidder Acts On Wigton
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company issued a statement yesterday confirming that it had decided to pay all legal bills, back salary and resume the salary of Richard B. Wigton, who had been charged earlier with insider trading.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: DEL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Film: Madonna in 'Who's That Girl'
description: No big-budget movie takes less than two years from the time it's conceived until it arrives, in one form or another, in front of the public. The odd thing about ''Who's That Girl,'' the new comedy starring Madonna, is that it looks as if it might have achieved its fairly modest goals had the people making it spent just 15 more minutes thinking about what they were doing.

title: Pappas Auto Is Found
description: An automobile belonging to the missing wife of Milt Pappas, the former pitcher, was pulled from a shallow pond yesterday in Wheaton, Ill., nearly five years after she disappeared, and a body was found inside, police said.

title: Maynard to Be Honored
description: Don Maynard, a former receiver for the Jets, is among seven stars who will be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame today. Maynard is the second Jet in the hall, joining Joe Namath. The two made up one of the most exciting passing combinations in history, and Maynard finished his career with 11,834 receiving yards and 88 touchdowns.

title: KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reagans Invite Soviet Emigre To Perform at White House
description: Vladimir Feltsman, the Soviet pianist who reached the West Thursday after an eight-year struggle to emigrate, will give a recital at the White House on Sept. 27.

title: Roberto Pane, Art Historian And Expert on Architecture
description: Roberto Pane, an Italian scholar of art and architectural history, died July 28 in Sorrento, Italy. He was 90 years old.

title: Police Chief Rejects a Call To Step Down in Rockland
description: The police chief of Clarkstown, accompanied by an honor guard of his officers, rejected calls for his resignation today. He said demands that he step down in the wake of departmental problems might be politically motivated.

title: Will the Diplomatic Spirits Come?
description: Resolving most international conflicts depends far less on discovering the proper outcome than on bringing it about. Until the spirits to make tough political decisions are awakened, until the stars have been aligned into a well-mapped constellation, all is maneuver or pretense. Consider Nicaragua, the Persian Gulf and the Soviet-American missile pact for Eurasia.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Minnetonka to Sell Liquid Soap Unit
description: LEAD: The Minnetonka Corporation, which pioneered the consumer liquid soap business in 1979, said today that it would sell the business to the Colgate-Palmolive Company. Minnetonka, which also makes Obsession perfume and other consumer products, said it would receive between $60 million and $65 million for the soap business.

title:
PATENTS;
Ship Warning Device
description: LEAD: A proximity warning device for use on ships has been invented for the Department of Transportation. Patent 4,684,949 was granted this week to Rudolph M. Kalafus, an engineer in the department's Boston center. The device also enables several ships to communicate with one another. Licenses will be granted for manufacture.

title: Defense of Free Speech Is Part of Milton's Legacy of Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C., in a Reversal, Offers Definition of Insider Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, ending years of vagueness, today spelled out a definition of insider trading.

title: Videotapes To Divert Exercisers
description: TO distract, divert, motivate, cajole, delude or push themselves into exercising, some people will go to extreme and expensive lengths. They buy ''psych-up'' books and designer outfits, hire personal coaches and hypnotists; some even build home gymnasiums.

title: Jays Top Indians, 15-1, to Move Into First
description: George Bell and Fred McGriff each hit a home run and Dave Stieb won his fifth straight decision tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays routed the Cleveland Indians, 15-1, and took over first place in the American League East.

title: Standard Chartered Set To Leave South Africa
description: Standard Chartered P.L.C. of Britain said today it would sell its shares in its South African subsidiary to local businesses for the equivalent of $254 million, the largest divestment ever by a foreign corporation.

title: Crusader Sword Wins the Special
description: Crusader Sword ran down Tejano in the final strides today to win the Saratoga Special by a neck at Saratoga Race Track and stamp himself as New York's most promising 2-year-old.

title: Consumer Debt Rose In June
description: Americans took out $3.46 billion more in credit in June than they paid off, but growth in borrowing this year is still far behind the 1986 pace, the Government said today.

title: HEMODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $250,000 for the quarter and $193,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $80,000 for the quarter and $41,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month includes a pre-tax gain of $480,000 representing Hemodynamics' equity interest in the net proceeds from a July public offering by Medirace Ltd.

title: Myron Stout, Abstract Artist And Minimalist, Is Dead at 79
description: Myron Stout, the searching, reclusive painter whose simple, concentrated geometric drawings and paintings made him one of the most respected abstract artists of the last 25 years, died of lung cancer Sunday in Chatham, Mass. He was 79 years old and lived in Provincetown.

title: AT ENGLAND'S 'GLORIOUS INDULGENCE,' IT'S ONLY SHEEP WHO ARE INDIFFERENT
description: ''Picnics is all right for the small town suckers, but we're used to the high life, you know,'' Sportin' Life sang this evening, prophesying the sunset tableaux that followed a short while later out on the pastoral grounds of the Glyndebourne opera estate as the privileged bearers of the single most coveted ticket of the English summer gathered for halftime picnics.

SRI LANKAN PUTS HID TRUST IN GANDHI
description: President J. R. Jayewardene said today that if the situation remained stable, he would ask Indian peacekeeping forces to leave Sri Lanka before the end of the month.

title: AUTOMATIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Miss Dahill, Law Clerk Marries Burr Johnson
description: Kathleen Dahill, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dahill of North Haven, Conn., and Arnold Burr Johnson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson of Wallingford, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Beloin, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Richard Simmons, a Methodist minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony at the Choate Memorial Chapel at Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford.

title: Unfair to New York Bikers
description: A few weeks ago, I was riding my bike up Sixth Avenue in New York City on my way to work. A woman crossed the street - against the light, in the middle of the block and without looking. ''Please look before you cross,'' I said, swerving to avoid her. ''Drop dead,'' she answered. This is a fairly typical conversation between me, a bicycle rider who stops for red lights, uses hand signals and says ''excuse me,'' and pedestrians who are blinded by their fury against daredevil bike messengers.

title: Congress Delays Action on the Deficit
description: With many members already on their way home, the House and the Senate tonight put off efforts to compromise on a proposal to reinvigorate the budget-balancing law and left for the four-week summer recess.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Hopes Rise For '88 Accord
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that ''the news is now positive'' that North Korea will accept the I.O.C.'s offer to stage five events of the 1988 Seoul Olympics in North Korea.

description: b-Includes a non-recurring expense of $733,900 for costs of reorganization.

description: The dollar rose again yesterday despite intervention by central banks, apparently driven by the tensions in the Persian Gulf and an encouraging report on domestic unemployment.

description: In a trade of third basemen, the Detroit Tigers sent Darnell Coles and a player to be named to the Pittsburgh Pirates for Jim Morrison.

title: Unemployment Rate Dips to 5.9% As Manufacturing Jobs Increase
description: Employment surged broadly in July, particularly in manufacturing, as the nation's jobless rate fell below 6 percent for the first time since late 1979, the Government reported today.

title: Ira C. Eaker, 91, Is Dead; Helped Create Air Force
description: Ira C. Eaker, a retired Air Force general who commanded United States air forces in Europe in World War II and helped establish the Air Force as a separate military service, died Thursday at the Malcolm Grow Medical Center at Andrews Air Force Base in Camp Springs, Md.

title: That Sleazy Junk Mail
description: LEAD: Have you noticed the increasingly manipulative quality of direct mail campaigns by companies seeking your business?

title: KEY RATES
Woman in Right-to-Die Case Dies After Tube Is Removed
description: Nancy Ellen Jobes, a 32-year-old woman who was kept alive for seven years by a feeding tube, died at Morristown Memorial Hospital at 1:30 A.M. today, six weeks after a New Jersey Supreme Court ruling that authorized her husband to have the tube removed.

title: SERVICE FRACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jose Carreras's Agent Denies Report of Cancer
description: Reports in the European press that Jose Carreras has cancer were denied yesterday by the Spanish tenor's New York management. Jack Mastroianni, a vice president at Columbia Artists Management, said the 41-year old singer had been hospitalized in Paris for a ''toxicity in his blood system.'' The condition, which has occurred several times in the last year, is the result of dental problems and an adverse reaction to antibiotics, he said.

title: Phillips Auction House Has 47% Rise in Sales
description: Phillips, the London-based auction house, has announced that its international sales for 1986-87 totaled the equivalent of $134.6 million, a 47 percent increase over the $91.1 million reported for the 1985-86 season. Christopher Weston, chairman of the privately owned house, said that ''New York has had its most successful year,'' but did not provide separate figures for the stateside sales.

title: Managua Journal; For the Sandinista Nine, It's No Time to Strike Out
description: Twenty highly trained young Nicaraguans went off to battle this week, bearing the weight of national honor on their broad shoulders.

title: DOLE URGES AIDS NOT BE ISSUE IN '88
description: Senator Bob Dole strongly disagreed today with Representative Jack F. Kemp on AIDS testing and urged that the issue of AIDS be kept out of the 1988 Presidential race.

title: Sailboats, Too, Add to Long Island Sound Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Recital: Alicia de Larrocha
description: Whenever Alicia de Larrocha decides to play Spanish music, as she did Thursday evening at the Mostly Mozart Festival, it is wise to put everything else aside and be on hand. This is one area - Mozart, I believe, is another - where the Catalan pianist currently rules the whole roost, and not merely the hen house. This time she offered what the program book identified as Granados's ''Goyescas'' (Book One), though she played only the first four of the six pieces, adding ''El Pelele'' as a rousing recital-closer. Earlier, in sharp contrast to the densely embroidered piano style of Granados, the deceptive simplicities of Mozart held the audience in rapt, almost palpable silence.

description: To the Editor:

Rabbi David Cedarbaum, 84, Retired Religious Educator
description: Rabbi David I. Cedarbaum, a retired religious educator, died July 30 at Saddleback Community Hospital in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Todd Shipyards Gets Offer for Unit
description: An investment group has offered $110 million in cash and notes to the Todd Shipyards Corporation for its Aro Corporation unit. Todd, which has had financial difficulties, is the largest independent shipbuilding company in the country. Aro, which was bought by Todd in November 1985 for $87 million, is an international producer of air-powered equipment.

description: The X-rays were negative. Howard Johnson, a source close to the situation, was sure they would be, but skeptics among National League managers refused to believe him.

title: KOCH EXPERIENCED A 'TRIVIAL' STROKE, NEW TESTS SHOW
description: Mayor Koch suffered a ''tiny, trivial'' stroke on Thursday, his doctors concluded yesterday after administering new tests because he had experienced for a second time the symptoms that had led to his hospitalization.

title: The Value of Testing Athletes for AIDS
description: LEAD: A number of professional football teams have announced plans for voluntary testing for the AIDS virus. The players generally think it is a good idea. But AIDS researchers, arguing that players are far more likely to die from a head injury than from AIDS contracted on the playing field, say that the testing will set AI

title: 4 Rumanian Circus Acrobats Say They'll Seek U.S. Asylum
description: Four Rumanian acrobats walked away from their tour with Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus on Thursday, saying they wanted to begin a new life in the United States.

description: Ben Medford, a Hollywood talent agent, died last Saturday in the Sepulveda Convalescent Hospital, in Van Nuys, Calif., after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Van Nuys.

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
At Doubleday, the New Boss's Ideas Start to Take Hold
description: From the moment Nancy Evans was named president and publisher of the Doubleday Publishing Division last January, her appointment was the talk of the book industry. It still is. But now there is less talk about the wisdom of appointing someone with no book-publishing experience to one of the top jobs in the industry, and more about whether Ms. Evans can help Doubleday again become competitive with such concerns as Random House and Simon & Schuster.

description: The Chrysler Corporation and its recent acquisition, the American Motors Corporation, said today that they would basically match buyer-incentive programs adopted by the General Motors Corporation on Wednesday and the Ford Motor Company on Thursday.

description: As developers creep toward them through the picturesque Litchfield Hills, residents of this old commercial and farming town on the Massachusetts border are waging a spirited debate over whether to end a 129-year tradition of unfettered building.

title: Pan Am Union Bid
description: A coalition of unions representing Pan American World Airways has reportedly asked the financier Kirk Kerkorian to invest in the financially troubled airline. The report was published in today's editions of The Los Angeles Times. Terry Christensen, president of the Tracinda Corporation, Mr. Kerkorian's Los Angeles-based holding company, refused to comment. A Pan Am spokeswoman, Pamela Hanlon, said that there had been ''rumors and speculation'' about many potential investors but that the airline had no further comment.

title: Dow Drops 2.23 Points, To 2,592.00
description: The stock market closed mixed yesterday, with broader market gauges outperforming the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average for a change.

PATENTS;
A Pillow for Patients Following Surgery
description: LEAD: A medical pillow designed for patients who have undergone open heart or abdominal surgery, has been patented by Herbert Lagin of Great Neck, L.I. The pillow holds a firm cushion flatly against the chest and is said to relieve the usual postoperative pain, including that caused by coughing.

title: 7-Year-Old Boy Killed In Harlem Building Fire
description: A 7-year-old Harlem boy was killed and 19 other people were hurt, none of them seriously, in an apartment fire yesterday morning, the authorities reported.

description: A runaway locomotive rammed into a Moscow-bound passenger train early this morning in the southern Russian city of Kamensk-Shakhtinsky, smashing two cars of sleeping passengers, the Tass press agency reported tonight.

title: Reagan's Nose Unbandaged
description: President Reagan's doctors say his skin cancer surgery was ''completely successful,'' and they have removed all stitches from the tip of his nose, his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today. Mr. Reagan appeared briefly in the White House press room, where reporters observed that the tip of his nose was red and glistening. Doctors cut a basal cell carcinoma of nearly a half inch from the President's nose last Friday.

title: 'If Hope Is Gone'
description: A new Congressional study finds that 38 states and the District of Columbia have authorized ''living wills.'' In these legally recognized documents, people specify how and when life-support systems should be discontinued should they fall victim to terminal illness or injury. New York, however, is not on the list. Albany needs to address the issue.

title: Greenmarket: One-Stop Meal
description: The Union Square Greenmarket has become synomymous with one-stop shopping. Who would have dreamed, when it began 11 years ago, that it would offer such a dazzling array of enticing ingredients? Or that when others have gone to the country on a summer weekend, so many of those who stay in town would go down to the Greenmarket on Saturday morning?

Film: 'Back to the Beach'
description: Annette Funicello, fresh from her peanut-butter commercials, plays a cheery Ohio Mom who practically force-feeds Skippy sandwiches to her teen-aged son. Frankie Avalon is her car-salesman husband - he was the Big Kahuna, the world's greatest surfer - who takes the family back to the scene of all those 60's Beach Party movies. Annette gets to sing and dance in a pink polka-dot bathing suit with matching headband. Frankie gets to flirt with Connie Stevens. There's even a guest appearance by the Cleavers - Wally, June and the Beaver. So with all this self-parody floating around, why isn't ''Back to the Beach'' funny?

title: 2 Americans Die in Ethiopia
description: Two American aid workers died when their helicopter crashed shortly after takeoff from Addis Ababa on Wednesday, the Government said today. The pilot, Steven Bartalsky, 36 years old, and Troy Waldron, 33, were the only people in a Bell Ranger 206 helicopter flying north of the province of Shoa to survey weather conditions and deliver relief supplies. The crash was about eight miles outside the capital, the Government said.

title: Home Loans By Credit Card
description: WHEN Andrew Russell, a Louisville, Ky., attorney, took out a home equity loan last year, he found that he could get access to the money available to him by using a gold Mastercard. And he has since used the credit card to buy a number of items, including a car and equipment for his farm.

title: John Warriner, Textbook Author
description: John Warriner, a retired teacher and author of a widely used series of English textbooks, died of cancer July 29 at his home in St. Croix, the Virgin Islands. He was 80 years old and also lived in Amagansett, L.I.

title: Mecca Pilgrims Say Iranians Concealed Weapons
description: Moslem pilgrims returning from Mecca said today that Iranian demonstrators who rioted there carried knives and fire bombs concealed in their clothes and that hundreds of people were trampled to death in a stampede as the Iranians attacked the Saudi police.

CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press on Wednesday from Caracas, Venezuela, about a court ruling in the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner, described one defendant incompletely. Although the defendant, Luis Posada Carriles, has been a fugitive since his escape from a Venezuelan prison in 1985, American airmen familiar with efforts to supply the Nicaraguan rebels say Mr. Posada, using the name Ramon Medina, has been involved in the supply operation.

title: Charter Vague on Ill Mayor's Replacement
description: The ''tiny, trivial'' stroke suffered by Mayor Koch has called attention to the City Charter's ambiguity on the issue of temporary succession to power when a mayor is ill, city officials say.

title: On the East End, Grace's Grows
description: Back in April, all the small, barely noticeable sign said was, ''It's Grace's.'' But then, that is all the sign really needed to say. For on Route 111 - a road that connects the Long Island Expressway to the Sunrise Highway and, therefore, New York City to the Hamptons - Grace's was an institution. A red-and-white, 27-foot-long institution that specialized in footlong hot dogs.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADNG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $51,000 for the quarter and $97,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Life at the Last Moment
description: PAST PERFECT By Yaakov Shabtai. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 291 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Is Altering Bats and Balls a Part Of Baseball?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 30 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. Letters should include the writer's n ber.

title: Copperware Center In Istanbul's Bazaar
description: Shoehorned between Istanbul's great mosques and its tangles of alleyways and chaos, the city's Grand Bazaar seethes with people and pushers of everything from phony French perfumes to genuine silk rugs glimmering with their own intricacy.

title: IRAN SEEKS TO WARD OFF ENEMIES WITH THREAT OF A HOLY WAR
description: THE crisis in the Persian Gulf is deepening, assuming more than ever the character of a religious war by Iran against fellow Moslems. Last week it shook the Islamic world, threatening many conservative Arab regimes.

title: MORMON OFFICIAL CASTIGATES PRESS
description: A senior official of the Mormon Church accused the press last week of ''Mormon-bashing'' and distortions in its coverage of a difficult chapter in recent church history: the church's dealings with a forger of historic documents who killed two people in 1985 to conceal his crimes.

title: Janice Savin Wed To C. J. Williams
description: The wedding of Janice Annette Savin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Savin of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif., to Christopher Judson Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Williams 2d of New Milford, Conn., took place yesterday at the Park Avenue Atrium. Justice William J. Davis of the New York State Supreme Court officiated.

title: MURAL IN SEARCH OF A WALL
description: LEAD: FOR 25 years it hung in a Rye Brook restaurant, but now a mural depicting a turn-of-the-century Main Street on a quiet Sunday morning is suspended in limbo.

title: Pope Cuts Out U.N. And a Beatification During Visit to U.S.
description: With just 40 days to go before he arrives in the United States for a nine-city tour, Pope John Paul II has set a firm schedule for the visit, deciding that he cannot beatify an 18th-century California missionary or address the United Nations General Assembly.

title:
GARDENING;
A Gardener's Fond Farewell
description: LEAD: IT was 4 P.M., and my last day in the garden. Soon I would begin new duties in a new setting. Today, as the sun drew low, I was saying goodbye to a landscape I had weeded, pruned, planted, worried over and loved for 10 years.

title: New Vermont Waste Law Sends Rates Soaring
description: A new law intended to reduce the volume of solid waste dumped in Vermont landfills is sending waves of shock through the state as landfill operators double and triple their rates.

title: A CORRECTION
description: A picture of the Progress Club that appeared with an article on Aug. 2 carried an incorrect source credit. It was supplied by the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Bringing Jacob's Pillow Into the Big Time
description: WHEN TED SHAWN DIED IN 1972, the continued existence of Jacob's Pillow, the dance festival he founded in Becket, Mass., seemed very much in doubt. Fifteen years later, the festival has both survived and thrived - thanks to the striking changes instituted by its current and dynamic executive director, Liz Thompson.

title: Shellfish Hatchery Debated
description: EAST HAMPTON town officials have been offered a gift horse - $163,000 in state aid to help build a shellfish nursery and hatchery - and are seriously looking it in the mouth.

title: RECALLING A SPECIAL PACT
description: To the Editor:

title: A LAWYER IS WED TO MS. BUTTIMER
description: The marriage of Margaret Mary Buttimer, a vice president of segment marketing for Citibank, to Thomas Griffith Vaughan, a partner in the New York law firm of Jones Hirsch Connors & Bull, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. John Stubbs performed the ceremony.

title: PLANS TO MODIFY TRIATHLON
description: ''UNFORTUNATELY, when a lot of people think of the triathlon, they think of the Ironman in Hawaii,'' said Steven Mitchell, who, with his wife, Kathy, is co-director of the Farmington Valley Triathlon in Canton.

title: South Africa Says It Is Ready for Namibian Talks
description: The South African Government, having reopened security talks with Mozambique after a two-year lapse, now appears ready to negotiate with Angola and Cuba on withdrawing Cuban troops from Angola and an independence settlement in South African-ruled South-West Africa.

title: President Nominates 2 From Jersey to Courts
description: President Reagan has nominated a Federal judge from New Jersey to the Court of Appeals in Philadelphia and has selected a lawyer from Bergen County to serve on the United States District Court in New Jersey.

title: FIGHTING FOR LAKE'S 'LAST OPEN SPACE'
description: LEAD: A LARGE private lake south of the nuclear power plant in Shoreham that residents have tried to protect from encroachment and pollution for almost 40 years is being threatened, they say, by a proposed town house development, setting off a classic Long Island confrontation.

title: Child of Two Dreadful Worlds
description: LALLIA: (Le Cow-Boy) By Djanet Lachmet. Translated by Judith Still. 150 pp. New York: Carcanet. $15.95.

title: His Pitches Sink, but He's Afloat
description: ALL around him, there is youth that can never be his again. The first baseman is 26 years old, the third baseman 27, the rookie pitcher just 23. But Tommy John does not seem out of place as he sits among them, dressing, talking, eating in the visitors' clubhouse at Tiger Stadium when the day is done. He still fits comfortably, after all these seasons.

title: Senators Voice Concern on Timor
description: A bipartisan group of 40 senators has written to Secretary of State George P. Shultz about what they called ''a renewed Indonesian military offensive against Timorese insurgents.''

title: A Guide to the Bicentennial
description: Australia will celebrate a culture as diverse as Crocodile Dundee's hat and Dame Nellie Melba's tiara during its 200th birthday next year. The headgear of the cinematic hero and the soprano are two icons that will travel Australia as part of the Australian Bicentennial Exhibition, which will visit 34 cities and towns throughout 1988.

title: SARAH DOYLE MARRIED TO C. P. MCCORMACK
description: Sarah Elizabeth Doyle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Doyle of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Christopher Paul McCormack, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. McCormack of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: MENTHOL AID FOR BEES
description: The state's Department of Agriculture says that menthol, the ingredient found in cough drops and some spray inhalers, cures bees' sore throats, too.

title: DUTCH PAINTING SEEN IN A SHARP NEW LIGHT
description: SINCE JUST THE OTHER DAY, Dutch painting looks different. To begin with, Rembrandt looks different because of a young American scholar, Gary Schwartz, who published in 1985 a revisionist study called ''Rembrandt: His Life, His Paintings.'' Working with day-to-day contemporary documents, rather than with traditional iconographical methods, he came up with new ideas on virtually every aspect of Rembrandt's career. Even if we may sometimes want to argue with those ideas, they stay with us. One may doubt, for instance, if the so-called ''Polish Rider'' in the Frick Collection in New York will ever look the same to us now that Gary Schwartz has suggested that the painting is not of a Polish rider at all, but a reminiscence of a historical play, put on in Amsterdam in 1657, in which the Mongolian conqueror Tamerlane, riding a real white horse on stage, pursues the Ottoman sultan Beyazid outside Constantinople.

title: New Soviet Missile Fuels U.S. Dispute on Compliance
description: The Russians are in the initial stages of deploying a new land-based missile, the SS-24, and that has started a new battle over Soviet compliance with the second strategic arms treaty of 1979.

title: The Real Bond
description: To the Editor:

title: Mumps Cases Rise Fourfold For the First Half of the Year
description: More than 9,000 mumps cases were reported in the first six months of this year, four times the number for the same period in 1986 and more than the reported total for all of last year, the national Centers for Disease Control say.

title: Reagan Reported to Decide On Nominee for F.C.C. Seat
description: Bradley P. Holmes, a former legal adviser to Dennis R. Patrick, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is President Reagan's choice to fill a vacancy on the commission, according to a Government source familiar with the matter.

title: PROBLEM GAMBLING: NEW DRIVE
description: LEAD: THE executive director of the Compulsive Gambling Council of New Jersey Inc. said last week that several moves were under way to increase public awareness of the ''hidden disease'' that affects some 400,000 gamblers in the state and a million of their spouses and children.

title: Removal of Caps Will Spur Rehabilitation
description: NEW YORK CITY'S J-51 tax incentive program has been a driving force in the rehabilitation of older residential buildings for years, but legislative changes periodically alter the way it is used.

title: REV. PRINCIA H. M. WU WEDS BRADFORD BENSON
description: The Rev. Princia Hung Mei Wu, pastor of the Forest Presbyterian Church in Lyons Falls, N.Y., and Bradford Brooks Benson, an associate at the law firm of Petersen, Ibold & Wantz in Chardon, Ohio, were married yesterday at the Rouses Point (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: A British Party Votes to Merge
description: Because they held only 5 of the 650 seats in the British Parliament, there did not seem to be overpowering reasons for the Social Democrats to continue as an independent party. For the June election campaign, they had joined the Liberal Party in the Alliance. Last week, in a bitterly contested sequel to the poor election showing, the Social Democratic rank and file voted for negotiations that are expected to produce a formal merger with the Liberals late this year.

title: BUILDING A BRIDGE FROM ISLAND TO HEARTLAND
description: THERE is a new bridge linking Long Island's North Shore with the fields of central Iowa. It was not created as a way of bypassing Long Island Expressway traffic. It is, instead, a cultural bridge, constructed by teen-agers from two different sections of the country.

title: Recovering From The Satellite Crisis
description: Because of a series of failures, including the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger in January 1986, the United States has been frustrated in its effort to send satellites into space. This has been especially disturbing to the military, which has had no way to replace aging spy satellites. Last week, recovery from the two-year crisis began as the first of 56 new Air Force rockets rolled off a production line in Denver.

title:
ART;
TWO COOPERATIVE GALLERIES EXCHANGE EXHIBITIONS
description: LEAD: IN a gesture of cooperation designed to bring the work of their members to new audiences, two of the Island's cooperative galleries are exchanging exhibitions. Through next Sunday, visitors to the Northport Galleries can see pieces from the B. J. Spoke Gallery in Port Washington, while Spoke is showing works by the Northport

title: MARTIN MCCANN IS MARRIED ON L.I. TO MISS MCGRATH
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Southold, L.I., Genevieve Marie McGrath, a daughter of Genevieve Daly McGrath of Southold and Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Kevin B. McGrath of New York, was married yesterday to Martin John McCann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. McCann of Lincroft, N.J. The Rev. Dennis P. Keane officiated. Amy Elizabeth McGrath and Gaffney Anne McGrath were maids of honor for their sister. Michael J. McCann was his brother's best man.

title: PLAYING TO A FULL HOUSE
description: IT IS ALMOST A UNIVERSAL decorating rule: every smart house or apartment has equally smart provisions for guests. Whether it's a quirky converted maid's room barely bigger than a broom closet, a conventional extra bedroom or a separate country guest cottage, these spaces, planned specifically for weekenders and transient friends, are the microcosm of an entire household.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: Everyone who spoke at a re-cent Senate committee hearing on Governor Kean's proposal for a coastal commission seemed to agree that the way New Jersey regulates development in its coastal areas is flawed. The consensus broke down, though, as soon as the speakers began to talk about just what the flaw was.

title: Best Sellers: August 9, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Fiction Week List 1 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, 1 2 $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles international terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 2 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. 2 7 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) What women can do about men who fear a commitment. 5 HOW TO MARRY THE NAN OF YOUR CHOICE, 1 by Margaret Kent. (Warner, $14.95.) Ways to find a mate.

title: TWO ROCK MUSICIANS TURN TO ADULT REALITIES
description: ROCK MUSIC IS NOT AN IDIOM that encourages the delineation of grownup experience. With its charged rhythms and aggressively defiant stance, the genre was invented to proclaim youthful independence from adult cares. Yet as the musicians who grew up on rock-and-roll reach middle age and their creative juices still surge, what other subject could be more pertinent?

title: Jets 'Prisoners' Leave Enclave
description: THE National Football League's most expensive campers took a day trip yesterday.

title: MAJOR DREAMS IN A MINOR LEAGUE
description: THE last member of the Diggers to take batting practice was the minor-league team's manager, George Scott. At 43, his swing is still mighty enough to show that he was once a big-league slugger, but a few soft line drives were all that came off his bat at the Hofstra University baseball field in Hempstead the other day.

title: Bowen Calls for States to Act on Malpractice
description: Unless states act to limit medical malpractice insurance premiums and reduce claims, Americans could find it harder to get medical care, Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said Friday.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Constitution Medals Say an Immigrant's Thanks
description: LEAD: Two United States coins and a number of private medals are being produced to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the U.S. Constitution. It is doubtful whether any of these numismatic tributes is more heartfelt than the ones recently created by Alex Shagin, a well-known medalist who makes his home in Los Angeles.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST MONTHS FOR LAWN WORK
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH both the weather and the calendar say it is still summer, lawn renovation time has rolled around again. In spite of what might seem unfavorable conditions, lawn improvements undertaken from mid-August until mid-October will yield better results than if done at any other time of the year.

title: 2 Koch Aides Quit Under Pressure
description: In separate episodes that seemed less a continuation of the New York City scandals than symbols of the city's response to them, two members of the Koch administration resigned last week under pressure. As the Mayor said of the ''errors in judgment'' he believed had been committed by his new Probation Commissioner, James A. Payne, who admitted that he had given city investigators incorrect information about his income tax returns: ''It might have been forgiven in other years, but it couldn't be now.''

title: AN ATYPICAL TREAT IN RIDGEFIELD
description: IN this era of excessive hype and ballyhoo, it is refreshing to find a restaurant that turns out to be far better than its modest locale and decor might lead one to expect.

title: Brain Drain
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT: NON-FICTION;
Prehistory on the Hoof
description: LEAD: The Serengeti plain is a reminder of what the whole world was like 12,000 years ago, before the last great wave of human population erased most of the megafauna. There we can still imagine the mammoths, marsupial lions, dire wolves, elephant birds, and other thunderous animals that confronted our wastrel ancestors not so long ago in evolutionary time.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A 'Forgotten Territory' Votes SUFFOLK COUNTY'S government may soon have the same address as the soap opera characters in ''All My Children'' if Pine Valley becomes Long Island's newest village this week.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST MONTHS FOR LAWN WORK
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH both the weather and the calendar say it is still summer, lawn renovation time has rolled around again. In spite of what might seem unfavorable conditions, lawn improvements undertaken from mid-August until mid-October will yield better results than if done at any other time of the year.

title: Delta Pilot Loses License Over Plane's Power Loss
description: The Federal Aviation Administration on Friday revoked the certificate of a Delta Air Lines captain who mistakenly shut off both engines of his jet airliner shortly after takeoff, causing the plane to plunge to within 500 feet of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Writers in China: How Long Is the Leash?
description: The Peace Hotel is a noble, well-preserved pile of gray stone at the corner of downtown Shanghai's main shopping street and the Bund, the embankment along the Yangtze. At night on the promenade young Chinese embrace their lovers; elderly men and women perform tai chi exercises at dawn; and students seek to practice their English with Western tourists attracted to the Bund by all of the above, as well as by the view of busy river traffic and the city skyline. In the hotel nightclub a seven-piece band of middle-aged Chinese musicians knock themselves out, and the audience, too, with snappy renditions of an impressive repertoire of such American standards as ''Take the 'A' Train,'' ''Oh, Lady Be Good'' and, so help me, ''Bei Mir Bist Du Schoen,'' a Yiddish melody made popular by the Andrews Sisters in 1938. Tourists of all ages sip their drinks and listen with amazement to the echoes of the time machine, but even more surprising is the group of Chinese couples in their 50's and 60's who occupy tables along the back wall of the nightclub and are the most frequent and most polished dancers in the hall. Jitterbug, fox trot, rumba - the Chinese partners are flawless and, in the tradition of ballroom dancers, impassive.

title: Library Shedding Precious Obscurity to Celebrate Its 175 Years
description: When Isaiah Thomas took his printing press and fled the British in Boston on April 16, 1775, two days before Paul Revere made his famous ride, he picked this city 39 miles to the west because he thought no one would pursue him to such an obscure place.

title: INFIGHTING HAMPERS ANTI-DRUG WAR
description: LIKE the angler who has hauled in a big fish, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d flew to Chicago the other day to pose for pictures before fruit boxes loaded with nearly three tons of uncut cocaine, believed to be the largest shipment ever seized by law-enforcement officials.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I welcome this commitment to peace and democracy by the five Central American presidents, and I hope it will lead to peace in Central America and democracy in Central America.'' - President Reagan [ 12:4. ]

title: Sarah Brand to Wed Dr. Michael A. Kelly
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Brand 3d of Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Babcock Brand to Dr. Michael Aloysius Kelly, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacques M. Kellly of Washington. A September wedding is planned.

title: 'GHOST' FINDS HER VOICE
description: LEAD: WHAT'S wrong with believing in ghosts? Marni Nixon, whose lyric coloratura invisibly graced the lips of Deborah Kerr, Audrey Hepburn and Natalie Wood in the big musicals of the 50's and 60's and whom a critic once dubbed the Ghostess with the Mostest, can be seen as well as heard tonight at the White Barn Theater in Westport, at which she will appear in ''An Evening With Marni Nixon,'' for a program of concert and popular songs.

title: Air Travelers Need 'Truth In Scheduling'
description: THE flying public might still be confused about the causes of - and solutions to - the worsening rash of flight delays, baggage mix-ups, near-collisions in midair and other signs of a deteriorating aviation system in America.

title: U.S., Soviet Agree To Speed Work on Draft Arms Treaty
description: The major obstacle to a new Soviet-American arms control treaty is Moscow's demand that the American nuclear warheads on West Germany's short-range Pershing 1A missiles be eliminated.

title: JANET FIFER TO MARRY
description: Janet Faye Fifer and Robert Edward Bolen, both graduates of Harvard College, plan to be married in October. The future bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Fifer of Elmhurst, Queens, who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Bolen of Garden City, L.I. Ms. Fifer is in public relations at Villard Books, a division of Random House. Her fiance is a member of the American Stock Exchange.

title: What Kind Of Pennant Races Do You Expect?
description: The Baltimore Orioles will catch the Cleveland Indians on the last day of the season, win the American League East in a one-game playoff and go on to World Series victory in a four-game sweep. Toto, I have a feeling that we're not in Kansas anymore. BORIS MOCZULA Edison, N.J.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: A LETTER from Steven D. Garber, author of the forthcoming ''The Urban Naturalist'' (John Wiley & Sons, New York, $12.95), sings the praises of city streets.

title: TO STOP ELECTED DICTATORSHIPS
description: Congress has just completed three months of hearings that have served the nation brilliantly.

title: FRIEDAN AND GROUP SEEKING A 'NEW NATIONAL STRATEGY'
description: LEAD: BETTY FRIEDAN, whose book ''The Feminine Mystique'' became the manifesto of a social revolution a generation ago, is getting ready to shake things up again.

title: STREETSCAPES: THE 81st STREET THEATER; The Curtain Falls, but Preservation Is in the Wings
description: OLD theater buildings in development areas are usually either demolished or given landmark designation - often over the owner's protests. But on 81st and Broadway, a hybrid solution is nearing completion, and part of a 1914 theater building is being preserved as part of an apartment development.

title: THORIUM SITE STILL TROUBLES MAYWOOD
description: ALTHOUGH soil containing thorium has been removed from residential properties here, longtime residents and elected officials say they are concerned that the storage site on the edge of town may become an infamous fixture.

title: He Gave Us the Gingko
description: ANDRE AND FRANCOIS ANDRE MICHAUX By Henry Savage Jr. and Elizabeth J. Savage. Illustrated. 435 pp. Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia. $27.50.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: LOST TIME. By Catharine Arnold. (Viking, $16.95.) This first novel by an English writer, Catharine Arnold, deals with the belated sexual awakening of Miles Tattershall, a Cambridge don who specializes in the writings of Robert Burton (''The Anatomy of Melancholy'') and is himself a case of terminal melancholia.

title: TENLEY-ANN JACKSON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Tenley-Ann Jackson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren G. Jackson of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Mashpee, Mass., to Howard Walter Hawkins 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hawkins Jr. of Chicago, took place yesterday at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Hartsdale. The Rev. Rayner Hesse Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: A Democrat in the White House?
description: THE END OF THE CONSERVATIVE ERA Liberalism After Reagan. By Robert S. McElvaine. 338 pp. New York: Arbor House. $18.95.

title: Recent Sales
description: Edison $119,900 79 Silver Lake Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,380. Hillsborough $122,900 912-D Merritt Drive 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old town house; deck, wall-to-wall carpeting, walk-in closets; taxes $1,670, monthly maintenance $105. . Rye, N.Y. $629,500 20 Intervale Place 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 64-year-old colonial; studio, den, mud room, walk to school and stores; taxes $4,523. Wantagh, L.I. $212,000 29 Ewell Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; fireplace, new kitchen; taxes $2,800.

title: BANK CROSSES BORDER
description: The Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, headquartered in Hartford, opened its first Westchester loan and production office in Purchase on July 23. The new office, at 2700 Westchester Avenue, will concentrate on making loans to business, real-estate and private banking customers, said Barbara Lawrence, a Connecticut Bank vice president and the commercial lending officer in charge of the Westchester operation.

title: Mosque by Le Corbusier
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Escorts Quietly Take 2 More Ships Into Gulf
description: Four United States warships with their crews at a high state of alert escorted three Kuwaiti tankers flying American flags into the Persian Gulf today within striking range of Iranian bases, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Brain Drain
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOLITION IRKS NEIGHBORS
description: LEAD: BACK in May, a few neighbors in Wantagh joined together to save an older home on their block that a developer wanted to demolish and replace with two houses. Residents of the area, known as Wantagh Woods, protested what they saw as redevelopment of an already developed area.

title: AIDES SAY INQUIRY HURT U.S. SPYING
description: Revelations in the Iran-contra hearings, including details of amateurism and bungling, have shaken the confidence of foreign officials in American secret operations, Government officials say. They add that the disclosures have prompted the intelligence services of some friendly nations to reduce the amount of information shared with the United States.

title: THE UNFLINCHING EYE
description: In Vicki Goldberg's article, she describes Diane Arbus's photography as being filled with a ''profound and contagious malice.'' This strikes me as a most fallacious characterization of the late Arbus's work. Vicki Goldberg seems to have made the elementary critical error of condemning the messenger for the message which she brought. Exposing a dark side and becoming one with it remain actions with entirely different moral consequences. Certainly, one who takes on the mantle of critic should be capable of such a distinction. JACK ROUTLEDGE Springfield, N.J.

title: Chinese Gold Coins Stolen
description: A $55,250 shipment of Chinese gold coins depicting pandas has been stolen from a storage area at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, the authorities said Friday. The coins had arrived from Germany for consignment to a dealer, a customs agent said, The coins had been in a secured warehouse area of the airport in the custody of the Customs Service, the agent said.

title: Book Clubs
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LAWN CONCERT As the summer winds down, lawn concerts take on added luster, such as the yearly Gala Sunset Concert and Lawn Picnic to be held at 6:30 P.M. Saturday at Boscobel, the restored Federal mansion in Garrison-on-Hudson.

title: Lack of Compliance Plagues Lobbying Law
description: New York City's new lobbying law, which took effect this year as an anti-corruption safeguard, is encountering problems.

title: Keeping Ahead Of Urban Blight
description: A MAN'S home may be his castle, but in Norwich, Conn., he keeps his castle looking nice or faces a steep daily fine.

title: Six Years After Daring Jailbreak, Suspect, 'Uncle Hank,' Is Caught
description: To the Frick family of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., he was known as ''Uncle Hank,'' a kindly man who took children fishing, was a whiz at ''Trivial Pursuit'' and was always willing to help with yard work.

title: RETAILER ASSISTS DETECTIVE'S WIDOW
description: Every year, Milton Petrie gives about $15 million of his $1 billion retailing fortune to hospitals, universities and other charitable causes. But he also helps individuals in need.

title: LOSERS AND WINNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOK IS BORN OF IDLE CHATTER
description: LEAD: A WESTON woman who spent a recent summer watching and listening to area residents at a local ice-cream parlor has compiled her observations into a book, ''Life: A Warning.''

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We have a large room with a parquet wood floor. Under the wood is a concrete slab that has radiant heating pipes. These pipes burst several times, so we disconnected them and use other heat. The flooring has been sanded, stained and refinished with polyurethane, but the finish dried spotty, especially along the seams. What is the problem and how can we solve it?

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
DUET FOR MOTHER AND SON: THEME AND VARIATIONS
description: LEAD: WE BEGIN together, my son (age 12) on the flute and I at the piano, accompanying.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 8 from United Press International, with an article about an Australian study that linked aides of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North with an Australian bank that collapsed in 1980, misidentified the man shown. He was Ken Nugan, a brother of Frank Nugan, co-founder of the bank, not Michael J. Hand, the other co-founder.
