In addition, a picture caption on Nov. 13, 1982, with an article about a suspected link between the bank and the Central Intelligence Agency misidentified two of the men shown. At left was Ken Nugan and at center was Frank Nugan. Mr. Hand was not shown.

title: 291 Tamil Rebels Freed Under Sri Lanka Accord
description: Sri Lanka released 291 Tamil terrorist suspects from jail today and sent them home by an Indian Navy ship under a peace accord.

title: SHERRI L. WASSERMAN WEDS JOHN GOODMAN
description: Sherri Lynn Wasserman and John Benjamin Goodman were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, George and Renate Wasserman, in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Klein officiated.

title: What Kind Of Pennant Races Do You Expect?
description: It is the beginning of August and there are still 15 teams with a reasonably good shot at capturing a division title. The six-team race in the American League West will probably whittle down to three or four by September. The A's have the most all-round talent, the Royals have the best pitching and the Twins have the most favorable schedule. These teams should be battling until the final week.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Farmingdale Grows as a Shopping Hub
description: LEAD: IN the view of Gregg Wasser, one of the principals of G&S; Investors, developers in Farmingdale, the stretch of Route 110 between the Babylon town line and the Southern State Parkway, has the potential to become a major discount retail center.

title: SAFE SEX
description: WHEN I was 13 years old, I remember one day feeling that I was very, very lucky, first of all to have been born a human being rather than an ant or a fly or a wart hog, to have the most wonderful parents in the world, to live in the finest city of all, Grand Rapids, Mich. - the Furniture City - in that greatest of all the countries in the world, America. Only one thing, my terrible pressing curiosity, threatened to ruin this wonderful life, my perfect existence. I had to know where babies came from.

title: Headliners; Separate Ways
description: The pain continues for Mary Beth Whitehead. A lawyer representing Mrs. Whitehead, who gave birth 16 months ago to Baby M under a surrogate-mother contract and then lost a widely publicized, seven-week court battle for custody of her daughter, disclosed last week that his client had separated from her husband, Richard. The lawyer, Harold J. Cassidy, said Mrs. Whitehead believed that the stress of ''public discussion of private matters'' had rendered her 14-year marriage ''an inevitable casualty of this unusual case.'' During the trial it was disclosed that the Whiteheads had previously separated and then reconciled. Mr. Cassidy said he had informed the New Jersey State Supreme Court of his client's ''change in circumstance.'' The court is scheduled to hear Mrs. Whitehead's appeal of a Superior Court ruling that awarded custody of Baby M to her father, William Stern.

title: ANDREA LIDDLE TO MARRY ALAN DORSEY
description: The engagement of Andrea Graham Liddle to Alan Harold Dorsey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Dorsey of Purchase, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harold V. Liddle of Salt Lake City. The couple plan to marry Sept. 5.

title: ABIGAIL S. ADAMS WEDS T. S. MILLER
description: Abigail Scott Adams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Adams Jr. of Chappaqua, N. Y., and Old Saybrook, Conn., and Ted Scott Miller, the son of Kenneth L. Miller of Grosse Isle, Mich., and Dr. Doris M. Miller of Ann Arbor, Mich., were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N. Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony.

title: NEW TECHNOLOGY EXTENTION CENTER
description: The Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology, the cancer research and treatment facility of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark, has become the fourth Technology Extension (Tex) Center established by the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GODDESS LETTERS. By Carol Orlock. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) This first novel is just what the book jacket says it is: ''The Myth of Demeter & Persephone Retold.'' Here expanded, touched up, re-created, it is retold in fact by mother and daughter themselves through letters spanning roughly the years 1500 B.C. to A.D. 425. Their initial occasion is Persephone's rape and abduction by Hades (here depicted as part sullen, ghoulish trickster and part hapless clodhopper). As we follow the two goddesses through Eleusis, Olympus and the nether world we become reacquainted with an array of Classical figures. (Even Homer makes a cameo appearance.) Demeter recounts her end of the story with a blend of carp and immortal hauteur, while Persephone settles into a vexing adolescent vernacular: ''Once long ago the immortals threw stones to decide who got what, and Poseidon won the sea. Mother got the fertility on earth - definitely best. And Zeus got sky. Zeus is my father - but he's married to Hera. I never actually met her, but I don't like her.'' Ms. Orlock uses her sensuous pictorial imagination to advantage in rendering the chilling underworld landscapes, where we embark as if on an eerie pleasure cruise down the Cocytus. The author has apparently devoted considerable research to her subject but her attempt to convey the power of ancient myth through modern sensibility and language is undermined by a self-conscious, academic approach; deeper concerns such as the complexities of mother-daughter relationships or the decline of matriarchal power are sounded, but only hollowly. One finishes ''The Goddess Letters'' feeling a little like Erysichthon, condemned to perpetual famine - the more he ate, the more he hungered.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: Arruza A docudrama about the bullfighter Carlos Arruza by Budd Boetticher. 1967. Embassy Home Entertainment. 91 minutes. $39.95.

title: Taking Life 'Real Hard'
description: BEYOND THIS BITTER AIR By Sarah Rossiter. 132 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $11.95.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: Pacific Isle Asks U.N. to Help Get Dirt Back
description: One of the world's smallest countries has appealed to the United Nations to help it redress what the country calls a crime that it says may threaten its existence: the theft of almost all its topsoil by three colonial powers during a 50-year occupation.

title: Mayor, Recovering, Might Leave Hospital Today
description: Doctors described Mayor Koch yesterday as sufficiently recovered from a minor stroke to be able to return to Gracie Mansion sometime today, but they said he still faced a period of greatly reduced physical activity.

title: BITTERNESS ABOUT BRADLEY REMAINS
description: HARRISON A. WILLIAMS Jr. has had a long time to remember those who stood by him and those who did not when he was convicted in his Abscam trial six years ago.

title:
ANTIQUES;
DESIGN: 'BEAUTY THAT REWARDS THE EYE'
description: LEAD: THE Dillon, Engelhard and Forbes estates are in the area, and Jacqueline Onassis and King Hassan of Morocco have homes nearby.

title: City, Teamsters Reach Accord
description: Little more than a month after the expiration of New York City's contracts with more than 100 labor unions, the first agreement was announced last week. The teamsters' union, representing 17,500 employees, including security guards, hospital technicians, cooks and bridge operators, settled tentatively for a package that would raise wages by 15.25 percent over three years.

title: CHILDREN
description: Of Stars and Men By John and Faith Hubley. Based on the book by Harlow Shapley. Walt Disney Home Video. 53 minutes. $49.95.

title: Jazz: Joe Henderson at the Vanguard
description: JOE HENDERSON and the quartet he is leading through today at the Village Vanguard was raising some male eyebrows the other night. Mr. Henderson's pianist, bassist and drummer are women, and in jazz, even in 1987, that is unusual. ''I'm not sure about the music,'' one male fan commented, ''but I think I'm in love.''

title: VOLUNTEERS WIDEN VIEW OF INNER CITY YOUTHS
description: IT was while watching a fireworks display along the Connectiut River in Hartford on the Fourth of July that a disturbing thought hit Ned Coll.

title: STUDY IN ARROGANCE
description: Though an international treaty imposes a moratorium on commercial whaling, Japan is reported ready to approve the slaughter of 875 whales in the Antarctic this fall. Japan justifies the hunt by saying the whales would be used for scientific research - before being sold as meat. That ruse won't work anymore.

title: L.I. SOUND: PERPLEXING WOES
description: LEAD: FOR boaters and beachgoers on Long Island Sound, fish kills, algal blooms and low levels of dissolved oxygen have created some unpleasant memories of the summer of '87.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST MONTHS FOR LAWN WORK
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH both the weather and the calendar say it is still summer, lawn renovation time has rolled around again. In spite of what might seem unfavorable conditions, lawn improvements undertaken from mid-August until mid-October will yield better results than if done at any other time of the year.

title: OLD LAB DUMPS STUDIED
description: LEAD: A CLEARING more than two miles around, straddling the headwaters of the Peconic River, stands out like a huge doughnut in aerial photographs of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, the 5,200-acre Government research center for advanced physics situated deep in the pine barrens of eastern Long Island.

title: INSECURITIES
description: Ask New Yorkers which of their possessions they dread losing most, and the common answer will be, ''My keys.'' Now those often-overlooked items, and the locks they fit, can be found in abundance at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, in an engaging exhibit of security devices from antiquity to the present.

title:
ART;
THE MENTOR SHINES THROUGH AT SHOW IN LITTLE SILVER
description: LEAD: SOMETIMES everything falls into place when you find out who an artist's mentor is. One of the most elusive aspects of painting is the mood, the temper that runs through an entire exhibition. For instance, a painter may seem to have a deep strain of sardonic humor, but this may just be the humor that the viewer is in.

title: POSTINGS: New Medical Facilities; Double Rx in Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn will edge closer to the 21st century with two planned health facilities, one at a hospital and the other at a university, that are designed to incorporate the latest advances in medical science.

title: The American Way of Occupation
description: LEAD: REMAKING JAPAN The American Occupation as New Deal. By Theodore Cohen. Edited by Herbert Passin. 533 pp. New York: The Free Press. $27.50.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 9, 1987
description: International 3-16 President Reagan expressed support for the tentative peace pact reached by five Latin American nations in a statement issued by the White House, but said ''there is much work to be done by the parties involved.'' Page 1 The Sandinistas called the accord a historic step toward peace, but are warning that important obstacles remain. Opposition activists said they had seen no concrete steps toward restoring political freedom since it was signed. 13 Revelations during the hearings on the Iran-contra affair have prompted the intelligence services of some friendly nations to reduce the information they share with the United States, officials said. 1 When the President gives his speech to the nation on the Iran-contra affair on Wednesday, he is expected to dispute Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's assertion that the ''buck stops here with me'' in the decision to divert arm sales profits to the contras. 11 The surrender of arms by Tamils in Sri Lanka and the agreement to end the guerrilla war marked the culmination of an extraordinary diplomatic breakthrough by Colombo and New Delhi, which had tried to arrange an end to the war since 1983. 1 Canada admitted Nazi collaborators to the country after World War II because of misleading information supplied by United States intelligence officers, a study for a Canadian Government commission says. 1 Moscow is beginning to deploy a new land-based missile, and that has started a new battle over Soviet compliance with the strategic arms treaty of 1979. Some officials said the Russians appeared to remain in compliance. 3 Pretoria may talk on Namibia 8 2,500 at South Africa funeral 9 Pope sets U.S. tour schedule 11 U.S. escorts 3 ships into gulf 12 National 18-27 Mail-in test kits for the AIDS virus that several companies plan to offer have stirred concern among public health officials and drawn harsh criticism from many doctors and groups working with AIDS patients. 1 Louisiana's execution process is part of what seems likely to be an inexorable national increase in executions as legal barriers fall and death sentences increase, experts said. 1 The American Antiquarian Society of Worcester, Mass., will celebrate its 175th anniversary with an open house. In a reading room usually closed to the public, people will find early American books, newspapers, maps and broadsides. 18 Vying to have a radioactive dump, three remote Mojave Desert towns hungry for jobs hope that being host to the dump will bring an economic lift. ''It'll bring people into the area,'' a resident of one town said. 18 Only a handful of Rajneeshees, followers of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, remain at his ranch nearly two years after allegations against the guru became public. 18 The American Bar Association began its annual meeting in San Francisco. The legal impliations of AIDS and the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court are among the topics occupying the people in attendance. 23 Democratic Presidential hopefuls Michael S. Dukakis and Richard A. Gephardt, who have been stalking each other in Iowa for weeks, jousted there over trade and energy policy in a one-on-one debate. 22 Ex-Armco chief is said to be choice for Commerce job 19 Delta pilot loses license 20 Hard times at anti-abortion PAC 25 Mormon official castigates press 27 Regional 28-36 New York City's heroin industry is in a sudden restructuring as Chinese criminals have taken over the dominant role in the multibillion-dollar enterprise that for decades was the preserve of the Mafia, officials said. 1 Doctors described Mayor Koch as sufficiently recovered from a minor stroke to be able to return to Gracie Mansion sometime Sunday, but they said he still faced a period of greatly reduced physical activity. 28 At the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, Calvin O. Butts, the executive minister, has taken on the city's white and black leadership and allied himself with more radical elements of the black community. 28 A plan to help compulsive gamblers stop gambling gained unusual support from two Atlantic City casinos last week. The casinos posted signs notifying patrons that help was available by calling 1-800-GAMBLER. 36 New York City's new lobbying law is encountering some problems. Some law firms that engage in lobbying have failed to file the required reports, or filed them late or incomplete, a city councilwoman said. 33 A junior high school in the Bronx has been ordered closed because of failure to improve its educational performance in reading and math and low attendance rates. 29 Longtime fugitive captured 30 Helping a detective's widow 31 Dolphin deaths examined 32 Poor lack adequate legal advice in evictions, report says 32 New York bolsters recreation programs 34 Employers warned on hiring illegal aliens 44

title: Dole Names Jersey Chairman
description: Senator Bob Dole named Assemblyman Garabed Haytaian as chairman of his New Jersey Presidential campaign Friday. Mr. Haytaian, Republican of Warren, is the Assembly's Majority Leader. Representative Marge S. Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, was named honorary chairwoman. The former state Transportation Commissioner, John Sheridan, was named operations and campaign manager for Senator Dole.

title: Beneath South Dakota's Black Hills
description: More than a century ago, an army of fortune-hunters descended upon the Black Hills of South Dakota in search of gold. Many did find gold, but they also happened on another underground treasure: one of the most extensive and spectacular limestone cave systems in the world.

title: CAROL A. RUSCHE MARRIES PAUL L. BENTEL
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari in Venice, Carol Anne Rusche, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Rusche of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Paul Louis Bentel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Bentel of Locust Valley, L.I. Msgr. Giuseppe Annabale performed the ceremony.

title: MILKING THE SOYBEAN FOR CHA-CHA CHERRY
description: LEAD: JUST five months ago, Elizabeth Appel was part of the corporate scene, working as a senior consultant with a prestigious accounting firm. Part of her job involved offering her expertise in manufacturing and data processing to executives at major companies nationwide.

title: LYING ABOUT LYING
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: I agree with E. Wallace Lawrence 3d that it is a good idea to take along bubble gum when going to the Soviet Union (Q & A, June 21).

title: Modern Architecture Adorns Europa Stamps
description: Each year the European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations chooses a common theme for one of its stamp issues, known as the Europa issue. The 1987 theme is ''Modern Architecture as Art.''

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Up to 60 Percent Off On Children's Clothes Liebman's, a source for children's clothing in the same building in New Rochelle for 60 years, has changed its retail policy and now discounts suggested retail prices by 20 to 40 percent, with reductions to 60 percent on seasonal clearances. The special services of the store remain - parochial school jumpers, skirts, knee socks and blouses for girls and the slacks, blazers, sweaters and shirts for boys; Boy and Girl Scout or camp uniforms, including labeling; plus alterations, a mailing list for sales and layaways.

title: ROBIN PEARL IS BRIDE
description: Robin Dawn Pearl, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry M. Pearl of Woodbury, L.I., and New York, was married last evening to James Gordon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gordon of New York. Rabbi Robert Raab officiated at the Cedar Brook Country Club in Old Brookville, L.I. The bride, a graduate of Ithaca College, is the special projects coordinator for United Synagogue of America. Mr. Gordon, a graduate of Queens College, will be a candidate for a doctorate in psychology at New York University.

title: STEPHANIE ZERNIK WED TO A LAWYER
description: Stephanie Karen Zernik, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Zernik of Philadelphia, and David I. Lewittes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Lewittes of New York, were married last evening at the Wyndham Franklin Plaza Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: JAva Gold Surges To Win Whitney HORSE RACING
description: Java Gold, the 3-year-old who missed the Triple Crown but still might turn out to be the best of his crop, ran down Gulch in the deep stretch to win the $288,500 Whitney Handicap today before the largest crowd in the history of Saratoga Race Track.

title: DECORATING
description: Maggie Cohen's Guide To Interior Decorating International Designs. (800) 628-2828, ext. 841. 98 minutes. $39.95.

title: BONNIE TESCHEMACHER PLANS WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Teschemacher of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Eyring Teschemacher, to John Alfred Hamilton Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton of McLean, Va.

title: The Pot's Bubbling Along Avenue of the Americas
description: TWO or three years ago it would have been unthinkable. But now one of Wall Street's old-line banks is negotiating to move its headquarters to 114 West 46th Street, not far from the hurly-burly of Times Square.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: 'Peace' at Hand In Boston Nynex

title: Where History Rests
description: Cemeteries mean different things to different travelers. To some, they are places for establishing links with figures from the past, whether they be George Washington or Elvis Presley. To others, cemeteries are quiet spots for reflection, places to ponder - perhaps fittingly - the meaning of life.

title: BASEBALL SALARIES
description: I read Bob Spitz's article about the struggles of free-agent baseball players with interest, but not much sympathy (''Is Collusion the Name of the Game?'' July 12).

title: DOCTORS URGE EDUCATION ON AIDS TO CUB SPREAD AMONG MINORITIES
description: A stern education campaign aimed at black and Hispanic people is needed to curb the spread of AIDS in minority communities, which have accounted for 38 percent of the virus's victims, doctors said today at a Federal conference.

title: City Schools Come Under Fire
description: The summer of '87 has developed into a season of embarrassment for the New York public school system.

title: CLIONA M. BURKE WEDS H.P. ROBB
description: Cliona Mary Burke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. P. Declan Burke of Culpeper, Va., and Henry Peter Robb, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard M. Robb of Brookline, Mass., were married yesterday at the Precious Blood Roman Catholic Church in Culpeper.

title: KIDS FROLIC, PARENTS LOOK WORSE FOR WEAR
description: In reference to the article ''Don't Tell - Camp Is Our Time'' [ Long Island Sound, July 19 ] : I was shocked at the drawings. No matter how cartoonlike this effort to illustrate the parents, no Roslyn or Great Neck lady would likely be caught appearing so greatly ''overnosed.'' What a terrible blow for cosmeticians serving this area! Also, the hairdos - oh! oh!

title: Crowding the Seashore on Every Coast
description: ON shrinking beaches, the crowds are thicker than they used to be. More than half of America's population lives within 50 miles of the ocean or Great Lakes, and that proportion is rising quickly. And despite erosion, pollution and proliferating condos, each year more people go to the beach.

title: VISUAL ARTS DEAN ARRIVES AT PURCHASE
description: LEAD: FOR George Parrino, the new dean of visual arts at the State University of New York at Purchase, the special excitement about his new position comes from being in a place that has ''the intensity of the conservatory experience combined with the broad resources of a university.'' That plus ''a campus which itself is an architectural museum; the presence of the Neuberger, a world-class museum, and a major performing arts center as well as distinguished individual departments'' all contribute to his pleasure in being on the

title: FIGHTING TO WIN
description: In the long Arab-Persian war in the gulf begun by Arab Iraq's aggression, the Persians have been fighting to win while the Arabs have been fighting to settle. If those strategies continue, the Persians in Teheran will triumph and the United States will have involved itself on the losing side.

title: Merger Mania Hits Jersey Banks
description: New Jersey is a hot item, at least in the banking industry. The economy of the much-maligned state has fared better than most, and its companies have become increasingly attractive. In the past week, three major Jersey banking companies have agreed to mergers - First Fidelity of Newark is to merge with Fidelcor of Philadelphia in a $1.3 billion deal, Carteret Savings will be purchased for $320 million by Home Group, a New York insurance company, and NatWest USA, the American unit of the British company National Westminster, agreed to buy First Jersey National, the No. 4 banking company in the state, for $820 million. The deals are being made possible by a regional banking agreement that allows mergers in the Northeastern states. And while the biggest banks, such as Citicorp, might have been expected to be the first to buy hot properties, they have been tied up with earnings problems from their Latin loans, leaving the door open for the smaller banks.

title: ARE THE WHITNEY'S ATELLITES OUT OF ORBIT?
description: CURRENT SHOWS AT the branches of the Whitney Museum of American Art are revealing - about art, about the way the Whitney thinks, about the strengths and weaknesses of the most important museum of American art. They are not encouraging.

title: Crowding the Seashore on Every Coast
description: ON shrinking beaches, the crowds are thicker than they used to be. More than half of America's population lives within 50 miles of the ocean or Great Lakes, and that proportion is rising quickly. And despite erosion, pollution and proliferating condos, each year more people go to the beach.

title: What Kind Of Pennant Races Do You Expect?
description: The National League East race is going to be exciting, especially since 10 of the Mets' final 23 games are against the Cardinals and the Expos. The Mets won half of the battle when Herzog impounded HoJo's bat. As we learned last October during the playoffs, whining only hurts the whiners. With any luck, he'll accuse Darling of scuffing the ball and investigate Orosco for throwing a spitter.

title: WHERE TO FIND ISRAELI ART IN NEW YORK
description: A MULTIPLICITY OF PERSPECTIVES - and the exhaustive paths traversed by many Israeli artists during the last two decades - is evoked in Israeli films, music, painting and sculpture available to New Yorkers in the coming months.

title: ERICA S. LINDBERG AND HENRI GOURD TO MARRY IN FALL
description: Erica Sames Lindberg and Henri Noel Gourd will be married Sept. 26, the future bride's parents, Amanda Atwood Lindberg of Stonington, Conn., and Sam Claes Lindberg of North Haven, Conn., have announced. Mr. Gourd is a son of Mrs. Michael Gourd of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late Mr. Gourd, Miss Lindberg, a member of the Junior League of Bronxville, N.Y., graduated from Miss Porter's School and Kenyon College. She is vice president for merchandising at Viacom International Inc., owner of the MTV Network, in New York. Her father is president of Image Development Inc., a print management service, in North Haven. Her mother is a psychotherapist.

title: ANCIENT AND MODERN CONFLICTS OF ISLAM MERGE DURING HAJJ
description: AT the end of the annual hajj, or pilgrimage, to Mecca last week, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia told Moslem leaders from 123 nations, ''We will never relent in the defense of our homeland and sacred shrines, with souls and money.''

title: Going After Crime by the Numbers
description: YOU may think your finances are nobody else's business, but private investigators don't agree. They spend a great deal of time these days tracking private financial information.

title: A Quick Fix That Would Be Harmful
description: THE search for a quick fix for the Latin American debt problem has generated numerous proposals for concessional debt relief. But a close analysis suggests that, except for some extreme cases (Bolivia, for example), such relief is not needed and actually would be counterproductive.

title: COWBOY CONFIDENTIAL
description: To the Editor:

title:
MUSIC;
DEBUT 'GIG' FOR DUDLEY MOORE
description: LEAD: ''I WOULD like to be taken seriously, not gravely,'' said Dudley Moore, the film actor, comedian and pianist. ''And I'm willing to take the slings and arrows that go along with that presumption,'' adding: ''I won't read them, of course.''

title: That's Hollywood: The Strike That Never Was
description: MORNING comes early in Hollywood. Power and money don't buy an extra hour of sleep for producers, directors and studio executives who have to rise at dawn if they want to keep practicing the tricky and well-paid art of making movies and cutting deals.

title: HOW INDIA PLIES ITS REGIONAL INTERESTS
description: AFTER an initial flush of satisfaction over its success in negotiating an accord in Sri Lanka, India has begun a period of soul-searching. The agreement, which provides 5,000 Indian troops to guarantee a solution to the island nation's ethnic conflict, has enhanced India's stature in the region, but it also has created enormous new burdens and risks.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Labor costs continue to hold more promise for the profit side of American businesses than in controlling retail inflation, which has been driven more by food energy and import prices.''

title: PLEASURES OF TRAVELING IN LIFE'S SLOW LANE
description: THE commute from Fairfield County into Manhattan was exciting, at first. Trains, taxis, subways. Then the novelty wore off. Suddenly it seemed that the trains were dirty, crowded and late; the taxis nonexistent when needed most; the subways packed, hot and smelly.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
N.F.L. Eligibility Rules: Open and Shut Case
description: LEAD: CRIS CARTER, an extravagantly talented wide receiver whose most recent jersey belonged to Ohio State, is about to provide an insight into the future of the National Football League's eligibility rules. Along the way, he will provide income for an assortment of attorneys, encouragement for out-of-work athletes and a topic of conversation for fans of the business side of sports.

title: Sports of The Times; Abbott Up Front At Games
description: CARRYING the American flag with his one hand was not a problem for Jim Abbott yesterday. He has handled tougher chores in far more demanding arenas.

title: AT STADIUMS, FANS GET INTO THE ACT
description: I'VE BEEN SPENDING A LOT of time in arenas and stadiums lately, places where this summer's main spectator sport seems to be music. Over the past few months, tours headlined by David Bowie, Madonna, the Grateful Dead, Bon Jovi, Boston, Huey Lewis and the News, Eric Clapton, Billy Idol, Luther Vandross, Peter Gabriel, U2, Genesis and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers have passed through the New York area, with the Run-D. M. C./ Beastie Boys/L. L. Cool J. package, Motley Crue, Whitney Houston and Roger Waters (formerly of Pink Floyd) soon to arrive.

title: Woman in Florida, Shot in Back, Waits 13 Hours for Surgery
description: Edwina Haynes, who had been shot in the back and had no health insurance, waited for 13 hours before doctors could find a hospital that would accept her for surgery, a hospital official has charged.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Milford, Pa.;
Tight Reins In the Poconos
description: LEAD: IN the exclusive residential subdivisions in and around the Delaware River community of Milford, it's not unusual for developers to place deed covenants on lots before they sell them.

title: Golf; Weibring and McCumber Tied in P.G.A.
description: Seve Ballesteros, the leader through 15 holes today, pushed two one-iron shots into water on the last three holes, allowing D. A. Weibring and Mark McCumber to move into a tie for the lead going into the final round of the 69th P.G.A. Championship.

title: New Alvin Ailey Official
description: Moy Eng has been named director of development of the Dance Theater Foundation Inc., the parent organization of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center. Ms. Eng, who received her master's degree in arts administration from New York University, has been development director for the St. Luke's Performing Arts Ensemble and was a member of the special arts services advisory panel of the New York State Council on the Arts from 1983 to 1986.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Worthington, Mass.;
Preserving The Farmland
description: LEAD: SINCE Massachusetts began its Agricultural Preservation Restriction program in the 70's, the state has saved 19,000 acres of farmland from development, said James P. Alicata, chief of the its Bureau of Land Use. He said he is hopeful that with additional funds from the Legislature, more will be saved.

title: ENCORE PERFROMANCES: NEW TACKS SUSTAIN SUMMER THEATERS
description: IN contrast to the shrinkage of summer stock theaters nationwide, four such professional theaters in Connecticut have developed their own special strategies for survival.

title: MOD, ECLECTIC MIX IN GREAT NECK
description: THE mode of the Kitchen restaurant in Great Neck is strictly mod. Suntanned, sport-clothed suburbanites dine amid mirrors, brass banisters, pink napery, dramatic floral arrangements and the obligatory strings of twinkling lights. They listen to the music of Porter, Gershwin and Berlin and peruse a wine list with exotic conversation pieces from the likes of Washington State and even Australia.

title: NATIONAL SECURITY ROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: THAT WAS NO PURPLE FINCH
description: Re: ''Tilling Doesn't Mean Killing,'' About Long Island, July 19:

title: FOR THOSE IN PURSUIT OF WESTCHESTER ESOTERICA
description: WESTCHESTER, so often recognized as the home of commuters, condominiums and carports, is claiming its rights to about 40 national ''firsts'' - plus an additional 260 seconds, thirds and just plain unusual facts about the county that range, according to the compiler, ''from the sublime to the ridiculous.''

title: Williams Discusses Prison Life
description: ONLY one man angered former United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. while he served his three-year sentence after being found guilty in his Abscam trial.

title: POSTINGS: Designers' Papers Sought; Unravelling A Mystery
description: The Old Executive Office Building in Washington -just the ''Old E.O.B.'' to locals - has been the workplace, at various stages of their careers, of William Howard Taft, Theodore Roosevelt, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur, Dwight D. Eisenhower and, more recently, Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver North. Vice President George Bush still has his office there.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the opening of the Cross County Square Shopping Center in Yonkers contained inaccurate information about financing for the Hudson River Museum. Federal and state contributions have increased; only the county contribution has been cut back, to $500,000 this year from $630,000 in 1986.

title: After Graduating From the Streets, Homeless Youths Find Better School
description: Constance Williams, born in the Bronx, left home when she was 11 years old and for seven years lived with friends, moving from place to place.

title: The Cost of Entering the Baby Chase
description: MANY people contemplating adoption have heard stories of bills totaling $20,000 and more - a cost that few can afford. Prospective adoptive parents should not despair, however. Adoptions need not cost dearly; with careful screening of the options available, the final bill will more likely run between $5,000 and $12,000.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Worthington, Mass.;
Preserving The Farmland
description: LEAD: SINCE Massachusetts began its Agricultural Preservation Restriction program in the 1970's, the state has saved 19,000 acres of farmland from development, said James P. Alicata, the chief of the state Bureau of Land Use. He said he is hopeful that more land will be saved with additional funding from the

title: U.S., Vietnam Resume Talks
description: The United States has refused to open diplomatic relations with Vietnam, but officials of the two countries have been talking for years about 1,700 Americans still listed as missing since the United States troops quit the war in 1973. Despite persistent reports that some of the Americans may be alive, no conclusive evidence has been found. Last week, a high-level American delegation went to Hanoi and agreed to add ''certain humanitarian concerns of Vietnam'' to the agenda.

title: DATA UPDATE: August 9, 1987
Fort Frederica
description: To the Editor: In ''A Georgia Port With a Royal Past'' (Travel, June 7), you state that Fort Frederica, guarding the coast against the Spanish, identifies its eponym Frederick, Prince of Wales, as the only son of George III. Instead, Frederick was the heir apparent of George II but he died in 1753. In 1760 George II was succeeded by Frederick's son as George III.

title: MELISSA RYAN TO BE A BRIDE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Ryan of Short Hills, N.J., and Bay Head, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Melissa Downey Ryan to Mark Joseph Nugent, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Nugent Jr. of Fair Haven, N.J. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned.

title: Eugen Loebl, 80, Dies; Former Czech Official
description: Eugen Loebl, a former Czechoslovak official who survived a purge trial of Czechoslovak leaders in 1952 known as the Slansky trial, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old. Dr. Loebl, who immigrated to the United States in 1968 after the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia, became a professor of political science and economics at Vassar College in 1969. He retired from the position in 1976.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: From the Bus, A Cross-Section Of Stockholm

title: How Germans Saw Hitler
description: LEAD: INSIDE NAZI GERMANY Conformity, Opposition, and Racism in Everyday Life. By Detlev J. K. Peukert. Translated by Richard Deveson. Illustrated. 288 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

title: Using Gardener's Gold
description: MULCH conserves soil moisture, keep roots cool and weeds out. The best mulch is the cheapest to buy and what is abundant locally; most gardeners like to save fall leaves and put them through a chipper; the fine pieces decompose in the soil to make it loose and friable. Other good mulches are chopped corn cobs, often available in rural areas, partially decayed compost, chopped straw or buckwheat hulls. Grass clippings can be used lightly, but they become rank if piled too thickly. Never use grass clippings from a lawn that has been treated with herbicide. Rudbeckia

title: SARA SLAFF IS THE BRIDE OF ANDREW H. LEVINE
description: Sara Slaff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Slaff of Annapolis, Md., was married there last evening to Andrew Herbert Levine, a son of Mrs. Robert H. Berkowitz of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Mordecai Schreiber performed the ceremony at the Governor Calvert House.

title: AIDS Virus Carrier Charged
description: Attempted murder charges have been lodged against a carrier of the AIDS virus who the police say cut his wrists and then bit and scratched emergency personnel and tried to infect them with his blood. A warrant was issued Friday for Donald J. Haines, 33 years old, of Lafayette, who will be arrested when he is released from a mental health center in West Lafayette, where he is being held for observation.

title: Baseball; Indians Defeat Blue Jays, 3-1, Behind Candiotti
description: Tom Candiotti scattered eight hits and Brett Butler scored two runs today as the Indians defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-1.

title: CHILE'S ELITE SEEKS 'SOFT LANDING'
description: ''SOMETIMES I have a dream,'' a bank chairman said recently, leaning back in his chair. ''It is that democracy returns to Chile, that I still have my car and house, my stock is secure, and the country takes off in fantastic development - instead of the left bringing back another Allende nightmare.'' The banker's attitudes are shared by many Chilean businessmen and industrialists.

title: MILLER MAX IS A BRIDE
description: Miller Max, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Conrad Max of Holland Patent, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Jean-Francois Fraysse, a son of Suzanne Malorey of Paris. the Rev. Dr. Stanley Gazek performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church. The bride, who will keep her name, is an actress. The bridegroom, a former actor and theater director, will be head chef at a new restaurant, La Luncheonette, which is to open in the SoHo area of Manhattan next month.

title: Heim and Quigley In Amateur Golf Final
description: Bill Heim, 17 years old, of New Franken, Wis., scored a 5 and 4 victory today over Hans Albertsson of Manchester, Vt., in a semifinal match of the 40th United States junior amateur golf championship.

title: OLD GRIEVANCES, NEW TACTICS
description: ISRAEL AND NBC NEWS REACHED A TRUCE THE other day; according to the terms, an Israeli official would be invited to appear on ''Today'' and explain his country's objections to an NBC documentary that was broadcast July 1. Israel had termed the documentary -''Six Days Plus 20 Years: A Dream Is Dying'' - ''biased and distorted.'' In retaliation, it said, NBC correspondents would not be allowed to interview Israel's Prime Minister, Foreign Minister or Defense Minister. NBC News, of course, denied the charge of bias and dispatched a vice president to Israel for negotiations. The appearance of an official on ''Today,'' supposedly, will mark the end of hostilities. In fact, it will not; it will just mean the end of the skirmish.

title: Let's Talk Nonsense
description: LEAD: NONSENSE is properly a negative thing - a lack of sense. By sense we mean not what the senses will accept but what seems logical to the brain. A sentence makes sense if it is a logical structure. Kill the structure and you have nonsense. The elements of a sentence - words - make sense when they relate to things you know.

title: SCARSDALE SUMMER MUSIC THEATER CONCERNED OVER FUTURE
description: LEAD: WHEN the curtain falls tonight on the 10th and final performance of ''A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court,'' the Scarsdale Summer Music Theater will have concluded its 14th year. Local supporters, parents and the 100 young people who participated in the program - the longest-running and most successful of its kind in the county -said they hoped it would not be the last.

title: ON THIS LITTLE TOUR, FOOD RULES OVER HISTORY
description: THERE are the Five Towns, and then there are the sixth, seventh, eighth and ninth towns. Here were these visitors from New Jersey, and it seemed like a good idea to show them the sights of East Rockaway, Oceanside, Baldwin and Freeport. Accompanied by my totally inaccurate thumbnail history of the area, we hit some of the high spots of these villages, which have never made it to the exalted status of the Five Towns.

title: UPSCALE RETAILING AND LIFE STYLES
description: The writing style that Brendan Dack of Carrefour U.S.A. and Patience O'Connor of Western Development Corporation use in their letter to the editor on June 28 is just as bad as the idea of their proposed Hypermarket for Brookhaven Town. I will copy their style in my response, so they can understand my objections.

title: Package of Banking Bills Is Signed by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo signed a package of consumer-oriented banking bills today intended to give New Yorkers greater protection against credit card theft and fraud.

title: About That Gold In the East River
description: WHAT glitters in New York's East River is usually the sun dancing off polluted debris, but a treasure hunter said in September 1985 that he had struck gold.

title: CHINA'S CULTURAL CRACKDOWN
description: I have just returned from three weeks in China as part of a small group of American film artists and educators. We found the Chinese consistently eager and available to meet with us; we enjoyed frequent and robust exchanges of views on a limitless variety of film arts issues. The films and discussions were quite wholly unrestrained, most especially with regard to criticism of the Cultural Revolution and, in particular, party ideology, orthodoxy, bureaucracy and security.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption accompanying an article on Brussels parks on July 5 misidentified the scene. The picture shows the Etangs d'Ixelles, Avenue General de Gaulle, in Brussels.

title: Mayoral Runoff for Nashville
description: A Congressman and his millionaire opponent began campaigning Friday after winning berths in a mayoral runoff, while backers of horse racing turned their sights to Memphis after a narrow loss in a parimutuel gambling referendum.

title: CHARTING A COURSE FOR NEW JERSEY
description: IN 1985, the Legislature charged the State Planning Commission with preparing a State Development and Redevelopment Plan. The commission comprises 17 civic and governmental leaders from throughout New Jersey, and is served by an unusually able professional staff.

title: Relocate The Broadcasters
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: I.B.M. Learns From the Macintosh
description: WHEN the first I.B.M. Personal Computer was introduced six years ago this week, it was easy for office workers to choose the computer they wanted to use at home. It would be the unadorned PC, the same one they had in the office.

title: John Artis Imprisoned Again
description: John Artis, who spent 14 years in prison as the accomplice of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, a former highly ranked middleweight boxer, before a Federal judge overturned their murder convictions, was in Passaic County Jail today.

title: The Lessons in Israel's Recovery
description: IS it a miracle befitting the Holy Land? Some crazy Old Testament economics? Or nothing but blue smoke and mirrors, an illusion that will soon be exposed?

title: Moses' Ghostwriters
description: LEAD: WHO WROTE THE BIBLE? By Richard Elliott Friedman. Illustrated. 299 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: YO, POE. By Frank Gannon. (Viking, $14.95.) This first collection brings together 25 very short pieces, a box of crazy candy to raid any time one feels a spell of perspicacity coming on. Frank Gannon's special gift is for mixing the highbrow with the lowbrow and nobrow, giving some goof a go at a high-toned text, a timeless truth, a literary grandee.

title: Boston Artists See End For Real Estate Wars
description: Like many artists, Chris Enos, a 43-year-old Boston photographer, has been through the real estate wars.

title: Editor at The New Yorker
description: LEAD: ONWARD AND UPWARD A Biography of Katharine S. White. By Linda H. Davis. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Turmoil at Library Dismays Port Jefferson
description: LEAD: AS a new director prepares to step into his post at the Port Jefferson Free Library on Aug. 13, the resignations of the current director and senior librarian have left the small community stunned and dismayed.

title: SOUND FOOTING
description: THEY ARE CERTAINLY not the most beloved part of the body. But there is no denying that the feet are highly capable, sensitive marvels of architecture. There are even those who believe the foot is the mirror of the soul. Reflexologists assert that when certain parts of the feet are pressed and massaged, corresponding parts of the body can be relaxed and repaired. Manolo Blahnik, the shoe designer, believes the foot contains information about the person's character. ''When you see a woman's foot, you know immediately what kind of girl she is,'' he says. ''If the toenails are fabulously groomed, that person is a perfectionist. Her mind is tidy and her house is in order.''

title: HELPING CHILDREN IN TROUBLE WITH THE LAW
description: WHEN I met David last year, he was a withdrawn but appealing 14-year-old, accused of committing a burglary with a group of 17- and 18-year-olds. A Family Court Judge appointed me as David's Law Guardian to represent him as he made his way through the judicial system. Since David readily admitted his guilt, the Family Court's task was to decide what would become of him. My job was to act as David's legal advocate in that process.

title: ITALY: POLITICS OF OPERA
description: IT WAS A FLORENTINE SUNDAY early in June when they rehearsed ''Il ritorno d'Ulisse in patria'' at the Teatro Communale. Claudio Monteverdi wrote it 347 years ago for a few of his friends; Hans Werner Henze (very much alive) has puffed it up for the modern stage. It's not a production you're likely to see in New York. One of our shoestring what-do-we-have-to- lose? companies might have the nerve, but couldn't begin to handle its size. This is a big opera - a fascinating, if grotesque, transposition of early Baroque refinement into the grandest of Romantic spectacles.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Las Vegas, Nev.;
Piped-In Water For an Oasis
description: LEAD: WORK has been completed on a 4.5-mile pipeline to bring water to a large-scale residential development under construction at the northwest fringe of this fast-growing city.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Far Rockaway
description: LEAD: THE fortunes of Far Rockaway, a seaside community that anchors the eastern end of the Rockaway peninsula in Queens, have tended in the last century to mimic the ocean: waves, followed by troughs.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTS PEACE AGREEMENT BY 5 LATIN LEADERS
description: President Reagan expressed support today for the preliminary peace pact reached by five Latin American nations, but said ''there is much work to be done by the parties involved.''

title: Philadelphia Recycling: 'It's a Living'
description: By midmorning the line of men with shopping carts stretches out of the old Nabisco factory, across the yard and to the street, where still more men unburden station wagons loaded with automobile radiators, newspapers and hundreds of aluminum cans.

title: Victorian Scenes On a Melbourne Walk
description: Sedate and stately Melbourne is more ''British'' than Sydney, and some might say not nearly so vibrant. The city does contain, however, some of the most splendid architecture in all of Australia, and points with civic pride to the 1,700 acres devoted to parks, playgrounds and brilliantly planned gardens, both private and public. The parks and gardens occupy about a quarter of the central city, where beautiful old buildings with ornate facades are neighbors of gleaming modern structures. Here, a walking tour not only presents a catalogue of fine examples of Victorian buildings but also offers the opportunity to discover a great deal about Melbourne's historical and esthetic evolution. This repository of architecture is protected by Australia's National Trust.

title: St. Patrick Monkeys Around
description: BRENDAN By Frederick Buechner. 240 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: Plot Thickens in America's Cup Challenge
description: The political infighting that has prevented the San Diego Yacht Club from naming a site for the next America's Cup series is beginning to pale in light of a controversy over an unorthodox challenge from New Zealand.

title: LIVING ROOM TO STAGE, VIA JAZZ
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH they are all seasoned musicians, the seven young men who, along with their mentor, the pianist-teacher Ranny Reeve, comprise the I.A.J. Ambassadors are a bit nervous about their latest gig.

title: Q and A
description: Madagascar Question: We would appreciate information on touring Madagascar. Is there a best time of year for a visit? - D. W. G., Philadelphia Answer: Since few American tour companies organize trips to Madagascar - tourist facilities there are not as well developed as in East Africa - information is not easy to obtain. The 975-mile-long island republic in the Indian Ocean has some modern hotels, internal flights and bus transportation, but tour companies say that planning travel there takes a lot of work. Among Madagascar's attractions are fishing and its variety of bird life. A bird-watching tour company, Field Guides (Post Office Box 160723, Austin, Tex. 78746; 512-327-4953), ran a tour last year and is doing another this fall. (Field Guides has wide experience with birders' expeditions in South America.) The three-week trip will depart New York on Oct. 23 and fly to Madagascar's capital, Tananarive, via Paris and Nairobi. Mauritius and Reunion are also included in the itinerary, and there is an optional extension to the Seychelle Islands. An official of Field Guides said about half of the 250 species of birds likely to be spotted can only be seen in Madagascar.

title: Be Sure To Check The Rules
description: WHEN owners are planning a major renovation or addition to a single-family house, few give adequate thought to the permits that will be needed before work can begin, or even that their plans might violate certain environmental or zoning regulations.

title: GUIDELINES SET BY COURT
description: LEAD: WHEN he left the bench six years ago, Judge Neil G. Duffy of State Superior Court did what many judges do when they retire: resume law practice.

title: SUZANNE WILCOCK TO WED IN SEPTEMBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bray Wilcock of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Jill Wilcock to Donnell Anthony Segalas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hercules A. Segalas of Morristown, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: HISTORIC HOUSES: 1 SAVED, 1 MOVED
description: ON a gentle, grassy slope, the Enoch Kelsey house stands, nestled in its hometown of Newington, an object of great pride to the community.

title: REAGAN TO DISPUTE POINDEXTER VIEWS
description: President Reagan is expected to dispute the assertion by Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter that the ''buck stops here with me'' for the decision to divert Iran arms-sales profits to the Nicaraguan rebels when he speaks to the country on Wednesday.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We have a large room with a parquet wood floor. Under the wood is a concrete slab that has radiant heating pipes. These pipes burst several times, so we disconnected them and use other heat. The flooring has been sanded, stained and refinished with polyurethane, but the finish dried spotty, especially along the seams. What is the problem and how can we solve it?

title: Lox & Yachts
description: To the Editor:

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS FIND FREEDOM AT IMMIGRATION CENTER
description: ''She says that she feels like she has wings,'' Park Yun said of his mother, who hd just been given an employment authorization card - the first major hurdle in the process for legalization of immigrant status under the new amnesty law.

title: A New Haven Hospital Widens Uses of Laser
description: A NEW HAVEN hospital is one of five sites in the country experimenting with expanded use of the YAG laser, and doctors there say the initial results show the laser holds a lot of hope for people who need delicate ear, nose and throat surgery.

title: Pianist at Work
description: Vladimir O. Feltsman, the pianist, appeared destined for the heights of Soviet stardom when, in 1979, he asked the wrong question: May I leave? The Kremlin promptly clamped a lid on his career. The concert halls of Moscow and Leningrad were closed to him, his records disappeared from the stores. Last week, however, in a move credited to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of greater openness, Mr. Feltsman and his family were given permission to emigrate. The 35-year-old pianist, who plans to settle in New York, said the eight lost years cost him a lot but also taught him much. ''I understand life better, I understand people better, I understand myself better, and that means I understand music better,'' he said, ''so I'm absolutely sure I play the piano better.''

title: MAGAININ, SHIELD AGAINST DISEASE
description: In July last year Michael Zasloff, a geneticist at the National Institutes of Health, watched an African clawed frog recover from a surgical incision. He had noticed the frog's sturdy healing process many times before, but this time he wondered why it healed so easily in tank water murky with bacteria. That was the first step toward a discovery that may prove of great importance to medicine.

title: GEORGE BLISS SCHWAB ENGAGED TO WED KATHERINE E. WHELAHAN IN SEPTEMBER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond James Whelahan of Virginia Beach, Va., of the engagement of their daughter Katherine Elizabeth Whelahan to George Bliss Schwab, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann C. Schwab of Oyster Bay, L.I. The wedding is planned for Sept. 26.

title: SOME PERPLEXING PROBLEMS ON THE SOUND
description: LEAD: FOR boaters and beachgoers on Long Island Sound, fish kills, algal blooms and low levels of dissolved oxygen have created some unpleasant memories of the summer of '87.

title: HEMPSTEAD WEIGHS ORDINANCE TO PROTECT TREES
description: LEAD: WHEN the Town of Hempstead's curb and sidewalk renovation project destroyed two dozen trees, a group of North Merrick residents banded together to save nine venerable red and sugar maples in the neighborhood. This latest protest of tree-felling has led Hempstead to consider an ordinance requiring developers to file ''tree plans'' with the town's Building

title: Kennedy Chapels
description: To the Editor:

title: This 'Magic Flute' Keeps the 'Spiel' in the 'Sing'
description: LEAD: THE NEW YORK CITY Opera is doing its first German-language version of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' this season, instead of the usual English, and it seems appropriate that the director for the new production is Lofti Mansouri, who first introduced supertitles at his own Canadian Opera Company. Like all Mozart operas, ''The Magic Flute,'' which opens on Friday (and will be broadcast on public television on Oct.

title: Calvin Butts: Maverick's Power Rises
description: When he was 13 years old, Calvin O. Butts sat in the balcony of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem and heard the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr. preach. ''I was amazed,'' Mr. Butts recalled. ''He was a larger-than-life figure, and people were in love with him. He was prophet, priest and king.'' In the years since, that image has remained a powerful inspiration for Mr. Butts. Today, at 38 years of age, he is the executive minister of the church that towers over West 138th Street - a rising voice in the city who has placed himself squarely in the black clergy's long tradition of social action.

title: WHAT OPTIONS FOR ACTION IN GULF?
description: ALTHOUGH Secretary of State George P. Shultz asserted last week that the United States could avoid hostilities in the Persian Gulf, specialists on the region and senior military officers were not so sure.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We have a large room with a parquet wood floor. Under the wood is a concrete slab that has radiant heating pipes. These pipes burst several times, so we disconnected them and use other heat. The flooring has been sanded, stained and refinished with polyurethane, but the finish dried spotty, especially along the seams. What is the problem and how can we solve it?

title: SARAH WEBSTER MARRIES
description: Sarah Knox Webster, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Knox of Old Saybrook, Conn., and George Lindsay Mayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Mayer of Milwaukee, were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Essex, Conn. The Rev. Joshua Crowell performed the ceremony. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom, who is the president of the Manhattan Realty Group.

title: JEANNE DONOVAN WEDS JOHN GARRETT ANDREWS
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J., Jeanne Marie Donovan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Christopher Donovan of Hudson, Ohio, was married yesterday to John Garrett Andrews, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Thomas Andrews of Colts Neck, N.J.

title: 3 Get Jail Terms in Philadelphia
description: Former City Councilman Leland Beloff, convicted of conspiring with a crime leader to extort $1 million from a waterfront developer, has been sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $150,000.

title: THE SPOTLIGHT NOW FALLS ON WALSH
description: WITH the close of Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair, attention now turns to a cluster of heavily guarded offices in downtown Washington where the special prosecutor and his staff are weighing criminal charges in the case.

title: Discovering Joy of Wildlife at Camp
description: Walking arm in arm, helping one another up a steep row of rocks, the girls from the Fresh Air Fund camp looked more like country cousins than the inner-city slickers they really are.

title: MARY SCORESE IS MARRIED TO HOLGER PATRICK SCHEID
description: At St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J., Mary Elizabeth Scorese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick E. Scorese of Saddle River, was married yesterday to Holger Patrick Scheid. The Rev. Edward F. Kavin performed the ceremony.

title: WINNING RAFT IN RIVER RACE IS TRIED, TRUE AND HIGH TECH
description: HAT'S in a name? Apparently not much, at least where the raft New Management is concerned. The vessel won its division in the 13th annual Connecticut River Raft Race last weekend, after winning five previous races under the name America.

title: Supertitles in Concert
description: To the Editor:

title: How Don Johnston Lost JWT
description: AS Donald Johnston flew back to New York from London on June 10, he knew he was up against a major corporate crisis. There had been many in his 13 years as chief executive of J. Walter Thompson, but this one could not be solved by the usual means. He could not dismiss anyone. There was no irate client to be soothed by the ad world's master diplomat.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on July 26 about Ann Magnuson incorrectly described a video program called ''Made for TV.'' The 15-minute work was produced and directed by Tom Rubnitz in 1984.

title: The Pain Behind The Laughter of Moms Mabley
description: SEVERAL YEARS AGO CLARICE Taylor was sitting around in a restaurant one day telling Moms Mabley jokes. She was shocked when a friend interrupted to ask, ''Who's Moms Mabley?' ''

title: COLIN WALTER CHURCHILL JR. MARRIED TO EMILY ROBERTS
description: At the Martha Mary Chapel in Sudbury, Mass., Emily Sue Dreyfus Roberts, the daughter of Barbara Allen Roberts of Framingham Center, Mass., and the late Sumner Burrell Roberts, was married yesterday to Colin Walter Churchill Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Churchill of Hilton Head Island, S.C. The Rev. Deborah Pope-Lance, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: My Mother the Despot
description: PRIVILEGED CHILDREN By Frances Vernon. 199 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $15.95.

title: Wiggins Reinstated
description: ALAN WIGGINS, who was suspended by the Baltimore Orioles for three days for insuborination, was reinstated yesterday.

title: OPERA THEATER RETURNS TO CLINTON
description: ENCOURAGED by the success and good attendance at its debut last year, the Opera Theater of Connecticut is returning to Andrews Memorial Theater in Clinton with two fully staged performances of Puccini's exotic classic, ''Madame Butterfly.''

title:
ART;
Paintings by Richter In Atheneum Exhibit
description: LEAD: THE German painter Gerhard Richter is the 95th in a distinguished series of contemporary artists to show in Matrix, the contemporary art program of the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. One of the more fruitful approaches to his art is to think of him as a kind of Andy Warhol in gray.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: DREAMS OF THE KALAHARI. By Carolyn Slaughter. (Scribners, $19.95.) Set in southern Africa and in London, this singular coming-of-age novel is about an 11-year-old English girl, Emily Jones, a misfit among the colonials, whose life we follow from childhood to sexual and political maturity. Emily's father is an inept administrator in the African desert; her unloving mother's single accomplishment is flirtation.

title: 70 RESERVE SUITES ARE OFFERED FOR SALE
description: LA RESERVE, which opened in May 1982 as the first all-suite hotel in the county, has begun to sell half the suites as condominiums.

title: U.S. PATENT CHIEF SEES FOREIGN GAINS
description: Last year foreigners accounted for almost half of the patents granted by the United States Government, with the largest proportion of those going to the Japanese, the head of the United States Patent Office said today.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Milford, Pa.;
Tight Reins In the Poconos
description: LEAD: IN the exclusive residential subdivisions in and around the Delaware River community of Milford, it is not unusual for developers to place deed covenants on lots before they sell them.

title: PROGRESS REPORT ON COUNTY CENTER
description: LEAD: HE is normally soft-spoken and polite, but lately Walter C. Schatz has been doing a lot of shouting, perhaps an understandable reaction when one is overseeing a $16 million renovation.

title: In August, Forecast for Jan. 31
description: WITH ALL PRECINCTS unaccounted for, the early Super Bowl favorites are the Giants and the Seattle Seahawks.

title: Portland
description: Contrary to rumors, the sun does shine in Portland, Ore. But because it drizzles considerably throughout the year, this city of 368,000 has earned a reputation of being a lush, but damp, place even though the annual rainfall is less than in Miami or Atlanta.

title:
INVESTING;
Aggressive Plays for Cautious Investors
description: LEAD: DESPITE this year's boom in stocks and gold, many conservative investors parked their money in short-term Treasury securities or bank certificates of deposit, at annual interest rates of about 6 percent. But those returns pale when compared with the 35 percent advance of the Dow Jones industrial average and a 20 percent rise in the price of gold since the beginning of the year.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WINDBREAK: A Woman Rancher on the Northern Plains. By Linda Hasselstrom. Barn Owl Books, Box 7727, Berkeley, Calif., 94707; $12.95.) One of the charms of women's autobiographical writing lies in the writer's willingness to record the minutiae of daily life rather than sacrifice them to heroic moments.

title: 'WOMAN OF THE YEAR' AT THE CLARIDGE
description: MORE than midway through ''Woman of the Year,'' the musical at the Palace Theater in the Claridge Hotel Casino, a glamorous, worldly, multiple-award-winning (one Pulitzer Prize, two Peabodies, three Emmies) television newscaster - about to lose at marriage for the second time - visits her first husband and his second wife in Colorado, to find out where she went wrong.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
EXERCISE
description: LEAD: Massage Your Mate V.I.E.W. Video. (800) 843-9843. 92 minutes. $39.95.

title: L.I. REPUBLICANS KEEP THE MACHINE ON TRACK
description: LONG Island Republicans are fond of pointing their fingers at New York City's Democratic ''bosses'' as election-time bogymen. But if anyone has inherited the Tammany Hall tradition of successful machine politicking, the Democrats say, it is the Republican ''bosses'' on Long Island. Recent maneuverings are cited as cases in point. Three of the top officeholders in Nassau and two in Suffolk County owe their jobs not to the voters, but to their party leaders. In a masterly game of political musical chairs, the Republican leaders have bestowed upon their loyalists the advantage of running this fall as incumbents without having been elected in the first place. In one case, a party leader even picked himself.

title: RED GROOMS'S CITIES OF THE MIND
description: THERE IS AN HONORABLE TRADITION, AT least in our time, of the artist as architecture critic. Saul Steinberg's collages have deftly demolished the banal, boxy facades of modern skyscrapers; Siah Armajani's sculptures comment subtly on the nature of architectural form. But surely no artist has looked at architecture as ambitiously as Red Grooms, who takes on not merely single buildings but whole cities. Red Grooms's vision of the city is total and complete - it is of a teeming place, alive with people and buildings and bridges and subways, richly aware of its history and yet vibrant in a way that suggests an energetic present. The city that Red Grooms shows us is wild and exuberant, dazzling and devastating.

title: CONGRESS ASSESSES SHOREHAM GEOGRAPHY
description: THE House of Representatives got a lesson in Long Island geography last week as Congress addressed in earnest the licensing dilemma that has held up operation of the Long Island plant and one in New Hampshire, Seabrook.

title: A Woman's Touch at the Friars Club
description: DECADES of cigar smoking had darkened the ceilings.

title: Hemingway in Dresses
description: To the Editor:

title: National League; Phillies Hammered by Herr and Pena
description: Tommy Herr hit a home run, two doubles and a single, driving in three runs, and Tony Pena added a three-run homer and a run-scoring single tonight to lead the St. Louis Cardinals over the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-5.

title: Managua Calls Latin Pact a Historic 'First Step'
description: The Sandinista Government has described the accord signed Friday by five Central American leaders as a historic step toward peace, but Managua is warning that important obstacles remain.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Pasta With Pumpkin Filling
description: LEAD: In Mantua they are known as tortelli, in Ferrara as cappellacci. To the uninitiated, these two lesser-known members of the vast family of filled pastas might be mistaken for their more famous cousins, the Tuscan ravioli and the Bolognese tortelloni. The pasta is the same: the classic sfoglia or egg noodle dough favored in parts of the Po River Valley.

title: Dr. Andrew Holt, 82, A University President
description: Dr. Andrew David Holt, president of the University of Tennessee in its period of greatest growth, from 1959 to 1970, died here Friday. He was 82 years old.

title: Art's Anguish Is A Constant Joy To Behold
description: THE REAPPEARANCE ON screen of Paul Gauguin, in ''The Wolf at the Door,'' is evidence of the enduring appeal to movie makers of the lives of artists. And why not? The 19th-century artist, that superbly suffering figure, challenger of convention, unbudgeably independent, holding to his unique vision despite the scorn of a philistine society, enduring poverty in his, yes, garret, solaced only by adoring and available serving girls and society women, is the hot stuff of romantic drama. If the fellow is slightly cracked or behaves outrageously, so much the better. Cut off an ear like van Gogh, and it's a highbrow ''Blue Velvet.'' Leave your family like Gauguin, and your chances of being memorialized take a leap.

title: MISS LOUBET WED TO A.W. SENEAR
description: Trudie Victoria Loubet, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Rothschild Loubet of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Weston, Vt., and Allen Wellman Senear, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Eugene Senear of Clyde Hill, Wash., were married yesterday at the Captain Whidbey Inn on Whidbey Island, Wash., by the Rev. Douglas Anderson, a Presbyterian minister.

title: OCTOBER WEDDING FOR MISS ENDERS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O. Enders of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Claire Whitmore Enders to Christopher H. W. Thomson, the son of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Bryan H. Thomson of Fife, Scotland. An October wedding is planned.

title: A FAMILY LIVING APART AND STAYING CLOSE
description: THREE years have passed since Shira went off to boarding school. Initially it was a very scary time for my husband and me. We had been raised to believe that good, caring parents simply did not cast off their children's upbringing on nonfamily members and certainly not away from the home environment.

title: HAGEN CELEBRATES WITH NEW ROLE
description: UTA HAGEN, the actress who will be celebrating her 50th anniversary in the theater this year, has a reputation for being choosy about roles. She has won Tony awards for her performances as Georgie in ''The Country Girl'' and Martha in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf,'' and she has been applauded for her other performances, including Desdemona in ''Othello'' and Blanche DuBois in ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' and, most recently, in ''You Never Can Tell.''

title: CAROLYN GOLDEN WEDS DAVID BAYNE, A LAW STUDENT
description: St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Carolyn Jane Golden, a daughter of Janet M. Golden of West Chazy, N.Y., and the late Raymond L. Golden, to David Forbes Bayne, a son of Katherine S. Bayne of New York and the late Carroll S. Bayne Jr. The Rev. Paul Dinter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Barbra Golden Rosner was her sister's matron of honor. Robert Brinkley Smithers 3d was best man.

title: An Australian Edition Of Cannery Row
description: Not many settlements on this earth, so far as one can gather, sport a life-size divers' recompression chamber on a plinth in the public park. Few enough have a crashed airliner set up as a monument at the end of the main street. Rare are the cities whose fortune is founded on an animal that can change sex depending on what food it eats. And it is unlikely that the world is much littered with places where an English lord employs a group of aborigines to feed 4 Arabian camels, 3 wombats, a pair of cassowaries and 13 rainbow lorikeets.

title: VINELAND SET BACK ON V. A. CLINIC
description: LEAD: THIS Cumberland County city's three-year effort to have a veterans' outpatient clinic built here instead of at a leased site approved in Ocean County by the Veterans Administration has been delivered a severe blow by Governor Kean, who said he would not take sides in the issue.

title: Hodel's Proposal To Undam a Dam
description: When Gifford Pinchot, who headed the Forest Service under Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and William Howard Taft, proposed that the Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park be dammed and flooded to provide water for San Francisco, John Muir denounced supporters of the project as ''temple destroyers.'' But Muir, the prophet of environmentalism, lost the fight.

title: Recent Sales
description: Copiague $135,000 60 Buchanan Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; basement, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. Garden City Park $200,000 112 Third Street 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old Tudor; dining room, finished basement; taxes $2,500. St. James $161,000 156 St. James Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, cedar and brick siding; taxes $3,100. Seaford $215,000 2594 Irene Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old high ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen family room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $4,100. Stony Brook $275,000 19 Westwood Avenue, 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 5-year-old Tudor; den with fireplace, central air-conditioning, 2-car garage, 0.75 acre; taxes $5,000. Wantagh $212,000 29 Ewell Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; fireplace, new kitchen, trees on property; taxes $2,800. OTHER AREAS Vernon, N.J. $87,900 4 Jorgin Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; fireplace, near lake, new heater; taxes $1,000. West Hartford, Conn. $220,000 52 Arnoldall Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, hardwood floors, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,080. Rye, N.Y. $629,500 20 Intervale Place 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 64-year-old colonial; studio, den, mud room, walk to school and stores; taxes $4,523.

title: Plans for Mail-In Kit To Check for AIDS
description: Several companies plan to offer mail-in testing kits for the AIDS virus, stirring concern among public health officials and drawing criticism from many doctors and groups working with AIDS patients.

title: TURBANS AND VEILS
description: THE THIEF OF BAGDAD With Sabu, Rex Ingram and Conrad Veidt. Directed by Ludwig Berger, Michael Powell, Tim Whelan and Zoltan Korda. Embassy Home Entertainment 106 minutes. $19.95.

title: EXECUTIONS ON THE RISE AS LEGAL BARRIERS FALL
description: In the 1950's Louisiana's oak electric chair and the generator that powered it traveled from parish to parish in a grim roadshow that allowed punishment to be meted out where the crime was committed.

title: Of Bugs and Bytes and Zoom Lenses
description: IF Bill Kizorek is tailing you, he won't be doing it from a few yards away with a newspaper hiding his face. Chances are he'll be a block away, watching you through a video camera in a surveillance van -and you'll never know he's there.

title: Yankees Regain First
description: The offense had been dormant and the pitching almost pathetic, but today the Yankees pulled themselves back into first place - even as their irascible owner, George Steinbrenner, issued a scathing public critique of his manager, Lou Piniella.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We have a large room with a parquet wood floor. Under the wood is a concrete slab that has radiant heating pipes. These pipes burst several times, so we disconnected them and use other heat. The flooring has been sanded, stained and refinished with polyurethane, but the finish dried spotty, especially along the seams. What is the problem and how can we solve it?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 2 on legislative proposals to make English the official state language in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey misstated the status of legislation in New York. A bill and a proposed constitutional amendment both died in the last legislative session.

title: Pope Will Meet Jewish Leaders
description: When Pope John Paul II gave an audience in June to President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, it elicited outraged protests, particularly from Jewish leaders, in Israel and the United States.

title: Jazz
description: Illinois Jacquet is usually thought of as a product of the swing era and the big bands that flourished then. And, in truth, he is. He played in territory bands in the Southwest during the late 1930's and he first joined a major band - Lionel Hampton's - in 1941. During the next five years he moved to Cab Calloway's band and then to Count Basie's.

title: Ex-Armco Chief Is Said to Be Choice for Commerce
description: C. William Verity Jr., the retired head of Armco Inc., is expected to be nominated for Commerce Secretary early this week, according to sources in business, Congress and the Administration.

title: Remembering Leichtentritt
description: To the Editor:

title: Chad Reports Expelling Last Libyan Troops
description: The Chad radio said today that Chadian troops had swept all remaining Libyan troops from Chadian territory and reconquered the Aouzou Strip, the northernmost area of the country.

title: COLLABORATION SPARKS CREATIVITY IN Wood
description: IN COLLABORATIVE works at their best, two or more talents rubbed together light a creative spark that takes each beyond its limits. At the Genest Gallery here, a selection of furniture and wood accessories does exactly that.

title: Real Trouble Ahead
description: HITTING MYSELF on the head with a pickax changed a pleasant afternoon of puttering in the yard into a revelation. Or perhaps I should say half a revelation. The blow knocked my glasses off; they haven't turned up yet, and my view of the event -and its meaning - is still unclear.

title: John Dewey in the Bauhaus
description: THE ARTS AT BLACK MOUNTAIN COLLEGE By Mary Emma Harris. Illustrated. 315 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $50.

title:
FOCUS: LAKEFRONTS;
Condos Intruding On 'Camps'
description: LEAD: THIRTY years ago, when John and Priscilla Dyer built their cedar-log vacation home on the shore of Lake Winnipesaukee for about $10,000, the place was a rural retreat surrounded by neighbors with similar homes and similar interests.

title: Patriotic Lying
description: TAKING THE OATH

title: LYNN GOLDENBERG MARRIES SCOTT BERNSTEIN, A LAWYER
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Lynn Goldenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goldenberg of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., and Scott Bennett Bernstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Bernstein of Woodmere, L.I., were married last evening by Rabbi Arnold Marans.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
RAISING MOTHS
description: LEAD: They don't fly yet - at least not in their adult form - but next spring, a dozen cecropia moths will be among the inhabitants of Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Pound Ridge.

title: THE ROLES OF ARTIST AND LISTENER
