description: A COUPLE OF WEEKS AGO, I FOUND MYSELF AT a Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra concert that ended with Gerard Schwarz conducting Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' Symphony. Now Mr. Schwarz is an enormously talented conductor who has been growing steadily as an interpreter in the years since he switched from the trumpet to the baton. On the other hand, the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra is an overworked, underrehearsed ensemble, for all the skills of its players.

title: Editors' Note
description: A dispatch on July 26 from La Habra, Calif., described the case of a Harvard University student, Jose Razo, who has been charged in several armed robberies. It said his history - that of a poor youth from the Mexican-American barrio who enters an elite university - ''illustrates the difficulties of living in two disparate worlds.'' It added, ''Harvard officials and others who have looked into Mr. Razo's case defend the preferential admissions programs that have allowed him and thousands of black and Hispanic youths from impoverished backgrounds to enroll in prestigious colleges.''

title: Romulus Linney Conjures Up His 'Holy Ghosts'
description: ''A SOUTHERN CHILDHOOD IS A very primal thing,'' says the playwright Romulus Linney, leaning forward in a chair in his West Side apartment, in the Manhattan he has lived in for almost three decades. ''I think Katharine Anne Porter said that what happens to you after you're 10 years old really doesn't matter very much, but the things that happen before you were 10 matter a great deal.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: NADINE. By Matt Cohen. (Crown, $16.95.) The meticulously constructed memoir of a middle-aged Toronto astronomer convalescing in her childhood Parisian apartment provides the vehicle for the Canadian author Matt Cohen's fourth novel. Nadine Santangel is born during the Nazi occupation to beautiful, doomed parents and brought up by a succession of standoffish guardians.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
NATURE AND PROPORTION
description: LEAD: TWO columbine are just now blooming in Connecticut.

title: STACEY E. ENGEL IS WED TO KENNETH F. COGLAND
description: Stacey Elise Engel and Kenneth Francis Cogland were married in Wilmington, Del., yesterday at the home of the bride's father, Ernest E. Engel. The Rev. L. Larry Pullen, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: It's Done with Mirrors
description: Most of us would give up the game quickly and gloomily if our opponents seemed able to see through the backs of the cards and make plays of extra-terrestrial wizardry. Luckily this is a very rare event, but one was described by this department in 1980. It occurred in Athens, and a recent sequel has been reported by Warren Dix.

title: East End's Natural Beauty Seen in 2 Photo Shows
description: LEAD: ''THE light on the East End is so beautiful for photography,'' said Janice Allen, a photographer who lives in Amagansett. ''Some say the fall is better, or the spring is, but to me all four seasons offer special visual advantages.''

title: Evictions Planned On Drugs
description: HOUSING AUTHORITY officials in Danbury, Hartford and New Haven say that tenant complaints have pushed them to try to rid their buildings of residents involved in drug crimes.

title: Opera: Santa Fe Offers 'Butterfly'
description: THERE is much to be said for the potential benefit of light lyric voices in Puccini, but it has to be said in a cloud of qualifications. Unless the conductor is far more sensitive than most are today, unless the house is well below City Opera or Metropolitan size, unless (most important) the singer is secure in his technique and comfortable with his own vocal identity - then lyric voices can wreck themselvs straining over Puccini's symphonic orchestrations. But if all conditions are met, a sweet and youthful-sounding voice can give us colors and qualities denied to all but a few of the more heroic singers.

title: JUDITH ELIZABETH HUPCEY WEDS DR. IAN C. GILCHRIST
description: St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Beacon, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Judith Elizabeth Hupcey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Hupcey of Hempstead, L.I., and Dr. Ian Charles Gilchrist, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bruce Gilchrist of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Center Harbor, N.H. The Rev. Martin Connolly performed the ceremony.

title: Italy: The Symphony Front
description: ITALY HAS PRODUCED MORE THAN its share of important composers, conductors and instrumentalists in this century, but it has not been renowned for the excellence of its symphony orchestras. The reason no longer lies, as it did for two centuries, in opera's predominance as public entertainment. Recent generations of Italians, like their counterparts elsewhere, have been raised on movies and television, and for most of them concert music as well as opera now count as Culture with a capital C, rather than popular entertainment.

title: Movies
description: Macao Starring Jane Russell, Robert Mitchum, William Bendix. Directed by Josef Von Sternberg. 1952. Fox Hills Video. 81 minutes. $19.95.

title: MARINES IN NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE Chicago White Sox activated a relief pitcher, Bob James, from the 15-day disabled list and removed acatcher, Ron Hassey, from the 21-day list. . . . Reggie Ritter, the Cleveland Indians' pitcher who was struck on the chin by a line drive in a game against the Toronto Blue Jays Friday night, was placed on the 21-day disabled list. The club activated an infielder, Julio Franco, from the list. . . . Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the Boston Red Sox pitcher who has been plagued with shoulder problems, will undergo tests this week. . . . Ron Essink, an offensive tackle who walked out of the Seattle Seahwawks's training camp Thursday night, may be sold to the Dallas Cowboys, Seattle officials said. . . Trevor Matich, an offensive lineman for the New England Patriots, broke a bone in his right foot on Friday and will be out several months. . . . A body found in car submerged in a pond in Wheaton, Ill., was tentatively identified as that of Carol Pappas, the wife of Milt Pappas, a former pitcher for the Chicago Cubs. She disappeared five years ago.

title: Family Reunion Crowds a Mountain
description: LEAD: MORE than 200 members of the Andrew family squeezed shoulder to shoulder last weekend on a meadow on Andrew Mountain in Naugatuck. Someone said the obligatory ''cheese,'' and everyone beamed as a videotape camera, two still cameras held by professional photographers, and three or four other cameras focused by members of the clan recorded the event.

title:
ART;
TRIBUTE TO WARHOL OFFERS KEY INSIGHTS
description: LEAD: FOR many, it has taken the death of Andy Warhol to provide the impetus to put his art in perspective. One place to examine a quantity of his work and to gain useful insight is the Dan Flavin Art Institute in Bridgehampton, where a small memorial exhibition fills the first-floor gallery.

title: Golf; Zahringer, Titus in Met Final
description: George Zahringer 3d, a four-time winner of the Metropolitan Amateur golf championship, and Stuart Titus, seven times the club champion of The Creek, will meet Sunday in the final match of the 85th Met Amateur at the Meadow Brook Club.

title: THE UNFLINCHING EYE
description: The photographs in The Times Magazine by Mary Ellen Mark (''The Unflinching Eye: Photojournalist Mary Ellen Mark,'' by Vicki Goldberg, July 12) touched me deeply and made an unforgettable impact. The story about her work gave not only a rare glimpse of someone who is an extraordinary artist, an expert with the mechanics of her camera, but also of a very caring human being who is able to care for her subjects. Her pictures make us take notice that life is not pretty for many and educate us about human conditions we otherwise might not know about. EVA SEINFELD New Milford, Conn.

title: A REDUCTION IN AIRCRAFT NOISE IS EXPECTED UNDER NEW LANDING SYSTEM
description: COUNTY residents will find airplane noise less disturbing and New York-area passengers will suffer fewer flight delays when the major airports in the New York City area agree to fully implement a new landing-control system, the Federal Aviation Administration said last week, The Microwave Landing System, or M.L.S., allows planes to approach a runway from a number of angles - as opposed to the current rigid lineup from one direction - and therefore would double capacity at the airports and substantially reduce noise by modifying takeoff and landing routes, F.A.A. officials told pilots at a briefing last week at the County Airport.

title: Employers Warned on Alien Hiring
description: A senior immigration official reassured the managers of a curtain factory in Long Island City the other day that he had come to explain the new immigration law's provisions on employer sanctions, ''not enforce them.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Washington dispatches on June 27 and July 12 about the Supreme Court career of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. described his legal education incorrectly. He received undergraduate and law degrees from Washington and Lee University; he earned a master of laws degree at Harvard Law School.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE PRIVATE EYE BUSINESS
description: PRIVATE eyes don't just spy on cheating spouses anymore. More and more, they are investigating companies involved in mergers and acquisitions, pursuing corporate embezzlers, checking out insider trading scandals, uncovering illegal apartment sublets and proving insurance fraud.

title: AQUACULTURE AND THE FUTURE
description: TWENTY years ago Dr. Robert B. Abel became founding director of the national Sea Grant program, a Federal effort to support marine research. One of its goals was to develop aquaculture, the ''farming'' of ocean, estuarine and freshwater environments.

title: INSURANCE: NEW FIGHT SHAPING UP
description: FOR the third time in 18 months, the Republican majority in the Assembly has passed a bill calling for a change in New Jersey's automobile insurance law. The measure aims at limiting suits arising from accidents, and for the third time the Democratic-controlled Senate appears ready to reject it.

title: KATE C. MURDOCH AND J.W. KERN 4TH WED IN PRINCETON
description: Kate Cullens Murdoch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Murdoch Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and John Worth Kern 4th, a son of Judge Kern 3d of Washington and Nancy Park Kern of Bethesda, Md., were married yesterday at the Miller Chapel of the Princeton (N.J.) Theological Seminary. The Rev. Richard H. Downes, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Flying From the Windows, Biking Down the Stairs
description: ILLUMINATION NIGHT By Alice Hoffman. 224 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: HOW THE DEMOCRATS ARE KEPT ON THE DEFENSIVE
description: IT came as no surprise that the 100th Congress spent much of its first seven months exploring the limits of power.

title: THE UNFLINCHING EYE
description: Mary Ellen Mark is not unlike a poet, dedicated to revealing and portraying the beauty and complexity of people in their infinite variety. In my work with children, I hope to incorporate photography as a tool for creative writing. When I do, Mark will be right there in the classroom with me. JANE GELLER New York, N.Y

title: Retirement Party
description: WITH their team in last place in the National League East, Pirates fans have needed a reminder of past glory, and Friday night they got it. In a ceremony at Three Rivers Stadium before a game against the Montreal Expos, 22,000 fans cheered Bill Mazeroski as his jersey, No. 9, was officially retired. Mazeroski, who won eight Gold Gloves in his 17 seasons as a Pirate second baseman, never had a batting average higher than .283, but is fondly remembered in Pittsburgh for the seventh-game home run that beat the Yankees in the 1960 World Series.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Natural Gas Goes Higher

title: A PROFILE OF THE NEWEST NEW YORKERS
description: IN a nation that honors its immigrant past, New York City lives an immigrant present.

title: It's the Right Time to Offer Real Relief
description: IT is time for a new direction in United States leadership in the Latin American debt crisis. Against all odds, the Reagan Administration has been supporting the banks in holding out for full payments of interest on the bank debt owed by Latin America, a strategy that has left Latin America in financial and economic stagnation.

title: IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO REPAIR OR REPLACE HOUSEHOLD SCREENS
description: ONCE summer is past, it's tempting to put off repairing household screens until next spring. But don't procrastinate. Many insects seek indoor shelter as fall approaches. Barring their entry now can mean not having to cope with them in months to come.

title: THE UNFLINCHING EYE
description: I enjoyed reading ''The Unflinching Eye'' and ''A Father's Pictures'' (About Men, by Dean Pitchford, July 12). We live in an age of autoload, autofocus and autoflash cameras where everyone considers himself a photographer. Our profession is much more than taking pictures. We create images that excite, stimulate and move the viewer. We are masters of composition, light and color and have the ability to bring out the personality and spirit of those whom we portray. It is nice to see appreciation for the eye and soul of the professional photographer - one who includes a bit of himself/ herself in every photograph. EVAN KOTEL Owner, Images by Evan Photography New Rochelle, N.Y.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
TRAVEL
description: LEAD: Traveling: How to Spend Less and Enjoy It More By Consumer Reports. Lorimar Home Video. 60 minutes. $19.95.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Pan Am Games Begin
description: After two and a half years of preparation, an unusually short time for such a massive event, the 10th Pan American Games began today with opening ceremonies at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway featuring Vice President Bush, nearly 4,500 athletes, Mickey Mouse and Goofy.

title: Construction Fails to Slow Conversions
description: SLOWLY but steadily New York, the city of rents, is becoming a place of mortgage payments and deeds. To be sure, about 70 percent of New Yorkers still send their landlords a monthly rent check, according to the New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey of 1984, which is based on the latest figures available from the Census Bureau. But ownership of cooperative and condominium apartments has been rising steadily for the last decade and experts expect that trend to continue.

title: Quinones Closes a Bronx Junior High With Low Test Scores
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones has ordered the closing of a junior high school in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx because it failed to improve its educational performance, an assistant to the Chancellor, Richard Riley, said last night.

title: The Lover She Met at the Mall
description: WATCHMAN TELL US OF THE NIGHT By A. B. Paulson. 344 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: MISS BRIDGEWATER TO MARRY SEPT. 12
description: Barrie Bridgewater, until recently an account executive with Wells, Rich, Greene Inc., an advertising agency in New York, and Nicholas Emmanuel Somers, who is studying for an M.B.A. degree at the University of Chicago, plan to be married Sept. 12.

title: Notebook; Steinbrenner's Message Is Coming Across Loud and Clear
description: THE signs are there. They may as well be posted on the signboards on the north and south sides of Yankee Stadium and on the electronic board on the Major Deegan adjoining the Stadium.

title: Cabinet Minister Killed in Manila
description: Philippine Communist urban guerrillas known as ''sparrows'' have claimed responsibility for half of the more than 50 murders of police and military officers in Manila since a brief cease-fire collapsed in January. The police blame right-wing groups and nonpolitical criminals for many of the other killings. Last week, a right-wing Cabinet minister and a military officer were gunned down, fueling criticism of President Corazon C. Aquino and her Government for a 30 percent increase in crime this year.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
LANDFILL CRISIS: STATE GIVES ITS SIDE
description: LEAD: The following is a response by Harold D. Berger, regional director of the State Department of Environmental Conservation, to a recent Opinion Page article, ''Landfill Crisis: State Isn't Helping,'' which was adapted from testimony given by Michael A. LoGrande, the Acting Suffolk County Executive, at a state legislative hearing in Riverhead.

title: Blackmun Out of Treatment
description: Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court completed the first half of his treatment for prostate cancer, a spokesman for the Mayo Clinic said Friday. Justice Blackmun, 78 years old, plans to return in September for a final course of treatment as an outpatient, the spokesman said.

title: THE LAWN'S CARE IS THE EARS' DESPAIR
description: IT'S Saturday afternoon. You've just finished all the little jobs you've had to do around the house, and now you're relaxing in a comfortable chair in the backyard. This is why you moved to the suburbs, isn't it? The peace, the quiet, the good smells. Ah, it's wonderful.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BABY TODD AND THE RATTLESNAKE STRADIVARIUS. By Teresa Kennedy. (St. Martins's, $17.95.) In 1830 or thereabouts, Mary Faith Beaudine took a lover and then his violin. Unable or unwilling to speak, she said only one word during her 82 years in Aytolles Parish, Louisiana - and then nobody was around to hear it. When the violin next landed in the chubby fingers of the boy destined to become the Fiddling Prophet of Jesus, who would have guessed he'd meet the Devil in the arms of little Icy Fee Moulder or that she would cast a charm on the violin with the rattle from a snake she killed? Thus Ms. Kennedy (whose previous books have been for young adults) traces the history of a prized Stradivarius through its unlikely possessors. Although not all its owners are aware of the monetary value of the instrument it becomes clear to most of them that a violin by any other name does not play as sweet. This violin evokes passion as well as odd behavior even when the player does not possess natural musical ability. Besides the Stradivarius, one constant throughout the book is the Strait family, the violin's current owners, who include an aged beauty queen, Baby Sheba Todd, a half-wit musician, Boo, and a preacher, Brother Heck, among other assorted eccentrics. The one thing the Strait women have in common is the susceptible Moseley men, who introduced the instrument to the family. About the only thing the diverse Strait men have in common is their name. The author of this very funny book appreciates both the ridiculous and the predictable goings-on of daily life. Generally a superb storyteller, Ms. Kennedy occasionally overwrites - her too-cute descriptions and Southernisms in the opening sections get in our way. But it doesn't take long to get past that as we're taken home to meet the family.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE GREAT WAR IN AFRICA, 1914-1918. By Byron Farwell. (Norton, $18.95.) World War I conjures up images of weary troops shooting it out in the trenches and daring aces dogfighting in the skies. All the action, of course, takes place in Europe. In ''The Great War in Africa, 1914-1918,'' Byron Farwell gives long overdue attention to theaters of war where wild animals were more feared than enemy soldiers, insects often bit harder than bayonets and bacteria actually accounted for more fatalities than bullets. Mr. Farwell, the author most recently of ''Eminent Victorian Soldiers,'' focuses on the eccentric characters and unlikely events of the period. For example, there was the expedition - possibly the inspiration for the book and film versions of ''The African Queen'' - in which two British launches were brought crashing overland through the muck and mire of the Belgian Congo to Lake Tanganyika, where they attacked and forced the surrender of a larger German gunboat. This quixotic mission was mounted by one Lieut. Comdr. Geoffrey B. Spicer-Simson, R.N., an aging braggart whose arms and torso were covered with tattoos and who wore a skirt he had designed himself. ''It was not a sarong or a kilt, but a skirt,'' Mr. Farwell writes in the droll and authoritative tone he maintains throughout the narrative. There is, unfortunately, little in this volume about the lives and lot of African soldiers; few African participants left accounts of their adventures. The tidbits Mr. Farwell has dug up are surprising. How many people know, for instance, that ''the first British bullet fired in anger'' in World War I came from a rifle aimed by a black soldier in what is now Togo?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SHEER FICTION. By Paul West. (McPherson & Company, $17.95.) A British-born American citizen, Paul West recounts how, in the literary circles of his adoptive land, he found ''yet another regime of deadheads.'' He writes in vinegar about the current American novel -''tofu fiction'' for ''pipsqueak readers,'' its prose deliberately flat, its characters invariably ''little people with mortgages.

title: BASEBALL SALARIES
description: In a recessed economy, the offer made to Mr. Gedman would put him among the top income-earners in Houston. He would probably be making more than all teachers, elementary, high-school or university level. He would be making more than virtually every doctor and surgeon in one of the nation's most highly regarded medical centers. He would be making more than our mayor.

title: What Kind Of Pennant Races Do You Expect?
description: This past week in baseball foreshadowed the pennant races.

title: DATA BANK: August 9, 1987
RETIRED JUDGES HELP EASE COURT LOGJAMS
description: LEAD: AT 7:30 A.M., Judge Aldona E. Appleton is usually in her chambers in the Middlesex County Court House, going over the paper work for a day's share of the Family Court's heavy caseload.

title: Report Says PCB Levels May Endanger Bluefish Fanciers
description: IF they choose to pay attention to a survey that discovered high concentrations of polychlorinated biphenyls - PCB's - in bluefish, East Coast anglers who excel at catching that species will have to embrace the realization that they can't always have their cake and eat it too, at least not in the quantities to which they are accustomed.

title:
RECORDINGS;
BOSTON POPS BOOMS UNDER WILLIAMS
description: LEAD: ARTHUR FIEDLER WAS SUCH AN institution that many Bostonians - and many of his other fans across the country - still think he created the Boston Pops. It only seems that way. Fiedler was ''Mr. Pops'' for 50 years until his death in 1979, but the orchestra was winning fans for 45 years before he took the baton.

title: L.I. SOUND: PERPLEXING PROBLEMS
description: LEAD: FOR boaters and beachgoers on Long Island Sound, fish kills, algal blooms and low levels of dissolved oxygen are creating some unpleasant memories of the summer of '87.

title: When Defensive Tactics Don't Stop the Enemy
description: THE logical method of refuting a gambit is to seize the sacrificed material, slowly wrestle the attacker to a stop and prevail in an endgame. But what if the attacker cannot be muzzled and one cannot see any light at the end of the tunnel of defense? If the gambit is this strong, it may be mandatory to forget about refutation and either decline the sacrifice or accept it but then return it as quickly as possible to re-establish equilibrium.

title: Panel Members Recount the Moments They Won't Forget
description: LEAD: AFTER hearing 250 hours of testimony from 28 witnesses and examining a quarter of a million pages of documents, the members of the select House and Senate committees on the Iran-contra affair have finished only the public phase of their work. The inquiry will continue this month while Congress is in recess, mainly with staff members taking depositions on questions arising from the testimony of Lieut.

title: LOTS ONCE STREWN WITH RUBBLE ARE BECOMING URBAN FARMS
description: LEAD: VEGETABLE gardens are replacing some of this city's rubbish-strewn lots as a result of a Federal program that leans heavily on state and local help and the participation of neighborhood residents.

title: The ''Dolly'' Count
description: To the Editor:

title: EDUCATION AND THE HANDICAPPED
description: In reply to the article ''Merrick Home for Autistic Opposed'' [ July 5 ] :

title: Bar Group Addresses Legal Problems of AIDS
description: The legal implications of AIDS and the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court are among the topics occupying the 20,000 people who have converged on this city for the annual meeting of the American Bar Association.

title: Csonka Enters Hall of Fame
description: Larry Csonka considered himself an emotional football player, so he wasn't surprised when he had to fight back tears as he was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame today.

title: Walk, He Said
description: WHEN the doctor said walk, my first response was that he had to be kidding. The first thing I learned, upon moving to Lindenhurst 32 years ago, was that nobody ever walked farther than to the car in the driveway.

title: Name Herzog Top Manager
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nancy Connors Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Nancy Ann Connors, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Connors of Plandome, L.I., was married yesterday to Kevin Richard Carey, a son of Mrs. John Joseph Hogan of New Dorp, S.I., and the late Lawrence Michael Carey, at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary's in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Niekro Loses His Appeal
description: Joe Niekro, the Minnesota Twins' knuckleballer who was ejected from a game against the California Angels last Monday after being accused of throwing illegal scuffballs that had been scraped with sandpaper and an emery board, lost his appeal of a 10-game suspension yesterday.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest Hemingway. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) Left unfinished at his death and now extensively edited, Hemingway's novel is ''highly readable . . . if not possibly the book he envisioned,'' E. L. Doctorow said in The Book Review last year. The story of a young novelist and his wife traveling in Spain and France in the 1920's, it presents a picture of a doomed marriage, sexual ambiguity and creativity in crisis. Its major achievement, Mr. Doctorow said, is the young wife, Catherine, who ''in fact may be the most impressive of any woman character in Hemingway's work . . . a brilliant woman trapped into a vicarious participation in someone else's creativity.''

title: Jets' Top Picks Impressive
description: Their two top draft picks, Roger Vick and Alex Gordon, produced outstanding performances today, but the Jets were beaten, 27-18, in a scrimmage against the Washington Redskins.

title: CHINESE NOW DOMINATE NEW YORK HEROIN TRADE
description: Chinese criminals have taken over the dominant role in New York City's heroin industry, in a sudden restructuring of a multibillion-dollar enterprise that for decades was the preserve of the Mafia, Federal law-enforcement officials say.

title: THE SPOILS OF SUCCESS
description: AT THE start of my investigations into the life styles of the juvenile and affluent, I visited the F.A.O. Schwarz toy store - toy heaven, is more like it - at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street in Manhattan. The average child in America will be presented with about $200 worth of toys this year. That sounds like a lot, but it wouldn't go far at Schwarz; Johnny would have to save for 25 years to afford the $4,900 mini-Porsche, almost three years for the $500 panda next to the $2,500 giraffe (12 years or so). I was just walking around, gaping at the price tags, when I saw a gorgeous, Perry Ellis-clad, ever-so-slightly-delayed-parenthood-type mom do a picturesque little foot stamp and eye-roll of frustration. ''JoBeth, come back,'' she called, and a little blond girl, about 5 years old, dressed in a white skirt, a white jacket, white tights and black patent-leather Mary Janes, obediently turned away from the $180 dolls and ran back to mother.

title: Money Problems At Birch Society
description: FOR the John Birch Society, battler of ''Red influences'' in government for nearly 30 years, the pressing problems in recent years have been mostly fiscal.

title: Jazz Hot and Cool in Copenhagen
description: LEAD: At 1:30 A.M. on a clear, balmy weeknight in Copenhagen, the street was quiet, and despite a tip that there would be live music and food at a jazz club called La Fontaine, it seemed hard to believe much would be happening at such a late hour.

title: GEPHARDT MEETS DUKAKIS IN DEBATE
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, two Democratic Presidential hopefuls who have stalked each other for weeks, jousted here today over trade and energy policy.

title: PIPELINES ARE LONG-TERM ANSWER TO OIL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: RETRIAL OVER DOG
description: WHEN Jonathan Zager clipped on Tucker's leash and led the 15-year-old dog out for a walk one cold morning in January last year, he had no idea the journey would end up in State Supreme Court.

title: IT'S STILL CALCUTTA, N.Y.
description: Scenes from a stroll along the Fifth Avenue side of Central Park:

title: 2 Survivors Of Holocaust Make Debut
description: LEAD: A PIECE of music that survived the Holocaust -and its composer, who survived the Dachau concentration camp - had their American debut here recently.

title:
DINING OUT;
CAJUN AND CREOLE TOUCH IN SEAFOOD
description: LEAD: WE FOUND the Chuckling Oyster in the Highlands quite by accident. Many months ago, we had a reservation at the Riverhouse on the Quay in Sea Bright. However, it was a stormy night, and we arrived to discover the Riverhouse without electricity and therefore not able to honor any of the reservations taken for that evening.

title: Jackson Perturbed By Rodino
description: THE Rev. Jesse Jackson says he is disappointed that the House Judiciary Committee Chairman, Peter Rodino, apparently plans to run for a 21st term.

title: Photography
description: Those who want to see the cutting edge of photography from a downtown New York perspective should pay a visit to the Annina Nosei Gallery (100 Prince Street, near Greene). Ms. Nosei's summerlong group show, which stretches into September, features more than a dozen artists perched on the brink of broad art-world recognition and is as definitive a summation of the 1987 zeitgeist in photography as one could hope for. The works on view are far removed from the conventional notion that photography is a descriptive medium; instead, they dote on blur, ambiguity and simulation.

title: Olympic Hopes In the Balance
description: KRISTIE PHILLIPS AND PHOEBE Mills, America's best hopes in women's gymnastics, have a best hope of their own. He is Bela Karolyi, the Rumanian-born coach who's been preparing them for this month's Pan American Games being held in Indianapolis, the World Championships in Rotterdam in October and, of course, the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul. Photographed practicing on the balance beam, 15-year-old Miss Phillips (seated) and Miss Mills, 14, ''are working out twice a day,'' Karolyi says, speaking from his training center in Houston. ''An hour a day on each event'' - vaulting, floor exercises, uneven parallel bars and balance beam - ''and, at the end, exercises for speed, strength and flexibility.''

title: McAuliffe Honor Is Planned
description: A planetarium topped by a pyramid will be built in honor of Christa McAuliffe, the teacher who died aboard the space shuttle Challenger, a special legislative committee announced Wednesday. The committee reviewed five proposals for a planetarium and teaching center to be built at the New Hampshire Technical Institute in Concord. No cost estimates were given, although a committee member said the planetarium would be a ''multimillion-dollar'' project. He said he hoped groundbreaking could take place in the spring.

title: History of Jewish Journalism On Display in Philadelphia
description: Just a short walk east of the Liberty Bell, the National Museum of Jewish History is celebrating the freedoms of speech and religion in a major exhibit, ''A People in Print: Jewish Journalism in America.''

title: The Healing Power of Friends
description: UTAH By Toby Olson. 282 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: PISTOL PACKER'S SAINT
description: To the Editor:

title: A Choice Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable Case Conviction
description: Michael A. Nussbaum, a public relations consultant described in testimony as a ''henchman'' of Donald R. Manes, the late Queens Borough President, was found guilty in State Supreme Court in Queens last week of ''acting in concert'' with Mr. Manes in soliciting a $250,000 bribe from a company seeking a cable television franchise. He is to be sentenced Sept. 18 and faces up to seven years in prison. His lawyer said he would appeal.

title: Behind Sri Lanka Accord: Intrigues and Frustrations
description: As Tamil rebels surrendered thousands of weapons this week and called an end to their bitter guerrilla war for a homeland in Sri Lanka, the dramatic turn of events marked an extraordinary diplomatic breakthrough.

title: A Down-Home Feeling Lingers in Tasmania
description: So blue are the sea and the sky in Tasmania that there is no horizon line between them. This would come as a surprise to most Australians, who like to joke about their southernmost island. One favorite is that there are more sheep than people.

title: RUTGERS AN ACTIVE PRESENCE IN WASHINGTON
description: ON THE windowsill of Representative Robert G. Torricelli's office, a gangly patch of New Jersey tomatoes stretches toward the sunlight, brightening an otherwise solemn atmosphere.

title: KERRY LOVELL ENGAGED TO PHILIP N. HASELTON
description: The engagement of Kerry Keen Lovell to Philip N. Haselton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Haselton of Short Hills, N.J., and Boothbay Harbor, Me., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Lovell Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Raymond Cape, Me. An October wedding is planned.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl vs. McEnroe Once Again: Ivan Lendl struggled past 17-year-old Andre Agassi, 6-2, 5-7, 6-3, and John McEnroe overcame his own shaky serve to beat Christo van Rensburg, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday to reach the final of the Volvo International tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt. The resumption of the unfriendly rivalry scheduled for today was to be the first Grand Prix meeting between Lendl and McEnroe since the former replaced the latter as the world's top player by beating him in the final of the United States Open in 1985. McEnroe was seldom troubled by van Rensburg. Lendl, however, had his hands full against Agassi, who is ranked 90th in the world and had become the crowd favorite when he upset Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, in the second round. Lendl fired 17 aces and needed them all as Agassi was able to match him ground stroke for ground stroke. (AP) Track and Field Dash Record Disallowed: Chidi Imo of Nigeria ran a 100-meter-dash heat in 9.92 seconds yesterday at the All Africa Games in Nairobi, but he failed to break the world record of 9.93 because his sprint was run under wind-aided conditions. Imo's dash in a semifinal heat came as a breeze of 4.4 meters per second blew through Moi International Sports Center. The allowable limit for records is 2 meters per second. The world record was set in 1983 by Calvin Smith of the United States.(AP) Golf Daniel in Four-Way Tie: Beth Daniel shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to share the lead with three other Ladies Professional Golf Association players in the Henredon Classic in High Point, N.C. Daniel, who has 14 career victories in eight years but has not won since 1985, had a two-round total of five-under-par 139. Heather Drew also shot a bogey-free 69 in the hot, humid conditions at the Willow Creek course. Colleen Walker shot a one-under-par 71 for her share of first place. Missie Berteotti mastered the heat with three birdies on the back nine and turned in a five-under-par 67 for a total of 139. (AP) Rodriguez Shoots 66 to Lead: Chi Chi Rodriguez finished with three straight birdies for a six-under-par 66 and a four-stroke lead after two rounds of the Seniors Professional Golfers' Association Classic at Nashawtuc Country Club in Concord, Mass. Rodriguez, seeking his sixth victory on the Senior Tour this season, was at 11-under 131, a tournament record, after 36 holes. (AP)

title: Crowding the Seashore on Every Coast
description: ON shrinking beaches, the crowds are thicker than they used to be. More than half of America's population lives within 50 miles of the ocean or Great Lakes, and that proportion is rising quickly. And despite erosion, pollution and proliferating condos, each year more people go to the beach.

title: AT LAST, TOMATO TIME
description: AFTER NINE LONG months of almost total abstinence, I am ready to eat tomatoes again. I am a tomato lover, but experience has taught me to resist the showy imported or hot-house varieties and wait for the beauties that arrive in summer. From mid-July through September, fresh tomatoes can be prepared simply and star in any number of meals.

title: CONCERTS ACROSS THE BORDERS
description: ASIDE from Caramoor, which is still going strong - the Tokyo Quartet plays Mozart, Shostakovich and Beethoven today at 5:30 P.M.; members of the Guarneri Quartet will be joined by the pianist Lydia Artymiw for Mendelssohn, Faure and more Beethoven in a 9 P.M. recital Friday; and Saturday at 8:30 P.M., it will be all Mozart, with the pianist Lilian Kallir and the New York Chamber Soloists - the classical program pickings are pretty slim in the county this week. Venture a bit beyond the county's borders, however, and the picture brightens considerably, especially for aficionados of chamber music.

title: A Charmed Life on the Street
description: IN 1974 the biggest problems facing high school students such as 15-year-old Joseph DiMenna, of Trumbull, Conn., were history and English tests.

title: A CENTRAL AMERICAN INITIATIVE
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN floated another Central American peace plan last week, only to have it quickly overtaken. The opposition this time was not Congressional resistance or Sandinista intransigence. It was a regional treaty signed by the presidents of the Central American nations, at a meeting in Guatemala from which Washington's representatives were barred.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DR. RUTH PHENOMENON: The Sexual Awakening of America? By Barbara Multer. (Richardson & Steirman/Kampmann & Company, $16.95.) Hello, Dr. Ruth? I've got a problem. It was bad enough when you parlayed your radio success as New York's ''Munchkin of Sex'' and ''Bavarian Charo'' into an inescapable empire of television, board games, ''how to'' video cassettes, feature films, lovemaking guides, fantasy tours to India and commercials for soft drinks, typewriters and condoms. But now, other people are trying to get in on the act. Barbara Multer, an associate producer on your cable talk show for two years, has written a book offering her perspective. She takes the broad view (the effect of Hitler's Final Solution in shaping your sexual attitudes) and the narrow (details about a copying machine on the show that never worked properly.) Maybe it was because you gave her that crummy plastic ashtray with a picture of the Eiffel Tower on it for Christmas, but she feels that you were often a pint-sized prima donna. On wardrobe:

title: DR. ELAINE JOSEPHSON TO WED IN DECEMBER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Barry M. Josephson of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Elaine Beth Josephson to Dr. Robert Jonathan Kornberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kornberg of Stony Brook, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: Mark IV: The Making of a Miniconglomerate
description: LEAD: SAL H. ALFIERO spends most of his time reading financial reports, or speaking softly into his phone, hidden behind a paper-laden desk that his secretary says he cleans twice a year with a garbage bag or two. The chairman of Mark IV Industries is, according to one associate, ''almost in the background, letting other people direct the traffic.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article July 12 about the Reina Sofia art center in Madrid did not identify the architects involved in the renovation of the museum. The architect in charge of the restoration of the building is Antonio Fernandez-Alba. The English architect Max Gordon has consulted on gallery design.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BLACK GIVEN A REBEL'S FUNERAL
description: A black union member active in anti-apartheid groups who was bludgeoned to death last month by unidentified killers was given a full revolutionary funeral here today under the black, green and gold flag of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: Telling Them What to Read and Think
description: LEAD: FREDA KIRCHWEY A Woman of The Nation. By Sara Alpern. Illustrated. 319 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $27.50.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK TO RISE AGAIN IN THE SOUTH
description: IN the last two Presidential elections, the 11 states of the Old Confederacy produced Republican majorities 21 times out of 22, only failing to support Ronald Reagan and his once-despised party when Jimmy Carter clung to his home state of Georgia in 1980. If the Democrats are going to stand any chance at all of recapturing the White House next year, political professionals agree, their candidate is going to have to reclaim states their party used to take for granted.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Fashion View column in The Times Magazine on June 21 misstated the relationship between the designers Yohji Yamamoto and Rei Kawakubo. They have never been married.

title: Pop Music
description: Connoisseurs of great singing will perk up their ears this week, because one of the greatest singers of all is coming to town. His name is Al Green, and he has ostensibly abandoned his ''prince of love'' image of the 1970's in favor of the Lord, whom he serves as reverend of his own church in Memphis. But that doesn't stop him from recording gospel albums in a style not very far removed from his secular hits, or from touring as headliner of lavishly produced gospel shows - such as the one he'll star in Saturday night at 8 at Radio City Music Hall (with him will be Tramaine, a popular woman gospel singer, and the New Jersey Mass Choir, which had a recent No. 1 hit on the Billboard magazine gospel chart).

title: A Correction On Records
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mack Lobell Captures Hambletonian
description: Mack Lobell majestically justified his reputation as the premier trotter of the year by capturing the $1,046,300 Hambletonian at the Meadowlands today.

title: GORDON GOULD IS WED TO SUSAN P. EASTERLIN
description: Susan Provost Easterlin, a daughter of Jacqueline Mandeville Miller Easterlin of Philadelphia and Richard Ainely Easterlin of Pasadena, Calif., was married yesterday to Gordon Lance Gould, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Lawrence Gould of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Alan Lachtman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: Sidewalk Franks
description: To the Editor: ''Selling the Sidewalk Frank'' (July 26) focused on Wall Street offices, and why the level of the stock market influences the number of hot dogs being sold during the lunch hour. Unfortunately, the article overlooked the importance of blue-collar workers. Construction workers, postal workers, maintenance people and the like all have hearty appetites and provide the vendor with plenty of business, forming a line the length of a city block. In front of the three-piece-suited executive waiting on line for a hot dog there is likely to be a construction worker. CAREN MAZURE New York, July 27

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended July 25 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $335,000 155 East 93d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. co-op in a renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, large kitchen; maintenance $565, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: A.J.

title: A MUSICAL GHOST MATERIALIZES
description: LEAD: WAT'S wrong with believing in ghosts? Marni Nixon, whose lyric coloratura invisibly graced the lips of Deborah Kerr, Audrey Hepburn and Natalie Wood in the big musicals of the 50's and 60's, and who was once dubbed by a critic the Ghostess with the Mostest, can be seen as well as heard tonight at the White Barn Theater in Westport, Conn., where she will appear in ''An Evening With Marni

title: Up the Hill, Through the Wood - Enchanted World
description: ON a Saturday afternoon six months after I moved to Dobbs Ferry from Manhattan, I discovered a man fishing in a pond I often passed while walking on a road around a golf course not far from my home. I watched him for a while casting his line, pulling out an orange fish and throwing it back.

title: Hard Times Descend Upon an Anti-Abortion PAC
description: Hard times have overtaken the Life Amendment Political Action Committee, once a major national force in the campaign against legal abortion. It now operates, deep in debt, from an office suite just off the freeway that runs between here and Seattle.

title: DESPITE SEASON, HOUSING STARTS DROP
description: CONNECTICUT housing starts and sales have been on a steady decline since April, and housing officials question whether the trend indicates a downturn in the economy, or a return to a normal market.

title: POPULATION RISING AT A FASTER RATE
description: LEAD: THE county's population, which declined from 1970 to 1980, is now increasing faster than expected and may already have reached or even surpassed its 1970 high of 894,104.

title: SPIKE LEE'S GOTTA HAVE IT
description: THE SCENE IS AN OLD FAIR-GROUNDS building in Atlanta, now Madame Re-Re's Beauty Salon, a surreal creation of plywood, plaster and paint. The set has been packed with a score of dancers, a film crew and the director Spike Lee, all of them sweating under 140,000 watts of lighting to piece together a production number. Now the crew is taking a break. The dancers, overheated, head for cooler air outside.

title: CANADA RELEASES A REPORT ON NAZIS
description: A study for a Canadian Government commission says people who would have been considered ''undesirable Nazi collaborators'' were admitted to Canada as immigrants after World War II because of incomplete and misleading information supplied by United States intelligence officers.

title: John BadhamJust Don't Call Him an Auteur
description: LEAD: WHEN THE CREDITS ROLL at the conclusion of John Badham's new picture, ''Stakeout,'' few people in the audience will catch the intended significance of the very first little title card, which says simply: ''A John Badham Movie.'' But for the prolific director - nine features in the last 11 years - that seemingly innocuous line is in fact a declaration summing up his approach to his craft.

title: INSIDE
description: The New Soviet Missile The Soviet Union has started to deploy another land-based missile, the SS-24. Although the Russians say they are abiding by the strategic arms treaty of 1979, the disclosure is fueling a new debate between supporters and opponents of the pact. Page 3.

title: The S.E.C. Speaks On Insider Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a definition of insider trading last week, after a few decades of letting the courts, and the people who buy and sell stock, guess what it consisted of.

title: Guru's City in Desert Sits Nearly Empty
description: Six years ago followers of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh purchased a remote 64,000 acre ranch near here for a new ''world commune'' in the desert.

title: Hungry for Jobs, 3 California Towns Seek Odd Prize: A Radioactive Dump
description: Three remote Mojave Desert towns, hungry for cash and jobs, are vying for an unusual privilege: to be the site of a dump for radioactive waste.

title: HOW IRANGATE DIFFERS FROM WATERGATE
description: Is Irangate Watergate revisited? As in Watergate, one little accidental revelation popped open a fantastic political can of worms, a pile of twisted deceptions, a tangle of operations running outside the constitutional fence. As in Watergate, what looked at first like a low-level imbroglio soon crawled up to the White House and eventually into the lap of the President himself. But there the similarity ends.

title: CYNTHIA COSTELLO MARRIED TO PAUL BOOZER, A STUDENT
description: The Helen Hills Chapel at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Cynthia Louise Costello and Paul Cimarron Boozer. The Rev. William G. Guindon performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ART OF THE NORTHEAST The associate curator of the Whitney Museum in New York, Patterson Sims, made the final selection of 71 works on view in the 38th annual Art of the Northeast exhibition at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan. More than 1,700 entries were submitted for the show, which continues through Sept. 4.

title: Loyal Listener For WFAN
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OLD THEATERS BRING DOWNTOWNS NEW LIFE
description: ONCE a sign of urban blight and seen as candidates for the wrecker's ball, old theaters are being refurbished and used as a tool by those seeking to revitalize downtown centers.

title: Travis Jackson A Joy to Watch
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Movies
description: Spetters Starring Rutger Hauer, Renee Soutendijk, Toon Agterberg. Directed by Paul Verhoeven. 1980. Embassy Home Entertainment. 108 minutes. $29.95. ''Spetters'' is an erratic, visceral work from the talented Dutch director Paul Verhoeven that follows three youths seeking fame on the motorcycle-racing circuit. What these ''spetters'' (hotshots) find is everything but celebrity. One meets with an accident that leaves him a paraplegic; another turns from mugging homosexuals to embracing the gay life himself; the third forsakes racing for a small family business.

title: HOME MUSIC MAKING ENTERS THE DIGITAL AGE
description: ELECTRONICS HAS OFTEN been blamed for the decline of Hausmusik - the amiable tradition of making music at home. Time was when many musical families could easily muster a string quartet among their members, and young ladies -as they were known then - counted passable piano playing among their indispensable accomplishments.

title: SEARCH WIDENING FOR CLUES IN PUZZLE OF MOUNTING DOLPHIN DEATHS
description: The search for the killer of bottlenose dolphins off the Atlantic Coast is widening, drawing in state environmental agencies, the Smithsonian Institution and researchers from Canada to North Carolina.

title: 4 Are Cited in Jail Disturbance
description: Four Jamaicans were blamed for initiating a four-hour disturbance involving 100 illegal aliens at a Federal detention center, immigration officials said today.

title: NEW YOUR PROGRAMS: A NEIGHBORHOOD FLAVOR
description: Just a block away from burned-out buildings in the South Bronx, a dozen boys sweated their way through pushups and situps at Forest Playground. Nearby, other youngsters played basketball and table top hockey.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section August 2 about the ''New Image Painting'' exhibition incorrectly described a planned exhibition of works by Robert Moskowitz. It is being organized by the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington.

title: View Tax Outrages a Connecticut Town
description: WHEN John Kryszpin moved into his expensive new home atop Taine Mountain in Burlington, Conn., three months ago and looked out his picture window for the first time, he was thrilled with the view that stretches more than 20 miles across hills and valleys and into Massachusetts.

title: Auto Racing; Fast Cars Come East, at a Slower Pace
description: America's two top auto-racing series come to the Northeast this weekend and next as new technical regulations have cut speeds on each circuit's fastest tracks.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Oakland, Md.;
A Ski Resort Is Expanding
description: LEAD: AN expansion has begun at the Wisp Ski Resort near Deep Creek Lake in Garrett County, Md., which, when completed late next year, will make this complex in western Maryland one of the largest recreation and convention facilities on the East Coast, according to developers.

title: The Road to Dyspepsia
description: DON'T TREAD ON ME The Selected Letters of S. J. Perelman. Edited by Prudence Crowther. Illustrated. 372 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: MEMORY: LEARNING HOW IT WORKS
description: WHEN THE neurobiologist Gary Lynch wants to instill in his students a sense of what it is like to do science - to wrest from the world's complexity a fact that is clear, simple and undeniably true - he tells them the story of Emil du Bois-Reymond. In 1843, the German physiologist became the first person to prove beyond doubt that electricity - and not some supernatural ''life force'' - runs through the nervous system. Working with electrodes and nerves from animals, he demonstrated the existence of what is now called the action potential, the electrochemical pulse that beats in our neurons with a rhythm that is no less than the language of the brain.

title: Israel-Jordan Alliance Quietly Taking Root on the West Bank
description: FEW Israelis have ever heard of Saeb Erakat, a West Bank Palestinian who has never been considered dangerous enough to grab many headlines here. But his story speaks volumes about the state of Israeli-Palestinian relations and the uncertain prospects for eventual negotiations.

title: 23 Aliens Are Freed From Captors in West
description: The police raided a house Friday, freeing 23 people being held captive by four gunmen who sought ransom, officials said.

title: ECONOMIST IS ENGAGED TO DR. NANCY H. COLES
description: Dr. Nancy Harriet Coles, a resident in ophthalmology at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, and Jeffrey Alan Goldstein, an economist at the investment banking and financial advisory firm of James D. Wolfensohn, are planning to be married in October, the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Coles of New York, have announced.

title: VALERIE RUTTENBERG AND RANDALL PATTEE, FELLOW LAWYERS, ARE PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Byron Ruttenberg of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Valerie Honore Ruttenberg, to Randall James Pattee, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lee Pattee of Dubuque, Iowa.

title: Managers Ignore Directive
description: For all of the recent controversy about whether bats have been altered, many major league managers are ignoring Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's directive allowing them to challenge one bat a game.

title: Mets' Streak Halted
description: The fastball that struck Darryl Strawberry on the right ear flap of his batting helmet in the second inning was the first jolt the Mets suffered last night. The second came more than three hours later on what they will remember as a long night of wasted opportunities. The Cubs ended the Mets' seven-game winning streak, 5-3, dropping the Mets four and a half games behind the first-place Cardinals in the National League East.

title: JILL BEHRENS IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Behrens of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Ann Behrens to Jeffrey Todd Underhill, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Underhill of Fairview, Pa. Miss Behrens and her fiance both graduated from Allegheny College. She is a district agent and financial planner for the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Tucson, Ariz. He is a graduate student in atmospheric sciences at the University of Arizona.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: 18TH CENTURY IN WORCESTER

title: ON THE 'CRIME' OF GOOD CITIZENSHIP
description: FOR TWO years, I worked as a ''liberal'' high school social studies teacher in an ultra-conservative suburban community.

title: Forbidden Pictures
description: CLANDESTINE IN CHILE The Adventures of Miguel Littin. By Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Translated by Asa Zatz. 116 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $13.95.

title: Shamir Proves a Master in Israel's Game of Politics
description: A biography of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir might well be entitled: ''Often Underestimated, Rarely Outmaneuvered.''

title: Staying Safe and Secure in Hotels
description: In its useful booklet ''A Safe Trip Abroad,'' the Federal Government advises selecting a hotel room between the second and the seventh floor, ''above the ground level to prevent easy entrance from outside, and low enough for fire equipment to reach.''

title: A LA CARTE
description: FERRIES descend on Long Island, disgorging summertime hordes of the hungry from Fire Island and Connecticut. Often upon disembarking their first thought is, ''Where should we eat?'' Many want a convenient seafood fix.

title: F.C.C. Decides to End the Reign of The Fairness Rule
description: Charged with regulating that intangible public property known as the airwaves, the Government has historically imposed on broadcasters restrictions that never would be tolerated by the press. One of the most controversial of these, the fairness doctrine, was repealed last week by the Federal Communications Commission as unconstitutional and ineffective.

title: Paperback Best Sellers: August 9, 1987
description: Weeks On Fiction List 1 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A 5 rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 2 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, 4 $4.95.) title: Wedding Planned By CLAIRE E. HAHN
description: The engagement of Claire Elise Hahn to John Buckhout Johnston Jr. has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Hahn of Jackson, Wyo. Mr. Johnston is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Buckhout Johnston of New Canaan, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: PHYSICIAN IS WED TO LANE HOFFMAN
description: Lane Hoffman, the daughter of Judith Palley Young of Albuquerque, N.M., and New York, and Dr. Paul R. Hoffman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Edgartown, Mass., was married at her mother's home in Albuquerque yesterday to Dr. Jonathan William Blank, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William C. Blank of Glens Falls, N.Y.

title: during the Debate Over Skirt Lengths, Democracy Reigns
description: Somewhere the great long skirt versus short skirt debate may be raging, perhaps at a fashion summit conference in Geneva, Dumbarton Oaks or Reykjavik. But out on the street, all is peaceful. Members of both camps are not only talking to one another, they can even be seen together, walking side by side. This is democracy at work. It is also a sterling example of assertiveness, freedom of choice, the pursuit of happiness and a number of other positive things. The women pictured here know what they like and are saying they won't be easily dissuaded by the arbiters of fashion. More importantly, they are saying they won't even be dissuaded by their best friends. So put on your long skirt, or your short skirt, or anything in between. The weather is fine and there is plenty of room for everyone.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: UP THE COUNTRY: A Saga of Pioneering Days. By Miles Franklin. (Beaufort, $15.95.) Readers may know Miles Franklin, the early feminist and prolific Australian writer (1879-1954), as the author of a classic novel, ''My Brilliant Career.'' But ''Up the Country'' was considered her finest work; first published in 1928, it is now appearing in this country for the first time. Based on tales told by her grandmother, the novel was written to extol the values and the individualism that Franklin felt were threatened by industrialism. By telling the story of three Australian families of the mid-19th century - the Mazeres, the Pooles and the Brennans - she re-creates the feisty spirit, feuding, ceremonial rituals and hardships of life on the frontier. Symbolically it begins with the baptismal showers of a great, overdue rain; it concludes with a tragic funeral that unites the community as evening falls. What's most compelling are Franklin's feminist loyalties: with the exception of Bert Poole, a headstrong frontier man, the women in the novel, notably Rachel Mazere, a tough-minded matriarch, outshine the men as they defy the elements - and often their husbands - to tame the wilderness. ''Men have not yet learned,'' she writes, ''. . . that male courage is often nothing but a recklessness, induced when the temperature is high. But women's courage is conceived in cold blood . . . and that is why it is the more deadly.'' Franklin has a keen ear for dialogue, a sharp eye and wit; though her narrative is densely poetic and her language at times florid, she can be ironic, especially when writing about men. And she never falters in rendering the rich texture of life on the frontier.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article July 19 on the Aland Islands misstated the status of the finnmark. It is a freely convertible currency and not pegged to the ruble.

title: Troubadors of the Cuban Revolution
description: TO MILLIONS OF LATIN Americans, Silvio Rodriguez and Pablo Milanes and their guitars are as much a symbol of Cuba and its revolution as Fidel Castro and his beard.

title: ALISON PRATT IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Loring G. Pratt of New York and Haines Falls, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Gardner Pratt to Patrick John Wedd, a son of Mrs. W. B. van Nostrand Wedd of Kimpton, Hertfordshire, England, and the late Mr. Wedd. A Sept. 26 wedding is planned.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MOSS GOWN By William H. Hooks. Illustrated by Donald Carrick. 48 pp. New York: Clarion Books. $13.95 (Ages 5 to 9)

title: TELLING THE IRAN-CONTRA KNAVES FROM THE FOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowding the Seashore on Every Coast
description: ON shrinking beaches, the crowds are thicker than they used to be. More than half of America's population lives within 50 miles of the ocean or Great Lakes, and that proportion is rising quickly. And despite erosion, pollution and proliferating condos, each year more people go to the beach.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Vacancy Decontrol Spurs Conversions
description: LEAD: MUCH of the New Jersey's growth has been in the developing suburbs, where people, followed by companies, have settled for the last two decades.

title: YESTERYEAR'S STYLES MAKE A SUMMER SHOW
description: IN THESE DOG DAYS OF AU-gust, the show ''Summer Silhouettes: Washable Fashion in the 19th Century,'' at the Museum of the City of New York (Fifth Avenue at 104th Street), provides an opportunity to marvel at the manner in which women of an earlier era outfitted themselves in the heat.

title: Random Tests Set For AIDS
description: LEAD: THE state is to begin random, anonymous testing next month of blood samples drawn from, among other groups, newborns and couples seeking marriage licenses, to determine the prevalence of the AIDS virus in the state.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST MONTHS FOR LAWN WORK
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH both the weather and the calendar say it is still summer, lawn renovation time has rolled around again. In spite of what might seem unfavorable conditions, lawn improvements undertaken from mid-August until mid-October will yield better results than if done at any other time of the year.

title: Pryor Knocked Out in Comeback
description: The Hawk no longer soars.

title: A Father Asks to Go With Son Into Secret Passage
description: I HAVE this theory about shy people. They can be wonderful friends but they never stop being shy. As a result they prefer their friends to live far away. That explains why some of my best friends are little more than pen pals. It also explains my son Charles's dream.

title: School Board Reappraising Decision on Housing Sites
description: YONKERS school officials, praised last year for solving the education portion of the city's landmark desegregation suit, were reassessing last week their earlier decision to reject a proposal to build housing on school land.

title: MARCY A. SISKIND IS MARRIED TO JONATHAN T. WEISS
description: Marcy Aileen Siskind, who will enter the Fordham University School of Law next month, and Jonathan Todd Weiss, who is due to become an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges in September, were married last night at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

title: Making His Mark
description: Baseball pitchers who specialize in the knuckleball tend to be categorized like prosperous people with no visible means of support: Though admired for their success, they are suspected of breaking the rules. So the umpires kept a sharp eye on Joe Niekro last week as the 42-year-old knuckleballer pitched for the Minnesota Twins in a game against the California Angels. In the fourth inning, according to the umpires, an examination of the baseballs Niekro pitched gave them probable cause to believe the balls were illegally scuffed to enhance the unpredictability that makes the knuckleball difficult to hit.

title: Norma O'Leary; 'I THINK FARMERS CAN SURVIVE'
description: NORMA O'LEARY and her husband, Ernest, operate a dairy farm of 250 head of cattle in Thompson, a town with 30 dairy operations 40 years ago but only a half dozen today. As the president of the Connecticut Farm Bureau, Mrs. O'Leary has been an active advocate for farmers in the state. She is the mother of three daughters - all of whom have chosen careers in fields outside farming. At her 500-acre farm in Thompson, Mrs. O'Leary talked the other day of her concerns for the future of farming in Connecticut. Following are some excerpts from the conversation:

title: Music: Berwald, Mozart, Firkusny and Szeryng
description: FRIDAY'S Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall was just that - three of the pieces by the great man himself, the other by Franz Berwald.

title: Crum's Hand-Picked Club Seems to Outclass the Rest
description: Denny Crum, the United States coach, didn't hesitate the other day as he discussed his team's chances in the Pan American basketball competition, which begins Sunday afternoon at Market Square Arena.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Few and far between are the times when watching a movie on television surpasses the experience of sitting in a darkened theater and seeing the action unfold on a large screen. But one of those occasions arises this week, when NBC offers the network premiere of Sergio Leone's hallucinatory gangster epic, ''Once Upon a Time in America.''

title: Matters of Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Long, Cold Swim
description: IT was a simple seaside picnic, a genteel tea party on the beach, but to get there took some doing for the guest of honor. The picnic on the island of Big Diomede in the Soviet Union was a tribute to Lynne Cox, the 30-year-old American endurance swimmer who had just endured two hours five minutes of 44-degree water to become the first person known to have swum across the Bering Strait.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: SIGHTINGS. By Susan Trott. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Susan Trott's deft novel, her fifth, shimmers with light and shadow like the sea on which her young heroine, Sunny, persistently casts her gaze. All normalcy ceases in dreamy, idyllic Inverness, tucked into the California coast, once Sunny's grief-crazed mother sets sail in search of her young son, lost and presumed drowned years before.

title: Artists vs. an Endless War
description: ISRAEL RADIO AND TELEVISION WENT ON A three-day strike A few weeks ago, and a strange thing happened here - everyone in the country was thrilled. Israelis loved not having to hear their local news. Many said it was like being on vacation without having to leave home. One college student remarked, ''Now, if only the newspapers would go on strike, we could really relax.''

title: POSTINGS: Builders' Fellowships; Matters of Degree
description: The Urban Land Institute, a 51-year-old education and research organization, believes future developers ought to go to graduate school, just as aspiring doctors and lawyers do. To encourage this, it has established a fellowship program to award $5,000 grants to 20 graduate students a year, with the first grants for 1987-88.

title:
DINING OUT;
BOLOGNESE COOKING IN CROTON FALLS
description: LEAD: OUR recent visits to Mona Trattoria found the kitchen still true to the venerable precepts of classic Bolognese cooking, the unusual Gothic-Victorian 1864 house freshly painted and looking spiffy and the menu trimmed and vital; in fact, except for the sometimes slow and limping service, diners would never guess that the restaurant has been in Croton

title: Editor Who Fought for Press Dismissed From Cape Times
description: Times Media Ltd., one of South Africa's major newspaper chains, has dismissed Anthony Heard as editor of Cape Times without explanation.

title:
INVESTING;
Comeback for Overland Express?
description: LEAD: WITH trucking-school executives at the wheel, will Overland Express Inc. take a profitable turn? The shares of the debt-laden, loss-plagued trucking concern have more than doubled from a 52-week low of $2.75 earlier this year, when bankruptcy threatened. Last week, Overland was quoted at about $6 in the over-the-counter market, down from its 52-week high of $7.75.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE BIRDS IN THE BAND
description: LEAD: TRUDY BATTALY, bird bander, pursues her hobby armed with bits of metal and lots of charts and the power to devise all sorts of theories and notations.

title: OLD HAYFIELD YIELDS INDIAN ARTIFACTS
description: LEAD: WHILE pheasant hunting in Rocky Hill in October 1978, June and David Cooke noticed pieces of pottery and stone tools spread across a large field.

title: On a Clear Day You Could See New Haven
description: Mount Holyoke. The Hudson Highlands. Niagara. Virginia's Natural Bridge. The falls of the Passaic River at Paterson, N.J. Long before Disney's ersatz castles, these were America's most famous tourist attractions. Travelers made pilgrimages to these sites and then wrote about them in flowery prose. Paterson seems to have lost its allure, but the others are still going strong. Tourist facilities at one of them, Mount Holyoke, overlooking the Connecticut River in western Massachusetts, are currently being refreshed.

title: Verbatim; Cracking Down
description: 'From now on, you are going to go where I want you to go, when I want you to go, and for the length of tour I want you to serve. . . .

title: Comment in Brief
description: To the Editor:

title: CLAIRE KERRIGAN, STUDENT, IS WED TO A COMPOSER
description: At St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., yesterday, Claire Kerrigan, a daughter of Richard Thomas Kerrigan of New York and Mrs. James Davis Robins of Pawcatuck, Conn., was married to Thornton Jenkins 3d, a son of Mr. Jenkins 2d of Marblehead, Mass., and Mrs. James Eugene Cummiskey of Greenwich, Conn.

title: SAUCES AND VINAIGRETTES THAT HELP SAVE TIME IN THE KITCHEN
description: DURING the summer I keep my cooking to a minimum.

title: Officials Cite 23 Food Outlets
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.
