title: High Heels and Gumshoes
description: THEY were merely ''dames'' in the world of Sam Spade - oftentimes his clients, but never his competitors. Today, women are breaking into the male-dominated field of private investigation in a big way.

title: Marrakesh
description: To the Editor: The June 21 article on La Mamounia beautifully re-creates the visitor's impressions of the exquisite revitalization of the 1923 hotel in Marrakesh.

title: WHAT REAGAN DID
description: The Iran-contra hearings left the image of a President airily detached from all that had gone on. Committee members spoke of a ''junta'' inside the Government, of William Casey and John Poindexter and Oliver North carrying out a ''coup.'' It was as if their activities had nothing to do with Ronald Reagan.

title: POOR SAID TO LACK ADVICE ON EVICTION
description: Poor people are being evicted in large numbers from housing in New York City because they lack adequate legal guidance, adding to the ranks of the homeless, according to a study released yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: PRESIDENTS AND PLAIN FOLKS
description: FEIFFER'S FOLLIES A Third Eye Production for Channel Four Television in association with RM Arts. Directed by Barrie Gavin. Produced by Penny Clark. Home Vision. 55 minutes. $39.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ON ICE

title: MARY VAN LEAR WRIGHT IS WED TO THOMAS BENNER
description: Mary Van Lear Wright, an assistant vice president with the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company in New York, and Thomas George Benner, a staff writer with the press office at Columbia University, were married yesterday at the Federated Church in Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Newell H. Curtis Jr., a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
TELEVISION;
TV IS AIDING IN TH GROWTH OF 'A:: THINGS GREAT AND SMALL'
description: LEAD: TWO YEARS AGO, JAMES Herriot told the BBC producer of ''All Creatures Great and Small'' that he did not want more shows made from his six best-selling books about his life as a veterinarian.

title: Low-Cost Housing Option for Greenwich
description: IN recent years Greenwich has converted outmoded schools and municipal buildings into a Town Hall, an arts center and low-cost housing. Now it has allocated $70,000 to study the conversion of a defunct railroad power plant on 10 acres into additional low-cost housing and a marina.

title: New Hampshire Gets Pro Team
description: New Hampshire will get its first professional basketball franchise when a United States Basketball League team begins play in the state next year.

title: How Meatballs Became Nerds
description: LEAD: CAMPUS LIFE Undergraduate Cultures From the End of the Eighteenth Century to the Present. By Helen Lefkowitz Horowitz. Illustrated. 330 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: 9 Philadelphia Judges Criticized
description: A state judicial review board has recommended the dismissal of nine Philadelphia judges for accepting cash from members of the Roofers Union.

title: The Fun and Flaws of the Tempting Zoom Lens
description: The allure of zoom lenses is not to be underestimated. Despite years of groans and grunts from professional photographers who considered them inferior to single-focal-length ''prime'' lenses, zooms have persevered and flourished. It has gotten to the point that today nearly every pro packs at least one zoom in his or her bag.

title: Head Over Googol
description: THE FEDERAL budget and the national debt are both getting higher than most of us can count. As in some primitive number systems that go ''one, two, three, many,'' we have reached the end of the known, or at least the end of our vocabulary. (Beyond lies the realm of numbers like a googol - a real number with a joke name.) Rather than appear to be baffled by what is after a trillion, Congress wants to reduce the numbers. But just in case it does not succeed, we had better all gain a passing familiarity with macro-numeration.

title: 2 Casinos Post Compulsive-Gambler Hot Line
description: In an action hailed as a breakthrough, two Atlantic City casinos posted signs last week listing the telephone number of a hot line for compulsive gamblers.

title: What Is Terrorism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Recovering After 'Tiny' Stroke Slurs His Speech
description: It may have been only a ''tiny, trivial'' stroke, but the attention paid to Mayor Koch's small cerebral incident last week underscored a fact New Yorkers often forget: The 62-year-old Mayor is one of the two or three most powerful elected officials in America. Thus the status of his health affects a wide range of political plans and ambitions.

title: PAROLE HEARING
description: Thomas Trantino, convicted in 1964 of murdering two police officers, is scheduled to have a hearing before the state parole board later this month. But Robert Egles, the board's executive director, said the controversial nature of the case would probably lead it to be referred to a hearing before the full seven-member board in mid-September.

title: HANDGUN LAWS AND FREEWAY SHOOTINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: Into the White Continent
description: THE EUROPEAN TRIBE By Caryl Phillips. 129 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95..

title: Sports of The Times; Looking for the Smoking Anything
description: CAN you imagine upstanding citizens, role models yet in the National Pastime, stooping to underhanded means to achieve their ends?

title: Q and A
description: Agent's Fee Question: A few months ago my husband and I went by the building where we used to live to see if there were any apartments available. The superintendent told us that we would have to go through the agent. The agent turned out to be a man working out of an apartment in one of the other buildings owned by the same landlord. The person we saw never showed us the apartment, but phoned the superintendant to say that we should be let into the apartment.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Terminal Wit In Paris prisons during the Revolution, many of the inmates showed the kind of irony that only a person with nothing to lose can afford. This is from ''Last Letters: Prisons and Prisoners of the French Revolution 1793-1794'' (Michael di Capua/Farrar, Straus & Giroux) by Olivier Blanc.

title: REAGAN'S WORTHY NICARAGUA PEACE PLAN
description: The tentative agreement last week by presidents of five Central American countries for a cease-fire in Nicaragua adds momentum to President Reagan's efforts for a negotiated settlement of the armed conflict in the region.

title: ANNE M. PINGPANK IS WED TO TIMOTHY JAMES DOYLE
description: Anne Margaret Pingpank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Pingpank of Somers, N.Y., and Timothy James Doyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Doyle of Sturgis, Mich., were married yesterday at St. John and St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Chappaqua, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. E. William Beauchamp, executive vice president of the University of Notre Dame, assisted by Msgr. Robert J. Skelly.

title: A NEW BUSINESS THAT'S STRICTLY FYI
description: WHILE struggling to keep afloat in a sea of information, executives often find themselves drowning in paper. Two former librarians - recognizing that companies might pay for information retrieval - have started a business doing just that.

title: 'The Family Mashber'
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 3d Inmate Slain in 2 Weeks
description: A 19-year-old inmate was stabbed to death in an argument with another inmate at the Watertown Correctional Facility on Saturday, state prison officials said.

title: Comfort Halsey Becomes a Bride
description: At All Saints' Parish in Peterborough, N.H., Comfort Anne Halsey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. MacDonald Halsey of Point Pleasant, N.J., and Peaks Island, Portland, Me., was married yesterday to Gregory Thomas Cope, the son of Harriet T. Cope of Francestown, N.H. Bishop John B. Coburn, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Lewis S. Stone Jr., the rector of All Saints'.

title: Theater: 'The Longboat,' On Captain Bligh at Sea
description: CAPT. WILLIAM BLIGH'S responsibility for the mutiny on the Bounty may remain a matter of dispute among historians, but they join in acclaim of his unequaled achievement in navigating an open boat with loyal members of his crew across 3,600 miles of the Pacific to safe haven. How he managed it is the cargo of John Chodes's new play, ''The Longboat.''

title: EXCERPT FROM THE S.E.C.'S INSIDER TRADING PLAN
description: Following is an excerpt from the memorandum of the Securities and Exchange Commission in support of the Insider Trading Act of 1987.

title: GROUP IN ACCORD WITH CRAZY EDDIE
description: A shareholder group consisting of Eddie Antar, chairman of Crazy Eddie Inc., and the Belzberg family of Canada said it had agreed not to buy more Crazy Eddie shares until next year, unless it made another merger proposal or a tender offer for at least 20 percent of the common stock.

title: EX-TRAVEL AGENT BEATEN TO DEATH ON EAST 87TH ST.
description: A 77-year-old retired travel agent who helped hundreds of European refugees resettle in the United States after World War II and later aided many immigrants, was found bludgeoned to death early yesterday in the Upper East Side apartment where he had lived more than 30 years.

title: Bork Represents A Threat to Women
description: LEAD: Why are many women so troubled by President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court? Because Senate confirmation of Judge Bork could jeopardize a generation of progress toward securing basic freedoms and legal equality for American women.

title: A Bomb Wounds 12 Near Honduras Base
description: A bomb exploded at a restaurant in a town north of Tegucigalpa Saturday evening, seriously injuring six American soldiers and six Honduran civilians, officials said today.

title: Leningrad Journal; When the Rich Get Richer, the Fur Really Flies
description: When the Dow Jones industrial average edged above 2,500 points in July, there was at least one corner of the Communist world that shared in Wall Street's sense of celebration.

title: Outdoors; Specialties in Shrimp
description: ''AND I said, 'This is scrumptious!' - a phrase I had learned from the Devonshire shrimpers,'' Lewis Carroll wrote in his poem ''Atalanta in Camden-Town.'' Yes, shrimp are scrumptious, and they are also expensive, but this is the time of year when you can catch your own in coastal waters as an unusual dish for the table, as bait, or as interesting animals to keep in a brackish aquarium.

title: N.F.L. Exhibition; Across the Ocean, Rams Rule
description: It was just another preseason sparring exercise, with the stars making little more than token appearances. And the inconvenient 6 P.M. kickoff was dictated by American network television's catering to its audience across the Atlantic.

title: On Heroin Battlefield, Half a World Away in Asia
description: The mountains at night appear like silhouettes in a Chinese brush painting - a line of dragon humps and stone spikes occasionally capped by an odd clinging cloud. They are the start of the China White Trail to New York.

title: Recuperating Mayor Shifts His Base to Gracie Mansion
description: Mayor Koch's personal secretary and his first deputy mayor will spend most of their time at Gracie Mansion this week as the seat of city government shifts several miles uptown during Mr. Koch's recuperation from a minor stroke.

title: Global Market Brings Auction Records
description: After an unprecedented season of wild spending at art auctions - a van Gogh painting sold for $39.9 million and record prices were also paid for a Mozart manuscript, a Philadelphia wing chair and the Duchess of Windsor's jewels - the major auction houses, Christie's and Sotheby's, are reporting record international sale totals.

title: SAMNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $73,000 and $260,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $173,000 and $280,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary charge of $373,000 from early extinquishment of debt.

title: National; Phillies Top Cards, 8-7, in 14th
description: Lance Parrish tied the score with a home run, and Steve Jeltz's two-out triple in the 14th inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies an 8-7 victory today over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: People
description: * Simon Turner, Robert Chestnut and Keith Sentis have been appointed senior vice presidents at Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: VISUAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $6,834,107 for debt restructuring. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $8,879,067 and $9,598,448 for debt restructuring for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Zimmerman Wins Henredon Classic
description: Mary Beth Zimmerman fought off the stifling heat and pulled away from two challengers on the last five holes today for a three-shot victory in the $300,000 Henredon Classic.

title: Sports of the Times; Silence Was Not Golden
description: When Jackie Joyner-Kersee was given the Sullivan Award a few months ago, she might have asked them to stress the outstanding-athlete part rather than the amateur part.

title: Latin Hope and Evasion; Pact Signed by Central American Leaders Offers an Opening but Avoids Tough Issues
description: The peace plan signed by five Central American leaders on Friday fails to address some of the region's most difficult problems, but it still seems to offer a tentative political opening that could take on a momentum of its own.

title: Doriann DiDio Is Married To John Hersh, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Doriann Marie DiDio, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank DiDio of Peekskill, N.Y., to John Herman Hersh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Hersh, also of Peekskill, took place yesterday at the James House in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Justice Anthony J. Ferraro of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Group Seeking to Visit Soviet Mental Wards
description: The American Psychiatric Association is quietly seeking to send a delegation to the Soviet Union to examine people the organization asserts are confined to psychiatric hospitals for political reasons.

title: BRITONS' BUYING SPREE IN U.S.
description: Corporate Britain appears to be trying to buy back the former American colonies. Last week, the recent surge in trans-Atlantic takeovers accelerated with an extraordinary series of bids for American companies that totaled nearly $4 billion.

title: Small Number of Survivors Found in Soviet Train Crash
description: Few passengers escaped death after the collision of two trains early Friday in a coal-mining district of southern Russia, a Soviet newspaper said today.

title: Teaching Inmates To Re-enter Society
description: From the linoleum to the blackboard, from the molded plastic chairs to the inspirational posters of swans and rainbows, the classroom resembles any other. Only when the teacher raises the window shade can the guard tower and the barbed-wire fence be seen.

title: Yanks' Pitching Tattered
description: He is the great mystery of the Yankee summer.

title: 'Reaganistas'
description: While Republicans are saying let's get the Iran-contra affair behind us, Democrats are saying let's keep it before us.

title: Speeches, Bratwurst and Indecision
description: ''Have you committed yet?'' a friend asked Kathryn McKay, a question that among Iowans requires no explanation.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Persia: The Great Game Goes On
description: On a fine September day 80 years ago, Iranians awoke to learn that their country had been carved like a cutlet into spheres of influence by Britain and Russia. Neither country troubled to consult Persia, as Iran was then called, even though the agreement expressed pious concern for its independence and integrity. What it actually meant became clear four years later when Russia sent troops into Iran to show its displeasure over an honest tax collector - in fact, an American.

title: Sports World Specials; Changes in Cycling
description: Everyone knows Greg LeMond, but along comes Jeannie Longo, and for all the recognition she gets you'd thing she was merely another Frenchwoman out for a Sunday ride.

title: Zahringer Captures 5th Met Amateur
description: George Zahringer 3d won his fifth Metropolitan Amateur golf championship today, the fourth in succession, but he had to go the full 36 holes to defeat Stuart Titus, two up.

title: Market Place; Wary Moves By Managers
description: WITH the Dow Jones industrial average tapping on the door of 2,600 last week, money managers were busily fine-tuning their portfolios. Although they generally did not tinker much with the asset mix of equities, cash and bonds, some professionals said they were becoming increasingly cautious about the stock market.

title: WEST AFRICAN WOMEN: POLITICAL INROADS
description: Madame Sanvee stopped chatting on her portable telephone and shouted in French at a Malian cloth merchant nearby: ''Have you been to the market? Have you asked the prices? It's 23,000 or nothing.''

title: Mission: Almost Impossible
description: People tell Chuck Faucette he faces an almost impossible task.

title: Testing Both Sides
description: Peace in Central America is not yet ''at hand.'' The Arias plan agreed upon by the five nations of the region suggests, however, that the Sandinistas now may be more open to a settlement, and that President Reagan might salvage some of his goals without financing more war in Nicaragua.

title: Lack of Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Haig's Biography
description: Presidential candidates do not always have complete control of what happens in debates, news conferences and the like, which is why they like to present themselves to the voters more frequently in ways that they can control: speeches, television commercials and brochures.

title: ELECTRONIC TELE-COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said Class B share earnings for the latest quarter and 6 months were 2 cents a share and 4 cents a share, respectively; and for the year-ago periods were 14 cents a share and 28 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 10, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Peru Suspends Bank Takeover
description: President Alan Garcia said Friday night that he was lifting the administrative takeover of private banks and credit institutions until the Peruvian Parliament approves a bill to expropriate them.

title: The Novelty Seems To Be Wearing Off
description: John Denver came to the Capitol to talk about the farm crisis the other day and was stood up by two senators.

title: Cuban Is Said to Defect With Intelligence Data
description: A Cuban intelligence agent with secret information on the activities of Cuban operatives around the world has defected to the United States, according to officials of Radio Marti, the Voice of America station aimed at Cuba.

title: Pan Am Games; U.S. Diver Wins
description: Kelly McCormick of the United States successfully defended her 3-meter springboard diving championship in the Pan American Games today with a meet-record 562.77 points.

title: Honolulu Telemarketer To Test Condom Ads
description: Transworld Teleproducts, a Honolulu-based telemarketing company, will begin testing the ability of television to sell condoms - largely to women who order by telephone.

title: South African Black Miners Start Strike in Gold and Coal Industries
description: The first of an estimated 200,000 black miners stopped work tonight in what could become the biggest strike over wages in South African history.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avalon Corp., which is engaged in acquisitions, ownership management and development and sale of real properties, named Joseph M. Alfano executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: L & N HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boxing: U.S. Accent Not Solely on Cuba
description: They have been assigned the same punishing responsibilities that more familiar names once faced. Names such as Whitaker, Biggs, Holyfield, Tillman and Gonzales; and before them Leonard, Pryor, Spinks and Dokes.

title: U.N. Needs a Connecticut Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: Sea World of Texas Signs Ogilvy & Mather
description: Sea World of Texas, scheduled to open in San Antonio next May, has selected Ogilvy & Mather as its agency for the $5 million account.

title: KRISCH AMERICAN INNS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The second quarter results include the operations of two units acquired during the period. The year-ago results are not available; the company went public in October.

title: Summer, and the Political Operatives Do Not Let Up
description: The torpor of Washington in August has hardly slowed Tom Donilon and Rich Bond.

title: U.S. Officials Criticized on Efforts To Curb AIDS Among Minorities
description: Federal health officials were accused today of snubbing black and Hispanic community workers who could offer valuable assistance in fighting AIDS, which has spread disproportionally in minority communities.

title: CUE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $46,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said computation of share earnings gives effect to the assumed exercise of certain outstanding common stock warrants and to dividend requirements on preferred stock.

title: Going Out Guide; Borough Bash
description: Yet another New York venue for outdoor summer musical performances is Brooklyn's Wingate Field, on Winthrop Street between Brooklyn and Kingston Avenues. At 7:30 P.M. today, the Martin Luther King Jr. concert series (718-469-1912) is presenting , Pieces of a Dream, which has appeared twice before in this series, and Grover Washington Jr., the popular jazz saxophonist who crossed over to become a successful pop-fusion artist. Blankets or chairs will enhance comfort. Parking is available in the Kings County Hospital lot on Kingston Avenue between Winthrop Street and Rutland Road. Sir Charles ''The Gold Rush,'' a 1925 silent movie, is classic Charlie Chaplin. The little clown is at his best. His eating his leather shoe provides one of the peak moments in this timeless film. The cast also includes Georgia Hale, Mack Swain and Tom Murray. This 82-minute feature is one of the silent films being shown at 7:30 P.M. every day except Sunday through Aug. 29 in the atrium at the Market at Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street (559-2330, a recorded message). A live pianist accompanies each movie. Future films feature John Barrymore, Rudolph Valentino, Lon Chaney, W. C. Fields and Buster Keaton.

title: Man Slain Gangland-Style in East Side Restaurant
description: A 50-year-old man was shot and killed in a gangland-style slaying while eating dessert Saturday night at an Italian restaurant on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Beth Marla Warshofsky Weds Arthur L. Herman
description: The wedding of Beth Marla Warshofsky to Arthur L. Herman took place yesterday at Garvins, a restaurant in Greenwich Village. Rabbi Robert Rothman officiated.

title: SKELETONS FOUND IN AN APARTMENT
description: Police officers discovered six bodies decomposing in a run-down apartment in North Philadelphia today.

title: A Republican Politician, In Both U.S. and Ulster
description: The summer patriots are back, and the militants among the Irish are grateful.

title: S.E.C. GOAL: SHARP AIM IN VAGUE INSIDER CASES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's proposal on Friday for a bill that would define insider trading could lead to a legislative landmark that would strengthen the Government's hand in prosecuting what are often complex cases, according to S.E.C. officials and experts on securities law.

title: Impounded Bats Found to Be Legal
description: Bats confiscated from R. J. Reynolds of Pittsburgh and Tim Raines of Montreal were X-rayed and found to be free of illegal tampering, Ed Vargo, the National League umpires supervisor, said today.

title: In Argentina, 2 Lost Instruments and Discord
description: Two missing instruments, a cello and a double bass, stumped the mighty of culture and business Thursday night in their efforts to present great music within sight of these awesome jungle waterfalls.

title: Golf; Nelson Wins P.G.A. in Playoff Against Wadkins
description: Larry Nelson, rarely a pre-tournament favorite, confounded everyone today when he sank a 6-foot par putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff to beat Lanny Wadkins for the 69th P.G.A. Championship. It was the third major tournament victory of Nelson's career.

title: Opera: Strauss's 'Schweigsame Frau'
description: Richard Strauss liked to compose every morning from 9 to lunchtime, and as he neared the age of 70 he began to feel that he had run out of ideas for ''absolute,'' or instrumental, music, so it was imperative for the maintenance of his daily regimen that he have an opera libretto always at hand to work on. When his longtime collaborator Hugo von Hofmannsthal died in 1929, the composer began an urgent search for a new poet and settled on Stefan Zweig. The first fruit of their collaboration was ''Die Schweigsame Frau,'' which the Santa Fe Opera has added this summer to its long survey of lesser-known Strauss.

title: AUTO INCENTIVES PRODUCE SALES BUT NO STAMPEDE
description: Car dealers reported increased sales over the weekend following the latest announcement of incentives for buyers. But most of them said customers had not responded as enthusiastically to the offers as they had last summer.

title: Horse Racing; Polish Navy Finds Last Year's Luster
description: Polish Navy, a brilliant 2-year-old last season but a disappointing 3-year-old until now, redeemed himself today by scoring a victory over six other 3-year-olds in the $177,900 Jim Dandy Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Singer's Trial on Nudity in Album Begins Today
description: Jello Biafra, the founder and lead singer of the Dead Kennedys rock band, goes on trial Monday on charges of violating a California statute that makes it illegal to distribute, exhibit or send harmful material to a minor.

title: 51 SENATORS LIST $1 MILLION IN AID
description: More than half the current United States senators have received at least $1 million each from political action committees in their Congressional careers.

title: Boxing; Pryor Is Dazed in Return Bout
description: It was a night of odd moments - boxing with the sort of dislocating twists commonly associated with the vaudeville of professional wrestling.

title: Jobs for Cabot And Ammirati
description: Ammirati & Puris's direct marketing unit has been tapped to work for Chemical Bank's Consumer Finance Group, while up in Boston, Cabot Advertising is taking on Northeast Savings, the largest savings institution in New England.

title: Kicking the Cold War Habit
description: After 40 years of cold war, the United States now has a basis for thinking anew about policy toward the Soviet Union.

title: KOCH FEELS 'GOOD' LEAVING HOSPITAL
description: Seventy-two hours after suffering a minor stroke, Mayor Koch was released from the hospital yesterday, saying he felt ''very, very good'' and thrusting his arms upright in a declaration of victory.

title: The Snake Oil Diet
description: The Food and Drug Administration is about to permit a dangerous experiment with the American diet. It plans to let food companies make health claims for their products under rules that invite the consumer to be confused and deceived.

title: Wright Says Third Party Could Speak for Contras
description: Jim Wright, the House Speaker, said today that the dispute over the role of the Nicaraguan rebels in peace negotiations might be resolved by having the rebels represented by third parties.

title: INSIDE
description: New Threat to Insiders

title: Truce Between Colombia and Rebels Is Unraveling
description: Once held up as a possible model for Central America, a three-year-old truce between the Colombian Government and the country's largest leftist guerrilla movement is slowly breaking down.

title: Sports World Specials; A Matter of Permission
description: When Gene Banks of the Chicago Bulls suffered a serious tear of an Achilles' tendon during a local all-star game in Philadelphia in June, it appeared to be just another one of those unfortunate mishaps that so often strike professional athletes between seasons.

title: HALSEY DRUG reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $111,000 and $25,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After tax credits of $131,000 for the quarter and $108,000 for the 6 months.

title: TV Reviews; 'Old Dogs,' Pilot Show For a Police Drama
description: THE hourlong ''Old Dogs,'' on Channel 7 at 8 tonight, is the kind of project that is often described in listings as ''a pilot not on the network's announced fall schedule.'' This probably means that the show has been rejected in its bid for fame and dollars as a regular weekly series. What, viewers may wonder, makes the difference?

title: Harlem Show Remembers Garvey
description: In the Harlem of the 1920's and 30's - then experiencing a renaissance of culture, music and art - there emerged an organization that fostered one of the largest movements for minority advancement to precede the civil-rights era of the 1950's and 60's.

title: Metro Matters; In a Tokyo Mode: Urban Solutions From the East
description: Imagine if cranes and other construction equipment didn't block nearby sidewalks and streets when skyscrapers went up. If residential and commercial garbage were collected together to reduce traffic congestion. If more electrical cables were placed under sidewalks to give utilities one less reason to mangle city streets. Visions of a faraway future? Faraway, yes, but not necessarily far out. A group of New York City officials has just returned from an exchange program in Japan, where they have seen these and similar visions of the future work.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months are translated into U.S. dollars at the rate of 20.3474 Philippine pesos per $1 and 20.3691 Philippine pesos per $1, respectively; and the results for the year-ago quarter and 6 months are translated into U.S. dollars at the rate of 20.3605 and 20.1158 Philippine pesos per $1, respectively. The company said year-ago results are restated and include gains of $427,000 in the second quarter and $864,000 in the 6 months from adjustments, relating mainly to depreciation charges for property and equipment of the Masbate gold operations.

title: Dr. Meg A. Rosenblatt Wed to David A. Stein
description: Dr. Meg Amy Rosenblatt, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Rosenblatt of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Alan Stein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Stein of Yonkers. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner performed the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Cynthia Eichler Wed To Clifford E. Oliver
description: At Congregation Adas Israel in Washington yesterday, Cynthia Dina Eichler, a daughter of Paula Seigle Eichler of Rockville, Md., and Dr. Martin Eichler of Bethesda, Md., was married to Clifford Evan Oliver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Oliver of Bedford Village, N.Y. Rabbis Matthew Simon and Jeffrey Wohlberg performed the ceremony.

title: Israel Says Its Gunships Hit A Guerrilla Post in Lebanon
description: Israeli helicopter gunships attacked a guerrilla group's headquarters in southern Lebanon today, an army spokesman said.

title: Sports World Specials; Catching Up
description: Jeff George, the former Purdue quarterback who quit the team last January in order to transfer to the University of Miami, has decided to transfer to Illinois instead. George, an acclaimed high school star from Indianapolis who was a starter as a Purdue freshman last fall, became disenchanted with the school after it hired a run-oriented head coach. He apparently became disenchanted with Miami after it signed Craig Erickson, an acclaimed high school quarterback from West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Japan's Bidder for Dunes Has International Goal
description: Masao Nangaku, who bid $157.7 million to buy the bankrupt Dunes Hotel and Casinos Inc. last Monday, has become a billionaire through his entertainment interests, which range from ski resorts to bowling alleys.

title: 'A Chorus Line,' for 5,001st Show, Makes the Dream Come True Again
description: ''The conservative word for 'A Chorus Line' might be tremendous, or perhaps terrific,'' began Clive Barnes's review in The New York Times on May 22, 1975. A conservative word for the show now might be venerable, or even legendary.

title: School Reform: Years Of Tumult, Mixed Results
description: Four years after a torrent of school ''reforms'' began to sweep across the country amid fears that American public education was lagging, schoolchildren in almost every state are facing tougher academic standards and billions of dollars have been pumped into their schools.

title: Vietnamese Ease Limits On Artists and Writers
description: At the 11th-century Temple of Literature in a quiet Hanoi park, there are three gates leading to the inner courtyard. The ornate one in the middle is for kings. Two modest ones flank it. One is for soldiers and the other for writers and scholars.

title: Armacost Taking Merrill Lynch Post
description: Samuel H. Armacost, the former president of the BankAmerica Corporation, is joining Merrill Lynch & Company as an investment banker in its San Francisco office.

title: Legislation Introduced To Spur Super Collider
description: Leaders of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee and more than 200 colleagues have introduced legislation to authorize the multibillion-dollar superconducting super collider.

title: Blue Arrow Obtains Loan
description: Blue Arrow P.L.C. said Friday it had arranged a bridge loan of $:837 million, or $1.31 billion, and two other financings to support its $75-a-share bid for Manpower Inc., the big American employment company.

title: Stop Intimidating Pit Bulls and Owners
description: LEAD: Hysterical righteousness, fueling moves to have pit bulls banned, has created an appalling situation, eerily reminiscent of the time in 1738, in Edinburgh, Scotland, when a dog - a single dog - started a lot of dog fights at the Edinburgh Flesh Market. The magistrate ordered that ''all dogs of the mastiff kind be forthwith put to death under penalty of $:5 Sterling and imprisonment of the owner for twelve calendar months.

title: THE PLIGHT OF FEMALE MINERS
description: Cosby Totten, a coal miner laid off since 1982, does not easily hide her opinion of what has happened to Appalachia's struggling coal industry since Ronald Reagan has been President. ''I can't fault the old man too much,'' she said. ''I bought a brand new color TV when Carter was President, and Reagan gave me the time to watch it.''

title: Quinones Closes Bronx School for Failing to Raise Test Scores
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, has ordered a Bronx junior high school closed because it failed to improve its academic performance after a year's warning, and he said yesterday that other schools would be put on a similar probation this fall.

title: THOMAS CUITE DIES OF A HEART ATTACK
description: Thomas J. Cuite, who retired in 1985 after 16 years as majority leader of the New York City Council, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 74 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: TV Reviews; Channel 2 Examines 'The Legacy of Racism'
description: RACISM does not lend itself easily to television exploration; it can be recognized in an overt form, but the nuances are misleading. ''The Legacy of Racism,'' on Channel 2 at 11:30 tonight, handles the topic with care. After it settles down, it asks questions.

title: WAREHOUSE CLUB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CHILDREN, STUTTERING AND TV
description: Max Headroom, television's computer-generated character known for his one-liners and fractured speech, may set a bad example for young people by encouraging them to stutter, a speech therapist said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 10, 1987
description: International A2-11

title: A Hart List Is Sold
description: The liquidation sale of former Senator Gary Hart's Presidential campaign continues.

title: Pan Am Games; U.S. Wins Medals, Loses a Runner
description: The anticipated United States dominance of the 10th Pan American Games started early today - in fact, not long after the games began on this first of 15 days of competition.

title: Bridge; Sweden and France Appear Headed for European Titles
description: At the midpoint of European Championship play in Brighton, England, the major titles seem headed for Sweden and France.

title: Guccione Son Defying Father Over Magazine
description: One day after Penthouse International Ltd. announced that Spin magazine, the pop music monthly, would cease publication, Robert Guccione Jr., its editor and publisher, announced his plans to keep it alive, albeit removed from the umbrella of support from Penthouse it has enjoyed over its two-year existence.

title: Big Move for Publisher
description: Can a book published 45 years ago resurface today as a commercial and critical success? Most publishers probably would not bet on it, but then North Point Press in Berkeley, Calif., is not just any publishing house.

title: British Caledonian Stands by Deal
description: British Caledonian Airways has decided to stick with its merger agreement with British Airways despite a Government inquiry that could stop the deal going ahead, British Caledonian's chairman, Sir Adam Thomson, said Saturday.

title: July Prices Up 8.1% in Mexico
description: Consumer prices rose 8.1 percent in July in Mexico, continuing to outpace the rate last year and bringing the inflation rate for the first seven months of the year to 67.5 percent, the central bank said.

title: Jets Lose Baldwin For 4 to 6 Weeks
description: Tom Baldwin couldn't really explain it -neither could a few curses. No one even hit him. But it has become almost axiomatic that, if you're a Jet, you don't have to be hit to be hurt.

title: Iran Bears Blame for Mines, Weinberger Suggests
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger suggested publicly today, for the first time, that Iran was responsible for placing mines that United States naval forces had cleared from the Persian Gulf.

title: Race Postponed
description: A steady rain postponed today's scheduled Budweiser at the Glen Nascar race.

title: INDUSTRIAL ELECTRONIC HARDARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-After tax credits of $105,000 for the latest first quarter and $99,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Marissa Martino Wed To Spencer E. Golden
description: Marissa Margaret Martino, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Martino of Great Neck, L.I., was married at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club yesterday to Spencer Eli Golden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Golden of New York. Rabbi Steven Folberg officiated.

title: Treasury to Set Details of Financing
description: The Treasury is expected to announce this morning details of a delayed but indispensable August note and bond financing.

title: MORE PAIN FOR TEXAS THRIFT UNITS
description: The troubled Texas thrift industry faces mounting difficulties in the coming months, with falling demand for home mortgages adding to the problems of a weak commercial real estate market and the high costs of attracting depositors.

title: Colonel North TV Ads
description: Perhaps inevitably, the Oliver North T-shirts, buttons, posters and coloring books have now been joined by Oliver North commercials.

title: A PLETHORA OF PROPOSALS
description: Following are the major Central America peace plans: Contadora Group

title: Genentech License
description: Genentech Inc., a leading biotechnology company based in South San Francisco, said that its foreign licensee, Boehringer Ingelheim International G.m.b.H., had received approval to market tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A., in Austria for the treatment of heart-attack patients. A human protein that dissolves blood clots, T.P.A. has also been approved in the Philippines, New Zealand and France and is awaiting approval in more than 20 other countries. The United States Food and Drug Administration has delayed approval of T.P.A., pending Genentech's showing proof that the protein does save lives by dissolving clots.

title: Doldrums on Eve of Bond Sale
description: On the eve of a major Treasury financing, the bond market is in the doldrums, with yields approaching 9 percent for long-term issues and no sign so far of strong investor demand.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Haitian Democracy Imperiled By a Rising Tide of Violence
description: Last Sunday a respected political leader and two aides were stoned and hacked to death during a meeting with about 150 peasants in a rural churchyard.

title: Washington and Moscow Together Can Make Middle East Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH IMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter loss includes a $1,827,000 non-cash charge relating to the exchange by an officer and director of 554,000 shares of junior common stock for 443,000 shares of common stock and a 10-year warrant to purchase 250,000 shares of common stock at $4.50 a share.

title: Study Puts New Hampshire On the Map, and in a Big Way
description: A political scientist at George Washington University here has drawn a map of the United States in which New Hampshire is 60 times as big as Alaska, Iowa dwarfs Texas, and the Western states, except for California, scarcely exist at all.

title: Colleges Review Curriculums
description: American colleges and universities are beginning to reform their curriculums and are making plans to measure what their students are learning, according to a survey made public today.

title: WEAKER U.M.W.'S HARD TASK
description: The bulletproof glass that once shielded the windows of the United Mine Workers' headquarters here has been removed, but the union's battles are far from over.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 10, 1987
description: Companies

title: TOURISTS CAUTIOUSLY VENTURE BACK TO EUROPE
description: Like hardy perennials that stayed underground for a season, American tourists have cautiously reappeared this summer on the streets of Paris, London, Rome, Madrid and Moscow.

title: TELEQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Soviet, Iran Set Pipeline Talks
description: Soviet experts are due this month in Teheran, the capital of Iran, to discuss plans for transporting Iranian oil through trans-Soviet pipelines to Black Sea ports for export, the Iranian oil minister said Saturday.

title: BEATRICE UNIT BRINGS $985 MILLION
description: The TLC Group, a New York investment firm, has agreed to buy the Beatrice International Food Company from the parent of the Beatrice Companies for $985 million, TLC officials said yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies Saturday on the minor stroke suffered by Mayor Koch misidentified one of the physicians treating him. The physician, who is the director of neuroradiology at Presbyterian Hospital, is Dr. Sadek K. Hilal.

title: DIAGNOSTIC PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
As U.S. Air Quality Deadline Looms, Cities Are Giving Up Hope of Solution
description: A delegation of officials from Houston recently visited the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Lee M. Thomas, and brought a disturbing message: The city had done everything it was told to do to meet the federally mandated standard for ozone, but was not even close to doing so.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail SalesJuly Friday Producer Prices...July Industrial Production...July Inventory-Sales Ratio...June Merchandise Trade...June

title: Tamils Halt Arms Surrender
description: The arms surrender by Tamil militants, called for under a peace accord, hit a snag today as Tamils in northern and eastern Sri Lanka staged a strike to protest purported torture killings by security forces.

title: AILEEN RYAN, COUNCILWOMAN FROM THE BRONX FOR 17 YEARS
description: Aileen Barlow Ryan, a former New York City Councilwoman who in 17 years on the Council played a key role in clashes over some of the most heated social issues of the 1970's, died Saturday of heart disease at Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. She was 74 years old.

title: Ron Rogerson, Princeton Coach
description: Ron Rogerson, the head football coach at Princeton University, died of an apparent heart attack Saturday morning while jogging in New Hampshire, where he was vacationing with his family. He was 44 years old.

title: Bevill Agrees To Payment
description: Robert L. Bevill, the former chairman of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., has agreed to turn over $2.3 million to court-appointed trustees managing the collapsed securities firm and a related firm, a trustee's attorney said.

title: GTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
B.J.K.& E. Buyback Keeps Executive Busy
description: Charles J. Peebler Jr., chief executive of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, is doing his best to take a few days off at his place on Long Island. But he is spending a lot of time on the phone talking to people interested in the progress of the company's buyback from its parent, the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, and particularly of a possible role of two of the agency's clients, Merrill Lynch and Chrysler.

title: Piniella Replies, In a Softer Tone
description: Lou Piniella, choosing to avoid a public confrontation with George Steinbrenner, issued his own statement today in which he said he disagreed with the Yankee owner but intended to put recent controversy behind him and the team.

title: Sports World Specials; Ringside Focus
description: It hasn't yet joined the water bucket, the sponge and the stool as a standard ringside fixture, but in a sport whose practitioners have too often ended their careers as reeling punch drunks, it may not be long before a little white box becomes a battered boxer's best friend.

title: Results Plus; Auto Racing
description: Two in a Row for Piquet: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, driving a Williams-Honda, won the Hungarian Grand Prix yesterday in Budapest. It was his second straight Formula One victory this year. Piquet won the West German Grand Prix at the end of July. Ayrton Senna, another Brazilian, was second in a Lotus-Honda, 37.727 seconds behind Piquet. Alain Prost of France was third. With the victory, Piquet extended his lead in the world championship drivers' standing. He now has 48 points, with Senna in second at 41. Nigel Mansell of Britain, Piquet's Williams-Honda teammate, led for the first 70 laps of the 76-lap race. In the 71st lap, Mansell had to stop after a nut flew off his car's right wheel.(AP) Boxing Lockridge Captures Title: Rocky Lockridge stopped Barry Michael last night to win the International Boxing Federation super-featherweight title in Windsor, England. Lockridge, from Mount Laurel, N.J., was well ahead on points when the bout was stopped after Michael did not answer the bell for the ninth round. The American, a former World Boxing Association champion in the same division, improved his record to 41-5-0. Michael, of Australia, who was making his fourth defense, fell to 48-9-3. The contest, at Blazer's nightclub in Windsor, which is 50 miles west of London, was delayed for 30 minutes when a bomb threat forced an evacuation of the building.(AP) Dog Show Rhodesian Ridgeback Best: Ch. Ketaru's Sheena of Fairview, a Rhodesian Ridgeback owned by Linda and Matthew Spector of South Windham, Conn., and handled by Ron Zucchi, was named best in show yesterday at the Sand and Sea Kennel Club Fixture in Lakewood, N.J. It was the first top award for the bitch, who will be 3 years old next month. She defeated a strong field, including five dogs who had previously taken top awards. Tennis Sanchez Defeats Mecir: Emilio Sanchez of Spain won the $250,000 Head Cup Grand Prix tournament yesterday in Kitzbuehel, Austria, surprising Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 6-1, 4-6, 6-1. The 22-year-old Spaniard had praised his opponent Saturday as ''the greatest talent there is,'' but had added that even Mecir, who is ranked fifth in the world, could have a bad day. After his singles victory, which won him $28,000, Sanchez joined Sergio Casal of Spain to defeat Mecir and Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 7-6, in doubles. (AP) Cycling West German Wins Stage: Little-known Andreas Kappes of West Germany won the latest stage of the Coors International Bicycle Classic yesterday in San Francisco, but the American-based 7-Eleven team continued its early dominance of the 1,385-mile event. Kappes finished the new 75-mile Presidio Circuit Race in 3 hours 8 minutes 30 seconds, about 2 seconds ahead of Jeff Pierce of San Diego, winner of the last leg of the recent Tour de France. (AP)

title: Robins-Rorer Talks
description: Directors of the A. H. Robins Company have deferred action on a merger proposal from Rorer Group Inc. because of questions about the trust fund to be set up for Dalkon Shield claimants, a spokesman said. Lawyers for the two pharmaceutical companies were to meet Monday in New York for discussions, a Robins spokesman said. The $1.75 billion fund, part of the reorganization plan Robins has filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Richmond, would be used for the more than 300,000 claims from women who say they were injured by the intrauterine birth-control device.

title: Phil Niekro Traded From Last to First
description: Phil Niekro, a 318-game winner who has never pitched in the World Series, was traded today by the last-place Cleveland Indians to the Toronto Blue Jays for Darryl Landrum, a minor league outfielder.

title: Books of the Times
description: YOU MUST REMEMBER THIS. By Joyce Carol Oates. 436 pages. E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: GAF to Kornhauser
description: Kornhauser & Calene has become agency for the country's leading maker of asphalt roofing products. The new client, the GAF Building Materials Corporation of Wayne, N.J., makes such brand-name products as Timberline, Woodline, Slateline, Sentinel and Royal Sovereign. The former agency is Shaw & Todd, which will continue to work for GAF's chemicals division.

title: Who'll Trust Debates Staged by the Parties?
description: To the Editor:

title: Libyan Planes Strike Back In Strip Retaken by Chad
description: As civilians in Ndjamena celebrated reports that Libya's 14-year-old occupation of northern Chad had ended, Libyan warplanes struck back today against the Chadian soldiers who had retaken the area, called the Aouzou Strip.

title: Mets Lose Again
description: As Dave Johnson sat behind his desk yesterday for the customary postgame interrogation, the television was tuned to the Cardinals-Phillies game in Philadelphia. In the locker room, whispered conversations were interrupted by an occasional question from a Met: ''Who's up?'' ''Did the Phils score?'' In the lounge, a few players became fans, rooting for the first-place Cardinals to lose.

title: BANK UNCERTAINTY IN PANAMA
description: Growing political unrest and the Government's response to it have severely damaged, perhaps irreparably, Panama's ability to function as an international financial center, according to bankers, business executives and diplomats here.

title: EASTERN L.I.'S DRY, WARY WEEKEND
description: When he saw what looked like two fins in the water 150 feet off Napeague Beach here, Bruce A. Pomerantz said he had just one thought.

title: Jo Klingenstein, Peter R. Ziesing Exchange Vows
description: Joanne Lee Klingenstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Paul Klingenstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Peter Raymond Ziesing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert August Ziesing of St. Davids, Pa., and Squam Lake, N.H., were married yesterday. Rabbi Daniel B. Wolk performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale.

title: Roar of Speedway Ruffles Neighbors
description: For Greg Richardson and other auto-racing fans, there is no sweeter sound on a warm summer night than the ear-splitting roar of engines at the speedway here.

title: PACK RATS: SAVING FOR WHATEVER
description: THEY are the guardians of all they survey - string, paper scraps, old report cards, broken buttons, instruction manuals for appliances they no longer have - most of which they keep. They are the friends and family members who stay the hands of would-be closet cleaners with those immortal words: ''Don't throw that out. You never know when you might need it.''

title: Workers Stage Sit-Ins In 4 South Korea Cities
description: The police said about 20,000 workers demanding better pay and conditions demonstrated in four South Korean cities today. Industry officials warned that 200 companies faced closure because of labor unrest.

title: Business and the Law; Insurers Sued On Waste Sites
description: IN a major battle with its insurance companies, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has fired the first volley in a legal contest that is expected to last years and determine who must pay to clean up some of the most dangerous waste sites across the country.

title: More Than Tidying Up
description: To the Editor:

title: ZYCAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $576,000 and $831,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Friday with an article on upper Broadway misidentified an intersection lined with park benches. It was West 90th Street and Broadway.

title: In Hungary, the Spirit of Change Reappears
description: Rezso Nyers, a founding father of Hungary's drive for economic changes, says this nation's current crisis is similar to what happened when conservative pressures temporarily halted the previous such program in the early 1970's.

title: Bernstein Wins MacDowell Medal
description: Thirty-one artists, writers and composers left their isolated woodland studios on the grounds of the MacDowell Colony this morning and helped honor Leonard Bernstein. Mr. Bernstein was given the Edward MacDowell Medal, an annual presentation rotated among the different arts. Last year the award went to Lee Friedlander, a photographer.

title: Times Sq. Development: Boom of Private Projects
description: Through the windows of his office high above Times Square, Vincent Tese, the chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, can barely hear the demolition going on across the street. The work being done is not part of the Times Square redevelopment project, however. It is for one of several private developments beginning to take shape in the area.

title: Mesa Verde: Where the Government's Mistake Is a Tribe's Good Fortune
description: For centuries, the only structures on Soda Point were the ancient cliff dwellings of the Anasazi Indians.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''High office, well-intended policies or popular policies do not place anyone above the law.'' - Lawrence E. Walsh, special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair. [ A1:6. ]

title: 4 WOMEN REFLECT ON A DECADE OF CHANGE
description: Ten years ago this summer, Joan Alagna traveled to Albany for the New York State Women's Meeting with other members of the National Congress of Neighborhood Women in Brooklyn. Ruth Dunne came from the Bronx, accompanied by 90 women from the New York Metro Area Postal Union and their friends, family members and neighbors. Alice Hall came from Syracuse with her husband and members of the John Birch Society. And Maxine Sobel went to Albany as a feminist journalist from Rochester.

title: U.S. Basketball Team Is Rusty but Wins
description: After three weeks of frustrating intra-squad scrimmages and games against off-season professional pickup teams, the United States basketball squad was turned loose on Panama in the opening contest of the Pan American Games.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What is the largest number of players from one major league team to be voted to the league's Gold Glove team of outstanding fielders at the end of a season?

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McEnroe-Lendl Stopped by Rain
description: The final between Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe in the Volvo International tennis tournament was suspended today because of rain.

title: Restless Wilson Has Big Day
description: After the game on Saturday night, he walked aimlessly around the Mets' locker room as if he were someone who was lost and looking for the way home. In his seventh full season with the Mets, Mookie Wilson does not feel that he belongs here, is not content to be a part-time player - even for a championship team.

title: Airliners Fly 600 Feet Apart Over New York
description: A Trans World Airlines jumbo jet arriving from Europe passed within 600 feet of a Pan American World Airways jetliner yesterday before being guided back to a safe landing at John F. Kennedy International Airport, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: IRAN-CASE COUNSEL PLEDGES TO PURSUE ALL LAWBREAKERS
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair said today that ''high office, well-intended policies or popular policies do not place anyone above the law.''

title: Under Pressure, Children Shelter Will Shut Down
description: Under threat of court action, New York City will close its largest shelter for abused and neglected children at the end of the month and has stopped admitting children to it, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. BONDS LURE JAPANESE DESPITE THIN RATE GAP
description: The Japanese bond market has been suffering a prolonged downturn, raising questions about whether Japanese investors will want to participate in further United States Treasury auctions.

title: Advertising; Hyatt Goes To Hill, Holliday
description: HILL, HOLLIDAY, CONNORS, COSMOPULOS last week won the $15 million Hyatt Hotels Corporation account, with creative work done by top creative people from both its Boston and New York offices.

title: Philippine Debt Dispute
description: Finance Secretary Jaime Ongpin hinted he would resign if the Philippine Congress repudiated any of the country's foreign debt.

title: Kimberly Switzer Becomes a Bride
description: Kimberly Belden Switzer, a daughter of Ruth Gray Switzer of East Sandwich, Mass., and H. KirtlandSwitzer of Hanson, Mass., was married yesterday to Brian Devin Robbins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Robbins of New York and Bedford, N.Y., at the Bedford home of the bridegroom's parents. Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Norman Summers.

title: Many Misperceptions Still Cling to Nursing
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth's Murder Trial Focuses on Role of Alcohol
description: It was after midnight last Jan. 28 when the second bloody act took place in a case whose stark twists could have come from the imagination of Shakespeare, had he known about Genessee beer, .22-caliber revolvers, automobiles and the habits of American youth.

title: Safety in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: American League; Blue Jays Win, Reclaim First
description: John Cerutti won his seventh straight decision and Jesse Barfield, Willie Upshaw and Lloyd Moseby hit home runs today as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Cleveland Indians, 5-1.

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONCORD COMPUTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A SIMPLE WAY TO AVOID GULF MINES
description: LEAD: Dispatching minesweepers to the Persian Gulf region is not the answer to preventing attacks on international shipping, like the one that occurred yesterday when an American-operated supertanker hit a mine just outside the Strait of Hormuz. Our problem in the gulf today is a lack of political will, not a lack of minesweeping capability or naval firepower.

title: Alberto-Culver Raises Lamaur Bid
description: The Alberto-Culver Company sweetened its offer to acquire Lamaur Inc. by $2 a share, or a total of about $12 million, and said it would consider a hostile takeover bid for the hair-care products company if the new offer was rejected. Alberto-Culver, a diversified health-care and cosmetics marketer, made its first bid for Lamaur on July 27. The latest offer, of $24 a share, values Lamaur at about $144 million.

title: Little of U.S.-Carried Iran Oil Is Imported
description: Oil experts said yesterday that it was common for tankers owned by American oil companies to carry Iranian crude oil from the Persian Gulf to Western Europe and Japan.

title: TIMBERLINE SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: LVI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $275,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $370,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 6 months.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for 16wks to May 28
description: The share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1987.

title: Gold and Coal Output Disrupted By Strike of South African Blacks
description: Industry officials said today that nearly a third of South Africa's gold and coal mines had been affected by a walkout by more than 230,000 black miners, and the miners themselves said the effects were even greater.

title: SOUTHLIFE HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $145,000 and $501,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $267,000 and $508,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses of $1,424,000 for the quarter and $2,304,000 for the 6 months from the company's equity in Syntech International Inc., and the interest carrying costs of the Syntech investment of $254,000 and $674,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes a loss of $210,000 from equity in Syntech and interest costs of $146,000. d-Net loss and includes a loss of $493,000 from equity in Syntech and interest costs of $310,000.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After the $459 million net charge for restructuring for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Opposition in Nicaragua: Dissenters Within Limits
description: Although the Sandinista front dominates every aspect of Nicaraguan political life, a lively internal opposition remains active in Nicaragua. Restrictions on civil rights are daunting, but dissent within limits is tolerated.

title: Charge Gives P.&G. A $324 Million Loss
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that a substantial charge for the restructuring of its operations resulted in a loss of $324 million in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1987, in contrast to a profit of $127 million, or 74 cents a share, in the corresponding three months of 1986.

title: CARDINAL O'BOYLE OF WASHINGTON, LIBERAL WHO ESPOUSED ORTHODOXY
description: Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle, who in 1948 became the first Roman Catholic Archbishop of Washington, D.C., and held the post for a quarter of a century, died yesterday morning at Providence Hospital in Washington after a brief illness. He was 91 years old.

title: RAYMOND MESELSOHN, BROKER
description: LEAD: Raymond Meselsohn, head of a Manhattan stock brokerage, died of a heart attack last Friday while jogging. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PHOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes $139,000, or 8 cents a share, from receipt of bankruptcy claim against Storage Technology Corp.

title: THE PRISON MIRROR, A NEWSPAPER, MARKS ITS 100TH YEAR
description: Articles in the award-winning Prison Mirror are a far cry now from those once written by members of Jesse James's gang, but the goal of the newspaper, which turned 100 years old today, is still the same, its editor says.

title: I.R.S. Search Meets Long Arm of the Law
description: The whereabouts of a reputed mobster, Rocco Argenti Jr., were known to some Federal officers, but not to all who wanted to know.

title: Peripherals; SPLASHES FROM BIG FISH
description: IT had been getting downright monotonous at the fishing hole this summer, but things finally started jumping last week. Two of the biggest fish in the personal computer industry, the Tandy Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation, made a big splash by adding new models to their existing lines. A Very Happy Anniversary

description: To the Editor:

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHROEDER IS FAR FROM GOAL ON MONEY FOR A CANDIDACY
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder is a long way from raising the money she said she needed to enter the Presidential race.

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Koch, Returning Home, Handles Queries in Stride
description: A soft summer breeze blew from the East River across the porch of Gracie Mansion in midafternoon yesterday. Mayor Koch, a glass of iced tea by his side, was back at home and back in his element: surrounded by a swirling pack of reporters, photographers and television cameras.

title: 7 Killed as Rock In Colorado Hits Sightseers' Bus
description: A huge boulder dislodged by a state highway worker rolled off a mountainside today and smashed into a sightseeing bus, killing 7 people and injuring 15, the authorities said.

title: Our Towns; Young Victims Of Cancer Find Joy of Summer
description: There is a famous story they tell here at cancer camp about a little girl named Arlene Pabon, who goes running across the lawn to the edge of the swimming pool, rips off her hat, bends over, disconnects her prosthesis, dives in the pool, and everyone yells, ''Arlene, you know you're not supposed to run across the lawn!'' There are rules, for Pete's sake.

title: Got an Extra $22,500?
description: From George Washington in 1789 through Ronald Reagan in 1983, American Presidents signed about 75,000 executive orders and proclamations, but only a third of them found their way into such available collections as the Code of Federal Regulations and the Public Papers of the Presidents. After a good deal of rummaging in dusty files, Congressional Information Service Inc., a private group, has come up with all of them and reproduced their full texts on microfiche.

title: HYLA STOWELL WATTERS
description: Hyla Stowell Watters, a Methodist missionary surgeon in China and India who remained in practice until 1974, died Aug. 2 of heart failure at Saranac Lake General Hospital, N.Y. She was 93 years old and lived in Tupper Lake, N.Y.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Chip Makers' Strong July
description: Orders to chip makers increased in July, although shipments declined, an industry group reported today.

title: MAN CONVICTED IN DRINKING CASE
description: A 21-year-old carpenter was convicted of third-degree murder today in the fatal shooting of the driver who killed the carpenter's teen-age sister in an accident last year.

title: Afghan Leader Returns
description: The Afghan leader, Najib, not seen in public for almost three weeks, returned to Kabul, Afghanistan today from the Soviet Union, the official Bakhtar news agency reported. Najib flew to Moscow July 19 on an unannounced visit and had talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. After a news conference July 21, he dropped from view.

title: Bond Prices Drop Modestly
description: Bond prices fell modestly yesterday in advance of a heavy supply of new Treasury offerings.

title: Not an Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Relief for Ryan?
description: Although Nolan Ryan has started all 238 games in which he has appeared since joining Houston in 1980, the Astros' manager, Hal Lanier, is considering using the 40-year-old right-hander as a long reliever, possibly as soon as Thursday in San Francisco. ''I've been giving it a lot of thought,'' said Lanier, who said he is concerned about Ryan's current slump. Ryan, limited to 110 pitches in each start, hasn't won since June 12 and has an eight-game losing streak. But Ryan said he'll talk to the pitching coach, Les Moss, to express his opposition to the idea. ''What people have to understand is that I'm at the state of my career where getting a win or breaking a streak doesn't mean that much to me,'' Ryan said.

title: Oilfield Project Set in Norway
description: Oil production was halted today at Norway's sinking Ekofisk North Sea field in preparation for a major rescue project, drilling platform operators said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about a murder in a Manhattan restaurant gave incorrect information about the victim, Irwin Schiff. It was another man, with the same name, who was sentenced to six months in Federal prison and fined $10,000 for failure to file income tax returns.

title: TRAVEL AGENT'S HOUSE GUEST IS CHARGED IN MAN'S MURDER
description: A 27-year-old man and a homeless friend were charged yesterday with killing a 77-year-old retired travel agent, who had let one of the men live in his Upper East Side apartment, after the travel agent resisted their attempt to rob him of $40, the police said.

title: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Preferred Offered By Hartford Fire
description: The Hartford Fire Insurance Company is offering $135 million of preferred stock whose dividend rate will be adjusted every seven weeks according to the results of an auction.

title: HELMERICH & PAYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months includes gains from the sale of securities of $2,260,000 and $15,927,000, respectively; and the year-ago periods includes similar gains of $931,000 for the quarter and $10,141,000 for the 9 months.

title: I. W. ABEL OF STEELWORKERS DIES AT 78
description: I. W. Abel, who came out of the blast-furnace steel mills of the Depression to help found the United Steelworkers of America and served as the union's third president for 12 years in the 1960's and 1970's, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Malvern, Ohio.

title: Lautenberg and Wife Considering Divorce
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and his wife Lois have separated and are considering a divorce, the Senator's office said today.

title: OPERA: A NEARLY COMPLETE 'ARIODANTE' BY HANDEL IN SANTA FE
description: A near-complete staging of ''Ariodante'' here revealed the beautiful work so naturally and convincingly that the days of doctored and truncated Handel, so recent in fact, seemed bizarrely remote.

title: ICEE-USA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $1,876,000 of territorial rights to sell the company's product in Canada and Mexico. c-Net income

title: Robins Target of New Move
description: Claimants against the A. H. Robins Company, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, sought court permission yesterday to sue three of its top officials and its former accounting firm for at least $530 million.

title: Christopher Shays for Congress
description: Both major-party candidates for Connecticut's vacant Congressional seat in a special election next Tuesday are well qualified. We favor Christopher Shays, the Republican, for his willingness to stake out clear positions and stick to them.

title: Offense Lacking, Mets Fall Again
description: He made up his mind, Sam Perlozzo said, when he saw Mitch Webster field Darryl Strawberry's base hit down the right field line, in foul territory near the box seats. Keith Hernandez was rounding third, a bit wide perhaps, but Perlozzo decided to send him home anyway. There was a chance that the lumbering Hernandez would take the Expos by surprise and score. It was a chance the Mets' third base coach was willing to take.

title: Justice Brennan to Undergo Tests For Prostate Ailment
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court, who is 81 years old, said today that he had registered at the Mayo Clinic for evaluation and treatment of ''a longstanding prostate problem,'' and expected to undergo a routine prostate procedure later this week.

title: Johnson & Johnson Sets $500 Million Debt Filing
description: Johnson & Johnson, which has a balance sheet rich in cash and securities and short on long-term debt, took steps yesterday that could lead to its first offering of corporate bonds.

title: EDGCOMB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,007,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for pensions.

title: Reagan Fails the Country
description: Whatever soothing words Ronald Reagan has for Congress and the American people tomorrow, they cannot alter one clear conclusion from the Iran-contra hearings: Mr. Reagan has failed in his responsibilities as President of the United States.

title: New Mellon Executive Rejoins His Ex-Bosses
description: Continuing to recast its top management, the Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that James D. Roy, a senior vice president at Mellon Bank, its principal subsidiary, had resigned and that Steven G. Elliott, formerly executive vice president and chief financial officer of the First Commerce Corporation in New Orleans, would succeed him.

title: HUBERT WELDON LAMB
description: Hubert Weldon Lamb, professor emeritus of music at Wellesley College, died of a heart attack July 27 in Blue Hill (Me.) Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Santa Fe, N.M., and Little Deer Isle, Me.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with a Washington dispatch about contributions to senators from political action committees misstated the party affiiliatiion of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York. He is a Republican.

title: STANDARD HAVENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $1,317,000 on, among other things, the sale of stock by the company's BHA Group Inc. subsidiary. c-Net loss

title: Michigan Bell Plans Financings
description: The Michigan Bell Telephone Company yesterday said it would offer from time to time up to $300 million of debt securities denominated in various currencies, with maturities ranging from 40 days to nine months. Salomon Brothers Inc. and Goldman, Sachs & Company will distribute the securities.

title: Exxon Will Buy Celeron
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the Celeron Corporation, its oil and gas subsidiary, to the Exxon Corporation for $650 million.

title: CHERNOBYL FALLOUT: AID TO CLIMATE STUDY
description: A thin layer of radioactive fallout on the Greenland icecap, a result of the Soviet Union's Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster, will eventually help scientists track global weather patterns, a researcher says.

title: Chasing the Heroin From Plush Hotel to Mean Streets
description: Group 41 of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has been assigned to break up the Chinese Drug rings that transport heroin along ''the China White Trail,'' from the mountains of Thailand to the secret criminal societies of Hong Kong to the quiet Chinese neighborhoods in Queens.

title: SUSPECT IS INDICTED IN SEXUAL ASSAULTS ON QUEENS WOMEN
description: A paroled convict arrested last month in three of the 13 sexual assaults that have frightened women in central Queens was indicted yesterday on charges of having carried out six of the attacks.

title: MICRO DISPLAY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $163,887 for the quarter and $226,887 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Cuomo Signs Bill Declaring Apple Muffin State's Own
description: Bowing to intense public pressure, Governor Cuomo today signed into law a bill declaring the apple muffin New York's official state muffin.

title: Tower Says Hearings Hurt Congress
description: Former Senator John G. Tower, who was chairman of the Presidential commission that investigated the Iran-contra affair, said today that his former colleagues in Congress had sought to enhance their own reputations during three months of public hearings on the issue but instead had damaged Congress itself.

title: AOI COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Science Watch; Data From Comet
description: A scientist analyzing data from the Giotto spacraft that flew by Halley's comet in March 1986 has identified the first polymer to be found in space, according to the Aug. 7 issue of Science magazine.

title: Accounts
description: Movietime Channel to W. B. Doner & Co., Los Angeles.

title: Foote, Cone and Grey Report Higher Profits
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications and Grey Advertising have announced their second-quarter earnings. For Foote, Cone, revenues were $85.4 million, up 3.8 percent from $82.3 million in the period last year. Net income rose 9.6 percent, to $5.7 million, or $1.36 a share, from $5.2 million, or $1.24 a share.

title: SURACUSE GROUP APPEALS FAIRNESS DOCTRINE RULING
description: The Syracuse group whose complaint led to the abandonment of the fairness doctrine by the Federal Communications Commission last week has appealed that decision in an effort to have the doctrine reinstated.

title: ROSE K. LIEBERMAN
description: Rose Kiesler Lieberman, a former editor who was the widow of Dr. Elias Lieberman, an associate superintendent of schools in New York City, died Saturday at her home in South Orange, N.J. She was 93 years old.
