description: b-After a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $87,000 for the quarter and a $345,000 tax credit for the 6 months.

title: UNIVERSAL MEDICAL BUILDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEY RATES
Dingell Has Surgery on Hip
description: Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, underwent successful surgery today at Georgetown University Hospital to replace his left hip, which sustained damage stemming from an old skiing injury. Mr. Dingell, 61 years old, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, is expected to be hospitalized for up to two weeks. He is expected to return to Congress Sept. 6 after the summer recess, his aides said.

title: Eason Signs Contract
description: The New England Patriots signed their No. 1 quarterback yesterday while the Cleveland Browns agreed to terms with their No. 1 draft pick. Tony Eason, who led the Patriots to the 1986 Super Bowl, signed a one-year contract for a reported $875,000 plus incentives that could boost his pay over $1 million. He made $450,000 last year. The Browns reached agreement with their top pick, Mike Junkin, a Duke linebacker.

title: DATASOUTH COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why do some people feel nauseated in moving airplanes, boats or cars? A. Nausea is one sign of motion sickness, a problem many people experience. Other signs include paleness, sweating, dizziness and vomiting.

title: Cowboys' Walker Out
description: Strained ligaments in his right knee will keep Herschel Walker on the sideline for this Saturday's exhibition game against the Chargers in San Diego, and the Cowboys think the running back could be out of action until their first home exhibition game Aug. 30, against the Raiders. Walker's injury was suffered in practice. . . . Dwight Hicks, a four-time Pro Bowl safety, was waived by the Indianapolis Colts. Hicks, released by San Francisco after the 1985 season, start

title: Word From a Happy Client
description: Instead of listening to prominent lawyers talk about the latest developments in family law, one group at the American Bar Association's convention heard today from a very prominent, and frequent, client: Zsa Zsa Gabor.

title: WOMEN OUTNUMBER MEN IN VETRINARY SCHOOLS
description: THE proportion of female applicants to the 27 veterinary schools in the United States has jumped in recent years, owing to a severe decrease in the number of male applicants, according to Dr. John B. Tasker of Michigan State University.

title: Ex-Guerrilla Leader Reported To Plan Return to Nicaragua (uf881) DTL
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the former guerrilla leader, was quoted today as saying he was preparing for a possible return to Nicaragua and was considering entering Nicaraguan politics.

title: Burger King Soda Deal
description: The Burger King Corporation will disclose today whether Coke or Pepsi will be served in its outlets starting next year. Pepsi is expected to win. Pepsi-Cola, a unit of Pepsico Inc., has been supplying soft drinks to Burger King since 1983. Before that, Burger King served Coca-Cola Company products. ''The intensive selection process took place behind closed doors over several months,'' said Charles S. Olcott, president of Burger King U.S.A. ''Both Pepsi and Coke presented excellent plans, and the choice, which we regard as critical to our long-range strategies, has been difficult.'' Coke has 60 percent of the fountain sales market and Pepsi has 26 percent, according to Jesse Meyers, publisher of Beverage Digest.

title: Five Foreigners Indicted In Illegal Export 'Sting'
description: Federal law enforcement officials announced today that a Denver-based ''sting'' operation had resulted in the arrest of four West Germans and an Austrian on charges of illegally exporting technology to Cuba, North Korea and Bulgaria.

title: Reagan Signs Banking Law
description: President Reagan today signed into law legislation to provide $10.8 billion for the savings and loan deposit insurance fund, even though he complained that portions of the comprehensive banking bill were ''anti-competitive and anti-consumer.''

title: BEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the prior year includes a pretax inventory writeoff of $12,500,000. The company also said the latest fourth quarter results were negatively affected by annual physical inventory adjustments of $1,380,000, which reduced net by $663,000 for the quarter.

title: LATIN PEACE PLAN IS SAID TO SET BACK HELP FOR CONTRAS
description: The peace plan signed by five Central American leaders has put the Reagan Administration's plans to win new aid for the Nicaraguan rebels ''on the back burner,'' a White House official said today.

title: KURZWEIL MUSIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Princeton Coach
description: Steven Tosches, offensive coordinator for Princeton University's football team, was named yesterday as interim head coach following the death of Ron Rogerson. The 31-year-old Tosches joined the Princeton staff in 1985 as offensive coordinator and backfield coach. He previously had coached for four years with Rogerson at the University of Maine. Rogerson died at age 44 on Saturday after suffering an apparent heart attack.

title: Doubts on Recess Appointment of Bork
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese in Town
description: A delegation of Japanese trade officials will brief the Reagan Administration this week on progress in tightening up Japan's export control system in the wake of an uproar over the sale of sensitive submarine technology to the Soviet Union by a subsidiary of the Toshiba Corporation. The Japanese Government wants to allay the Administration's concerns and to forestall a ban on Toshiba imports sought by Congress.

title: Investigation Starting In Near Collision of Jets
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has begun an investigation into the near collision Sunday of two jetliners about to land at Kennedy International Airport, aviation officials said yesterday.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $520,000 and $920,000 in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

description: LEAD: The bull market on Wall Street accelerated again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average and broader market indexes surging to record highs.

title: Kansas City Southern Stake
description: A group led by a New York insurance holding company said today that it had acquired 7.9 percent of the common stock of Kansas City Southern Industries and might make a friendly bid for the railroad and financial-services concern.

title: Personal Computers; Remote Control
description: ONE of the pleasures of reviewing is reading the mail it inspires. For example, one reader in Chappaqua, N.Y. wrote to comment on my mention in a review of the Equity II, a PC clone from Epson, that the computer could even be programmed to turn itself on. ''That's a wonderful idea,'' he wrote, but how in the world did I expect to overcome the ''insurmountable problem of programming a computer to do anything'' when it was turned off? He urged me to reveal my secret for ''this feat of magic.''

title: ENDEVCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TWO MISSILES MISS
description: A United States Navy fighter plane fired two missiles at an Iranian plane above the Persian Gulf over the weekend, but the Iranian aircraft was not hit, Reagan Administration officials said tonight.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,883,000 for the quarter and $3,492,000 for the 6 months, and a loss on disposal of $8,054,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,911,000 and $2,874,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

A Night With Young Conservatives
description: On a sticky evening in July, 80 young adults gathered at a conservative research organization here to discuss the topic of the day - individual freedom and the political process.

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Notes on Fashion
description: THIS is it. Time to shop for fall clothes. It's a task that separates lovers of fashion from the rest of the world. Women who follow fashion are combing the racks in search of short skirts and fitted jackets so they can face the coming season in the newest styles. In fact, these eager beavers have been snapping up short skirts as quickly as they reach the stores, causing a shortage of such popular styles as Calvin Klein's bird's-eye tweed suit (jacket, $560; slim skirt, $180).

title: Athens Car Bomb Wounds 9 U.S. Airmen on Bus
description: Nine American airmen and their Greek driver were slightly wounded this afternoon when a car bomb exploded next to their bus near an American air base here, the United States Embassy announced.

title: SQUARE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $1,476,000 on the sale of a parking facility.

title: Allegheny Stake
description: David H. Murdock, chairman of Castle & Cook Inc., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he held a 7.3 percent stake in Allegheny International Inc. Mr. Murdock said he holds 140,550 shares of Allegheny's Series C convertible preferred shares, according to the filing. An Allegheny spokesman declined comment on Mr. Murdock's purchase. Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis financier recently disclosed that he and, Carl Pohlad, owner of the Minnesota Twins, held 7.9 percent of Allegheny's common stock.

title: 'CHORUS LINE' NO. 5001 IS NOTED, WITH EMOTION
description: Sometime around November 1999, this may all happen again. If the fates agree, ''A Chorus Line'' - the seemingly immortal musical that celebrated its 5,001st performance last night - would then become the first Broadway production to have been performed 10,000 times.

title: Going Out Guide; Dwyer in Concert
description: Doriot Anthony Dwyer is first chair flutist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and the doyenne of female flute players in major symphonies. She came to the Boston Symphony in October 1952, after her appointment as its principal flutist - making her the first woman to hold a principal chair with a major symphony orchestra. In a New York Times review, she was acclaimed for ''a flexible technique, a bright tone and a musical personality'' highly suited to ensembles. This afternoon, accompanied by Stephen Swedish, a pianist, Ms. Dwyer is to perform works by Telemann, Faure, Prokofiev and Virgil Thomson in a recital at Trinity Church, 74 Trinity Place, at 12:45 P.M. Admission is free. For information: 602-0768. Sign of a New Season The Washington Square Music Festival Orchestra will present tonight the grand finale of its 30th season, with works by several Latin-American composers - Heitor Villa-Lobos of Brazil, Ricardo Lorenz Abreu of Venezuela, Jose Serebrier of Chile, Roque Cordero of Panama and Silvestre Revueltas of Mexico. Tania Leon, who was born and educated in Havana, is to conduct the 25-member orchestra. A composer and a professor at Brooklyn College, Ms. Leon is also part of a class whose ranks are scarce: female conductors. Today's free program begins at 8 P.M., near the statue of Garibaldi in Washington Square Park. Rain moves the event into the N.Y.U. Loeb Student Center at 566 La Guardia Place. Information: 431-1088.

description: HOPING to participate in a historic turning of the tide in human affairs - or at least in an unusual communal experience - people from coast to coast are planning to watch the sunrise Sunday from sites of great scenic beauty or religious significance.

title: Debt
description: * Mitsui Trust and Banking Co. is offering $50 million of 8.65 percent deposit notes due 1990, priced at par to yield 70 basis points more than comparable Treasury securities, through E. F. Hutton & Co. Noncallable for two years, the issue is rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Sims Takes Geography
description: Robert B. Sims, the top Pentagon spokesman, announced yesterday that he was leaving the Defense Department to become vice president for communications at the National Geographic Society. Instead of fielding endless questions about Iranian mines, the re-registering of Kuwaiti oil tankers and the dispatching of Navy ships to the Persian Gulf, come Sept. 21 Mr. Sims will help promote a 10-year program to improve the public's understanding of geography.

title: POTENT TOOL FASHIONED TO PROBE INHERITED ILLS
description: SCIENTISTS are filling in the last major blanks in a map of chemical signposts to the entire human system of genes, an accomplishment that should have revolutionary effects on understanding the heredity of disease.

title: Advanced Micro
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. introduced its own version of the Intel Corporation's 80286 microprocessor, which the company said is 28 percent faster than other versions of the chip. Advanced Micro said its device can be used in machines compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC-AT personal computers. The device is to be in full production during the fourth quarter.

description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $79,300 and $56,700 for the quarte and 6 months, respectively. The company completed the acquisition of Micro Plus, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Philadelphia House Yields More Dead
description: A green duffel bag filled with what the police said appeared to be human bones was found today on the roof of a dilapidated row house a day after six bodies were discovered in an apartment on the third floor.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES RESEARCH CENTERS ON CROPS
description: The Reagan Administration, fulfilling a commitment made by the President in his State of the Union Message in January, has completed a plan for a network of research centers for developing less expensive farming techniques and discovering new varieties of crops.

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: The company said year-ago quarter results include $2,116,000 in revenue from lasercard optical memory card equipment licenses and engineering fees.

title: PARKER HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Idealism Grows Older
description: In the years after its creation in 1961, the Peace Corps seemed to capture the best of youthful idealism. A quarter-century later, it demonstrates the value of idealism backed up with skills and life experience. These days the typical Peace Corps volunteer is less likely to be a 22-year-old altruist English major, more likely to be a 55-year-old agricultural scientist who does welding on the side. When Loret Ruppe took over the agency in 1981, 3 percent of the volunteers were over the age of 50; now 11 percent are.

title: State Passes Bill for Boeing
description: State lawmakers, meeting in emergency session, overwhelmingly approved antitakeover legislation today to help the Boeing Company fend off unwanted suitors such as T. Boone Pickens.

title: Ohio Awaits Honda's Plans
description: The Honda Motor Company was reported today to be close to approving construction of a $500 million assembly plant in Ohio to make cars for its Acura division. But a spokesman for Honda said no final decision had been made.

title: Solidarity With the Black Miners
description: In a sense, much that has been happening in South Africa has been merely preliminary. The strike of black miners against the nation's gold and coal producers is the main event. Black unions like the mine workers, acting lawfully, offer the best remaining hope for a peaceful transition to democracy. It is in the interest of South Africans, black and white, that the miners succeed. It is in the interest of the United States and the West to help them in any way possible.

title: Japan's Global Surplus Down
description: Japan's trade surplus with the United States rose 6 percent in July from a year earlier even though its global trade surplus fell almost 15 percent, the Government said today.

title: Pipelines Backed in Gas Sale Dispute
description: A Federal agency has granted natural gas pipeline companies some pricing relief.

title: Restaurant Merger
description: Keg Restaurants Ltd., a steak and seafood chain, said today that it had agreed to merge with a subsidiary of the British brewer Whitbread & Company in a deal worth $10.2 million (United States).

title: JOSEPH H. ARONSON
description: Joseph H. Aronson, a rabbinical scholar who served as a vice president of the Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada in the 1940's and 50's, died of a stroke Saturday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 96 years old and lived in Monsey, N.Y.

title: Conservatives Try a TV Hard Sell for Contras
description: Encouraged by the public reaction to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and hoping to recover from the negative effects of the Iran-contra hearings, a conservative organization has been running a $250,000 television advertising campaign extolling the anti-Sandinista movement.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 11, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

BORK QUIT AN ALL-MALE CLUB AFTER DISPUTE OVER SEX BIAS
description: Judge Robert H. Bork, the President's nominee for the Supreme Court, resigned from an all-male club in New York City in 1985 after a dispute arose over whether the club was practicing sex discrimination, according to a questionnaire made public today.

title: PILGRIM'S PRIDE reports earnings for 13wks to July 4
COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $37,000. c-After a loss of $260,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Hollywood Intrigue About Paper's Fate
description: The Hollywood Reporter, a leading Hollywood trade publication, appears to be up for sale, media industry executives say. Several sources said they had been approached by a Los Angeles media broker, Norton J. Lehman, who recently handled the sales of both Broadcasting, a trade maagazine, and Variety, the trade paper, about a possible sale.

title: SOVIET ORBITS GIANT RADAR FOR STUDY OF RESOURCES
description: THE Soviet Union has launched a huge radar satellite for ''remote sensing'' of the earth's surface that is far larger and more ambitious than any lofted by the West. The launching has stirred debate among American scientists and Congressional leaders over whether the United States, which plans to loft a similar system a decade from now, is losing its edge in the development of new technologies for use in space.

title: Baseball; Gross Ejected, But Phils Survive
description: Lance Parrish and Von Hayes hit home runs tonight as Philadelphia defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4-2, after Kevin Gross, the Phillies' starter, was ejected for allegedly tampering with the baseball.

title: Need for Translators Is a Costly Burden For Judicial System
description: With two juries and a welter of conflicting evidence, the capital murder trial here of Hau Cheong Chan and Sang Nam Chinh would be complicated enough even if Mr. Chinh could understand English. But all through the long trial, a translator has relayed the proceedings to the 21-year-old Chinese man by whispering into his right ear in Cantonese.

title: Rookie Savoring It One Play at a Time
description: The occasion was one of those controlled scrimmages with 50 plays a side, the Jets against the Washington Redskins last Saturday on Fisher Field at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa. Hardly memorable for most players, but for Walter Briggs, it was special.

title: Iacocca Tells Lawyers Suits Threaten Business
description: Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, told lawyers here today that Americans' propensity to file lawsuits had made businesses reluctant to take risks, threatening the nation's competitiveness.

title: KNAPE & VOGT MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Both latest periods include the results of Roll-It Inc., acquired in January.

title: Longest-Running Movie House in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $2,318,000 and $3,707,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $792,000 for the quarter and $1,175,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes investment gains of $2,675,000 for the quarter and $8,369,000 for the 6 months.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $193,307,000 on the sale of Canadian Pacific Airlines Ltd. and the sale of a building. c-Net loss and after a writedown of assets of $362,523,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Iona Loses Two
description: Jonathan Duck, from Our Savior Lutheran High School in the Bronx, and Gerald McClease, from Wilbur Cross of New Haven, will be lost to Iona for next season for failing to meet N.C.A.A. academic requirements for freshman recruits. ''If there is one positive thing that comes out of this situation,'' said Gary Brokaw, Iona's coach, ''it is that both Jonathan and Gerald will be allowed to concentrate solely on their studies without having to worry about basketball.''

title: Test of Worker-Owners Is Ending on Sour Notes
description: After a six-year struggle to save Hyatt Clark Industries, an effort that was one of the most important experiments in employee ownership in the nation, the company is dying a slow, painful death. And the costs of the funeral are rising.

title: SIPPICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOR THE WATER AND AFTER, NEW LOOKS IN SWIMSUITS
description: Swimsuit fashion is not for swimming only. Once there were two basic styles for the water: bikini and maillot. Skirted suits with support tops were for women who were beyond fashion.

title: VANDERBILT GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $1,308,000 in restructuring costs from mergers completed in the first quarter. c-Net income

title: After Tough Steps, Quinones Is on the Spot
description: Twice in the last week, Nathan Quinones, New York City's Schools Chancellor, has acted with uncharacteristic forcefulness, dismissing the head of the high school division and closing a junior high school in the Bronx after a year of probation for underachievement.

title: Lear Unit Acquires Broadcast Publications
description: Norman Lear's Act III Communications, a Los Angeles-based media and entertainment company, has acquired the assets of Broadbank Information Services, which publishes Broadcast Management/Engineering, World Broadcast News and Educational and Industrial Television in New York.

title: M-I SCHOTTENSTEIN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results are pro forma and reflect the results of three affiliates acquired last year as if they had been taxed at a 50 percent rate before their acquisition.

title: FOR U.S., A STROKE OF RYDER CUP LUCK
description: Larry Nelson, the quiet 39-year-old Georgian, is not anybody to tangle with when his golf game is right and the tournament gets down to match play.

title: QUARTZ BLADE OFFERS INSIGHT ON PACIFIC TRIBES
description: The discovery last month of a delicate quartz crystal cutting tool, 2,800 years old, has led some archeologists to conclude that Pacific coast Indians were more technologically advanced than previously thought.

title: Careers; INDUSTRY'S NEW FOCUS ON ETHICS
description: ETHICS is drawing new attention.

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INSIDE
description: Taking On the Heroin Trade

title: THE ENERGY OF YOUTH REVIVES A BRONX PARK
description: The youngsters are in it for the money, they say. But the community is also rewarded, residents say. With the help of teen-agers from the Parks Council's work-study program, St. Mary's Park in the South Bronx has been transformed from a bleak, isolated drug hangout into an animated, welcoming place.

title: Chilean Unlikely To Receive a Visa
description: The State Department is expected to announce its decision Tuesday on a visa request by a member of Chile's team at the Pan American Games. Based on information that the athlete has been involved in ''multiple cases'' of murder, torture and public beatings in Chile, the request is likely to be denied, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Chapter 11 Filing
description: American Healthcare Management Inc. said that it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The hospital company said last week that it would take the action if it did not reach an agreement with its banks on rescheduling repayment of $233 million or at least extending the deadline for repayment, which was last Friday. The company said the filing would not affect the 32 hospitals operated by its subsidiaries because they are not obligated for the parent's debt.

title: Chess; Short, an Interzonal Winner, Reveals a Powerful Gambit
description: The first Interzonal Tournament, in Subotica, Yugoslavia, has ended in a tie for first place among Nigel Short and Jonathan Speelman of Britain and Gyula Sax of Hungary.

title: On a Remembered Street
description: The street is called Knox Place and it is one block long, in a corner of the northwest Bronx. Two men are walking on it. David McKenzie is 32 years old and lives here with his young family. And I lived in the small apartment house near the corner, before he was born.

title: CHARTWELL GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $10,000 for the quarter and a loss of $3,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and tax credits of $248,000 for the quarter and $412,00 for the 6 months.

title: Gold Sales By Lebanon
description: Acting Prime Minister Salim Hoss today proposed selling 20 percent of Lebanon's gold reserves to calm the nation's worst financial crisis since civil war broke out in 1975.

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $1,133,000 for the quarter and $1,917,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-After capital gains of $982,000 for the quarter and $1,475,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago periods' amounts are restated to include Loyal American Life Insurance Co. as a combination of previously separate entities under common control.

title: TRANSTECH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rev. G.P. Musselman; Wrote Self-Help Books
description: The Rev. G. Paul Musselman, an Episcopal clergyman who was co-author of ''The Twelve Step Recovery Program of Alcoholics Anonymous,'' died Friday at his home in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: Home of Napoleon, Idyllic Days and Quick Death
description: It has been a gorgeous summer on Corsica, and the sun has smiled down from sapphire skies on beach-goers and wind-surfers skimming over the Mediterranean's breeze-tufted waters. But it has also been a deadly summer.

title: Borland Software
description: Borland International Inc., a personal-computer software company based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said it would offer a spread-sheet program for the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer and compatible machines. The company said its new Quattro program is compatible with the industry standard Lotus 1-2-3, but has superior graphics and faster speed on certain operations. Though no official price has been released, Borland's president and chief executive, Philippe Kahn, has said that Quattro would retail for less than $200.

title: Louganis Springs To Third Gold
description: Greg Louganis became the first three-time winner of a diving event at the Pan American Games with a victory in the three-meter springboard competition tonight.

title: INTERNATIONAL HOLDING CAPIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ELXSI LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $540,000 non-recurring gain from the sale of assets. c-Net loss The company said the year-ago quarter results include a non-recurring charge of $6 million related to the purchase of technology rights from a research and development partnership.

title: The Mayor at 62, 28 and 40
description: In reacting to the warning signal from deep inside that he received last week, New York's Mayor, Edward Koch, displayed a jauntiness of spirit that evokes admiration. It also evokes a word of advice.

title: Doctor Dies in Plane Cash
description: A 48-year-old doctor from Philadelphia was killed today when the small airplane he was piloting crashed into a bay here, the police said. The doctor, Samuel Kasden, who has a home in Margate, was pronounced dead at the scene shortly after the plane went down about 9 A.M., said Tammy Soltes, a Marine Police operator. Dr. Kasden was alone on the twin-engine Piper Aerostar plane, she said. Ed Goddard, manager of Bader Field, said Dr. Kasden left from the small airport at 8:55 A.M. for Philadelphia. The crash occurred 200 yards south of the Atlantic City Expressway in the resort's back bay, said Seaman Richard Huber of the Coast Guard. The cause of the crash is under investigation.

title: Serious Contender On Offensive Line
description: Coach Bill Parcells had an acid appraisal today for his offensive linemen. It concerned their performance in last Saturday's 125-play controlled scrimmage.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $101,400 for the quarter and $215,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $204,000 for the quarter and $269,000 for the 6 months.

title: LEON KEYSERLING, ECONOMIC AIDE TO TRUMAN, DIES
description: Leon H. Keyserling, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Harry S. Truman and a longtime proponent of full employment, died Sunday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 79 years old and lived in Washington.

title: CAST OF 10,000 AT EDINBURGH FESTIVAL
description: The Edinburgh International Festival, the world's largest cultural extravaganza, has opened its 41st season with thousands of performers, a huge Soviet contingent and too little cash.

title: Giant European Merger To Create Rival to G.E.
description: ASEA A.B. of Sweden and BBC Brown Boveri of Switzerland announced a merger today that analysts said was the most signficant development in the electrical equipment industry in years.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Six Israelis Wounded At Outpost in Lebanon
description: Six Israeli soldiers were wounded in southern Lebanon today when their position in the security zone declared by Israel came under mortar fire.

title: Kemp's Lucky Number
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, a contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, has been known to refer gleefully to the 1988 Democratic field as ''The Seven Dwarfs,'' unarguable numerically if not with respect to stature. Presenting a political contrast, the upstate New Yorker has now designated a group of fellow Congressmen, all Republicans and all supporters of his 1988 campaign, as ''The Magnificent Seven.''

title: Tension Grows On Rikers I., Inmates Warn
description: Jail administrators and inmates say tensions are mounting among the most dangerous group of prisoners on Rikers Island -those who have been sentenced to state prisons but who have not been sent there because state authorities say their own prisons are overcrowded.

title: Action and Distractions for Cubans at Games
description: Leaflets, fistfights and an airplane trailing a banner have stolen attention from athletes at the 10th Pan American Games and angered Cubans who are more interested in medals than meddlers.

title: Hanoi Says It Keeps No Live Americans Missing in the War
description: A Presidential envoy who visited Hanoi last week said today that Vietnam insisted it did not have control over any living Americans missing in action from the war.

title: G.O.P. COMMITTEE LOSES ITS LUSTER
description: For nearly a decade, the National Republican Senatorial Committee was one of Washington's premier political success stories. A series of vigorous and ambitious chairmen hired bright young professionals who raised unparalleled amounts of campaign money, recruited promising candidates and provided them with expert political services.

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax loss of $10,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $81,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-Includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $3,499,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and tax credits of $304,000 and $389,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago loss on disposal of discontinued operations is the cost related to settlement of indemnification liability.

title: Two Soviet Editors Clash on Glasnost
description: Sergei I. Grigoryants is a veteran of the prison camps and an unofficial journalist who has set out to test the limits of glasnost by openly publishing a magazine free of state control in the Soviet Union.

title: Ill Served by Our Primary System
description: To the Editor:

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Air of Resignation
description: New York air travelers used to brandish their impatience with a perverse pride, but a native who flew out of the city recently found reason to believe they are losing their edge. Stuck on a runway at La Guardia, she was puzzled by the docility of fellow non-travelers during the seemingly endless delay.

title: AFTER ACCIDENT ON A BRIDGE, A MOTORIST OPEN FIRE
description: A 32-year-old motorist with a history of mental illness, apparently angered by a minor traffic accident on the Triborough Bridge, opened fire with a .44 magnum rifle yesterday and discharged at least nine shots into the ground and air before surrendering calmly minutes later, the police said.

title: France Refuses to Back Chad Offensive
description: France distanced itself today from the Chadian Government's campaign to retake a disputed border area from Libya. It called instead for the matter to be submitted to international arbitration.

title: DR. STUART STEVENSON
description: Dr. Stuart Shelton Stevenson, retired director of pediatrics at St. Luke's Hospital and a former professor of pediatrics at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, died on July 28 of cancer. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: McLain Release Sought
description: If the Federal Government waives a bond hearing, Denny McLain, whose conviction was overturned on Friday, could be released from the Federal Correctional Institute at Talladega, Ala., in five to seven days, said Arnold Levine, his attorney. McLain, who is 43 years old, has served 28 months of a 23-year prison term for racketeering, extortion, conspiracy and possession of cocaine with intent to distribute. Levine filed a motion in Federal District Court in Tampa, Fla., yesterday seeking release of the former Detroit Tigers star, the last man to win 30 games in the major leagues. If the government does not agree to waive the bond hearing, it may take up to 30 days to get McLain out of prison, Levine said. In throwing out the conviction, a Federal appeals court cited improper conduct by both the judge and prosecutor during the trial. The government could appeal to the United States Supreme Court, move for dismissal of the charges or ask for a new trial.

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW RAIDS BY IRAQ
description: Iraq broke a 25-day lull in the Persian Gulf war with air strikes on Iranian oil installations today, increasing the possibility of Iranian retaliation against shipping in the region.

title: SYSTEM INTEGRATORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books of the Times
description: CLOAK & GOWN. Scholars in the Secret War, 1939-1961. By Robin W. Winks. 607 pages. Illustrated. William Morrow. $22.95. THE 10 men who helped to found and build up the Central Intelligence Agency had strong links with academia - with a handful of Ivy League colleges in particular, and above all with Yale. It seems only appropriate that the grounds of the agency headquarters in Langley, Va., should be known to those who frequent them as ''the campus,'' and that in front of the main building there should stand a replica of the statue at New Haven commemorating Nathan Hale, ''the first American spy'' (as he has often been called) and a member of the Yale class of 1773.

title: TV Reviews; 'BREAKING SILENCE,' EFFECTS OF SEX ABUSE ON CHILDREN
description: ''BREAKING SILENCE'' is not so much about incest as it is about the pain suffered by its victims. In this sensitively done documentary, they speak. ''Breaking Silence,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is not trivial; it is a moving piece of work.

title: ARNOLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHOENIX MEDICAL TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Schools Are Falling
description: To the Editor:

title: UNDERSEA QUEST FOR GIANT SQUIDS AND RARE SHARKS
description: ABOARD THE TWIN DRILL OFF BERMUDA - Inside the small submarine, the thick steel wall against the outside felt cool and moist. The oxygen blower hummed reassuringly. The tracking pinger's signals to the surface, heard inside as a steady throbbing, brought to mind the thumping heartbeat of a great whale. Pisces VI was descending to the bottom of the sea.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everybody in the gulf must know that this is a lake shared by all, and it will bring wealth or disaster to all.'' - Tariq Almoayed, Bahrain's Minister of Information. (A8:1.)

title: Lauren's Quiet wy sport closes
description: After three and a half months away from Seventh Avenue, Ralph Lauren returned yesterday, looking tanned and fit, to deliver commentaries at a series of small showings of his resort collection. Recovered from surgery for a brain tumor, he said he had organized the presentations so that people could ask him questions and see that he was well again.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $361,000.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
American Joins Air-Fare Rise
description: American Airlines became the latest air carrier to match some of the fare increases and ticket restrictions announced by Continental Airlines, whereas Delta Airlines said it would match the ticket restrictions. Delta has not yet decided about the fare increases.

title: Apple to Introduce Unusual Software
description: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce an unusual database and management information program Tuesday that the company hopes will help it maintain its lead in technology for making computers easy to use.

title: The Latin Peace Plan According to Wright
description: The sudden appearance of an accord under which five Central American countries are to try to bring peace to the strife-ridden region seemed to burst from nowhere. But according to Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Latin-sponsored peace plan was in considerable part the product of efforts he quietly started months ago that were brought to fruition by intense negotiations over the last 10 days.

title: BROOKLYN JUDGE CLEARS BURNING OF BARGE TRASH
description: New York City can proceed with its plan to burn the 3,100 tons of garbage aboard the barge Mobro, anchored in New York Harbor, a State Supreme Court judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

title: ALLIED RESEARCH ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago 6-month results reflect income of $1,619,922, or 75 cents a share, from the sale of a portion of the company's loss reserves on discontinued lines of Reinsurnace.

title: STAGE: 'NIGHT OF THE IGUANA' REVIVAL
description: In its earliest form in 1948, ''The Night of the Iguana'' was a short story about Hannah Jelkes (at this point her first name was Edith), a spinster temporarily sequestered in the Costa Verde, a bohemian hotel in Mexico. Years later, when Tennessee Williams re-created the story as a play, Miss Jelkes was joined at the Costa Verde by the characters of Shannon, the defrocked preacher; Maxine Faulk, the earthy hotel owner, and Nonno, the spinster's aged poet-grandfather.

title: IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
The Lure of Investing Abroad
description: While the United States stock market has been breaking record after record, markets overseas have attracted American investors seeking even better gains.

title: Slain Man's Bodyguard Was Absent
description: The bodyguard of a man gunned down execution-style in an Upper East Side restaurant Saturday night did not accompany the victim to the restaurant, a police official close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: An International Chapter 11
description: LEAD: With their large-scale loan-loss provisions last spring, the United States' big international banks finally began to acknowledge the third world debt crisis for what it really is: a long-term dilemma of economic solvency, not just a short-term liquidity squeeze. But banks remain reluctant to take the next logical step: debt relief.

title: Moody's Rates Life Insurers
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had started a new rating service for North American life insurance companies and the guaranteed investment contracts they provide. As part of the new service, Moody's announced ratings for 16 life insurance companies in addition to the six it had already rated. Nine of the 22 companies are rated triple-A, five are rated Aa-1, six are Aa-2 and two are A-3.

title: ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REDEFINING PRIME TIME: IT'S ALL IN WHO YOU ASK
description: Exactly what time constitutes prime time nowadays seems to depend upon which channel you watch. Traditionally, the term has defined the period between 8 and 11 P.M., but the times are changing.

title: NAVY REVERTING TO STEEL IN SHIPBUILDING AFTER CRACKS IN ALUMINUM
description: The Navy, reversing a trend that began after World War II, is going back to building ships with steel rather than aluminum superstructures, in part because the lighter metal was found to crack, officers say.

title: Ex-Armco Chief Is Chosen to Fill Commerce Post
description: President Reagan today named C. William Verity Jr., retired chairman of the steelmaker Armco Inc. and a strong advocate of expanded trade with the Soviet Union, as his choice to head the Commerce Department.

title: BACKSTAGE WITH STARS OF MUSIC
description: For the fifth summer, Mostly Mozart mavens are making personal contact with creativity at ''Meet the Artist Suppers,'' a genteel pre-concert alternative to stage-door mob scenes.

title: ADDENDUM
description: Golf Magazine will increase its rate base almost 6 percent, to 900,000, from 850,000, in October.

title: Bridge; The Prudential Team Adds A New Title to Its Collection
description: For domination of an annual event over a long period in any sport or recreation, it would be hard to match the record of the Prudential Insurance Company in Roseland, N.J. With a strong finish to the season, its bridge team recently won its 31st victory in 54 years in the Commercial Bridge League of Northern New Jersey.

title: Advertising; CONDE NAST MAGAZINE ON TRAVEL
description: CONDE Nast will make its first foray into the travel magazine business on Sept. 1, betting that there is an unoccupied niche.

title: One Wrong Turn, And Secret Is Out
description: Lady's Secret wants to go home.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid next month.

title: U.S. Envoy Talks With Shamir About Mideast Peace Parley
description: A United States envoy, Charles Hill, met for two hours today with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and discussed a proposed conference on Middle East peace, an Israeli official said.

title: A Partisan Economic Appraisal
description: The Joint Economic Committee of Congress reaffirmed today that economics is far from a nonpartisan science.

title: Third Doctor Is Charged in Death
description: The physician who admitted a young woman to New York Hospital three years ago has been charged by the state health authorities with gross negligence and unprofessional conduct in her death at the hospital.

title: U.S. Fights Court Bid By A.T.&T.
description: The Justice Department yesterday asked a Federal court in Washington to deny a motion by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that could prevent the Martin Marietta Corporation from competing for a multibillion-dollar Government telephone contract.

title: Citicorp to Convert Choice Card to Visa
description: After nearly 10 years of marketing its Choice credit card, Citicorp said yesterday it would convert it to Visa.

title: Platinum Up Strongly; Oil Price Slide Steepens
description: A strong platinum market helped gold and silver prices yesterday to recover some of their steep losses of Friday. But the decline in crude oil prices steepened, despite news that another tanker had struck a mine in the Persian Gulf.

title: Market Place; A Busy Sector: Office Supplies
description: THE computer's failure to bring about the much-promised paperless office and the strength of the national economy's service sector are proving a boon to companies that make paper, staples and other office supplies.

title: Yoel Levi to Be Director Of Atlanta Symphony
description: Yoel Levi, the 36-year-old former assistant conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, is to be named the new music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra today, officials of the orchestra said yesterday.

title: Father in Texas Ends Search For Son After Bus Accident
description: John Bankston Sr. has searched for three weeks for his son's body along the Guadalupe River, and he has now finally admitted there is no point in continuing.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Wallace Wins at Watkins Glen: Even a last-lap stop for gas could not keep Rusty Wallace from winning the rain-delayed Budweiser at the Glen stock-car race yesterday at Watkins Glen, N.Y. He took the white flag, which signifies the start of the last lap, just as his Pontiac sputtered into the pit. After taking on a gallon of gas, Wallace roared back onto the track in time to take the checkered flag 11.5 seconds ahead of Terry Labonte in a Chevrolet. The 219-mile event was rained out Sunday. Track and Field Canadians Win in 100 Meters: Two Canadian sprinters, Ben Johnson and Angela Issajenko, were impressive winners in the 100 meters and Edwin Moses cruised to a easy victory in the 400 hurdles yesterday at the international meet in Malmo, Sweden. Johnson captured the men's dash in 10.05 seconds. Issajenko won the women's event in 11.17. Moses won his event in 48.36 seconds. (AP) Cycling Pierce Retains Overall Lead: Paolo Rosola of Italy won yesterday's stage of the Coors International Bicycle Classic, but Jeff Pierce of the United States held onto the overall lead by 2 minutes 25 seconds. Rosola finished 45 grueling laps at Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco in 1 hour 29 minutes and 32 seconds. Pierce finished 15th yesterday. (AP) Tennis McEnroe-Lendl Stopped Again: The first match between Ivan Lendl and John McEnroe in two years was washed out again yesterday as a second straight day of rain put off the final of the Volvo International in Stratton Mountain, Vt. Jim Westhall, the tournament director, said officials would try to work out a way to complete the final at a later date. Lendl and McEnroe were scheduled to play today in the Canadian Open in Montreal. On Sunday, McEnroe won the first set, 7-6, but Lendl was ahead, 4-1, in the second set when a drizzle halted play.(AP)

title: A Short Silence By Steinbrenner
description: The quarreling that emerged last week between George Steinbrenner and Lou Piniella apparently is not finished.

title: F.E. Newbold Jr. Dies; An Aviation Executive
description: F. E. Newbold Jr., a former executive of Rolls-Royce Inc. who was deeply involved in the development of the company's vertical-takeoff Harrier jet, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Washington. He was 69 years old.

title: Mustang Now a Lion
description: John Robinson, a reserve linebacker left without a team when the National Collegiate Athletic Association imposed a ban on Southern Methodist University football, expects to be a starting defensive end for Columbia come September. The 6-foot-3-inch, 235-pound Robinson, from Highlands, Tex., said yesterday he was transferring to Columbia, the school with the longest current football losing streak. The Lions have not won in their last 34 games dating back to Oct. 15, 1983, and have lost 31 straight. When S.M.U. was deprived of football this season because of violations of N.C.A.A. rules, all players transferring got immediate eligibility at their new schools.

title: Kennedy Boat Runs Aground
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy safely piloted 50-foot yacht to shore early today, two hours after the schooner ran aground off Cape Cod in a heavy rain and began taking on water, the Coast Guard said. Mr. Kennedy called the Coast Guard for help at 11:26 P.M. Sunday, but searchers could not immediately find the yacht, a Coast Guard official said. In the meantime, the Senator had freed the yacht and sailed to Green Pound harbor in Falmouth. Seven other people were aboard the boat.

title: About Education; PUBLIC TV TRIES TO REACH TEEN-AGERS
description: PUBLIC television is getting ready for a daring and significant test: Can teen-agers be won over to entertainment that is not mindless, violent or sexually irresponsible? The new 26 half-hour series, ''Degrassi Junior High,'' will have its debut next month. It is an attempt to do for adolescents what ''Sesame Street'' did for children.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $761,000 due to termination of the company's pension plan.

title: Tough Tiger
description: For a president of tormented Lebanon to die a natural death sounds almost like a sick joke. Yet Camille Chamoun, known to his Lebanese followers as ''the tiger,'' was 87 when he died peacefully the other day, notwithstanding four assassination attempts.

title: KIMMINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $194,000 for the quarter and $358,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $113,000. The share earnings adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February.

title: Japanese Profit Outlook
description: Two surveys of Japanese corporate profits have been revised upward. The Wako Research Institute of Economics, an affiliate of the Wako Securities Company, said today that net income would decline an average 6.7 percent in the year ending next March 31, less than the 13.5 percent drop it forecast in June. The Nomura Research Institute revised its projection of pretax profit growth for 100 big Japanese companies to 13.6 percent in the year ending next March 31 from the 8.5 percent it forecast in June.

title: ROLLINS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last September and a 3-for-2 stock split paid last month.

title: Tax Watch; Mortgage Shift And 'Kiddies'
description: TAX lawyers attending the American Bar Association's annual convention here have found the restaurants splendid, the scenery breathtaking and the pronouncements by Washington tax officials exasperating. At seminars over the weekend with Treasury and Internal Revenue Service officials, the lawyers learned of more disturbing wrinkles in the new tax law.

title: Long-Married Couples Do Look Alike, Study Finds
description: SCIENCE is lending support to the old belief that married couples eventually begin to look alike.

title: Oil-Rig Count Climbs
description: The number of American oil rigs rose by 10 last week, to 983, up sharply from 734 at the same time last year, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The rig count, considered an important indicator of the health of the oil industry, has been rising in the last year along with crude oil prices.

title: Martin Marietta
description: The International Telecommunications Satellite Organization signed a contract for the launching of two satellites aboard the Martin Marietta Corporation's commercial Titan rockets. The contract, worth $220 million, marks the first commercial communications satellite launching to be approved for license by the Department of Transportation. The two Intelsat VI satellites are to be launched in 1989 and 1990 from Kennedy Space Center, under the contract. Intelsat is an international commercial cooperative of 114 member nations that operates a communications satellite system.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared June 17, 1987, for shareholders of record July 2, 1987. Latest quarter consists of 13 weeks, and the 6 months, 26 weeks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, AUGUST 11, 1987
description: International A2-8, A10

title: New Era for Electric Utilities: Residential Rates Might Rise
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company recently learned it was losing its biggest customer. The Chevron refinery in Richmond, Calif., decided to save money by generating its own electricity.

title: MEDICAL CARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $472,000 for the quarter and $790,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $239,000 for the quarter and $392,000 for the 6 months.

title: Science Watch; Magnetism Mystery
description: The changing intensity of the earth's magnetic field over the last 6,000 years was more complex than previously believed, according to a study of 70 samples of ancient Chinese pottery from a variety of provinces and dynasties.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 11, 1987
description: Markets

title: PEOPLE
description: * Gary Watson has been appointed senior vice president and creative director at Poppe Tyson, Union, N.J.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $713,000 for the quarter and $744,000 for the 6 months.

title: INDIANA SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in February.

title: A YOUNG COMPANY GUIDES RAP MUSIC INTO THE MAINSTREAM
description: When Russell Simmons talks about the explosive popularity of rap music across America, the one theme he comes back to again and again is image.

title: RESOURCE ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: Chris Bosio, a pitcher with the Milwaukee Brewers, was charged yesterday with assault and battery after being accused of breaking an attendant's nose in a fight July 19 in a downtown Milwaukee parking lot. . . . Mickey Marvin, who has started all but one game at right guard for the Los Angeles Raiders in the last two years, suffered a knee injury and will be lost indefinitely, pending tests by team doctors. Marvin, 31 years old, has played 10 seasons with the Raiders since becoming a fourth-round draft choice out of Tennessee in 1977. . . . Steve Fuller, one of the Chicago Bears quarterbacks, has decided to undergo shoulder surgery, according to Coach Mike Ditka. Fuller, who started two games last year, is expected to miss the entire season. Fuller, 30, tore loose scar tissue in his right shoulder while lifting weights July 27. . . . Clark Kellogg, the Indiana Pacer forward, has decided to retire after being plagued by ailing knees that have sidelined him for most of the last two seasons, The Columbus (Ohio) Dispatch reported.

title: S.E.C. Investigates Harcourt Offering
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an inquiry into the company's $3 billion recapitalization plan. Under that plan, Harcourt offered its stockholders $40 a share and a share of new preferred stock in return for each share of common they held. The offer was designed to ward off a $44-a-share hostile takeover by the British publisher Robert Maxwell.

title: Advertising; Publishing Expansion By Act III
description: WHEN Norman Lear, the television producer and former head of Embassy Communications, decided to build Act III Communications, a diversified media operation, he was less preoccupied with the publishing arm than with his television and movie production division. After all, Act III's first feature, ''Stand by Me'' was a hit, and, as the creator of such programs as ''All in The Family,'' Mr. Lear's track record in television programming is unique.

title: MAGMA COPPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $9,834,000 from pension plan revision. c-Net loss Magma said that during the latest second quarter it received $21 million from the liquidation of surplus balances in Magma's pension trust funds for salaried employees following the purchase of annuities for these pension plan participants. Of this amount, $9,834,000 was recorded as a gain and the remainder as liabilities for excise taxes and projected future benefits.

title: SCANFORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Weinberger Opposes Aspects of Latin Peace Plan
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today criticized aspects of a peace plan signed by five Central American leaders, arguing that if it caused the anti-Sandinista rebels to lose their military ability, the leverage over the Nicaraguan Government would disappear.

title: Fire Kills 3 Trapped by Bars
description: Three people trapped in a home barred to deter burglars were killed and two others were injured today in an early morning fire, officials said. Flames were spouting from the front of the one-story house when firefighters arrived, and bars on the front and rear doors hindered the victims' escape, said a Fire Department spokeswoman, J. J. Howe.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net gain from sales of properties and investments of $1,461,000 and $1,728,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes net gain from sales of properties and investments of $297,000 and $453,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Non-Utility Electricity Rising
description: As part of an effort to increase its profits, the Procter & Gamble Company recently announced that it would close a soap and detergent factory in Long Beach, Calif. The factory had been generating its own electricity and selling the excess to the local utility. Now, unless the company finds a buyer for the plant, that electricity will no longer be available.

title: Paula Bauersmith, 78, Dies; Actress on TV and the Stage
description: Paula Bauersmith, an actress whose career in the theater, radio and television spanned more than three decades, died of cancer on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GROSS SUSPENDED FOR 10 DAYS
description: The National League suspended Kevin Gross, a pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, for 10 days today for putting sandpaper on his glove. The suspension was appealed, but Gross has admitted having the sandpaper.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A page one report yesterday about protests against the Cuban team at the Pan American Games incorrectly identified one of the groups involved.

title: VESTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: BIRMINGHAM STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Trade Deficit Revised Down
description: Last year's record American trade deficit has been revised downward to $156.2 billion, from $166.3 billion after the reconciliation of American and Canadian trade data, a Commerce Department official said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1987
description: International A2-10

title: CEDAR FAIR LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $13,887,000 from a loan prepayment penalty. c-Net income

description: To the Editor:

title: TARO VIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results converted into U.S. dollars from new Israeli sheckels at the rate of $1 equals 1.6 sheckels, the representative rate at June 30.

title: INSIDE
description: Licensing Setback to RKO

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary Saturday of Ira C. Eaker, a retired Air Force general, incorrectly described one of his missions in World War II. In June 1944, he flew the first bombing run between bases in Italy and the Soviet Union, hitting targets in Hungary and Rumania.

title: 1,900 Mellon Jobs May Be Eliminated
description: The new chairman of the Mellon Bank Corporation, Frank V. Cahouet, said a $65 million belt-tightening program would result in the elimination of up to 1,900 jobs by the end of the year. ''We have to deal with the cost levels in the company, and we're dealing with them,'' Mr. Cahouet said in an interview with The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette.

title: An English Wine Called Breaky Bottom
description: THIRTEEN years ago Peter Hall, who owns the Breaky Bottom Vineyard here in southeast England, got tired of raising pigs and decided to plant a crop. Strawberries and raspberries were ''too boring,'' he said. So he planted four acres of grapes for wine. There hasn't been a dull moment since.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1987
description: Markets

title: AVALON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,903,000 for the quarter and $2,386,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $1,095,000 and $1,315,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The 1986 results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: 20TH CENTURY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TESTIMONY BEGINS IN TRIAL OF MARINE
description: Civilian lawyers for Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, accused of spying as a Marine Corps guard at the United States Embassy in Moscow, charged today that their client was being made a scapegoat for lax State Department security policies.

title: Moses Zucker Is Dead; Professor at Seminary
description: Moses Zucker, Professor Emeritus in Rabbinics at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, died Friday at a nursing home in Miami, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Cone Making Progress
description: David Cone, the Met pitcher who has been on the disabled list for more than two months because of a broken finger, continued working his way back last night in a five-inning performance for Tidewater at Columbus. ''Physically, I feel I'm ready,'' said Cone, who had surgery May 29. ''I've given up some runs and hits, but I've felt better physically each time out. From that standpoint, I have to be encouraged.''

title: Pretoria Plans Tough Laws as Mine Strike Goes On
description: The South African Government said today that it planned to introduce tougher labor laws giving ''more protection'' to employers.

title: Trottier Withdraws
description: Bryan Trottier of the Islanders is suffering from tendinitis in his left shoulder and will be unable to compete for Team USA in the Canada Cup Series, which begins Aug. 28, Bill Torrey, the general manager of the Islanders, announced yesterday.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of other investment of $303,000, or 7 cents a share. Share earnings and shares outstanding for the 1986 periods have been restated to reflect a 1-for-3 reverse stock split effected in August 1986.

description: b-Net income

description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid August 1986.

Results for year-ago second quarter and 6 months included gains from the sale of the Oak Materials segment, the retirement of debt and tax credits.

title: Market Place; Technology's Stock Surge
description: TECHNOLOGY stocks stumbled during May and June, but they are off and running again - and helping the overall equity market sprint to new records.

Ex-Nurse Leading Veterans' Body Recalls Her War
description: Almost 15 years after she returned from duty as an Army nurse in Vietnam, Mary R. Stout began to relive the war.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $625,000. The year-ago results were adjusted to reflect the acquisition of U.S. Design Corp. in May 1987.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New World Freed To Pursue Kenner
description: A Massachusetts judge freed New World Entertainment Ltd. to pursue its $41-a-share tender offer for Kenner Parker Toys Inc., worth about $400 million. Justice John P. Forte of Essex County Superior Court vacated a temporary restraining order imposed last week that barred New World from proceeding with its hostile takeover of the toy maker. Lawyers for New World, based in Los Angeles, said the company would proceed with its offer. Calls to Kenner Parker, based in Beverly, Mass., were not answered.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ONE of the favorite lunch hour pleasures of people who work in downtown Manhattan is strolling along the Battery Park promenade, there to daydream while sitting on a bench or leaning against the railing and enjoying the splendid view of New York Harbor.

title: QMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Quarterback Ineligible
description: Jeff Burger, the quarterback who led Auburn to a 10-2 record last season, has been declared ineligible by university officials because an assistant coach, Pat Sullivan, violated a National Collegiate Athletic Association rule by signing a property bond to free Burger from jail last month.

title: Yanks Fall to 3d
description: In the clubhouse, they moved slowly and quietly. It was another night, another loss. The Yankees did not talk tonight about giving up, but they seemed unsure when all this would finally end.

title: STARS TO GO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Food Shops, the Old and New
description: FOOD shopping in the East Village is like following a time line. Still thriving are traditional Ukrainian and Polish establishments, and some Italian and Jewish shops, all vestiges of turn-of-the-century immigrant populations. The neighborhood also has some organic-food holdovers from the 1960's. And the latest are catering shops and bakeries. Some of these, both new and old, are worth a stop if you happen to be in the neighborhood, and a few merit a special trip.

title: Beer-Loving Inmate Draws an Extra 15
description: A work-release inmate who smuggled eight cans of beer into prison on Christmas Eve will serve an extra 15 years' confinement, his attorney said today.

title: The Pop Life
description: Tina Turner's Vacation

title: Leach Goes 10-0
description: There he was again, the oldest and the best pitcher on the Mets' staff, one of the lowest paid, probably the most long-suffering and even-tempered: Terry Leach of Selma, Ala., tossing the old submarine stuff for eight innings last night in Shea Stadium, pitching the Mets to a 6-2 victory over the Montreal Expos and winning for the 10th time this season against no losses.

title: Players; COSTA RICA'S HEROINE, AGE 16
description: On one side stood two Spanish speaking reporters from Costa Rica. On the other stood two English speaking reporters from the United States. In between stood the focus of a sudden, growing interest in the Pan American Games, a tall 16-year-old with yet another championship bouquet of gladiolas in her arms.

title: A&W BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring loan origination adjustment charge of $135,000 before income taxes (non- cash) for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss The company said the 1986 results represent operations of A&W Concentrate Company, the Company's predecessor, for the period Jan. 1, 1986 to May 20, 1986 and A&W Brands, Inc. from May 21, 1986 to June 30, 1986. The second quarter is for the period April 1 to June 30, and the 6 months is for the period Jan. 1 to June 30.

title: U.S. CONVOY DOCKS SAFELY AT KUWAIT
description: An American-escorted convoy of re-registered Kuwaiti tankers arrived safely in Kuwait today, but new mines were found in what had been considered a safe haven outside the entrance to the Persian Gulf.

title: 6 Are Killed in Munich As Small Plane Crashes
description: A plane practicing landings with a student pilot aboard crashed into a busy section of Munich today, killing 6 people, injuring 14 and setting a fire that burned a McDonald's restaurant and a city bus, the police said.

title: The Last Tango: Isn't Anybody Out There Dancing?
description: LEAD: THE 20's had the Charleston.

title: Theater: 'Holy Ghosts,' Salvation for the Lowly
description: THE setting for Romulus Linney's ''Holy Ghosts,'' a makeshift church, rises from a pit of dirt, and, in the American pecking order, its inhabitants are dirt, too. Mr. Linney's characters in this 1971 work are the largely white trash of the contemporary rural South: the uneducated, the unemployed, the foolish, the cruel, the humiliated. They have nothing but their religion, and their religion is a despised minority creed of the dispossessed. The worshipers of ''Holy Ghosts'' belong to a Pentecostal sect that, taking a cue from a literal reading of Mark, finds divine ecstasy only in the handling of large, hissing, lethal snakes.

title: MAI BASIC FOUR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $989,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Eugene F. Bartley Jr. has been appointed executive vice president, general manager at Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Hodel Plan May Revive Era of Big Dams in West
description: More than 35 years ago, California politicians began lobbying for a huge dam on the American River 130 miles east of here. Twenty years ago, construction of the dam began. Twelve years ago, the construction was halted. Now the Auburn Dam is in the news again, suggesting that once a giant public works project gets a life of its own, it is difficult to smother.

title: Goldome Sets $7 Stock Price
description: Goldome, the nation's eighth-largest thrift institution, is offering 13.95 million shares of common stock at $7 each, for a total of $97.6 million, according to Merrill Lynch & Company, the lead underwriter.

title: PUERTO RICAN CEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
India Is Emerging as No. 1 in Sugar
description: India, in an important measure of economic progress, is poised to become the world's largest sugar producer.

Both year-ago periods had pre-tax securities losses of $19,683,000. The results for the year-earlier periods reflect pre-tax charges of about $50 million related to writedowns of certain assets and establishment of certain reserves for its non-casino- hotel operations.

title: PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: Report for Bar Group Urges Renewal of Prosecutor Law
description: A law authorizing the appointment of independent prosecutors to investigate top Government officials should be renewed by Congress next year, a report presented to the American Bar Association said today.

title: Music: Solemn Rock From the Cure
description: GRIM, disconsolate and stubbornly inexorable, the Cure brought mope-rock to a sold-out Madison Square Garden on Monday night, in a concert that was thoroughly impressive and thoroughly singleminded.

title: Sports of the Times; Urrutia Lifts the Weight
description: This was the day Tony Urrutia had been waiting for, ever since that impulsive moment in Mexico City in 1980 when he jumped out of his hotel room and vaulted over a fence outside the United States Embassy.

title: Chilean Is Denied Visa
description: A member of the Chilean team participating in the Pan American Games has been denied a visa to enter the United States because of involvement in violent incidents in Chile, the State Department said today.

title: Metro Datelines; Ex-Museum Chief Wins Reinstatement
description: An arbitrator has ordered the reinstatement with back pay of the director of the Connecticut State Library museum, who was dismissed after being accused of improperly trading away priceless pieces of the state's Colt firearms collection.

title: On Public Recreation; Our Pools Are Filled With Dollars, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: LAYDEN HITS 3-POINTERS WITH 1-LINERS
description: ''I never met a meal I didn't like.

title: Cabdriver, 38, Is Slain In a Possible Robbery
description: A 38-year-old medallion taxi driver was slain in his cab in Brooklyn yesterday morning during a possible robbery attempt by a passenger who then fled on foot and left his luggage behind, the police said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MISS UNDINE'S LIVING ROOM. By James Wilcox. 275 pages. Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Bush Backs Dole
description: George Bush, long active in Republican politics, has endorsed Bob Dole for President.

title: Guatemala Journal; Re-education and Other Trials for Broken Tribes
description: Twice a day for two years, if the rain did not fall, 32 Indian refugee families in Coban put aside their native Cakchiquel tongue and sang the Guatemalan national anthem in Spanish.

title: MERIDIAN DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago periods' figures were restated to reflect favorable adjustments of $1.3 million, or after-tax of $700,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter, and $2.6 million, or $1.4 million after-tax, or 10 cents a share, for the 6 months for a change in accounting for pension costs in accordance with FASB No. 87. The year-earlier quarter results also reflect a pre-tax gain of $1,330,000 from the sale of a building. The effect on net income amounted to $1,115,000, or 8 cents a share. The year-ago 6 months' pre-tax loss includes a special charge of $5.5 million for doubtful accounts. The effect after taxes amounted to $2.7 million, or 20 cents a share.

title: McLain May Be Retried
description: The United States Attorney's office in Tampa, Fla., intends to put the former Cy Young Award winner Denny McLain on trial again if necessary, Terry Zitek, chief of the criminal division, said yesterday.

title: A Flaw in the Latin Plan
description: LEAD: The euphoria produced by the new Central American peace plan shows how much everyone wants to ''give peace a chance.'' Yet good intentions should not blind us to a very serious flaw in the agreement: the absence of penalties in the event of noncompliance.

title: BRITISH, IN SWITCH, ADD MINESWEEPERS FOR GULF PATROLS
description: Eleven days after rejecting a deeper involvement in the Persian Gulf, Britain announced today that it would send four minesweepers to the area.

title: Zenith Gets $104 Million U.S. Order
description: The Pentagon yesterday awarded the Zenith Corporation a $104 million contract to provide the military with laptop computers, in a major setback for the embattled Toshiba Corporation.

title: Maker to Stop Sale of 2 Cancer-Tied Pesticides
description: The only manufacturer of two highly effective pesticides used to kill termites in homes has agreed to stop selling the products immediately, the Environmental Protection Agency announced today.

title: Music: Milanes, From Cuba
description: PABLO MILANES, the 44-year-old Cuban folk-pop troubadour, exudes a warm, ruefully knowing humanitarianism that makes him more than just a popular entertainer to Latin American audiences. Mr. Milanes, who shared the bill with the Puerto Rican singer Lucecita Benitez at the Festival Latino's Concert for Peace and Friendship on Monday at the Delacorte Theater, is a cultural hero in Cuba and an emissary of Latin American unity who sings in unsentimental terms of Latin American solidarity and a better life.

title: Advertising; Bayer Bess Announces A Reorganization
description: Bayer Bess Vanderwarker & Flynn, which became a spinoff of Backer and Spielvogel's Chicago office back in March, has announced the reorganization of its media department into three groups. The fledgling agency, which opened for business April 1 with some $60 million in billings, says the department will consist of Broadcast Negotiation, Media Planning and Media Research divisions.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Renewal Rejected for RKO Stations
description: In an action that could roil the broadcasting market in several cities, an administrative law judge denied license renewals yesterday to RKO General Inc. for its two television stations and 12 radio stations.

title: Man in the News; A Nominee's Casual Style: C. William Verity Jr.
description: The man President Reagan has chosen as his next Secretary of Commerce favors plaid sport coats rather than business suits and penny loafers rather than dress shoes, and he prefers to travel the streets of his Ohio hometown by bicycle rather than automobile.

description: b-Net income
