description: Year-ago results include an after- tax gain of $768,000, or 24 cents a share, resulting from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Where Diners Can Walk on the Wild, But Savory Side
description: PERHAPS the best place to start a tour to take in some of the hundreds of restaurants and food shops in the East Village and Alphabet City is at St. Marks Place. This three-block-long thoroughfare is variously described as the East Village's spiritual heart or its corrupted, overtouristed center.

title: Bernadette Peters Wins Role in 'Into the Woods'
description: Bernadette Peters will play the Witch, one of five leading roles, in ''Into the Woods,'' a new musical by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine, according to a spokesman for the production. The show, which is to begin previews Sept. 29 at the Martin Beck Theater and open Oct. 29, follows some of the best-known characters from the Grimm Brothers' stories.

title: JUSTICES REPORTED TO FAULT OFFICIAL
description: Several unidentified members of the Supreme Court, in private interviews with a journalist last year, criticized Solicitor General Charles Fried for his aggressive pursuit of the Reagan Administration's legal agenda in 1985 and 1986, according to the coming issue of The New Yorker magazine.

title: Colombia Polishes Its Image as a Debtor
description: On a continent where governments routinely resort to threats and cajolery to extract new loans from reluctant commercial banks, the manner of Colombia's credit request in early May seemed unusually elegant.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago results are restated.

title: U.S. Insurers on Texas Rescue Missions; Sharp Attack On Governor
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today sharply criticized Gov. Bill Clements of Texas, who was quoted as saying that the Federal Government would not stand behind all insured deposits at troubled thrift institutions in Texas.

title: 1986 Jets Picks Get 2d Chance
description: Last year's draft, often described as the least productive in the Jets' history, is having a second life at this year's training camp and may turn out to be not so bad after all.

title: Missile Attack: Pulling the Hair Trigger
description: United States Navy planes did not wait until Iranian fighters took overtly hostile steps before one of the American fighters fired air-to-air missiles at one of the Iranian planes on Saturday over the Strait of Hormuz, military officials said today.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Electronic Data Official A Key to Navy Contract
description: Paul J. Chiapparone, senior vice president of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, is accustomed to overcoming difficult conditions.

description: b-Net loss Reliance Group said its underwriting results in 1986 were adversely affected by a significant increase in the provision for insured events of prior years, including a $100 million charge in the second quarter of 1986 to strengthen loss reserves. The income tax provision for the latest periods reflects benefits of $9 million for the quarter and $18 million for the 6 months resulting from discounting property and casualty loss reserves in accordance with the Tax Reform Act of 1986. The latest quarter also includes a one-time income tax benefit of $16.3 million, which represents the deferred income taxes applicable to title insurance loss reserves which, pursuant to the Tax Reform Act of 1986, are no longer required. The year-ago 6 months includes an after-tax gain of $52.4 million on the sale of the company's Canadian property and casualty subsidiary. Reliance Group Inc. is a wholly owned subsidiary of Reliance Group Holdings Inc.

description: The financial troubles of Mcorp, a Texas banking company, spread to the market for auction-rate preferred stock yesterday, where there were not enough buyers to accommodate all the sellers.

title: Going Out Guide
description: Chinese-American Art

title: Congress Under Cover
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver North is not the only guy in Washington who gets to try his hand at the cloak-and-dagger stuff.

title: Baseball; JAYS WIN ON BARFIELD'S HOMER
description: Jesse Barfield hit a home run to snap a sixth-inning tie, and Jimmy Key won his fifth consecutive decision tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays rallied past the Boston Red Sox, 8-3.

title: Following Reagan
description: When President Reagan travels around the country making speeches about his economic ideas, he often tells audiences how great he feels being away from Washington and all those big spenders who keep adding to the national deficit. But when Mr. Reagan visits North Platte, Neb., today, on his way to a California vacation, Washington will be following him.

title: Generic Confusion
description: Controversy over generic drugs keeps roiling the pharmaceutical industry. Heavy debate erupted when the House of Representatives added a prescription drug benefit to the new catastrophic-illness Medicare bill. Generics were also a source of contention when Governor Cuomo wrangled last year with the New York State Legislature over prescription drug aid for the elderly. Such debates are stirred chiefly by drug makers apparently willing to put profit before any public obligation.

title: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Upgrade the Court
description: Ronald Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert Bork to the Supreme Court was the best decision of the President's otherwise dismal second term.

title: LINPRO SPECIFIED PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Linpro went public July 30, 1986.

title: MOSINEE PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Clara Peller, the Actress In 'Where's the Beef?' TV Ad
description: Clara Peller, the diminutive octogenarian who uttered the famous hamburger challenge, ''Where's the beef?'' in television commercials for a fast-food restaurant chain, died here today. She was 86 years old.

title: Trade Deficit Dips in Britain
description: Britain said today that its trade deficit declined in June to $:168 million, or about $264 million, easing fears that the economy was overheating and imports were rising too rapidly.

title: SUPRADUR COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 5
Pan American Games; Eight Dominicans Leave Village Site
description: Eight Dominican athletes, all members of the armed forces, were missing from the Pan American Games athletes' village today, and the head of that nation's delegation called them ''traitors.''

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,450,000 from an accounting adjustment.

description: b-Reflects a pretax charge of about $4.5 million resulting from the writeoff of nonperforming assets at the company's Telematic Products subsidiary, inventory adjustments, increases to certain reserve accounts and other one-time charges. c-Net income Year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Telematics Products as a pooling of interests.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Propper Manufacturing Co., a maker of medical and laboratory products, to the Alden Group, for print and public information programs.

VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $49,000 and $96,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $60,000 and $160,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Additions to Pizza

title: The Dance: Alfred Desio, In a Tap-Dancing Program
description: ALFRED DESIO offered the perfect hot-weather entertainment on Monday at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, under the aegis of the workshop's summer ''Out-of-Towners'' series. Mr. Desio and his two engaging sidekicks, Damon Winmon and David Sharp, danced and acted their way through 11 numbers, two of them choreographed by Mr. Sharp, that involved an amazing variety of electronic equipment.

title: MTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTERN AUTO SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $200,000 from the early retirement of debt. Year-ago figures are pro forma; the company went public in January.

title: Piniella to See Henderson
description: Manager Lou Piniella said today he still had one order of business left before dismissing the controversy that has swirled around the Yankees: to speak with Rickey Henderson when the Yankees return home Thursday.

title: Vera Allen, 89, Acted in Film, In Theater and in Television
description: Vera Allen, an actress who performed in leading roles on Broadway, in Hollywood and on radio and television, died of heart failure Monday in a retirement home in Croton-on-Hudson, N. Y. Miss Allen, who was active in Actors Equity and was a president of the American Theater Wing, was 89 years old.

title: M-A-R-C INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tips by Messrs. Inside and Outside
description: Over two decades, Michael Pertschuk, as a well-placed Congressional staff member and then as the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, became known as a Washington insider who helped set agendas and make policy.

title: Reagan to Nominate Envoys
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Robert M. Pringle to become the United States Ambassador to Mali, the White House announced today. Mr. Pringle has been deputy chief of mission at Port Morseby, in Papua New Guinea, since 1985. The White House also said Mr. Reagan would nominate David H. Shinn to be the Ambassador of Burkina Faso, the West African nation formerly known as Upper Volta.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FARM CREDIT SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $6 million for the quarter and a gain of $19 million for the 6 months both on other property owned. c-Includes gains on other property owned of $73 million and $117 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Revenue represent net interest income. The 1986 results are reclassified for comparative purposes.

title: DR. RODNEY LEE HITE
description: Dr. Rodney Lee Hite, a pediatrician and an authority on working mothers, died of a heart attack Monday at Park City Hospital, Bridgeport, Conn. He was 45 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: VALLEY CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Times Magazine Group Promotes Executives
description: The New York Times Company's magazine group announced several promotions yesterday. The company named Win Stevens, 46 years old, to be vice president and advertising director at Family Circle. He had been advertising director at Golf Digest. In addition, Susan Baron, 38, a vice president at Family Circle, will become national advertising manager of the women's service magazine.

title: U.S. Insurers on Texas Rescue Missions; F.D.I.C. Seen Near Big Sale
description: Federal regulators are close to finding a buyer for the troubled First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc. in a deal that could include a Federal financial assistance package worth almost $1 billion, Government officials said today.

title: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest periods include the results of operations from date of acquisition of Lambda Novatronics Inc. acquired in May 1987; 9-month figures also include the results of operations from date of acquisition of Magnapower, Inc. and UPA Technology, Inc. acquired in December 1986.

title: Advances; Low-Alcohol Wine Gains More Taste
description: AT last summer's Los Angeles County Fair, judges were both pleased with and embarrassed by a white wine entered by Ariel Vineyards of San Jose: pleased enough with its taste that they awarded Ariel Blanc, a blend of chenin blanc and riesling, a gold medal, placing it ahead of more expensive wines, including a reserve chardonnay, in the competition among miscellaneous white wines.

title: North Koreans Lower Demands
description: North Korea said today that it was reducing its demand that it be allowed to stage eight events of the 1988 Olympics, and would settle for five full events and part of another.

title: Chicago Court Official Admits He Took Bribes
description: The chief investigator for the Cook County Circuit Court system pleaded guilty Monday to charges of accepting bribes to influence decisions on multimillion-dollar city contracts, the United States Attorney said.

title: MTV Networks Fills Its Top Spot
description: MTV Networks Inc. said yesterday that Thomas E. Freston, president of its entertainment division, had been named president and chief executive of the company. For nearly a year MTV did not have a chief executive.

title: Swing Votes to Settle Bork's Fate, Biden Says
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today that the panel's decision on the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court depended on three swing votes.

title: PENSION RISE IS REJECTED BY GOVERNOR
description: Governor Cuomo vetoed a bill today that would have supplemented the pensions of thousands of retired New York City and state employees, saying that it was ''legally flawed'' and that its cost may be ''unreasonably high.''

title: Metro Datelines; Woman Questioned In Restaurant Killing
description: The blond woman who ate dinner with the victim of a gangland-style killing in an Upper East Side restaurant Saturday night has been identified and was being questioned yesterday, the police said.

title: Forest Fires Rage in Greece
description: Forest fires raged out of control on the island of Rhodes today despite firefighting reinforcements flown in from all parts of Greece. Government officials said Greece's entire force of 13 water-dropping aircraft was being used to combat the flames.

title: SOVIET CONFIRMS NEW MISSILE BUT DENIES VIOLATION
description: The Soviet Union said today that it was deploying a new intercontinental ballistic missile but denied that the missile violated the second strategic arms limitation treaty, signed in 1979.

title: MDC ASSET INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is in its first year of operations.

title: MCGWIRE HITS 38TH AND TIES RECORD
description: Mark McGwire of the Oakland Athletics hit his 38th home run tonight to tie the major-league record for home runs by a rookie and set the American League record.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,833,000 from an accounting change.

title: A Record Shared
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Guns in August
description: One of the largest buildups of American forces since the Vietnam War is now assembling in and around the Persian Gulf. Given Iran's threats and unpredictability, attacks on the force are far from unlikely. More mines have been found and a United States fighter plane recently had to fire missiles to ward off Iranian aircraft. Secretary of Defense Weinberger yesterday reiterated hair-trigger but necessary rules for dealing with threats.

title: M-A-COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $874,000 and $3,402,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss $8,385,000 on disposal of assets for the quarter, and a gain on disposal of assets of $10,355,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $893,000. d-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $16,932,000, a loss on disposal of assets of $12,815,000 and a tax credit of $14,346,000. The company said results for the latest quarter loss included an $8.35 million writeoff for the shutdown of its telephone switching business, part of a previously announced restructuring.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes nonrecurring gains of about $108,000 in the second quarter and $528,000 in the first half representing insurance proceeds for business interruption and for equipment destroyed in a fire at a Tampa, Fla., plant in July 1986.

title: A SCORER IS ADDED TO GIANT ARSENAL
description: Every day at the Giants' training camp here, Phil Simms and the other quarterbacks unload long passes. And every day, Stephen Baker catches one or two in the clear, and the thousand or so spectators oooh and aaah and scream.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $282,163 for the quarter and 6 months from the early retirement of debt; the 6 months also includes a gain of $908,717, or 12 cents a share, on the sale of property.

title: COMPUCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: The company said year-ago second quarter and 6-month earnings and revenue were restated to reflect certain year-end adjusments, which increased net by $21,000 and revenue by $44,000. Corrected from Wednesday, Aug. 5, editions.

description: b-Net loss

title: TIME OUT FROM THE PAN AM RIVALRIES
description: It is midafternoon and the heat of the last few days has given way to a near-perfect day: blue skies, lazy sun and a teasing breeze that keeps the temperature at a comfortable 83 degrees.

title: Texas-Grown Game Is a House Specialty
description: THREE years ago, Jeff Blank, a chef at the Wineskin Restaurant in Snowmass, Colo., and Gert Rausch, the chef and owner of the Austin Courtyard Restaurant here, wondered what they could possibly offer in a town that already had Tex-Mex, barbecue, French, Italian, Spanish, Chinese and Japanese food. The two had known each other since the early 1970's, from their days at Lakeway, a resort on Austin's outskirts, and had long wanted to work together.

description: b-Includes an investment gain of $476,000. c-Net loss and includes an investment gain of $169,000. The company said the year-ago 6 month loss is primarily due to a one- time charge of $716,000 taken in the first quarter related to a contractual obligation to the company's former chairman, who is now deceased.

title: Harlem Legend Saluted
description: The sounds of tap-dancing have been floating down for 50 years now from the Mary Bruce School of Dance, a Harlem landmark where generations of children have trained in dance, piano and deportment from a woman who also taught them about humanity. And Miss Bruce is to be celebrated this morning in ''Salute to Mary Bruce,'' at 11 in Public School 92 at 134th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard.

title: New Mexico Utility Discloses Utah Bid
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico disclosed that it had made a bid to merge with the Utah Power and Light Company, but it said it was withdrawing the offer because Utah Power's board had not accepted it. On July 29, Utah Power said it had received merger proposals at prices above its market value, which at that time was more than $1.4 billion. It did not give the names of the bidders or other details, although Pacificorp said it had held discussions with the utility.

title: Deformed Great Lakes Birds
description: A new study has found deformities at birth and reproductive failures in some species of water birds that feed on fish in the Great Lakes, suggesting potential toxic threats to humans that may have been overlooked, an expert says.

title: Metal Trading Move Backed
description: The Chicago Board of Trade won unanimous approval today from Federal regulators to trade gold and silver futures contracts, a move that will intensify competition among American exchanges for precious metals trading.

title: WESTON, GEORGE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: 21 Injured in Mattress Fire At Welfare Hotel in Brooklyn
description: A mattress fire forced the evacuation yesterday of a Brooklyn welfare hotel where four children died in a fire a year ago, the police and fire officials reported.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch in some copies yesterday from Manama, Bahrain, about Iraqi raids on Iranian oil installations misstated Iran's daily oil output. It is estimated by the Department of Energy in Washington to be 1.8 million barrels.

title: BROWN TRANSPORT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Why Stocks Are Booming
description: THE fifth anniversary of the bull market has kicked off a celebration on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring above 2,600 Monday for the first time and hitting 2,680.48 yesterday without catching its breath.

title: BASIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $5,931,000 and $6,278,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After net from discontinued operations of $251,000 for the quarter and $1,343,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results are reclassified.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Potatoes Undefiled
description: LEAD: THE ways of nutrition are sometimes truly inscrutable.

title: Man With Link to Klan Found Nailed to Board
description: A man once linked to neo-Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan was found nailed to a board through the palms of his hands on Saturday, but he has refused to say what happened, officials said Monday.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid last month.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Navy Holds 2 in Gulf Ship Death
description: Two United States Navy men are being held in the robbery and slaying of a 20-year-old crewman who disappeared late last week from the aircraft carrier Constellation, deployed near the Persian Gulf, Navy officials said today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: DEATH is a fact of life. As rational adults we all know this. As anxious parents, however, we also want to deny it and to protect our children from the painful reality, especially when someone close to them is dying or dies.

title: Nuclear Power Isn't a Key to Oil Independence
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $402,000 and $857,000, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the quarter also includes $700,000 of inventory writedowns.

title: Moscow Ballet Tickets
description: Tickets go on sale today for performances by the Moscow Ballet on Nov. 27 and 28 at 8 P.M. at the War Memorial in Trenton, N.J. The company is a touring group of performers from the Bolshoi and Kirov Ballets in the Soviet Union, and is under the direction of Vacheslav Gordeyev, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi. Tickets are $18.50, $28.50 and $55 and may be ordered by calling Teletron at 800-233-4050. Patron tickets at $100, which include a post-performance champagne reception, may be ordered by calling 609-394-1000. All tickets to the performances, which are benefits for the Greater Trenton Symphony Orchestra and Trenmos, an educational and cultural exchange program between Trenton and Moscow, are tax deductible.

title: HYDE ATHLETICS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COSTA RICAN CHIEF WARNS NICARAGUA ON PRESS FREEDOM
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, whose Central American peace proposal was signed by regional leaders last week, has declared that the plan cannot succeed unless Nicaragua allows opposition press outlets to reopen.

title: Data General Addition
description: The Data General Corporation, which makes a broad line of computer systems, said today that it added a more powerful model to its MV/7800 series of superminicomputers. The new MV/7800 XP is 40 percent faster than the original MV/7800, according to the company, which also announced the MV/7800 DCX, an office version of the new system.

title: Sisters' Island Neighbors Uneasy
description: On this tiny island the nuns often outnumber the other Catholics, and they have created quite a quarrel.

title: Correction Board Moves to Ease Rikers Crowding
description: New York City can no longer crowd inmates waiting to be sent to state prisons into an ever smaller amount of space, the agency that oversees the city's jails ruled yesterday.

title: LEXINGTON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $751,000 for the quarter and $678,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and the 6 months is after an extraordinary charge of $118,000.

title: NEW CENTURY ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $218,000 for the latest first quarter and $21,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Arthritic Banking Laws in a Samurai Arena
description: I recently expressed some frank concerns about the ability of United States banks to compete in global financial markets under existing laws and regulations. Much to my surprise, those observations have since taken on a life of their own, having been widely misinterpreted as meaning that the United States Treasury has a ''plan'' (secret, of course) to promote American ''superbanks,'' or, even worse, ''megabanks.''

title: STRIKES MOUNTING IN SOUTH KOREA
description: A wave of labor unrest is sweeping through this country, with thousands of employees from bus drivers to factory workers striking for higher wages and the right to organize unions without Government interference.

title: MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Widening of New Jersey Turnpike to Add Marshes for Wildlife
description: The proposed $2 billion widening of the New Jersey Turnpike will include a project to create 322 acres of low-lying salt marshes and mud flats in the Hackensack Meadowlands, including 153 acres just south of Giants Stadium, officials said today.

title: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income of $58,200,000 from discontinued operations, and includes a one-time charge of $20,900,000 taken in the second quarter for the closure of a pet foods division manufacturing plant. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2.7 million and $12,900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Man Said to Tell of Slaying 34
description: A nurse's aide has said he killed at least 34 people, primarily at two area hospitals, according to a television station's report today.

title: Mexican Pact on Private Debt
description: Mexico will sign a new agreement on Friday to stretch out payments on about $10 billion in the foreign debts of private Mexican companies, a spokesman for the Treasury Department said today. The agreement ends a series of rescheduling negotiations the Government has held with private bankers over the past year.

title: 56th Dolphin Dies in Jersey; A Survey by Air Is Planned
description: The 56th dolphin known to have died of a mysterious malady off New Jersey this summer floated ashore here today as scientists prepared to take to the air in their search for a cause.

title: F.B.I. Says Public Officials Accepted 105 of 106 Bribes Offered in 2-Year Operation
description: In a ''sting'' operation that swept from Long Island to the Canadian border, 58 people, including 44 New York municipal officials, have been charged with taking bribes and kickbacks from an undercover F.B.I. agent, Federal officials announced yesterday.

title: Abloom With Color And Song
description: 1. 'Flowers' for Patios Stylish outdoor entertaining calls for this tray decorated with pink and purple irises. Made in Italy of sturdy white plastic, the tray measures 11 by 17 inches and costs $18. Other sizes and shapes are available. In the New York Botanical Garden's Shop in the Garden, 590 Madison Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets, in the atrium of the I.B.M. Building. 2. Colorful Viewing Boring black binoculars are relics of the past. This updated Binocolor by Tasco is bright red; the binocular also comes in yellow, white, gray, light blue or mauve. The price is $59.99 in electronics on the fifth floor at Macy's Herald Square. Also available at branch stores. 3. Exhibiting a Tour For a memorable photograph taken on your summer vacation, here is a travel-wise picture frame. It is covered with a road map. The frame is available in two sizes, 5 by 7 inches for $12 or 3 1/2 by 5 inches for $10. At the Museum of American Folk Art shop, 62 West 50th Street. 4. Keeping Score(s) Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival has come up with a cool and fashionable summer accessory - this cotton scarf, made in Italy. It is decorated with pages of the scores of ''The Magic Flute,'' ''Don Giovanni,'' ''The Marriage of Figaro'' and other Mozart operas. For $16.95 in the lobby of Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Koch Shifts on New Site For Museum
description: Faced with the possibility that the Museum of the American Indian might move to Washington, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Mayor Koch reversed themselves yesterday and said they would support relocating the museum to the old United States Custom House at Bowling Green.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: TO my mind, one of the finest and most versatile techniques in the world of Western cooking is the one known as breading. It's easy and quick, and foods properly breaded and cooked are particularly tempting.

title: When It's Better to Give Back and to Receive
description: They say you can't unscramble an egg. But Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas seems to have come fairly close.

title: CBS Officer Joins Agency
description: George F. Schweitzer, vice president of communications at CBS Inc., has resigned to join Young & Rubicam as a vice president and director of corporate relations. Mr. Schweitzer had been at

title: The Six- and Seven-Story Solution
description: If New York City ends up as a home for only the very rich and the very poor, part of the blame will fall on municipal laws that discourage construction of sound middle-class housing. The Board of Estimate now has a chance to effect a badly needed change.

title: Networks Will Carry Reagan Address Live
description: President Reagan's address on the Iran-contra affair and the recently completed Congressional hearings will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. today on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. C-SPAN, the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network, will carry the speech at midnight. Some local affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the address, either live or later.

title: MASTROIANNI PICKED TO OPEN 25th NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL
description: Beginning with Mastroianni and ending with Mamet, the 25th New York Film Festival opening Sept. 25 at Lincoln Center will contain discoveries from Japan, Hong Kong and Mali.

title: At Rope's End
description: People are more fed up than usual. I noticed it at Sunday dinner with the family. The whole family was all fed up. They were fed up with the Iran-contra hearings, which had just ended, and fed up with Congress for not letting the President do what he wanted to do.

title: CASTLE, A M & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
An Organist Who Makes Music For Silent Films
description: Years ago, before movies started to talk and movie-theater organists were consigned to a world of wistful remembrances, almost every theater in America had its own keyboard accompanist.

title: West 45th Street: Shadows Near the Bright Lights
description: By day, West 45th Street just east of Times Square is a vibrant jumble of the old and the new, the beyond-redemption and the just-begun, a place where rundown hotels, tattered billboards and a turn-of-the-century theater mingle with bright restaurant facades, a gleaming bank and two nascent office towers.

title: BMW Roadster
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. said it would introduce a 170-horsepower sports car, to be called the Roadster Z1, in June 1988. The two-seat car will be shown at the Frankfurt auto show in September, BMW said. A spokesman said that a price had not been set and that production would be limited to about six cars a day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe we have surfaced a deeply rooted system of corruption that rots the core of municipal governments and provides the taxpayers of those communities with inferior goods and services.'' - Thomas L. Sheer of the F.B.I.'s New York office on the indictment of 44 New York State municipal officialsfor accepting bribes. [ B4:5. ]

title: BUCKEYE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $150,000 and $475,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Offer for Day Completed
description: The M. A. Hanna Company said today that it had successfully completed its tender offer for shares of the Day International Corporation of Dayton, Ohio. Hanna offered on July 14 to buy all outstanding Day common shares at $48 a share and all outstanding Day preferred shares at $258.72 a share. The offer expired Monday. A preliminary count indicated that about 5.6 million Day common shares and 10,339 Day preferred shares were bought by Hanna in the tender offer. The shares purchased in the tender offer, when added to the shares previously owned by Hanna and assuming conversion of the preferred shares, represented about 85.6 percent of all outstanding Day common shares.

title: WINE TALK
description: JUST over a mile east of Wiltingen, a village in the pastoral Saar River valley, a steep vineyard called the Scharzhofberg rises near the road. In West Germany the riesling grape is king and this slope is its throne room.

title: Cuomo Vetoes Bill for Revamping System of Reimbursing Hospitals
description: A fundamental revision in the way hospitals are reimbursed by insurance companies and the government was vetoed today by Governor Cuomo, who said it would have cost New Yorkers $400 million more a year.

title: Biden and His Party Risking High Stakes In Fight Over Bork
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, scheduled to begin Sept. 15, may profoundly affect not only the Court's ideological balance but also the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: Bridge; Double Knockout Format May Be Due for a Revival
description: Playing 16 deals in a major team championship can on occasion be an exercise in futility.

title: Man of the Street Crosses Swords With the I.R.S.
description: Of the estimated 50,000 homeless people in New York, John-Ed Croft is probably the only one asking passers-by on the street for the name of a good tax lawyer.

title: Results Plus
description: Boxing Rosario Wins: Edwin Rosario won a knockout in the eighth round last night in Chicago against a fellow Puerto Rican, Juan Nazario, and retained his World Boxing Association lightweight title. Rosario had cornered Nazario and pummeled him with a combination of punches to knock him off balance for the final blow in the bout at before 2,300 people. Nazario was cut over the right eye in the fourth round. Rosario took control of the fight from that point after pacing himself in the earlier rounds. The fight was called at 2:43 of the eighth round. Rosario's record improved to 26-2, with 22 knockouts. Nazario is 18-1-1.(AP) Tennis Sznajer Upsets Doohan: Unseeded Andrew Sznajder of Canada rallied from a three-game third-set deficit yesterday to upset Peter Doohan of Australia, seeded 16th, in the first round of the $300,000 Player's International tournament in Montreal. Doohan was leading, 5-2, in the third set when Sznajder began a series of brilliant passing shots that enabled him to win, 7-6, 2-6, 7-6. (AP) Mecir Upset in First Round: Miloslav Mecir, the top-seeded player, was upset yesterday in the $180,000 grand prix tournament in Prague by a fellow Czechoslovak, Jaroslav Navratil, 6-3, 5-7, 7-6. Mecir, the world's fifth-ranked player, was the only one of the top eight seeded players to bow out in the first round.(AP) Cycling Pierce Retains Overall Lead: Jeff Pierce kept his overall lead in the Coors International Classic yesterday as Micol Gianelli of Italy captured the daily honors. Gianelli finished a 105-mile road race from Sonoma, Calif., to Sacramento in 4 hours 16 minutes 40 seconds. He finished just ahead of Roy Knickman of Boulder, Colo., and Raul Alcala of Mexico, a member of the United States-based 7-Eleven team. Knickman moved into fourth over all, 3:09 behind Pierce in the 1,385-mile event. Pierce, of the 7-Eleven team, has an overall time of 21:15:10. Andrew Hampsten of Boulder is in third place overall, 1:49 behind Pierce.(AP)

title: USPCI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 15.

title: COLORADO TO PAY COSTS OF ACCIDENT
description: Gov. Roy Romer named an executive team today to investigate the seven deaths that resulted when a seven-ton boulder rolled down a mountainside onto a tourist bus.

title: Church Scrutinizes 3 Groups of Nuns
description: Three small groups of strongly traditional nuns in Michigan, Connecticut and Washington State have aroused the concern of Roman Catholic officials, who are looking into reports of coercion, deception and a peculiar brand of theology in religious communities largely beyond the control of local bishops.

title: GAMES' DRUG TESTS: NO SIMPLE SYSTEM
description: It was just about this time four years ago that the issue of drug testing in amateur sports exploded onto the international scene. At the ninth Pan American Games in Caracas, 11 athletes from six countries, including two from the United States, were stripped of their medals after testing positive for banned substances. Twelve other American athletes left the games before they could be tested.

title: COMMERCIAL FEDERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $519,000 and $1,990,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings. The company said results for the latest year include a writeoff of $977,000 of the company's interest in the Federal Savings & Loan Insurance Corp's secondary reserve.

title: XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Adirondack Rodeo: Hard Dirt, Low Stakes and Daring
description: Jim Love, the announcer at the Adirondack Championship Rodeo, was taking requests before the performance tonight when he cranked up the song ''Mammas Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Cowboys.'' But from the looks of it, the advice was too late. Outside the wooden bleachers that ringed the small arena, more than 100 bronc riders, steer wrestlers, barrel racers and team ropers waited for their chance to win points and prize money at the longest-running weekly rodeo in the country. Amid a confusion of horse trailers, house trailers and pickups filled with feed, they exercised their mounts, set their saddles and practiced by roping plastic calf heads tethered to bales of hay.

title: Opera: 'Albert Herring,' by Berkshire Company
description: Britten's ''Albert Herring,'' which the Berkshire Opera Company presented ably in the first of four performances last night, can be counted among the small group of nearly foolproof musical theater pieces. Not unlike Thomson's ''Mother of Us All,'' ''Herring'' is informed by a humane comic vision in which the characters, no matter how absurd they may be, are touched and redeemed by a certain winning charm. There's always more to them than first meets the eye.

title: Concert: The Cleveland Quartet, at the Mostly Mozart Festival
description: Since its first performance at the Marlboro Festival in 1969, the Cleveland Quartet has remained three-quarters intact, with Donald Weilerstein and Peter Salaff still manning the violins and Paul Katz playing the cello. The viola has been the unstable spot. First there was Martha Strongin Katz, then, more recently, Atar Arad. Now he has been replaced by James Dunham, a founding member of the Sequoia String Quartet. Mr. Dunham is making his first formal appearances as a quartet member at the Aspen Festival and, Monday night, at the Mostly Mozart Festival in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: SO I'm reading about Joan Collins, who got married last year in Las Vegas to a man 14 years her junior whose only resume description was ''former Swedish pop star.'' And I'm reading about Sylvester Stallone, who married a woman, usually photographed wearing no more than the equivalent of a bandanna, who introduced herself by sending a photograph to his hotel room after she had ditched her baby and her first husband in Denmark. (I mean, what are they feeding them in Scandinavia? Human blood?) And I see that these people are getting divorced.

title: Reuters Stake Reduced
description: The News Corporation Ltd., the media and entertainment concern controlled by Rupert Murdoch and based in Sydney, Australia, has reduced its stake in Reuters Holdings P.L.C. to 3.8 percent, from 9.5 percent. News Corporation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its holdings in the news agency, based in London, were reduced as the result of an exchange offer with preferred shareholders.

title: DR. WILLIAM MacDONALD
description: Dr. William G. MacDonald, a surgeon and former house doctor for the Metropolitan Opera, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 75 years old.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-After a charge of $39,000 for settlement of a U.S. Environmental Protection Agency superfund claim. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $102,000.

title: GULF CANADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1 million and $2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $78 million for the quarter and $227 million for the 6 months; and the 6-month also includes a $72 million charge from the redemption of debentures. The company said the second quarter and six months results will be the last reported under the name of Gulf Canada Corp. In a reorganization plan, which became effective July 1, holders of common shares received their proportional interest in all of the businesses of the company through direct ownership in three separate, publicly traded companies: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., which carries on the business formerly conducted by Gulf's oil and gas division; Abitibi-Price Inc., the forest products company; and GW Utilities Ltd., which holds Gulf's remaining businesses. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $629,033 and $1,499,446 in the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes realized capital gains of $784,705 and $2,653,018 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $178,699 and $1,385,845 for the same periods, respectively.

title: AON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $6,345,000 for the quarter and $7,064,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $29,047,000 and $58,988,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago figures include the results of Life of Virginia for May and June 1986.

title: Real Estate; Limiting Growth in Stamford
description: DURING the last 15 years Stamford, Conn., has been transformed by the development of more than 10 million square feet of office space, making the former industrial town a national business center.

title: Burger King Picks Pepsi
description: The battle over which soft-drink company will supply the Burger King Corporation's domestic restaurants ended today, with the current supplier, Pepsico Inc., winning the deal.

title: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
WESTERN CAPITAL INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6,500,000 which reflects provisions of $5.7 million for special loan losses and a chargeoff of $2.8 million for FSLIC secondary reserves. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $18,082,000 and $20,332,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: A Geographical Error
description: To the Editor:

title: William C. Doherty, Ex-President Of Letter Carriers' Union, Is Dead
description: William C. Doherty, a former president of the National Association of Letter Carriers and a former Ambassador to Jamaica, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at the Collingswood Nursing Center in Rockville, Md. He was 85 years old and lived in Nalcrest, Fla., a community for retired mail carriers that he founded.

title: Decline in Corn Crop
description: This fall's corn crop is expected to yield 7.23 billion bushels, down 12.4 percent from the 1986 harvest of 8.25 billion bushels, the Agriculture Department said today. According to the department, the 1987 corn harvest would be the smallest since 1983, when drought and Government acreage programs reduced production to 4.18 billion bushels.

title: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Designing for Assembly Lines
description: UNTIL recently, industrial designers and manufacturing engineers did not have much to do with each other.

title: Psst! They're Dining Well in the (Far) East Village
description: IN a neighborhood afflicted with burned-out buildings, crime and drugs, a restaurant that offers arugula with smoked pheasant, roast monkfish and flourless chocolate cake might seem incongruous - and it is.

title: 3-Year Notes Well Received
description: Compared to the enthusiasm of the stock market, the Treasury's note auction yesterday had all the excitement of a parking lot outside a three-ring circus.

title: WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TV Review; 'At the Guggenheim,' a Series on 13
description: FOR well over a decade, Channel 13 has being trying to mine, electronically speaking, the riches to be found in New York's cultural institutions. After all, with its constant mix of home-nurtured and imported attractions, the city can justifiably claim title to being the world's international arts center. Television, however, has had a difficult time designing formats to take advantage of the situation. Too often, the results come out looking like third-rate commercials for a particular institution or show.

title: Stocks Surge; Volume Rises To 2d-Highest
description: Stock prices climbed to new heights yesterday, driven by the heavy buying of large institutions and small investors. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was the second-largest ever.

title: Metro Datelines; Store Owner Draws Prison in Fraud Case
description: A Queens shoe store owner and his brother were sentenced yesterday to prison terms ranging from one to four and a half years for stealing $230,000 in Medicaid funds in 1985.

title: HOME OFFICE REFERENCE LAB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After non-recurring securities gains.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: SENATE
description: Making a Federal Case of the Bork Nomination

title: Fall of Tower Silences An Anti-Castro Station
description: The 250-foot tower of an anti-Castro radio station collapsed on a house today, and station officials said it was a result of sabotage.

title: PTL Considers Severing Ministry and Real Estate
description: Officers of the PTL ministry want to divide its holdings into two separate corporations, one nonprofit and the other for-profit, The Atlanta Constitution reported today.

title: IDB COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company noted that year-ago results reflected utilization of investment tax credits which were subsequently repealed by Congress.

title: MANITOWOC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Net loss and includes a non-recurring pre-tax charge of $40 million from restructuring of the company's crane business and related operations for the quarter and year.

title: A Jazz Legend at Jezebel's: Friends, Food and Memories
description: HIS legs are slowed after a half-century of knocking around smoky jazz clubs and concert halls, but when Lionel Hampton enters a room the pace quickens and everything is finger-snapping table-tapping cool. That's how it was at Jezebel's, a stylish soul-food restaurant at 630 Ninth Avenue and 45th Street where I dined last week with the legendary band leader and vibraphone player.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
The U.N. Today: Aug. 12, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. Is Encouraging Democratization in Chile
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Stake In America West
description: A unit of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd., an Australian airline company, has purchased a 21.6 percent stake in America West Airlines. The News Corporation, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, owns 50 percent of Ansett.

title: Woolen Mill Co-Owner Dies After Being Wrapped in Yarn
description: The co-owner of a woolen mill suffocated today when he fell onto a machine and was wrapped in about 800 yards of yarn, the police said.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARARA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Decreased by about $1 million as a result of the writeoff of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. secondary reserve. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $900,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary Saturday of Myron Stout, an abstract artist, gave an incorrect date for a memorial service for him in Provincetown, Mass. The service is scheduled for Aug. 20.

title: U.S. Is Pressing Israelis to Drop Costly Jet Effort
description: The United States urged Israel today to scrap its costly program to produce a new jet fighter known as the Lavi.

title: MEDIA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NACCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Nacco said the sale of Quarto Mining Co. contributed $1.10 a share to earnings in the latest quarter, and in the year-ago period the sale of certain coal reserves accounted for 32 cents a share.

title: ELCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Text of Agreement by 5 Central American Leaders on Peace in the Region
description: Following is the text of an agreement, titled ''Procedure for the Establishment of a Strong and Lasting Peace in Central America,'' that was signed last Friday by five leaders of the region, as translated and made public by the Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry. The bracketed material was part of the text provided by the Foreign Ministry.

title: Giving Two Founding Fathers Their Due
description: To the Editor:

title: JORGENSEN EARLE M CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.3 million, or 36 cents a share, resulting from an inventory reduction.

title: A Decade of Schubert Planned at 92d Street Y
description: In an undertaking of extraordinary proportions, the 92d Street Y will begin during its 1987-88 season a decade-long project to present the complete works of Schubert, which include over 60 chamber pieces, 600 songs and numerous operas, masses and pieces for keyboard. The project, overseen by the baritone Hermann Prey, begins with eight concerts in late January and early February of next year.

title: 200 Cabbies Protest At Newark Airport
description: About 200 taxicab drivers at Newark International Airport declared themselves on strike last night to protest the arrest of two drivers of their cab company. The two were charged with assaulting a gypsy-cab driver at Terminal B. About 9 P.M., the two drivers were arrested on charges of simple assault in an argument with the gypsy-cab driver, who they said was stealing their business by soliciting passengers inside the terminal. They were released about 11 P.M.

title: Busch Writes His Own
description: No one else seemed to be writing the kind of roles Charles Busch thought he should be playing, so he started to write them himself.

title: Shopping Around For Electric Power
description: Last year, fed up with what it claimed were high rates, the Chicago suburb of Geneva, Ill., stopped buying power from the local electric company, Commonwealth Edison, and began buying from the Wisconsin Electric Power Company.

title: HEALTH CARE R.E.I.T.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represents gross income.

title: New York Ekiden: Pass-the-Sash Race
description: Ekiden, an ancient Japanese word that means ''messenger between stations,'' is Greek to most New Yorkers. But if Kazuo Aichi, the president of the recently formed International Ekiden Federation, and Hugh L. Carey, the former governor of New York and currently the president of the even more recently formed America's Ekiden Federation, have their way, it won't be long before the word is as familiar to American ears as ''marathon.''

title: Cereal Production
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization predicted today that world cereal production in 1987 would decline, partly because American farmers have cut back on plantings. But the organization also predicted that world supplies would remain abundant because of record stocks.

title: PIONEER ELECTRONIC
description: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation will begin exports of 50-inch projection television sets to the United States in October, a company spokesman said. About 3,000 sets will be produced monthly, exclusively for export to the United States, he said.

title: Solicitor General Expresses Doubt On Accuracy of a Critical Article
description: Solicitor General Charles Fried today questioned the accuracy of an article in The New Yorker magazine that reported that several unidentified members of the Supreme Court had criticized his aggressive advocacy of the Reagan Administration's legal agenda.

title: Slow Tellers: Undoing Of Thief at 3 Banks
description: A would-be bank robber had a busy day in Brooklyn yesterday, but not a profitable one.

title: THERMO ELECTRON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prisoner Tests Show No AIDS Epidemic Yet
description: Two months after the Reagan Administration began testing Federal prison inmates for AIDS, officials say they have yet to find an epidemic in the prisons but will extend the program by six weeks to get a larger sample.

title: Ellsberg Fined in Protest
description: The antiwar activist Daniel Ellsberg has been fined $50 for his involvement in a protest last April at the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency. The former Pentagon analyst, who says he disclosed the Pentagon Papers to the press, pleaded no contest Tuesday in Fairfax County General District Court to a charge of obstructing free passage.

title: Latin Pact Seen as Helpful to Duarte
description: Salvadoran rebel and Government officials have reacted cautiously to the newly signed Central American peace accord and have so far offered no new formal proposals for negotiations to end the war here.

title: THE REAL COST OF GAS: $5 A GALLON
description: Forget oil taxes, import fees and subsidies for alternate fuels, say Reagan energy experts: the market alone will produce the right amount of oil at the right price. That has always been a glib analysis. Now, in light of the Administration's willingness to risk lives and dollars in the defense of oil from the Persian Gulf, it seems absurd.

title: Don't Dump All of New York's Garbage Problem on Staten Island
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: RAGAN BRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $399,000, or 18 cents a share, from reduction of certain inventory lines for both periods, and 6 months also includes a gain of $150,000, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of an airplane.

title: Oil From Ecuador Again
description: Ecuador plans to resume exporting crude oil next week when a repaired pipeline goes back into service, the state oil company said today. Mudslides, caused by earthquakes, ruptured the line in March.

title: F.D.A. Rule to Restrict Shipments of Raw Milk
description: Interstate shipments of raw milk packaged for consumer use will be banned after Sept. 10 under a final rule issued by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Just What Is U.S. Policy Toward Palau Islands?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 13, 1987
description: International A2-13

title: No Retirement Yet For Lady's Secret
description: Lady's Secret, who refused to finish the first race at Saratoga Race Course Monday as the 3-10 favorite, will be kept in training instead of being sent home, her handlers confirmed today.

title: Pirates' Walk Shuts Out Cards on 4 Hits
description: Bob Walk pitched a four-hitter and completed Pittsburgh's eight-run fourth-inning with a bases-loaded single tonight as the Pirates routed St. Louis, 11-0. It was the first time the Cardinals had been shut out in 113 games this season.

title: Start With a New Chancellor
description: No public service is more important to New York City's future than education. Yet the school system has lately suffered a number of embarrassing public failures. Graduates are unable to qualify even for entry-level jobs made specially available by concerned companies. Bureaucratic bungles paralyze remedial programs. And the percentage of students who drop out is either 30, 37 or 54, depending on who's counting.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-Includes gains of $289,000 from the sale of West Los Angeles real estate for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes gains of $1,145,000 and $9,630,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the sale of West Los Angeles real estate.

title: Steinbrenner Keeping Tabs on Yanks
description: In times of trouble, George Steinbrenner has been known to follow a pattern: Observers are sent to watch games, reports are filed, opinions are formed. Sometimes, a manager is dismissed.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
METRO MOBILE CTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRUDENTIAL OFFICER PUT ON TOP COUNCIL
description: Richard G. Merrill, who yesterday was elected an executive vice president and a member of the executive office at the Prudential Insurance Company of America, got a big break in his career at the giant company in 1971.

title: ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago 6-month loss includes a writedown of $41,505,000 for property impairment resulting from the sharp deterioration in oil prices at that time. Share earnings represent units.

title: Czech Flees by Hang Glider
description: A truck driver from Czechoslovakia fled today by piloting a motor-assisted hang glider across the border into Austria, the police reported. The pilot, identified as Ladislav Terync, 29 years old, landed in a field near here and said he wanted to go to the United States.

title: Wiesel, Critic on Waldheim, To Have Visit With the Pope
description: Elie Wiesel, the Nobel laureate who severely criticized Pope John Paul II for meeting with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, will visit with the Pope this month, American Jewish and Catholic officials said yesterday.

title: 2-1 Choice Gets Wilson Rail
description: Armbro Global drew the rail today and was made the early 2-1 favorite for the $1,422,500 Woodrow Wilson Pace for 2-year-olds Saturday night at the Meadowlands.

title: ENERGAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $585,000 from repeal of the investment tax credit and a one-time charge of $1,200,000 for costs associated with an early retirement program. c-Net loss Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect the adoption of new pension accounting standards.

title: Alcatel Gets Bulk Of Belgian Orders
description: Alcatel N.V., a joint venture of the ITT Corporation and the French concern Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, has won the bulk of a huge contract to modernize Belgium's telephone system, the telecommunications ministry said. Industry sources said the modernization would cost around 50 billion francs, or $1.3 billion, over five years, with 1.5 million new lines to be installed.

title: Easing The Task Of Using Waxes
description: LEAD: A FEW centuries ago waxes and oils were probably applied to the surface of furniture more to preserve the wood than to enhance its appearance. The wax was probably melted in a solvent or simply rubbed into the surface grain and then buffed with a coarse cloth.

title: Andrei Sets Shot-Put Mark
description: Alessandro Andrei of Italy set a world record in the shot-put today with a throw of 75 feet 2 inches.

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Connecticut Rivals Are Typical of Atypical District
description: Voters in Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District will not be choosing from a pair of political stereotypes when they go to the polls next week to fill the House seat left vacant by the death of Stewart B. McKinney.

title: HOME INTENSIVE CARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Preferred stock dividends exceeded net income in the year-ago periods.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Sports People; Extra Pay for Howe
description: Steve Howe, the pitcher signed by the Texas Rangers a week ago, will be paid retroactively to July 12, nearly a month before the team signed him, according to a report in USA Today. Michael Stone, the Rangers' president, denied that Howe had signed a deal in which his major league contract is retroactive.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misstated the day for President Reagan's visit to North Platte, Neb. It is today.

title: OPTROTECH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-After tax credits of $810,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,331,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss on the exchange of long- term debt for common stock of $1,310,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The results for the latest second quarter include a $2 million pre-tax loss, representing the company's share in Value Television's Home Shopping program, a discontinued television show produced in a joint venture with Lorimar-Telepictures Corp. and Fox Television Stations Inc.

title: Beck Will Be Ranger Again
description: Exactly one year after announcing plans to sit out the 1986-87 National Hockey League season because of ''philosophical differences with the coaching staff,'' Barry Beck observed the anniversary yesterday with a cheerier piece of news for New York hockey fans: He will play the 1987-88 season for the Rangers.

title: U.S. Is Reviving Its Push to Build Fast Computers
description: More than three decades ago, after struggling through pioneering computer projects with names like Eniac, Ordvac and even Maniac, the United States Government gave up trying to build the world's fastest computers by itself. The expense and the technological hurdles convinced Federal officials that private industry was better equipped to define the state of the art.

title: Strikes Shut Korea's Car Plants
description: Miners set buildings ablaze and workers barricaded a factory with forklift trucks as spreading labor turmoil halted car production in South Korea today, the Government said.

title: A Defense of Thrift Remarks
description: Gov. Bill Clements of Texas defended his remarks on thrift institutions today after being criticized by the savings and loan industry.

title: I.B.M. Credit
description: The I.B.M. Credit Corporation is offering $200 million of 8 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of 99.731, to yield 8.102 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes, which are rated triple A and are not callable before maturity, were offered to yield about 16-hundredths of a percentage point more than the Treasury's new three-year notes.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MAHINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; People
description: * Donald J. Lorenzet was promoted to senior vice president at Hirsch Elliot, a business-to-business and recruitment agency.

title: A PROPER WORD IN COURT
description: The word ''conclusory'' is not in Webster's New World Dictionary, but the Wyoming Supreme Court has ruled it fit for courtroom use.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $10,909,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The latest quarter net was reduced by $1.1 million as a result of the writeoff of the company's investment in the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp.'s secondary reserve.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about prime time on local television incorrectly described the moving of the ABC News program ''World News Tonight'' to 6:30 P.M. from 7 P.M. on Channel 7 in New York. It was the station, not the network, that moved the program.

title: THERMO PROCESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Concert: Chamber Music at a Festival in Santa Fe
description: The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival brings together a roster of prominent instrumentalists, mostly young, for six weeks of well-rehearsed concerts in the small, acoustically congenial auditorium of the Museum of Fine Arts here. Not everyone stays for the duration, but neither do the players jet in, deposit a standard program and jet back out. While here, they are mixed and matched on the concerts: Sunday's program, for instance, required one cello in each of four pieces, but four cellists played; their names - Timothy Eddy, Marcy Rosen, Nathaniel Rosen and Carter Brey -give an idea of the roster's level.

title: SOLITEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax loss of $200,000 from reversal of research and development contract income, $116,000 in expenses associated with the termination of an officer, an extraordinary charge of $98,000 from reversal of tax credits, a pretax gain of $191,000 on disposal of an investment, and a $399,000 credit for reversal of accrued federal income taxes which are no longer estimated as payable. c-Includes a pretax loss of $100,000 from reversal of contract income, expenses of $116,000 associated with termination of an officer, a pretax gain of $191,000 on the disposal of an investment in an affiliate, a pretax gain of $118,000 on the sale of a division, a $277,000 credit for reversal of accrued federal income taxes which are no longer estimated as payable and an extraordinary gain of $77,000 from debt restructuring. d-Net loss and includes for the 9 months a pretax charge of $4,105,000 related to writeoff of certain intangible assets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 9 about mail-in tests for AIDS virus infection incompletely described the procedures of National AIDS Testing Hotline Inc.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies of Business Day yesterday about stock offerings by Goldome incorrectly characterized their size. The savings and loan institution raised $170 million, which is most of the $240 million it originally hoped to raise.

title: NOVO INDUSTRI A-S reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months include results for the Danish Ferrosan Group, acquired in the fourth quarter of 1986. Novo said it wrote off about $2.9 million in the first half of 1987 in anticipation of a loss on investments in research and development related companies. The share earnings are per American Depositary Share. The results for all periods translated at the June 30, 1987 exchange rate of one U.S. dollar equals 6.95 Danish kroner.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: 'UP TO THE JUDGES'
description: For nearly 200 years now the United States has lived under a Constitution enforced by judges. Our system was unique for most of that time. But now, to a far greater extent than we generally realize, other democracies have adopted the view that judges should protect individual liberty from invasion by governments.

title: COPLEY PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTHERN MINERAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transcript of Reagan Address on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech this evening, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: NEWHALL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a writedown of $1.1 million on oil and gas producing fields. Share earnings are in units.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its share in losses of 50-percent subsidiaries in the latest second quarter was $160,000, compared with $869,000 in the year- ago quarter. For the 6 months, the company's share in those losses was $648,000 in the latest period and $1,315,000 in the prior period.

title: Bush Taking Some Positions At Odds With White House
description: Vice President Bush, long President Reagan's faithful No. 2, has gradually begun to take positions that differ, however subtly, from those of the White House.

title: The Marriage Tax Isn't Dead Yet
description: LEAD: While the effects of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 have been debated from here to kingdom come, it is curious that the one topic that has received scant coverage is how the new law will affect the tax consequences of being married.

title: Fanciful Designs In Wood And Fiber
description: A FANTASY menagerie - the turtles, birds and insects that are part of Judy Kensley McKie's furniture designs - now occupies the space usually reserved for more restrained handcrafted furniture at the Pritam & Eames Gallery in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Search For Outer Limit of 'Glasnost'
description: Less than four years ago, the exiled poet Joseph Brodsky, who lives in the United States, gave a lecture on the surrealistic novels of Andrei Platonov, a Soviet author, and was bitterly certain of one thing: ''These books never were published in Soviet Russia, and they never will be published there, for they come closest to doing to the system what it has done to its subjects.''

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After special charges of $7.5 million and $5.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively, arising from the disposition of two businesses and the writedown of certain inventories, less the effect of adopting new pension standards in accordance with FASB No. 87.

title: Justice Marshall in Hospital With Blood Clot in His Foot
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court was admitted to Bethesda Naval Hospital today suffering from a blood clot in his right foot.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INUSTRIES reports earnings for 13wks to July 4
description: b-Includes a loss of $7,000 for the quarter and a gain of $3,065,000 for the 6 months, both on disposal of facilities, and also includes an extraordinary item of $141,000 from call premium on repurchase of debentures for both periods. c-Includes losses of $265,000 for the quarter and $296,000 for the 6 months on disposal of facilities; the 6 months also includes equity in earnings of assoc. co. of $99,000.

title: New York Soars to a Record In Financial Industry Jobs
description: The surging financial market has pushed employment in the securities and commodities industry in New York City past 150,000 for the first time, part of a steady growth during the bull market of the last five years, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Reagan Leaves Gaps In Discussion of Bork
description: In reiterating his backing for Judge Robert H. Bork for the Supreme Court, President Reagan repeated tonight that none of Judge Bork's 400 opinions had been overturned by the High Court.

title: A Good Veto, if . . .
description: The New York Legislature approved new payment formulas for the state's hospital reimbursement program, which expires Dec. 31. Now Governor Cuomo has slapped his veto onto this complex piece of legislation.

title: MICRO HEALTHSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year includes more than $1 million in development and marketing expenses related to its Medtake Data System.

title: New York City Refuses to Use Private Ambulances as Backup
description: New York City's municipal ambulance system, which has been under fire for increasingly slow responses to life-and-death calls, has declined to use an estimated 270 commercial and volunteer corps ambulances that would be available to help fill the gap.

title: Talking Deals; Debate Grows On Insider Plan
description: INSIDER traders have played fast and loose with information about sensitive corporate deals whenever they could get their hands on it. Now the Securities and Exchange Commission is trying to curb the use of such information by spelling out more clearly what is and is not legal.

title: NEW HEAD OF U.S. BAR ASSOCIATION: ROBERT MacCRATE
description: Robert MacCrate, who took over as president of the American Bar Association today, began his one-year term with rave reviews - not for his professionalism or his dedication to public service, but for his singing.

title: CONCERT: ANDRE WATTS PLAY MOZART
description: IN the raft of cancellations and postponements that afflicted the early days of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival, Andre Watts had to withdraw from his scheduled July 12 piano recital because of bursitis. He made it up Sunday night, but his concerto appearances this week - the Mozart Concerto No. 24 in C minor (K. 491) with George Cleve and the Festival Orchestra Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, with a repeat last night - were as originally planned.

title: Chad Reports 4th Day of Attacks by Libyan Planes
description: For the fourth day in a row, Libyan warplanes attacked Chadian positions today with ''napalm and fragmentation bombs,'' the state radio said.

title: Stage: 'Calisto,' at the Festival Latino
description: LUST, greed and deception pervert innocence in the 15th-century Spanish work of Fernando de Rojas usually called ''La Celestina,'' and turn the garden where two teen-agers meet and fall in love into what the girl's father calls ''a lagoon of slime, full of snakes.''

title: Canada M.P.'s Move to Tighten Rules on Refugees
description: A month after 173 Indian Sikhs and one Turkish woman landed clandestinely on Nova Scotia's coast and claimed refugee status, the Canadian Government has opened an emergency session of Parliament to tighten what has been one of the Western world's most liberal refugee systems.

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Health Experts Fault U. S. on Response to AIDS
description: Efforts to prevent the spread of AIDS have been hampered by weak Federal leadership and inadequate funds, according to leading health experts interviewed for a Congressional study released today.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $78,000. c-Net loss

title: KAPPA NETWORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Photo of Sue Chin Lim, a teaching assistant, instructing high school students in a remedial math class at Boston University. (NYT/Rick Friedman) Job + Classes - Anti-Dropout Plan
description: Children from impoverished homes can lose as much reading skill over a summer as they gain in a whole school year, according to educators here who are adding remedial instruction to a Federal program that gives summer jobs to poor teen-agers.

title: VIDEO LIBRARY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 6-month net is restated for changes in the amortization period for video cassettes and a change in the estimated period tapes were held prior to sale.

title: Ford Motor Credit
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $300 million of 9 1/8 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 99 1/2, to yield 9.223 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The seven-year notes are not callable before maturity and yield about 70-hundredths of a percentage point more than comparable Treasury notes. The issue was rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: RALEIGH FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $344,000 writeoff of the FISLIC secondary reserve.

title: OAKITE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SITTING PRETTY ON THE CUSTOM FENCE
description: FENCES are as American as Tom Sawyer, who spent a legendary Missouri day whitewashing one, and Robert Frost, who recommended good ones between neighbors. American politicians are said to spend a lot of time mending them, while people who are noncommittal sit on them. Quiet, often recessive elements in American yards and fields, fences have entered both the dictionary, as idiomatic expressions, and the culture, as lore.

title: F.D.I.C. Assets Rise Modestly
description: Total assets of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation grew a modest $164 million in the first half of this year, to $18.4 billion, officials said today.

title: DI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
What Once Was Old Is Now Made New
description: TWO weeks ago Paula Zanger, a 24-year-old textile designer, and Peter Otsea, a 28-year-old furniture designer and carpenter, opened Zaot, a shop that sells refurbished found objects as well as a few chairs, ottomans and pillows designed by the proprietors. At least 10 times in the past year, Ms. Zanger and Mr. Otsea, above, have scoured the streets of New York for unwanted furniture. One night, they found chairs outside a church in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, and another night, Mr. Otsea's sister called with news of 20 chairs spilling from a trash bin in Chelsea in Manhattan. Once they had gathered about 75 pieces of furniture - including swivel chairs, stools and tables - Ms. Zanger designed textiles for upholstery, and Mr. Otsea stripped and refinished the furniture.

title: MODINE MFG reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Death Toll at Eight in Crash Of Boulder Into Tourist Bus
description: An eighth victim died today of injuries suffered Monday when a huge boulder tumbled down a mountainous slope and tore into a tourist bus.

title: MMI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Rights Unit Says Argentina Faced an Army Threat
description: The human-rights organization Americas Watch charged today that the Argentine Government and Congress were under ''ominous threat'' from the armed forces when they decided to limit the prosecution of military officers for human-rights violations.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 12wks to July 18
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $208,700 for the 12 weeks and $296,900 for the 28 weeks.
