title: DEMOCRATS STRESS POSITIVE IN SPEECH
description: Democratic Party leaders said tonight that they would not let President Reagan escape responsibility for what he had just called ''the Iran-contra mess,'' but they also expressed the hope that the President's speech might have opened the way for good feelings between Congress and the White House.

title: Banks Get New Powers
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it was granting new authority to American banks to swap their loans in developing countries for property.

title: Exhibits At Morgan Library
description: A 12-month series of major exhibitions is to start next month at the Pierpont Morgan Library with ''Views of Florence and Tuscany by Giuseppe Zocchi (1711-1767).'' On display from Sept. 1 to 27 will be 76 drawings by Zocchi of Florentine churches, piazzas and palaces and of villas of the Tuscan countryside. Many of the buildings and villas he portrayed will also be shown in modern photographs.

title: SAVANNAH FOODS & INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Motorized Wheelbarrows and More
description: Tens of thousands of tools and gadgets designed to make life a bit easier, or at least more fun, made their debut here this week at the National Hardware Show. Manufacturers played show-and-tell for nearly 70,000 retailers and wholesalers scouting for merchandise they hope will tickle the consumer's fancy.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,969,000 and $8,222,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Sports People; Boyd Out for Season
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the right-hander who helped lead the Boston Red Sox into the World Series last season, will be out for the rest of the season with a small tear in a ligament in his right shoulder.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: DOG-DAY heat and humidity call on air-conditioners to deliver peak performance under grueling conditions. Even if your air-conditioner was properly prepared for use at the start of the season, you should inspect and maintain it at least once in midsummer to assure that it performs well in the season's second half.

title: BAMBERGER POLYMERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUNSHINE MINING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NATIONAL MINE SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $196,000.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Clark Kellogg, a forward for the Indiana Pacers, announced his retirement yesterday after 18 months of rigorous rehabilitation for an injured left knee that had left him sidelined for most of the last two seasons. . . . Fredd Young, the linebacker, signed a series of one-year contracts with the Seattle Seahawks, leaving Brian Bosworth as the only unsigned player with the team. . . . Chuck Noll, head coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers, said of Rod Woodson, a cornerback from Purdue who was the Steelers' top draft choice but who remains unsigned: ''Some football players are concerned about becoming the best players, others are concerned only with becoming the best paid.'' Woodson has developed into one of the world's top high hurdlers and is scheduled to return to the European track circuit this weekend in Cologne, West Germany.

title: Schools and Ethics: More Than Just Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: SPEAR FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $83,881 and $503,032 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $177,470 and $349,633 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: ARNOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes interest expenses of $321,634 and $635,617 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of $123,666 from a litigation settlement for both the quarter and 6 months; and the 6-month also includes an interest gain of $19,854.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2 1/2-for- 1 stock split in June. The latest periods' results include gains of $675,000, or about 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $1,350,000, or 4 cents a share, in the 6 months from an accounting change.

title: Archbishop Antonio J. Plaza, Catholic Leader in Argentina
description: Archbishop Antonio Jose Plaza, a controversial leader of Argentina's conservative Roman Catholic Church, died here Tuesday night after a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: Indictment in Syracuse: A Mayor's 16-Year Trail
description: The Federal indictment that charges Lee Alexander with extorting more than $1.5 million from city contractors here begins with the oath of office that he took four times during his 16 years as Mayor. To Mr. Alexander, whose public career earned him a national reputation as an expert on urban problems, the oath was fulfilled.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Federal Agency Investigates Safety Charges on G.M. Cars
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating complaints about sudden acceleration in three 1986-87 models of General Motors cars.

title: HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $1,278,000 for the purchase of shares from a foreign investment group. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $210,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 6 months.

title: Banks Study Strategies To Replenish Reserves
description: Now that the nation's major banks have used up most of their cushion against loan losses to account for problem Latin American loans, how are they going to rebuild it?

title: BANCROFT CONV FUND reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Group Assails Plan to Charge Midtown Cars
description: A group of prominent business leaders yesterday attacked a proposal to charge motorists $10 to enter the Manhattan business district, an idea that Mayor Koch endorsed last week as a way of reducing air pollution.

title: Dutch Credit Card Deal
description: The Bank of America is negotiating, it said today, to sell its 38,000-customer Dutch Visa credit card operation to Verenigde Spaarbank N.V., a Dutch savings and loan company.

title: HEI INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Space Weapon Is Disparaged by Missile Lab
description: An orbiting weapon meant to destroy enemy missiles by smashing into them will fail to shield the United States from new Soviet missiles planned for the next decade, according to a report by a Federal laboratory working on President Reagan's antimissile plan.

title: School Union Chief Killed in Brooklyn In Gangland Style
description: The head of the custodians' union at the New York City Board of Education was shot to death yesterday morning in an execution-style attack as he sat in his car near his Brooklyn home.

title: Harcourt Considers Asset Sale
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the publishing house that recently repulsed a takeover attempt by Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, has disclosed that it might have to sell assets if its ambitious cost-cutting falls short of its goals.

title: Restoring Sharp Edges To Dull Kitchen Knives
description: SHARPENING knives is ''a dying art,'' according to Nicholas DeVito, who has been in the business 50 years. He worked with his father and grandfather, and his grandson now represents the fifth generation of his family to work at Delbon Cutlery, a concern that has been sharpening and selling knives since 1840.

title: LONDON HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Old-Movie Houses Dwindle And the Die-Hard Buffs Worry
description: Old-movie buffs count the casualties. The Thalia is closed and the Metro has gone first-run. Cross off the New Yorker, too. Also the Carnegie Hall, Bleecker Street and Hollywood Twin Cinemas. And don't forget the old Elgin.

title: A Good Veto
description: Many retired New York State employees and their survivors doubtless face serious financial difficulties. Though their pensions have been supplemented by special legislation, the increases have not kept pace with the cost of living. The same applies to pensioners of local governments, including New York City.

title: Events; Art Classes and a Brooklyn Tour
description: Folk Art Institute Workshops

title: Advertising; B.J.K.&E. to Join Colgate Agency Roster
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Minneapolis, has not only been retained to handle the $4 million Minnetonka Group I account, but will also be able to boast of being a Colgate-Palmolive agency.

title: MTS SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ITT Notes
description: The ITT Corporation is offering $100 million of 8 3/8 percent notes due in 1990 at a price of 99.725, to yield 8.48 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. The notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P. and yield about 54-hundredths of a percentage point more than the Treasury's new three-year notes.

title: U.S. Studies Financial Dealings Of Businessman Slain on East Side
description: Federal prosecutors have begun studying the tangled financial dealings of a flamboyant businessman shot gangland-style in a Manhattan restaurant last weekend, United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Grumbles and Moans About Baker
description: The tenure of Howard H. Baker Jr. as White House chief of staff has not been easy. In trying to act as a buffer between the moderate and conservative factions that have long contended for power in the Reagan Administration, he has acquired some painful bruises and disappointed some old friends in his first six months in office.

title: BONN TRADES SPY FOR EAST GERMAN
description: West Germany today exchanged a top Soviet-bloc spy for an East German prisoner whose release was long sought by Bonn.

title: Fireman's Fund To Buy Its Stock
description: The Fireman's Fund Corporation, a major insurance company based in Novato, Calif., said that its board has authorized the repurchase of up to six million shares, or about 9.5 percent of its outstanding common stock. In December, the board had authorized the repurchase of 5 percent of common shares, nearly all of which have been purchased.

title: 'Mayor Stein': His Foes Wince At the Thought
description: After visiting Mayor Koch in the hospital last week, Governor Cuomo pronounced him in great shape. When City Council President Andrew J. Stein dropped by that same day, he reported that the Mayor's speech was still slurred.

title: CINEPLEX ODEON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Astro Runs Are Only Relief Ryan Needs
description: In suggesting that he might use Nolan Ryan as a relief pitcher in an effort to end his eight-game losing streak, Hal Lanier, manager of the Houston Astros, threatened to change baseball thinking dramatically. The Boston Red Sox aren't winning so make Wade Boggs a pinch-hitter. The Philadelphia Phillies are having trouble so make Mike Schmidt a utility infielder. The Yankees are struggling so when Rickey Henderson returns (if Rickey Henderson returns) make him a pinch-runner.

title: GCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $46,957,000 from financial restructuring for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $1,496,000 and an extraordinary gain of $962,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 1-for-50 reverse stock split.

title: PIEDMONT AVIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $5,047,000 related to divestitures. Preferred stock dividends exceeded net in the latest quarter.

title: GALVESTON-HOUSTON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,194,000 from a note redemption and a tax credit of $1,742,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $9,187,000 for the quarter and $12,248,000 for the 6 months.

title: CANCER OF COLON IS BELIEVED LINKED TO DEFECT IN GENE
description: Scientists in Britain have found strong evidence of a genetic defect that contributes to the development of colon cancer, one of the most common forms of human malignant disease.

title: Jersey Panel Rejects Caesars World Plan
description: In a move that could reopen the battle for Caesars World Inc., the New Jersey Casino Control Commission yesterday rejected the company's recapitalization plan, saying it ''would abandon a prudent, successful corporate strategy for an imprudent, risky one.''

title: Crazy Eddie Offer Dropped
description: Crazy Eddie Inc. lost its sole remaining suitor yesterday when the company's founder and chairman, Eddie Antar, indicated that the company's worsening financial condition no longer made his offer viable.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The bath in our four-year-old house is over the living room and kitchen. When the toilet is flushed, the water gushes loudly inside the walls. Is there a less noisy toilet, or any other way to reduce the flushing sounds? A.Some flushing mechanisms and bowls are more noisy than others, but I think your toilet is not causing the problem. Plastic pipe was probably used for the waste lines; this does not muffle the sound of flowing water as well as older cast-iron pipes.

title: A Teaching Task On Flood Insurance
description: DAVID L. COBB, who around his office at the Federal Emergency Management Agency is sometimes referred to as ''the flood expert,'' tells of a man who lost his home during a hurricane in the early 1960's.

title: Dow Declines 11.16, to 2,669.32
description: LEAD: After a two-day surge that drove the Dow Jones industrial average and most other market gauges to stunning peaks, stock prices fell prey yesterday to profit taking and a general sense of exhaustion.

title: Biologists' Search Finds More Dolphin Deaths Than Expected
description: Marine biologists searching for clues to the mysterious deaths of bottle-nosed dolphins this summer flew over Chesapeake Bay on Tuesday and discovered the problem is more widespread than they had suspected.

title: NBC OFFERS 'THE DAYS AND NIGHTS OF MOLLY DODD'
description: WELL, ''The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd'' seems to have made it, after all. The series was created by Jay Tarses, who is considered a bit of a maverick in television land because, among other things, he hates laugh tracks, and was supposed to make its debut on NBC last September. But realizing that it was dealing with something slightly different, the network kept the show on the shelf for nine months. ''Molly Dodd'' finally had its premiere this spring and, lo and behold, has managed to spend most of its time - Thursdays at 9:30 - in the charmed ratings circle of the Top 10. NBC has ordered 13 more episodes. It is unlikely that they will be kept on hold very long.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: 10 Paintings By O'Keeffe To Be Sold
description: Ten paintings by Georgia O'Keeffe - five of flowers, three of trees and two of leaves - will be auctioned at Sotheby's on Dec. 3.

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-Includes a $4,240,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: AMC ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Alitalia in Booking Unit
description: Italy's Alitalia has joined with six other air carriers - Swissair, British Airways, KLM Royal Dutch, Austrian Airlines, British Caledonian and United Airlines - in a plan to set up a European airline computer booking system, Swissair said today. The system is to be known as Galileo. A rival system, named Amadeus, is backed by West Germany's Lufthansa, Air France, Spain's Iberia and Scandinavian Airline Systems. The systems will offer services ranging from car rentals to theater tickets.

title: REPUBLIC SAVINGS FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERFACE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Both latest periods include results from Winterhalter Inc., acquired in December 1986, and have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend distributed to shareholders June 16.

title: Restored Retreats in Texas Hill Country
description: WHILE much of Texas is arid, the breezy hill country surrounding Austin is verdant with hardy grasses and oak and cypress trees. Rivers cut through the gently rolling landscape. Here, in sleepy little towns that look almost the same as they did 100 years ago, many Texans from Austin and San Antonio have restored houses as weekend retreats.

title: Speech Skirts Issues And Sets New Goals
description: Addressing the American people tonight, President Reagan acknowledged that after nine painful and confusing months of the Iran-contra affair, ''I know you have doubts in your own minds about what happened.''

title: ALBERT C. WINTERS
description: Albert C. Winters, president of Manhattan Store Interiors, Inc., a Brooklyn company that makes and sells store fixtures, died of a heart attack last Sunday at his home in Mill Neck, L.I. He was 66 years old.

title: Uncertainty on 10-Year Notes
description: The Treasury sold $9.25 billion of 10-year notes yesterday, amid conflicting views among securities dealers about investor demand for the issue at yesterday's average yield of 8.74 percent.

title: An Abiding Love Affair With the Bomb
description: The movie ''Dr. Strangelove'' was subtitled ''How I Stopped Worrying and Learned to Love the Bomb.'' The current debate over the pending agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate nuclear ballistic missiles with ranges of 300 to 3,500 miles shows that many strategic thinkers have an abiding affection for nuclear weaponry.

title: 12-Meters Will Sail In 4-Race Pro Tour
description: Sailboat racing joined the ranks of big-time professional sports as plans were announced here today for a 12-Meter racing circuit worth $1 million in prize money.

title: 14% Dutch Jobless Rate
description: The Dutch unemployment rate rose to 14 percent in July, the Social Affairs Ministry said today. By the end of the month, 686,100 Netherlanders were out of work, up 4,300 from the previous month, according to preliminary figures released by the ministry. The figures have been adjusted for seasonal factors and do not include the estimated 600,000 people receiving state disability payments.

title: Where Dolls Aren't Quite Child's Play
description: The competition is stiff, as 12,000 dolls vie for prizes at the 38th annual convention of the United Federation of Doll Clubs.

title: Texas Air's Offer Halted
description: A Federal District Court judge here today halted a controversial tender offer by the Texas Air Corporation for certain preferred stock held by employees of its Eastern Air Lines subsidiary.

title: The Joffrey Finds a Summer Home in the Midwest
description: The Joffrey Ballet and the Joffrey II dancers, an apprentice company, spent a month in Iowa City this summer working on Tchaikovsky's Christmas ballet, ''The Nutcracker.'' which they will add to their repertory. A mix of artistic and financial concerns brought them to the Midwest.

title: OFFICELAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
PRESIDENT OF BIG BAKERY CONSIDERS OWNERSHIP
description: LEAD: For Robert W. Hatch, the president and chief executive of the Interstate Bakeries Corporation, running the nation's largest independent wholesale baking company is not enough: He would like to own it.

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANGERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $100,858 and $251,311 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a realized investment gain of $279,306 and $480,195 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said a federal income tax adjustment favorably affected the 1987 6-month operating income by $314,000.

title: 'Living Daylights' Holds Movie Box-Office Lead
description: The latest incarnation of James Bond, in ''The Living Daylights,'' did $7.7 million in business in its second weekend.

title: Brooklyn Won't Fight Ruling on Trash Barge
description: Brooklyn officials said yesterday that they would not challenge a court ruling issued Monday that allows New York City to burn the 3,100 tons of trash on the barge Mobro anchored in New York Harbor.

title: Anchorage Feels the Heat
description: The United States' denial of a visa to a Chilean athlete scheduled to compete at the Pan American Games may have ended any chance Anchorage had of winning a bid to be host to the 1994 winter Olympic Games and could hurt any future American bids to hold the Olympics, the vice president of the International Olympic Committee said today.

title: Brooklyn Couple Linked to Turoff Are Sentenced in Tax Fraud Case
description: A Brooklyn couple convicted last spring of income-tax charges along with Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, were sentenced yesterday to four months of house detention and three years' probation.

title: Soviet Police Shadow Unofficial Publication
description: Policemen showed up today at an apartment where several dissidents were typing copies of an unofficial magazine, Glasnost, and made arrangements to take the dissidents to the police station, the magazine's editor said.

title: CALPROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Film: 'Monster Squad'
description: THE best thing about ''The Monster Squad'' is the ad campaign, a series of wanted posters for Count Dracula, the Wolfman and other anti-social types. These can be seen in most subway stations for the cost of a token.

title: WEBB, DEL E, INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A SINGER FINDS HIS CREATIVE RANGE
description: ''One of the mistakes singers of my sort make nowadays is to spread themselves too thin,'' said Jerry Hadley, who has been so busy lately that a casual observer might worry whether he follows his own injunction.

title: STATER BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
A MUSICIAN FOLLOWS HIS IDOL
description: WHILE classical music has a long-established tradition in which young musicians are carefully groomed to assume roles handed down from professional mentors, it is the rare jazz musician who finds the opportunity to step into the shoes of his childhood idol. But that is exactly what Walt Levinsky, one of New York's busiest studio musicians, is doing at Michael's Pub right now. Five nights a week, Mr. Levinsky leads a hand-picked ensemble of 14 alumni from Benny Goodman's big band in classic arrangements created over three decades. To top it off, he gets to play many of the Goodman clarinet solos he learned by heart when he was a child growing up in Paterson, N.J.

title: Juilliard Season Opener
description: A concert by the three winners of the Gina Bachauer International Piano Scholarship Competition will open the 1987-88 performance season at 9 P.M. Sept. 16 at the Juilliard School, Broadway and West 66th Street. The concert, which is free, will feature Gustavo Romero, Dan-Wen Wei and Jeannie Yu. It will be broadcast live over WQXR-FM (96.3) and WQXR-AM (1560). Ticket information: 874-7515.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $62,740 for the quarter and 6 months. The share earnings adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend paid in February 1987.

title: Underhanded Days in the Big Leagues
description: To the Editor:

title: BELVEDERE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $223,000 and $719,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After realized investment gains of $707,000 for the quarter and $1,414,000 for the 6 months.

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a writedown of $9,278,000 for the quarter and $20,382,000 for the 6 months.

title: IMMUNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Banks Wins; Cuban Is Next
description: ''Right now,'' Kelcie Banks said, ''the main thing is to maintain who I am.''

title: An Avenue Out Of the Afghan War
description: LEAD: The Afghan resistance, now better supplied than ever, has recently won important military successes in key regions of the country. This is unknown to most of the outside world, but not to their opponents.

title: CAMPAIGN FORMED OPPOSING CONTRAS
description: A coalition of political and religious organizations opposed to aid for the Nicaraguan rebels is embarking on a national campaign to counter conservative groups seeking Congressional approval of more aid.

title: RONALD BUSCH, 58, A PUBLISHER, DIES
description: Ronald Busch, a leader in paperback-book publishing for 30 years, died during triple-bypass heart surgery Wednesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SCIENTIFIC SYSTEMS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $43,000 and $200,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and for the 6 months also includes a gain of $194,000 from the sale of a building, land and certain equipment. c-Net loss

title: Espionage Trial of Marine Hears From C.I.A. Agents
description: The espionage court-martial of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree heard testimony in closed session today from witnesses identified by defense lawyers as Central Intelligence Agency officials code-named ''Big John'' and ''Little John.''

title: Body Unearthed on S.I. Is That of Missing Girl
description: The police yesterday identified the body found buried in a shallow grave on the grounds of the Staten Island Developmental Center on Wednesday night as that of Jennifer Schweiger, ending a grueling 35-day search for the 12-year-old handicapped girl.

title: ROSS REIMUELLER
description: Ross Reimueller, a conductor and music administrator who worked at the New York City Opera and led performances of both opera and musicals, died Wednesday evening in Los Angeles. He was 49 years old.

title: SEA CONTAINERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: GARDENAMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $17,000 and $90,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Hotel to Donate Money For AIDS Care Benefit
description: The Marriott Marquis Hotel, a corporate sponsor of the ''Dancing for Life'' benefit on Oct. 5 for AIDS care, research and education, plans to donate a portion of its Labor Day weekend room receipts to the benefit.

title: Nicaragua Warns U.S. on Contra Aid
description: Nicaragua's Vice President says the Sandinista Government is ready to restore full press and political freedoms, but only if the United States stops aiding the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Louis Peck, 82, Former Judge Who Was a Bronx Legislator
description: Louis Peck, a New York State and City legislator for 12 years and a Municipal and Civil Court judge in New York City for 20 more, died of heart disease yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 'Phantom' to Open Jan. 26
description: ''The Phantom of the Opera'' will open Jan. 26 at the Majestic Theater, according to a spokesman for the show, Sandra Manley. The Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, which is directed by Harold Prince, is to begin preview performances Jan. 9.

title: PILOTS ASSAIL NEW RULES AT LOS ANGELES AIRPORT
description: Operators of private planes today criticized new Federal flight rules adopted for the Los Angeles International Airport after a rise in near accidents in recent months.

title: Pentagon Says Contras Get 'Tactical Initiative'
description: An internal Pentagon document asserts that the United States-backed guerrillas fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government have destroyed at least five Soviet-made helicopters this year and have seized the ''tactical initiative'' on the battlefield.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income of $7,404 and a loss of $98,853 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations, and the quarter also includes a tax credit of $16,872. c-Net income d-Includes a tax credit of $14,300 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: CHAMPION PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings results are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in April.

title: New York City Opera
description: The New York City Opera will introduce a new production of Mozart's ''Zauberflote,'' directed by Lotfi Mansouri and conducted by Sergiu Comissiona, this evening at 8 at the New York State Theater. Tomorrow afternoon at 2, City Opera will present Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' and tomorrow evening at 8, Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly.'' Tickets are $8 to $42. Information: 870-5570.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: The Allegis Corporation said its United Airlines unit had ordered 60 Pratt & Whitney 4000 jet engines and spares in a deal worth about $400 million. Pratt & Whitney is a unit of United Technologies Inc. The engines will power 15 Boeing 747-400's ordered by the airline from the Boeing Company in May.

title: Visa Denial: A Basic Conflict
description: In the next few days, the State Department will try to resolve a tricky diplomatic problem that has jeopardized the chances of the United States to stage future Olympic Games.

title: Insurers Shift Health Costs to Consumers
description: The surgeon's bill for Dorothy Thomas's foot operation at Lenox Hill Hospital was $2,500. Mrs. Thomas, a freelance writer, said she got back $394 from her Blue Shield health insurance and $1,106 from her major medical policy. That left her owing $1,000.

title: In India, 40 Years Free, Pride Turns to Bitterness
description: Forty years ago, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru unfurled the flag of a new nation and spoke with hope of its ''tryst with destiny.'' Today, Nehru's grandson, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, governs an India shaken by violence and scandal, uncertain whether the years since independence have brought more problems than progress.

title: Daniel Katz, Chairman Of a Parking Concern
description: Daniel P. Katz, board chairman and chief executive officer of the Kinney System Inc., a nationwide parking company, died of a gunshot wound Wednesday. The police termed his death an apparent suicide. He was 48 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: ATALANTA-SOSNOFF CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6-month results are reported on a pro forma basis. The company said year-ago pro forma earnings reflect pro forma provision for income taxes and adjustment of shareholders compensation to the levels provided in current employment agreements for periods before closing of the company's initial public offering on June 17, 1986. The company also said the year-ago second quarter period reflected substantial tax credits resulting from the termination of the company's ''S'' Corporation status in June 1986.

title: Israelis Use Tear Gas to Stop Protest at the U.S. Consulate
description: Two people were wounded and six were arrested today when the police broke up a demonstration in front of the American Consulate in East Jerusalem to protest the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Writers Guild Rules On Screenplay Credit
description: The Writers Guild of America East upheld an earlier ruling yesterday that the playwright Israel Horovitz be added to the credits, as co-writer, of ''A Man in Love,'' a new film directed by Diane Kurys.

title: BRADLEY REAL ESTATE TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February 1987.

title: NORTH-WEST TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: Dow Jumps To 2,691.49, Up by 22.17
description: Wall Street marked the fifth birthday of the bull market yesterday in appropriate fashion: The Dow Jones industrial average jumped to another record close, its third of the week.

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN CHOCOLATE FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BELLO A H reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''You love your family, you love your husband, you love your children and you love Elvis.'' - Cathi Averell [ A1:3. ]

title: CONVERGENT SOLUTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a net realized loss from securities transactions of $1,947,796 in the latest year, compared with a net realized gain of $3,529,657 in the previous year. Revenue represents net assets, and net income represents net investment income.

title: Money Funds Decrease
description: Assets of the nation's 392 money market mutual funds decreased by $75.3 million, to $241.9 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 100 institutional funds were up $171.1 million, to $66.9 billion. Assets of the 200 general purpose funds were down $757.9 million, to $68.3 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds increased $511.5 million, to $106.7 billion.

title: Botha Says Foreign Envoys Undermine Pretoria's Rule
description: President P. W. Botha said today that some Western diplomats in South Africa were promoting opposition outside Parliament and hinted at steps to restrict certain diplomats' movements.

title: FILM: 'TOKYO TIME,' JAPANESE IN U.S.
description: WHETHER the twain can meet is the issue addressed in ''Living on Tokyo Time,'' the twain being Kyoko, a young Japanese woman who comes to San Francisco with a desire ''to have independent American experience,'' and Ken, a Japanese-American youth with the accent on American. He knows no Japanese, she knows little English, but that doesn't stop them from getting married so that she can stay in the United States.

title: STEAMOATS, MAGIC, DANCING AND ARTS AND CRAFTS AROUND THE HUDSON VALLEY
description: Steamboats, magic, dancing, and arts and crafts await visitors to the Hudson Valley this mid-August weekend.

title: CCC INFORMATION SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON: The Making of an American Symbol. By Barry Schwartz. 250 pages. Illustrated. The Free Press. $22.50.

title: Guarneri Quartet
description: The Guarneri Quartet and Lydia Artymiw, pianist, will present works by Beethoven, Mendelssohn and Faure tonight at 9 in the Spanish Courtyard at the Caramoor Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y. The pianist Lillian Kallir and the New York Chamber Soloists will play an all-Mozart program tomorrow evening at 8:30 at Caramoor's Venetian Theater. And Sunday at 5:30 P.M., the pianist Andras Schiff will perform pieces by Bach, Schubert and Brahms in the Spanish Courtyard. Tickets for tomorrow evening's concert are $10 to $27.50; tickets for the other concerts are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-5035.

title: This Year, Jets' Top Picks Ready to Start
description: Reversing last year's dismal record, a top draft choice will finally start a game for the Jets this weekend, when the team's No. 1 and No. 2 picks start in place of incumbents who are holding out.

title: Bid Lifted to $2.43 Billion Is Taken by Jim Walter
description: The Jim Walter Corporation, a leading builder of low-cost houses, has agreed to a sweetened all-cash takeover offer of $60 a share, or $2.43 billion, from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the highly successful leveraged buyout firm.

title: CONSUMERS WATER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects a 4 cents a share gain from the sale of properties.

title: Article 696887 -- No Title
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who says he gets more bang for his political buck than any other Presidential candidate, has raised more than $520,000 so far and hopes to double that with two major fund-raising events this month in New York and Chicago, a spokesman said today.

title: LINCOLN N C REALTY FUND reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AME INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COHU INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bach in the Bronx
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will present a program of works by Bach, Mozart and Wagner, conducted by Michael Spierman and including Amanda Halgrimson, soprano, as soloist, Sunday at 2 P.M. at Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx and again at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall on the Fordham University Bronx Rose Hill Campus at Southern Boulevard. Admission is free. Information: 549-1899.

title: BOSTON EDISON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $9,292,000 from the sale of its steam business.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects litigation expenses of $59,000 for the quarter and $239,000 for the 6 months. Corrected from Tuesday, Aug. 11, editions.

title: Health Agency Sets Guidelines For AIDS Exam
description: Federal health officials today recommended routine tests for AIDS infection for the sex partners of those who carry the AIDS virus, people with other sexually transmitted diseases, intravenous drug users and others.

title: Bank of Montreal Buying Into Nesbitt
description: The Bank of Montreal said today that it had agreed to acquire a 75 percent equity interest in the securities dealer Nesbitt Thomson Inc. for up to $290.9 million ($218 million United States).

title: Portrait Painter Is Accused In Theft of Rare Documents
description: A portrait painter and art scholar was arrested in Boston today in connection with the theft of rare documents from the Library of Congress and the National Archives, including letters written by Abraham Lincoln and James Whistler, the American painter.

title: Police Seeking More Witnesses In Baffling Case
description: After two days of investigation, New York City detectives said yesterday that they still did not know the reason for Wednesday's gangland-style slaying of the head of the custodians' union at the Board of Education.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Climb Again

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Film: 'No Way Out,' Washington Drama
description: THOUGH its title has been used before, and though its story about a political conspiracy and cover-up is guaranteed to bring out the plausible in the least rational of moviegoers, ''No Way Out'' has the exuberance of something freshly conceived. It's so effective, in fact, that when it's all over, you might want to sit through the beginning again just to see if the end is justified by the means. I suspect that it is.

title: Firefighters Union Cites Lax Building Inspections
description: New York City firefighters chronically fail to inspect many high-rise buildings because of a shortage of manpower, the president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association told a City Council committee yesterday.

title: New World Offers To Talk on Kenner
description: New World Entertainment Ltd., the filmmaker and comic book publisher, said it was willing to negotiate with Kenner Parker Toys Inc. on all aspects of its offer to acquire the company, including price. Kenner Parker's stock is trading well above the $41-a-share price of the tender offer that New World began Wednesday. It closed down 62.5 cents a share, at $45.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading today. The deal is valued at about $475 million.

title: Sports People; Dolphins Sign Strock
description: Don Strock, the veteran backup quarterback, signed a new contract with the Miami Dolphins yesterday, ending a two-week holdout. Strock is entering his 14th season with the Dolphins. He has started only 20 games but stands fourth on the team's passing list with 4,499 yards.

title: VALLEY FORGE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $687,754 and $765,861 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $926,000 and $1,294,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $301,466 and $502,076 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the quarter also includes net from discontinued operations of $9,405, and the 6 months include a loss from discontinued operations of $31,334.

title: Last Productive Chance For the Garbage Barge
description: To the Editor:

title: Play at Woods Hole
description: ''Lost Shoelaces,'' a musical entertainment designed by Edward Gorey and directed by Genie Stevens, will be presented by the Magical Oysters Theater tonight through Sunday and Aug. 20 to 23 at 8 P.M. at the Woods Hole Community Hall, Water Street, Woods Hole, Mass. Tickets are $10. Directions and reservations: (617) 540-3603.

title: Market Place; A Bull Market For Gold Bugs
description: FEW groups of investors have been as estatic over the soaring stock market this year as the gold bugs, who normally view any positive economic news as a disaster. Have the investors in gloom and doom suddenly been converted into optimists? Hardly. Rather, the gold bugs view each record-breaking advance in stock prices as a step closer to the inevitable end of the bull market.

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone to Acquire Direct Response Shop
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Krupp/Taylor U.S.A., one of the largest direct response agencies in the country. The Los Angeles agency, which has annual revenues of $40 million has offices in eight cities. Details of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: DENNING MOBILE ROBOTICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 1-for-25 reverse stock split effective on Nov. 18, 1986. The company is a development- stage company.

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Duarte Offers to Meet Rebels on Sept. 15 for Talks
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte offered today to meet leftist guerrillas in El Salvador on Sept. 15 for new peace talks, and he called on the Nicaraguan Government to open peace talks with its rebel opponents on the same day.

title: Sports People; Indictment Dropped
description: The one-count drug indictment against Garfield Heard, a former National Basketball Association forward, has been dismissed by a Maricopa County Superior Court Judge in Phoenix at the request of the prosecutor in the case and Heard's attorney.

title: New York City Is Striving To Reduce State Inmates
description: The most dangerous inmates on Rikers Island, those convicted of felonies and sentenced to state prisons, are demanding their rights. They want to go to prisons in upstate New York where they would have more room and more to do.

title: China Tugboat Chief Seized
description: Chinese authorities arrested the captain and first mate of a tugboat involved in a collision with a passenger ferry in May in which 105 people drowned. The China News Service, monitored in Hong Kong, said today that Capt. Tian Shouguang and First Mate Wang Jianguo were found to have breached navigation rules in the accident on the Yangtze River near Nantong on May 8. The agency said an investigation had found the crews of both vessels guilty of negligence.

title: WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $246,000 in the latest quarter and a loss of $44,000 from discontinued operations for the year-earlier period.

title: ART: JOHN MARIN'S OILS AT AN L.I. MUSEUM
description: JOHN MARIN was in some ways an artist with two careers. In the two decades after 1910, he established himself as a master of watercolor, absorbing the lessons of Fauvism, post-Impressionism and Cubism to form a distinct style and a major American reputation, which - nurtured by his dealer, Alfred Stieglitz -endured throughout his lifetime. But after 1930, Marin devoted himself increasingly to oil painting, a development that dismayed many of his most fervent admirers, including Stieglitz himself. In fact, it was 1950 - four years after his dealer's death and three years before his own - before Marin finally had an exhibition of only oil paintings at An American Place, Stieglitz's last gallery.

title: IRT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $176,000.

title: F.T.C. to Fight Sale by Shell
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would seek a court order blocking the Pacific Resources Company from buying the Hawaiian petroleum-products assets of the Shell Oil Company.

title: Lester Gaba, Mannequin Artist
description: Lester Gaba, who staged elaborate fashion shows in the 40's and 50's and created the lifelike display-window mannequins known as the Gaba Girls, died of cancer of the colon Wednesday at Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Housing Issues Spark Debates At Long Session
description: The New York City Board of Estimate, in a meeting that began yesterday and threatened to stretch through the weekend and into Monday, grappled with three key housing issues, including Mayor Koch's proposal for 17 new shelters for the homeless.

title: Bonds Soar In Last Day Of Auctions
description: The Treasury's August financing ended on a strong note yesterday, with a surge of demand from investors and speculators.

title: PUBLISHERS EQUIPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: The Long-Distance Sprinter
description: He was going to be as big as Michael Jackson, according to his manager, but the boos in the Coliseum on that gold-medal night in 1984 squashed that goal faster than you could say ''Victory Tour.''

title: Shall We Dance?
description: Social dancing, The Times reported this week, is dead. Health-conscious young people jump in the gym doing aerobics. Health-conscious older people labor in the barn doing the Virginia Reel. Everybody else lies on the couch watching ''Crocodile Dundee.'' What does it all mean? It means that pretty soon America's oldsters are going to have a new bedtime story to tell the kiddies.

title: NUTRITION WORLD reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: STANWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: 'Infiltrator,' On CBS
description: The big moment in ''Infiltrator'' comes toward the end: a young scientist, trapped in a cloud of poison gas, turns into a robot with a red light in his head. A moment later, he's back in his normal state, looking dreamily at the woman he loves, who is also a young scientist. ''Infiltrator,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight, is a particulary goofy one-hour movie.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-Net income

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
CHIEF AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
Defense Indigestion
description: Each year, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger sends Congress his ''heartburn'' letter, identifying pending legislative measures that the Pentagon finds offensive. This year it appears Mr. Weinberger has more than his usual case of indigestion.

title: Baseball; Niekro Loses Toronto Debut
description: Floyd Bannister spoiled the Toronto debut of Phil Niekro with a six-hitter, and the Chicago White Sox scored seven runs in the eighth inning tonight to beat the Blue Jays, 10-3, in front of a sellout crowd at Exhibition Stadium.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest 6 months.

title: MARCI INTERNATIONAL IMORTS reports earnings for Year to May 3
description: The company went public in February 1987.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Car Sales Up 12.1% on Incentives
description: Bolstered by buyer incentives, domestic car sales rose 12.1 percent in early August from the 1986 period, their best increase in four months, the seven domestic makers reported today.

title: In New York City, There Are No Ideal Circumstances for Milk
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate;
description: To witness the revitalization taking place in Hoboken, N.J., a visitor need not venture much beyond the PATH station at the southern end of the city. An area once noted for its unsavoriness because of the bars that catered to dockworkers in the waterfront's heyday has in recent years taken on a more genteel air, with sidewalk cafes, health clubs and even a takeout shop featuring food delicacies.

title: CHARTER-CRELLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter and 6-month results reflect the previously announced acquisition of Sebro Plastics Inc., effective May 22.

title: HEALTH MANAGEMENT ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $146,000 related primarily to the elimination of investment tax credit previously provided for during fiscal 1986.

title: Tree Scientist Tests Bacteria, Disobeying U.S. Regulations
description: A plant expert at Montana State University said today that he had injected genetically altered bacteria into about 14 elm trees after deliberately ignoring Federal regulations that he called ''almost ludicrous.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * First Commerce Corp., New Orleans, a bank holding company, promoted Thomas L. Callicutt Jr. to senior vice president and controller.

title: Bank Search In VW Case
description: Police investigating a currency fraud at the Volkswagen Company searched West Germany's central bank and seized papers belonging to a secretary of the bank's president, Karl Otto Pohl, it was reported today.

title: Daughter's Truancy Lands Parents in Jail
description: A court referee has sentenced the parents of a teen-ager who habitually missed school to jail.

title: Banks Generally Praise Fed's Third World Shift
description: In announcing earlier in the week that it would permit banks to acquire 100 percent of third world companies, the Federal Reserve provided an important mechanism for dealing with the debt crisis, bankers said yesterday.

title: U.S. Won't Aid U.N. Population Unit
description: Over strong Congressional and internal objections, the Agency for International Development announced today that it was again withholding its contribution to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities because of charges that the fund supports coerced abortion in China.

title: Ex-J.D.L. Head Pleads Guilty To Federal Bombing Charges
description: A former head of the Jewish Defense League and two associates pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that they took part in a series of ''terrorist bombings'' in the New York area since 1984, including a firebombing at Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center last October.

title: Quinones, Under Attack, to Leave As Schools Chief Six Months Early
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, whose stewardship of the nation's largest school system has come under increasing criticism, announced yesterday that he would retire Jan. 1, six months before his contract expires.

title: EUGENE BORDINAT Jr.
description: Eugene Bordinat Jr., a former chief designer for the Ford Motor Company, died Tuesday at Henry Ford hospital here, the company said today. He was 67 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 14, 1987
description: International A2-9

title: Sex Bias Suit Is Filed Over Laundry Charge
description: A sex discrimination lawsuit filed against a laundry asserts that it charges women more to clean their shirts than it does men.

title: Alberto-Culver Bid
description: The Alberto-Culver Company, the health and beauty-aids company that wants to acquire Lamaur Inc. in a deal worth about $135 million, said it had secured a $150 million revolving credit agreement from the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company to finance the bid. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Alberto-Culver said the agreement was subject to Alberto-Culver buying at least 30 percent of each class of Lamaur's voting stock. Minneapolis-based Lamaur, which makes personal-grooming products, has not responded to the bid.

title: Carrie Fisher, Novelist, Looks Back at the Edge
description: Carrie Fisher prowled her room at the Ritz-Carlton. She sipped a 7 Up, curled up briefly on the couch, bounced into the bathroom to fuss with her hair for the fourth time in 10 minutes and then returned, sipping a glass of milk.

title: LIFETIME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: b-After a tax credit of $422,000. The results for the latest quarter include results of Kimberly Services Inc. and National Medical Home Care Inc., acquired earlier this year. The year-ago results include only about one month of results from Superior Care Inc., acquired in May 1986. The company recorded a pre-tax gain of about $1.1 million in the latest quarter from the sale of part of its stake in Office Angels Ltd.

title: VSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: STOCKTON SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Phil Housley, considered one of the National Hockey League's best offensive defensemen, has signed a multiyear contract with the Buffalo Sabres. Housley had 21 goals and 46 assists last season to become the Sabres' leading goal scorer among defensemen. . . . Michael Olajide will fight Frank Tate for the vacated International Boxing Federation middleweight title Oct. 10 at the Felt Forum. . . . Leslie Stewart will defend his World Boxing Association light heavyweight title against Virgil Hill Sept. 5 at Trump Plaza in Atlantic City. . . . The ownership group of the St. Louis Steamers, one of the original franchises in the Major Indoor Soccer League, has signed an option to sell the team to a group of investors headed by Bing Devine, former president of the football Cardinals and former general manager of the baseball Cardinals.

title: HORIZON FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $196,752 from the one-time writeoff of Horizon's investment in the FSLIC secondary reserve fund and a pre-tax gain of $133,387 on the sale of loans. The company went public in November 1986.

title: VIETNAMESE FLOW INTO HONG KONG
description: Thousands of Vietnamese who had settled in China over the last decade are flooding into Hong Kong, straining the territory's capacity to handle them and raising concerns about China's role in the exodus.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEY RATES
Pilot Accused in Fatal Crash
description: A 23-year-old pilot whose plane crashed into the Pacific last April 9, killing two passengers, after he apparently tried to dip a wing into the ocean, was charged today with second-degree murder and drunken flying, a city prosecutor said. The pilot, Roger Amiran, was released on bail of $5,000. He was charged in the deaths of Matthew Fry, 23, and John Harris, 22, were rescued by the coast guard.

title: TELESCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $3,962,494 and $5,838,932 from an unconsolidated subsidiary for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for 1987 account for the restructuring of the company and its investment in Telesciences C O Systems Inc. under the equity method.

title: Ashkelon Journal; When Dogs Become an Archeologist's Best Find
description: As riddles of the ancient world go, it will never compare with that of the Sphinx, but a mysterious 2,500-year-old dog cemetery discovered here this summer has archeologists stumped just as much.

title: Setting Continental's Strategy
description: Thomas C. Theobald has a big job ahead of him.

title: Advertising; Giorgio of Beverly Hills Picks Eisaman Agency
description: Giorgio of Beverly Hills has decided to retain Eisaman, Johns & Laws, Los Angeles, after reviewing four agencies in the last four months. The other Los Angeles agencies vying for the $3 million fragrance account were Chiat/Day, BBDO/West and DDB Needham/Los Angeles.

title: Albany Bars AIDS Test For Health Insurance
description: New York State issued a regulation yesterday that will bar insurers from requiring health-insurance applicants to be tested for the virus that causes AIDS.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Otis Blackwell Meets the Black Rock Coalition Orchestra, Prospect Park Band Shell, Prospect Park West at Ninth Street, Brooklyn (718-768-0699). While the 10th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death (on Aug. 16, 1977) has stirred up nostalgia and hype, here's a concert that might bring something new to the Presley legacy. Otis Blackwell wrote some of the best-remembered Presley songs - among them ''Don't Be Cruel'' and ''All Shook Up'' - as well as ''Great Balls of Fire'' and ''Breathless,'' for Jerry Lee Lewis. His demo recordings helped shape Presley's phrasing. Tomorrow, Mr. Blackwell will sing with the Black Rock Coalition Orchestra, led by Vernon Reid, a fireball of a guitarist who'll probably have some unorthodox ideas about updating the impact of rockabilly. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., Celebrate Brooklyn will also present two other rock concerts this weekend. Tonight's double bill, starting at 8, features the gruff, terse, muscular, angry songs of Persian Gulf. And on Sunday at 8 P.M., the Persuasions will harmonize - all voices, no instruments - on a repertory that encompasses doo-wop, gospel and their own songs. A $1 donation is requested.

title: BUSH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid February 1987.

title: GULF RISKS: MINES AND SUICIDE BOATS
description: As the United States Navy is finding out, protecting shipping in the Persian Gulf is no easy task. Kuwaiti tankers flying the American flag entered the gulf last month with a naval escort prepared to cope with air attacks and suicide speedboats, only to have one of the ships unexpectedly fall victim to an aged mine planted in a narrow shipping channel.

title: HADRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Art: Stuart Davis
description: HENRY McBRIDE was barking up the wrong tree when he said, in 1931, that Stuart Davis thought ''in terms of abstraction'' as naturally as a child born in China speaks Chinese. No doubt it was the nonchalance of the painter's style that prompted the conclusion. But what must have looked like a kind of Primitivism then, and still seems somehow innocent, was in fact as laboriously calculated as the Cubism that was its main inspiration. Davis himself makes no bones about it in his writing, but this doesn't lessen the impact of the visual evidence now hanging at the Mary Ryan Gallery.

title: Happy McDemocrats
description: The Democratic National Committee found gold at the end of the Golden Arches yesterday. The committee announced the largest single political contribution that it had ever received, $1 million, from Joan B. Kroc, widow of Ray A. Kroc, founder of the McDonald's chain of fast-food restaurants.

title: ROBERT M. LEYLAN
description: Robert M. Leylan, a retired art dealer and former head of the American branch of Christie's, the London-based auction house, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. A Manhattan resident, he was 79 years old.

title: What the Next Chancellor Needs
description: With Nathan Quinones's decision to retire as New York City's School Chancellor, the Board of Education can now settle down to pick a first-rate successor. Mr. Quinones's graceful offer to help in that search assures a smooth transition. But choosing a new chancellor, and a strong new management team, is only the first step in revamping the schools. Unless the system is changed, it will suffocate yet another chancellor.

title: Advertising; Reebok's New Spots For TV
description: REEBOK'S new $12 million television advertising campaign will make its debut next Wednesday. Four of the five spots were created by Chiat/Day, the agency that Reebok turned to after its widely publicized dispute with Ammirati & Puris earlier this year. Heller Breene created the fifth spot. Chiat/Day's four 30-second commercials, which will run during the back-to-school period as well as during the winter holidays, are aimed at men and boys who buy basketball, workout, walking and tennis shoes.

title: Dark Thoughts on a Santa Cruz Sunday
description: Santa Cruz, Calif., is a beach town of about 50,000 on the northern edge of Monterey Bay. Not as chic as Carmel, nowhere near as rich as Santa Barbara, it is mostly a resort for middle-class and working-class people, seasoned with commuters from San Jose, university people from the magnificent state university campus in the redwoods and a goodly helping of hippies for whom the year will always be 1969. On a recent Sunday, at the Crown College campus of the University of California, a tennis camp for youngsters was just starting. Nine, 10- and 11-year-old boys and girls, all beginners, were lined up in a dormitory courtyard and being solemnly warned by counselors not to throw furniture out of the windows. On the sidelines, parents chatted before getting into cars to head home.

title: LE PEEP RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Piedmont Aviation Names a New Chief
description: Willaim G. McGee, who yesterday was named chairman, president and chief executive of Piedmont Aviation Inc., faces not only the challenges of his new posts but the intricacies of heading a company that has agreed to be acquired.

title: Time to Reconsider
description: To the Editor:

title: Stubborn? Yes. Also Wrong.
description: The President's promised accounting for the Iran-contra scandal came down to a minute a month. In his speech Wednesday, he glossed over eight months in less than eight minutes before turning the page to the rest of his term. Even now, the most he can bring himself to do before the court of public opinion is to enter a plea of nolo contendere, no contest, neither denying guilt nor affirming innocence.

title: SEQUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-net from continuing operations includes $8,605,000 and $10,088,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, of equity in net of Chromalloy American Corp.'s continuing operations; net from Sequa's discontinued operations of $3,486,000 and $5,905,000 for the same periods, respectively; equity of $2,436,000 and $3,719,000 in Chromalloy's loss from discontinued operations for the same periods, respectively; and net income for both periods include a one-time benefit of about $12.2 million, or $1.53 a primary share, stemming from the settlement of Sequa's claim with the U.S. Government and final cost adjustments on a military contract, as well as termination of certain pension plans of Chromalloy. Year-ago figures were restated for discontinuance of graphic arts businesses. Chromalloy was a 44-percent owned affiliate in the second quarter of 1986 and merged with Sequa at the end of 1986.

title: Bidder Talks To Manpower
description: Manpower Inc. disclosed today that it held exploratory talks with top officials of Blue Arrow P.L.C. last week, following the announcement of Blue Arrow's $1.21 billion hostile takeover bid for the Milwaukee-based employment service concern.

title: Nuclear Blasts Seek Soviet Oil
description: The Soviet Union is trying to extract oil from deep layers of rock through underground nuclear explosions, a senior energy official said today. Alexei Zolotov, head of the

title: QUIPP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Trash Washes Ashore in Jersey, Closing a Beach
description: A State Department of Environmental Protection officer examining debris that washed ashore yesterday and forced the closing of the beach at Harvey Cedars, south of Barnegat Light. James Staples, a spokesman for the department, said the refuse, which consisted partly of used medical supplies, including syringes with needles, had been cleaned up and the beach reopened by late afternoon. ''The ocean gave back some of what man gave it,'' he said, ''but unfortunately not at the point of origin.'' (NYT/Ray Fisk)

title: Sports People; Pete Johnson Indicted
description: Pete Johnson, a former Cincinnati Bengals fullback, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on four counts related to a six-month investigation into cocaine trafficking, the United States Attorney's office in Columbus, Ohio, said.

title: Stephens Stays Busy With Big Purchase
description: The word around Saratoga this season was that Woody Stephens might finally be slowing down. His streak of Belmont Stakes winners had come to an end in June, and he had not cracked out his usual contingent of star 2-year-olds this summer.

title: Jager Breaks Biondi Record
description: Tom Jager of Collinsville, Ill., set a world record in the 50-meter freestyle today and two other Americans, Craig Oppel and Mitzi Kremer, broke other freestyle meet records at the Pan Pacific swimming championships.

title: Brazilian Star Sizzles On the Court
description: Except for a blue ribbon tied just under the right knee, there is nothing about her appearance that suggests athletic majesty. She is not that tall, a stringy 5 feet 8 inches, her hands are not exceptionally large and her physique isn't particularly imposing.

title: OTF EQUITIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that the second quarter was affected by non-recurring events at its subsidiary, Bayly Corp., during the month of April. As a result, the second quarter was after provisions for store closing expenses of $300,000. The company changed to a calendar year from a Nov. 30 year.

title: Sotheby's Says Boone Letter Is a Fake
description: Sotheby's, the auction house, has acknowledged a historic letter purportedly written by Daniel Boone that was sold at auction in New York City for $31,900 in 1985 was a forgery.

title: FRENCH WILL RAISE TITANIC STRONGBOX
description: A French expedition has found one of the strongboxes that sank with the Titanic and, in a move certain to provoke strong criticism, plans to bring the strongbox to the ocean surface in the next few days, a spokesman for the expedition said today.

title: Steinbrenner Keeps on Swinging
description: Lou Piniella's job appears safe -at least for today - but George Steinbrenner, who will ultimately decide the fate of the embattled Yankee manager, is offering neither a guarantee nor a prediction of the immediate future.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Cash Upset in Montreal: Unseeded Peter Lundgren of Sweden shocked Pat Cash of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, 6-4, 7-6, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Player's International tournament in Montreal. The triumph by Lundgren, the 112th-ranked player in the world, earned him a berth against the tournament's defending champion, Boris Becker, who defeated Richie Reneberg, 6-2, 6-2. Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe also advanced to a quarterfinal showdown. Connors, seeded fourth, needed 2 hours and 46 minutes before his opponent, Jay Berger, seeded 13th, withdrew because of cramps, with Connors leading, 4-6, 7-5, 4-0. McEnroe, seeded sixth, coasted to a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Jonas Carlsson of Sweden. Second-seeded Stefan Edberg also reached the final eight, defeating Jimmy Arias, 7-5, 6-2.(AP) Navratilova Advances: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova recovered from a shaky start yesterday and defeated Eva Pfaff of West Germany, 7-6, 6-1, to move into the quarterfinals of the Virginia Slims of Los Angeles tournament in Manhattan Beach. Navratilova failed to convert 8 set points in the opening set before winning it in a tiebreaker. ''I'm not sharp yet,'' said Navratilova, who is playing in her first tournament since hurting her ankle in a basketball game five weeks ago. Third-seeded Chris Evert also had to overcome a slow start to defeat 18-year-old Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-3, to move into the quarterfinals. (AP) Cycling Italian Wins a Stage: Sauro Varocchi of Italy jumped out to an early lead and then held off Chris Bailey of the United States to win the ninth stage of the Coors International Bicycle Classic yesterday. Jeff Pierce of the United States retained a substantial overall lead. Varocchi had leads of more than five minutes before finishing the 98-mile course from Squaw Valley, Calif., to Reno in 3 hours 55 minutes 51 seconds. Bailey finished about a minute behind. Pierce, racing for the 7-Eleven team, held an overall lead of 4:33 over teammate Raul Alcala of Mexico.(AP) Track and Field Johnson Takes 100-Meter Dash: Ben Johnson of Canada won the 100-meter dash in 10 seconds yesterday at an international track and field meet in Koblenz, West Germany. Johnson, who won a bronze medal in the 100 meters at the 1984 Olympics, finished ahead of Stanley Floyd of the United States, who was second in 10.39 seconds. William van Dijck of Belgium ran the best time of the year in the 3,000-meter steeplechase, in 8 minutes 13.27 seconds.(AP) Golf Lietzke Has Blue-Chip Finish: Bruce Lietzke chipped in on each of the last two holes and led the advance through yesterday's second portion of first-round play in the International golf tournament in Castle Rock, Colo. Lietzke chipped in from 40 feet for an eagle 3 on the 17th hole at the Castle Rock Golf Club and holed another chip, this from about 25 feet, for par on the 18th to complete a round of six-under-par 66. Scoring in the tournament is based on a system in which points are awarded or subtracted depending on a player's performance on each hole. Five points are awarded for an eagle, 2 for a birdie, none for par, minus-1 for bogey and minus-3 for double bogey or worse. Lietzke's effort converted to a score of 14 points, the best of the day. (AP) N.F.L. Chiefs Defeat Oilers: Nick Lowery of Kansas City kicked six field goals and Bill Kenney hit Darrell Colbert on a 40-yard touchdown pass with five minutes to play to lead the Chiefs to a 32-20 exhibition victory over the Houston Oilers last night. Lowery kicked a 22-yard field goal to give Kansas City the lead for good, 22-20, with 7 minutes 58 seconds left in the game, which was played in Houston. His fifth field goal came after Michael Clemens, an eighth-round draft choice, returned a punt 51 yards to the Oilers' 10-yard line. Sherman Cocroft intercepted a pass by John Witkowski, the Houston quarterback, and returned the ball for 5 yards, setting up Kenney's touchdown pass. (AP)

2 PBS SERIES ADD TWIST TO FORMULA
description: TELEVISION is not partial to surprises. The standard practice is to devise a format and then squeeze it until chronic numbness sets in. Even public television is wary about taking chances. The best of its schedule, from ''Masterpiece Theater'' to ''The McNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' is by now as comfortable as an old aerobics sneaker. There are, however, two series that do a fairly good job in avoiding predictability, and they are currently running back-to-back on Channel 13 Sunday evenings: ''Alive From Off Center'' at 10:30, and ''Independent Focus'' at 11.

The seasonally adjusted unemployment figure registered a larger-than-expected drop of 47,600 last month, to 2.87 million, or 10.4 percent of the work force.

title: Film: 'Can't Buy Me Love'
description: ''CAN'T BUY ME LOVE'' is a nerd's dream come true, as a self-described ''social leper'' discovers what it costs to be a high-school hero: $1,000. For that fee, Cindy, the head cheerleader, pretends to date Ronald, who is so out of it he can't sit at the same lunch table as Cindy's friends. A little hair mousse, a few oversized jackets and nearness to Cindy make Ronald the senior-class ''heartbreaker,'' all in one short month.

title: Film: 'North Shore'
description: ''NORTH SHORE,'' which opens today at the Movieland and other theaters, is about surfing on Oahu's north coast, where, apparently, more perfect waves break per annum than anywhere else in the world. It's about young Rick (Matt Adler), who is torn between a career as a professional surfer and pursuing his studies on an art scholarship in New York. ''I know you love surfing,'' says his mom, ''but don't throw away your career.''

title: Dining Out Guide: Seafood
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. COASTAL, #300 Amsterdam Avenue, at 74th Street (769-3988) - **(June 12, 1987) A contemporary glass-fronted dining room and coastal mural provide the backdrop for a serious new fish house on the Upper West Side. Among the recommended appetizers is a trio of vibrant little ceviches, each in a large mussel shell and four-pepper gravlax. The New England clam chowder is a tasty starter as well. Good options for main dishes are broiled halibut with a choice of sauces; red snapper under a concasse of tomatoes, scallions and basil, and broiled grouper with a Provencal sauce with olives, capers and onions, and any of the grilled fresh fish of the day. Entrees $10 to $17.25. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 P.M. to 2 A.M.; Sundays, 6 to 10:30 P.M. HATSUHANA, #17 East 48th Street (355-3345) - ***(Feb. 21, 1986) Cheerful dining rooms on two levels, each with elongated sushi bars flanked by rows of simple wooden tables, provide a suitable stage for the colorful production put on by the personable sushi chefs. The highlights of the menu are sushi and sashimi in many varieties; and you might order the Hatsuhana special, which includes both of the raw fish specialties as well as tempura and grilled skewered fish. With fish as fresh as this, some of the least elaborate presentations may be the most appealing: negihamachi, which is chopped mild-flavored yellowtail flecked with scallions; negitoro, chopped belly of tuna with scallions, and slices of mackerel blended with pickled ginger and wrapped in Japanese white radish. Dinner entrees $15 to $29. Fridays, 11:45 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 5 to 10 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 10 P.M.; closed Sundays. JANE STREET SEAFOOD CAFE, #31 Eighth Avenue, corner of Jane Street (243-9237) - *(May 8, 1987) This Greenwich Village restaurant has a rustic tavern-like setting with brick and natural wood walls, low lighting and blackboard menus; and the kitchen prepares a staggering variety of fish and shellfish. Starters include steamed clams; fried bluepoint oysters with tartar sauce, and mussels steamed in wine and sherry with shallots and garlic. You can usually rely on the cripsy golden-brown fried fillet of sole, or when available, fried soft-shell crabs. Other winners are poached fillet of salmon with a mild dill sauce, and red snapper under a profusion of sauteed onions, tomato and basil. Entrees $11.50 to $19.95. Fridays and Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 4 to 10 P.M. JOHN CLANCY'S RESTAURANT, #181 West 10th Street (242-7350) -

title: After 100 Years, Rabbi Wonders Why All the Fuss
description: Probably the single worst thing about turning 100 is the TV cameras. Channel 7 News had landed at the Long Island Hebrew Living Center and stationed a crew one foot from Rabbi Moses Rosenthal's nose. A 14 trillion-watt light bulb was blinding the poor rabbi. People kept shouting orders: ''Rabbi, look into the camera. Say something for the camera, Rabbi, please say something for the camera. Rabbi, could you cut the cake now? Cut the cake, Rabbi. Give him a knife. Oh that's beautiful, Rabbi. Make a wish, Rabbi! Make a wish!'' The old rabbi made the mistake of sitting down. ''Rabbi, you have to get up once more! We need one more picture.'' They gave him a balloon and pinned a blue ribbon on him and then the TV guys left; they had everything.

title: Cautious View Of Stock Surge
description: WHILE the stock market was soaring to record heights this week, breaking 2,700 yesterday before falling back, there was no talk - as there was in 1929 - of a ''new era'' in which everyone had better buy stocks right away. On the contrary, many economists and sophisticated investment advisers were feeling the pangs of acrophobia (a fear of high places) and warning that ''the tree does not grow to the sky.''

title: British Caledonian
description: A small London travel company said it had offered to acquire the British Caledonian Group P.L.C., which previously agreed to be acquired by British Airways P.L.C. for the same price, $:237 million, or about $374 million. The British Government last week referred the British Airways offer to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission for review of possible antitrust problems. British Airways is Britain's largest airline. British Caledonian ranks second. The travel company, Travel Eye Ltd., is owned by brothers, Atul and Virendra Patel. It did not indicate how it would finance its offer. But a spokesman for British Caledonian, who did not want to be identified, said, ''No offers have been received from anybody.''

title: A Drug Defendant Uses the Telephone To File Guilty Plea
description: A defendant who was shot and seriously wounded during the ''pizza connection'' drug trial pleaded guilty by telephone from a hospital yesterday to two charges in the case.

title: Trading-Link Instrument Set
description: The Chicago Board of Trade, the leading futures market, and the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the largest options exchange, have selected the first financial instrument for their historic trading link-up, exchange sources said today.

title: Diego Della Valle Brings His Classic Shoes to SoHo
description: Diego Della Valle decided many months ago to open a shoe store in New York. He already has nine stores in Italy that sell his shoes and those his company makes under the labels of Gianfranco Ferre, Azzedine Alaia, Zoran, Romeo Gigli and J. P. Tod's.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising column in Business Day last Thursday, about Food & Wine magazine, incompletely cited the timing of American Express's takeover of the magazine. While the acquisition was completed in 1984, American Express took operating control in 1980.

title: Colombia Official Guilty In U.S. Drug Trafficking
description: A Federal jury today convicted a Colombian Senator on charges that he helped import and sell large quantities of cocaine.

title: On Loan At Auction Galleries
description: Nothing is for sale in the special Americana art exhibitions, on view weekdays at New York's largest auction houses. For the first time, both Sotheby's and Christie's have opened their galleries to loan shows. Folk art reigns at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, through Sept. 4, and American art pottery fills the vitrines at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, through Aug. 28.
