title: The Camp That Was Hoover's
description: Even before his inauguration as President, Herbert Hoover knew he would need a rural retreat from the White House, a place where he could shrug off the responsibilities of office in the great outdoors. He told his secretary, Lawrence Richey, that the site had to be within 100 miles of Washington, at least 2,500 feet above sea level to avoid mosquitoes and, above all, near a good trout stream.

title: CAREERCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Turner Acquires 'Gone With the Wind'
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., the cable broadcasting company, said today that it has acquired from CBS Inc. all the television rights to the film ''Gone With the Wind.''

description: New York State's bond rating was raised to AA-, from A+, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

description: A Brooklyn woman, described by the police as a bystander to a domestic dispute, was killed Wednesday night at a busy intersection in the Sunset Park section by a man who then killed himself.

title: Present at the Creation: Memories of 1947 Partition
description: LEAD: In the pale light of a north Indian dawn, a troop of whooping horsemen came out of the early morning mist on both sides of the Frontier Mail train, which came to a screeching stop.

title: REAGAN PLANNING TO SEEK MORE AID FOR THE CONTRAS
description: The White House is planning to ask Congress next month to provide additional military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, should peace talks in Central America falter, senior Administration officials said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, a table with an article in Business Day yesterday about consumer interest rates misstated the return on accounts at Midlantic Banks. The annual effective yield on its money market account is 5.44 percent.

description: The Internal Revenue Service today released lengthy and complicated new forms for claiming home mortgage interest deductions and for making Individual Retirement Account contributions under the new tax law.

CHINESE PARTY EXPELS PLAYWRIGHT
description: A leading Chinese playwright said today that he had been pressed to quit the Communist Party, suggesting that he had become the latest target of hard-line dissatisfaction against those who have spoken out against party policy.

description: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that Afghan guerrillas had shot down a transport plane with an American-made Stinger missile, killing 12 people aboard.

title: Gooden Can't Hold a Five-Run Lead
description: Dwight Gooden blew a five-run lead today for the first time in his career, and the Mets did not survive.

description: Governor Cuomo, reversing the decisions of past administrations, is planning to build an interchange on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to spur the development of the largest piece of private timberland in the New York metropolitan area.

title: SUMMER SPLENDORS OUTSIDE THE CITY
description: LEAD: Take along your most up-to-date and cosmopolitan lexicon to view art in the three-state region this weekend. Over the past decade, art outside New York City has become virtually indistinguishable from what can be seen in Manhattan's museums and galleries. About the changed scene one can borrow Empedocles' language: Today's art world has a circumference that is everywhere and a center that is nowhere.

title: Restaurants; Midtown Greek and Chinatown.
description: GREEK restaurants can offer some of the best dining bargains around, which is why the paucity of good ones in New York City is so nettlesome. The old Pantheon on Eighth Avenue used to be a dependable little spot for a quick wholesome lunch in the Times Square neighborhood - that is, until the Internal Revenue Service padlocked the door for nonpayment of taxes.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Advertising; McDonald's Files Suit Against Alberto-Culver
description: The Alberto-Culver Company's butter substitute Molly McButter has prompted the McDonald's Corporation to file a suit in Federal District Court in Chicago against Alberto-Culver for trademark infringement.

description: Speed and agility helped Chad's lightly armed desert fighters last week to rout 1,000 Libyan soldiers stationed in a disputed border strip.

Home Sales Increase by 5.6%
description: Sales of existing homes overcame a big jolt from rising mortgage rates during the spring to post double-digit increases in 20 states, a housing trade group said today. The group also said New York displaced Boston as the metropolitan area with the highest-priced housing.

title: 'Colegas,' From Spain
description: ELOY DE LA IGLESIA is a prolific Spanish movie maker (21 movies in 20 years) who is not well known in the United States. ''Colegas'' (''Pals''), now at the Thalia SoHo on a double bill with ''El Diputado,'' his only other work to be commercially distributed in this country, should do nothing to change that situation.

title: Sports People; Sneva Dismissed, Again
description: Tom Sneva, the 1983 Indianapolis 500 winner, was dismissed and then rehired recently in a four-day battle of words with Mike Curb, the owner of the cars Sneva drives. Now Sneva has been dismissed again, and this time he is apparently gone from the team for good. A spokesman for Curb said Wednesday that the team's March race car had been withdrawn from Sunday's Quaker State 500 in Long Pond, Pa. The 39-year-old Sneva, who has won 13 races and more than $3.8 million in his 15-year career, has not won since the 1984 season finale at Las Vegas, Nev.

title: LPL INVESTMENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter includes results from operations of Amphenol Corp., acquired from Allied-Signal Inc. on June 2, of a loss of $68,000 on sales of $33,473,000.

Khomeini, Ortega & Joe
description: There is a lot more to be written about Ayatollah Khomeini of Iran and President Ortega of Nicaragua but this seems precisely the moment to write instead about Joseph Papp of New York.

description: President Reagan has nominated Maj. Gen. Ernest T. Cook Jr. of the Marine Corps for promotion to lieutenant general and a new assignment as commander of the Atlantic Fleet Marine Force, the Defense Department said today. If the promotion is approved by the Senate, General Cook will replace Gen. Alfred M. Gray as commander of the Atlantic force. General Gray was named Commandant of the Marines earlier this this.

The company also said year-to-date results continue to be distorted by the unrealized gain on foreign exchange and shouldn't be in its financial and operating situation. The unrealized gain on foreign exchange was $116 million in the first quarter, which has been reduced to $69 million at the end of the 6-month period as a result of a second quarter decrease in the valueof the Canadian dollar. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: The United States Customs Service gave back to Ecuador today 153 ancient artifacts that were confiscated last year during a smuggling attempt in Florida, the agency said.

description: Those who wonder if the Mets have enough pitching to win again should consider what's happening in old Wrigley Field this week. One day, Dwight Gooden blew a five-run lead for the first time in his career. The next day, two rookies were pounded for three home runs, and the Mets took a 6-1 pasting from the Chicago Cubs.

title: WILFRED W. SMITH
description: Wilfred W. Smith, retired chief engineer of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, died last Saturday at Putnam Hospital, Carmel, N.Y., of complications of a neck injury received in a fall. He was 87 years old and lived in Holmes, N.Y.

title: Morton Weiss, 67, Leading Spokesman For Security Traders
description: Morton N. Weiss, a retired president of the National Security Traders Association who was long considered a leading spokesman for the over-the-counter securities market, died of pancreatic cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: Lamaur Bars Bid
description: Lamaur Inc., a Minneapolis-based marketer of hair-care products, said today it rejected a sweetened $135 million takeover bid by the Alberto-Culver Company as inadequate. On Monday, Alberto-Culver raised its original $22-a-share offer to $24 a share.

title: Bosworth Signs
description: Two months after being picked in a supplemental draft by one of the teams he said he would not play for, Brian Bosworth signed an $11 million, 10-year contract with the Seattle Seahawks yesterday.

title: Patents
description: Alden Schloss of Woodland Hills, Calif., who belongs to the Inventors Workshop International, has invented a rotary kite. Patent No. 4,685,642, issued to him this week, says the lift-to-weight ratio enables flying in gentle breezes. The kite is five feet in diameter, but folds, umbrella-fashion, to a bundle two and a half feet long.

description: The Philippine Government raised gasoline and fuel oil prices by nearly 20 percent today, producing calls for strikes.

description: John D. Ehrlichman, once the top domestic adviser to President Nixon, is seeking a Presidential pardon for his role in the Watergate scandals, the Justice Department said today.

title: Sandspit Journal; With Logging Banned, The Logger Is Mourned
description: Frank Beban was a big man in this little town, physically and otherwise, and he might have chuckled if he had known how his death brought a measure of concord, at least about Mr. Beban, among people who had agreed on little else in years.

title: Cuomo, Citing a 'Crisis,' Lauds New Ethics Law
description: Governor Cuomo, re-enacting the signing into law of a stricter code of government ethics, said today that the measure was an important affirmation of principles at a time when the country is in a ''crisis of values.''

description: At least four members of the Cuban boxing team and an official with the Cuban delegation to the Pan American Games fought with spectators during a boxing match tonight at the Indianapolis Convention Center.

description: A blue whale has been sighted off New England, the fourth sighting since October. Previously, a blue whale had not been seen in this area since 1936.

description: Several explosions ripped through a chemical warehouse near a housing development today, killing 5 people, injuring 70 and forcing 1,500 to flee, the police said.

description: A committee of scientists at Montana State University recommended today that an experiment involving an unauthorized test of genetically altered bacteria be terminated by destroying the American elms into which the altered microbes had been injected.

description: The state commission that regulates the Hackensack Meadowlands - once despoiled swamp, now home of New Jersey's Sports Complex and clusters of shining new offices - has hit on rocky times.

description: Although the Nucor Corporation will not break ground until next month for a steel mill it intends to build in central Indiana, all eyes in the steel industry have been on the project since the plans were announced early this year.

description: Two players' shoulders will be in harnesses and two other players will limp to the line. After all, these are the Jets.

British Inflation Rate
description: Britain's annual inflation rate rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July, to 4.4 percent, the Government said today. The annual inflation rate reflects the rise in the retail price index, a measure of the costs of consumer goods, over the previous 12 months. Inflation fell one-tenth of 1 percent from June to July, mainly because of lower costs for seasonal foods and summer store sales. But the annual rate rose because prices fell faster, by three-tenths of 1 percent, in July 1986 after a slump in world oil prices.

title: 'Fulton's Folly,' and Now the Port Authority's
description: Exactly 180 years ago this Monday, Robert Fulton gathered a crew that shared his sense of adventure (if not an outright foolhardy spirit), boarded what was commonly called ''Fulton's Folly'' and set off from the waterfront that is now the edge of Greenwich Village.

But British Airways put off the sensitive decision on whether to spend an additional $1 billion on American or European longer-range jets.

More than 100 Russian patients with various tumors have been treated with the compound - a composition containing 2-carbamoylaziridine - and the results are reported to have been highly successful.

description: The American Express Company said that its commercial banking unit had acquired a stake in Sovardino, one of the largest stock brokerages in Italy. American Express did not disclose terms, but company sources indicated that a 50 percent share had been purchased for $30 million, American Express is seeking an expanded role in the growing Italian capital markets. Italian banks and brokerages have recently spent heavily to promote mutual funds, asset management and other services.

title: Farm Spending Drops
description: Farmers spent $4.7 billion on new and used machinery last year, down 16 percent from 1985, and another reduction is expected in 1987, the Agriculture Department said today. ''Although farm net cash income continues to grow, expenditures are likely to remain weak this year, ranging from $4.1 billion to $4.7 billion,'' the department's Economic Research Service said. ''Reductions in planted acres, the reduced level of crop prices, high real interest rates, and an apparent propensity of farmers to reduce their debt burdens are contributing to the continued weakening in farm machinery demand,'' the report added.

title: Sale of Jewels: An Adventure
description: The problem is one that many people face at one time or another: a need or a desire to sell personal jewelry. Maybe it was inherited, maybe it came from an ex-husband or maybe it's just old-fashioned and unappealing and has been sitting too long in the vault. But how to go about selling it without knowing a jeweler or a dealer? How to be sure a fair price is offered?

title: Photo of A motorist on top of his stalled car yesterday on a flooded underpass in Hillside, Ill. (AP) Record Rain Floods Chicago Area; Airport Cut Off
description: A record 9.2 inches of rain fell on the Chicago area today, flooding homes and expressways, stranding passengers at O'Hare International Airport and knocking out power and telephone service to thousands of people.

description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday about three former members of the Jewish Defense League who pleaded guilty to Federal charges in a series of bombings omitted their names. They are a former J.D.L. leader, Victor Vancier, 30 years old, of Whitestone, Queens, and two former members of the group's governing board, Jay Cohen, 24, of Forest Hills, Queens, and Murray Young, 59, of East Meadow, L.I.

The Risks Of Shared Cosmetics
description: THE seductive palette of makeup testers at cosmetics counters has long invited consumers to experiment with beauty products before buying them. Having actual products in hand makes it easy to judge color, consistency and scent.

title: Race Car Hits Deer
description: A deer that wandered from nearby woods onto the race track at the Oesterreichring race course in Zeltweg, Austria, during practice runs yesterday for the Austrian Grand Prix tomorrow was struck head-on and killed by a Formula One car driven by Stefan Johansson of Sweden. Although the car burst into flames and repeatedly hit the barrier while skidding down the track after the accident, the driver of the McLaren-TAG racer was not injured.

title: Black Woman Who Lost Job Is Asked Back by Pharmacist
description: A pharmacist who dismissed a black college student from his store because of her race has offered the student her job back.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the 1986 results are restated to reflect acquisitions accounted for by the pooling of interests.

title: Vincent Persichetti Dies at 72; Composer of Wide Repertory
description: Vincent Persichetti, a prolific American composer, educator, theorist, pianist and conductor, died yesterday at his home in Philadelphia, of lung cancer. He was 72 years old.

title: CARLYLE R. BENNETT
description: Carlyle R. Bennett, an archivist for the Federal Government and for New York City, died Monday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a short illness. He was 73 years old and had homes in Twin Rivers, N.J., and in Margate, Fla.

title: Deal With Managua? Pro and Contra.
description: I know what all that palaver about Central American peace plans is about. It's a liberal scam. If those Sandinista Communists sign a peace agreement, they'll cheat, lie and not comply. And if they don't sign, they'll dawdle until American aid for the contras expires. That's what this is all about.

title: KINGSTON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Awash in Garbage
description: During the long debate this summer over the plight of a garbage-filled barge with no place to unload, no one ever dared suggest the trash simply be dumped into the ocean. Yet every year far more than a bargeload gets dumped from ocean liners, navy and merchant ships. Increasingly, that trash contains indestructible plastic that washes up on beaches and poses a lethal hazard to ocean life. New laws to curb this dumping deserve support.

title: Skinner Shoots 67 For L.P.G.A. Lead
description: Val Skinner had a round of golf today that resembled her success of last year on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

title: Arms Agency Aide Resigns
description: David F. Emery, deputy director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that he planned to step down from the post he has held for the last four years. In a letter to President Reagan, Mr. Emery, a former Maine Congressman, said he planned to return to private life and hoped his resignation could take effect by Jan. 1.

title: Son, 20, Confesses To Killing Parents
description: A man accused of killing his parents with an ax last month at their home in Darien told the police that he had intended to kill them a year earlier, but fell asleep while waiting to attack.

title: Baseball; McGwire Breaks Rookie Homer Record
description: Mark McGwire of the Oakland Athletics broke the major league record for home runs by a rookie when he hit his 39th homer of the season in the sixth inning tonight.

title: Chad Reports New Libyan Attack
description: Chadian troops beat back a land and air attack by Libyan troops on the northern village of Aozou today, killing more than 150 Libyans and capturing 48, the Chadian radio said tonight.

title: ROBERT HALF INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $276,000 for the quarter, and for the 6 months includes income from discontinued operations of $372,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $115,000 and $300,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Heat Silences Beirut Radio
description: A summer heat wave silenced the state-owned Beirut radio today and caused its first extended shutdown in 51 years of broadcasting. ''All the wires in the transmitter have rotted because we don't have air conditioning,'' Ayoub Hmayed, secretary general of Lebanon's Information Ministry, told a news conference shortly before the radio went off the air. In the meantime, Lebanon will not be starved for news. Its airwaves are crowded by dozens of commerical radio stations run by rival militias.

title: After Long Disdain, Moscow Plans Show Of Chagall's Works
description: The first major exhibition in the Soviet Union of the paintings of Marc Chagall will open at the Pushkin Museum in Moscow next month, one of the show's organizers said today.

title: Contractors Reported to Give Money to Washington Mayor's Friend
description: Two District of Columbia contractors who are political allies of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. have acknowledged giving money to a woman who refused to cooperate with an investigation into drug use by city employees, including the Mayor, a published report says.

title: Dow Falls, but Has Record Week
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average again failed to pierce the 2,700 barrier, but the stock market had a week to remember.

title: Business Sales Rose 1.5% in June
description: Business sales climbed by 1.5 percent in June, the biggest advance in four months, while inventories grew by a much smaller four-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $3,500,000 due to the cancellation of a disk drive program. c-Net income

title: LEXITECH INTERNATIONAL DOCUMENTAION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boy Bitten by a Snake Dies
description: An 8-year-old boy who told medical personnel he was bitten by a snake that made a rattling sound has died after he was treated by a doctor who said he thought the snake bite was not poisonous. The boy, Jason DeNio, of Albuquerque, was bitten on his right leg Tuesday while on a day camp field trip to the Bitter Lakes National Wildlife Refuge, and was pronounced dead Wednesday afternoon. Dr. Don Clark, who treated the boy, said the wound did not show characteristics of the presence of a toxin.

title: Dollar Plunges on News Of Huge Trade Deficit
description: The dollar fell sharply on heavy volume yesterday, as traders bailed out of the currency after the Commerce Department reported that June's trade deficit was possibly the worst ever.

title: Watery Room of Horrors
description: Shampoo burnout is one of the new American scourges. It's what happens when your shampoo can no longer cut the mustard, much less the grit on your scalp.

title: Opera: 'Pastore,' At Mostly Mozart
description: One of the duties of a court composer in the 18th century was to write operas that flattered and glorified the aristocracy, usually by dramatizing the legend of some monarch's magnanimous acts. ''Il Re Pastore,'' which a 19-year-old servant named W. A. Mozart wrote in honor of an archduke's visit to Salzburg, is not the composer's most successful effort in the stiffly formal genre known as opera seria - ''Idomeneo'' and ''La Clemenza di Tito'' both overshadow this two-act ''dramma per musica.'' Still, the score contains enough intimations of better Mozart to justify revival, if only in the concert form chosen for Thursday evening's performance at the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: TV: 'Music of Tommy Dorsey,' on 13
description: When the time rolls around once again to fund raising, public television is inordinately partial to nostalgia. Innumerable specials have featured singers and musicians resurrecting the songs of yesteryear while older couples clutch each other blissfully on a crowded dance floor. Presumably these excursions into the past work, because PBS keeps churning them out.

title: Buddy Guy
description: Buddy Guy, a blues singer and guitarist, performs tomorrow at midnight at the Limelight, 660 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street (212-807-7850). Tickets are $12.

title: Opera: Changes in 'Cavalleria Rusticana' and 'Pagliacci'
description: Most of the principal roles in the New York City Opera's production of ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' changed hands on Thursday night. In the first opera, two sides of its love triangle were replaced -namely the roles of Santuzza and Lola. Outside of Frederick Burchinal's Tonio, all of the ''Pagliacci'' players were new.

title: BBC STUDY FINDS U.S. TV MORE VIOLENT
description: A study of four months of British television concludes that while television violence is generally declining, the popular shows imported from the United States are three times as violent as English-made programs.

title: HUTCHINSON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes after-tax income of $150,000, or 4 cents a share, for the latest quarter, recognized on the sale of certain technology to a Japanese manufacturer, compared with after- tax income of $250,000, or 7 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The latest quarter net also includes $165,000, net of tax recovery, related to the sale of certain claims against a bank debtor. Both year-ago periods' results have been restated to reflect the company's adoption of new interim reporting periods.

title: Charles Camp Cotton Dies; A Judge in Nuremburg Trials
description: Charles Camp Cotton, a judge in the Nuremberg war-crimes trials, died Wednesday at the Greenbriar East Nursing Home here. He was 83 years old and lived in Woodbury, N.J.

title: Concern Reported in U.S. Military on Gulf Command Structure
description: Some senior Navy officers have criticized command arrangements for operations in the Persian Gulf because responsibility is divided, officers said today.

title: Chyron Rejects Offer
description: The Chyron Corporation, which makes digital electronic graphics, said today that it had received an unsolicited offer from an undisclosed bidder to acquire the company for about $87 million, or $8.50 a share. Chyron said it advised the suitor that, in view of the prospects of some new products, the company was not for sale. Its stock closed at $7.625, up 62.5 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Cabaret: Lillias White
description: Lillias White underwent a striking personality transformation on Thursday night. At 10:30 she was on the stage of the Ambassador Theater portraying Effie, the hefty, mistreated pop singer in the economy-sized Broadway revival of ''Dreamgirls.'' An hour later, Ms. White stepped onto the stage of the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street), inaugurating a Thursday night cabaret act in which she exuded an intelligence and self-assured sophistication that were almost opposite in spirit to the grovelingly insecure character she had impersonated an hour earlier.

description: Denise Parker may not pull as many pounds as older competitors do, but in three days of archery competition, the eighth-grader from South Jordan, Utah, has pulled her weight.

description: Investors pushed the stock of the Jim Walter Corporation slightly above $60 yesterday, on speculation that a higher bid for the company might be forthcoming.

description: President Reagan's Central America peace plan, proposed in part to demonstrate that the Administration was moving forward after the Iran-contra hearings, is instead causing the White House nothing but difficulty.

description: Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities, bolstered by a rebound in oil and gas drilling and gains at auto plants, surged eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, the biggest increase in 15 months, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Norma B. Watson, 90, Dies; Among First Women Marines
description: Norma B. Watson, one of the first women to serve in the Marine Corps, died on Aug. 8 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Coatesville, Pa., after a stroke. She was 90 years old and lived in Scullville, N.J.

title: ANSERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: F.A.A. Revokes License of Pilot In Near Miss With Reagan Copter
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, citing a ''serious breach of safety,'' today revoked the license of the pilot of a small plane who flew within 200 feet of President Reagan's helicopter. The pilot was identified as an Army private who was absent without leave.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We must strike a wise balance between the thrust of innovation and the restraint of regulation.'' - National Academy of Sciences panel on genetic engineering. [ 7:5. ]

title: Blues: Hemphill and Lester, From Bayou Country
description: Living in New York, far from the heartland of the blues, it's easy to imagine - and many people do -that blues music is becoming moribund and is largely bereft of imagination. After all, the only blues one usually has the chance to hear is played by the same handful of well-known artists, performing the same familiar tunes year after year. But there is plenty of life left in the music, and plenty of originality. On Thursday at the Lone Star Cafe, two blues artists from the Deep South offered a striking confirmation of the music's vitality and resilience.

title: LeMond Joining Team
description: Greg LeMond, the first American to win the Tour de France, has signed a letter of intent to ride for PDM, a Dutch cyclying team. LeMond is recuperating from an April hunting accident in which he was sprayed with buckshot and from an appendectomy in July.

title: Truck Incentives Offered by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation has offered a new buyer incentive program for compact trucks that is similar to the one it offered car buyers last week. The truck program is retroactive to Aug. 11, when the previous one expired; both car and truck incentives last until Sept. 30. Buyers have a choice of 1.9 percent financing for 24-month contracts, 3.9 percent for 36 months, 4.8 percent for 48 months, and 8.9 percent for 60 months.

title: Yankees Lose Fifth in a Row
description: Lou Piniella, the embattled Yankee manager (for now), apparently experienced greater success diplomatically than strategically last night.

title: Your Money
description: DAVID EVANS, a businessman in Springdale, Ark., went shopping for jewelry recently as an anniversary present for his wife and eventually bought a pair of diamond earrings. But he realized right from the start that he had no expertise in judging the quality of diamonds, so he sought guidance from a specialist in the field.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 15, 1987
description: International 2-5, 28 Philip C. Habib resigned as President Reagan's special envoy to Central America. He was reported to be displeased with the White House's failure to assign him a major role in diplomatic efforts to work out a regional peace settlement. Page 1 News analysis: The Latin peace plan proposed by President Reagan, put forth in part to demonstrate that the Administration was moving forward after the Iran-contra hearings, is instead causing the White House nothing but difficulty. 5 The Salvadoran rebels accepted President Jose Napoleon Duarte's offer to meet for peace talks next month as part of a regional peace effort. It would be their first official negotiating session in three years. 5 In Moscow, a Marc Chagall exhibit will open at the Pushkin Museum next month, marking a posthumous official homecoming for an artist long slighted by his native land, one of the show's organizers said. 1 Some senior Navy officers criticized command arrangements for operations in the Persian Gulf because responsibility is divided, Pentagon officers said. The Joint Chiefs of Staff have reportedly reviewed the arrangements. 3 Chad beat back a Libyan attack on the northern town of Aouzou, killing ''more than 150'' Libyans and capturing 48 prisoners, the Chadian radio said. 3 The miners' strike in South Africa turned increasingly violent. Police officers fired birdshot into crowds of strikers, wounding at least 13 in the first reported use of live ammunition in the six-day strike. 3 South Korea's Defense Minister offered the first public pledge of military support to the country's next president. The Defense Minister was responding to unusually bold questioning by opposition legislators. 3 The Indian-Sri Lankan accord to end ethnic strife in Sri Lanka has been slowed by the bitter divisions and suspicions among the Tamil rebel groups, Indian officials say. 3 Kohl and Waldheim meet 2 An Irish family wins a review 2 Sandspit journal 4 Court gets Marine's confession 4 Colombia's revolutionary leader 28 National 6-8, 33 The largest monthly trade deficit was reported for June, as the United States imported $15.71 billion more than it exported. The unexpected deterioration reflected a quickening pace of higher-priced imports. 1 A panel studying genetic engineering found no evidence that organisms developed by such techniques present any ''unique'' ecological hazards. The report was made by a panel of the National Academy of Sciences. 1 An unauthorized test of a bacteria that had been genetically engineered should be ended by destroying the American elms into which the altered microbes have been injected, a committee of scientists said. 7 The pilot of a small plane who flew close to President Reagan's helicopter on Thursday lost his pilot's license for commiting a ''serious breach of safety,'' according to the Federal Aviation Administration. 1 The encounter points up a need to re-establish order in the skies, aviation experts said. Private planes, which account for most near misses, are a particular concern. 8 An archbishop in California called for increasing the role of women in the church and for changing the language of church teachings to show greater sensitivity to women's concerns. 6 The plight of the bottle-nosed dolphin is causing increased concern. Nearly every day, several dead or dying dolphins are washed up onto beaches from New Jersey to Virginia. Scientists are trying to find what is killing them. 6 Record rains fell in Chicago, flooding homes and expressways, stranding passengers at the airport and knocking out power and telephone service to thousands of people. 6 Blue whale seen in New England 6 Atomic structure of superconducting material identified 6 Ehrlichman applies for a Presidential pardon 7 Contractors said to give money to friend of Washington Mayor 8 Black woman fired from pharmacy is asked back 8 Bond revoked for suspect in hospital deaths 33 Regional 29-32 In a proposal on the homeless, the Federal government would reduce its contributions to the cost of keeping families in hotels. The proposal would have a dramatic effect on New York City, a Government official said. 1 Agreement on a citywide rezoning was reached by the Board of Estimate. The rezoning is intended to encourage construction of lower and bulkier apartment buildings for middle-income housing. 1 A playground is at the centerpoint of one of the roughest neighborhoods in New York City. The Gouverneur Morris Playground in the South Bronx is the site of fun and friendliness, as well as crime and drug sales. The police have intensified their presence. 1 Private volunteer ambulances will be used by New York City to help shorten life-threatening delays in responding to medical emergencies, the city's top hospital official said. The decision is a reversal of the city's position. 29 The search for a Schools Chancellor is beginning. The board members said they hoped to act quickly in finding a successor to Nathan Quinones, who announced his retirement Thursday. 29 Community affairs police officers say the dual nature of their job - intelligence gathering and public relations - has often led other police officers to discount the information they have passed on. 29 New government ethics legislation signed into law by Governor Cuomo is important because the country is in a ''crisis of values,'' the Governor said. He portrayed the country as drifting with little respect for principles. 31 A New Jersey regulatory agency has hit on hard times. The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission is facing the deepest problems in its history, raising questions about its future strength and mission. 29 Two are ordered jailed for contempt in Wedtech case 8 Garbage closes Jersey beaches 31

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Moses and Reynolds Win: Edwin Moses and Butch Reynolds of the United States continued their preparations for the world track and field championships with comfortable victories yesterday at the International Athletes Club I.A.A.F.-Mobil Grand Prix meet in London. Moses, 31 years old, won the 400-meter hurdles, the event he has dominated for a decade, in 48.07 seconds. Kriss Akabusi of Britain was second in 49.34. Reynolds, who has set the three fastest 400-meter dash times in the world this year, took the lead with 50 meters to go and won in 44.42 seconds. Innocent Egbunike of Nigeria, the only man to beat Reynolds this season, was second in 44.80. In other events, the men's world high jump record-holder, Patrick Sjoberg of Sweden, won with 7 feet 7 1/4, four inches below his world record, and an American, Arthur Blake, was the surprise winner of the men's 110-meter hurdles in 13.31 seconds, upsetting an Olympic champion, Roger Kingdom.(AP) Tennis Navratilova Advances: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova defeated a 17-year-old qualifier, Elly Hakami of Tiberon, Calif., 6-3, 6-2, in a quarterfinal match yesterday at the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Los Angeles women's tennis tournament in Manhattan Beach, Calif. With the victory, Navratilova moved into the semifinals, where she will meet the winner of the Chris Evert-Lori McNeil match scheduled for last night. The final of the tournament will be played Sunday. The winner will earn $50,000; the runner-up $21,300. In the other two quarterfinal matches, second-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany breezed past ninth-seeded Bettina Bunge of Monaco, 6-1, 6-1, and seventh-seeded Gabriela Sabatini defeated fourth-seeded Hana Mandlikova, 7-6, 2-6, 7-5. Graf will meet Sabatini in the other semifinal.(AP) Carlsson Withdraws: Top-seeded Kent Carlsson of Sweden withdrew from his match against unseeded Francesco Cancellotti of Italy yesterday because of an aching left knee, sending Cancellotti into the semifinals of the $121,000 Aosta Valley clay court tennis tournament in Saint Vincent, Italy. Unseeded Pedro Rebolledo of Chile also made the semifinals by defeating an Australian, Paul McNamee, 6-2, 6-2, in their quarterfinal match.(AP) N.F.L. Redskins Beat Steelers: Ricky Sanders and Art Monk each caught touchdown passes last night in Washington to lead the Redskins to a 23-17 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in the exhibition opener for both teams. With the Redskins leading by 16-14 early in the second half, Sanders slipped behind Harvey Clayton and grabbed a 14-yard pass from Doug Williams to cap a 77-yard 9-play drive. Pittsburgh, hampered by three third-quarter fumbles, could manage only a field goal by Gary Anderson in the second half. The Steelers drove to the Washington 48-yard line in the final minutes, but an illegal-motion penalty wiped out a first-down pass from Steve Bono to Danzell Lee and Pittsburgh did not threaten again. Jay Schroeder completed 11 of 17 passes for 160 yards while playing only the first half for Washington. (AP) Auto Racing Andretti Wins Pole Position: Mario Andretti, the defending champion, earned the pole position for the Quaker State 500 Indy-car race Sunday with a lap of 200.915 miles per hour yesterday at Pocono International Raceway in Long Pond, Pa. A two-time Pocono winner, Rick Mears, was next at 200.611, the only other driver to get above 200. Third, at 198.820, was Bobby Rahal, the defending CART-PPG series champion, who goes into the race leading Andretti's son, Michael, in the point standing, 119-110.(AP)

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT INCREASES SHARPLY AND UNEXPECTEDLY
description: The United States imported $15.71 billion more than it exported in June, a figure that represents the largest trade deficit for any month, the Commerce Department reported today. The unexpected deterioration reflected a quickening pace of higher-priced imports. These included oil, which Government and industry analysts said was being bought in anticipation of Persian Gulf hostilities.

title: Cleric Seeks Wider Role for Women
description: The leader of the nation's largest Roman Catholic archdiocese declared today that sexist language and the exclusion of women from positions of power were alienating Catholic women from the faith.

title: DEVRY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
Missouri Is to Sell $6 Billion In Funds Tied to South Africa
description: Gov. John Ashcroft has signed a measure requiring Missouri's largest pension funds to divest themselves of holdings in companies involved with South Africa.

title: Dolphins Are Still Dying And Baffling Scientists
description: The plight of the bottle-nosed dolphin has become as much a part of the summer scene here as video games and beach umbrellas.

title: A Bill for Better Control of Hazardous Wastes
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $331,000 and $536,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: If Eastern Europeans Object to Military Service
description: LEAD: The United Nations Commission on Human Rights, in a March resolution, acknowledged conscientious objection to military service as a universal right. It called upon member countries to stop imprisoning objectors and to create opportunities for alternative service. Since most Western countries recognize this right, it may seem that the

title: Philadelphia Police Find Skull
description: The police found a human skull early today in a house near a trash-strewn North Philadelphia apartment building where the remains of seven people were found earlier this week.

title: MR. GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Paris dispatch on Tuesday about France's decision against sending troops to an area disputed by Chad and Libya characterized the Chadian forces of President Hissen Habre incorrectly.

title: FILM: FAT BOYS RVISITED
description: You like the Fat Boys or you don't, but they are what they are: three huge (the thin one is a couple of hundred pounds) rap music stars. Either way, you won't get much of what they're famous for in ''Disorderlies,'' a blatant attempt to cross over from rap to mainstream comedy that virtually leaves the group's music behind. Instead, they are dropped into a comedy-suspense plot that's a very cut-rate blend of ''Miami Vice'' and the Three Stooges.

title: At Princeton, They Call it an Education
description: What follows is sheer curmudgeonry. It is my intention to twit, tease, insult and discomfort any and all of my friends connected with Princeton University, however tenuously, by calling attention to what I consider the total disintegration of Princeton's academic standards.

title: Bronx Playground: Focus of Area Under Siege
description: From her vantage point beneath the rustling maple trees at a playground in a South Bronx housing project, Sallie M. Coleman, a grandmother of five, sees young men and women standing in the shadows, wasting their lives in drugs and alcohol.

title: Salvador Rebels Agree to Talk Peace
description: The Salvadoran leftist rebel front today officially accepted President Jose Napoleon Duarte's offer to meet for peace talks next month as part of a new regional peace effort.

title: CNW Stock Up $13.125 After Takeover Talks
description: The CNW Corporation's stock surged $13.125 yesterday, to $39.25 a share, after the Chicago-based railroad company said it might restructure or sell itself.

title: Seoul's Military Vows to Abide by Vote
description: With the military under intense pressure to show its commitment to democracy, South Korea's Defense Minister has offered the first public pledge of military support to the country's next president.

title: How Right-to-Lifers Promote Abortion
description: African hospitals contain ward after ward of women convalescing from botched abortions. One day those wards could be a thing of the past because of sub-Saharan Africa's growing network of family planning clinics, most of them underwritten by the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.

title: Turning Over an Old Leaf
description: LEAD: Before leaving Boston for a week of camping, I stopped into the local bookstore to stock up on summer reading. After only a few minutes, I staggered out empty-handed. The friendly bookstore had been transformed into a high-pressure showroom. The assault came from every table.

title: DETREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Judge Revokes Bond for Suspect In Inquiry Into 28 Hospital Deaths
description: Bail has been revoked for a nurse's aide who is under grand jury investigation in several dozen suspicious hospital deaths.

title: MAXXAM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $8,120,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss Both latest periods include a pre-tax gain resulting from the termination of a pension plan of $18,355,000. As of Dec. 31, 1985, a 90 percent owned unit of Maxxam owned 64.7 percent of Pacific Lumber and in February 1986 acquired the remaining minority interest through a merger. Accordingly, Maxxam's results of operations for 1986 include the results of Pacific Lumber's forest products operations based on 64.7 percent ownership of Pacific Lumber for the first two months of 1986 and 100 percent ownership thereafter.

title: 13 Miners Are Reported Wounded By Police in South Africa Strike
description: A strike by hundreds of thousands of black miners turned increasingly violent today as police officers fired birdshot into crowds of strikers, wounding at least 13 in the first reported use of live ammunition in the six-day strike.

title: Board Seeks A Paragon For Schools
description: Members of the New York City Board of Education, beginning a potentially explosive search for a new Schools Chancellor, said they were looking for a candidate so outstanding that his credentials would quell any possible dispute over the selection.

title: RUSS BERRIE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ESI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $199,851 for the quarter and $164,817 for the 6 months.

title:
Patents;
A Method To Alter Atmosphere
description: LEAD: A METHOD for altering a selected region of air above the earth's surface was patented this week for a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: MICROSCOPE YIELDS ELECTRIC SECRETS
description: A scientist at North Carolina State University said yesterday that he had identified the precise atomic structure of a material that carries electric current with no loss to resistance at close to room temperature.

title: Blind Sailor Docks in Bermuda
description: Jim Dickson, who was trying to become the first blind sailor to cross the Atlantic alone, docked here today, his sloop guided through rough seas and treacherous Bermuda reefs by its designer.

title: Peter Israel Resigns Putnam's Chairmanship
description: Peter Israel resigned yesterday as chairman of the Putnam Publishing Group and as a vice president of MCA Inc., its parent company. A spokesman said only that both parties had agreed ''to end their relationship.'' Mr. Israel was said to be unavailable for comment. No successor was named.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After restructuring costs and writedowns. c-Net income The company said the fourth quarter loss was due principally to the writedown of tobacco inventories of far eastern origin and provision for anticipated losses in its Philippine and Canadian operations.

title: RIFT IS REPORTED
description: Philip C. Habib resigned today as President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, reportedly displeased with the White House's failure to assign him a major role in the new diplomatic efforts for a regional peace settlement.

title: Manpower Meets On Takeover Bid
description: The board of Manpower Inc., the nation's leading temporary help agency, met today to weigh alternatives to an unwanted $1.21 billion takeover bid by Britain's Blue Arrow P.L.C. A company spokeswoman said the company probably would not have a statement until the weekend and maybe not until Monday.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Marine's Confession Presented at Espionage Trial
description: Marine Corps prosecutors put in evidence today the signed confession of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, saying he was recruited by Soviet agents to spy on the American Embassies in Moscow and Vienna, where he was a Marine guard.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Dallas dispatch yesterday about a lawsuit on care for the mentally retarded in Texas misstated the age of residents of state institutions. Most are adults. Because of an editing error, some copies also misstated the filing date of the original lawsuit. It was 1974.

title: Woodson Off to Europe
description: Rod Woodson, the defensive back from Purdue who was the Pittsburgh Steelers's top pick in the college draft last spring, left Thursday night for Europe to compete for a month as a 110-meter hurdler. He has no plans to play football this season and, further, would like to compete next year for the United States in the Olympic Games and then report to the Steelers in early October.

title: A Festival Of Arts in Los Angeles
description: The 10-week Olympic Arts Festival that accompanied the Olympic Games here in 1984 cost more than $11 million, spotlighted 145 companies from 18 countries and every continent and added to Los Angeles's cultural stature. Now a leaner but no less provocative sequel is almost at hand.

title: New Dumping Fees Vex Garbage Haulers
description: Some central New Jersey garbage collectors could not unload trash-laden trucks because they could not afford a 227 percent increase in dumping fees that went into effect yesterday at the state's largest landfill here, officials said.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EQK REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Two Ordered Jailed for Contempt in Wedtech Case
description: The former financial adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the adviser's business partner have been ordered jailed for contempt after they refused to comply with subpoenas issued by a Federal grand jury looking into allegations of corruption at the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Carrie Smith
description: Carrie Smith sings blues and jazz tonight at 9 o'clock at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, below East Fourth Street (212-505-5660). Tickets are $10.

title: MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $77,000 for the quarter and $161,000 for the 6 months.

title: WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $246,000 in the latest quarter and a loss of $44,000 from discontinued operations for the year-earlier period. Corrected from Thursday, Aug. 13, editions.

title: Sonny Fortune
description: Sonny Fortune, an alto saxophonist and flutist, leads a quartet tomorrow at 4 P.M. in a free concert at the Rotunda in Riverside Park, at West 79th Street and the Hudson River near the Boat Basin. Information: (212) 662-5944.

title: DIONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINTOUR LEAVING BRITISH VOGUE FOR HOUSE & GARDEN
description: Anna Wintour, the editor who changed British Vogue from a quirky, insular fashion magazine to a slicker international publication, is coming back to New York to become editor in chief of House & Garden magazine. She starts Sept. 9. ''I've missed New York terribly,'' Miss Wintour said yesterday in a telephone interview from London. ''I'm enormously looking forward to coming back.'' Her new job is not her only cause for celebration. Two weeks ago, Miss Wintour, who is married to Dr. David Shaffer of New York City, gave birth to their second child, a daughter named Kate.

title: Late Rally Lifts Bond Prices
description: A late rally raised prices of Treasury securities yesterday after the bond market was battered early in the session by a Government report of an enormous $15.7 billion trade deficit for June.

title: Panel Discounts Special Hazards In Gene Splicing
description: A panel of the National Academy of Sciences has concluded there is no evidence that organisms developed by the techniques of genetic engineering present any ''unique'' ecological hazards.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 15, 1987
description: The Economy

title: A PASSION FOR UNCLE
description: YOU MUST REMEMBER THIS By Joyce Carol Oates. 436 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: TOBACCO GOES BACK ON TRIAL
description: TOBACCO never grew in this part of the South. But Ella Mae Horton and her lawyers hope it will begin to die here.

title: SHEILA ELIZABETH WILLIAMS IS MARRIED TO DAVID BRUCE
description: Sheila Elizabeth Williams, managing editor of Isaac Asimov's Science Fiction Magazine, and David W. Bruce, data processing chief of Davis Publications, both in New York, were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Universalist Church in Springfield, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Ahlburn officiated.

title: Up the Apalachee Captures a Slowly Run Alabama Stakes
description: The cliche that Saratoga Race Track is the ''Graveyard of Favorites'' requires a bit of alteration this year. It has become the graveyard of D. Wayne Lukas-trained favorites.

title: SAVING A MUSEUM'S BEAUX-ARTS PAST ...
description: THE NEW GALLERIES OF EURO-pean painting at the Art Institute of Chicago do not seem, at first, to be new at all. They are graciously proportioned rooms, detailed with a restrained classical precision, and they look as if they had been displaying paintings and drawings since the institute's Beaux-Arts building by the architects Shepley, Rutan & Coolidge opened in 1893.

title: Dissidents in Mexico's Ruling Party Challenge Half-Century of Tradition
description: THE leader of a dissident faction of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party has threatened to go to court if the party does not hold an open convention to select its candidate for president of Mexico.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Floating Jitney For Amsterdam Museumgoers

title: JEAN K. KASHIWABARA WEDS NORMAN FUTAMI
description: Jean Kiyoko Kashiwabara and Norman Akio Futami were married yesterday at the Marina Del Rey (Calif.) Hotel by the Rev. Dr. Richard Engdahl, a Presbyterian minister.

title: AMBIGUITIES CLOUD OTHERWISE CLEAR AMNESTY CASE
description: LEAD: IN many ways, the life Reyes Ortega has built in the United States is more stable than that of other illegal aliens. He has a wife and four children, a steady job and a home he recently bought in Perth Amboy.

title: NEW SERIES RECOGNIZES FAMOUS ENTERTAINERS
description: TODAY marks the 10th anniversary of the death of Elvis Presley and the collecting craze for ''Presleyana'' has reached philately. Stamps released to honor the rock-and-roll star have generated renewed interest in entertainers on stamps.

title: Recollections of the Ink-Stained
description: THE PARIS EDITION The Autobiography of Waverley Root 1927-1934. Edited by Samuel Abt. 208 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $16.95. WITNESS TO A CENTURY Encounters With the Noted, the Notorious, and the Three SOBs. By George Seldes. Illustrated. 490 pp. New York: Ballantine Books. $19.95.

title: Doctors, Becoming and Unbecoming
description: To the Editor:

title: A DESPERATE SCRAMBLE LEADS THE WAY TO VICTORY
description: TWO of the winners of the recent Interzonal Tournament in Subotica, Yugoslavia, took their prizes in regal style, but the third needed a last-minute desperate scramble to gain a piece of the pie.

title: Doctors, Becoming and Unbecoming
description: To the Editor:

title: LOADS OF LAUNDRY, LOADS OF LIFE
description: WHEN I was 13, my mother taught me to iron so I would be ''a good wife'' someday. I stood in the kitchen, stringy adolescent bangs flopping in my eyes, and sullenly said that I didn't see what was so important about ironing.

title: For Successful Lace Maker, a Threat
description: LEAD: THE American Fabrics Company in Bridgeport, one of Connecticut's two remaining lace manufacturers, is enjoying the current popularity of the elegant material in clothing and fashion accessories. But, like other American manufacturers, it is concerned about foreign competition and a shortage of low-cost skilled workers.

title: NEW TRAILWAY SECTION ADDS ANOTHER LINK TO COUNTY SYSTEM
description: LEAD: ONCE upon a time in Westchester gun-toting desperadoes on horseback would swoop down on an unsuspecting train making its way through a quiet gully in the Town of Mount Pleasant, terrorizing the genteel passengers and stealing the company strongbox.

title: ROUTE 55 EXTENSION PLAN DUE
description: LEAD: A HIGHWAY-NEEDS study is expected at summer's end to offer a financing plan for a Route 55 ''final'' extension that official statistics show could severely cut Atlantic City Expressway revenue.

title: Music: Pinchas Zukerman and Midori
description: MIDORI is such a charmer that she can easily make one overlook the things she is not. She is a crowd pleaser; she is not yet an artist with distinctive ideas.

title: AGNES WALKER
description: Agnes Walker, the widow of an investment banker, died at New London (N.H.) Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. She was 74 years old and lived in New London.

title: Surprises, Rude and Welcome
description: A surprise is welcome when you're on the bridge in St. James's Park and the sun lights up Whitehall or when Mount Rainier materializes after days of rain. A surprise is not welcome if it's a catch in the arrangements or an extra charge for something that already seems to be costing plenty. Here are a few unwelcome surprises reported by letter writers. Knowing about them may defuse the shock for you.

title: Saratoga Fashion; A Place to Enjoy Linens, Languor And the Rustle of Silk
description: SARATOGA and late summer: the combination is almost magical. Perhaps it is the hue of the greensward, which is especially deep and lush this time of year. Or the swift click of the race horses' hooves, or the jockeys in their colorful silks. Or the track crowd languorously strolling the elm-shaded paddock area between races.

title: Developing A Riverfront
description: FOR years, residents of this south-central Maine town failed to see the development potential of the Androscoggin River, which in the 1970's was found by a Federal study to be one of the 10 dirtiest rivers in the nation.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FESTIVE TIMES Quick, before the fall festival season starts, this is a good week to take advantage of what summer still has to offer on the fair front. That action begins today with the Huntington Historical Society's 24th annual Heritage Festival, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at Heckscher Park. Celebrating the town's ethnic diversity, the event will offer historical displays and programs, foods and craft items of a more contemporary nature, and entertainment ranging from an ''All-American Hoedown'' staged by the Frank Ohman Dancers to ethnic music and dance. Admission is $2, or 75 cents for children 5 through 12; those under 5 are admitted free. People with staying power might want to remain at the park for the fully staged performance of the musical ''The King and I.'' It's at 8:30 P.M. and is free.

title: WHEN WILL THE WELSH BE RECOGNIZED?
description: WHY are the Welsh angry? First, let's identify the Welsh. For the uninformed they are descendents of Iberians, the original inhabitants of Wales, the country that bounds the west of England and faces the Irish sea. The Iberian stock is the most widely represented in Wales even though they were displaced by a tall, fair, red-haired people, the Celts, who originated in the valley of the Danube. All this long before the pre-Christian Empires.

title: GYPSIES WITHOUT ROMANCE
description: LEAD: THE PARIAH SYNDROME An Account of Gypsy Slavery and Persecution. By Ian Hancock. Illustrated. 175 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Karoma Publishers. Paper, $17.95.

title: MISS LOUNSBERY WED TO W. R. HEMPHILL Jr.
description: At the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church, Abigail Lounsbery, the daughter of Mrs. DeWitt Lounsbery Jr. of Rye and the late Mr. Lounsbery, was married yesterday to William Rushing Hemphill Jr., the son of Mrs. Hemphill of Austin, Tex., and the late Mr. Hemphill. The Rev. Vance Polley performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Urges Israel To Scrap the Lavi
description: Israel is the largest recipient of American aid, receiving about $1.8 billion in military grants and $1.2 billion in economic assistance yearly. And of this, Israel has been authorized under American law to spend $550 million a year trying to produce a jet fighter called the Lavi.

title: Security Increased In Wake of Fight
description: The tense coexistence between the Cuban delegation at the Pan American Games and opposition groups erupted late Friday night with a fight outside the boxing ring at the Indianapolis Convention Center.

title: 2 Queens Men Arrested in Series of Midtown Hotel Robberies
description: Two Queens men, believed to be members of a team of French-speaking thieves that robbed tourists at three hotels in midtown Manhattan in the last month, have been arrested in the robberies, the police said yesterday.

title: NEAR-MISS FLiER IN ARMY CUSTODY
description: The soldier who while absent without leave piloted the small plane that nearly collided with President Reagan's helicopter Thursday has been turned over to the Army.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'DIGNIFIED' HOUSING On display until Aug. 31 in Westport Town Hall is an exhibition of 50 architectural drawings, plans, photographs and industrial designs defining the work of David Martin, an industrial designer turned architect.

title: KEEPING WILDLIFE FROM MOVING IN
description: TWIN baby raccoons tumbled out of a Woodbridge fireplace and they were angry.

title: IVES SERIES a la Danbury And Canterbury School
description: COMPOSERS and others intrigued with the contemporary music scene are looking to the Charles Ives Center for American Music. The center will begin its eighth summer program, focusing on music for voice, tomorrow at the Canterbury School in New Milford.

title: The Cost of Pursuing a Private Adoption
description: A Brooklyn couple whom we shall call Mary and Phil had been trying to have a child without success for several years when they decided to adopt. For them, agencies were not an option. ''We hadn't been married long enough, and the waiting list was so long,'' Mary said. Instead, they decided to pursue an independent adoption - a procedure in which the would-be parents search out an expectant mother who plans to give up her baby. The prospective parents often pay the pregnant woman's medical and reasonable living expenses, and handle other arrangements an agency would, usually in consultation with an attorney.

title: AT BRADLEY AIRPORT, ART SWAYS IN THE AIR
description: IT is more than a year since Bradley International Airport's new passenger terminal opened, but construction seemed under way again last week as, with the aid of an electric scaffold, T. Merrill (Tim) Prentice installed his new creation, a 230-foot-long vermilion kinetic sculpture, which will sway gently beneath the building's skylight.

title: Civil War Papers Found in Safe Box
description: Another cache of documents, including letters signed by Ulysses S. Grant, has been discovered in a safe-deposit box of Charles Merrill Mount, a portrait painter and art historian who was arrested in Boston Thursday on Federal charges of interstate transportation of stolen property, the authorities said today.

title: Cabaret: Comedians at the Ballroom
description: IN one of the more pungent skits in the new comedy show ''Mixed Doubles,'' which plays late nights at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street), the quick-witted Maura Moynihan and Adam Green portray a Puritanical young couple practicing to go on ''The Newlywed Game.'' Adopting the coyly smutty vocabulary of the show, the couple pepper each other with sample questions inquiring about their ''whoopee sessions.'' ''Was it more like poker, war or pin-the-tail-on-the-donkey?'' ''Would your wife describe you as Dr. Feelgood or Dr. Doolittle?'' Soon enough, egos are bruised and the marriage begins to unravel. ''I want the things I read about in 'Penthouse' and that I saw on 'The Newlywed Game,' '' the young husband pouts plaintively.

title: 'DIRTY DANCING' ROCKS TO AN INNOCENT BEAT
description: KELLERMAN'S, THE FICTIVE Catskills hotel that provides the setting for the new film ''Dirty Dancing,'' is meant to be more than the sum of its parts, which are golf, gossip and gefilte fish. It stands as a metaphor for America in the summer of 1963 - orderly, prosperous, bursting with good intentions, a sort of Yiddish-inflected Camelot. So when Frances (Baby) Houseman, the doctor's daughter at the film's center, loses both her virginity and her political naivete to a street-smart dance teacher, the collision should shake the audience, too, out of a certain complacency.

title: THE NATION: Verity Chosen; A Surprise For Commerce
description: IT was a surprise all around, though a pleasant one to most businessmen and legislators, when President Reagan chose C. William Verity Jr. to head the Commerce Department. In two weeks of speculation about a successor to Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, who died July 25 after a steer-roping accident, Mr. Verity's name had not come up.

title: TV VIEW
description: ELVIS PRESLEY DIED 10 YEARS ago today at the age of 42, and for the past week, the occasion has been marked with everything from the publication of new books about the performer to special TV reports from the garish Memphis mansion he called Graceland. The Elvis industry clearly continues to flourish. Elvis remains a key pop icon for the 20th century, right up there with Valentino, Garbo and Garland.

title: Russia Is 'In' For Potpourri Of Americans
description: ''This year, if it's Soviet, it's sexy.''

title: SUSHI AND BEYOND IN BROOKFIELD
description: WHILE some food trends travel like a flash flood through Connecticut's back roads (witness Cajun cooking), others, such as Japanese cuisine, move at a tortoise pace.

title: Police in Chile Add Mystery To Death of 2
description: Murder was committed on Dec. 15, 1985, in a rustic setting on the eastern edge of Santiago, where the suburbs rise to the Andes.

title: Defective Gene May Contribute To Colon Cancer
description: Many scientists have long thought that environmental factors, such as high-fat and low-fiber diets, contribute to the development of colon cancer. Last week, researchers in London reported that the disease might also have a genetic cause.

title: MOVIES
description: The Girl From Petrovka Starring Goldie Hawn, Hal Holbrook, Anthony Hopkins. Produced by Richard D. Zanuck and David Brown. Directed by Robert Ellis Miller. 1974. MCA Home Video. 103 minutes. $59.95 She's flouncy, she's cutesy, she's adorable, she's Goldie Hawn. Alas, she never comes close to being believable as a Russian ballerina named Oktyabrina. In chyaracteryizing Ms. Hawn's attyempts to appryoximate a Ryussian accyent, perhyaps it wyould be myost chyaritable to say that she has been cyomically myiscast.

title: NAOMI AUGUST IS WED
description: At the Church Center for the United Nations in New York, Naomi August, the daughter of Bella August of New York and Michael August of Elmhurst, Queens, was married yesterday to Richard Imbrogno, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Imbrogno of Johnsonburg, Pa. The Rev. James J. Gardiner, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. The bride is a student at Hunter College. The bridegroom, a graduate of Pennsylvania State University and the New York University School of Law, is a partner in the New York law firm of Yeager & Lang.

title: ROBERT STAVINS, ECONOMIST, WEDS MISS WROBLEWSKA
description: Joanna Wroblewska, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrzej K. Wroblewski of Warsaw, and Robert Stavins, a son of Mrs. Sidney Stavins of Chicago and the late Mr. Stavins, were married last evening at the Wayside Inn in Sudbury, Mass., by Rabbi Neil Kaminski.

title:
NUMISMTICS;
A MAJOR COIN SHOW WILL OPEN NEXT WEEK
description: LEAD: Hundreds of coin dealers and thousands of collectors will gather next week in Atlanta for the 96th anniversary convention of the American Numismatic Association. The A.N.A. convention is the world's biggest coin show and the most diverse with a wide variety of activities including a bourse with more than 400 dealer tables, an extensive exhibit area, a major auction, an educational forum and a Young

title: Pumps and Conservation
description: The Federal Government and, increasingly, the states have spent billions trying to move water from where it is to where it is wanted. But many factors - faster-than-expected growth, changing patterns of water use or a summer without rain - can still confound those plans. What follows are reports on how different regions are coping with the problems of providing enough water to their industries, households and farms.

title: Q and A
description: Paris Terminal Question: Where can I find the Charles de Gaulle Airport bus terminal in Paris? - F. M. R., Wilmington, Del. Answer: The terminal for Charles de Gaulle Airport buses is at Porte Maillot (also a Metro stop) in the Palais des Congres convention center. Buses leave for the airport from outside the center; coming from the airport, they arrive near the Concorde La Fayette Hotel on the other side of the block. The buses also stop at Avenue Carnot and Rue de Tilsitt near the Place de l'Etoile. They run from 5:45 A.M. to 11 P.M. every day. Departures are scheduled every 12 minutes for the No. 1 terminal at de Gaulle and every 15 minutes for the No. 2 Terminal. The one-way fare is about $6, with reduced rates for groups of three or four people traveling together. The journey takes 30 to 45 minutes, depending on traffic.

title: Chad's Toyotas Rout Libyan Tanks
description: Disdaining French advice to try international arbitration, Chad sent its desert fighters on a sweep into the disputed Aozou Strip last weekend, inflicting new defeats and humiliation on the Libyan forces occupying the area. Chadians and diplomats in Ndjamena, the capital, said Chad's lightweight Toyotas, armed with French Milan antitank missiles, knocked out 82 military vehicles, including 7 Soviet-built T-55 tanks. Outflanking Libyan defenses, the Chadians raced through mountain passes and dry riverbeds. They said they routed 1,000 Libyan soldiers, killing 650, and capturing Aozou village, 50 miles south of the border.

title: Appalachian Trail Gathering Marks Its 50th Anniversary
description: Friends of the Appalachian Trail celebrated its 50th anniversary today by dedicating a trailside plaque honoring the work crews of the Depression era that forged the final link in the famous footpath from Maine to Georgia.

title: Lake Called 'Eyesore'
description: LEAD: NEIGHBORS of Massapequa Lake, a 400-acre preserve that is a Nassau County park, have complained to the county that the area has been fouled by illegal dumping, is infested with rats and is used by teen-agers who take drugs.

title: If the Bard Worked in the Bronx
description: As a student of literature, I feel sure that if Shakespeare were alive today and a baseball fan, his Sonnet XXIX would be changed in the following manner: When, in disgrace with fortune and men's eyes, I all alone beweep my outcast state, And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries, And look upon myself and curse my fate, Wishing me like to one more rich in hope, Featur'd like him, like him with friends possess'd, Desiring this man's art, and that man's scope, With what I most enjoy contented least; Yet in these thoughts myself almost despising, Haply I think on this; and then my state, Like to the lark at break of day arising From sullen earth, sings hymns at heaven's gate; That though my life's been stained by grief and loss, I've never had Steinbrenner as a boss. KEN RADER Edison, N.J.

title: Giants Move Into Tie for First
description: Dave Dravecky pitched a four-hitter and the San Francisco Giants defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-0, today to move into a first-place tie with Cincinnati in the National League West.

title: MIAMI'S IMAGE
description: Robert Sherrill's article ''Can Miami Save Itself?'' (July 19) does not reflect the current reality of this cosmopolitan and vibrant city.

title: Television and Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: 'NIMBY' TAKES HOLD
description: AS new or heightened social needs require the building of new or expanded means to meet them, community opposition has become a phenomenom so pronounced that it has acquired a nickname: ''Nimby,'' for ''Not in my backyard.''

title: WHEN THE JURY'S OUT (EATING)
description: LEAD: EVERY week 225 doughty citizens fill the central jury room at the Westchester County Courthouse in White Plains, answering the civic call to serve two weeks as trial jurors. Every day shortly after noon, this body is recessed for a leisurely 90-minute lunch. Like almost everyone else at this hour in White

title: Resources for Pied Pipers
description: It may sound smart to say that London is a man's town or that the English don't really care for children. But those who propound such views are having to refine their appraisals. There are enough push-chairs (strollers to people west of the Atlantic) on the streets of London these days to create a new sort of traffic jam. And shopping is not just Harvie & Hudson, Turnbull & Asser and Hilditch & Key. Visitors used to making a beeline for Jermyn Street should put Hamleys (for toys), Young World and Mothercare on their lists, too.

title: Booming Cities Buy Up 'Water Ranches' in Southwest
description: The Federal Government and, increasingly, the states have spent billions trying to move water from where it is to where it is wanted. But many factors - faster-than-expected growth, changing patterns of water use or a summer without rain - can still confound those plans. What follows are reports on how different regions are coping with the problems of providing enough water to their industries, households and farms.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: WASHINGTON, D.C.;
Home Builders Insure Buyers
description: LEAD: THE home-building industry says it is now the nation's largest insurer of home buyers against the cost of repairing major defects in new homes.

title: They Love Him Tender, Love Him True
description: LEAD: Elvis came to my hometown of Wichita Falls, Tex., when I was in the seventh grade. He came in a pink Cadillac, and he played the Memorial Auditorium downtown, selling almost every seat. My friends and I sat up in the balcony, sailing paper airplanes and showing off for the girls while we waited for the show to start.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A LITTLE UNSCHEDULED ESPIONAGE TO HELP UNCLE SAM
description: LEAD: A STRANGER approaches and I wonder, Should I be afraid? My husband and I recently faced this question at a rest stop on I-95 when a young woman walked up to us and pleaded with us to take an envelope from her.

title:
DINING OUT;
DUTCH-INDONESIAN IN MAMARONECK
description: LEAD: ONE in a handful of interesting eating spots to open recently is Luke's, bringing to the county some Dutch cooking from the owners Linda and Luke Teurlinckx. Under a somewhat deceptive rotisserie chicken sign - for the place often serves more and better than that - the storefront restaurant is hardly more than 10 feet wide and easy to miss.

title: PIERRE S. DU PONT 5TH WEDS JEAN YOUNG IN DOBBS FERRY
description: Jean Averill Young and Pierre Samuel du Pont 5th were married yesterday at the Zion Episcopal Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. Godley performed the ceremony.

title: IN THE TRENCHES OF SCIENCE
description: CERTAIN AMERICAN SCIENTISTS WASTED SOME time recently trying to make a superconductor out of the wrong element. They were chasing a phantom - a typographical error by the physicist Ching-Wu Chu. Certain American scientists believe that the error was no accident.

title: Gandhi Promises Support for Victims of Drought
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, unfurling the Indian flag in celebration of the 40th anniversary of the country's independence, pledged that his Government would cope with a severe drought.

title: MARCIE SMITH MARRIES ALI BARKER, FELLOW CHEF
description: Marcie Smith, sous-chef at the Union Square Cafe in New York, and Ali Halim Barker, executive chef there, were married yesterday at the Mayfield Country Club in Cleveland by the Rev. Dr. Lewis Raymond, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Mysterious Case Of a Rich Friar
description: WHEN he joined a Roman Catholic order of friars at a New Jersey monastery in 1934, the Rev. Angelus DeMarco took a vow of poverty. When he died in Virginia of a brain tumor in 1984, he left an estate valued at $873,000 and no explanation of how he had acquired the wealth.

title:
RECORDINGS;
The Many Colors of Music for Winds
description: LEAD: COMPARED WITH THE STRING quartet, whose emotional display is inherent in the pronounced vibrato of each voice combined with the friction of rosined horsehair drawn against gut or wire, there is an almost chaste quality to the sound of a wind ensemble, a crispness and cleanness that can impress one as being a bit detached at times.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: THE OTHER EVENING, AS I SAT in the Festspielhaus in Bayreuth trying to make out Wagner's ''Parsifal'' through a scrim of obscurantism thrown up by a much-publicized Gotz Friedrich staging, it struck me that this was an archetypal 1980's opera production: enormous amounts of theatrical energy and technical expertise had been expended to rescue a work that did not need rescuing. Despite a currently fashionable notion to the contrary, the better an opera -and ''Parsifal'' certainly qualifies as one of the better ones - the less it should require radical staging to make its point. I do not want, for instance, a director to demystify ''Parsifal'' or make me think its ambiguities do not exist. Even less do I want its murky poetry ignored in favor of some director's political agenda or social theories - Wagner's own ideas are hard enough to swallow.

title: THOSE INFURIATING, BUT MEANINGLESS HATS
description: GROWING up I learned that hats come off when you enter a public building. Through 21 years of sitting in classrooms, I never saw a hat on the head of a fellow student. Wearing a baseball cap in a classroom would be as disrespectful as wearing one at a wedding or a funeral or in a church at any time.

title: PRANKSTER PALS: THE APPEAL NEVER AGES
description: SO WHAT'S THE SPECIAL KICK of ''Stakeout,'' John Badham's new movie about a team of detectives assigned to keep an eye on the house of an all-time bad guy's sometime girlfriend? Not exactly a novel plot or situation - cop teams are a drug on the movie and television markets; they're due for a bust - and you don't have to have second sight to predict love at first sight between one of the cops at least and the shapely woman under surveillance.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: THE state Department of Transportation plans to add a second exclusive bus lane on the Route 495 approach to the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Gold but No Rush inConnecticut
description: AS gold discoveries go, the initial word on the find in Connecticut was impressive, to say the least.

title: CHEWING ON WORDS
description: I have been ''grazing'' in restaurants for years, but not in the mode described by Bryan Miller. His ''grazing'' might more correctly be called restaurant hopping.

title: EVACUATION PLAN FOUGHT ON ZONING
description: LEAD: THE Long Island Lighting Company has run into further problems in Nassau County with its emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: THERE'S MORE TO LIFE THAN ASTRAL VOYAGES
