description: THE SAVIORS By Helen Yglesias. 306 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: HEALTH INSURANCE FOR MENTAL ILLNESS: 6-BILL Package Called Vital First Step
description: LEAD: ''WITH mental illness,'' said the mother of a young schizophrenic from Bergen County, ''there is no middle, beginning or end. There are so many uncertainties; you never know what is going to happen. It is worse than dealing with a terminal illness.''

title: KATHLEEN FRANCIS WED
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, Kathleen Gail Francis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Francis of Nutley, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter John George, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. George of Reading, England. The Rev. John Andrew, the rector, officiated. The bride is an account executive for Independent Television Sales Inc. in New York. The bridegroom is president of Peter George Associates, acoustics and theater consultants in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: A COUNTRY YEAR: Living the Questions, by Sue Hubbell. Illustrations by Lauren Jarrett. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) In this chronicle of a year in the Ozark Mountains, Sue Hubbell, a former librarian, describes how she has filled the void that opened with her divorce by building ''a new kind of order, a structure on which a fifty-year-old woman can live her life alone.

title: GALPIN BRIDE OF K. L. TWOMBLY
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Priscilla Bliss Galpin, manager of the alpine and perennial plant departments at Oliver Nurseries in Fairfield, Conn., was married to Kenneth L. Twombly, president and chief executive of Kenneth L. Twombly Tree Experts and Nursery in Monroe, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony.

title: Lilla Matheson to Wed C. F. Ohrstrom
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tompkins Matheson of The Plains, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lilla Youngblood Matheson to Christopher Finley Ohrstrom, a son of Ricard Riggs Ohrstrom of The Plains and Sun Valley, Idaho, and Mary Viscountess Rothermere of Newport, R.I. The wedding is to be Sept. 26.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HUNGARIAN FESTIVAL A Hungarian Festival of Music and Food in Roebling next Sunday is being presented by the Catholic Church of St. Nicholas, Byzantine Rite.

title: TV DRAMAS: SWEET AGREEMENT, LITTLE GRIT
description: TELEVISION AWARDS, AS ANY dedicated viewer knows, have become an elaborate and sleep-inducing exercise in self-congratulation.

title: Harlem's Hedge Against Gentrification
description: IT is not the first struggle over the gentrification of Harlem and it certainly won't be the last, but new battle lines in the war were drawn last week when David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, condemned a city plan to turn over 45 empty buildings there to a white construction company to develop 900 units of new housing.

title: The Candidates vs. the Deficit
description: If all the Presidential candidates' promises to wipe out the Federal budget deficit were laid end to end, the surpluses would stretch well into the 21st century. They agree, with disarming unanimity, that the deficit is terrible. They disagree on remedies. And they underestimate the difficulties. If they want to be taken seriously on one of the most serious issues, they'll have to do better.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: THE party line of disciplined people who lead disciplined lives is that lack of time isn't a terribly good excuse for not doing a whole bunch of worthwhile things. In fact, according to these people, it's no excuse at all because most of the worthwhile things they are fond of lecturing and hectoring about can be done in a matter of minutes.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended Aug. 1 MANHATTAN Chelsea $530,000 116 West 29th Street 3,182-sq.-ft. loft-studio co-op in a renovated prewar building; living/ work area, 2 baths, hardwood floors; maintenance $565, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Jaffe LaSalle) Upper East Side $156,000 118 East 60th Street (Plaza Tower) 1-bedroom, 1 bath, 700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, windowed kitchen, balcony; maintenance $728, 55% tax-deductible (Broker: Olshan Realty Upper East Side $215,000 425 East 79th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 950-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, windowed kitchen, optional parking; maintenance $516, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) Upper West Side $201,000 5 West 107th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. co-op in a renovated prewar building; dining area, washer/dryer in kitchen; maintenance $532, 70% tax-deductible (Broker: Gala Realty) Washington Heights $125,000 350 Cabrini Boulevard 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 850-sq,-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar Art Deco building; part-time doorman, sunken living room, Hudson River view; maintenance $448, 41% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) BRONX Allerton $148,000 2722 Pearsall Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, brick, semi-attached house; formal dining room, den, finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Tryax Realty) Baychester $168,000 614 East 241st Street 2-Family, detached, frame house; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in both units; full-basement, 2-car garage, hardwood floors, 50- by 64-ft. lot; taxes $970 (Broker: Sterling Realty) BROOKLYN Boerum Hill $540,000 376 Pacific Street 2-family, attached ''Eastlake Facade'' brownstone; 4 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths in upper duplex; 3 bedrooms, 2 1/2 baths in other; large kitchen, dining room, fireplace, original moldings in both; 21- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $2,088 (Broker:

title: EDMUND KEEN GRAVELY JR. IS MARRIED TO MISS LOONEY
description: Stacy Ashlin Looney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Crawford Looney of Rocky Mount, N.C., was married there yesterday to Edmund Keen Gravely Jr., a son of Mrs. Gravely of Rocky Mount and the late Mr. Gravely. The Rev. Charles I. Penick performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd.

title: A LA CARTE
description: A LONG time ago, pizza became one of America's favorite foods. Recently, Long Island has broken out with a rash of interesting pizza possibilities. Decidedly non-Italian restaurants are offering individual pizzas, and even the familiar pizza parlors have added surprises.

title: Rhode Island Bans Pesticide
description: Rhode Island today became the third state to ban the pesticide chlordane, a termite killer that has been found to cause cancer and liver problems in laboratory tests. New York and Massachusetts have also banned the pesticide. The ban takes effect here Dec. 1.

title: Food; Desserts for Melting Days
description: ICE CREAM IS THE STUFF that memories are made of. At least that is true for me, for I never fail to recall the jingle of bells from the Good Humor truck announcing its load of cooling refreshment. Packs of children came running from every direction to the truck, parked at the end of a sandy road that led to the beach. We crowded close to the cooling vapors that curled from the freezer while the Good Humor man handed out the treats: sticks of cream covered in toasted almonds, coconut or chocolate, or orange ice that stuck to your tongue on the first lick, slowly giving way to the pleasure of smooth vanilla cream. All of us clamored to be served first.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SPOTLIGHT ON KEROUAC ''Tea With Mommy and Jack,'' a play about Jack Kerouac, the beat-generation writer, and his relationship with his mother, will have its world premiere at the Byrdcliffe Theater in Woodstock Thursday through Sept. 6. Sylvia Miles portrays the mother, James Eckhouse plays Jack, and Laura Innes is his girlfriend Josie.

title: OSHA
description: To the Editor:

title: Hudson River PCB Dredging Is Seen as Damaging Farms
description: The state's Agriculture Commissioner charged this week that the Department of Environmental Conservation had ignored the dangers to farming in its plan to dredge PCB's from the Hudson River and bury them ashore.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Someone should check the market's bat for cork.''

title: Nile River Hotel Fire Kills 2
description: Two people died and a man and his infant daughter were reported missing today after fire engulfed a floating hotel on the Nile River, the police said. The fire was believed to have started in the hotel's souvenir shop in the early morning. The police said 10 people had been rescued.

title: The System Is Robin Hood in Reverse
description: OVER the past several decades, a significant redistribution of Federal funding has occurred across the country. In the case of both grants-in-aid and total Federal procurement of goods and services, most states in the Southern region of the United States have witnessed an erosion of their relative positions on a per capita basis. Last year, for example, Federal grants to state and local governments in New York totaled $679 per capita, fourth highest in the country, while Texas received only $313, putting it next to the bottom.

title: Switching Sides in The Indian Wars
description: It may have come too late to improve New York City's chances of keeping the Museum of the American Indian, but last week Mayor Koch and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato withdrew their opposition to a plan that might yet work. Rather than let the museum move its nearly one million tribal artifacts to Washington, they said, they would support relocating it to the old United States Custom House at Bowling Green.

title: Uncertain Future Of Historic Ruins
description: ONCE it was one of the largest and grandest hospitals in New York City, a granite haven on Roosevelt Island whose staff cared for thousands of Union soldiers during the Civil War and many more of the city's poor after that. It was designed in 1858 by James Renwick Jr., who drew the plans for St. Patrick's Cathedral the same year. First it was called Island Hospital, then Charity Hospital and finally City Hospital. In that time the island's name changed from Blackwells to Welfare to Roosevelt.

title: Budapest
description: Budapest is one of the great European music bargains in almost any season, but never more so than in autumn. On Sept. 15, the opulently restored Hungarian State Opera will open its 104th season, and on Oct. 20 the company's second - but equally first-rate - house, the Erkel Opera, reopens its doors. This means that, at the rate of six evenings plus Sunday matinees, the operagoer has 14 performances from which to choose any week. And the price for the best seats in either house (the State Opera is at 22 Nepkoztarsasag Avenue, telephone 320126, the Erkel at 30 Koztarsasag Square, 330540) ranges from less than $3 to a little more than $5, depending on the production, if you buy them at the box office. The rate goes up on the infrequent occasions when a guest star, who has to be paid in a scarce foreign currency, appears.

title: KENYA
description: NAIROBI'S LOCAL BARS, thick with people, cigarette smoke and rough-edged good times, rock to a staccato beat that echoes the traditional rhythms of Kenya's rural villages.

title: GLEN COVE MAYOR FACES CHALLENGE
description: LEAD: A POLITICAL storm is hovering over the City of Glen Cove this summer, pitting Democrats against Democrats, with Republicans watching with interest on the sidelines.

title: Press Notes; Forbes Silent, Goodson Isn't, A Bad Review
description: Forbes magazine's refusal to answer questions regarding a recent controversy involving one of its columnists has put the business biweekly in the middle of a second controversy over the decision to remain silent.

title: A Man in Jersey Kills Ex-Wife and Daughter
description: A man fatally shot his former wife outside her house today, then went inside the home and killed their 4-year-old daughter and himself as the police arrived, authorities said.

title: From Baby Toys to Exercise Gear
description: BACK in 1970, if there were gas stations on all four corners of an intersection in the Far West, chances were all offered Blue Chip Stamps. That was the period when the company hit its peak; it had 90 redemption stores in California, Nevada, Oregon and Arizona.

title: SUNY Expected to Act on Executive Salaries
description: Trustees of the State University of New York are expected to consider a new executive pay plan this week that would raise the salaries of top administrators to levels comparable with those offered at state universities across the country, officials said last week.

title: HOLMDEL WOMAN FINDS THIRD FULL-TIME CAREER
description: LEAD: WELL into her third career, Lenore Herson of this Monmouth County community is strong evidence that a woman can achieve many goals and be happy without being locked into one profession.

title: Roman J. Lexton Dies at 70; Retired Judge in Connecticut
description: Roman J. Lexton, a retired Superior Court judge, died at his home here early today after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: MIAMI'S IMAGE
description: I have ambivalent feelings about Robert Sherrill's article. Having recently returned to New Jersey from a two-year assignment with my company in Miami, I believe that he has accurately highlighted some of the problems facing that city. However, he has perpetuated some of the unwarranted fears and misconceptions concerning the area.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: ANTIQUES IN TARRYTOWN

title: The City Opera: A New Production Of 'Die Zauberflote'
description: STRANGE, but true. The New York City Opera, for the first time in its history, put on ''Die Zauberflote'' last evening. Of course, the company has often performed Mozart's opera, but always as ''The Magic Flute,'' never in the original German. This staging replaced Beni Montressor's 1966 production, which had reached such a point of decay that fire insurance could not be obtained for it.

title: Leashes for Bipeds?
description: To the Editor:

title: Marlboro
description: To the Editor:

title: Langella Finds Playing Holmes Isn't Elementary
description: IN THE MIDST OF SIPPING A 1794 Chateauneuf-du-Pape, flirting with a fine-boned redhead, smoking hashish from his calabash pipe, and explaining a few things to Dr. Watson about jiujitsu, sodium sulfate and Tibetan yoga, Sherlock Holmes takes a moment to discuss his feelings.

title: A RECORD HONEY CROP IS EXPECTED FOR THE STATE
description: BEEKEEPERS in the state can expect this year's honey harvest to be their biggest ever, according to an Agriculture Department official.

title: MOVIES
description: The Four Feathers With John Clements, Ralph Richardson, Joan Duprez, C. Aubrey Smith. Directed by Zoltan Korda. 1939. Embassy Home Entertainment. 115 minutes. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: JACKIE COCHRAN: An Autobiography. By Jacqueline Cochran and Maryann Bucknum Brinley. (Bantam, $18.95.) This story of a pioneer aviator and quasi politician could be called a profile in gumption.

title: Nuts to Nomenclature
description: WHAT THIS COUNTRY needs is a polite word meaning ''right-wing nut.'' At present, you cannot call a right-wing nut ''a right-wing nut,'' at least not in respectable journals.

title: Don't Base Decisions on Distorted Data
description: FOR more than a decade, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, has issued annual reports about the flow of Federal funds. He has shown that the Northern states have consistently paid more in taxes than they have received in total Federal expenditures. In fact, he notes that the Northeast-Midwest region's balance-of-payments deficit with the Federal Government has become ''structural,'' rooted in underlying defense outlays and procurement practices.

title: 'Punches in Bunches' for U.S.
description: As they continue to develop a group identity, and as they attempt to reverse the Cuban dominance of recent years, the United States boxers at the Pan American Games have displayed two characteristics.

title: Pop/Jazz
description: In the United States, George Gershwin and Leonard Bernstein, among many others, pulled 20th-century popular music into the concert hall. In Argentina, Astor Piazzolla reversed the equation: He took the harmonies and structures of Stravinsky, Bartok and other 20th-century modernists and applied them to Argentina's own popular music, the tango. The result - denounced by some, embraced by others -brought him international recognition. Mr. Piazzolla, a virtuoso on the bandoneon (an Argentine accordion), leads the Quinteto Tango Nuevo, a group (with piano, violin, bass, guitar) that plays with a gutsy precision comparable to the Juilliard String Quartet; the music, by turns steely and sultry, is filled with undeniable passion. Aston Piazzolla and Quinteto Tango Nuevo will be at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Design Flaw Reported at 2 Westchester Reactors
description: The two Indian Point nuclear reactors operated for several years with a design flaw that could have blocked the automatic start of a key safety system, according to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Chicago Reshapes A Treasure
description: THE REDESIGNED AND RE-installed new galleries at the Art Institute of Chicago are by common consent a model of what such things should be. Not only do we see great and famous works of art in profusion, but we are led to look with fresh eyes at others, not so famous and perhaps not always so great, that have been placed in such a way as to hold our attention. The adventure speaks throughout for a curatorial intelligence that is as radical as it is unostentatious. At every turn we are enriched, and when we are all done with the tour we walk out with a headful of new ideas and a sweet persistent exhilaration. What more can we ask of a museum?

title: Film
description: Going to Alice Tully Hall these days is a little like going to a cocktail party where all the hors d'oeuvres border on the irresistible.

title: Suspended Animation
description: HE has a lot of time on his hands while serving a 10-game suspension for scuffing baseballs, and Joe Niekro of the Minnesota Twins was trying to make the best of it Friday night, playing the offense for laughs as a guest on ''Late Night With David Letterman'' in New York.

title: THOUSANDS GATHER IN SEOUL TO MARK DEMOCRATIC GAINS
description: Several thousand people gathered on this day when Korea marks its liberation from Japanese occupation in 1945 to hail the democratic changes they won last month and to call for more.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Altering Bats and Balls a Part Of Baseball?
description: Of course it's a part of baseball. The same as synthetic playing surfaces and the various dimensions of the outfields. Just as allowing seven-footers and over to play basketball without raising the height of the baskets or using oversized racquets in tennis. If everything in baseball was the same except for the talents of the players, what would there be to write or talk about in the press or on radio and television. BUD WEILL Bronx, N.Y.

title: OUTLOOK DOUBTFUL ON CHARTER SHIFT
description: Even though President Reagan pointed out in his televised speech Wednesday night that a new constitutional convention ''is only two states away from approval,'' there are widespread doubts that such a gathering will ever convene.

title: SCHOOLS JOIN ON SUICIDE EFFORT
description: LEAD: AT a time when many school systems in the state are developing their own programs to address various aspects of teen-age suicide, several school systems in eastern Fairfield County recently joined together to create a regional program.

title: Martha Bailey Is Married
description: At Grace Church in New York, Martha Davenport Bailey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Davenport Bailey of New York, was married yesterday to David Paul Filosa, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Filosa of Stony Brook, L.I. The Rev. Ross Wright, an Episcopal priest, officiated. The bride is a member of the class of '88 at the Brooklyn Law School and is a summer associate at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Mr. Filosa is in trading and sales at Drexel Burnham Lambert's international division in New York.

title: THE SPY THEY LEFT BEHIND
description: CONSPIRACY OF SILENCE The Secret Life of Anthony Blunt. By Barrie Penrose and Simon Freeman. Illustrated. 616 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: STRATFORD RESTORES ITS CIVIL WAR STATUE
description: RELATIVELY few century-old monuments cast in zinc survive these days, but in Stratford, townspeople have rescued a treasured statue honoring their Civil War heroes.

title: A Sri Lanka Run on Saffron Robes May Bode Ill
description: In what could be a curious omen of more violence, the authorities here have reported a run on saffron robes, the traditional garb of Buddhist monks.

title:
THE MIDWEST;
Saving on Irrigation
description: LEAD: The Federal Government and, increasingly, the states have spent billions trying to move water from where it is to where it is wanted. But many factors - faster-than-expected growth, changing patterns of water use or a summer without rain - can still confound those plans. What follows are reports on how different regions are coping with the problems of providing enough water to their industries, households and farms.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Altering Bats and Balls a Part Of Baseball?
description: It is unfortunate that altered bats and balls are now and always have, to some extent, been a part of major league baseball. It is equally unfortunate, however, that the regulation strike zone (the armpits to the knees) is no longer a part of the major leagues.

title: Cold Spring Harbor
description: A WALK along Main Street in Cold Spring Harbor is like sauntering into a village downtown of the mid-19th century, with brick sidewalks, white picket fences and Victorian-age facades masking modern boutiques.

title: Stiff Massachusetts Bill Would Speed Removal of Lead Paint
description: As medical evidence emerges that the point at which lead becomes harmful to children may be lower than previously supposed, the Massachusetts House of Representatives has passed a tough bill that would speed the removal of lead paint from dwellings.

title: Bonn 'Summer Theater' Turns Nasty
description: To anyone unfamiliar with Bonn's traditional ''summer theater,'' it may not be immediately clear why there is a political hubbub in this city about 14 people jailed in Chile under threat of execution.

title: DEBRA LYNN STEIN, BANKER, AND SCOTT ROSEN TO MARRY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Stein of Allentown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Debra Lynn Stein, to Scott Ira Rosen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rosen of Wayne, N.J.

title: Miners' Strike in South Africa Raises the Spirit of Resistance
description: THE nationwide strike launched last week by more than 300,000 black miners has caused new political uncertainty in South Africa. The strike raised the spirits of the anti-apartheid movement, battle-weary after 14 months of emergency rule that has effectively stifled resistance to white domination. And it produced new headaches for the Government and the mine owners at a time when gold prices have been rising, bolstering the economy and inflating profits.

title: DIANE ADAMS TO MARRY
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Halstead J. Adams of New York and Quogue, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter, Diane Lynn Adams, to Richard Henry Rush Toland Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Toland of Malvern, Pa. The future bride, a daughter also of the late Mr. Adams, is employed by the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation in New York, and her fiance is a communications manager for Bear Stearns & Company in New York. An October wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
LYME DISEASE MONEY
description: LEAD: IN May, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke asked the Board of Legislators to allocate $240,000 for a comprehensive seven-month program to combat Lyme Disease, the tick-borne malady that has afflicted more than 1,400 people in Westchester since 1983. This month, the board's Budget and Appropriations Committee approved $121,000 for a revised package of programs that will run through the end of this year.

title: DR. JILL ARMBRUST WED TO JONATHAN HOLTZMAN
description: Dr. Jill Armbrust, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of California at San Francisco, and Jonathan Holtzman, a special assistant to the San Francisco City Attorney, were married yesterday at the Auberge du Soleil, a restaurant in Rutherford, Calif. Rabbi Charles Familant and Rabbi Myron Fenster, an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: VARIATIONS ON '2' IN SOUTH NYACK
description: PORING over stacks of obscure show albums in an out-of-the-way record store in Manhattan, the Belfry Repertory Company's artistic director, Joseph A. Verlezza, came upon ''2,'' a little-known revue performed under the auspices of the Equity Library Theater at Lincoln Center in 1978.

title: COUPLE SUE IN SIEGE OF HOME
description: DEC. 26, 1986, was supposed to be nothing more than the traditional do-nothing day after Christmas for Gladys and Allan Olson - yet another sizing up of the gifts, a few greetings shared with long-time neighbors and later a family dinner with a son, a granddaughter and her boyfriend, all home for the holday.

title: CORRECTION
description: The ''On Language'' column in The Times Magazine today refers incorrectly to the Neville Chamberlain who originated the term ''snooker.'' The originator was Col. Sir Neville Francis Fitzgerald Chamberlain (1856-1944), a career officer in the British Army, not the Neville Chamberlain who later became Prime Minister of Britain.

title: Thousands Strike In the New Korea As Army Relents
description: The South Korean economy has boomed with considerable help from 57-hour work weeks and $1.75-an-hour industrial wages that enabled Korean exporters to undercut many competitors in the United States and other markets. The average hourly wage for American production workers, for example, was more than $13 an hour in 1985.

title: Super Giants Fit and Willing
description: Only six and a half months after they played their last game, the Giants will play another football game Sunday.

title: Stocks Zoom, But Economy Is Dwadlinge
description: WHILE Wall Street was cheering the fifth anniversary of the big bull market that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average from 776.92 on Aug. 12, 1982, to a record close of 2,691.49 Thursday, some experts were worrying that the economy was ready to throw the stock market a curve.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LIFE ERA: Cosmic Selection and Conscious Evolution. By Eric Chaisson. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) Eric Chaisson opens ''The Life Era'' with nearly 50 pages of the cosmic, hyperbolic kind of prose that Carl Sagan has made famous. This is followed by an equally long section that almost seems an attempt to recapitulate the history of Western thought. Finally, on page 109, the book begins. Here Mr. Chaisson, the author of the much-acclaimed ''Cosmic Dawn: The Origins of Matter and Life,'' gives us an exceptionally clear exposition of the subtle interplay between entropy and information and the ways in which structure arises from chaos. All this is in preparation for his history of cosmic evolution, in which the Energy Era gave birth to the Matter Era, which spawned the Life Era, a time when intelligence and consciousness become as active as the laws of physics in choreographing the great pageant of universal change. This isn't as mystical as it sounds. While Mr. Chaisson, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, shows an appreciation for such metaphysicians as Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, at the core of his being he is a materialist who rejects vitalism and teleological explanations of all kinds. While some readers will dismiss Mr. Chaisson's call for a holistic, global ethic as naive, others will be struck by how much he seems to care - not only about the fate of the earth but of the universe. Unfortunately, his self-conscious style interferes with his message. Even when discussing ancient and medieval philosophy, he manages to refer to himself on almost every page.

title: Comedy and Philosophy
description: TALK OF THE TOWN Starring Cary Grant, Jean Arthur, Ronald Colman. Directed by George Stevens. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 118 minutes. $69.95.

title: L.I.'S ROLE IN EARLY MODERN PROVIDES A SURPRISE
description: LEAD: ALARMED by the demolition of a landmark 1946 modernist house in East Hampton, Alastair Gordon, under the banner of Guild Hall, set out more than two years ago to inventory notable early modern buildings on Long Island before they, too, fell victim to progress and the bulldozer.

title: 'THE WORLD HAD A LABEL FOR ME'
description: LITTLE EDEN A Child at War. By Eva Figes. 140 pp. New York: Persea Books. $14.95.

title: Neglected Barber
description: To the Editor:

title: SURROUNDED BY RASCALS
description: BEYOND THE GOLDEN DOOR By William O'Dwyer. Edited by Paul O'Dwyer. 457 pp. Jamaica, N.Y.: St. John's University. $18.95.

title: Freedom Urged for Seoul Political Prisoners
description: As Korean-Americans marked South Korean Liberation Day yesterday with rallies for democracy, Amnesty International urged the South Korean Government to release all prisoners of conscience and provide new guarantees for human rights.

title: Toyotas and Tanks
description: Chadian forces last week resoundingly defeated the forces of Muammar el-Qaddafi, which have long occupied much of their country. Chadian means are as pleasing as their goal: clever tactics to defeat the Libyans' advanced Soviet weaponry.

title: Shaw's Long Goodbye
description: To the Editor:

title: CUTTING LARGE PANELS DOWN TO SIZE
description: CONSTRUCTION materials that come in panel form, such as plywood, particleboard and flakeboard, are popular among both professional homebuilders and do-it-yourselfers because panels are usually less expensive per square foot than lumber, are sometimes stronger and generally require less time and skill to apply effectively. But their large size can make handling and cutting them difficult.

title: Moscow Confirms Gas Leak During Nuclear Weapons Test
description: The Soviet Union revealed today that gas had leaked during an underground nuclear test earlier this month, but said there was no radioactive fallout.

title: Recent Sales
description: Chatham $375,000 11 Colonial Way 4-bedrooom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; family room, skylights, cathedral ceiling, patio, oak floors; taxes $5,444. Edison $163,400 82 Woodbury Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,900. Morristown $345,000 19 Wetmore Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 85-year-old Victorian; fireplace, stained-glass windows, porch; taxes $2,400. Mount Olive $172,000 10 East Forest Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old frame contemporary; family room, fireplace, basement, 2-car garage, oak floors; taxes $2,618. Oradell $295,000 762 Schaffer Street. 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old split level; central A/C, hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $3,146. West Milford $125,500 12 Eastside Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old raised ranch; 1-car garage, basement, fireplace, cathedral ceiling; taxes $1,254. OTHER AREAS Brookhaven $191,000 6 Hearth Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $2,100. Hartford, Conn. $129,900 25 Yale Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, exceptional plantings; taxes, $1,824. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $282,000 50-52 Carpenter Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old frame contemporary; deck, family room, den, walk to station; taxes $4,187.

title: Engraver Alters Die of a Postage Stamp
description: An unauthorized Star of David, invisible to the naked eye, was etched into the die of a $1 postage stamp issued last September to mark the 100th anniversary of Yeshiva University.

title: THE ENVIRONEMNT
description: LEAD: THE American Cyanamid Company has offered the state a partial solution to its hazardous-waste disposal problem: a 135-ton-a-day incinerator proposed for Cyanamid's facility in Bridgewater.

title: Post-Muppet Primitives
description: EARLIER THIS YEAR, THE PORTFOLIO of puppets for ''Inner Tube,'' Jim Henson's newly conceived television show, just wasn't taking shape. Henson, the creator, of course, of the Muppets, and the deity who populated ''Sesame Street,'' felt that ''designwise,'' he and his associates were getting a little stale. Then he visited the primitive wing at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, and realized, he says, ''that there were ways of stylizing the human face that we weren't using.'' Thus were spawned the Primitives, the covey of puppets now being constructed at the Henson Associates workshop in Manhattan.

title: DOUGLAS C. HEIDT WEDS MISS LEWIS IN OLD GREENWICH
description: The marriage of Kathryn Suzanne Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Lewis of Riverside, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., to Douglas Carl Heidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Heidt of West Simsbury, Conn., took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Lowell Stiers performed the ceremony.

title: Mets Sink Again
description: As it must to all men, defeat came today to Terry Leach, who had won 10 games for the Mets without losing this season and who hadn't lost in the big leagues in nearly two years.

title: Getting Intimacy and Passion Past the Censors
description: IT is a steamy evening. A woman in strapless dress reclines on a sofa, as a man enters the room and rushes to her side. The seduction that follows begins with an ice cube: He runs it over her face and neck - then moves it lower. This is an ''An Intimate Evening, '' Revlon's new television commercial for its fragrance, Intimate.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE WORKS OF THE WORKERS
description: LEAD: Chinese art: for most of us these words call forth images of the jades, bronzes and porcelain vases of imperial palaces, the delicate landscape paintings and exquisite calligraphy of aristocratic homes. In CHINESE FOLK ART: The Small Skills of Carving Insects (New York Graphic Society/Little, Brown, $50), Nancy Zeng Berliner examines the ancient, living artistic traditions of another China - of peasant, village China, where 80 percent of the country's population still lives.

title: KEVIN WALSH WED TO KEARSLEY RAND
description: Kearsley Rosalind Robin Rand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Arthur Rand of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Kevin Michael Walsh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Michael Walsh of Spring Lake, N.J. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Philip H. Kasey, assisted by the Rev. Patrick Brown, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SOUND
description: WHEN COMPACT disks emerged about four years back, extravagant attributes were ascribed to them. They were supposed to be perfect and to last forever.

title: LISA LOVE AND ROBERT F. CORROON JR., A REAL ESTATE DEVELOPER, ARE MARRIED
description: At the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., Elizabeth Ruth Love, a daughter of Mrs. George I. Reynolds and James Spencer Love Jr., both of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Robert Francis Corroon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Corroon, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Stephen Goldstein, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Thomas A. Guinan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: LONG DAYS FOR PILOT OF CRUISE
description: WHAT Wendy Elson describes as ''Lady Joan burnout'' is beginning to set in, as it usually does in mid-August.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: McCarthy: Death of a Witch Hunter A film by Emile de Antonio. Introduction by Paul Newman. MPI Home Video. 58 minutes. $29.95. Emile de Antonio, the strong and politically oriented documentary producer, tackles themes that are avoided by run-of-the-mill film makers. One of his boldest documentaries, originally shown in movie houses, was the 97-minute ''Point of Order!'' Its subject was Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army-McCarthy hearings. Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate in 1952, who was steadily attacked by the Senator during the campaign, called him ''the most formidable presence in America.''

title: Bomb in Basque City Kills 2
description: Two people were killed when a bomb exploded near their car in this northern Basque city today, the police said. They said the two victims were burned beyond recognition, and it was not immediately known whether they were police officers or civilians.

title: LEWIS, AT 26-5 1/2 , QUALIFIES FOR FINAL
description: With poor wind conditions despite a bright and cheery sky, Carl Lewis did just enough today to qualify for the long jump final Sunday in the Pan American Games.

title: RACES FORESHADOWED IN LEGISLATURE
description: THE Senate and Assembly have almost cleared their desks in preparation for the fall legislative elections. Each house plans one more session -the Assembly later this month and the Senate early in September - before the lawmakers go back to their districts to do battle.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NETTIE'S TRIP SOUTH By Ann Turner. Illustrated by Ronald Himler. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last week on thorium removal in Maywood misstated the amount of new contaminants the borough had been asked to accept at a temporary storage site. The correct figure is less than one-half of 1 percent of the 180,000 cubic yards now stored there.

title: Jackie Chan Plots a Conquest
description: LEAD: JACKIE CHAN EASILY DIS-patches enemies with a karate chop or a kung fu kick, but his real problems come from his fans. Young Chinese and Japanese women cluster in his office, pleading for his attention with a passion that makes American film stars look unwanted by comparison. Twice, neglected female admirers have tried to commit suicide in his foyer.

title: By Hans Fantel Toward Easier Tape Editing
description: FROM DISNEYLAND TO Notre Dame and from the Tivoli Gardens to the Taj Mahal, vacationers and tourists are swarming over the globe in unprecedented numbers, and this year their adventures will be documented as never before. Millions of camcorders are whirring away, arresting the fleeting moments of these summer journeys.

title: Care for Those Who Can't Care for Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Spartan Advice for Managers
description: CORPORATE resuscitation - the near-heroic art of bringing a company back from the dead - is no place for the faint-hearted. Salvaging a terminally ill organization often means making gut-wrenching decisions, performing radical surgery and living with slim odds of success. It's the ultimate ''bet your company, bet your job'' crap shoot for which consensual good guy-managers need not apply. Darth Vader is more the type. No one demonstrates this better than the toughest turnaround manager of them all, Lycurgus. It was during a Helot uprising (read: ''labor unrest'') that he was asked to rescue his organization, Sparta. He succeeded so well that Sparta not only recovered, but later whipped the Athenians in the Peloponnesian War. Lycurgus's steeliness more than 3,500 years ago can be a model for 20th-century managers. His strategy boils down to nine very modern steps: 1. Preparation

title: JANE BUCKLEY TO WED IN FALL
description: Dr. and Mrs. Michael B. Buckley of Watertown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hylda Jane Buckley to Christopher Newell Hurd, the son of Edward A. Hurd Jr. of Chicago and Nancy Whitney Lutz of Redding, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
THE NEED TO SAVE TREES FROM 'PROGRESS'
description: LEAD: WHEN Walt Whitman looked eastward across the fields from his Huntington, L.I., home, he could see a massive spreading oak. Since it was mentioned in his writings, it became known at the ''Walt Whitman oak.'' When Joe Ramsaur looked eastward from his Kearny, N.J., apartment window, he could see a majestic spreading red oak across a vacant lot.

title: Turks Kill 2 Kurdish Rebels
description: Turkish troops killed two Kurdish rebels today during a raid on terrorism suspects in a village near the Syrian border, officials reported. The rebels were suspected of involvement in the killing of 41 military personnel and civilians in recent weeks. One of the those killed today was identified as Ramazan Karatay, a local leader of the Kurdistan Workers' Party.

title: Cable TV
description: This is a rewarding week for musical movie buffs, with Gene Kelly in Paris, Tony Martin in Algiers, Betty Grable on Coney Island and Judy Holliday in the heart of the Big Apple.

title: An Aquino Rival Is Now a Senator
description: Juan Ponce Enrile, the former Philippine Defense Minister who helped Corazon C. Aquino oust Ferdinand E. Marcos from the presidency 18 months ago, then turned against her and was dismissed, resumed his attacks on the Aquino Administration last week from his new position as a senator. He seemed ready to use the post in his role as the chief political opponent of the president.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: POSTCARDS FROM THE EDGE. By Carrie Fisher. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) This first novel by the actress known to ''Star Wars'' fans as Princess Leia is an intermittently funny update of ''Valley of the Dolls.'' Suzanne, an attractive starlet, has a drug problem. She goes from a detox center to an affair with a womanizing producer, then makes a comeback in a grade Z movie and finally lives happily ever after with an implausibly nice screenwriter.

title: POSTINGS: It's Illuminating; G. E.'s Art Deco Tower
description: The General Electric Building, a Gothic-inspired Art Deco design that was declared a landmark two years ago by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, is coming to the end of one of New York's longest-running restoration jobs.

title: Rangers at Mt. Shasta Brace for a 'New Age'
description: At sunrise Sunday, believers in ''harmonic convergence'' plan to resonate and meditate, hold hands and hum here, preparing for a new age supposedly predicted in Mayan, Aztec and Hopi writings. National Forest Service rangers made plans of their own to keep order over the two-day ''planetary purification.''

title: OSHA
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia Effort Against Drugs Hits Dead End
description: When a reputed chief of one of the world's most powerful cocaine trafficking organizations was extradited to the United States in early February, there was a flurry of optimism that Colombia's powerful drug barons might at last be thrown onto the defensive.

title: Effects Beyond The Final Score
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
THE NEED TO SAVE TREES FROM 'PROGRESS'
description: LEAD: WHEN Walt Whitman looked eastward across the fields from his Huntington, L.I., home, he could see a massive spreading oak. Since it was mentioned in his writings, it became known at the ''Walt Whitman oak.'' When Joe Ramsaur looked eastward from his Kearny, N.J., apartment window, he could see a majestic spreading red oak across a vacant lot.

title: GRAND PRIX TENNIS COMES TO COUNTY
description: IT was in 1968 that big-time tennis went from amateur to ''open'' status, enabling amateur players to compete with professionals for prize money. In actuality, though, according to Gene Scott, tournaments on the international Grand Prix circuit are usually ''open'' only to the world's top 250 players.

title: JOHN KINGSLEY LOOMIS WEDS SHANE EMERSON
description: Elizabeth Shane Emerson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joe Silas Emerson of Bells, Tenn., was married there yesterday to John Kingsley Loomis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Kingsley Loomis of Windsor, Conn. The Rev. Joe Geary performed the ceremony at Cypress United Methodist Church.

title: Why Our Persian Gulf Policy Is So Murky
description: To the Editor:

title: POP VIEW
description: GROUPIE MEMOIRS AND interviews, of which there has been a recent onslaught, might seem only peripherally related to actual music. But at their best they shed light not just on the world of rock, but on music itself.

title:
ART;
'MAKING WAVES' IN PRINTS
description: LEAD: THE 22 printmakers currently ''Making Waves'' (in the show of that title) at the Graphic Eye Gallery in Port Washington aren't agitators in the political sense, nor, for the most part, are they New Wave artists stirring up esthetic waters. Their theme is, in fact, waves themselves - ocean waves and sound waves, interpreted in a variety of print media.

title: Carolyn Hartwell Becomes a Bride
description: At the Unitarian Church in Nantucket, Mass., Carolyn Kay Hartwell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Aston Harris Hartwell of Piedmont, Calif., was married yesterday to Donal Clare O'Brien 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Brien Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Nantucket. The ceremony was performed by the church's minister, the Rev. Edward B. Anderson, who was assisted by the Ven. Robert A. Bryan, an Archdeacon of the Anglican Church of Canada.

title: If Steinbrenner Wants Winner, He Doesn't Have to Look Far
description: IN CITING Yankee tradition, George Steinbrenner often points to the fact that the Yankees had the best overall record in the major leagues from 1976 through 1986. Actually, the owner is being modest. From the day in 1973 they played their first game with Steinbrenner as their principal owner to this very day, the Yankees have had the best record in baseball (a .564 won-lost percentage to Baltimore's .560).

title: Molitor's Hitting Streak Reaches 30
description: Paul Molitor of Milwaukee extended his hitting streak to 30 games with a single on the second pitch of the game tonight, but the Baltimore Orioles hung in to defeat the Brewers, 2-1.

title: Ballet: The Choreography Project
description: Liz Thompson, director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, described herself and the Choreography Project as adventuresome in a curtain speech before a performance by the group on Thursday night. But the program highlighting new choreography by dancers of the New York City Ballet also demanded a certain degree of adventurousness - as well as generosity - from its capacity audience.

title: Jets Win on a Late Kick, But Fail on Key Questions
description: Enough was enough.

title: Groups Plan Homes for AIDS Patients
description: LEAD: CHURCHES, social groups, the State Department of Human Resources and the widow of Representative Stewart B. McKinney, the Westport Congressman who died of AIDS, are involved in planning two or more model residences for AIDS victims.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FURTHER PARTICULARS. By C. H. Rolph. (Oxford University, $19.95.) ''By elimination,'' C. H. Rolph writes on the first page of this second volume of his memoirs, ''I had arrived at something between the essayist, the historian, the polemicist, and the crusader'' as the definition of his life's work. For a 17-year-old's vision (recalled 68 years later), it was remarkably prescient. After stabs at accountancy in an effort to find ''the 'bread-and-butter job' which would earn me the leisure time for writing,'' Mr. Rolph turned to his father's profession. In a quarter-century on the City of London police, he acquired the grounding in the ''huge national industry'' devoted to ''the preservation of what we nowadays call Laura Norder'' that along with his social compassion informed his writing. He wrote part time while on the force and full time after that - scripts for the BBC, pieces for The New Statesman (he was a member of the staff) and reports for the countless commissions on which he sat, on penology, on mental health, on the aging. Charming when not resigned at how little injustices change, and at times highly personal, ''Further Particulars'' is a cross between autobiography and social history that lets the reader share everything from the slow fading of the 19th century in the City to Dame Rebecca West's style of character assassination - all transmitted with the polish and tony modesty that educated Britons of not inconsiderable achievement use to such advantage.

title: A Time of Trauma for Hospital Agency
description: THE Health and Hospitals Corporation, the nation's largest city hospital system and the family doctor to millions of New Yorkers, is suffering a rash of life-and-death crises and embarrassing controversies.

title: NAUGHTY KEARNY AVENUE
description: LEAD: AFTER THE GARDEN By Doris Jean Austin. 324 pp. New York: New American Library. $17.95.

title: Brazil Stopped By U.S.
description: For the last five days, Teresa Edwards had read newspaper stories about Hortencia Marcari, whose skills as a basketball player have made her a national hero in Brazil and the talk of the Pan American Games.

title: Unwritten Rules of Engagement in the Gulf
description: ON May 17, an Iraqi fighter pilot drew an electronic bead on a ship sailing in the Persian Gulf. Seconds later, two Exocet missles slammed into the hull of the frigate Stark, sending a fire raging through the cramped crew quarters, killing 37 American sailors. It is not known whether the Iraqi pilot received the Mercedes that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein customarily bestows on victorious pilots or the rather less pleasant rewards of those who displease the strongman. The pilot was not seen by the American inquiry team sent to Baghdad and has not been publicly mentioned.

title: Skinner Shoots 70 to Maintain 2-Shot Lead in L.P.G.A. Event
description: Val Skinner maintained a 2-shot lead today after the second round of the MasterCard International golf tournament as only seven players were under par.

title: RKO Faces Loss Of 14 Licenses
description: RKO General Inc., which has been in trouble with the Federal Communications Commission for 22 years, last week was denied renewal of the licenses for its 14 radio and television stations, worth about $1 billion in all.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SOUTH BEND, IND.;
Enlivening The Riverfront
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER here is finding new uses for a historic industrial property on the riverfront. In October, Thomas Brooks Brademas opened a restaurant and hotel, and by this fall work will be complete on a new marina that he hopes will attract sport fishermen.

title: A CAREER OF GIVING NEW PLAYS A CHANCE
description: ''I SAY it every year,'' Lucille Lortel said. She was talking about giving up her time-honored tradition of presenting new works - a brand-new one for three performances every summer weekend - at the White Barn Theater adjacent to her Westport home; a policy that she let lapse just once in 40 years.

title: Sightseers' Sanctuaries; For the footloose and footsore, where to stop for tea or a bite to eat
description: The last thing a weary visitor wants during a day of sightseeing is a long trek for a decent lunch or afternoon tea. But if you go to the nearest establishment, especially in London, you run the risk that the inflated bill and bad cooking will add a sour taste to your already tender condition.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: CHILD OF THE NORTHERN SPRING. By Persia Woolley. (Poseidon, $17.95.) The Arthurian cycle is arguably a primary myth of Western culture, and lately the preserve of women from Mary Stewart to Marion Zimmer Bradley and Gillian Bradshaw. This is not surprising, since the romances of Arthur originated in the desire of the great courtly women of the 12th century for a new type of love story.

title: U.S., a Month After Tripoli Raid, Reportedly Planned to Meet With Libyan
description: One month after the United States bombed Libya in 1986, a handful of American officials approved plans for a secret meeting with a shadowy Libyan official who wanted better relations with Washington, according to documents and a participant in the dealings.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN TRADING STAMPS
description: A GENERATION ago, saving trading stamps from supermarkets and service stations was an all-American pastime. By filling up enough books of stamps, frugal families to acquire useful household appliances and long-coveted gifts just for shopping at their favorite stores. Three-quarters of all grocery stores and supermarkets in the nation offered stamps to attract loyal shoppers, and 10 major stamp companies competed for the business. Sperry & Hutchinson, the country's oldest and largest stamp company, serviced 100,000 retailers at its peak in 1969.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
EXERCISE
description: LEAD: The American Academy of Family Physicians Bodyband Workout Created by Tamilee Webb, produced by Feeling Fine Programs/Dr. Art Ulene. Warner Home Video. 53 minutes. $39.95. Those who are something less than coordinated and in something less than good shape may be a bit daunted by the peppy warmup to Bodyband Workout, a shape-up method utilizing elastic bands to create resistance.

title: A Window on the Blackboard World of the 1890's
description: THE end of a seven-year preservation battle in the Beekman Place area of Manhattan may be at hand. Public School 35, out of service for 20 years, is scheduled for auction next Wednesday. Although not a designated landmark, the 94-year-old school will be sold by the city with preservation restrictions, putting to rest community fears that a new building might rise on the site.

title: Novels That Don't Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum, With Just a Relic to Go On, Tries to Rebuild Lost Piece of History
description: Almost 230 years ago, British forces retreating on Lake George after a catastrophic defeat in the last French and Indian War scuttled their fleet of large troop-carrying rowboats before marching south.

title: POLICE RECRUIT MORE MINORITIES
description: LEAD: THE Nassau and Suffolk County Police Departments, under tough Federal orders to hire more women and members of minority groups, are turning to radio, television and publications to advertise jobs and are sending recruiters to schools, churches and even Long Island's beaches.

title: INSIDE
description: Stamp With a Secret Star Officials said an engraver for the Bureau of Printing and Engraving secretly altered a postage stamp's die to include a Star of David. Page 26.

title: LOVE WITH THE RIGHT FARM HAND
description: GETTING MARRIED IN BUFFALO JUMP By Susan Haley. 276 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: BETH COBERT TO MARRY ADAM J. CIOTH IN FALL
description: The engagement of Beth Frances Cobert to Adam Julian Cioth has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Cobert of Montclair, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boguslaw Cioth of Rolling Hills Estates, Calif. A November wedding is planned.

title: Genetic Scientist Defies U.S. Rules
description: To avoid the delays that have accompanied other experiments in genetic engineering, a scientist at Montana State University announced last week that he had committed civil disobedience. In June, as he was about to inject trees with bacteria altered to fight Dutch elm disease, Dr. Gary Strobel learned that he needed Government permission. Concerned that the slow wheels of bureaucracy, and of plant cycles, would postpone his work until next year, he applied to the Environmental Protection Agency but refused to wait for approval.

title: The Woes of a Robot Peddler
description: IT was early March. Jim Repko, the lanky young East Coast manager of sales for Adept Technology Inc., had just finished lunch with three engineers from Grumman Aircraft Systems who he hoped would buy several Adept robots.

title: A HALF-CENTURY VIEW FROM A FARM IN BETHEL
description: IN 1934 I bought 50 acres and a little old house in Bethel for $7,500. America was deep in a crisis, politely called a depression, and I had to borrow all of the $7,500.

title: Guidelines On Conduct Of Judges Approved
description: LEAD: THE State Supreme Court has adopted guidelines restricting the nonjudicial activities of full-time judges, including belonging to organizations that discriminate, participating in fund-raising efforts, teaching and publishing for a fee and competing with other judges for honors or awards.

title: Correction
description: Several words were inadvertently omitted from Phyllis Braff's Aug. 9 review of the Andy Warhol exhibition at the Dan Flavin Art Institute in Bridgehampton. The sentence should have read: ''At a time when artists were defining reality as the materials of the art surface, or as shapes without any trace of illusionistic reference, or as the intuitive idea itself, Warhol defined reality as images already in the public consciousness.''

title: No-Smoking Rules Working in Rochester Region
description: The imposition of one of the toughest antismoking laws in the nation here has met with wide acceptance, but there have been some curious exemptions.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LEAGUE OF NIGHT AND FOG. By David Morrell. (Dutton, $17.95.) In 1941 Hitler ordered his henchmen to grab people ''endangering German security'' and drag them off without a trace into the ''night and fog.'' David Morrell's latest thriller, whose title comes from the infamous ''night and fog decree,'' is about how a group of Israelis scarred by the Holocaust turns the tables on a menagerie of former Nazis. It's not a bad idea for a novel. Probably everyone who suffered at the hands of the Nazis has imagined giving his tormentors a dose of their own medicine. But Mr. Morrell doesn't let well enough alone. Instead, he gives us a class reunion of cutthroats from his previous thrillers, bringing back Saul (a k a Romulus), the C.I.A. gunslinger from ''The Brotherhood of the Rose,'' and Drew, the church hit man from ''The Fraternity of the Stone.'' One wonders why he didn't also call in Rambo, the one-man army from his aptly named debut novel, ''First Blood.'' Unfortunately, Mr. Morrell's facility with words doesn't help him in creating credible characters. He has a Swiss peasant woman who spouts some stilted mumbo jumbo about how to identify a priest in mufti. And he has a couple of cardboard killers who try to save their fathers from the avenging Israelis (actually, a cabal of spry old coots who used to be Mossad agents). The Nazis, for their part, have a sort of gray power Elks Lodge and, like good old boys, toast one another on such occasions as the Fuhrer's birthday. But don't despair. If you haven't had your fill of Drew and Saul, you're in luck. Mr. Morrell hints that the pair will be back for an encore.

AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) DON'T TREAD ON ME: The Selected Letters of S. J. Perelman, edited by Prudence Crowther. (Viking, $19.95.) The letters -interesting, charming, sometimes beautifully written - show the great humorist as precisely the furious, self-centered, half-paranoid grouch all his readers knew and loved all the time. ILLUMINATION NIGHT, by Alice Hoffman. (Putnam, $18.95.) Panic attacks, irrational presences and childhood mysteries abound in this intelligent novel about six characters whose lives intersect for a while on the island of Martha's Vineyard. WHO WROTE THE BIBLE? by Richard Elliott Friedman. (Summit, $18.95.) This fresh approach to the four-source ''documentary theory'' of the authorship of the Torah argues that Jeremiah wrote Deuteronomy and that Ezra edited all five books. PAST PERFECT, by Yaakov Shabtai. (Viking, $18.95.) A painful, urgent novel about a man who expects to die soon, reflecting the circumstances of its author, who died in 1981 at the age of 47. THE SONGLINES, by Bruce Chatwin. (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking, $18.95.) A brilliant, assertive not-exactly-novel, set in Australia/ Arcadia and containing adventurous meditations, anecdotes, visions and speculations on basic issues like nomadism and the nature of man (originally good, nowadays not so great). THE BOYS OF WINTER, by Wilfrid Sheed. (Knopf, $16.95.) Literary careerism, sex and softball in the Hamptons are the raw material of this novel - his ninth - by a shrewd and playful former alien no Yank can long deceive. BECOMING A DOCTOR, by Melvin Konner. (Elisabeth Sifton/ Viking, $19.95.) Mr. (now Dr.) Konner, an anthropologist, went through medical school and produced this engaging account of the long, painful initiation by which people become physicians.

title: THE GOLD WATCH
description: I was moved by George Jellinek's article ''The Gold Watch'' (About Men, June 28). My mother is a survivor of the Holocaust who lost a sister, two brothers and her parents. My father was lucky enough to visit the 1939 World's Fair in New York, but he left behind his mother and five brothers and sisters, who were murdered by the Nazis. Mr. Jellinek's description of the goodbyes to his mother, sister and father conjured images I have of my parents' last moments with my grandparents.

title: 'Sting' Catches Bribery Suspects In 40 N.Y. Towns
description: A ''sting'' operation in 40 New York municipalities last week spread a cloud of suspicion over the way public business is done in much of the state.

title: GETTING A START IN THE WORLD OF WORK
description: BERNITA CROFT runs the Vernon Heights Day Care Center in Mount Vernon, and last week she recalled with pleasure the day that Veronica, one of six youngsters working with her as part of a summer youth employment program, received her first paycheck.

title: Testaverde Passes Test
description: Vinny Testaverde passed for three touchdowns in the final 6 minutes 18 seconds tonight in a spectacular debut for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. His heroics weren't enough, however, as the Cincinnati Bengals scored a 31-30 victory.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SHOW TO HELP RESTORE Historic Mill Complex
description: LEAD: A HISTORIC and scenic place on the Delaware River will be the site this week of the seventh annual Prallsville Mills Antiques Show, which previews Friday evening and runs Saturday through next Sunday.

title: Complied With U.S. Law
description: To the Editor:

title: TV AND PUBLIC VALUES
description: To the Editor:

title: Confessions of a Soon-to-Be Ex-Nondriver
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Beaches in Jersey Reopen; Source of Medical Waste Is Sought
description: A 30-mile slick of household garbage, discarded medical and hospital trash and timbers floated for a third day just off some of New Jersey's most popular ocean beaches today, discouraging tens of thousands from entering the surf.

title: PRODUCTIVE FALL VEGETABLES NEED AN EARLY START
description: LEAD: THIS is the time of year to think about cool-season vegetables. It is the time for Brussels sprouts, cauliflower, broccoli and Chinese cabbage plus beets and other root crops as well as chard, radicchio and many kinds of lettuce.

title: LIFE WITHOUT SHOREHAM? YES
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company and its allies have repeatedly challenged nuclear critics to provide alternatives to the Shoreham nuclear plant [ see ''Shoreham's Critics Ignore Realities,'' Opinion Page, July 19 ] . The reality is that not only have alternative supply plans been offered by citizen groups, the State Energy Office and even the Public Service Commission, but parts of these plans are already being implemented, to the benefit of Long Island ratepayers.

title: AN INTERNATIONAL ESSENCE PERVADES DURHAM
description: THIS SUMMER, THE AMERICAN Dance Festival is celebrating its 10th year in Durham, N.C. The festival has certainly been a success there. Yet, when plans were first announced to move it from Connecticut College in New London, its home since 1948, eyebrows were raised, for Durham had no reputation as a dance center. However, thanks to the festival's shrewd planning, the city has become one. Dance is even front-page news in the area: both The Durham Morning Herald and The Durham Sun regularly print the festival's daily schedule in boxes on page 1.

title: MOVIES
description: Pete Kelly's Blues Starring Jack Webb, Janet Leigh, Edmond O'Brien, Peggy Lee, Andy Devine, Lee Marvin, Ella Fitzgerald. Written by Richard L. Breen. Directed by Jack Webb. 1955. Warner Bros. 95 minutes. $59.95. The jazz scene, on film, is rarely a happy one. In ''Pete Kelly's Blues,'' a 1955 look back to Kansas City and its speakeasy gin mills in 1927, the scene is less happy than most, for both the characters involved and the audience.

title:
GARDENING;
THE NEED TO SAVE TREES FROM 'PROGRESS'
description: LEAD: WHEN Walt Whitman looked eastward across the fields from his Huntington, L.I., home, he could see a massive spreading oak. Since it was mentioned in his writings, it became known at the ''Walt Whitman oak.'' When Joe Ramsaur looked eastward from his Kearny, N.J., apartment window, he could see a majestic spreading red oak across a vacant lot.

title: YALE- A GREAT NURSERY OF SPOOKS
description: CLOAK & GOWN Scholars in the Secret War, 1939-1961. By Robin W. Winks. Illustrated. 607 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: The New Decolletage
description: THE old-fashioned decolletage reappeared as an important evening fashion in the Paris fall and winter couture collections. Highlights of those clothes were seen in New York Wednesday night in a show sponsored by the Fashion Group Inc. at the Waldorf-Astoria. Sweetheart necklines and rounded scoops were emphasized by bows, ruffles and velvet bands.

title: Cuomo to Require More Exact Reports From Regents Board
description: The State Board of Regents, periodically under fire for persistent problems in New York's education system, will have to begin making annual reports on the state of schooling in New York under legislation approved this week by Governor Cuomo.

title: E.P.A. Action Urged on Agricultural Runoff
description: The General Accounting Office has recommended that the Environmental Protection Agency be empowered to protect the nation's wildlife refuges from pesticide-contaminated runoff from irrigated farmland.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Altering Bats and Balls a Part Of Baseball?
description: Unfortunately yes, along with such developments as artificial turf, fences being moved in, players being unable or unwilling to bunt, players who don't start demanding to be traded, the media extolling the value of .256 hitters, and acceptance of the idea that players who amass impressive totals over a number of years without ever having a really good year are worthy of consideration for the Hall of Fame. EDSON F. SCUDDER New York, N.Y.

title: MORE AMERICANS FIND ROOM AT THE OPERA PODIUM
description: COLLECTIVELY, THEY MAY NOT possess the skills and experience of their European colleagues, and they remain a fraction of the native-born conductors working in the United States. Yet despite considerable odds against them, American opera conductors are, for the first time, staking a significant claim on the podiums of major houses here and abroad.

title: Clinton Traces His Decision Not to Run for President to Family Obligations
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, say his decision not to run for President was simply a more public version of the decisions that millions of couples in their generation have had to make in recent years.

title: Gunmen in the Punjab Kill 6; Independence Day Toll at 13
description: Two gunmen raided two villages in Punjab state today and opened fire at random, killing six people and wounding at least three, the Press Trust of India said.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: BOSTON;
Revitalizing The Rundown
description: LEAD: HAVING finished a $4 million renovation creating 101 apartments for low-income tenants in this city's Roxbury section, the Quincy-Geneva Housing Corporation wants to rehabilitate 94 more units this fall and build 140 new apartments in the next few years.

title: CELEBRATING THE LYRICS OF JOY AND LAMENTATION
description: They came from Seattle and St. Louis and Nashville and New Orleans and anyplace else where a few chords, a good organ and a stout spirit beget gospel music, the sad, triumphant poetry of black Americans.

title: Lacemaking: Alive and Gaining Strength
description: LEAD: FOUR stamps commemorating lacemaking were issued last week by the Postal Service, lending new credence to a recent prediction by a British lace vendor that ''lacemaking in the United States is on the verge of an explosion.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Evert Tops Navratilova: Chris Evert overpowered Martina Navratilova, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims of Los Angeles tournament in Manhattan Beach, Calif. It was the 74th time Evert had played against Navratilova, who leads the series, 39-35. In another semifinal, second-seeded Steffi Graf worked hard to claim a victory against seventh-seeded Gabriela Sabatini, 7-5, 7-5.(AP) Golf Missed Putt Helps Zoeller: Fuzzy Zoeller watched as Denis Watson missed a 15-foot putt yesterday, giving Zoeller the last final-round berth at the International golf tournament in Castle Rock, Colo. Watson was one of seven golfers playing for the final six positions in the 18-man field that will compete for a $180,000 first prize today. Zoeller had a bogey 5 on the playoff hole. Zoeller and Watson finished their round tied with Scott Simpson, John Cook, Steve Pate, Mike Hulbert and Nick Price, all with 4 points. The other five had par or better on the playoff hole. Chip Beck led the field of 18 finalists with 13 points under the tournament's scoring system: 5 for an eagle, 2 for a birdie, 0 for par, minus-1 for bogey and minus-3 for double-bogey or higher.(AP) Boxing Holyfield Retains Titles: Evander Holyfield retained his World Boxing Association junior heavyweight and International Boxing Federation cruiserweight titles last night by stopping Ossie Ocasio in the 11th round in St. Tropez, France. Holyfield (16-0) scored at will with jabs in the early rounds, dominating Ocasio (32-5), who looked sluggish and bewildered. Holyfield was scoring at will with solid combinations when Referee John Coyle of Britain stopped the fight.(AP) Successful Defense for Espinoza: Louie Espinoza knocked out Mike Ayala in the ninth round last night in San Antonio to retain his World Boxing Association junior featherweight title. Espinoza, making his second defense of his title, improved his record to 43-1. Ayala, failing in his third title shot in eight years, dropped to 44-6.(AP) Swimming American Wins Second Medley: Dave Wharton completed a double over Alex Baumann, a Canadian world-record holder, last night in the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships in Brisbane, Australia. Wharton, an 18-year-old from Warminster, Pa., scored an upset victory over Baumann in the 200-meter individual medley final, edging his rival by one-hundredth of a second. Wharton was timed in 2 minutes 2.49 seconds to collect his second individual gold of the meet. He swam a world record 4:16.17 in beating Baumann in the 400-meter individual medley final Friday night. The United States took seven of the eight gold medals at stake last night to run its meet total to 19 gold in 24 races. Janet Evans of Placentia, Calif., and Nicole Livingstone of Australia both won their second individual gold medals. Evans took the 400-meter freestyle final in a time of 4:09.32. Livingstone captured the 200-meter backstroke final in 2:11.84, the fastest time in the world this year and the seventh-fastest ever.(AP) Cycling Happy Homecoming for Hampsten: Andy Hampsten came home to Colorado to lead a top-three sweep for his 7-Eleven team yesterday and capture his first-ever stage victory in the Coors International Bicycle Classic. Hampsten, of Boulder, Colo., broke away with his teammates Jeff Pierce and Raul Alcala at the start of the second lap over the Colorado National Monument west of Grand Junction and cruised to a victory margin of 5 minutes 10 seconds in the 83-mile stage. Pierce, the race leader, finished second. Meanwhile, Jeannie Longo, the French champion riding for DuPont's Team Lycra, opened an imposing lead of 3:02 in the first day of women's competition, a 47-mile road race.(AP)

title: SATING MUSICAL APPETITES
description: RANSOM WILSON orchestrates the Chestnut Hill Concerts in Madison the way a chef creates a fine dish. ''I think of a program like a meal,'' said the music director. ''I don't enjoy turkey, ham and beef all at the same time. I like to have little things that enhance one big thing.''

title: THE NATION: Airspace Intruder; Reagan Copter In Close Call
description: A DAY after the Government cracked down on private planes in the skies over Southern California, a small Piper Archer came dangerously close to the helicopter carrying President Reagan and his aides to his ranch near Santa Barbara. The plane strayed into the restricted airspace over the ranch Thursday afternoon, forcing the helicopter's pilot to veer to avoid the craft; they passed within 200 to 300 feet of each other. The plane's pilot was identified as Ralph W. Myers of Lake Oswego, Ore. After he landed at an Orange County airport, he was detained and released, and the Federal Aviation Administration revoked his license. When it was learned that he was an AWOL Army private, he was taken back into custody.

title: Macao Called New Center of North Korean Spying
description: Behind a two-way mirror on the door of a freshly painted house here, intelligence experts say, is North Korea's new overseas center for espionage.

title: Rekindling a Vested Interest
description: PEELING OFF HIS BLACK frock coat to reveal a gray vest, he was the picture of sobriety. Later, toying with the crimson buttons of another waistcoat, he looked playfully eccentric. As Prof. Henry Higgins in the recent New York production of ''Pygmalion,'' Peter O'Toole made a convincing case for the vest as an expressive prop, not to mention a serious component in one's wardrobe.

title: WENDY FROMER IS WED TO HOWARD WEINSTEIN
description: Wendy S. Fromer and Howard M. Weinstein, who will join Manhattan law firms as associates next month, were married last evening in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Ruben Levine officiated at the Chanticler.

title: A PLEA TO PARENTS WHO LET CHILDREN PLAY IN THE STREET
description: JUST before dusk a week ago, I drove my car up the winding common driveway of the condominium complex in which I live at the posted 10 miles an hour. As I rounded the curve just before the second ''speed bump,'' two little boys on bicycles shot across the two-lane drive 10 feet in front of my car. Fortunately for all three of us, I was able to jam on my brakes fast enough to avoid hitting them. With my heart pounding, I pulled the car over and called out to the two boys.

title: Rock-a-Bye Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Mount Kisco, N.Y. $282,000 50-52 Carpenter Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old frame contemporary; deck, family room, den, walk to station; taxes $4,187. Rye, N.Y. $547,500 12 Hook Road 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 31-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, patio, walk to school and stores: taxes $6,288. Canton, Conn. $79,900 130 Main Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, condominium apt. in restored turn-of-century hotel; river view; monthly charges $62, taxes $850.
