title: Yankees Erupt
description: The Yankees rediscovered the way to win last night, but a development in the stands was as intriguing as the game on the field because Yankee Stadium fans entered the feud between George Steinbrenner and Lou Piniella, and lined up squarely behind Piniella.

title: SPORTS
description: The Super Fight: Hagler vs. Leonard Executive producers, Brian Bedol, Les Garland. Producer, David Dinkins Jr. QMI Video. 75 minutes. $19.95. Half of this cassette is devoted to 12 rounds of ring action and the between-rounds respites of this April 6, 1987, middleweight championship boxing match. The other half is the Las Vegas venue, luminaries and limos, the weigh-in, the locker rooms, Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Ray Leonard's prognostications, and snippets of each of them devastating previous opponents.

title: A First in Spain: Study on How Women Fare
description: Spaniards do not spend much time sitting around drawing rooms debating whether Spain's is a macho society. That is a given.

title: Travel Agents Report a Strong Summer
description: AT first glance, travel agents might appear to be working in a difficult climate this summer. New and merged airlines, battling in deregulated skies, have produced a baffling array of discount fares and rearrange them constantly. The lower fares mean smaller commissions.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: EVIL ANGELS. By Pascal Bruckner. Translated by William R. Beer. (Grove, $16.95.) ''I was going to Asia in search of a holy turmoil,'' declares the narrator of Pascal Bruckner's novel, published to some acclaim in France in 1981. He gets a double dose without ever leaving the Mediterranean. Scarcely has his ship left Marseilles when Didier, an earnest young Parisian, falls under the spell of a morally twisted doctor, Franz, who, Ancient Mariner-style, grips him by the arm and over the course of five nights relates a bizarre tale of sexual obsession. Initially repelled, Didier listens with growing fascination as Franz tells how he emotionally enslaved his beautiful, exotic wife, Rebecca, tormented her mercilessly and eventually became her pathetic plaything. As it happens, Rebecca has already succeeded in mesmerizing Didier, with Franz's approval. Together these evil angels set about corrupting Didier and alienating him from his longtime girlfriend. All this should make for wicked entertainment, but it doesn't. The prolix doctor's analyses of the human passions grow appallingly tedious. The miserable Didier has to endure such weighty observations as: ''Feelings are something that can be lost, like your watch; they can be slowly drained, like a bank account, but they can also be found again, like a hat you have misplaced.'' In addition, a wretched translation turns Franz's monologues into a weird mishmash of slang and pompous pronouncement. The main problem, though, is that Mr. Bruckner aims for evil but never gets beyond kinky. For the real thing, readers might turn to ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses.''

title: Advance Warnings
description: The Federal Government and, increasingly, the states have spent billions trying to move water from where it is to where it is wanted. But many factors - faster-than-expected growth, changing patterns of water use or a summer without rain - can still confound those plans. What follows are reports on how different regions are coping with the problems of providing enough water to their industries, households and farms.

title: LESLIE D. YUNKO WED TO THEODORE J. FINN
description: At the Nassau Inn in Princeton, N.J., Leslie Denise Yunko, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Yunko of Princeton, was married yesterday to Theodore J. Finn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Finn of Newtown, Mass. Barbara Boggs Sigmun, the Mayor of Princeton Borough, officiated.

title: Move to Oust Governor In Arizona Is Gaining
description: The group leading the effort to oust Gov. Evan Mecham from office has reported that it has nearly half the signatures needed to force an election on the Governor's ouster. At the same time, Mr. Mecham has accused the Democratic Party of being behind the effort.

title: U.S. Signs Pact Protecting 1,000 Miles of Rivers
description: After a year of negotiations prompted by complaints from an environmental group, the United States Forest Service has agreed to protect 1,000 miles of rivers in the East and Midwest.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BEST INTENTIONS. By Kate Lehrer. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) The 17-year-old daughter of an influential Washington political commentator is murdered, and subsequently a mother-daughter relationship based on guilt trips comes to light. The journalist, Sarah Corbin Adams, has made it big by charming intimate truths out of powerful interview subjects; in her own life, she is an insecure, dictatorial phony whose obsessive love is like a bear trap. Demanding perfection of her only child, Sarah is the sort of woman who buys her daughter's clothes, lays out her outfits at bedtime and meddles with unacceptable friends. In her first novel, Mrs. Lehrer (who lives in Washington) presents a milieu of genteel materialism populated by stressed-out functionaries and bitchy party guests. We find it difficult, however, to sustain interest in her self-centered characters, all thinly drawn. It doesn't help that the narrator, Sarah's researcher, is unperceptive and demonstrates little gift for description: ''She was 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood' come alive for grown-ups,'' she gushes about her employer's social ease at a soiree. At 28, the researcher is unable to detach herself from the domineering mother-mentor figure who attempts to impose order on everyone within reach. A subplot about a former national security adviser involved in shady dealings with a tiny African nation only intrudes on the frequently compelling domestic drama and its violent conclusion. Distasteful as they are, the shouting matches between the publicly serene Sarah and her tormented daughter come through as raw and real.

title: CRICKET, COUSIN OF BASEBALL, CATCHES ON
description: THE crowds at Mount Vernon's Memorial Stadium next Saturday and Sunday are expected to exceed 10,000, bigger than the turnout for some Major League baseball games. But in this case, the fans will be watching not Dwight Gooden or Don Mattingly but Andy Roberts and Clive Lloyd.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My experience in simulation is that there are always surprises.'' - Col. Richard R. Paul, former director of the facility testing ''Star Wars.'' [ 1:6. ]

title: At the Second-Oldest Ball Park, the Final Innings
description: The Birmingham Barons had already taken the field for the Southern League game against the Greenville (S.C.) Braves when the light towers high above old Rickwood Field suddenly went dark.

title: Taking Chances
description: 'When we punish the normal risks, then we're also punishing competitiveness and we're also punishing progress. We do not live in a risk-free world and never will. If we're not willing to accept some of the risk that other countries are, then even if the Constitution lives to 300 years I'm not sure there'll be much to celebrate. . . . It's time to change some of the rules, even if we have to compromise some of our rights to do it because America today cannot afford all this unbridled advocacy.'

title: Developing A Riverfront
description: FOR years, residents of this southcentral Maine town failed to see the development potential of the Androscoggin River, which in the 1970's was found by a Federal study to be one of the 10 dirtiest rivers in the nation.

title: Ads by LoGrande Draw Criticism
description: A RECENT mailing and radio ads by Acting Suffolk County Executive Michael A. LoGrande on the drug problem have come under fire from his Democratic opponent.

title: CRIME
description: John le Carre has a lot to answer for. Thanks to him the British espionage novel has developed a kind of writing as murky as the bottom of the Atlantic shelf. Characters talk elliptically and allusively. Nobody seems to know exactly what is going on, including the masters who dangle their marionettes. It is hard to differentiate between the good and the bad guys. Plots become so complicated, the action often so tenuous, that the exasperated reader is tempted to hurl the book through the window. And yet we captive wretches persevere. Where will all this take us? When will the fog lift? It is worth the effort to work your way through FOR THE GOOD OF THE STATE by Anthony Price (Mysterious Press, $16.95). Mr. Price is one of the better practitioners of the post-le Carre genre. He gives us two elderly secret agents. One is a Russian archeologist who also is high up in the K.G.B. The other is his opposite number in England - a former professor, a medievalist, an espionage agent who was in the field and now is an invaluable analyst of Russian affairs for an arcane agency. They have previously had an encounter in which the Briton came out best. Now the Russian is visiting England and wants to meet his old antagonist. He has some information he wants to impart.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: MY DEFENSE - C'EST MOI Generalizing about Americans and Europeans is a grand sociological parlor game. This is from ''Painted in Blood: Understanding Europeans'' (Atheneum) by Stuart Miller.

title: From Fresh Air Visits, Strong Bonds
description: Doreen Yoder Ross had no intention of throwing the bouquet to Robin Griffith, one of her bridesmaids, at the reception after her wedding to Scott Ross.

title: LISA MAZURE WED TO ERIC GOODISON
description: Lisa Carla Mazure, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Mazure of Oceanside, L.I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married last evening to Eric Stuart Goodison, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jules Goodison of Elkins Park, Pa. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Indigo: Three Spots For Clothes Savings Three stores in the county share a corporate identity and the name Indigo - two are in Chappaqua: Indigo Deluxe at 57 King Street, with contemporary women's clothing, and Indigo West nearby at 29 King, with contemporary adult play clothes. The third site, in Hastings-on-Hudson, is called Indigo-on-Hudson and has some items from the designers and manufacturers of both country and casual styles represented in

title: HOIST WITH OUR OWN HEGEMONY
description: THE POLITICAL ECONOMY OF INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS By Robert Gilpin. With the assistance of Jean M. Gilpin. 449 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $9.95.

title: DENT'S READY, BUT NOT EAGER
description: THEY were teammates for six seasons, including three they finished in the World Series, and they remain friends. Furthermore, Bucky Dent has never been a person to promote himself or undercut someone else. That's why he spoke reluctantly and tentatively when an inevitable question was posed about the turbulence that may sink Lou Piniella as the Yankees' manager.

title: A WEEK OF FINALES FOR CLASSICAL FARE
description: IF classical music is your beat, take advantage of the last busy week in Westchester for a while; thereafter, the concert scene goes into virtual hibernation, and it will be late September or early October before anything like our normal performance pace is resumed.

title: 24 ARTISTS AND FRIENDS IN KENT SHOW
description: JACQUES KAPLAN had good reason for naming his gallery Paris-New York-Kent. The first city was his birthplace and the second was where he made his name after serving in the Free French forces during World War II. Kent, meanwhile, is the scene of his operations as an art dealer - has been since 1984.

title: D. V. ROWLAND IS WED TO LISA DEBENEDICTIS
description: The marriage of Lisa Rene DeBenedictis, a television and film production coordinator, to Daryl Verne Rowland, a television and movie screenwriter, took place last evening in the White and Gold Suite at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: Hanging In There
description: IT SEEMS ODD TO THINK THAT BUILDINGS in the International Style have reached a mature enough age to require serious restoration. Yet many of these examples of pure modernism from around the 1930's are now aging relics, often in need of repair.

title: Howard Baker's Folly
description: After a couple of years trying to run foreign policy without the Congress, the Reagan Administration then swung to the other extreme: it sought to wheedle continued aid to the contras by abdicating foreign policy leadership to the Speaker of the House.

title: A Govenor's Work: Between Crises, Blueberries
description: When governors assume office they swear to uphold the state constitution and laws, to dispense equal justice to all and to faithfully carry out their duties.

title: Re-admitted
description: If, as Ariel Dorfman put it, exile is a ''a convenient substitute for death,'' then Mr. Dorfman has been restored to life. Mr. Dorfman, a Chilean novelist who is among the hundreds of opponents of the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet who have been banned from their country, said last week that the Government has lifted the order to exclude him. In fact, the Pinochet regime extended its forgiveness to a total of 22 people among the 500 or so who are believed to have been officially exiled. Mr. Dorfman, who lives most of the time in Durham, N.C., where he teaches at Duke University, is one of the best-known of the Pinochet Government's exiled critics. The 45-year-old writer said he learned earlier this month that he had been secretly put on the exclusion list last October. He said the regime's decision to allow him back in the country only returned to him something that was his.

title: Sex, Risk and the Actuarial Equation
description: CONTENDING that rates based on a person's sex are discriminatory, feminist and civil rights groups have been pushing for ''unisex'' insurance. But insurance companies have vigorously opposed this effort, arguing that gender is a valid and necessary factor in determining risk.

title: Trader Joe's
description: To the Editor: Joan Cook's article on Trader Joe's (Travel, July 5), although extremely informative and helpful, mouthwatering and mostly true, does have two misstatements.

title: U.S. Swimmers End With 27 of 32 Golds
description: Katie Welch of St. Louis set a Pan American Games record in the 200-meter backstroke tonight as 16-year-old Silvia Poll of Costa Rica, who finished second, lost her bid for a record four gold medals in individual swimming events. Earlier tonight, 14-year-old Jennifer Thompson of Dover, N.H., won the 50-meter freestyle over Poll.

title: Officer Is Shot in Thigh Arresting Drug Suspect
description: A police officer was shot in the thigh during a struggle with a drug suspect in the South Bronx yesterday afternoon, authorities said.

title: Debate Over Bork Dominates Bar Association Convetion
description: THERE were fife-and-drum ensembles, actors dressed as Dolley and James Madison, and re-enactments of events of 200 years ago, but as a topic of discussion at the American Bar Association convention last week, the bicentennial of the Constitution took a back seat to Judge Robert H. Bork.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about the Red Grooms retrospective at the Whitney Museum attributed several of the artist's large environmental works incompletely. The artist Mimi Gross collaborated on these pieces, which included ''Ruckus Manhattan'' and ''City of Chicago.''

title: POSTINGS: Big Lots, Fewer Houses; Putnam Plan
description: For home buyers whose hearts are set on a fading commodity - a largish chunk of property within commuting distance of New York City - a new development called Barrett Ridge in Putnam County, N.Y., might offer the ambling room.

title: MATTHEW D. MCDONALD WEDS EUGENIE MACKEY
description: Eugenie Lewis Mackey, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barton L. Mackey of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Matthew Dale McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McDonald of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. John O'Hear performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: When You Buy High and Sell Low
description: AN investor who buys an over-the-counter stock, particularly an obscure, thinly traded one, faces longer odds of making a profit than a buyer of stocks listed on an exchange. The difference comes from the different ways the two markets operate. In O-T-C trading - unlike that on exchanges - an individual can virtually never buy at the low price of a stock's bid-asked spread, or sell at the higher price.

title: Americans, It's 'Britain'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Joe Robbie's Success Story
description: DOME or no dome?

title: Dog of Mayor's Chef Bites a City Worker
description: For some reason, a dog belonging to Mayor Koch's chef bit a sanitation supervisor at Gracie Mansion yesterday. Afterward, the Mayor said he would have to decide whether the dog must go.

title: KID CREOLE BRINGS THE REAL WORLD TO POP MUSIC
description: AHEAD OF THE TIMES IS no picnic. Ask August Darnell, whose band, Kid Creole and the Coconuts, forecast late-1980's urban pop back in 1980, when Mr. Darnell became Kid Creole full time. The band Mr. Darnell and the songwriter-arranger Andy (Coati Mundi) Hernandez formed from the remnants of Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band set out to make real New York pop the way they heard it - all the sounds of the city from Broadway to the Bronx, from Tin Pan Alley to the Caribbean enclaves of Brooklyn and Queens. The sixth Kid Creole album, ''I, Too, Have Seen the Woods'' (Sire 25579-1, album and cassette), sounds thoroughly contemporary - but then again, so does their 1980 debut LP, ''Off the Coast of Me.''

title: Chicago Bears Owner's Body Is Exhumed for a 2d Autopsy
description: The body of the former president of the Chicago Bears football team, George Halas Jr., was exhumed today and a second autopsy was performed to determine the cause of his death eight years ago.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Sol Hurwitz's article ''A 5-Day Hike in the Valais of Switzerland'' (Travel, June 7), since I grew up in Martigny, a town in the middle of the area described. I spent many weekends hiking and fishing with my father in the Vallee de Bagnes, as well as in Champex, a mountain resort not far from Verbier.

title: Recent Sales
description: Brookhaven $191,000 6 Hearth Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $2,100. East Patchogue $135,000 272 Dunton Avenue 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; deck, water view, 2-car garage; taxes $1,000. Franklin Square $235,000 690 Morton Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old ranch; finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,900. Head of the Harbor $425,000 24 Pinoak Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; library, porch, basement, 2 fireplaces, maid's wing, private road; taxes $7,200. Hicksville $233,000 98 Ketcham Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old split level; den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,400. Port Jefferson $525,000 34 Waterview Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; basement, 2 fireplaces, skylights, water view, 1 acre; taxes $6,800. OTHER AREAS Oradell, N.J. $295,000 762 Schaffer Rtreet 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old split level: central A/C, hardwood floors, 2-car garage; taxes $3,146. Hartford, Conn. $129,900 25 Yale Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, exceptional plantings; taxes, $1,824. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $282,000 50-52 Carpenter Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old frame contemporary; deck, family room, den, walk to station; taxes $4,187.

title: A Generation of Victors
description: COMMANDER IN CHIEF Franklin Delano Roosevelt, His Lieutenants, and Their War. By Eric Larrabee. 723 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $25.

title: TORRICELLI REFLECTS ON U.S. AND STATE
description: REPRESENTATIVE Robert G. Torricelli was in his district office in Hackensack on May 5 when he first heard that The Miami Herald was accusing his friend, former Senator Gary Hart of Colorado, of spending a weekend with Donna Rice.

title: Court Officers Ask for Protection From AIDS
description: Union leaders representing New York court officers urged the administrator of the state's courts last week to adopt strong new rules to protect them and the public from criminal defendants with AIDS.

title: WILL ISRAEL FINALLY GET A CONSTITUTION?
description: IT has always been ironic that Israel, the nation descended from Moses the lawgiver, the state where lawyers and Talmudic scholars seem to grow on trees, could never produce a constitution of its own.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Altering Bats and Balls a Part Of Baseball?
description: Every time a pitch is thrown or a bat swung in the major leagues, millions of dollars are directly or indirectly at stake. So are the career prospects of those who stand to lose by the efficacy of those pitches and swings. Doctored balls and bats, then, should be regarded as much a part of baseball as are doctored dice in a casino, inside trading on Wall Street and cheating on S.A.T. and civil service exams. CARLETON FREEDMAN Brooklyn

title: CITIES SEEN AS KEY IN 4TH DISTRICT ELECTION
description: FOR the past four weeks, Christopher Shays and Christine M. Niedermeier have spent each day barnstorming through lower Fairfield County in their short campaign to succeed the Congressman who represented the Fourth Congressional District for 17 years.

title: MUSIC, EVERY WHICH WAY
description: TO WATCH A COMPOSER watching his new work come to life, shaped into sound by performers over whom he has no direct control, is to observe nervous apprehension made painfully apparent. William Bolcom went through just that anxiety recently when the St. Louis Symphony and its music director, Leonard Slatkin, rehearsed his Fourth Symphony, which the orchestra had commissioned. The St. Louis Symphony is a fine group and, as the most important American orchestra led by a native-born American, is accustomed to working with new American scores. Slatkin, in turn, has known Bolcom since they were together at the Aspen Music Festival in 1964 and is a brisk and efficient master of rehearsal time. Still, the first run-through was full of opportunities for improvement.

title: ALMS HOUSE RECALLED
description: LEAD: Homelessness may be a pressing problem, but it is not a new one: in the 1800's, thousands of inmates - as they were then called - occupied the county Alms House. Located on what is now the Grasslands Reservation in Valhalla, the Alms House was a self-sufficient, working farm where the indigent could stay.

title: Medical Use of Fetal Tissues Spurs New Abortion Debate
description: The surge of interest in medical uses for tissue from aborted fetuses has opened a new debate about medical technology and the beginnings of life and added a new dimension to the longstanding controversy over abortion.

title:
A VOICE FROM MADRID;
Spain Is Learning to Cope With Democracy and Progress
description: LEAD: EVERY day, indifferent Spaniards stroll past the 20-foot-high bronze equestrian statue of the dictator, Francisco Franco, on a Madrid avenue. A tattered flag and withered wreath linger as tributes by nostalgic followers of fascism.

title: Sri Lanka Delays Lifting Emergency Decree in Tamil Areas
description: The Government today delayed its expected declaration lifting the state of emergency in Northern and Eastern Provinces, where Tamil separatists fought a bitter four-year guerrilla war until last month.

title: Bargains From Spain
description: FROM THE OUTSIDE, Harlequin looks like any other Greenwich Village restaurant. Peek in. Right up front, on a long table, is an inviting display, a sort of cornucopia, of fruits, vegetables, seafood and meats of the season. Beyond is the dining room -attractive, conservative, traditional. No fey Village decor, drop-dead lighting or Actors' Studio waiters who introduce themselves.

title: OSHA
description: To the Editor:

title: Up and Around
description: Prepared, at least for now, to work less, eat less and worry less, Mayor Edward I. Koch returned to his office at City Hall last week. New York's Mayor was greeted by cheering subordinates on his first day back at work since he was hospitalized 10 days ago after suffering a minor stroke. Mr. Koch, who spent three days in the hospital, said he would heed his doctors' orders to cut back his hectic schedule. Holding forth at his second news conference in five hours, he said, ''I'm a person who takes advice from physicians. I came within a hair's breadth of being paralyzed.'' The stroke, which was characterized by his doctors as ''tiny'' and ''trivial,'' caused a temporary slurring of his speech and a slight drooping of the left side of his face. The Mayor said he was not concerned about the political ramifications of his illness. He said he was just ''happy that I came through this without what the doctors refer to as a deficit.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: India's Drought Is Worst in Decades
description: Dawn broke in these parched farmlands today with gray clouds, raising a few hopes of rain. But by midmorning the sun was ablaze, once again burning farmers' hopes of relief from India's driest rainy season in decades.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Over the years I have put many coats of clear sealer on my flagstone patio. This finish has yellowed over the years, so I would like to take it all off and get back to the natural flagstone. Any suggestions? A. Although I am not familiar with the particular brand of sealer you have been using, most stone sealers can be removed with a chemical paint and varnish remover. I would recommend a semipaste type that can be washed off with water. Spread it onto a few square feet at a time, wait about 15 minutes, then scrub off the softened finish with a stiff brush dipped into a detergent solution. Flush off with lots of water. Q. The uninsulated air-conditioning ducts in my basement drip condensation onto the carpet. The ducts in my garage are insulated, but they also drip when the unit is running. My air-conditioner man told me to cover the ducts with a special blanket that can prevent this, but then where would the condensation go? A. The ''blanket'' he is referring to is insulation with a vapor barrier on the outside. Insulation without a vapor barrier lets air through to the cold metal ducts so condensation can form. But a vapor barrier around the outside will keep warm, moist air from coming in contact with the cold metal - so condensation will not form at all. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: MINE SINKS VESSEL IN A STAGING AREA FOR GULF SHIPPING
description: A small ship servicing oil tankers in a supposedly safe anchorage just outside the Persian Gulf was blown to bits today by a mine.

title: How a Managing Change Affects Players
description: THE old adage that a manager is hired to be fired takes on an additional degree of imminence as it relates to New York Yankee managers in the reign of George Steinbrenner. In my eight-plus years as a major leaguer I was subject to eight different field managers, but this lack of stability pales terribly in the face of what Willie Randolph or Ron Guidry, the oldest Yankees in seniority, have been subject to. They have also had the advantage, or disadvantage, of having some of their managers recycled for stints No. 2, 3, 4. . . .

title: 2 Pedestrians Killed; College Student Is Held
description: Two pedestrians were killed early this morning when a car driven by a 22-year-old college student went out of control, crossing onto the shoulder of Sunrise Highway here, the police said.

title: Ship Travel
description: To the Editor: I embarked on the QE2 in New York, May 24, for Southhampton. A storm over the Atlantic (force-10 gale winds) delayed docking by three hours to about 8 P.M. on Friday, May 29. At that hour longshoremen refused to unload passengers' luggage, and they would not allow the ship's stewards to help passengers carry luggage ashore. Landing was thus delayed to Saturday morning.

title: Avian Flu Reaches Michigan
description: An outbreak of avian influenza has prompted the quarantine of 60,000 turkeys, officials say. Dan Torrington, vice president for farm operations at Bil-Mar farms, said Thursday that the outbreak was the first of its kind in Michigan. The influenza strain forced farmers in Pennsylvania, Virginia and other Eastern states to destroy millions of birds in 1983 and 1984.

title: TEN-AGE FILMS: LOVE, DEATH AND THE PROM
description: BEFORE I BECAME A TEEN-ager in the mid-60's, my clearest vision of what it would be like to be one was taken from the movies, and while I thought Andy Hardy adorable and Annette and Frankie clearly self-satisfied, the one image that seemed to me to define what life then would entail was the final scene in ''West Side Story,'' where the dying Tony sang with the tear-filled Maria ''There's a Place for Us.''

title: This May Be the Time to Limit the C.I.A.'s Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Bad Roof Repair Job Question: I am a tenant in a rent-stabilized building that was recently converted to a co-op. In the amendment to the conversion plan the sponsor agreed to a roof repair job in which it would be stripped, insulated and covered with a four-ply cap sheet. But what the sponsor did, which can be verified in photographs and an engineer's report, amounted to a patch job that saved $25,000 in repair costs. As the repairs were negotiated in lieu of money for the reserve fund, can the rental tenants force the sponsor to make good on the repair job agreed to in the amendment if the co-op board refuses to press the issue? . . . R. M., Manhattan Answer: Yes. Russell McGurk, a spokesman for the New York Attorney General's office, says the interests of rental tenants, just like those of co-op or condominium buyers, are protected by the laws pertaining to conversions. If you believe terms of the conversion plan for your building have been ignored or violated, file a complaint with the Attorney General's Real Estate Financing Bureau at 120 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10271. Zoning in Queens Question: My parents live in a section of Queens that has mostly one- and two-family homes. An absentee homeowner on their block is renting a house to unrelated men who are working on a construction project nearby. There are as many as eight men living in the house at one time. Is this practice against the zoning for the area? . . . C. H., Fresh Meadow, Queens Answer: The living arrangement you described might not be in violation of the zoning code but could be illegal nevertheless. The area where your parents live is in a R-32 zone, which permits residential uses of all types including single-family homes, multiple dwellings and facilties for unrelated residents.

title: Amy Donovan to Wed R. M. Bender 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Lee Schreiber Donovan of New Canaan, Conn., and James Robert Donovan of West Harwich, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Amy Louise Donovan, to Robert Michael Bender 3d, a son of Mr. Bender Jr. of New York and Mrs. Robert Scolamiero of Scituate, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: Quarterback to Stay
description: AN academic honesty committee at Auburn twice found Jeff Burger, the starting quarterback for the university's football team, guilty of plagiarism on a term paper and recommended that the senior be suspended from school. Suspension would have cost Burger his last season of eligibility. But in an unprecedented move, Warren Brandt, Auburn's vice president for academic affairs, overruled the committee of four professors and three students, allowing Brandt to stay in school.

title: Studies Indicate New Sickle Cell Anemia Clue
description: A natural protein produced through genetic manipulation may provide a new treatment for sickle cell anemia by stimulating victims' bodies to manufacture normal blood cells, animal studies suggest.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
A Hoboken Plan Staves Off Displacement
description: LEAD: HOBOKEN, the old industrial port on the Hudson River opposite lower Manhattan, is more than 10 years into a revival that has produced mixed results.

title: Foreign Policy Challenging President's Staying Power
description: RONALD Reagan came into the Presidency in January 1981 with pledges to make the United States a stronger country than ever before, one that would be respected, even feared, in the rest of the world.

title: Botanical Prints Are Nosegays To Collectors
description: WHETHER THE CUR-rent renaissance in gardening activity has increased the popularity of botanical prints may be a matter of debate; yet, it is fairly clear that prints of buds, blooms and blossoming greenery have become coveted collectibles.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: The March of Time - The American Family: The War Years 1941-1945. Embassy Home Entertainment. 89 minutes. $24.95. This compendium of five ''March of Time'' newsreels - monthly documentaries that were screened nationwide as part of movie programs for some 16 years - explores the depths to which domestic American life was transformed by World War II.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: AUGUST 16, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 2 6 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 3 2 HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) A top New York model's encounters with three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men. 4 4 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $5.95.) Four hundred years of history in fictional form. 5 3 THE UNWANTED, by John Saul. (Bantam, $4.50.) A teen-age girl, lonely in a Cape Cod town, finds herself endowed with terrifying powers. 6 6 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Pocket, $4.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 7 7 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 8 8 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 9 2 THE ROMULAN WAY, by Diane Duane and Peter Morwood. (Pocket, $3.50.) Dr. Leonard McCoy battles for survival in a new ''Star Trek'' novel. 10 * 66 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.)
