description: Record Day for Mets

title: AMERICAN LEARNING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHECKROBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company is a development stage company and said the anticipated losses are the result of continued investment in the marketing and development of its automated checkout machines.

title: FRANKLIN COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sailor Is Closer To Record for Age
description: Three years ago, Tania Aebi was a disgruntled teen-ager, tired of her part-time job as a bicycle messenger in New York City. She quit after high school, trading in her bicycle for a boat. If all goes well within the next month, she will become the youngest person to sail around the world alone.

title: Martin McGowan Wed To Virginia Ann Cook
description: Virginia Ann Cook and Martin Rogers McGowan were married yesterday at the Orcutt Ranch, a historic site in Canoga Park, Calif. The Rev. James A. Maronde, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Market Place; Interstate Tops Bakery Stocks
description: BAKING bread and cakes may sound like a pretty dull business, but shares of the major publicly traded producers of baked goods sold last week at or near record prices.

title: Mets Belt Out 23 Runs
description: After five straight losses over the last two weekends, and many bad memories over the years, the Mets turned on the Chicago Cubs today with a fury: 21 hits and 23 runs, the most runs the team had ever scored in their 26 years in the National League.

title: The Bobbsey Twins Carry On (and On and On)
description: Nan, Bert, Freddie and Flossie sat under a tree in the backyard. They tried to clear up the case.

title: Tigers Win to Stay In the Chase in East
description: Alan Trammell tripled, singled and hit a tie-breaking double that sparked a five-run seventh inning today as he led the Detroit Tigers over the Kansas City Royals, 10-6.

title: Critic of Pinochet Returns
description: Ariel Dorfman has returned to Chile, saying he was baffled that the military Government had allowed him in after refusing to let him enter just two weeks ago. Mr. Dorfman, a writer who has been an outspoken critic of the Government, arrived at the Santiago airport Saturday with his 8-year-old son, Joaquin. He said he planned to visit friends and to register to vote in the presidential elections. The writer, who has been living in the United States, was barred from Chile after President Augusto Pinochet seized power in 1973.

title: Search for a 'Difficult Character' in 'No Way Out'
description: ''To tell you the truth,'' said Sean Young, ''every role scares me half to death - because you never really know a character as fully as after you finish with her and you're done and she takes you someplace and makes you learn. And what you learn sometimes can be very frightening if you're honest.''

title: Chad Reaps a Windfall in War Booty
description: Chadians like to tell the story of a diary found recently on a desert battlefield. In it, they say, a Libyan soldier had penned this bitter line: ''Muammar el-Qaddafi has wasted all our wealth here.''

description: b-Net income

title: Niedermeier for the Connecticut House Seat
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Announces Key Staff Changes
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, announced executive changes on his staff yesterday, including the promotion of David W. Denton to the third highest post in the prosecutor's office.

title: Putnam's President Promoted
description: The president of the Putnam Publishing Group, Phyllis Grann, was named chief executive officer of the group yesterday. Mrs. Grann was also elected a vice president of MCA Inc., the leisure-time and entertainment conglomerate of which Putnam's is a subsidiary.

title: Japan's Export Stance Queried
description: The United States expressed concern today that Japan had too few inspectors checking for illegal strategic exports to Communist countries, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said.

title: MANPOWER INC.
description: Shares of Manpower Inc., the world's largest temporary service company, rose 87.5 cents today on speculation that Britain's Blue Arrow P.L.C. would sweeten its $1.2 billion takeover bid. The stock closed at $75.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. On Saturday, the company rejected as inadequate a hostile $75-a-share offer from Blue Arrow, Britain's leading employment services concern.

title: O'Connor Leads Rites as 500 Mourn Slain S.I. Girl
description: More than 500 people packed a Staten Island church yesterday to mourn for Jennifer Schweiger, a 12-year-old with Down's syndrome whose body was found in a shallow grave last week, more than a month after she was reported missing.

title: Call for General Strike in Panama Fails When Most Businesses Open
description: Most businesses opened as usual in the capital today despite a call for a general strike that was issued by opposition leaders seeking to oust the leader of the nation's military, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: AIR FORCE SEES BEAUTY IN UGLY DUCKLINGS
description: AS military scientists devise new ways to foil enemy radar, the Stealth program is also addressing a need to make combat planes less conspicuous to the naked eye.

title: Iran Court Deliberates on a Cleric Whose Arrest Exposed Arms Sale
description: A special religious court has begun deliberations on a sentence for Mehdi Hashemi, a radical cleric whose arrest last October was believed to have led to the revelation of American arms sales to Iran.

title: GV MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
At 93, Oldest Park Ranger Still Stands Guard
description: For Frederico Sisneros, protecting the sandstone ruins of a 360-year-old church built by the Spanish and the pueblos built by the Tampiro Indians has been a way of life.

title: FINNIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $443,000.

ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Oil Reserve Passes Test
description: The Energy Department said today that a test involving its Strategic Petroleum Reserve had been a success. In the exercise this summer, the department emptied part of the reserve to see if the oil could be brought to market quickly in an emergency.

title: Habre Policy in Chad: Name Ex-Foes to Key Posts
description: A few years ago, soldiers led by Col. Kamougue Wadal Abdelkader hunted down a rebel chieftain named Hissen Habre and pursued him as he fled from Chad into the Sudan.

title: PROFFITT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LTV Pensions
description: The LTV Corporation said the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit had denied a request by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to delay enactment of a labor agreement ratified Aug. 6 by employees of the LTV Steel Company. The agreement with the United Steelworkers union was approved July 16 by the Federal Bankruptcy Court. LTV said it had issued supplemental payments to nearly 10,000 retirees whose income was reduced when the pension agency ended the company's pension plans in January.

title: The Habib/Stone/Motley/Enders Exit
description: Resignations speak louder than explanations. A State Department spokesman strained all credulity in explaining the resignation of Philip Habib, the President's special Central American envoy. Given the peace initiative by regional leaders and the peace plan worked out between President Reagan and House Speaker Jim Wright, the spokesman said Mr. Habib ''has decided that this is an appropriate moment for him to return to private life.''

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL ALERT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Theater Colleagues Dispute Authorship of 'Moms'
description: The authorship of screenplays can often be in dispute, but usually in the theater a play is a play is a play. In the case of ''Moms,'' however, there are two plays (or variations thereof), two playwrights and a disagreement between two old friends and distinguished theatrical colleagues over a question of plagiarism.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Spandau's Prisoner No. 7
description: The death of Rudolf Hess closes two thick black books. One concerns Germany. Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's deputy and a founder of the Nazi Party, took it on himself in May 1941 to parachute into Scotland in what Winston Churchill called a ''frantic deed of lunatic benevolence.'' According to the British, Hess came only to propose peace with Germany.

title: Lincoln Documents Recovered
description: Nearly 200 Civil War documents, including papers signed by President Abraham Lincoln, were discovered in a safedeposit box used by a Washington portrait artist who has been accused of stealing manuscripts from the Library of Congress and the National Archives, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: FISHER TRANSPORTATION SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Careers; A Future In College Teaching
description: THERE is a graying of America that can lead to good jobs at the nation's colleges for both young people and middle-aged career changers. In the next decade or so, about 40 percent of American college professors will be retiring, according to Karen Hiiemae, vice president for research and graduate studies at Syracuse University.

title: BRANDON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Copters Prepare for a Gulf Convoy
description: Minesweeping helicopters from the American amphibious assault ship Guadalcanal carried out maneuvers off this Persian Gulf island today in preparation to escort the next convoy of re-registered Kuwaiti tankers.

title: Top U.N. Official May Visit Teheran Soon to Discuss War
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will probably visit Teheran in the next four weeks, at the invitation of Iran's Government, for talks on the Iran-Iraq war, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: 3 Maturities On CSX Bonds
description: The CSX Corporation is offering $195 million of secured bonds divided into three maturities through Salomon Brothers.

title: JAMCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes a $163,000 loss on disposal of discontinued operations. The company said the latest third quarter loss consisted primarily of one-time noncash charges, including $211,000 for miscellaneous items such as obsolete inventory and goodwill writeoffs; $587,000 expensed for anticipated losses on closed or subleased restaurant properties; and expense provisions of $599,000 for bad debts and settlement of litigation.

title: Sink or Swim With Semiconductors
description: LEAD: The Administration is hotly debating a proposal that would make the Federal Government a sponsor of research and development in the semiconductor industry. A decision is due this month.

title: Revlon Asks to Bid For Gillette
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman and chief executive of the Revlon Group Inc., revived his pursuit of the Gillette Company yesterday, but once again was immediately rebuffed.

title: COMPUTER WARNED PILOTS IN CRASH OF 'STALL' DANGER
description: The pilots of the Northwest Airlines jetliner that crashed in Detroit Sunday evidently had no indication of trouble until a computer voice intoning ''stall, stall'' told them they were flying too slowly, officials close to the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Life 'in the Trenches'
description: To the Editor:

FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Chess:; A Sluggish Karpov Survives An All-Out Attack - Barely
description: Anatoly Karpov passed his last practical test before his title match with the world champion Gary Kasparov in October, but not with flying colors.

title: EMIL PETERS
description: Emil Peters, a retired general counsel for General Electric in Schenectady and former president of the board of trustees of the Albany Law School, died Aug. 8 at his home in Schenectady. He was 79 years old.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs Is Potential Target
description: A group led by David F. Bolger, an investment banker based in Ridgewood, N.J., has purchased a 5.1 percent stake in Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. for $10.2 million and may seek control of the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Bolger said he and three partners had requested a meeting with managers of the iron ore and drilling concern.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Cycling Rosola Wins Colorado Race: Paolo Rosola of Italy, vaulting into the lead when a brief fistfight broke out between two other riders, cruised to a convincing victory yesterday in the 107-mile Aspen-to-Copper Mountain Road Race in Colorado in the Coors International Bicycle Classic. Ron Kiefel of the powerful 7-Eleven team finished second and moved up to fourth place over all, giving 7-Eleven the first four spots in the general standings. In the women's race, Leslee Schenk broke into the lead 18 miles from the finish and won the 58-mile Copper Mountain Road Race. Jeannie Longo of France is the overall leader. Rosola, 30 years old, of the Bianchi-Italy team, won his second race of the Classic. Running in a lead pack of six riders, Rosola went in front with about 25 miles to go when Jaanus Kuum of Norway and Roberto Pagnin of Italy exchanged blows. Kuum contended he was pushed by Pagnin and responded with a shove of his own. Pagnin said the incident started on Sunday when the two had words. He and Kuum were fined $25 each for the incident and will be assessed 20-second penalties in the overall standings. Jeff Pierce of 7-Eleven finished 14th yesterday but retained his overall lead. His teammates, Raul Alcala and Andrew Hampsten, rank second and third, respectively. (AP) Tennis Wilander Struggles to Victory: Top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden struggled yesterday to defeat Leonardo Lavalle of Mexico in the first round of the Association of Tennis Professionals Championships at Mason, Ohio. Wilander beat Lavalle, 7-6, 7-6, after two tiebreakers, 7-1 and 7-3.(AP) Potter Defeats Budarova: In Toronto, Barbara Potter of the United States defeated Iva Budarova of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-2, in the first round of the Player's Challenge women's tennis tournament. (AP)

title: Novel Breathing Method
description: When a wallaby bounds across the Australian Outback, it breathes once per hop no matter how fast it moves in its two-legged stride. The timing apparently represents an energy-saving arrangement the animals have developed in the course of evolution. While it moves at high speed, the wallaby does not have to exert extra energy in breathing. Its internal organs surge forward and back, giving the effect of a mechanical air pump impelled by the changing momentum of the animal's stride. Air is squeezed out of the lungs as the internal organs push forward against the diaphragm; air is drawn back in as the lungs are forced to expand when the viscera move back.

title: Pryor Charges Dropped
description: State prosecutors in Miami yesterday dropped the most serious of the charges facing Aaron Pryor after the woman that the professional boxer had purportedly assaulted could not be found to testify. Pryor pleaded no-contest to lesser charges and was fined $5,000. He will not have a criminal record. The prosecutor dropped charges of sexual battery, kidnapping and six counts of aggravated assault. Pryor pleaded no contest to two other charges of aggravated assault against others at the scene.

title: Bombs Hurled in Sri Lanka Assembly
description: Three bombs were hurled into a meeting of leaders of the governing party in Parliament today, wounding four ministers and 10 legislators shortly before they were to begin discussing a new peace accord with Tamil separatists, a senior official said.

title: U.S. ENVOYS TOLD TO CONVEY DOUBT OVER LATIN PLAN
description: Senior United States envoys to the five Central American nations were told at a meeting here today that they should convey Washington's deep concern about a regional peace plan adopted this month, Administration officials said.

title: Primerica Sells Lomas Holdings
description: The Primerica Corporation disclosed that it had sold 2.72 million shares of the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation - its entire 8.6 percent stake - for $86.2 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Primerica gave no reason for selling the shares of the Dallas-based mortgage banking company.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $578,000 from a reduction of a provision for a loss on discontinued operations and a gain of $1,416,000 from the sale of woodstream stock for both the quarter and 6 months; and tax credits of $295,000 for the quarter and $309,000 for the 6 months.

title: James T. Moock Dies at 79; Dockworkers' Union Official
description: James T. Moock, a retired first international vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association, died of complications resulting from pnuemonia Saturday at the Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 79 years old and lived in West Deptford Township, N.J.

title: Lucille Mason Rose, First Woman Named As a Deputy Mayor
description: Lucille Mason Rose, a former New York City Deputy Mayor, died after a heart attack Saturday in Brookdale Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Profits Climb At Unilever
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch household products company, said today that its net income jumped 31.9 percent in the second quarter from a year ago.

title: Where Plastic Is a Passion and the Polar Ice Is Hot
description: This country has grown so rich so fast that its people sometimes have trouble devising ways to spend their money.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK UNDERDOGS FIGHT FOR 'WINDOW ON CREATION'
description: Here in the North Country, the truth is not cloaked in fancy rhetoric. So when the Federal Government announced it wanted to build a $6 billion superconducting supercollider, people did not pretend their enthusiasm for supercolliders was based on a sudden interest in particle physics.

title: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INSIDE
description: Bombing in Sri Lanka

title: Tax Amnesty Is Set in Jersey, With Warning
description: Governor Kean announced today that an amnesty for tax delinquents would begin Sept. 10 and that those who failed to pay by Dec. 8 would face some of the toughest penalties in the nation.

title: SANDWICH CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Dance: Terry Beck Troupe
description: TERRY BECK'S ''Passer-by'' opened with Mr. Beck, who performed with his company on Saturday evening at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, standing in a dim spotlight at the side of a stage over which masks hung suspended. When the masks stirred in the air, they were revealed as eerily double-sided faces. Mr. Beck's face was troubled, and his fingers twitched into the air to a sound score of clock chimes and distant traffic. The sounds were followed by silence, the silence by German song, with a return at last to the traffic and bells. Mr. Beck moved to the other side of the stage and back in ''Passer-by.'' He engaged in hermetic semaphoric gesturing with his arms and stepped from a chair as if into a void.

title: BEARN STEARNS COS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
USG to Buy Dap
description: The USG Corporation, a producer of building materials, said its USG Industries subsidiary had signed an agreement to buy Dap Inc. from Britain's Beecham Group P.L.C. for about $123 million. Dap, based in Tipp City, Ohio, makes caulks, sealants, adhesives and related products for the construction and repair of buildings. It reported 1986 sales of $131 million. USG, which last year earned $225 million on sales of $2.72 billion, said it expected to complete the acquisition within a month.

title: New Man From Bonn
description: Sometime this autumn, West Germany will send a new Ambassador, Jurgen Ruhfus, to Washington to replace Gunther Van Well, who is retiring.

title: No Action on Foyt
description: Officials have decided to take no immediate action against A. J. Foyt despite his run-in with a race official Sunday at the Quaker State 500 at Mount Pocono, Pa. On Sunday, Championship Auto Racing Teams' chief steward, Wally Dallenbach, said he would consider fining Foyt for accosting an official at the conclusion of the race. But John Evenson, director of communications for CART, said yesterday that officials planned no action at this time against Foyt. Foyt was accused of accosting the race official, Dick Perry, after finishing seventh. Rick Mears won the race. Foyt was one of five drivers charged with a penalty during the race for exiting the pits with wheels above a yellow demarcation line. Foyt killed his engine in his stop-and-go penalty trip.

title: 6 Disqualified From Pan Am Games for Drug Use
description: Six athletes from five countries, including a silver medal winner from the United States, have tested positive for banned substances during the Pan American Games, the president of the Pan American Sports Organization said today.

title: A Coming of Age: Shulman Emerges To Lead in Queens
description: The applause began as the woman quietly entered the hearing room. As more people noticed her, the applause grew.

title: Is the Air Pure or Foul? Lichens Can Tell the Tale
description: AT the turn of the century, when ''botanizing'' was a popular pastime, dozens of naturalists spent countless hours collecting and identifying lichens, unusual unions of algae and fungi forming picturesque plants that resemble neither ''parent.''

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'NOT NECESSARILY THE MEDIA' ON HBO
description: IN the craft of hit-or-miss comedy, the kind that flings dozens of jokes at you in the expectation that a few may actually connect, few series have been more energetically determined than ''Not Necessarily the News.'' The show, created by John Moffitt and Pat Tourk Lee, has been carried on the Home Box Office pay-cable service for more than four years, using a mixture of actual news footage and sketch material to take satirical pokes at names in the headlines. The Reagans, needless to say, are special favorites.

title: TIME INC. CHIEF TO BE NAMED AS ENVOY TO AUSTRIA
description: Henry Anatole Grunwald, the editor in chief of Time Inc., will be nominated by President Reagan to be ambassador to Austria, according to Administration officials.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Amid the Wreckage, 4-Year-Old Girl Lives
description: A critically injured 4-year-old girl, found whimpering beneath the body of a dead woman, is the sole survivor of the fiery plane crash that killed at least 152 people, including her parents and brother, officials said today.

title: British Deal For Broker
description: British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C. said today that it would sell parts of Mercantile House Holdings P.L.C. to Quadrex Holdings Inc. for $:280 million, or the equivalent of $446 million, if British and Commonwealth succeeds in acquiring Mercantile House.

title: Cooling-Off Time
description: You could have sworn it was Bernstein on the podium, flailing his baton for the last measures of Tchaikovsky, or maybe it was Peter O'Toole swinging down from the balcony with a sword in the closing minutes of ''My Favorite Year.''

title: A Convention That's Uncalled For
description: You folks better approve a balanced budget amendment, President Reagan threatens Congress, or else ''the call for a constitutional convention will grow louder. The prospect for a constitutional convention is only two states away from approval.'' That's a false alarm as well as a bad idea. A constitutional convention would require applications to Congress from 34 states. Mr. Reagan implies that 32 of the required 34 have applied. There are indeed 32 applications on file, but 29 of them are more than seven years old. That's hardly the expression of current sentiment that Congress must heed. There simply is not anything like a national convention call.

title: Upsets Continue As Bailrullah Wins
description: Bailrullah, a 36-1 shot who had finished behind Perfect Point and Videogenic in a prep race last time out, turned the tables on those two horses to win the $130,600 Diana Handicap today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The purpose of Spandau Allied War-Crimes Prison has ceased with the death of Rudolf Hess.'' - The Allied Prison Administration. [ A1:1. ]

title: Among Relatives of Victims, Sorrow, Anger and Disbelief
description: For the families of the victims, all that made sense today was the piercing cry of a mother raging at fate.

title: Surfboard Bitten
description: A Santa Cruz man has received six stitches in his hand after the surfboard he was sitting on was bitten, apparently by a great white shark, a sheriff's deputy said. John Mattes of the San Mateo County Sheriff's Department said Craig Rogers, 40, was surfing near Tunitas Beach about 30 miles south of San Francisco on Saturday when the attack occurred. ''From the looks of his surfboard, it was a great white,'' he said, adding that Mr. Rogers was treated at a Santa Cruz area hospital for his injuries.

title: Business and Health; Efforts to Cut Medical Costs
description: EMPLOYERS and insurers are wondering whether they can reduce their health-care costs by paying for preventive care to keep workers healthier.

title: A Drug Suspect Is Shot In Fight With Detective
description: One of four people arrested yesterday on drug charges was shot in the neck while struggling with a narcotics detective, the police said.

title: Rudolf Hess Is Dead in Berlin; Last of the Hitler Inner Circle
description: Rudolf Hess, the onetime deputy to Hitler who early in World War II parachuted into a Scottish meadow in what he called an attempt to make peace between Nazi Germany and Britain, died yesterday in West Berlin. He was 93 years old.

title: 'Text' Isn't Destroyed In Movie Colorizing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook: A Friendly Place for Books; How to Sell Reading In East Harlem
description: In an age of TV and less than perfect schools, is there a way to instill the habit of reading in children, especially poor children? An affirmative answer is provided by The Friendly Place - ''El Situo Simpatico'' in Spanish -a double storefront in the Metro North Housing Project at 101st Street and First Avenue in Manhattan. The storefront houses a library used by about 6,000 East Harlem youngsters - and their parents - each year. Every New York City neighborhood could use this sort of friendly place.

title: Julius Helfand Is Dead at 84; Led New York Boxing Inquiry
description: Julius Helfand, a retired Brooklyn judge who served as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission and had a major impact on reforming boxing, died Sunday at the Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., of complications from brain tumor surgery. He was 84 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.

title: Correction
description: The statistics page in SportsMonday yesterday gave the number of innings incorrectly for the baseball game between Cuba and Nicaragua.

title: Simon's Blossoming Empire
description: William E. Simon has in his 59 years mastered the rough-and-tumble world of bond trading, served as ''energy czar'' and Treasury Secretary, headed the United States Olympic Committee and gained a reputation as one of the most successful investors in Wall Street history.

title: Anheuser-Busch
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies is offering $100 million of 8 7/8 percent notes, due in 1994, at a price of 99.612 to yield 8.95 percent, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company. The notes are not callable for five years and yield about 55-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes due in 1994. The issue is rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: War and Trust
description: The reward of a freely elected government is the trust of the people.

title: Bond Prices Fall Moderately
description: Bond prices fell modestly yesterday as weak investor demand and a lower dollar overpowered the beneficial effects of falling oil prices.

title: Botha Criticizes Leftist Journalists in South Africa
description: President P. W. Botha delivered a wide-ranging attack on foreign and domestic journalists today, saying that left-wing newspapers and news agencies would have to be ''investigated and dealt with.''

title: Candidate in Bronx Disqualified
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday disqualified one of the two remaining Democratic candidates for Bronx Surrogate, leaving just one name on the ballot in what originally was a four-way primary.

description: James Galanos proves two things in his fall collection: that he is one of the world's top designers and that short skirts can be appropriate for sophisticated women.

title: ESSEF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Interest Rate Swaps Increase
description: The volume of interest rate swaps rose to a record $57.4 billion in the first quarter of 1987, according to a survey by the International Swap Dealers Association.

title: Trucker Dies in Collision
description: A 1 1/2-ton tractor-trailer slammed into an N.J. Transit commuter bus here early today, killing the truck's driver and injuring the two passengers and driver on the bus, the police said. The accident occurred at Elizabeth and Watson Streets at about 8:30 A.M. Detective Joseph Fouschee of the Newark police said the brakes on the truck failed.

title: Condoms: Experts Fear False Sense Of Security
description: MANY health officials have begun to voice concern that the campaign to encourage condom use to curb the spread of AIDS may be misunderstood, creating a false sense of security in people whose behavior continues to put them in danger.

title: U.S. Sues in Bid-Rigging Case
description: The Justice Department has filed a civil suit to recover more than $2.5 million from one of the nation's largest electrical contractors and four individuals accused of rigging bids on a federally financed project in Tennessee.

title: New Chief Named For Cleveland Fed
description: W. Lee Hoskins did not intend to stay long at the Federal Reserve Bank when he first took a job in the Philadelphia office after graduate school in 1969. But, he said yesterday, ''one thing led to another'' and he ended up in various Federal Reserve economic research posts for 10 1/2 years before he went into the banking business.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE KENZO boutique on Madison Avenue closed briefly this month, but reopens this week under new management. Joseph Ettedgui, a London-based retailer, is its new owner, and he hopes to raise Kenzo's profile in New York.

title: For Doctors, Risk of AIDS Infection Is Serious
description: To the Editor:
