Former Meese Adviser To Appeal U.S. Ruling
description: Lawyers for the former financial adviser to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said yesterday that they would appeal a Federal court decision directing that the adviser be jailed indefinitely for contempt of court.

title: HARRIS-TEETER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago results are not available; the company began operations in August 1986. The company declined to furnish share earnings figures.

title: Bridge:; Poisoning at Spingold Event Was Technical but Also Fatal
description: There was a poisoning epidemic during the recent Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Baltimore, and in some cases teammates of the poisoned were affected.

title: Arab League Meeting On Issue of Terrorism
description: The Arab League was meeting in Damascus, Syria, today to seek a common position on the issue of terrorism.

title: Southland Weighs Cost-Cutting Plan
description: The Southland Corporation, which is being taken private by the company's founding Thompson family, is considering several savings measures as it tries to reduce the debt from the $5.1 billion buyout. Southland officials said they were reconsidering whether to move into the Cityplace development, constructed as the company's headquarters and considered to be a showpiece. Executives said they did not know how much, if any, of the 42-story building Southland would occupy.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 15. Year-ago results reflect change for pension accounting.

title: Schwab Hired by Chase For Market C.D. Sales
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that it had hired Charles J. Schwab & Company to help promote sales of certificates of deposit whose interest rate is pegged to changes in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

title: Suspension Is Reduced
description: The American League announced yesterday it had reduced the suspension of the Cleveland Indians outfielder, Brett Butler, from five games to three. The suspension went into effect for last night's game in Cleveland against the Milwaukee Brewers. Butler was involved in a brawl in a game against the Royals on July 8.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,522,000 and $1,587,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a pretax gain of $3,632,000 on the sale of assets for both periods. c-Net loss

title: Three Ideas in One
description: Some novel ideas, or their discovery, come in threes. Or, perhaps, each idea arises three times.

title: Koch Offers Bill to Ban Sale And Possession of Pit Bulls
description: Responding to a spate of attacks on New Yorkers by pit bulls, Mayor Koch proposed yesterday to ban the sale or possession of the dogs in the city.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Zenith Picks President For Its Computer Unit
description: LEAD: John P. Frank is moving from the marketing side to become president of the Zenith Electronics Corporation's computer products subsidiary, Zenith Data System.

title: Officer Is Suspended After Fatal Accident
description: A Southampton Town police officer was suspended after a fatal off-duty car accident and charged with driving while impaired, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Advertising McAdams & Ong, MRI Advertising Merge
description: McAdams & Ong and MRI Advertising, two agencies based in Philadelphia, have merged to form McAdams, Richman & Ong Advertising. The merger makes it the fifth-largest agency in the area, with billings of $55 million.

title: Spandau Prison: Hess's Lonely Dungeon
description: Spandau Prison, where Rudolf Hess spent the last four decades of his life, is a cheerless red-brick complex of four three-story buildings in West Berlin.

title: LSI LIGHTING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
White House Will Again Seek More Arms for Saudis
description: The White House intends to revive its proposals to sell additional arms to Saudi Arabia later this year, but has made no final decisions on the timing of the sale or what the package would contain, White House officials said today.

title: Fannie Mae Using Realty Conduit
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association's first issue of conventional mortgage securities through a real estate mortgage investment conduit, or Remic, is expected this week through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: ASEA to Purchase Norway's Elektrisk
description: ASEA A.B. of Sweden has agreed to buy control of Norway's largest maker of electronic components, Elektrisk Bureau A.S., for the equivalent of $214 million. Securities analysts said ASEA's 63 percent stake in the Norwegian company was a logical step in the Swedish group's strategy to expand in Europe.

title: Carbide Offers Bhopal Funds
description: The Union Carbide Corporation offered today to deposit $4.6 million with an Indian court as interim relief payment for victims of the 1984 gas disaster at Bhopal.

title: Apartment Fire Kills Boy and His Father
description: A 5-year-old boy and his father were killed early yesterday when a fire broke out in their Brooklyn apartment, trapping them in a back bedroom where a padlocked gate on a window sealed their only escape route, the authorities said.

title: Injured Saudi Diplomat Reported Dead in Iran
description: A Saudi diplomat, hurt when his country's embassy in Teheran was ransacked after Iranian pilgrims were killed in Mecca, has died of his injuries, the Saudi press agency said.

title: Nature Trails Law Faces Roadblock in Missouri
description: Plans for one of the country's longest and most historic nature trails, created under a recent act of Congress, have run into resistance here in rural Missouri from a determined group of landowners led by a descendant of one of the area's earliest families.

title: Yanks Return to Road, Mets to Reality; Injuries, West Are Problems
description: Dave Johnson brought his Mets home from Chicago yesterday, four and a half games behind the St. Louis Cardinals with 44 to go, and he didn't want to hear about those 23 runs they scored Sunday in Wrigley Field.

title: Islanders Sign Two
description: The Islanders signed Brad Dalgarno and Derek King, both of whom were selected by the team in the first round of the 1985 National Hockey League entry draft. Dalgarno, a right wing, and played for the Hamilton Steelhawks of the Ontario Hockey League last season. King, a left wing,played for the Oshawa Generals of the O.H.L. last season. Dalgarno and King, both 20 years old, will both be invited to the Islanders' training camp.

title: Town in Montana Endures As an Outpost of Polygamy
description: A man can have as many wives as he wants in this town of about 700 people tucked against the craggy Bitterroot Mountains, and no one around here objects.

title: Starrett Wins Its Iran Claims
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation, the builder of Trump Tower and Trump Plaza, said yesterday that it had received an award of about $60 million in connection with longstanding claims against Iran.

title: CUBAN BOXERS BET AMERICANS
description: When the United States and Cuba complete the boxing confrontation at the Pan American Games, the tabulations of medals won or lost may not provide as accurate an appraisal as the words of Patrick Byrd.

title: HAKO MINUTEMAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-earlier 6-month results are on a pro forma basis, net of Janpanese and Australian operations sold on Jan. 1, 1986, which resulted in a net gain in the 1986 first quarter of $296,000 and the recognition of previously eliminated inter- company sales of $165,000 and related gross profits of $73,000.

title: Hawley Seeks ADT
description: The Hawley Group, a fast-growing British services conglomerate, bid $635 million today for ADT Inc., a leading American supplier of security services.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Vows to Oppose Bork Nomination
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. today formally joined a chorus of civil rights organizations, civil libertarians and women's groups in opposing President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court.

title: Loss at Smith International
description: Smith International Inc. said today that it lost $59.3 million in its second quarter and attributed the poor results to the sale of its McEvoy-Willis wellhead equipment division for $47.6 million below its book value.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREAT AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Axlon Ending TV Venture
description: Axlon Inc. said today that it would withdraw from an interactive animated television program, resulting in a $325,000 charge for the second quarter ended June 30. Discontinued operations and products also contributed to widened losses for the maker of electronic toys, which was founded by, Nolan Bushnell, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur.

title: GREAT SOUTHERN FEDERAL SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yanks Return to Road, Mets to Reality; On Horizon, Uncertainty
description: The Yankees left home today on the wings of a lost weekend. Behind them were two losses in three games to the Cleveland Indians; ahead of them was uncertainty.

title: U.S. Shipyard Prepares Minesweeper for Gulf
description: The dairy farms and cherry orchards that hug the banks of Sturgeon Bay make images of war difficult to conjure, but that is what is on the minds of shipyard workers building five minesweepers destined for the Persian Gulf.

title: FOODMAKER INC reports earnings for 12wks to July 5
MILTOPE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Books: Chic Frivolity
description: LEAD: AGE OF OPULENCE: The Belle Epoque in the Paris Herald 1890-1914,'' by Hebe Dorsey. Harry N. Abrams Inc. Illustrated. 224 pages. $29.95.

title: The Quest For Speed
description: AS I passed a travel agency one day not long ago, my eye was caught by the window display. Sitting there was a miniature of an ocean liner - a cruise ship, actually, the liners having gone the way of the dodo bird. Their unexpectedly swift demise brought to mind the staggering changes in technology of late.

title: Ancient Mosaic Shows 'Mona Lisa of Palestine'
description: An American-Israeli archeological team has discovered, in excellent condition, a 1,700-year-old mosaic that includes the stunning portrait of a woman who is being called the ''Mona Lisa of Roman Palestine.''

title: Stored Blood: A Research Treasure
description: AS fossils of human infections, stored blood specimens can offer some of the most important clues to the spread of epidemics.

title: Youth, 16, Is Charged In 5 Georgia Murders
description: A 16-year-old boy has been charged with five counts of murder for the weekend beating deaths here of three women and the April slayings of two retired University of Georgia professors, the police said today.

title: GEORGIA GULF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Accounts
description: * Nyack Hospital, a health care facility in Rockland County, to I. Goldberg & Partners.

title: Bear Stearns Doubles Profit
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that its earnings more than doubled in the fiscal first quarter, ended July 31, from a year before. The brokerage house earned $47.9 million, or 53 cents a share, in the latest quarter, up from $18.9 million, or 22 cents a share. Revenues rose to $482.7 million from $334.1 million.

title: Cunningham Settles
description: Billy Cunningham said yesterday he has agreed to sever his ties with the Miami Heat - a National Basketball Association expansion franchise - to become the top analyst for CBS-TV's N.B.A. telecasts. But he will be allowed to stay with the new team through its formative stages. CBS had asked Cunningham to end immediately his association with the Heat, but he said he persuaded the network to accept a compromise that will let him offer the Heat his counsel for about one more year. That means Cunningham will have a say in the choosing of a coach and player-personnel director and in both the collegiate and dispersal draft. But the former Philadelphia 76ers player and coach will have to divest his financial interest and end any managerial chores with the Heat before the team plays its first game in the fall of 1988. Cunningham's three-year contract with CBS begins this fall. Terms of the pact have not been released.

title: Admission of Ex-Criminal to Illinois Bar Is Blocked
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today barred a former criminal from practicing law, reversing a decision by a bar committee and ignoring recommendations from a law school dean and a Federal judge.

title: An Amtrak Worker Touches Live Wire
description: An electrical technician was critically injured yesterday when he touched a live wire inside a railroad tunnel, an Amtrak spokesman said.

title: Advertising Morris Broadens Horizons
description: MAYBE Morris the Cat has been in therapy. Maybe he is just getting older. But after championing 9-Lives cat food for 17 years, the furry phenomenon has undergone a personality change.

title: Capacity Use in July Up to 80.5%
description: America's factories, mines and utilities operated at 80.5 percent of capacity in July, the fastest pace in 18 months, as manufacturers benefited from higher exports, the Government reported today.

title: Help Wanted: Leaders
description: ''IT becomes harder and harder to believe that we once had a President who, long before coming to office, drafted the Declaration of Independence. And another capable of composing the Gettysburg Address.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said its Boeing Military Airplane Co. had received a $164.2 million contract from the Air Force for equipment to improve KC-135 tanker aircraft. [

title: Vision Chemical Is Found to Absorb Radar
description: AMID concern that Soviet weapon builders may have found a way to detect and track America's supposedly radar-proof Stealth aircraft, a scientist studying the chemistry of vision believes he has hit upon a way to foil Moscow's latest electronic defenses.

title: GROFF INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chilean in Suit Reportedly Home
description: A former Chilean army officer sued for $10 million while participating in the Pan American Games in Indianapolis has returned home, according to a report published today.

title: GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $130,000 for the latest quarter and $95,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: It's, Well, HyperCard
description: IN 1983, Bill Atkinson introduced his MacPaint program for the Apple Macintosh, and it forever changed the way people think about personal computers. Here he goes again. At the Macworld Expo here last week, Mr. Atkinson unveiled HyperCard. It is software for the Apple Macintosh, but beyond that no one is quite sure what to call it. Almost everyone who saw the program being demonstrated here agreed, however, that it was astonishing, and the word ''revolutionary'' was heard quite a bit.

title: Leonard's Next Round
description: Citing ''a natural progression,'' Sugar Ray Leonard said yesterday that with his fighting career definitely finished after his victory over Marvin Hagler in April, he would move on to a new role in boxing.

title: Brain at Work Revealed Through New Imagery
description: SCIENTISTS are beginning to decipher the extremely faint magnetic fields that envelop the human brain, generated by the flickering electrical currents of mental processing.

title: Marine's Defense Finds Omission in Evidence
description: The defense in the spying court-martial of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree drew a concession from a Government interrogator today that the interrogator had omitted from a written confession of spying by the marine his statement that he ''loved his country.''

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid July 15.

title: All Whom TV Deems Quotable
description: In the lexicon of Joe S. Foote, a researcher on the press and politics, members of Congress come in three basic species defined by how much television coverage they receive: the Anointed Ones, the Surfers and the Untouchables.

title: London Board Trading Study
description: The London Stock Exchange has set up a committee to investigate allegations that equity market makers refused to trade shares one day earlier this month when stock prices suffered a record drop, a source said today.

title: K Mart Profit Rises by 22.5%
description: The K Mart Corporation said today that its net income rose by 22.5 percent in the second quarter, with the jump attributed to higher sales that in turn were spurred by increased promotional advertising.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: South Street Theater

title: Decision Eases Rule Setting Wage Floor on U.S. Projects
description: In a ruling that will affect thousands of communities across the country, the Justice Department has narrowed the requirement that contractors pay prevailing wages when they work on community development projects assisted with Federal funds.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JIG. By Campbell Armstrong. 495 pages.

title: 1,500 Mourn Slain Leader Of Custodians
description: More than 1,500 school officials, union members and friends filed into St. Ephrem's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn yesterday to pay their respects to Daniel F. Conlin, the head of the school custodians' union who was shot to death last Wednesday in front of his home.

title: Stage: 2 Eichelberger 'Classics'
description: LONG before he made his legitimate - so to speak - debut in ''The Comedy of Errors'' at Lincoln Center, Ethyl Eichelberger was celebrated in downtown experimental-theater circles for his chamber-size epics and his performances in Charles Ludlam plays at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company. This actor, author and director has in fact been deviously reinventing the classics in his own image.

title: U.S. Said to Back AIDS Vaccine Test on Humans
description: A Connecticut company has become the first to win approval by the Food and Drug Administration for limited testing of a potential AIDS vaccine on humans, according to published reports.

title: U.S. Crude Falls Below $20 a Barrel
description: Prices of the leading American crude oil dropped sharply yesterday, falling below $20 a barrel for the first time in two months. The market, oil analysts said, is now intent on eroding the high prices of early this summer.

title: Philips Offers $50 a Share for the Rest of U.S. Unit
description: Philips N.V., the giant Dutch electronics company, said yesterday that it plans to acquire all the remaining shares of its United States subsidiary, the North American Philips Corporation, through a tender offer valued at $600 million.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
On a Summer Night
description: The air was balmy and the sky was clear. Except for the hungry mosquitoes, the evening was perfect for a dinner dance under a tent. So the women dolled themselves up in their prettiest dresses to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Boys Harbor, the camp for disadvantaged children that Anthony Drexel Duke founded when he was still a schoolboy.

title: Advertising; Lorimar Publishing Bought by President
description: Donald E. Welch, 43 years old, who has been president of the Lorimar Publishing Group during the last five years, announced yesterday that he would be acquiring the children's publishing group from Lorimar Telepictures for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Ulster Doctors Learn to Deal With the Victims of Violence
description: Sean McCartan, 19 years old and outspoken, was at a drinking club on Springfield Road one lively weekend night when masked gunmen arrived, dragged him onto the stage, announced he would be executed and took him into the lavatory, where the explosion of two gunshots could be heard by the frightened crowd.

title: Molitor's Bunt Stretches Hit Streak to 32 Games
description: Paul Molitor extended his hitting streak to 32 games, the longest in the American League in 38 years, with a third-inning bunt single and also walked and scored in the first inning as the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Cleveland Indians, 5-3, tonight.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
At the Fringe in Edinburgh, Theater in Crypt and Streets
description: The Fringe, the freewheeling sideshow to Edinburgh's traditional arts festival, has drawn 1,000 plays to Scotland, from speeded-up Shakespeare to a work set in one of the city's laundry rooms.

title: How to Keep a Barn Down on the Farm
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCIAL NEW NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Martin: Farewell to Ambiguity
description: An era, of sorts, is drawing to a close. At the end of this week, David H. Martin will pack up his law books and framed photographs and bid farewell to his staff at the Office of Government Ethics.

title: Neptune Rendezvous
description: LAUNCHED 10 years ago this Thursday, the Voyager 2 spacecraft has visited the three largest planets, discovered new moons and planetary rings and observed the first active volcano beyond Earth. And still it cruises on, more than two billion miles from Earth, heading for a rendezvous in two years with the planet Neptune.

title: GLENEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $3,564,408 from credits and the sale of treasury shares by subsidiary Hal Roach Studios. c-Net loss The company said its prior year loss was primarily attributable to a writedown in carrying value of U.S. oil and gas properties. The company recently changed its name from International HRS Industries.

title: EL POLLO ASADO CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 20
description: b-Net income

title: 2 Businessmen Seized In Refrigerator Thefts
description: Two company executives were arrested last night and charged in connection with the theft of industrial refrigerators worth $175,000 from a Hunts Point warehouse a week ago, the police said.

title: Foreign Aid at the Grass Roots Can Still Work
description: To the Editor:

title: DONOVAN HAVING FUN SHOOTING FOR THE GOLD
description: Anne Donovan had spent most of the morning talking basketball and discussing the United States women's Pan American team. When she began talking about the fun she had been having during the games, someone asked about the comment she made after helping the Americans win the 1984 Olympic gold medal.

title: Panel Urges Lunar Station as Step to Mars
description: The United States should avoid a spectacular ''race to Mars'' and instead establish an outpost on the Moon as part of a measured exploration of the solar system, a study team headed by the astronaut Sally K. Ride said today.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Partial List Of Casualties Of Flight 255
description: Following is a partial list, compiled by The Associated Press, of crew members and passengers aboard Flight 255 who were killed or injured. Northwest Airlines yesterday released the names of the crew and three-off duty employees who were killed aboard the plane. However, the airline will not release a passenger list in order to protect the privacy of the victims' families. Crew MAUS, John R., 57 years old, Las Vegas, Nev., the captain. DODDS, David J., 35, Galena, Ill., first officer. KAHLE, Michael L., 34, LeSeuer, Minn., flight attendant. RADEMACHER, Roberta E., 35, Eagan, Minn., flight attendant. ELFERING, Bruce R., 23, Eagan., flight attendant. SPARKS-SHAFFER, Pamela D., Chandler, Ariz., flight attendant. Passengers BARBERIO, Paul, 24, Lansing. BLAKELY, William C., 41, Phoenix. BRANTLEY, Herbert, 26, Phoenix. BURNETT, James R., 64, Okemos, Mich. CICHAN, Michael, 32, Tempe, Ariz. CICHAN, Paula, 33, Tempe. CICHAN, David, 6, Tempe. COOK, Jerome D., 48, Phoenix, off-duty Northwest captain. DAVIS, Judy, age not available, Phoenix. ENGLERT, Charles, 27, Tucson, Ariz. ENGLERT, Karen, 28, Tucson. ENGLERT, Charles Jr., 14 months, Tucson. GEIGER, Robert, 39, Phoenix. GEIGER, Emily, 13, Phoenix. GEIGER, Elizabeth, 7, Phoenix. HALE, Craig, age not available, Peoria, Ariz. HALE, Kimberly, age not available, Peoria. JOHNSON, Marshall, 31, Phoenix. KAROW, Barbara, 39, Phoenix. KEENER, Justin, 12, hometown not available. MORRIS, Suzanne, 35, Federal Way, Wash., off-duty Northwest flight attendant. PEACOCK, Michael M., 39, Phoenix. RATLIFF, Hidi, 16, Santa Ana, Calif. ROSS, John J., age not available, Phoenix. ROUNDY, Melvin C. Roundy, 53, Mesa, Ariz., off-duty Northwest captain. TALLARICO, Pat, 24, Lansing. VANOS, Nick, 24, center for the Phoenix Suns basketball team. ZIGLER, Phyllis A., 32, Buffalo. Injured CICHAN, Cecilia, 4, Tempe, in critical conditon with a broken leg and collarbone and third-degree burns over 30 percent of her body. FAVIO, Lawrence, 30, Lincoln Park, Mich., in critical condition with burns over 39 percent of his body. GERSES, Elizabeth, 65, Minneapolis, treated and released for minor skin irritation. GOSSELL, Nancy, 34, of Indianapolis, treated released for minor injuries. MODLIN, Barbara, 32, New Hope, Minn., treated and released for minor skin irritation.

title: Market Place; New Optimism On Fast Food
description: SOME of the smaller fast-food companies are beginning to attract the attention of analysts, who are predicting higher earnings. That is a signal that the entire group - after languishing in the doldrums for more than two years - might be on the brink of a turnaround.

title: Jets' New Fullback Is Earning the Title
description: Roger Vick, the impressive rookie from Texas A&M, does not regard himself as the Jets' first-string fullback, but he is the exception.

title: Our Towns; Pine Valley Call: No Taxation Without Repairs
description: Living in Southampton is nothing if Southampton hardly knows you exist. When you live 25 miles and a toll call from Town Hall. When you shop in downtown Riverhead, just across the Peconic River here, and send your kids to Riverhead schools. When you receive your mail at a Riverhead address and dial each other on Riverhead telephone prefixes.

title: Confession Report in 7 Deaths
description: An unemployed handyman has confessed to killing seven women whose remains were found at his Philadelphia apartment house, the police said today.

title: U.S. Culture Impresario Is Leaving Moscow
description: Continuing a long season of caviar-and-vodka leave-takings at the United States Embassy, Raymond E. Benson has stepped down from his post monitoring the frontier where Soviet culture and politics meet.

title: INAMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Fighting Words Are Bowe's Trademark
description: Riddick Bowe, he made a promise as a kid that he would do what Ali did; Remember, Riddick, remember too now that your dreams come true. Working hard and being smart is the way to really start; Being honest and being cool, not acting like a stupid fool; Those are the things to keep in mind and being champ is what I'll find.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do some people stutter?

title: Water Shortage Strikes Cuba
description: Some residents of Cuba's capital are getting water only a few days a week because of sparse rainfall, the press reported today. Inadequate rainfall in the last four years has caused serious shortages throughout Cuba.

title: Man Foots Bill for Class Cruise
description: Laden with souvenirs and memories, nearly 200 members of a Pennsylvania high school class headed home today from a 35th-year reunion cruise to the Bahamas courtesy of a classmate who made it big.

title: U.S. Predicts Deficit to Decrease for Next 5 Years
description: The Reagan Administration projected today that the nation's budget deficit would decrease this year to $158.4 billion, down from the record $220.7 billion in 1986, partly because of an unanticipated tax windfall.

title: GOULDS PUMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dow Climbs 15.14 to Pass 2,700 Mark
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,700 yesterday for the first time, helped by a late-afternoon surge.

title: Surgeons Who Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 18, 1987
description: International

title: Chrysler Pricing Plans
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that in some cases it would keep prices steady on its 1988 model domestic cars and in other cases raise them by as much as 5 percent. The decision is tentative, it said, while it completes its pricing strategy. The company said it would not be able to provide an average price increase until all models were introduced in September.

title: Dallas Treads Painfully Toward Opening Kennedy Assassination Exhibit
description: Amid continuing controversy, this city is moving toward opening to the public its most infamous space: the sixth-floor nest from which Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots that killed President Kennedy.

title: MULTI-LOCAL MEDIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings figures are unavailable; the company, which went public in June, was previously a limited partnership.

title: Workers Seize Hyundai Plants In South Korea
description: More than 20,000 workers occupied factory buildings and a shipyard operated by the Hyundai group, the nation's largest conglomerate, in an industrial dispute in Ulsan today.

title: Bird Charges Dismissed
description: A charge of terroristic threatening against the Boston Celtics' Larry Bird stemming from a dispute involving members of his family was dismissed yesterday in Louisville. Judge Charles Anderson said he dismissed the charges against Bird; his brother, Mark Bird, and his sister, Linda Campbell, because the prosecuting witness, Benjamin Campbell, had advised the county attorney's office he wanted to drop the court case. The Campbells were in the process of obtaining a divorce when the warrants were issued earlier this month. Campbell had charged that the three made threats against him by telephone last month.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Eliot Russman has joined Siegel & Gale, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., as senior vice president, advertising account group director.

title: Grand Jurors Open Inquiry on PTL Ministry
description: A Federal grand jury today began investigating whether Jim and Tammy Bakker and their former top associates should be charged with crimes connected with the PTL television ministry.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, AUGUST 18, 1987
description: International A3-12

title: Parcells Likes Most Of What He Sees
description: Though the Giants won their preseason opener Sunday, Coach Bill Parcells stayed in character today. After he watched a tape of the game, he found a few things that pleased him and a few that did not.

title: Edward Weston Show
description: A retrospective of works by the American photographer Edward Weston is to begin Sept. 11 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. More than 100 photographs, including landscapes, figure studies and still lifes, are to be featured in the show, which runs through Oct. 31. The exhibition, organized by the Center for Creative Photography of the University of Arizona, will then travel to other museums around the country. Information: 879-5500.

title: Hospital Officials Asked About Trash on Beaches
description: New Jersey officials questioned administrators at two hospitals yesterday, including one in New York City, as they tried to trace the origin of medical waste that washed onto some of the state's most popular beaches last week from a 50-mile-long garbage slick in the Atlantic.

title: Stevenson May Return
description: The weight class that Teofilo Stevenson of Cuba once dominated in the boxing competition at the Pan American Games is now occupied by Felix Savon, an imposing 19-year-old heavyweight, but a return by Stevenson has apparently not been ruled out. ''This is a decision that has not been decided,'' Alcides Sagarra, the Cuban coach, said through an interpreter. Stevenson, the 36-year-old three-time Olympic and world amateur champion, has not retired from the sport, according to his national coach. The coach did confirm that Stevenson is awaiting a trial on charges that resulted from a death in a traffic accident. He said that Stevenson had not been imprisoned.

title: FAIR, ISAAC & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Inquiry Finds Engine Blast or Fire Didn't Cause Crash
description: An examination of the two engines of a Northwest Airlines jetliner that crashed here shortly after takeoff Sunday, killing at least 152 people, found no evidence of an explosion or of a fire before the impact, investigators said tonight.

title: It Wasn't Firemen's Actions That Cost Lives at Schomburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Hicks & Haas To Buy Palco
description: Hicks & Haas, a Dallas-based investment firm, said it had agreed to buy Palco Industries from a unit of the Maxxam Group for more than $300 million. The deal is expected to be completed in early September. Palco, a division of the MXM

title: Pilkington to Buy Revlon Unit
description: Pilkington Brothers, a British glass maker that has steadily expanded its presence in the market for corrective lenses, has agreed to buy the Vision Care business of the Revlon Group Inc. for $574 million, the companies announced yesterday.

title: MORE MISERY FOR THE ELDERLY
description: LEAD: The House of Representatives was widely praised last month when it passed a bill that would provide relief under Medicare - the program for the elderly and the disabled - for catastrophic-illness costs. But barely noticed in the bill were regressive and mean-spirited changes in the way Medicaid - the health program for the poor and the medically needy -would pay for nursing home care.

title: Politics and Marriage
description: A chance hazard of running for President is that the marriage of a contender's daughter during the campaign may attract a lot of uninvited guests to the wedding. None of these guests are likely to be bringing presents, but a lot of them are likely to be bringing microphones, cameras and thirsts.

title: Colorado Tabloid Keeps Eye on Environment
description: What began 17 years ago as the printed instrument of one rancher denouncing strip mining, timber harvesting and oil drilling remains an important environmental voice for the Rockies, although the newspaper, The High Country News, is now run by committee.

title: Anjelica Huston to Star In Drama Off Broadway
description: Anjelica Huston will play the title role in ''Tamara,'' an environmental drama by John Krizanc, set in Italy during the rule of Mussolini. The play is scheduled to open in late October at the Seventh Regiment Armory, on Park Avenue at 66th Street. Ms. Huston has been signed for three months, according to Moses Znaimer, the producer.

title: Pressure Increases On Rail Company
description: An investment group led by Howard Kaskel, a New York real estate developer, sought clearance yesterday from the Securities and Exchange Commission to increase its stake in Kansas City Southern Industries from 7.9 percent to at least 50 percent.

title: Todd Shipyards Files For Chapter 11 Status
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation, struggling against steep losses, cost overruns and an unwanted offer for its only profitable business, said yesterday that it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for 13wks to July 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $200,000 and $500,000 for the 13 weeks and 26 weeks, respectively.

title: Black Group Backs Regent for Schools Chief
description: An organization of black educators yesterday called for the appointment of a black Board of Regents member as the new Schools Chancellor in New York City.

title: Darker Side to Franklin Is Reported
description: In his writings and public pronouncements, Benjamin Franklin comes across as witty, wise and, above all, optimistic. To this day, his brilliance as an inventor, politician, scientist and diplomat is overshadowed by his upbeat maxims and bromides - his reassurance that ''God helps them that help themselves'' and his counsel to ''Hear no ill of a Friend, nor speak any of an Enemy.''

title: KEY RATES
Loss by Xebec Tied to I.B.M.
description: Stung by the loss of a major contract with the International Business Machines Corporation, the Xebec Corporation today reported a big third-quarter loss. Xebec, which is based in Carson City, Nev., has been best known as the producer of the hard-disk-drive controller used in the now-discontinued I.B.M. PC-XT personal computer. For the quarter ended July 3, Xebec lost $33.9 million, in contrast to earnings of $25,000 a year ago. Revenues plunged 66 percent, to $10.3 million, from $29.9 million. I.B.M. sales have represented about half of Xebec's revenues for four and a half years.

title: Population Trend Is Reversed
description: New York State reversed a decade-long loss of population during the first half of the 1980's and is losing fewer educated and skilled workers to other states, a business lobbying and research group, the Public Policy Institute, reported today.

title: KILLER OF DIPLOMAT'S SON IS GIVEN PRISON TERM
description: A man convicted of killing a diplomat's son who had gone to the aid of two robbery victims was sentenced yesterday to 21 years to life in prison.

title: Big Public Pension Fund Indexing Bond Portfolio
description: The California State Teachers' Retirement System, the fifth-largest public pension fund in the country, yesterday announced plans for a change in how it manages its $7 billion portfolio of debt securities.

title: HEITAGE ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax credit of $94,000.

title: 2 Flight Attendants' Unions Announce Merger Agreement
description: The nation's two largest unions of airline flight attendants announced today that they had tentatively agreed to merge with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Not Guilty Plea Made In Parkway Shooting
description: A retired investment banker pleaded not guilty to attempted murder yesterday in the shooting of a teen-ager after a dispute on the Hutchinson River Parkway.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: New School Cooking

title: Dollar Drops Sharply In Early Tokyo Trading
description: The dollar continued to take a beating early today.

title: NEW YORK G.M. PLANT HONORS 5 ABOARD PLANE
description: Flags flew at half-staff today outside a plant of the General Motors Corporation in tribute to five engineers killed Sunday in the jetliner crash in Detroit.

title: Waiting for the Cook
description: To The Living Section:

title: SAVINGS SUGGESTED ON BYPASS SURGERY
description: The Federal Government could get the best treatment for heart bypass patients receiving Medicare and in doing so save nearly $200 million a year by sending them to selected surgical centers, a Federal report said today.

title: Concern Rises Over Steroids
description: American athletes are engaged in one of the largest, most haphazard and questionable medical experiments in modern times - the illicit use of drugs to improve their bodies and their performances.

title: COMTREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: San Francisco Vote Advances Proposal For Battleship Port
description: The city today moved one step closer to making San Francisco Bay the home port of the battleship U.S.S. Missouri and its 10 support vessels.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: ENDOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEW YORK, FACING AID CUTS, SAYS SHELTER NEED WILL RISE
description: New York City officials, facing the possibility of sharp cuts in Federal financing for sheltering homeless families, said yesterday that they saw no way to reduce the need for emergency housing over the next five years.

title: People
description: * Roderick C. Evans and Bruce Weinreb have joined McNamara, Clapp & Klein as executive vice president and director of client services, and senior vice president, respectively.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wollman Rink Pipe Suffered Minor Leak
description: A minor leak was found in June in the plastic pipes at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink, the New York City Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, said yesterday.

title: Bartow, Citing Flu, Resigns as Coach
description: Gene Bartow, the basketball coach at Alabama-Birmingham, resigned today as head coach of the Puerto Rican men's team at the Pan American Games for what he said were health reasons.

title: Ford Offering Truck Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company is offering financial incentives on two lines of light trucks in response to competition. On Friday, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation offered incentives on some light-truck models. The three companies' programs expire at the end of September.

title: 'SNOW WHITE' STIRS MEMORY AND FEMINIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Auld Lang August
description: So far in the news we have had Marilyn Monroe, Elvis Presley and the Titanic, the news being that: 1. Marilyn Monroe has been dead 25 years; 2. Elvis Presley has been dead 10 years, and 3. The Titanic, dead for 75 years, may yield up a safe, which may be opened on television, which is only half dead.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,498,000.

title: How to House the Homeless, and Where
description: It's the latest illustration of Nimby - ''not in my backyard.'' For two long days, hundreds of New Yorkers have sat in the Board of Estimate chamber waiting to express their fear of 15 temporary shelters proposed for the homeless. That these citizens are still afraid reflects the failure of their elected representatives to stand up and support what they know to be true:

title: Pilot for Eastern and His Son Killed in Private Plane Crash
description: An Eastern Airlines pilot and his son died when their single-engine private plane apparently stalled and crashed into trees late Monday, officials said today.

title: Film: 'Where the Heart Roams,' About Romance Novelists
description: AT its best, there's something sad and, one might even venture to say, ineffable about George Paul Csicsery's ''Where the Heart Roams,'' a good, informative documentary-feature about romance novels, the women who write and edit them and the women who, by buying and reading them, have turned paperback junk into a $300 million-a-year industry.

title: Jack-Up Project Saves Sinking North Sea Rigs
description: Engineers in Norway's Ekofisk oilfield today completed the last delicate phase of a $600 million operation to raise sinking oil rigs. Six huge platform decks, perched on steel legs driven into the North Sea floor, have been jacked up by 18 feet.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: AUG. 19, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 2 BILLS TO STOP DOG ATTACKS DEBATED
description: Banning pit bulls, as Mayor Koch proposed Monday, is not an effective way to prevent attacks by dogs and would be impossible to enforce, most speakers told a panel of Republican assemblymen yesterday at a hearing on similar statewide proposals.

title: ALLIANCE TIRE & RUBBER CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars; convenience translation into U.S. dollars at the rate of exchange on March 31, 1987, $1 equals 0.62 New Israeli Shekels.

title: Bridge: British Women's Low Finish Was Big Suprise in Brighton
description: A major surprise in the European Women's Team Championship, which ended Friday in Brighton, England, was the relative failure of the British. Their team included four reigning world champions, but they could only finish third, behind France and Italy, and will not have an opportunity to defend their world title in Jamaica in October.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Boston dispatch on Aug. 8 about salvage rights in international waters miscalculated the value of gold reported aboard the vessel Central America. The gold, estimated at $1,219,000 when the ship sank in 1857, would today be worth about $634.8 million, or nearly 521 times the original assessment. The calculation is based on the difference between the price of gold on the New York market the day the article was written, $468.70 an ounce, and the price at the time of the ship's sinking, 90 cents an ounce.

title: LANDS'S END reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split approved for stock of record Aug. 14; the stock split is to be paid Sept. 1.

title: 15% of Bennett Estate AIDS Groups
description: Michael Bennett, the choreographer and director who died on July 2 of lymphoma as a result of AIDS, bequeathed 15 percent of his estate to organizations ''which are involved in the research of or the cure or treatment of patients afflicted with the disease known as AIDS or Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome,'' according to his will, which was filed in Tucson, Ariz., this month.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Iranian carpet market is not good. The revolution, for carpets, was not good.'' - Mohammed, a Teheran rug merchant. [ A1:5. ]

title: SANDWICH CO-OPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The bank converted to a stock company from a mutual organization in July 1986.

title: Park Place Group Plans A Campaign on AIDS
description: Bette Klegon, president and creative director of the decade-old Park Place Group Advertising, has devoted eight months, along with her partner, Gary Halby, the agency's chairman, to a pro bono celebrity campaign against AIDS, which is scheduled to begin on Sept. 14. About 100 billboards around New York City, as well as several newspapers and magazines, will carry ads displaying a photograph of one of about 30 celebrities with the headline ''Don't Die of Embarrassment.'' The ads will give the telephone number for the AIDS hot line.

title: Amateur Leads Met Open
description: A 22-year-old amateur who plays for the Old Dominion University golf team took a three-stroke lead today in the first round of the 72d Met Open.

title: TV Review; 'FIRST AND 10,' HBO FOOTBALL SITCOM
description: HOME BOX OFFICE, the pay-cable service, is plunging ahead with its football sitcom called ''First and Ten.'' Timed to coincide with the regular football season, from summer training to winter championship bowls, the saga of the California Bulls got under way in 1985, returned last year for a trek to the championship game in January and now is being continued in ''First and 10: Going for Broke,'' which for the time being can be seen Wednesdays on HBO at 10 P.M. The final fictional episode is being timed to unfold with next January's real-life Super Bowl.

title: Parcells Frets as Nelson Yields to Injury
description: Apart from a barrage of news media requests befitting the reigning Super Bowl champions, this summer has been a light one for Bill Parcells, the coach of the Giants. He has been relaxed, suntanned and even expansive.

title: About New York; Guiding Hands: Teaching Adults How to Read
description: Ernest McNeill's lips move faintly as his index finger tracks the words of the simple text: ''Ann Smith works in a dress shop. The dress shop is in the city. The dress shop is in a big building.''

title: Bork's Nomination Opposed By the Women's Law Center
description: The National Women's Law Center today announced its opposition to President Reagan's nomination of Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, calling Judge Bork's views ''a clear and present danger to the principles of equality.''

title: TEJON RANCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins have signed two left wings, Randy Cunneyworth and Bob Errey, to multiyear contracts. Terms were not disclosed. Cunneyworth had 26 goals and 17 assists in 79 games, including 5 game-winning goals. Errey had 16 goals and 18 assists. . . . The Nets named John Mertz as their coordinator of public relations and Brian Ricco as assistant director of public relations. Mertz replaced Jim Lampariello, who was recently named a vice president with the club.

title: BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $22,407,000 for certain development costs. c-Net income Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid on July 24.

title: IMATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest periods' results include charges for lease termination and retrofit costs of $1.1 million for the quarter and $1.5 million for the 6 months.

title: Right Move for the Indian Museum
description: Mayor Koch of New York and Senator Alfonse D'Amato have finally agreed to back Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in providing the Museum of the American Indian with the perfect new home, the old United States Custom House at Bowling Green in lower Manhattan. This welcome reversal now puts the museum's trustees on the spot.

title: Trading in Hill Samuel Halts
description: Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., a leading British merchant bank and financial services firm, asked today that trading in its shares be temporarily suspended on the London Stock Exchange amid signs that it would accept a takeover bid from a Swiss bank.

title: SHAYS BEATS DEMOCRAT FOR FAIRFIELD HOUSE SEAT
description: In a special election marked by a surprisingly high voter turnout, Christopher H. Shays, a Republican, soundly defeated Christine M. Niedermeier, a Democrat, today to complete the House term of Stewart B. McKinney, who died three months ago.

title: St. Tropez Journal; Tourist Throngs Overshadow a Place in the Sun
description: A horrified Brigitte Bardot has fled to a secluded villa in the parched hills above this fishing village she made famous.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Addendum
description: * Newmark, Posner & Mitchell, a real estate, financial and recruiting agency, will be opening an office in Coral Gables, Fla.

title: Iranian Vessels Said to Fire on Chemical Tanker
description: Two Iranian patrol boats fired at a Liberian-registered chemical tanker today just outside the Persian Gulf, smashing a porthole with a bullet, shipping officials reported.

title: Pagliarulo Homer Salvages Yankees
description: The Yankees' eight-game trip looked bleak even before it started, but Mike Pagliarulo delivered them from trouble in the first game tonight. The third baseman hit a home run leading off the ninth inning, and it took the Yankees to a 4-3 victory over the Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome.

title: Thrift Official Plans to Resign
description: The Commissioner of the Texas Savings and Loan Department, L. Linton Bowman 3d, has disclosed plans to resign at the end of the year. No reason was given.

title: A Louisiana Chef Spreads His Gospel Of Cajun-Creole Food
description: THE cooking of Cajun and Creole food is not the carved-in-granite affair that most people presume it to be, according to John Folse, one of America's foremost Cajun-Creole chefs. Yes, there are dishes - like jambalaya, gumbo and shrimp creole - that are the foundation on which the cuisine is built. But even these foods can be transformed while retaining their bayou-country character.

title: The Pop Life
description: Bossa Nova Redux

title: BROUGHER INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $352,029 from an offering of common stock of a subsidiary.

title: No Fraud Was Found In Cholesterol Report
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HERSELF IN LOVE. By Marianne Wiggins. 184 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: Tenneco Automotive Moves to Thompson
description: Tenneco Automotive consolidated its worldwide advertising budget of $48 million at J. Walter Thompson of Detroit. The account was formerly handled by the New York and Toronto offices of SSC&B:Lintas.

title: PACAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $13.6 million for the estimated loss on the disposal of certain operations for both the quarter and 6 months; and the 6-month also is after a charge of $10.4 million in the first quarter. c-Net income

title: DIRECT PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results in the latest periods include a charge of $80,000 for an addition to the company's reserve for bad debt expenses.

title: New York Officials Shifting Blame In Struggle to Combat Corruption
description: As corruption cases mount throughout New York State, officials are unable to agree on what needs to be done about dishonesty in government and are caught up in a scramble to blame one another for the problem.

title: LEISURE CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAGIC YEARS CHILD CARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kenner Toys Seeks Alternatives to Bid
description: Kenner Parker Toys Inc., urging its shareholders to reject a $41-a-share tender offer by New World Entertainment Ltd., said today that it was exploring a management buyout and other alternatives.

title: Off Canada, The Hippies Are Evolving
description: David Phillips will be offering a host of ideas for future development when he runs for mayor later this year in this town of 1,500 people, one of only two incorporated communities on the Queen Charlotte Islands off Canada's northwest coast.

title: MICRO HEALTHSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: IIS INTELLIGENT INFORMAION SYSTEMS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. The results are translated from Israeli Shekels at the June 30, 1987 exchange rate of 1.607 Shekels per dollar.

title: CONTRA AID A KEY, U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The Reagan Administration has decided that a regional peace plan for Central America cannot work unless the United States provides long-term support for the rebels in Nicaragua, perhaps even months after a cease-fire, a senior official said today.

title: Court Says Massachusetts Welfare Must Give Enough to Live at Home
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today that the state must provide welfare families enough benefits to allow them to live in their own homes.

title: Citicorp Sale Of New Stock
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it would seek to rebuild its capital base by selling 17 million new common shares next month. The banking company also said it would split its stock after the share offering.

title: Where Growth Is King, a Move to Rein It In
description: If any place stands for the right of people to do what they want with their property, it is Orange County, the wealthy territory south of Los Angeles that has boomed over a matter of decades from lush ranchland into the fifth most densely populated metropolitan area in the United States.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Belfast dispatch yesterday about medical advances arising from the violence in Northern Ireland misstated the number of counties there. It is six.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects the continued impact of downturn in energy industry, including the adverse impact of natural gas production and prices. Year-ago 9-month loss was primarily attributable to a writedown of about $58.5 million of oil and gas assets.

title: Bulgaria Revamps Government and Economy
description: Bulgaria adopted broad economic and political changes today, drastically reorganizing the Government and regional administration and paving the way for changes in the Constitution.

title: Financing for BankAmerica
description: Japanese banks appear to be closer to giving the BankAmerica Corporation a major infusion of new capital.

title: KEY RATES
MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $5,755,000 and a gain of $25,711,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: ARYT OPTRONICS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gooden Pitches 7 Stout Innings
description: No, the Mets didn't score 23 runs again last night, the way they did Sunday in Chicago. But then, they didn't have to.

title: Bell Homer Helps Blue Jays Retain First
description: George Bell hit a two-run homer with two outs in the eighth inning and Dave Stieb pitched a three-hitter for eight innings as the Toronto Blue Jays stayed in first in the American League East with a 2-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics tonight.

title: Ameritrust Plans Stock Repurchase
description: The Ameritrust Corporation will repurchase as many as 4 million shares of its stock owned by Alfred Lerner's Clevebaco Limited Partnership at a cost of up to $112 million, the company said. Clevebaco stands to make between $30 million and $58 million on the deal.

title: LORI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a reversal of tax credit of $802,000. c-Net income d-Includes reversal of tax credits of $114,000 and $992,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Chairman of ADT In Role of Defender
description: Raymond B. Carey Jr., president and chairman of ADT Inc., disagrees vehemently with analysts and others who characterize his company's financial performance as lackluster.

title: Anxiety in Mexico: Elections Are Near
description: Mexican businessmen, bankers, economists and investors are glancing nervously at their calendars these days. The ''Year of Hidalgo,'' with all its attendant dangers and potential for economic disaster, has come around again.

title: Bank Increases Reserve
description: The Bank of Montreal said it will increase its reserves for possible losses from Third World loans, a decision that will result in a third-quarter charge of $753 million Canadian, or $565 million United States. The bank increased its reserves to 35 percent of the $6 billion Canadian in Third World loans, from 15 percent. The bank did not expect the move to affect its dividend.

title: The Naughty Folies
description: To The Living Section:

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances;
Auto Industry Is Now Using Bar Codes
description: LEAD: THE bar codes designed to hurry groceries through checkout lanes are now being applied to parts on the automobile assembly line, allowing auto makers and suppliers to cut costs by managing their inventories more tightly.

title: Why Should the Public Care About the Contras?
description: To the Editor:

title: Any Way You Cut It, Ice Adds Sparkle to Life
description: LEAD: ICE. Hard, clear and cold, as benign as cubes in a glass or as awesome as the glacier that gouged out the Hudson Valley. Appreciate ice by imagining its absence from our lives: no ice cascading from refrigerator doors on demand, no huge tumblers full of ice moistened with soda dispensed by fast-food restaurants.

title: Salomon Sets Hiring Freeze
description: Salomon Brothers has instituted a hiring freeze, fearing that the staff's rate of growth, which has already been cut this year more than 50 percent from 1986, may still be too fast, company officials said yesterday.

title: CODENOLL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Emigre Pianist In U.S.
description: Vladimir Feltsman, the celebrated pianist who had been refused permission to leave the Soviet Union since he asked to emigrate in 1979, arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday afternoon with his wife, Anna, and their 4-year-old son, Daniel. After hugging and greeting relatives and supporters, Mr. Feltsman said, ''We have never been in your great country but already love it.''

title: WAKE UP! AND READ THIS
description: Conventional wisdom has it that officials flee the capital when the steamy month of August rolls around. Congress goes on vacation, the Supreme Court is in recess, and the President heads for his getaway, be it Key West, Gettysburg, Hyannis, San Clemente, Plains or a ranch in Texas or California.

title: Oil Prices Hold Steady, But Further Fall Is Seen
description: Reacting against Monday's sharp declines, petroleum prices essentially held firm yesterday in cautious trading. But most oil analysts said they expected further declines because fundamental factors overshadow, for the moment at least, concerns about the tension in the Persian Gulf.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the increase in earnings for the first quarter resulted primarily from the increased volume of sugar sales and the inclusion of the results of the Union Sugar division, which was acquired June 29, 1986.

title: General Foods to Reorganize
description: The General Foods Corporation, a part of the Philip Morris Companies, said yesterday that it would eliminate most of its corporate staff and create separate operating companies to run its three lines of business.

title: PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $140,000,000 provision for the cost of relocating headquarters. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $11,000,000 and $35,000,000 from debt restructure for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: ISRAELIS EXPECTING SOVIET CONTACTS
description: Israel and the Soviet Union have agreed to set up regular political contacts, Israeli officials said today, describing it as a possible step toward renewing diplomatic ties broken 20 years ago.

title: 45.91 Drop Puts Dow At 2,654.66
description: A plunge in the dollar and falling bond prices sent stock prices plummeting yesterday from their newly won records.

title: Travel Eye Ends Caledonian Bid
description: A small travel company said it had abandoned a $:237 million offer for British Caledonian Group P.L.C., which previously agreed to be purchased by British Airways P.L.C. for the same amount. The company, Travel Eye Ltd., said that it had withdrawn its offer for its own business reasons. The company had announced its offer, which was for the equivalent of $380 million, last Thursday.

title: 1,600 Lose Jobs in Yugoslavia
description: About 1,600 construction workers lost their jobs today as Yugoslavia declared the first casualty of a tough new bankruptcy law aimed at rooting out money-losing companies.

title: Performance by a Loquacious King
description: This wasn't simply a news conference announcing yet another world's heavyweight championship fight - in this case, Tyson-Biggs - this was a Donald King news conference, with a dais of about 20 straight men, all with the astonishing ability to stay awake, as neologisms, solecisms, hyperboles and references, half-references and tortured literary, historical and biblical allusions from John Paul Jones to the Bard of Avon were flung about by King at a dizzying rate.

title: Syria Delivers American Who Fled Beirut Captors
description: An American journalist who got away from his kidnappers on the outskirts of Beirut was turned over to United States officials in Syria today.

title: VIOLIN: PINCHAS ZUKERMAN
description: AS he demonstrated during an all-Mozart recital Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Pinchas Zukerman does easily the things other violinists struggle with, but he does so with a nonchalance that suggests indifference. Whole movements at Monday's performance passed without making any distinct impression.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jet Rose Only 150 Feet Before Plunge
description: A Northwest Airlines jet took off at an unusually steep angle and rose only 100 to 150 feet before plunging to the ground at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Sunday, officials said at a news briefing this evening.

title: Burger Disavows Statements Critical of Solicitor General
description: Warren E. Burger, the retired Chief Justice, today denounced as ''flagrantly false and irresponsible'' statements critical of Solicitor General Charles Fried that have been attributed to him.

title: NEW YORK CITY CANCELS CONCRETE PLANT DEAL
description: New York City has canceled its agreement with a concrete company that it helped set up to spur competition in the industry, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: MAYBE it's because I made pickles this week. Until now I had always thought of pickles, like applesauce or ketchup, as something manufactured, not something you made yourself. And then I planted this vegetable garden and wound up with more cucumbers than you can imagine. (Never mind the zucchini. They're too numerous and horrible to mention, like U.F.O.'s growing beneath those enormous spatulate leaves.) So I decided to make pickles: vinegar, sugar, turmeric (whatever that is), mustard and celery seeds, cucumbers. They're good pickles, too.

title: Art Scholar Is Seized For 2d Time in Week In Documents Theft
description: An art historian and portrait painter was arrested today for the second time in a week in connection with what Federal authorities described as one of the largest known thefts of historic American documents.

title: Greek Church Leader Begins Visit to Churches in Russia
description: Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios of the Greek Orthodox Church arrived in the Soviet Union today for a 12-day official visit to Russian Orthodox churches, the first such visit in 400 years.

title: Rates Up a Bit At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose slightly at Citicorp's weekly commercial paper auctions.

title: On Insurance; Don't Alter the McCarran-Ferguson Act

title: Marine Weeps as He Hears of K.G.B. Seductions
description: Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree wept in court today as an expert on operations of the Soviet security police, the K.G.B., described as routine the recruiting methods of the Soviet security agency that precisely matched the marine's own experience.

title: Marathon Trial on Dioxin Spill Nears End in Illinois After 3 1/2 Years
description: No fanfare or flourishes greeted Rex Carr as he strode up to the jury box to begin closing arguments in the sure-to-be legendary trial of Kemner v. Monsanto, a trial that began three and a half years ago here in the St. Clair County Circuit Court.

description: An 11-year-old boy has been charged with the murder of a 37-year-old man who was set afire while asleep in a stairwell, the authorities said.

Grunwald's Delicate Deliberations on Austria

C. Drummond de Andrade, A Brazilian Modernist Poet
description: Carlos Drummond de Andrade, a poet who was a leader of Brazil's modernist movement in literature, died Monday night following a heart attack. He was 85 years old.

title: Senegal's Envoy Surrenders Son's License After Accident
description: Senegal's Ambassador to the United States has surrendered his son's driver's license to the State Department in connection with an accident last week, a spokesman said today.

title: Building Of Housing Rebounds
description: Housing construction edged up nine-tenths of 1 percent in July, the first monthly increase since February and a sign of a market recovery from the sharp jump in mortgage rates in April and May.

title: Chrysler Sees '88 Price Rises
description: The Chrysler Corporation today said the average price of its 1988 cars would not rise more than 1 percent over comparably equipped 1987 cars. Many of the 1988 cars, however, will come with more standard equipment, so the comparison is against 1987 models with options.

title: AIRLINE INSPECTED ALL OF A JET TYPE
description: Northwest Airlines inspected the engines on all its MD-80 jets this summer, including the one that crashed Sunday night in Detroit, in response to a service bulletin from the engine manufacturer, an airline spokesman said yesterday.

Tower Opens a Firm
description: After finishing his commission's investigation of the Iran-contra scandal, and after turning down an offer to head the Central Intelligence Agency, former Senator John G. Tower has joined the crowd of past Government officials with their own lobbying and consulting firms in the capital.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ON this date 54 years ago there were showers in New York City; the temperature ranged from 70 to 83 degrees; The New York Times reported that Eleanor Roosevelt paid a visit to coal miners in Morgantown, W.Va., and that Babe Ruth was bruised on the right ankle in a game with the St. Louis Browns (the Yankees won, 8 to 3). Appearing on stage at the Paramount Theater on Times Square were George Olsen and his orchestra and the singer Ethel Shutta; the on-screen attraction was ''Three-Cornered Moon,'' starring Claudette Colbert, Richard Arlen, Mary Boland and Lyda Roberti. And this, as you will see, brings us to 1987 and Alma Denny.

title: STRATAMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $98,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $98,000.

title: IOle! A 3-Star Restaurant in Madrid
description: JESUS MARIA OYARBIDE, the owner of the restaurant Zalacain in Madrid, was diplomatic. It was difficult, he said, for any restaurant to win three Michelin stars. Benjamin Urdiain, the restaurant's normally self-effacing chef, was more blunt. Zalacain, he said, was at least as good as many French restaurants that already had three stars.

title: Honda to Ford Museum
description: The first Honda car made in the United States has been permanently lent to the Henry Ford Museum, which was founded by the automobile pioneer. Honda officials said that the gray 1983 Accord sedan, built Nov. 1, 1982, at Honda of America's plant in Marysville, Ohio, would be part of the museum's $6 million ''Automobile in American Life'' exhibit. It will be featured as a symbol of the worldwide expansion of the auto industry.

title: WAS TREATED FOR RECORD DOSE
description: Harold R. McCluskey, a chemical technician who suffered what is believed to be the largest human dose of radiation ever recorded when a nuclear contamination accident occurred nearly 11 years ago, died Monday in Puyallup, Wash. He was 75 years old.

title: Ex-Speaker Reports on Spending of Excess Funds
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the retired House Speaker, has spent a good portion of $100,000 in leftover campaign contributions on politics, helping the poor and on dining out, his campaign finance records show.

title: Husband Is Slain by His Wife In Bedroom Gunplay Incident
description: A 25-year-old woman shot and killed her husband while the couple played in bed with what both apparently believed were unloaded pistols, the authorities said today.

title: Aouita Doubtful
description: Said Aouita of Morocco, who holds world records in three long-distance running events, is suffering from an inflamed nerve in his left leg that is virtually certain to force him out of an international track and field meet today in Zurich.

description: To the Editor:

title: Icemen for All Seasons
description: THERE is no rest for the weary, no down time for the King of Cool. Not now, not when we are all clamoring for those eight-pound bags of cold, clear ice to chill our beer cans and worry into snow between our teeth.

description: California man says he and his brother missed Northwest Airlines Flight 255 because their parents' car broke down about 15 miles from the Detroit Metropolitan Airport.

title: LIMITS ON ADS COOLERS
description: THE WINE INSTITUTE, a trade association in San Francisco representing 517 California wineries, has adopted new guidelines for advertising wine coolers. Members' adherence to the principles is voluntary.

title: CHARLES L. SCHREIBER
description: Charles L. Schreiber, founder and former president of Royal Farms Dairy, a chain of grocery stores with headquarters in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Friday. He was 87 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Swimming East German Women Set Relay Mark: East Germany set a world record in the women's 800-meter freestyle relay yesterday, winning the event at the European championships in Strasbourg, France, in 7 minutes 55.47 seconds. The team of Manuela Stellmach, Astrid Strauss, Anke Mohring and Heike Friedrich broke the mark of 7:59.33 set by the East Germans in the 1986 world championships in Madrid. In the men's 200 meters, Anders Holmertz of Sweden upset Michael Gross of West Germany. Holmertz won in 1:48.44. (AP) Tennis McEnroe loses to Annacone: John McEnroe, seeded fifth, lost to Paul Annacone, 7-6, 6-4, last night in the opening round of the Association of Tennis Professionals championship in Mason, Ohio. McEnroe hurt his back at the end of the first set but continued to play. ''It's something I think I can get over in three or four days,'' he said. ''This is my first setback in six weeks, so I'm still optimistic.'' In another upset, sixth-seeded Henri Leconte of France was beaten, 6-3, 7-5, by Jonathan Canter. Stefan Edberg of Sweden, seeded second, beat Jimmy Arias, 6-4, 6-3. Boris Becker, seeded third, and Jimmy Connors, seeded fourth, each had to rally. Becker beat Marcel Freeman, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1, and Connors beat Jay Berger, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2. (AP) Minter Upsets Sukova: Anne Minter of Australia upset fourth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-1, eliminating the defending champion from the $293,000 Player's Challenge tournament in Toronto. Minter reeled off seven straight games to win the first set and give her control of the second.(AP) Votavova Defeats Mascarin: Olga Votavova of Czechoslovakia upset Susan Mascarin of Boca Raton, Fla., the defending champion and top-seeded player, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the U.S.T.A. $25,000 Challenger tournament at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club in Manhasset, L.I.(AP) Cycling Brunet Wins Race Stage: Genny Brunet broke away from the lead pack on the 14th lap yesterday at Copper Mountain, Colo., and went on to win a stage of the 13th annual Coors International Bicycle Classic. The victory capped a two-year recovery from a car accident in which she suffered ankle and eye injuries. Complications from the accident, which included bouts with pneumonia and asthma, kept her from regaining racing form last year. Brunet, a Canadian now living in Monument, Colo., extended her margin with each lap during the 29-lap, 44-mile circuit that wound around the base of a ski area about 70 miles west of Denver. The victory moved her from 16th to fifth place in the standings.(AP)

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS anyone familiar with the latest eating habits knows, blackened redfish has become one of the most prestigious foods on American menus. The principle behind its preparation is to heat a cast-iron skillet until it is extremely hot, almost smoking. The fish is dipped into hot spiced butter and then pan broiled in the skillet until done.

MARKET PLACE;

title: Boeing 747 Sale

The plane, a version of the jumbo jet with a lengthened upper deck, is to be delivered in October 1988. It would augment the airline's fleet of three 747's. The airline was established in 1975 to resume Japan-Taiwan flights formerly flown by its parent company. It is the carrier's first purchase from Boeing. The announcement brings total 747 orders to 808 aircraft, of which 78 are the 300 model.

title: Pettis Sent Down

To replace Pettis on their roster, the Angels purchased the contract of an 11-year big league veteran, Tony Armas, from Edmonton. The switch-hitting Pettis, who captured his second straight Gold Glove last year, has struggled throughout this season, hitting only .204 and striking out 115 times in 354 times at bat. Pettis, 29, hit .258 last year with 50 stolen bases. He has stolen only 19 bases in 1987.

The new Central American peace initiative forces Sandinista leaders and President Reagan to choose between the prospect of more fighting and the risks of peace. There is every hard-headed reason for Mr. Reagan to choose the diplomatic path toward peace.

description: Elinor Raas Heller, the first woman to head the University of California Board of Regents, died of cancer Saturday. She was 82 years old.

title: In Iran, Food Is Better Gift Than Gold
description: On the first day of the Persian New Year, the Government usually gives its employees a small gift of gold. This year, according to a longtime resident, the bonus was granted in food rations instead of precious metal.

title: Pan Am Drug Issue Widens
description: A day after six athletes were disqualified for testing positive for the use of banned substances in the Pan American Games, three other athletes were said to have used a substance that could hide the use of steroids.

title: Allies Now Indicate Hess Killed Himself
description: Rudolf Hess, the onetime Hitler deputy who died Monday after 40 years in Spandau Prison, probably committed suicide with an electrical cord, an official statement said today.

title: Travels With Bush
description: Vice President Bush's whirlwind 10-day tour of Europe beginning late next month will include visits to West Germany, Poland, France, Belgium and Britain, his office says.

title: Hewlett Adds Terminals
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced its entry today into the general-purpose market for computer terminals.

title: Armtek Considers Pirelli Venture
description: The Armtek Corporation said it is considering a venture with Pirelli Societe Generale in which Pirelli would acquire 80 percent of Armtek's Armstrong Tire Company subsidiary.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O., Split Over '88, Allows Unions Some Leeway
description: Unable to unite behind a candidate, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today abandoned hopes of making an early Presidential endorsement and freed unions and individuals within its ranks to work on behalf of a variety of candidates.

title: McWherter's Warning
description: While Congress is in recess, the forces of grass-roots lobbying continue in anticipation of its return. Gov. Ned McWherter of Tennessee sent a letter last Friday to all 11 members of the Tennessee delegation in Congress urging them to save jobs in their home state by not backing a measure that would ban Toshiba imports from the United States.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE French, who should know better, are exporting a wine labeled ''nouveau'' that they make in Australia. Did they forget that English is the country's language?

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ALCOHOLISM runs in families, a fact recognized since ancient times. Although familial alcoholism has long been attributed to an inherited ''weak character,'' until recently most researchers thought it was almost entirely the result of environmental influences: imitation of parental drinking habits, poverty and other social and family pressures.

title: Pickens Lifts Newmont Stake
description: Ivanhoe Partners, the investor group headed by T. Boone Pickens, turned up the heat on the Newmont Mining Corporation today by buying more of it.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Man Gets 30 Years In Slaying of Wife
