description: A New London man who bludgeoned his wife to death with a sewing machine has been sentenced to 30 years in prison despite his request for leniency because he has been exposed to the AIDS virus.

title: Granger's 1-Hitter Puts U.S. in Final
description: It was a performance most pitchers would have relished: one hit - a last-inning two-out blooper - 14 strikeouts, one walk and a 4-0 victory against a tough-hitting team from Puerto Rico.

title: Before School Begins
description: THE start of a new school year is only weeks away: just after Labor Day in most places. And when it's time for youngsters to go back to school, it is usually time for parents to go shopping. They will find stores around town stocked with all the necessities of school life: everything from jackets and sweaters to rain boots and lunch boxes. Here is a sampling of what's available: 1.Denim for Girls Denim is a wardrobe requirement this fall. This girl's jacket, from Giacca Blu's, has a quilted cotton lining and polyester filler. It closes with a zipper, and for added warmth there is an overlapping flap with snaps. The front is covered with four handy pockets, one with a zipper and three with snaps. The price is $75 in sizes 4 to 6X, 7 to 14 and teens on the fifth floor at Macy's Herald Square. Also available at branch stores. 2.For Books and Gear This backpack will likely cheer up the student who is glum about returning to the classroom. It is aqua, with electric yellow shoulder straps and trim. Other bright color combinations, including purple and pink, are also available. The backpack has three outside pockets, one that zips closed and two that snap shut. For $9.99 in children's accessories on the fourth floor at the A&S flagship store in Brooklyn. Also available at some branch stores. 3.Stripes and Patterns Socks can add adventure to dressing. These red and blue argyles, for $9, are part of a colorful collection from France. They are 56 percent wool and 44 percent nylon and are available in a variety of stripes and patterns. In Gingerbread Shoes on the second floor at Bloomingdale's Manhattan store. Also available at some branch stores. 4.Fashionable Leather Leather is the fashion rage this season, even for little girls. This leather skirt comes in red or black, with an elasticized waist. It is available in sizes 2, 4 and 6 for $58. In Kidz at Bendel'z at Henri Bendel. 5.Wearing a Lesson This sturdy plastic apron, useful for a young child's adventures in art class, is also a lesson in nutrition. It shows the four basic food groups, with their recommended daily servings. The apron is part of the Straight Edge's new line of educational aprons, which also offer lessons in the alphabet and numbers. The price is $9.99 at the Hired Hand, 1324 Lexington Avenue, between 88th and 89th Streets. 6.Warm and Sporty Boys will be warmly and sportily dressed in this black baseball jacket by M. Julian. It is a blend of wool and acrylic, with red leather sleeves and leather trim on the pockets. The collar, cuffs and waist are black knit, trimmed with red and white. The jacket is available in sizes 4 to 7 for $119 in K.I.D.S. on the eighth floor at Saks Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Also available at some branch stores. 7.Custom Bows Hair accessories can be banners for school spirit. Magic Windows offers custom-made bows decorated with school names. They come in an array of bright colors, for $12. Personalized barrettes are also available, at $6 a pair. At Magic Windows, 1046 Lexington Avenue, between 74th and 75th Streets. 8.A Colorful Sweater This cotton sweater will put color in a school wardrobe. It has blue and green crayons on a bright red background, with black trim at the neck and cuffs. The price is $48, in sizes 2 through 6X, at Judy Corman, 198 Columbus Avenue, at 69th Street. 9.Sleek Lunch Box This bright yellow lunch box, highly styled with sleek curves, is made of molded plastic, with an easy-to-grip handle, and comes with a color-coordinated thermos bottle. The lunch box is also available in red or blue and costs $12.75 at Penny Whistle, 448 Columbus Avenue, at 81st Street; 1283 Madison Avenue, at 91st Street, and 132 Spring Street, between Wooster and Greene Streets. On the Cover: Ducks and Frogs Weather appropriate for ducks calls for the rubber boots shown on page C1. They are white, with yellow bills. Made in Britain by Wellipets, the boots come in sizes 6 to 12, and cost $31. Another style, in green with a frog face, is also available. At Chocolate Soup, 946 Madison Avenue, between 74th and 75th Streets. Rah-Rah Spirit For the student with one eye on the clock, there is a water-resistant quartz watch from Coca-Cola. It has a face decorated with a red cheerleader's megaphone, a second hand and lots of bright color - a blue rubberized strap and yellow and red trim. The watch, which sells for $35, is part of Coca-Cola's back-to-school collection of timepieces for boys and girls. At Fizzazz, 280 Columbus Avenue, between 73d and 74th Streets.

title: New Superconductor Markets
description: THE recent discoveries of materials that lose all resistance to electricity at warmer temperatures than previously thought possible have astonished the industrial world.

title: Renovating Buildings For Offices
description: WHEN commercial condominiums appeared on the market about five years ago, the first to be developed were designed for medical professionals seeking to avoid escalating office rents.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Stalking Vitamin C
description: LEAD: VITAMIN C (ascorbic acid) is our best-known, most celebrated nutrient. Credited with the ability to help boost iron absorption and the formation of teeth and bones - and by some, with the power to help prevent colds - the vitamin is an easily available and important component of our diets.

title: The Outlook For Inflation
description: WITH the economic news full of surprises -most strikingly the jump in the United States trade deficit to a record level in June, when it was supposed to shrink - the stock market has become extremely nervous.

title: A BRIDGE DILEMMA: PATCH IT OR SCRAP IT
description: As they try to diagnose the Williamsburg Bridge's many ills, officials are confronting a perplexing choice: spend $250 million to repair the heavily used crossing and replace its cables, a task that has never been tried while a bridge is still in service, or build an entirely new structure, which might be twice as expensive.

title: Horn & Hardart
description: The Horn & Hardart Company, which has tried unsuccessfully to sell its unprofitable Bojangles' fast-food division since last October, said it had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to take on the job. The chicken-and-biscuit chain has 218 outlets in six states, mostly in the Southeast. Proceeds from the sale would go toward an $84 million acquisition fund that Horn & Hardart plans to use to bolster its direct mail marketing operations. Horn & Hardart is based in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: NEW YORK DAIRY FARMERS FACE TRANSITION AMID UPHEAVAL
description: The flow of milk to New York City begins here every day in the darkness before sunrise, when John and Larry Burgin come into their barn to start milking their 50 cows.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 19, 1987
description: International A2-11

title: The Heath Bar Finds Its Metier: Ice Cream
description: STEVE HERRELL didn't know a Heath bar from a hole in a doughnut until a friend gave him one in the late 1960's. But when he tasted the milk-chocolate-covered bar of crunchy toffee, he recalled, he had a single, all-penetrating inspiration: ''This would be great with ice cream!''

title: AW COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: A Boston dispatch on Aug. 5 about the economic policies of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts misidentified the city chosen as the state's Center for Excellence in biotechnology. It is Worcester. (Amherst is home to some recipients of biotechnology grants under the Centers for Excellence program.) In some copies, the article and a map misidentified the city that has been selected as a Center of Excellence in microelectronics; it is Westborough.

title: Survival of a 4-Year-Old Girl Bewilders Crash Investigators
description: Huge chunks of charred fuselage, torn and twisted like aluminum foil, sat awaiting inspection today, as a 4-year-old girl lay in a nearby hospital, living evidence of what seemed to be the impossible.

title: CALSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
20 IN BUILDING INDUSTRY HELD IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: Twenty people, including six officers of four unions, were indicted yesterday in a continuing investigation into labor racketeering and corruption in the billion-dollar construction industry in New York City.

title: Fast Travers Drill For Temperate Sil
description: A standing joke at California race tracks, when people ask the distance of the major grass races, is to answer, ''They just keep on running until Charlie's horse gets to the front.''

title: SUFFOLK SOLID-WASTE BILL COULD LEAD THE NATION
description: In the fast-food industry, they are innocently called ''clam shells.'' But a majority of the Suffolk County Legislature considers them to be a nuisance or worse, and wants to ban them.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 19, 1987
description: International

title: NAVISTAR INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $14.2 million, or 5 cents a share, from tax benefits for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a charge of $112.9 million from redemption before maturity of four high coupon debt issues. c-Net income

title: VW Delay in U.S.
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said production of 1988 Golfs, GTI 16V's and Jettas would be delayed at its southwestern Pennsylvania assembly plant for at least a week because of supply problems. Volkswagen officials said a strike by employees at Volkswagen de Mexico's auto plant near Mexico City was responsible for the delay. Volkswagen de Mexico supplies a number of parts used at the assembly plant in Westmoreland County, including sheet metal components, fuel-injection engines and rear axles. Production of 1988 Golfs, GTI 16V's and Jettas was originally scheduled to begin Sept. 14, Volkswagen officials said.

title: In China, Kremlin Watching
description: LEAD: During a recent visit to China, I asked my dinner host, an urbane provincial official, what he thought of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's prospects for success with economic reforms. He said, somewhat unconvincingly, ''I suppose he will succeed.'' Then, his face brightening, he added, ''but not before the Chinese.

title: Dooley Wants to Know
description: Vince Dooley, the Georgia football coach, has asked the seniors on his team to inform him when they have contact of any kind with sports agents, even though there is no rule barring contact.

title: Knicks Fined For Workout
description: The Knicks said yesterday that they had been fined by David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, for allowing their top four picks in this year's college draft to work out earlier this month at a basketball camp run by their new coach, Rick Pitino.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HAPPINESS is an overhead garage door that slides smoothly up in the morning with no more than a slightly authoritative tug, and descends gently at night with the same small effort. Struggling with a pesky door invites grumpiness and back strain; worse, it could lead to a dislocated shoulder or a broken toe. Because of their many parts, garage doors need periodic maintenance to operate well and safely. Here's how to get yours in shape.

title: Oslo Widens Export Case
description: Norway's state arms company, already embroiled in a dispute with Washington over high-technology exports to the Soviet Union, may also have sold equipment to China in violation of Western rules, the police said today.

title: SOUTH KOREAN COMPANY AGREES TO RECOGNIZE UNION
description: The nation's biggest labor dispute ended today when officials of South Korea's leading conglomerate agreed to recognize an independent union formed by employees.

title: MAILBOX ETC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Joyce Shares Lead In Met Open at 141
description: Tom Joyce shot a three-under-par 67 today to move into a tie for the second-round lead of the Met Open at 141 with Jim McGovern, the amateur who led the tournament after the first day.

title: Surge of Textile Imports From Iran Protested
description: A surge of low-priced textiles from Iran has prompted an outcry from a textile state Senator and a promise by the Reagan Administration to study the possibility of imposing import curbs.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Rock in Brooklyn

title: Finding Higher Values In Mason's Low Humor
description: IN the immortal words of Frank Loesser: So sue me. I hereby confess that I was the last drama critic in New York to catch Jackie Mason's act on Broadway - a full six months after the comedian's opening night. I had ignored the favorable reviews, ignored the Tony Award, even ignored the entreaties of a persistent friend who had pleaded Jackie Mason's case to me on two continents. ''You'll laugh,'' my friend said. ''You've got to be kidding,'' I replied. After all, I remember the Sunday nights when Jackie Mason was my second most dreaded act on ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' (after the talking mouse Topo Gigio, of course).

title: Baseball Notebook; Dome, Sweet Dome Gives Twins Edge
description: If the Minnesota Twins can figure out how to win games they play outside their Metrodome, they might be able to cite a 12-day period in August as the perfect way to break open a close division race.

title: MICRO GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stage: 'Bunker Reveries' At Roundabout Theater
description: DAVID SHABER calls ''Bunker Reveries'' a fantasy. Actually it is more like a figment of history.

title: Dispute on Tree Injections Surprises Experimenter
description: The scientist who injected elm trees with genetically altered bacteria without Federal approval says he did not anticipate the outrage many scientists have expressed about his experiment. And he says he is not sure he would do it again.

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago second quarter and 6-month include a non- reucrring $8.6 million non-cash charge resulting from the writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Giving Flowers Long Life
description: YOU might say that J. Barry Ferguson lives with and for flowers. He's known for the grandiose arrangements he devises for private parties (such as Malcolm Forbes's May extravaganza) and for charity events (such as the annual Winter Antiques Show in New York). He is much sought after as a lecturer at garden clubs, and he grows all sorts of flowers in the gardens surrounding his home on the North Shore of Long Island. Also, he is writing a book called ''Living With Flowers.''

title: The Flaw in Controlling Arms by Tritium Decay
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharing Shelter
description: A morning rain poured down just as people started pouring out of a Fifth Avenue bus. Few had umbrellas. The rest cowered under newspapers or ran for shelter in nearby building entrances. There they found themselves sharing the space with homeless people, for whom such locations are home.

title: SILVER KING MINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Late Rally Lifts Dow To 2,665.82
description: The stock market snapped back yesterday in late trading on a wave of buying by bargain hunters and by investors who had been selling short.

title: Advertising; President Is Leaving Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
description: Stephen E. Humphrey is leaving Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss after five years, the last year and a half as president and a director. Leonard Sirowitz, co-chairman of the agency, said Mr. Humphrey, 44 years old, was leaving on ''amicable terms.''

title: Spermicides Reported to Be Safe as Birth Control
description: Two new studies have turned up no evidence that spermicides cause birth defects, and researchers say the findings should relieve lingering doubts about the safety of this form of birth control.

title: INSIDE
description: A Gentle Man Who Killed

title: U.S. Orders 8 Old Minesweepers to the Gulf
description: The Reagan Administration, preparing to enlarge the United States naval presence in the Persian Gulf, has ordered the Navy to activate at least eight reserve minesweepers and send them to that region, officials here said today.

title: U.S. PLANNED IN '84 FOR SOUTH AFRICA TO HELP CONTRAS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials approved a plan in early 1984, under which the Nicaraguan rebels would receive training and equipment that would ultimately have been paid for by South Africa, Government officials said today.

title: VIRGINIA FIRST SAVINGS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of about $300,000 from the elimination of the FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: Youmans Disabled
description: The Montreal Expos have placed Floyd Youmans, a pitcher, on the disabled list and recalled another pitcher, Pascual Perez, from Class AAA Indianapolis. Perez, 30 years old, has not pitched in the major leagues since 1985. He was released by Atlanta during spring training in 1986. He has admitted to a cocaine problem in the past.

title: 4,000 Back at G.M.
description: Two thousand workers out of work since the General Motors Corporation canceled the second shift at its Arlington plant in April 1986 are back on the job, along with 2,000 others out for the summer while the plant was being retooled. G.M. decided to recall most of the second-shift workers and give the plant new business after union officials agreed to a new local contract last year. The contract includes new work rules and production procedures at the 30-year-old plant, once considered to be among G.M.'s least efficient.

title: Mixed Results for U.S. Boxers
description: Was Riddick Bowe suffering from a broken hand, or just a broken heart?

title: Dance: Cunningham's 'Carousal,' at Jacob's Pillow
description: ''That's Merce,'' a summer visitor to the Berkshires murmured cosily to her friends as Merce Cunningham padded across the stage in a dance presented by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Tuesday at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

title: Excerpts From Agent's Testimony
description: Following are excerpts from testimony to the Iran-contra committees by Duane (Dewey) R. Clarridge, a Central Intelligence Agency official, as made public today by the committees. The committees, in releasing the testimony, left certain words blank. Officials have said the unidentified country under discussion in portions of the questioning by the committee was South Africa.

title: 'Apocalypse Now' to Be Re-released
description: Spurred by the success of such recent films about the Vietnam War as ''Platoon'' and ''Full Metal Jacket,'' United Artists is re-releasing Francis Coppola's 1979 movie ''Apocalypse Now'' in six cities next week.

title: 2 Bystanders Shot, 1 Fatally, in Dispute
description: A pregnant Brooklyn woman died early yesterday after being caught in a shooting involving two neighbors, the police said, and her 7-month fetus could not be saved. Another resident of the area, also an innocent bystander, was critically wounded, they said.

title: Priest and 3 Others Arrested In $1 Million Ticket Robbery
description: A Roman Catholic priest and three other men were arrested yesterday in connection with the theft of $1 million worth of tickets to ''Les Miserables'' from a Broadway theater ticket agency earlier this year, the police said.

title: Namibia Police Arrest 5 Foes of Pretoria Rule
description: The police in South-West Africa arrested five top officials of the main black opposition to South African rule in the territory today.

title: Allies Report Hess Left a Note Indicating He Planned Suicide
description: Rudolf Hess, the former Hitler deputy who died Monday when he apparently strangled himself with an electrical cord, left a note that clearly implied he intended to commit suicide, Allied officials said today.

title: BELZBERGS SEEKING MORE OF ROBERTSON
description: A unit of the First City financial Corporation, controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada, said it would seek permission under Federal antitrust laws to increase its stake in the H.H. Robertson Company to 49.9 percent, from 24.9 percent. With the disclosure, made in filings with the Government, the Belzbergs may be renewing a battle with Robertson that began more than three years ago, when they bought a stake in the Pittsburg based building products concern.

title: Autopsy Conducted In Policeman's Death
description: An autopsy on the body of an off-duty New York City police officer who died early Tuesday, hours after he was found unconscious in a vacant lot in Harlem, showed he had ''a bad heart and a bad liver,'' the police said yesterday.

title: U.S.-Escorted Tankers Start 3d Voyage
description: A third American-escorted convoy of reregistered Kuwaiti tankers was moving up the Persian Gulf today, having slipped through the Strait of Hormuz overnight.

title: Deaths of Dolphins Along Eastern Shore Linked to Bacteria
description: Common bacteria normally found in coastal waters have recently become lethal to the bottle-nosed dolphins that swim and feed along the shore from Virginia to New Jersey, a marine pathologist said today.

title: PATLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Talking Deals; Using Stock For Financing
description: WITH the stream of mergers and acquisitions continuing, the stock market surging and the 1986 tax law taking hold, a method of financing once popular in the 1960's is again creating interest. Companies acquiring others are taking a fresh look at using stock to pay for their deals. While cash deals still far outnumber those financed by equity, the value and number of stock deals have been rising.

title: Deadline on Meese Case
description: The special prosecutor investigating links between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Wedtech Corporation expects to decide soon whether to bring criminal charges.

title: BOARD APPROVES PLAN FOR SHELTERS
description: A bitterly divided Board of Estimate last night approved the construction of 11 of 15 new shelters for the homeless that had been sought by the Koch administration.

title: ORGANOGENESIS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company had no revenue for the year-ago second quarter and 6 months; it was in its startup phase.

title: ENGLISH GREENHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Manila Assassination Trial Is Barely Moving
description: ''Hey, boss, we've got a crowd,'' said a defense lawyer the other day as a reporter walked in to the empty courtroom where, for the third time, lawyers were trying to determine who killed Benigno S. Aquino Jr. four years ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no doubt that the sufferings endured by the Jews are also for the Catholic Church a motive of sincere sorrow, especially when one thinks of the indifference and sometimes resentment which, in particular historical circumstances, have divided Jews and Christians.'' - Pope John Paul II. [ B14:4. ]

title: Garbage Haulers Balk At Jersey Landfill Fees
description: Garbage piled up in many communities in four northern New Jersey counties today as nearly half the haulers who use an East Brunswick landfill refused to pay a 227 percent increase in dumping fees.

title: Terrifying but Effective
description: To The Home Section:

title: For British Trust, Money Is Not All Bad
description: IN November 1986, Ightham Mote, a medieval manor house in Kent, began to court the pocketbooks of its visitors seriously. Until then the 14th-century property, owned by the British National Trust, sold a small collection of trinkets and books from a trestle table. But its shop today occupies an old coach house on the property, stocks hundreds of items and does a bustling trade, especially at this time of year, when up to 4,000 people a week visit the vast moated estate.

title: Corporate Boon: Real Estate
description: A 60-story tower rising in the heart of the downtown office district will house the regional headquarters of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. But rather than serving as a monument to A.T.&T.'s domination of the telecommunications industry, as its New York headquarters does, the tower here represents the company's new approach to its huge real estate holdings.

title: Thrift Concern Reports Loss
description: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara said today that its securities and futures trading operations lost about $13 million in the third quarter. As a result, the company said it expected to post a loss for the quarter.

title: Jersey Dairy Is Sued By Publicity Agency
description: A public-relations agency has charged that a New Jersey dairy failed to pay the bill for its successful campaign to break into the New York milk market.

title: MOLECULAR BIOSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Eloquent Bones
description: ''Consider it a mystery in progress,'' says Harvard's Lawrence Stager of 50 dog skeletons unearthed in Israel by archeologists at an ancient seafront resort in Ashkelon, near modern Tel Aviv. The dogs, resembling modern greyhounds, died of natural causes and were carefully buried in individual plots around 450 B.C., when Persians ruled in Palestine. The discovery was greeted with relief; Orthodox Jews oppose excavations if they suspect the remains are of Jews.

title: Gunman Kills Mother, 13 Others, Then Himself in an English Town
description: Fourteen people were killed today when a man leveled his assault rifle at marketplace strollers in this peaceful Berkshire town and sprayed them with bullets.

title: Australian Union Stance
description: Australia's trade unions said today that they would consider buying large stakes in state corporations if the Labor Party Government went ahead with plans to privatize the companies or sell them to the public. The union movement opposes the sale of such public companies as Qantas, Australian Airlines, Telecom and the Commonwealth Bank.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Izaak Walton's Own Frog-Immunity Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish Kill Reported In Norwalk Waters
description: Low oxygen levels have killed tens of thousands of bunker fish in Norwalk Harbor, the Connecticut Coastal Fisherman's Association said yesterday.

title: Reacting to Document Thefts, Libraries Move to Add Security
description: In light of charges against an art historian involving stolen historic documents, librarians and archivists in New York and across the country are taking a hard look at how to safeguard manuscripts against vandalism and theft.

title: MINISTERS DISCUSS LATIN PEACE PLAN
description: Central American foreign ministers opened two days of meetings here today in the first formal step toward carrying out a new peace plan for the region.

title: HARVARD TEACHER IS FREE OF CHARGE
description: A 23-year-old woman has dropped assault charges against a Harvard professor who had been under consideration for the second highest post in the Federal Department of Education.

title: CROWN BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company completed its initial public offering in February.

title: Joint Project Is Seen on New Japanese Fighter Jet
description: Japan is likely to yield to United States pressure on an important defense issue by abandoning long-discussed plans to develop a new fighter plane on its own, American and Japanese officials say.

title: Why Offer Nightmares?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Agency Foresees Big Deficit Rise in '88 and '89
description: The Congressional Budget Office agreed today with the Reagan Administration's prediction that the Federal budget deficit would drop dramatically this year. But, unlike the Administration, it also projected big increases in the deficit for 1988 and 1989 unless Congress and the President take strong action.

title: Aouita May Skip Rome
description: Said Aouita of Morocco, the world-record holder in three long distance running events, as expected did not compete yesterday in an international meet at Zurich, Switzerland, beause of an inflamed nerve in his left leg. Now, the runner himself says he is ''85 percent sure'' that he will also miss the world championships of track and field that begin Aug. 29 in Rome.

title: For Getting Your Things From Here to There
description: WHEN Steven Fiore was running a moving company from a brownstone on West 96th Street seven years ago he wasn't in the business of selling boxes, just packing and moving them. But he said, ''People came in looking for moving materials - I was doing business selling boxes without advertising and without looking for the business.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Sports World Specials column on Monday incorrectly described the prospect that Michael Chang, winner of the national boys' 18 singles tennis championship, will enter the United States Open. Although the winner of the boys' championship is traditionally invited to the Open, an invitation is not mandatory. Invitations are to be issued later this month by the United States Open tournament committee.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 20, 1987
description: International A3-12, A17-19, B14

title: International Minerals Spinoff
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation said it would spin off its fertilizer unit, selling a large share to the public, and might use the money to buy back up to a third of its outstanding shares. The announcement sent the Northbrook, Ill., company's stock up $4.375, to $49.375, on volume of more than one million shares.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
ACC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Shares Slip On Citicorp Stock Plan
description: Bank stocks fell yesterday as investors braced for a possible avalanche of common stock offerings.

title: ABOLITIONIST PORT FOCUS OF DIG ON THE MISSOURI
description: On an overgrown hillside here, close to the Missouri River, an abolitionist river port named Quindaro enjoyed a brief moment in history.

title: HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Clarence Brown, a Director And Six-Time Oscar Nominee
description: Clarence Brown, a motion picture director who was nominated six times for an Academy Award, died Monday of kidney failure. He was 97 years old.

title: Call It Fast Food for Thought
description: Considering that debates seem to be the height of political fashion and that brevity remains indisputably the soul of wit, it was probably inevitable that television would come to the one-minute debate.

title: Advertising; Banjo Aids Agency's Recruiting
description: BEFORE Larry Kopald, senior vice president of Ketchum Advertising, sold his new client on its first campaign there, he had a tougher sale to make.

title: MCCORMICK CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in September 1986.

title: DiMaggio's 57 Varieties
description: Curious that public attention began to be fanned as Paul Molitor hit in his 32d and 33d consecutive ball games. Curious that his team, the Brewers, played in Cleveland those last two games, with appearances again last night and tonight in the same town.

title: Stunned Sri Lanka Studies Parliament Attack
description: Investigators said today that they were trying to determine if a grenade attack in Parliament had been made with the cooperation of security guards or employees in the building.

title: South Korea Broadens Democracy
description: The South Korean Government, which two months ago made a public commitment to democracy, now enlarges the commitment by supporting economic fairness. Applause is in order for both acts; the two go hand in hand.

title: World Steel Output Up
description: Crude steel production in the principal non-Communist nations rose 6.9 percent in July from July 1986, reflecting a huge rise in American output, the International Iron and Steel Institute said today. The Brussels-based institute said that 30 countries in the survey produced 35.44 million metric tons of steel last month, up from 33.16 million a year earlier.

title: Caesars Slows Plan
description: Caesars World Inc. has asked the Nevada Gaming Commission to defer consideration of its proposed $1.1 billion recapitalization plan after New Jersey's casino regulators ruled against the plan. The plan, intended by Caesars to ward off a hostile takeover bid by the New York investor Martin T. Sosnoff, was recently blocked by the New Jersey Gaming Control Commission on the ground that it would burden the company with excessive debt.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Agrees to End Boycott of Coors
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. today ended its decade-old boycott of Coors beer, the longest-running labor-management dispute in recent history and one of the most bitter.

title: WIENER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Texas Thrift Detective Faces Tough Deadline
description: Bobby R. Gillham, the special agent in Dallas in charge of the F.B.I.'s investigation of the savings and loan industry in Texas, is working under the gun.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Armtek Corp., New Haven, said its board had adopted a shareholder rights plan intended to discourage hostile takeovers.

title: Hired by Japan
description: Industry and government officials from Japan have long made it a practice to retain former senior American officials from the executive branch to act as their representatives or lobbyists in Washington.

title: Dollar's Fall Continues; Steep Drop Against Yen
description: The dollar fell sharply against the yen yesterday and weakened over all, continuing its reaction to the bulging trade deficit reported on Friday.

title: MARINE'S LAWYERS CRITICAL OF JUDGE
description: Denied permission to call a half-dozen witnesses in the espionage court-martial of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, defense lawyers today publicly denounced the judge for ''restrictive'' rulings.

title: TV Review; Thelonious Monk's Jazz Featured on Channel 13
description: OVER the summer, Channel 13 has been devoting its time slot on Thursdays at 11 P.M. to jazz, packaged in a series called ''Jazz Tonight.'' This evening, the spotlight is on ''Celebrating a Jazz Master: Thelonious Sphere Monk,'' which was taped in Washington last year and shown, with little fanfare, on Channel 13 last March. With two six-minute breaks for fund-raising, the program runs to about 90 minutes.

title: Massachusetts Warns Hutton
description: Massachusetts officials accused E. F. Hutton & Company of misrepresenting the value of a stock offering and said all the firm's offices in the state could be ordered closed unless restitution was made. Secretary of State Michael J. Connolly issued an order notifying Hutton and 11 of its present and former agents that their registrations could be revoked unless the firm refunded investors' money in a mining company stock and allowed an independent audit of its books.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Calendar: Terra Cotta, Ceramics, Stars
description: Terra-Cotta Panels Municipal Art Society, Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); 212-935-3960.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GOLDEN GURU: The Strange Journey of Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh. By James S. Gordon. Illustrated. 248 pages. Stephen Greene Press. $19.95.

title: Football Playoff Is Likely Topic
description: A one-game playoff will most likely be on the agenda at next the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention in January, giving schools a chance to vote on a national football championship for the first time. If approved, a championship game could be staged after the 1988 season.

title: Open the Archives
description: To the Editor:

title: Slow Start Aside, A Cadet Corps Shows Promise
description: It's rare that a government program winds up costing less than it was supposed to. It's even more unusual when nobody is pleased about the surplus.

title: Books: Champion of the Individual
description: TRAITORS AND HEROES: A Lawyer's Memoir. By Martin Garbus. 305 pages.

title: John J. Conroy, an Ex-Coach Of Tennis Team at Princeton
description: John J. Conroy, a former coach of tennis and squash at Princeton University, died of pneumonia Monday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Doubts Are Cast By Envoy on Bid For Senate Seat
description: Ronald S. Lauder, United States Ambassador to Austria, confirmed yesterday that he would leave his post and return to New York, but not necessarily to run for the United States Senate.

title: Abidjan Journal; Black Africa's Oddities: Preserves of White Power
description: In the Ivory Coast, they call him ''Caesar.'' In Senegal, he is ''Jesus Christ.'' In the Central African Republic, he is the ''Bwana of Bangui.''

title: CVD EQUIPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Linens That Evoke the Past
description: AT Lawrence Ltd., in Southampton, L.I., Ann Lawrence sells over 1,000 pieces of one-of-a-kind linens dating from the 1820's to the 1940's. Collected from her travels in England, France, Ireland, Austria and Spain, the cache includes tablecloths, sheets, pillowcases and rare items, like a lace chaise-longue cover.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: IFR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IBP Sale Set By Occidental
description: As expected, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it planned to sell to the public 49 percent of its hog and cattle processor, IBP Inc., for between $446.5 million and $517 million.

title: Airline Is Still Refusing To List Victims of Crash
description: Northwest Airlines has reaffirmed its refusal to make public a passenger list from the crash of one of its airliners Sunday at the Detroit airport, saying it wanted to protect the victims' families from harassment.

title: A Bit Late, New York Finds Jobs for Students
description: Three weeks after conceding that a program to provide summer jobs for thousands of high school students had failed, city officials announced yesterday that almost 500 of the students had been placed in monthlong positions.

title: Ford Mustang Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company will extend production of its hot-selling Mustang for at least three years at its Dearborn, Mich., plant, a top union official said. ''They've been telling us 1990, 1991,'' said Bob King, chairman of the United Automobile Workers' national bargaining committee. Ford had been expected to replace the current rear-wheel-drive Mustang with a front-drive model assembled at a new plant built by its Japanese affiliate, the Mazda Motor Corporation, at Flat Rock, Mich. Ford spokesmen declined to comment on future production plans.

title: SEITEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $137,081 from debt extinguishment. c-Net income

title: Make the Best of the Junta in Haiti
description: The Reagan Administration rightly presses Latin military dictators from Panama to Paraguay to yield power to civilian democrats. But in Haiti it supports Gen. Henri Namphy's discredited junta as long as it adheres to its announced timetable and ground rules for transition to elected government. Going along with the military is a sensible course because Haiti simply doesn't have other functioning political institutions.

title: Excerpts From Pope's Letter On Catholic-Jewish Relations
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a letter written by Pope John Paul II to Archbishop John L. May of St. Louis, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops:

title: NEW PRIDE IN JERSEY IS NO JOKE
description: Heard any good New Jersey jokes lately? Neither has Robert R. Ferguson Jr., the chairman of First Fidelity Bancorporation, the state's largest bank.

title: An Old Pattern
description: No one should be surprised that the Reagan Administration is backing away from the new Central American peace plan, since President Reagan has never wanted a negotiated settlement on any terms but his own. This time, however, he has good reason to think anew.

title: Move to Head Clinique Logical for Editor of Elle
description: Karen Anderegg, the newly named president of Clinique Labs Inc., the cosmetics company, sees her current job as editor in chief of Elle magazine as a logical launching pad for her new post.

title: Court Backs Inquiry on Meese
description: A three-judge panel today authorized a special prosecutor to investigate whether the dealings that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d had with the Wedtech Corporation violated Federal conflict-of-interest laws.

title: E.P.A. Proposes New Waste Disposal Rules
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed new rules for the underground disposal of hazardous wastes. The rules were immediately attacked by environmentalists as too lenient.

title: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Cockpit Data Suggest Jet's Flaps Were Not Positioned for Takeoff
description: Federal investigators said tonight that the flaps on the wings of the Northwest Airlines MD-80 that crashed Sunday had apparently not been lowered for takeoff and that the crew had apparently not included the wing flaps and slats in their routine preflight check of the airplane.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Good Map Is Like a Scorecard
description: LEAD: Good maps are as important as good boots to the serious hiker and backpacker, and woodlands wanderers in New York and New Jersey would do well to become acquainted with those published by the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference.

title: Magistrate Accused in Scuffle
description: A United States magistrate was given a summons yesterday after she swung at a bicyclist and a police officer on the Brooklyn Bridge, the police said.

title: US FACILITIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a securities gain of $66,000 and $100,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a securities gain of $2,000 and $25,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: What 'Luxury' Means
description: To the Editor:

title: Welfare Mothers Can Help Moynihan on Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Smile and Gentle Ways Masked Slayer of the Ill
description: With his gentle ways and cheerful smile, Donald Harvey was the kind of person who could get away with making jokes about killing people and, for a while, get away with the killings.

title: BAKER J INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,038,000 and $1,596,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter results were adversely affected by the addition of $1,500,000 to its reserve for losses.

title: Music: Thuli Dumakude Leads South African Band
description: NEW YORK can now boast a superb South African band - the one led by Thuli Dumakude, a singer, at Carlos 1 on Tuesday and Wednesday. Ms. Dumakude's husband, Welcome Msomi, is the director of the Izulu Dance Theater, which has been based in New York since 1979, and she played the lead in the play ''Poppie Nongena.'' But she doesn't need dance or theater to make strong, stirring music. Although only Ms. Dumakude and Morris Goldberg, the band's saxophonist and penny whistle player, are from South Africa, the group has a genuine South African flavor, from the close harmonies of its four female singers to the band's smoothly building, gentle-to-buoyant-to-unstoppable grooves.

title: Hewlett Net Up 20.3% in 3d Quarter
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported today that third-quarter earnings rose by 20.3 percent, while sales rose 14.5 percent. The results disappointed analysts and Wall Street, where Hewlett's stock dropped $2.50, to $65.

title: Declaring Impasse, Washington Post Imposes New Wages on Union
description: After 16 months of bitter bargaining, The Washington Post Company has declared an impasse in talks with the Newspaper Guild, the newspaper's largest union.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
2d Defendant Is Subpoenaed By Howard Beach Prosecutor
description: The prosecutor in the Howard Beach assault case has moved to gain the testimony of a second defendant by subpoenaing him to testify as a state's witness, the defendant's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Dresser Net Rises 17.6%
description: Dresser Industries, a major oilfield services and energy company, said that its third-quarter earnings increased 17.6 percent, to $22 million, or 29 cents a share, from $18.7 million, or 24 cents a share, last year.

title: League Again Does Service With Championship Book
description: Each year since 1954 the American Contract Bridge League has provided a major service to players everywhere by preparing a substantial book describing each world championship.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 20, 1987
description: Markets

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Phillips Sparks U.S. Team
description: Kristie Phillips, the national champion, helped the United States take the lead during compulsory competition for the women's gymnastics team title today at the Pan American Games.

title: Pan American Games Notebook; All They Need Now Is a Bowling Alley
description: At a meeting last fall in Barbados, officials of the Pan American Sports Organization approved bowling as a gold-medal sport for the 1991 games in Havana.

title: Rangers Sign Crossman
description: The Rangers yesterday signed Jeff Crossman, a 22-year-old, 6-foot-2-inch, 200-pound defenseman who played last season with New Haven of the American Hockey League. At New Haven, he scored 2 goals and was credited with 5 assists in 61 games. Crossman was obtained on March 10 from the Los Angeles Kings as part of the deal that brought Marcel Dionne to New York in exchange for Bob Carpenter and Tom Laidlaw. . . . Defensemen for both Winnipeg and Hartford have been sidelined after being injured while preparing for the Canada Cup series, which begins next week. Fredrik Olausson of the Jets is out indefinitely after dislocating his right shoulder while playing for Sweden in an exhibition game with Finland. Scot Kleinendorst of the Whalers broke a bone in the instep of his left foot when hit by a teammate's shot in a Team USA practice and will miss at least a month.

title: Bonds Take Another Plunge
description: Bond prices continued to plunge yesterday in tandem with the dollar. The currency's latest decline has once again heightened fears of another resurgence of inflation, the bane of the fixed-income market.

title: Left and Right Fight for Custody of 'Family' Issue
description: With one eye on shifting demographic data and the another on the 1988 Presidential election, many liberal groups are trying to wrest the ''pro-family'' label from its conservative proprietors, and their ultimate focus is on policy made in Washington.

title: MICROSIZE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Eyes on Jackson
description: C. Anthony Broh, a political scientist from Princeton University, watched 2,189 network television reports on the Democratic primary race between November 1983 and the party's July 1984 convention.

title: Safe in a Parent's Lap
description: To The Home Section:

title: Tandy's Profit Increases 66%
description: The Tandy Corporation, the nation's largest retailer of consumer electronics products with more than 7,000 Radio Shack stores, has reported surprisingly strong earnings.

title: 9.35% Notes Issued By Republic Bank
description: The Republic National Bank of New York is offering $100 million of 9.35 percent notes due in 1994 at par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BERRY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Honda Scooter Account Is Returning to Dailey
description: Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has been awarded the $10 million Honda Scooter account after a three-year hiatus.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Hudson Rescues Yankees in Relief
description: Charles Hudson, banished to the minor leagues in June and to the bullpen in July, rescued the Yankees in relief tonight.

title: A Way to Begin
description: The Central American peace plan signed by the region's five presidents makes Nov. 7 the target date for its various elements: cease-fires, the end of outside military support, democratization. But if doubts are not to overwhelm the hope of peace, there will have to be concrete steps long before that date.

title: Mafia Killer to Lose Federal Protection Of Witness Program
description: Aladena Fratianno, an admitted Mafia hired murderer turned Government informer whose testimony helped convict six Mafia family leaders, will be dropped from the Federal Government's witness protection program, the Justice Department said today.

title: Whip It Wood Is Trot Favorite
description: Whip It Wood, winner of the American Trotting Championship last week, was made the 3-1 early favorite today over eight rivals for the $200,000 International Trot Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: COW, 15, GETS U.S REPRIEVE ON SLAUGHTER
description: Old Mama, a beloved 15-year-old cow adopted as a pet by a farmer, has been granted a Government reprieve from slaughter.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $4,262,000 for the quarter and $26,420,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $137,000 and income of $947,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: Citicorp Unit Said To Seek Fairchild
description: Citicorp Venture Capital has reportedly joined in the bidding for the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, which is being sold by its parent, Schlumberger Ltd. The San Jose Mercury News said today that Citicorp had been working with Fairchild's president, Donald Brooks, to finance a leveraged buyout. Schlumberger has been considering several buyout offers for Fairchild since March, when it bowed to Government pressure and withdrew a proposal to sell 80 percent of Fairchild to Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan.

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were unchanged to slightly higher in the week ended yesterday.

title: New York Cabbies Win Right To Ban Passenger Smoking
description: Smokers lost yet another refuge yesterday when the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission voted to give medallion cabbies the right to put up ''no smoking'' signs and put out passengers who do not comply.

title: Judge Allows Robins Suits
description: A Federal judge overseeing the bankruptcy proceedings of the A. H. Robins Company ruled today that a committee representing women who claim injuries from the Dalkon Shield contraceptive device could sue officers of the company.

title: Pit Bulldog Killed by Police
description: A police officer shot and killed a pit bull terrier this morning because the dog was about to attack a fellow officer, the police said. The officer, David Barnes, killed the dog with a blast from a 12-gauge shotgun, said Sgt. Roy Adams of the Rochester Police Department.

title: Redesigned Shuttle Booster Faces Full-Scale Test Aug. 27
description: The first full-scale test firing of a redesigned booster rocket for the space shuttle has been scheduled for Aug. 27 in Utah.

title: New World Raises Bid for Kenner Toys
description: New World Entertainment Ltd. increased its bid for Kenner Parker Toys Inc. to $47 a share today, $6 a share higher than its previous offer but still less than investors were betting the company would be worth if it were sold or restructured.

title: Group Gets Stake in Manpower
description: A group of investors led by Bear, Stearns & Company announced today that it had acquired a 5.1 percent stake in Manpower Inc., the temporary employment services company that is the target of an unsolicited takeover attempt by Blue Arrow P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Tips on Rescuing New York Schools
description: Since the Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, decided to retire, there has been incessant speculation about who should succeed him. Even more important than who takes his place, however, is the question of what the new chancellor should do to improve the city's public schools.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Department Stores Inc., named Frank Kiernan executive vice president for stores operations.

title: Pilot in a Near Miss With Reagan Returns to Duty Pending Review
description: The soldier whose private plane nearly collided with President Reagan's helicopter Thursday returned to active duty here today, pending a review of his absence without leave.

title: Cuomo Aide Is Buffeted By the Vagaries of Albany
description: Evan A. Davis said he used to wonder how Gov. W. Averell Harriman could be so adept at dealing with the Russians, yet never quite get the hang of dealing with the New York State Legislature.

title: HYUNDAI, KOREAN SYMBOL
description: Hyundai, a group of 25 major companies engaged mostly in heavy industry, has become the first South Korean business conglomerate to win worldwide recognition. As such, it serves as a symbol of the intense growth of the economy of a nation little known until the end of World War II.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Our house is about 10 years old and for the last couple of years I have had a problem with nail heads backing out or popping loose on the walls in several places. I have tried hammering the loosened nails back in and then plastering over them, but later the same thing happened again. Can you recommend a permanent cure for this problem?

title: Lawns May Need Benign Neglect
description: MANY lawns are now straw-colored instead of green. This is normal: the grass plants are dormant. In spite of the common penchant for a velvety greensward, nature knows best at this time of year. When rainfall is scant and the thermometer breaks records with little cool-down relief at night, the lawns go on vacation.

title: Music: Two Concertos By Festival Orchestra
description: IT has often been said that the considerable number of concerts major orchestras must play each season precludes the chance of maintaining high standards, and the same criticism could be leveled at the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra. The festival's ensemble presents a good number of events during its concentrated two-month season, with the result that many performances suffer. There remain bright spots, of course, even this late in the schedule, and Tuesday's program at Avery Fisher Hall was among them, though not exactly because the orchestra itself performed consistently well.

title: Judge Rejects Kaiser Change
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has denied a motion to force the Kaiser Steel Corporation into liquidating under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, instead of a Chapter 11 reorganization, the company announced.

title: DIAGNOSTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Flight Attendants Set Merger
description: The nation's two largest unions of airline flight attendants have announced they have tentatively agreed to merge.

title: U.S. Women Rally to Top Cuba, 85-80
description: For nearly 25 minutes of this afternoon's Pan American Games semifinal with Cuba, the undefeated United States women's basketball team was ripe for an upset loss. Beatriz Perdomo was not missing from the outside and nobody could stop Leonor Borrell, Cuba's dominating center, either.

title: Molitor Extends His Streak to 34
description: Paul Molitor's three-run homer extended his hitting streak to 34 games and Rob Deer hit his first career grand slam, all during Milwaukee's eight-run fourth inning, as the Brewers beat the Cleveland Indians, 13-2, tonight.

title: Israeli in Pollard Affair Says He Had Approval
description: The Israeli Defense Ministry official who organized the Jonathan Jay Pollard espionage operation against the United States spoke publicly about the affair for the first time today, saying he had approval for all his activities.

title: Hospital Releases Huston
description: John Huston was released from Charleton Memorial Hospital here today, ending a 22-day stay in the intensive care unit after being stricken with pneumonia, the hospital said.

title: Sharon Steel Reorganization
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has rejected the Sharon Steel Corporation's request for more time to file its reorganization plan, paving the way for creditors to file their own proposal. Federal Bankruptcy Judge

title: Beeper Chargers Recalled
description: Motorola Inc. today announced a nationwide recall of Korean-made battery chargers for beeping devices used to page people. It cited the inadvertent omission of an insulator in the manufacturing process, creating a potential electrical shock hazard. Chargers for these beepers are affected: Sensar, Sensar Display, BPR 2000, Dimension 2000, Minitor II and Director II.

title: For Nicaragua, Soviet Frugality Starts to Pinch
description: The Soviet Union's refusal to increase aid to Nicaragua has produced an economic crisis here.

title: HERS
description: IF you think of anything hard enough, it shows up everywhere. There isn't a woman I know who hasn't dreamed of killing her husband.

title: Arson Badly Damages Main Office of CORE
description: A fire that the authorities said was deliberately set heavily damaged the national headquarters of the Congress of Racial Equality in Brooklyn early yesterday morning.

title: Georgia Power's $250 Million Issue
description: Among the new bond issues brought to market yesterday was a $250 million offering by the Georgia Power Company. Morgan Stanley & Company heads the underwriters.

title: Texaco Wait Ends For Holmes a Court
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier who already owns 9.6 percent of Texaco Inc., said yesterday that a regulatory waiting period had expired and that he could now increase his holdings in Texaco to 15 percent.

title: Replacing Or Fixing Antique Locks
description: LEAD: THESE days antique desks and cupboards usually do not serve as safe deposit boxes.

title: Bonds Marketed By Florida Utility
description: The Florida Power and Light Company is offering $100 million of 30-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: A Dual Financing From Telemundo
description: Telemundo, a Spanish-language television network based in New York, is offering $220 million of zero coupon bonds through a two-part offering handled by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as lead manager.

title: Reagan Press Aide Named
description: President Reagan today announced the appointment of B. Jay Cooper as a deputy White House press secretary, focusing on domestic issues. Mr. Cooper, 37 years old, has been director of public affairs and press secretary at the Commerce Department since 1983. He will succeed Albert R. Brashear, who took a job in private industry. A former editor for The Waterbury, (Conn.) Republican and American newspapers, he served as communications director for the Reagan-Bush campaign in Connecticut in 1980.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a charge of $15,451,000 from the writedown of oil and gas properties and other unusual items of $310,000.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Symbol Technologies to Arthur Kramer Advertising, Jericho, L.I., for its portable laser scanners.

title: Pope Played a Complex Role in Waldheim Visit
description: To the Editor:

title: Napa Valley's Stylish Newcomers
description: OVER the last two decades, newcomers to the Napa Valley have come in search of the good life, the better grape and the finest wines. As a result of the influx of wine lovers - some of them name-brand wine lovers like Fritz Maytag, Lillian Disney, Francis Ford Coppola and Baron Philippe de Rothschild - an agricultural valley that long belonged to Napa's old farming families has gradually been gentrified. A prime acre priced at $7,500 a decade ago sells today for $30,000 to $40,000.

title: A Pleasing Witch
description: To The Home Section:

title: SCHMIDT HITS 521ST TO TIE FOR 9TH PLACE
description: Mike Schmidt hit a three-run homer, tying him for ninth place on the career list with 521, and the Philadelphia Phillies beat the San Diego Padres tonight, 6-5.

title: N.F.L. Talks Friendlier
description: There is apparently a friendlier tone in talks between the National Football League and the N.F.L. Players Association to replace the contract that expires in 11 days.

title: Homeless Are Saturating Chelsea and Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Pact on Software
description: Four major personal computer hardware and software companies said they had agreed on a standard to allow software to work with memory added to I.B.M. and compatible personal computers. Previously, there were two major formats for such expanded memories, one put forth by the Intel Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation and the Lotus Development Corporation, and the other by AST Research Inc., a major manufacturer of add-in memory boards. Today, all four companies said they would support an improved version of the Intel-Lotus-Microsoft specifications that would allow the computers to use more than 640 kilobytes, or 640,000 characters, of memory.

title: The Unseemly 'Hard Sell' of Lotteries
description: LEAD: A woman runs through her office telling everybody that she just won the lottery and is quitting. One elegantly dressed couple dances while another relaxes aboard a yacht. A song proclaims, ''I got two chances at a buck a pair, and by 7:05 I was a millionaire.''

title: Mets Are Beaten By Giants in 10th
description: They waged another battle of the corked bats before 50,511 enthralled fans in Shea Stadium last night, and the Mets did not survive it.

title: ELEXIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $43,753 and $47,798 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Calling the House?
description: If you get no answer when you call the office of a member of the House of Representatives over the next few days, that may be because the House is trying to save you money.

title: Tiny Company Joins Front Ranks of AIDS Fight
description: Although most medical experts expected that some company would receive approval this year from the Food and Drug Administration for human clinical trials of an AIDS vaccine, the list of possible candidates never included Microgenesys Inc. Indeed, until this week few analysts who follow the biotechnology industry had heard of the tiny company, which is based in West Haven, Conn., and has now become the first company to get that F.D.A. approval.

title: Teach the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Freed Hostage Rejoins Family
description: Charles Glass, the American journalist who was missing in Lebanon for 62 days, celebrated his freedom with his family here today after a debriefing by United States diplomatic and intelligence officials.

title: Census Bureau Is Urged to Adjust '90 Count to Include Those Missed
description: Statisticians and Democrats in Congress are urging the Census Bureau to figure out how many people the 1990 census will fail to count and then adjust the figures to include them.

title: Marketing 'Les Miserables,' Or, Maneuvering Behind a Hit
description: ''Les Miserables,'' the lavish stage musical based on Victor Hugo's novel, officially turns into a gold mine for its investors this week. The $4.5 million show, which opened March 12 at the Broadway Theater, recoups its investment today after only 23 weeks, a notably quick rate of return for an expensive musical.

title: Bank Accord In Canada
description: Canada's banks have agreed to increase their reserves against third world loans to more than double their present levels.

title: KELLEY OIL & GAS PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings represent units.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 20, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Computers Generate Monopoly Game Strategy
description: A computer enthusiast and Monopoly fanatic who spent six months testing tactics says his how-to manual reduces the role of chance for investors in Boardwalk and Park Place - and maybe even Wall Street.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Finance Briefs column of Business Day on Friday misidentified the issuer of notes sold through Kidder, Peabody & Company. It is the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

title: LETTER FROM POPE CITES SUFFERING OF JEWS IN 1940'S
description: Pope John Paul II has written an emotion-laden letter that addresses Jewish suffering during the Holocaust and appears to be a conciliatory gesture toward Jews angered by his audience with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria.

title: For Chancellor, Someone Like . . .
description: Who should take over as head of New York City's troubled school system? A distinguished committee of outside advisers will help the Board of Education identify candidates to succeed Nathan Quinones. The corporate community wants a person who will foster a new alliance between business and education; minority leaders call for a black or a Hispanic. But the most basic requirement is leadership: the schools need a tough administrator of stature who is capable of inspiring a demoralized educational system.

title: U.S. Decides to Send Its Envoy Back to Syria
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to send the United States Ambassador to Syria back to his post in Damascus around Sept. 1, two American officials said today.

title: Meese Cautions China on Laws
description: United States Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reminded China today that it must provide attractive conditions to entice American investors, who have grown wary of what some call the inconsistency and unpredictability of the Chinese system.

title: OLD SPAGHETTI WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MHP MACHINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $20,000, while year-ago period net includes a tax credit of $34,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,000.

title: Quilting Comes Into Its Own as an Art
description: Every Wednesday, the women of Grace Lutheran Church gather with their thimbles and shears to share neighborhood news, boast about their grandchildren and quilt.

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
De Laurentiis Fills Position
description: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc., an independent film maker, said today that it had filled the newly created position of director of internal audit, one day after the company was charged with accounting infractions.

title: U.S.-Europe Options Link
description: The American Stock Exchange said that starting Monday its popular Major Market Index option contract would be traded on the European Options Exchange. The contract would be the first American options contract to be traded on a foreign exchange.

title: Library Missing Eight James Letters
description: The Library of Congress reported today that it was missing a total of eight letters written by the novelist Henry James, and that they might be linked to a series of recent thefts from the library and the National Archives.

title: Swiss Bank Ends Bid For Hill Samuel Group
description: In a surprise move, the Union Bank of Switzerland said today that it was no longer seeking to acquire the Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., the British merchant bank and financial services firm.

title: Jackson Return Feeble
description: Bo Jackson of the Kansas City Royals, who recently lost his regular job in left field to Lonnie Smith, was in the starting lineup on Monday and Tuesday for the first time since Aug. 7 because Danny Tartabull, the right fielder, had a sore arm. Jackson, the rookie who will play pro football for the Los Angeles Raiders as a ''hobby'' later this year, did not do much in the two games against the Rangers at Arlington, Tex., to win his way back into the starting lineup.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Advisory Panel of 7 to Help In Search for Schools Chief
description: A seven-member advisory group will help the New York City Board of Education select a new schools chancellor, and the appointment will be made by early November, the board's president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday.

title: P.&G. Splits Duties Of Former Ad Chief
description: When the Procter & Gamble Company looked around to replace the late Robert V. Goldstein, who had been in charge of all of its consumer advertising, it decided to split those duties between two men who had been with the company all of their professional lives.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
RESULTS PLUS
description: Swimming 2 World Records Lowered: A West German relay team and Tamas Darnyi of Hungary set world records yesterday at the European championships in Strasbourg, France. In the 800-meter freestyle relay, Peter Sitt, Rainer Henkel, Thomas Fahrner and Michael Gross combined for a time of 7 minutes 13.10 seconds to better the 7:15.69 mark set by the United States at the 1984 Olympics. The second-place team from East Germany also bettered the old mark, finishing in 7:14.27. Darnyi set a mark in the 400-meter individual medley race with a time of 4:15.42. Darnyi's mark bettered the 4:16.12 set by Dave Wharton of the United States less than a week ago in the Pan-Pacific Games in Brisbane, Australia.(AP) Cycling Rosola Edges Phinney: Italy's Paolo ?osola edged Davis Phinney in the final turn to become the latest Coors International Classic stage winner. In women's stage 6 competition, Peggy Maass of Orange, Conn., won the Vail Criterium Gold medal.(AP) Tennis Evert Defeats Gomer: Top-seeded Chris Evert overcame a slow start yesterday to beat Britain's Sara Gomer, 6-3, 6-2, in a second-round match at the $293,000 Player's Challenge tennis tournament in Toronto. Evert split the first six games with her 23-year-old opponent.(AP)

title: White House Said to Pick a Replacement Chef
description: The White House has selected a Florida hotel chef for the post of executive chef from among 20 contenders, the retiring chef, Henry Haller, said yesterday.

title: ATKINSON, GUY F CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEY RATES
SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Worker at Zoo Is Shot to Death In Bronx Attack
description: An off-duty Bronx Zoo employee was shot to death and a co-worker was slashed yesterday when they were attacked by a group of eight youths that included the jealous boyfriend of another zoo worker, the police said.

title: Refurbished Glory Of Rooftop Gardens
description: AT 6:30 A.M., before the sun has slipped onto Fifth Avenue, Dave Murbach, manager of the gardens division of Rockefeller Center, watches birds forage in new plantings on the center's four seventh-story rooftops.

title: EDUCATIONAL COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed July 17.

title: Forty Niner Wins the Sanford
description: The 2-year-old season officially began today at Saratoga Race Track because Woody Stephens finally made it to the winner's circle with a promising young colt.

title: Brock Has Eye Operation
description: William E. Brock, the Secretary of Labor, was reported in good condition today at Georgetown University Hospital after an eye operation. Mr. Brock underwent surgery Tuesday for a detached retina, which he suffered last weekend.

title:
Market Place;
Schwab Turns To the Public
description: LEAD: FOR the second time in this decade, Charles Schwab & Company is trying to go public. The nation's largest discount broker headed down this route in 1980. But plans for an initial public offering were shelved and Schwab was ultimately sold in 1983 to the BankAmerica Corporation.

title: Backers of Inmates' Rights Criticize the State for Adding Prison Beds
description: Advocates of prisoners' rights expressed concern yesterday about the Cuomo administration's decision to install 1,000 additional beds in state prisons, saying the move could dangerously aggravate tensions in the crowded state prison system.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Like Marsupials
description: Once there was a summer when every other young woman in Manhattan wore a droopy white cotton hat. A few summers later, every other young woman wore a wraparound batik skirt. This was followed by the summer of the pink-and-blue-plastic-vegetables-on-an-elastic-band bracelet.

title: Norway Oil Output Up
description: Norwegian oil production in July rose to more than one million barrels a day, but will fall sharply this month because of maintenance shutdowns, oil companies said today. July production totaled 1.04 million barrels a day, up 20.5 percent from 828,172 barrels in June.

title: Tiny Gear Offers Students Good Fidelity and High Security
description: TINY stereo systems, pocket-size television sets and miniature tape recorders are becoming standard gear for college students these days.

title: TELEBYTE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 11, about a midyear report of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, misidentified the deficit about which the Democratic majority warned. It was the nation's foreign debt, not the trade deficit. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the foreign debt; at the end of last year, it totaled $263.6 billion.

title: Supplying the Props for War Films
description: When Stanley Kubrick wanted some palm trees, vehicles and military uniforms for his movie ''Full Metal Jacket,'' he called Charley Biggs.

title: Iran Shows Off Its Minesweeping In Tour of Zone in Gulf of Oman
description: Only miles from the waters where American warships were escorting Kuwaiti tankers to protect them against possible Iranian mine and rocket attack, Iran flew foreign journalists to the Gulf of Oman today to watch its navy put on a demonstration of clearing mines that, Washington says, Iran laid in the first place. It was an unusual day. Even though the Iranians assiduously demonstrated their latest minesweeping equipment and techniques, they steadfastly refused to discuss who might have laid the mines that have caused so much concern.

title: Ex-Garbo Duesenberg Sells for $1.4 Million
description: A Texas millionaire bought Greta Garbo's custom-built 1933 Duesenberg convertible Tuesday night at a benefit auction for $1.4 million.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch yesterday from Irvine, Calif., about growth in Orange County described the Maginot Line incorrectly. France built the line, a system of heavy fortifications on its eastern border, in the years before World War II.

title: Humphery Signs Reluctantly
description: Unlike some of their players on the field, the Jets' front office successfully held the line today as the club broke through the holdout ranks and signed Bobby Humphery.

title: Housekeeping Today: Just a Lick and a Promise
description: LEAD: THE oven hasn't been cleaned in weeks. The floors need a shine.

title: Immigrant's Family Pins Hope on Amnesty
description: For Wilton Beach, a 61-year-old retired policeman from Trinidad, the Federal amnesty program for illegal aliens has been nothing short of a blessing.

title: Moody's Lowers Rating Of 2 Japanese Concerns
description: Debt ratings of the Mitsubishi Corporation and the Sumitomo Corporation were downgraded yesterday by Moody's Investors Service. The rating of Mitsui & Company, another Japanese concern, was affirmed.

title: Buyout Gives Viacom Loss
description: Viacom Inc., the company created in June when National Amusements Inc. acquired Viacom International Inc., said yesterday that expenses related to the takeover had resulted in a net loss of $6.68 million in the quarter ended June 30.

title: U.S. ENVOY URGES END OF APARTHEID
description: Edward J. Perkins, the United States' first black Ambassador to South Africa, said today that his country and other Western nations must continue pushing for ''the complete elimination of discrimination and exclusion in South Africa.''

title: Advertising; David Deutsch Receives Three New Accounts
description: David Deutsch Associates announced yesterday that it had received three accounts.

title: Broadway Music, Live on WQXR
description: An hour of live music from Broadway shows will be broadcast on WQXR AM (1560) and FM (96.3), Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Several Broadway performers will appear during the show, including Janet Williams Adderley from ''Starlight Express'' and John Ehrlich and George Merritt from ''Big River.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE Quilted Giraffe, which has reopened in its dramatically designed new home at the A.T.&T. arcade, formerly the site of the Casual Quilted Giraffe, is serving lunch for the first time to try to attract the sort of big-league corporate clients that frequent the Four Seasons, La Cote Basque and Aurora.

title: Watershed for the Homeless
description: In the third day of argument, the Board of Estimate's dispute over shelters for New York's homeless came down to a choice between principle and fear: Is it better to improve emergency accommodations for homeless families or to defer to exaggerated anxieties in neighborhoods that might house shelters?

title: Singer's Offices Move to Jersey
description: The Singer Company said it had moved its executive offices here from Stamford, Conn., possibly for protection from a hostile takeover bid. Singer's move came after the oilman T. Boone Pickens announced earlier this month that his Mesa Limited Partnership owned 4.4 percent of the aerospace electronics company's shares and might acquire up to 15 percent.

title: Course Flooded
description: A decision will be made Friday morning on when, where and if the first round of the flood-delayed Western Open golf tournament will be played.

title: KEY RATES
Giants Trade Bobby Johnson
description: There were developments on three fronts involving personnel at the Giants' camp today:

title: Phone Calls From the Fast Lane: Life Inside a Freeway Telephone Booth
description: It is 4:00 P.M. in Southern California and the freeways have become one big moving telephone booth.

title: What Privacy Case Says of Bork's Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 21, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY
