title: 1 Assist for Twins in Loss
description: Doyle Alexander pitched a five-hitter over eight innings and Chet Lemon hit a two-run double in the fourth inning today to lead the Detroit Tigers to an 8-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins. The victory gave Detroit a sweep of a three-game series with the Twins.

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble, conducted by Stephen Somary, will perform works by Haydn and Britten and a set of Puerto Rican art songs, featuring Puli Toro, a mezzo-soprano, as soloist. The program will be performed twice on Sunday: at 2 P.M. at Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, and at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall on the Fordham University Bronx Rose Hill Campus at Southern Boulevard. Admission is free. Information: (212) 549-1899.

title: Uniform Rating on Tampon Absorbency Is Urged
description: Scientists from the Centers for Disease Control urged today that tampons be better labeled to help women avoid toxic shock syndrome, a rare but potentially lethal illness that continues to strike hundreds of women each year.

title: No Women's Rights Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: McMahon-Ditka Rift
description: It didn't take long for a rift to develop between Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears and his quarterback, Jim McMahon. McMahon skipped practice yesterday, and an angry Ditka said McMahon would be fined for his absence and would not play tomorrow night against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Living in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Astros Sweep Cardinals, 5-4
description: Scoring two runs in the seventh inning on a sacrifice fly by Glenn Davis and an error by the third baseman, Jose Oquendo, the Houston Astros rallied to a 5-4 victory today and a sweep of their three-game series with the St. Louis Cardinals, the leaders of the National League East.

title: Owners Close a Mine In South Africa Strike
description: Mine owners, in the toughest response yet to the strike by black miners, today announced the closing of a gold shaft, threatened to shut down another and planned a lockout at a third.

title: AUCTIONS
description: DESPITE all the hoopla about Beatles anniversaries, many rock-and-roll fans still have trouble believing that it has been 23 years since the premiere of ''A Hard Day's Night.'' But it has been that long, long enough for the script of the Beatles' first major film to become a collector's item. It will be offered next week at one of two London sales that promise to provide fresh evidence of the Beatles' enduring popularity.

title: Shade in the Park
description: A tour of Central Park's esthetic underbelly - those romantically Gothic arches that pierce embankments along the drives - can keep you out of the sun and fill you with a renewed appreciation of the care and details that went into this expanse. Short, squat and somewhat dank, the arches of Central Park are nonetheless exuberant, rhythmic and well-ordered architectural compositions that seem to have been carved out of the rustic landscape. They can be quite surprising, too. From a distance, the Dipway Arch, near Seventh Avenue, appears handsome but no-nonsense. As you get closer, however, you see that there is a fanciful arcade within. Seven tall but shallow brick niches, each framed by an arch with keystone, line both sides of the tunnel. Quite different is the next arch to the northeast, Driprock, which has a deeply coffered ceiling and recessed panels along the walls, looking something like a brick rib cage. To the northeast again is Willowdell Arch, which combines an arcade and coffered ceiling. Willowdell also has a poignant reminder of a day when these arches truly functioned as subterranean oases: an ornate drinking fountain, its plumbing stilled, its basin long ago shattered.

title: Agency Acts to Speed Times Sq. Project
description: Insisting that the rebuilding of 42d Street was imminent, New York State officials took steps yesterday to hasten condemnation of private property around Times Square and to change the use of a huge parcel across Eighth Avenue from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, a site that was to have been a computer and apparel mart.

title: Top Swiss Court Backs U.S. Bid For Bank Data
description: Switzerland's highest court, rejecting the claims of several leading figures in the Iran-contra affair, gave the go-ahead today for Swiss banks to turn over confidential documents to American prosecutors in the case.

title: Ethical Omission
description: In a recent mailing to his Manhattan constituents, State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, a Democrat and the minority leader, portrays himself as a champion of government ethics. The four-page newsletter reports on the state's sweeping new ethics code, which he rightly hails as a step toward ''greater accountability for government expenditures for employees and services.''

title: Haulers Resume Trash Collection In North Jersey
description: Normal trash collection in four northern New Jersey counties resumed today after state regulators granted certain garbage haulers a reprieve from higher dumping costs at the state's largest landfill.

title: A Subtle Addition to Status of Travers
description: None of the owners really need the money and no horse is running because of it, but the sensational field that Saturday's Travers Stakes has attracted probably has a lot to do with the fact that it was made a $1 million race this year.

title: Some Pharmacies Quote Prices Far Over Cost for AIDS Drug, New York Study Finds
description: A handful of pharmacists in New York State may be making exorbitant profits - sometimes thousands of dollars above cost - for the only federally approved drug proven to prolong the lives of AIDS patients, according to a study released yesterday by the state's Consumer Protection Board.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch in some copies yesterday from Hungerford, England, about a gunman's rampage reversed the order of the first two killings. The gunman killed a woman in a woodland, then returned home and killed his mother, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Wilander Falls in an Upset: Peter Lundgren of Sweden used crisp passing shots and aggressive net play to score the biggest upset of the $375,000 Association of Tennis Professionals Tournament, beating top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-1, 6-4, yesterday afternoon in Mason, Ohio. Lundgren is ranked 79th; Wilander, the defending champion, is ranked second. Also advancing to the quarterfinals were second-seeded Stefan Edberg and eighth-seeded Anders Jarryd, both of Sweden, and fourth-seeded Jimmy Connors and seventh-seeded Brad Gilbert of the United States.(AP) Potter Edges Mandlikova: Barbara Potter, who withdrew from a doubles match because of a back injury the night before, upset second-seeded Hana Mandlikova, 6-4, 6-4, moving into the quarterfinals of the Player's Challenge tennis tournament in Toronto. Potter beat Mandlikova for the first time in eight meetings. (AP) Cycling Mexican Takes the Lead: Raul Alcala of Mexico became the men's leader in the Coors International Bicycle Classic yesterday in the Golden-to-Estes Park Road Race in Colorado. In the women's event, Jeannie Longo of France held her commanding lead by finishing first in the women's seventh stage. Alcala completed the 74-mile mountainous course in 3 hours 30 minutes and 18 seconds to reclaim the red winner's jersey that had belonged to Jeff Pierce for 11 days. A spill in the first lap of the women's race downed three riders and helped Longo establish an early lead that she never relinquished. Longo, of Grenoble, France, was alone when she crossed the finish line of the 27-mile race in 1 hour 11 minutes 14 seconds. Longo's victory increased her overall lead in the women's race to 3:58.(AP)

title: Time Sharing on the Connecticut Shore
description: At the close of the 1930's, when Catskill hotels were fashionable resorts for Jewish families from New York City, Bill Hahn, a hotelier and showman, thought he would be able to attract some Catskill devotees to a similar hotel by the shore if he could find a suitable property.

title: Rangers Add One
description: The Rangers signed Jay Caufield, a 22-year-old right wing who spent most of last season with Flint of the International Hockey League and New Haven of the American Hockey League.

title: Iran and Saudis Differ on '43 Incident in Mecca
description: To the Editor:

title: Abdullah Ibrahim
description: Abdullah Ibrahim, a pianist, is to lead his septet, Ekaya - featuring Carlos Ward and Sonny Fortune on saxophones - tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Yankees Lose in 12 Innings
description: The Yankees were one out away from a sweep of the Seattle Mariners, but it got away. Dave Righetti gave up the tying run in the ninth inning and Brad Arnsberg allowed the deciding run in the 12th when Harold Reynolds hit a bases-loaded sacrifice fly to center field to give the Mariners a 4-3 victory at the Kingdome.

title: Bonds Gain in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury bonds recovered along with the dollar yesterday. But dealers attributed the recovery in bonds to some nervous short-covering in a thin summer market that was still basically bearish.

title: Manhattan With Ice
description: What's cool and cool?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * First Illinois Corp., Evanston, Ill., a bank holding company, announced the resignation of Howard B. Silverman as chairman, president and a director, saying he plans to pursue other interests. Replacing him as chairman and chief executive is William C. Croft. The company also announced the appointments of Bruce I. McPhee as president and chief operating officer of its First Illinois Bank Group and John N. Brincat as president and chief operating officer of its First Illinois Financial Services Group. Both were also elected directors of the parent company. In addition, James A. Doyle was promoted to executive vice president and chief financial officer of the holding company.

title: Advertising; Magazine Ad Pages Up
description: In July, members of the Publishers Information Bureau, representing most of the country's largest magazines, carried a total 9,312.27 ad pages, a 6.4 percent increase over last year. Estimated revenues for the month were $320.6 million, a jump of 7.9 percent compared with July 1986.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Orchestra Calalu, Central Park North, 110th Street at Lenox Avenue (675-8189). The grand finale of this season's Musica Para Hot Sundays series, presented by Yomoma Arts Inc., will feature the 12-piece Orchestra Calalu, led by Eric Darton, performing fusions of African, jazz and zydeco. Formed three years ago, the band has created a repertory of collectively developed pieces for Afro-Caribbean instruments and salsa horn section. Also appearing is the Johnny Colon Orchestra, a 10-piece salsa band led by the director of the East Harlem School, and the Larocque Bey Dance Company, a Harlem-based young people's troupe performing contemporary interpretations of traditional African dance. Kwok, a Hong Kong-born, New York-based environmental and performance artist, is presenting on-site installations that use plastic bags and giant calligraphy. Festivities begin Sunday at 2 P.M. and continue until 8. Admission is free.

title: 2 CARGO JETS CRASH ON GROUND
description: Two cargo jets - one landing, the other taxiing from a runway - collided this morning at Stewart International Airport, officials said.

title: Brooklyn Battle Site
description: A walk through the Brooklyn neighborhood where the ''Battle of Long Island'' was fought during the Revolutionary War is planned for Sunday at 1 P.M. by the Prospect Park Environmental Center. The tour, in the Park Slope section, will begin at the Lefferts Homestead in Prospect Park (enter from Flatbush Avenue, north of Empire Boulevard) and will cover the park and nearby streets. Admission: $4. Information: (718) 788-8500.

title: North Keeps 'Busy'
description: How does Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North spend his time now that he is not conducting covert activities for the National Security Council or testily testifying before Congressional committees?

title: LAYOFFS AT G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would eliminate one of the two shfts at its assembly Plant in Wentzville, Mo., slowing production of Buick Electra and Park Avenue models, and of Oldsmobile 98 and Delta 88 models. The company said the move, scheduled for Oct. 19, would idle about 2,700 of the plant's 5,800 employees.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A San Francisco dispatch yesterday about a dispute over census figures misidentified the president and general counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund. She is Antonia Hernandez.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Up at Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Aug. 14 rose by 62.7 million, or 13 percent, to a record 546.3 million shares. The previous high of 483.6 million shares was set in the month prior, which ended July 15. The period a year earlier totaled 374.9 million shares.

title: Art: 'Art Nouveau Bing' At the Cooper-Hewitt
description: ''ART NOUVEAU BING,'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, is a well-deserved and consistently seductive tribute to a man who mated great business ability with an evangelical connoisseurship. In Paris at the turn of the century it was Siegfried Bing, as much as anyone, who set the tone of the new, not only in the decorative arts but to a certain extent in painting and printmaking as well.

title: L.I. Baymen Join Scientists Studying Deaths of Marine Life
description: With their work-hardened hands and deep suntans, Bob Wemyss and Vito Randazzo are not the type normally seen at academic conferences. But today they sat in the front row of a stuffy room at Hofstra University, listening carefully as scientists delivered their detailed, complicated papers.

title: British Rail Invites Bids
description: British Rail, the state-owned transportation company, said it had invited six bidders, including the General Motors Corporation and the General Electric Company, to compete for a contract to supply it with 100 diesel locomotives for hauling freight.

title: A Welcome Attack on Davis-Bacon
description: The Davis-Bacon Act was conceived during the Depression as a way to protect Northern construction workers, most of them white, from job competition on Federal projects with Southern blacks who would work for less money. The law is still on the books, 56 years later, inflating the cost of Government construction and sticking taxpayers for the gravy. Now, however, the Justice Department has issued a welcome ruling that may limit the scope of Davis-Bacon.

title: Vote Sought on Playoff
description: An N.C.A.A. committee recommended today that member schools vote next January on whether they want a football playoff to determine the national champion.

title: Apparent Lapse On Wing Flaps Shocks Experts
description: Aviation experts said today that they were astonished to learn the wing slats had apparently not been extended for takeoff on the Northwest Airlines jet that crashed here Sunday. They said setting the position of wing slats and flaps is as basic as closing a car door before driving away.

title: Aide Denies Shultz Tie to South Africa Contra Aid
description: The State Department denied today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz had supported a proposal in 1984 to obtain aid from South Africa for the rebels in Nicragua.

title: Samuel Lubell Is Dead at 76; Predicted Election Outcomes
description: Samuel Lubell, a writer and public opinion analyst whose door-bell-ringing technique of voter interviews led him to successful predictions of winning candidates and issues in the 1950's and '60's, died Sunday of a stroke at a Los Angeles nursing home. He was 76 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: A Welcome Pollution: Currency at Seashore
description: Dead dolphins and medical syringes have washed ashore in some New Jersey seashore communities this summer, but in this one, residents are finding money.

title: MARY COVER JONES
description: Mary Cover Jones, most remembered for the Oakland Growth Study of youths at the Institute of Human Development at the University of California at Berkeley, has died at the age of 91.

title: Iran Says It Doesn't Oppose U.S. Escort of Gulf Tankers
description: Iran is prepared to tolerate American military escorts of Kuwaiti tankers in the Persian Gulf, the spokesman for the nation's Supreme Defense Council said today.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Killed By Hit-Run Driver in Bronx
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was killed late yesterday in the Bronx when a car that was involved in a collision on the Major Deegan Expressway suddenly accelerated and struck him as he attempted to approach it, the police said.

title: The Fugs Look Back to 1967's 'Summer of Love'
description: LOOKING back 20 years to the ''summer of love,'' when hordes of long-haired flower children roamed the streets of the East Village, Ed Sanders, one of the pied pipers of 60's counterculture, said he felt more than a twinge of nostalgia.

title: BERLIN TRIBUTE
description: Charles Strouse, the composer of ''Annie'' and other Broadway shows, is to present a tribute to Irving Berlin tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Summer-pier series at the Sougt Street Seaport Museum's Pier 16, Fulton and South Streets (669-9424). Admission is free.

title: 2,600 Flee Leak at Air Base
description: White phosphorus leaked from a storage tank at the Buckley Air National Guard base today, catching fire and forcing the evacuation of about 2,600 people, the authorities said. The volatile substance was contained in a 4,000-gallon railroad tanker that had arrived from the Rocky Mountain Arsenal last fall, a base spokesman said. He said the tanker had been presumed to be empty, but instead had a small residue of white phosphorus. He said that it appeared the blaze had started after the tank tipped over, but that details were sketchy.

title: Indictments At Bank in Chinatown
description: The United Orient Bank in New York's Chinatown and five of its officers were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday on charges of failing to report cash transactions exceeding $10,000.

title: Some Limits Supported For Intern Work Hours
description: The Greater New York Hospital Association yesterday endorsed proposals to limit the working hours of residents and interns in emergency rooms and to require doctors to be on duty at all times to supervise them.

title: LATIN PEACE PLAN SAID TO BE SLOWED BY HONDURAS VIEW
description: Central American foreign ministers appear to have failed to make significant progress toward carrying out a new regional peace plan in two days of meetings here, largely because of opposition from Honduras, diplomats involved in the talks said today.

title: HOW TO LOWER BODY TEMPERATURE
description: The only really effective way to treat heat stroke, say doctors, is to plunge the victim into a bath of ice water, perhaps administering a shot of phenothiazine to keep the patient from shivering unduly. This approach may be a trifle extreme for someone merely sweltering through a heat wave, but relief from simple discomfort depends upon the same principle: cooling the skin.

title: Man, 20, Is Accused of Posing As a Disaster Official in Flood
description: A man who ordered evacuations and arranged for sandbags when flooding struck this affluent suburb of Chicago last week has been arrested and accused of posing as a government disaster official, the authorities say.

title: Diversion Suspect Seized by Mounties
description: A fugitive under indictment for illegally exporting millions of dollars of computer equipment to the Soviet Union was apparently captured late Wednesday, not through a high-tech sting or amid crates of chips, but after being spotted by a Mountie while on a fishing trip in the Yukon.

title: Expecting the End, Molitor Rolls Along
description: Paul Molitor knows it will end. Maybe that's why it has gone on so long.

title: Cello and Piano
description: Joshua Gordon, cellist, and Joy Michelle Cline, pianist, will perform works by Debussy, Webern and Stravinsky tonight and tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. in the Museum of Modern Art's Sculpture Garden (14 West 54th Street). The concerts are free. Information: 708-9480.

title: Occidental to Get Nearly $1 Billion
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will receive nearly $1 billion in a complicated transaction involving the sale of 49 percent of its meatpacking subsidiary, IBP Inc. The company said it would sell 23.5 million shares for $19 to $22 a share, which could raise up to $517 million for IBP. Before the public offering, IBP would pay a $960 million dividend to Occidental, borrowing the money to do so. In turn, Occidental would pay a note for working capital owed to IBP that could range between $20 million and $90 million.

title: Refreshing Snacks
description: Even the most fervid New York diners, whose idea of an extended restaurant trend is one that lasts about as long as an American Express billing cycle, change their priorities in August. The burning question of the hour is not ''what's hot?'' but rather ''what's cool?''

title: Old Island Ways Bow to Parties and Chic
description: ''People are starting to care about what they wear,'' John Churchill said sadly as he watched the sun set over Lambert's Cove. He was wearing beat-up khakis and an old T-shirt. For 50 years Mr. Churchill, a New York lawyer, has summered on Martha's Vineyard. ''The Vineyard is becoming like the Hamptons, and the Hamptons are like New York,'' he said.

title: Ornette Coleman Music
description: John Zorn and Tim Berne on saxophones, Mark Dresser on bass and Bobby Previte on drums are to play music by Ornette Coleman tonight and tomorrow at at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Admission is $5.

title: Lyons Shares In Mets' Victory
description: Most days when Barry Lyons goes to work, he is certain of only one thing: Gary Carter will do the catching for the Mets, and Lyons will sit and watch.

title: Franklin Joins WFAN
description: Pete Franklin, a radio sports talk show host in Cleveland for more than 20 years, announced that he has signed a two-year contract worth $600,000 with WFAN-AM, the all-sports station in New York, and will begin his new job Sept. 14.

title: Talks Held With Coke About Stake in Viacom
description: Viacom International Inc. said yesterday that it had held preliminary talks with the Coca-Cola Company about the sale of a minority stake in several of its operations.

title: Appeal Challenges Manville's Plan
description: A second challenge to the Manville Corporation's bankruptcy reorganization plan has been filed in Unitrf States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York, the company said. The appeal by a building materials distributor challenges the Federal Bankruptcy Court's approval of more than $700 million in settlements between Manville and 29 insurance carriers involving payments for asbestos-related injuries.

title: Possibility of New Hart Presidential Bid Raised, Along With Doubt
description: A close associate of Gary Hart said today that he might renew the Presidential campaign he abandoned in May, and another associate said Mr. Hart was reconsidering his withdrawal.

title: China's Myopic Purge of Intellectuals
description: LEAD: Once again a dozen or so intellectuals are under attack in China. That is not unusual except that this time it contradicts all the political signals coming from Beijing.

title: Nicaraguans Call for More Protests
description: Opposition leaders said today that they plan to call more anti-Government demonstrations to test Managua's commitment to provisions of its peace accord with other Central American nations.

title: Bridge: New York Administrators Are Also Expert Players
description: In most of the country, the players do little but play and the administrators do little but administer. But the distinction is blurred in New York City, where for many years prominent players have done most of the hard work behind the scenes.

title: Bork's Worth Put at 1 Million
description: Robert H. Bork, President Reagan's nominee to the Supreme Court, has a net worth of nearly $1 million, according to documents filed with the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Those Dancing Feet
description: This may be the weekend for dancegoers to put the old summer-curry theory to the test. Those in the know, to whom a still, hot afternoon in Delhi or Madras is living to the ultimate, say that the best thing to cool the body on a scorching day is to forgo the gins and tonics and opt for a hair-raisingly hot curry. Forsake the air-conditioned apartment, then, or the cool recesses of the neighborhood movie theater. Get over to the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival tonight or the Cat Club on Sunday night. And start dancing.

title: COUNTLESS WAYS TO KEEP COOL AND CULTURED IN NEW YORK Cool as a Cucumber
description: After 14 consecutive summers in New York, I have established a rhythm of near-refrigeration that goes roughly as follows:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 21, 1987
description: International A2-7

title: U.S. Expanding Workplace Rule On Right to Know of Toxic Perils
description: The Labor Department has extended regulations requiring employers to tell workers about toxic substances to virtually every major workplace in the country.

title: Hayden Rorke, Actor In Film, Plays and TV
description: Hayden Rorke, a stage, screen and television actor whose career spanned six decades, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: New Face; At 6 Foot 3, All Knees and Elbows in 'Holy Ghosts': Don R. Manus
description: THE first thing that happened to Don R. McManus after his arrival in New York with the San Diego Repertory Theater was a mugging, which he accepts very philosophically.

title: MCA Shares Rise As Rumors Grow
description: MCA Inc. stock rose $4.125, to $63.375 a share, amid continuing rumors of either an impending restructuring or a possible takeover. But MCA's president, Sidney Sheinberg, said, ''I don't have a scintilla of information other than what has been printed.''

title: Appeals Court Ruling Reinstates Candidate for Surrogate in Bronx
description: An appellate court, in a potentially far-reaching decision, yesterday reinstated a candidate for surrogate in the Bronx who had been removed from the Sept. 15 Democratic primary ballot, and it paved the way for another candidate to rejoin the campaign.

title: Massachusetts Weighs Health Insurance for All
description: Massachusetts is moving toward enacting the nation's first system to assure health insurance for everyone, a step that could turn the state into a testing ground for an idea that has been debated in Congress for years.

title: Snake Bites Store Customer
description: A poisonous 14-inch pygmy rattler snake hiding in a plant has bitten a customer at a discount store. The customer, Edward N. Cullom, 40 years old, was hospitalized with blurred vision, nausea and a swollen hand.

title: Top Yield of 7.4% On Michigan Issue
description: The Michigan State Building Authority is offering $101.2 million of revenue bonds with tentative yields ranging from 4.5 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6.9 percent in 1997 and 7.4 percent in 2001 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Art Scholar Asserts Innocence in Letters Case
description: Charles Merrill Mount, the art historian linked to thefts from the Library of Congress and the National Archives, insisted today that he had not stolen documents from the Government and that charges against him stemmed in part from ''hysteria'' among librarians and rare-documents dealers.

title: Browning-Ferris Offers Convertible Debentures
description: Browning-Ferris Industries, a Houston-based waste-management company, yesterday began offering $300 million of 6 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: A Smattering of Suggestions On Where to Refresh Oneself
description: Here is a sampling of places that are recommended to help New Yorkers keep cool: AUNTIE YUAN, #1191A First Avenue, at 65th Street (744-4040). Open today and tomorrow, 11:30 A.M. to midnight; Sunday, 11:30 A.M. to 11 P.M. BAHAMA MAMA, #2628 Broadway, near 100th Street. Information and hours: 866-7760. BOTTOM LINE, 15 West Fourth Street. Buster Poindexter. Sets tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M. ; tickets, $11. Information: 228-6300. CAT CLUB, #76 East 13th Street. Lindy-hopping free-for-all, Sunday from 8 P.M. to midnight; admission, $8 ($4 for the elderly). Information: 505-0090. CLOISTERS, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fort Tryon Park. Open today through Sunday, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Admission, $5 ($2.50 for students and the elderly; free for those under 12). Information: 923-3700. DEAN & DELUCA'S, 121 Prince Street (431-1691). GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL, 12 East 12th Street (925-2415). Today, noon to 2:15 P.M. and 6 to 11:15 P.M.; tomorrow, 6 to 11:15 P.M.; Sunday, 5:30 to 9:30 P.M. LEXINGTON MARKET, 852 Lexington Avenue, at 65th Street (861-8051). LINCOLN CENTER, Out-of-Doors festival, Damrosch Park. Tonight at 8:15, Country Dance Party. Information: 877-4804. MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, #11 West 53d Street. Hours today through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission, $5 ($3.50 for students; $2 for the elderly; free for those under 16). Information: 708-9480. NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, the Bronx. Grounds are open today through Sunday 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.; admission is free. The Conservatory Garden is open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; admission $2.50 ($1.25 for children and the elderly), free on Saturdays from 10 A.M. to noon. Information: 220-8700. NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. Weekend hours, Friday and Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; closed Sunday. Information: 661-7220 or 869-8089. NEW YORK STATE THEATER, New York City Opera; today at 8 P.M., ''Le Nozze di Figaro''; tomorrow at 2 P.M., ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci''; tomorrow at 8 P.M., ''Die Zauberflote.'' Tickets for tonight and tomorrow afternoon range from $8 to $32; tomorrow at 8 P.M., only partial-view seats are available, ranging in price from $12 to $32. Information: 870-5570. ORCHARD BEACH, Pelham Bay Park, Bronx. Latin pop, jazz and salsa concert, Sunday, from 1 to 9 P.M. Free. Information: 885-3371. JOSEPH PATELSON MUSIC HOUSE, 160 West 56th Street (582-5840). Today, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. PETROSSIAN, 182 West 58th Street (245-2214). Today, 11:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. and 5:30 to midnight; tomorrow, 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Closed Sunday. RUSSIAN TEA ROOM, 150 West 57th Street (265-0947). Today, 11:30 A.M. to 11:30 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 11:30 P.M. BESSIE SCHONBERG THEATER, #219 West 19th Street. Out-of-Towners series; ''Crosstalk,'' tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Admission, $8; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Information: 924-0077. SKYRINK, 450 West 33d Street, at 10th Avenue. Skating sessions, today, 8 to 10:30 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday, 1 to 3 P.M. and 3:15 to 5:15 P.M.; Admission, $7 tonight, $6.50 tomorrow and Sunday; skate rental, $2. Information: 695-6555. STATEN ISLAND FERRY, the Battery and the St. George Terminal in Staten Island. Continuous departures, 24 hours a day. Admission, 25 cents. Information: 806-940 or (718) 390-5253. TOMMY TANG'S SIAMESE CAFE, 323 Greenwich Street, at Duane Street (334-9190). Today, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 6 to midnight; tomorrow, 6 P.M. to midnight; Closed Sunday. WORLD TRADE CENTER OBSERVATION DECK, Tower 2, lower Manhattan. Open daily, 9:30 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Admission, $2.95 ($1.50 for those 6 to 12 and the elderly; free for those under 6). Information: 466-7377.

title: Hormel Group in Town
description: More than a dozen former employees of the Geo. A. Hormel & Company, maker of Spam and other meat products, came to the capital this week to protest what they say is unfair treatment by both the company and the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union.

title: Soviet Spokesman Describes Parley With Israelis in Bonn
description: Soviet and Israeli Foreign Ministry officials have held talks in Bonn on the Middle East situation, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said today.

title: PHONE RATES CUT FOR POOR PEOPLE IN NEW YORK STATE
description: Poor people in New York State will be able to get basic telephone service for as little as a dollar a month under a plan adopted by the state's Public Service Commission.

title: Sallie Mae Sells Notes Due in 1991
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $100 million of 8.55 percent fixed-rate notes due in 1991 at a price of par through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities Inc.

title: Let Public In on Search For School Chancellor
description: To the Editor:

title: Eulogies, and Schubert, for a String Quartet
description: Three generations of classical musicians gathered today to grieve doubly at the death of a violist and the demise of the Amadeus String Quartet, long a beacon in the resurgence of postwar culture.

title: Merc Weighs London Link
description: The board of the New York Mercantile Exchange has voted to explore an evening trading session and to pursue a link with London's International Petroleum Exchange.

title: 4 Youths Arrested in Slaying Of Custodian Union's Leader
description: Four Bronx youths were arrested last night and charged with the murder of Daniel F. Conlin, the head of the school custodians' union who was shot to death Aug. 12 on the street near his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Signing Day
description: The Devils yesterday reached agreement on contract terms with Brendan Shanahan, their first pick in the National Hockey League's June draft and the second pick over all.

title: It's Time to Get S.D.I. Off the Ground
description: Four years have passed since President Reagan announced a national effort to seek a defense against ballistic missiles. Yet the debate over strategic defense, rather than growing focused, has become largely irrelevant. Public support for the program is overwhelming. We are making tremendous technological progress. Still the critics of our Strategic Defense Initiative seem to ignore all this.

title: Microsoft Warns Of Counterfeits
description: The Microsoft Corporation said that several thousand counterfeit copies of the Redmond, Wash., company's operating software had been seized from two Northern California businesses. The seizure netted about 30,000 copies of I.B.M. PC DOS, the International Business Machines Corporation's version of the MS-DOS operating system for personal computers.

title: Amtrak Changing Stop In Eastern Westchester
description: Amtrak said today that it would move its eastern Westchester stop from Rye to New Rochelle on Oct. 25, using the existing Metro-North Commuter Railroad station instead of building a new station one mile to the south.

title: Art: 'The Social Graces, Satire at the Whitney
description: FOR all anyone knows, satire may be as old as art itself: who can be sure the Willendorf Venus was meant to be a serious portrait of womanhood? Officially, though, visual mockery in the West didn't begin until after the arrival of Protestantism and the development of the printed image. Susan Lubowsky mentions this in her introduction to the social comments that she has assembled at the Philip Morris branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: SALSA ON THE BEACH
description: A sea breeze should cool off the listeners - but not the music - in a free concert of Latin pop, jazz and salsa on Sunday at Orchard Beach in the Bronx between 1 and 9 P.M. The main attraction is Eddie Palmieri, a pianist who was born in the Bronx but now lives in Puerto Rico. Mr. Palmieri's bands have changed the course of modern salsa, beginning with his group La Perfecta, formed in 1961; where Cuban-style charanga bands had used a front line of violin and flute, La Perfecta used trombone and flute, lending the music a brassy, jazzy impetus. Mr. Palmieri also delved into modal 1960's jazz, especially the piano style of McCoy Tyner, and to those modern elements he added a thorough grounding in Cuban traditions. Now, his sets are likely to encompass traditional Yoruba drumming, jazzy solos and irresistible Afro-Cuban dance music, a free-wheeling mixture of experimentation and tradition.

title: Folk Music And Blues Outdoors
description: ''THERE are different kinds of classicism,'' Jenneth Webster, assistant producer of this summer's Lincoln Center Out-Of-Doors performance series, remarked the other day. ''Lincoln Center is known for classical music, but blues, gospel music and jazz are representative of an American kind of classicism. I think it's more than timely that we are recognizing these different kinds of classicism now; it's important.''

title: Going to Coney Island to Visit the Aquarium
description: THE world's most famous roller coaster and hot-dog emporium may be just down the boardwalk in one of America's best-known beach communities, but the dolphins and whales and 22,000 other creatures at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island rarely make the sort of splash that their honky-tonk neighbors do.

title: Market Place; Merger Talk In Textiles
description: THE recent $2.8 billion acquisition of the textile field's largest producer, Burlington Industries, by a management-supported investment group led by Morgan Stanley & Company seems to have set the stage for more mergers.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A CAPTIVE LION: The Life of Marina Tsvetayeva. By Elaine Feinstein. 289 pages. Illustrated. E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: 21 Rikers Inmates Are Hurt in Brawl About Phone
description: A dispute over the use of a jail telephone erupted into a brawl between 44 black and Hispanic inmates in a Rikers Island dormitory Wednesday night, the New York City Correction Department said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't mix in politics. I must be all things to all people.'' - Mother Teresa, in Moscow. [ A5:4. ]

title: His Watergate Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Chase Executive To 'Pick Up Pace'
description: Richard J. Boyle, named yesterday a vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation and head of its global bank, says he hopes ''to pick up the pace now that the strategy has been set.''

title: DOLLAR GAINS SLIGHTLY ON EVE OF G.N.P. REPORT
description: The dollar inched up yesterday in nervous seesaw trading after four days of decline, and continued to rise this morning when the Tokyo foreign exchange market opened.

title: Crucial Vote for Koch: The Mayor's Power Is Reassessed
description: Mayor Koch's third term, now in its 20th month, has not proved as triumphant as he and his top aides must have anticipated after he won re-election in November 1985 with nearly four of every five votes cast.

title: Go-Ahead for Shelter Plan Generates Visions of Ruin
description: Over the years, even as he watched his neighborhood deteriorate, Carlo Formisano, who lives in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, had held onto the hope that the area would flourish again.

title: SOVIET GETS A PLEA BY MOTHER TERESA
description: Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun who has built a small empire of good works, arrived in Moscow today and said she hoped the Soviet Government would let her set up a charity mission near Chernobyl.

title: Howard Beach Case Defense To Request Ruling on Perjury
description: Lawyers for several white youths indicted in the Howard Beach assault case said yesterday that they would ask the judge to determine if one of the surviving black men had committed perjury that warranted dismissal of the charges.

title: Right On, Susan: Up Against The Cabana Wall
description: Another hot summer is winding down, but the great cabana controversy here drones on.

title: Allies Transfer Hess's Body To Bavaria for Family Burial
description: The Allies today returned the body of Rudolf Hess to Bavaria for burial, and concern grew that his grave could become a shrine for neo-Nazis.

title: Cuomo's Son Cleared In Hirschfeld Dispute
description: An Appellate Division disciplinary committee has cleared Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, of charges that he acted unethically in a dispute with Abraham Hirschfeld, the developer who sought the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor last year.

title: Gamble In Nicaragua
description: Let's stand back a minute and see what is happening to the peace proposals for Nicaragua before they are killed by a fascinating combination of American enthusiasts of the Sandinistas, haters of the President and conservatives who once devoted their political lives to supporting him.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 393 money market mutual funds increased $1.86 billion, to $244.49 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 101 institutional funds grew $383.7 million, to $67.24 billion. The 201 general purpose funds were up $1.13 billion, to $70.15 billion. The 91 broker-dealer funds were up $343.1 million, to $107.10 billion.

title: Marine's Defense Is Seeking Second Motion for a Mistrial
description: The defense in the espionage trial of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree will present a second motion for a mistrial on Friday, when the case is scheduled to move to closed-door deliberation by the jury of eight Marine Corps officers without the testimony of a single defense witness.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Nygene Corp., a new biotechnology company in Yonkers, to Barnum Communications, a health-care marketing communications agency.

title: 'Tempest's' Villain, Ethyl Eichelberger, Is a Real Fire-Breather supposed to teach
description: Ethyl Eichelberger has peopled the stage with characters that are larger than life, many times more exotic, and yet curiously endearing. There was his Clytemnestra, for instance, a heroic figure singing a vaudevillian tune, and a demented King ''Leer'' inspired by ''white-haired father images'' like Colonel Sanders of Kentucky Fried Chicken fame.

title: Savon of Cuba Dominates Bent
description: Despite an impressive performance by Michael Bent of Cambria Heights, Queens, 19-year-old Felix Savon of Cuba tonight won a unanimous decision to become his nation's tenth fighter to advance to a championship match at the Pan American Games.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: FIRST they contended with rush-hour traffic to get to Pier 86 at the western end of 46th Street. Then they trudged the length of a long city block to where the tugboat Hackensack was docked. Then they had to step over a sliver of lapping water and clamber over the side of the gently rocking tug.

title: Out of the Black Box: A Crash Replay
description: The flight data recorder retrieved from the Northwest Airlines plane that crashed Sunday has preserved a wealth of data to be analyzed by aviation sleuths seeking to discover the cause of the accident. But experts acknowledge that even the most advanced flight recorders may miss essential clues or even fail completely in a sudden catastrophe.

title: Broadway
description: Cyma Rubin's New Musical

title: Advertising; People
description: * Lynn Seid has been promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor, at the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

title: Little Progress In Japan Talks
description: Talks between the United States and Japan this week resulted in few achievements likely to dampen protectionist sentiment in Congress, trade officials said.

title: Zendejas Released
description: The Washington Redskins have waived the place-kicker Max Zendejas, who replaced the veteran Mark Moseley last year but was dropped with one week left in the regular season after missing five field goals and five conversions in nine games.

title: BLOOD-CHILLING BOOKS
description: When the heat grows hard to bear, the kind of things I try to read are 800-page novels set in imaginary medieval kingdoms, restaurant guides by Seymour Britchky, profiles of Tama Janowitz, interviews with Gore Vidal, revisionist histories of American literature, biographies of Lillian Hellman, the thoughts of Sam Donaldson, books with titles like ''How to Raise Your Child to Be a Mensch'' (it exists), books about Bill Cosby by Lee Iaccoca (and vice versa), books that offer to help me through the midlife crisis (too late!), and anything available in paperback by Shirley Conran, Leo Buscaglia or Jimmy Breslin. I find that they can all generally be guaranteed to make my blood run cold.

title: Honeymoon at Bank Board
description: Danny Wall, the new chief regulator of the $900 billion savings and loan industry, is enjoying his honeymoon while he can.

title: Sonny Rollins
description: The tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins is leading a group that includes Monty Alexander on piano, Bob Cranshaw on bass and Marvin (Smitty) Smith on drums tomorrow on Musicruise (595-5272), a concert aboard the Hudson River Dayliner. The boat leaves Pier 81, at 41st Street and 12th Avenue, at 9 P.M. and returns at midnight; boarding begins at 8 P.M. Tickets are $20 in advance and $22.50 tomorrow, available through Ticketron (399-4444).

title: Johnson's Bat Is Cleared
description: Howard Johnson's favorite bat passed X-ray inspection yesterday for the second time in two weeks, and it was returned to him by the National League office. And Candy Maldonado of the San Francisco Giants also got clearance for his bat, which was impounded Wednesday night by the umpires at Shea Stadium when the Mets and the Giants got into the battle of the corked bats.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Joel Smith Ensemble featuring Griselle Colon and Mario Bauza, Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, between Ninth and 10th Streets (982-3260). Mario Bauza initiated Dizzy Gillespie into the mysteries of Afro-Cuban music back when they played side by side in Cab Calloway's trumpet section, and put together the first modern Latin-jazz band, Machito's Afro-Cubans. This weekend, he is celebrating the end of the Latin-jazz mini-festival he has been producing at Carlos 1 by making a rare appearance as a small group soloist. Heard on alto saxophone with his own orchestra recently, he displayed a huge, creamy sound and sculpted-from-granite phrasing reminiscent of Willie Smith or, perhaps, Pete Brown. The Joel Smith ensemble also features a new Latin-jazz vocalist, Griselle Colon. Shows are around 9:30 and 11:30 tomorrow and Sunday. Admission is $10, with a $7 minimum.

title: Not a One-Woman Team
description: For someone who stands 4 feet 11 inches, Kristie Phillips casts a long shadow. On those days her scores approach perfection and that cereal-box smile brightens the arena, her presence all but obliterates the other gymnasts on the floor.

title: New Worry for Sri Lanka: Threat to Pact by the Right
description: A pamphlet circulating earlier this year contained a prophecy widely dismissed at the time. It warned that President J. R. Jayewardene was about to conclude a secret deal to divide Sri Lanka with the help of troops from India.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 21, 1987
description: Markets

title: Orders for Boeing
description: Singapore Airlines ordered its first all-freighter version of the Boeing 747, and a West German charter carrier ordered its fourth Boeing 757-200 twinjet, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company said. The 747-200F, valued at about $100 million, is scheduled to be delivered to Singapore Airlines in August 1988. The 757, valued at about $40 million, is to be delivered to Lufttransport-Unternehmen K.G. in Dusseldorf, West Germany, in April 1988.

title: Verbal Strides
description: It comes with a navigation strut, a propulsion platform, a comfort module and a force moderator. The diagram in a New York Times ad displays sleek lines that flow from front to back. Can it be one of the Navy's new Aegis cruisers? No. At $69.99, the price is about $1 billion too low. It's a leisure shoe, for whose parts an imaginative designer has found names with a high-tech, pseudo-military ring.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Beirut dispatch on Wednesday about Charles Glass, the American hostage who is now free, gave an incomplete list of the Americans missing and believed to have been abducted in Lebanon. The dispatch listed five missing Americans but omitted three, all professors at Beirut University College who were kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987: Alann Steen, 48 years old, a communications professor; Jesse Turner, 39, a business computer professor, and Robert Polhill, 53, a business professor.

title: COUNTLESS WAYS TO KEEP COOL AND CULTURED IN NEW YORK
description: THERE is an art to keeping a cultural cool in the red-hot center of New York in midsummer. There are the snobbish coolings: a frosty maitre d'hotel or a chilly box-office person turning you down, a lowering of room temperature when you confess that you are confused about what post-modernism means, a definite freeze when you declare that you enjoyed the latest generational epic of a best-selling storyteller.

title: Film: Elliott Gould in 'Inside Out'
description: TALK about bad luck! In the space of about a week, Jimmy Morgan learns that he has lost his shirt in the stock market (a real trick these days), has his pants and underwear removed by a crooked business associate and takes a bath betting on boxing and football (even college games). Not only that, but Jimmy's estranged wife notifies him that she is taking his adored 11-year-old daughter to Chicago.

title: Palco's Acquirer Plans To Linger After Deal
description: James N. Mills, the chairman of the privately held HHM Group of St. Louis and the head of Clarke Industries, is attempting to add even more titles to his job description.

title: U.S. Passes Toughest Test in Basketball by 80-75
description: The United States basketball team, un-tested and unchallenged through its first five games, got everything it wanted and almost more from Puerto Rico today in the Pan American Games semifinals.

title: Russian Seeks PC Venture
description: A Soviet scientist is seeking to form a joint venture with Western companies to increase the quality of Soviet personal computers, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.

title: Shivers at the Movies
description: Does the thought of ducking into a movie on a soggy day set off chills of guilt? Sure it does - a carryover from childhood, when the outdoors was considered wholesome and the shadow-filled movie house held a hint of naughtiness, like the corner bar. But now we know that the sun is no friend to eyeball or epidermis; stay in it too long, and you're inviting skin cancer. Moreover, high temperatures produce dehydration and a general desiccation of the organs. The prescription is a movie house. Unlike some Off Off Broadway theaters, where art is still connected to suffering, movie theaters are invariably air-conditioned, sometimes to a degree at which pneumonia beckons.

title: Brock Has Eye Operation
description: William E. Brock, the Secretary of Labor, was discharged from Georgetown University Hospital today after an eye operation. Mr. Brock underwent surgery Tuesday for a detached retina, which he suffered last weekend.

title: Advertising; Texas Monthly Plans Quarterly Supplement
description: Texas Monthly plans to introduce a new supplement called Domain by the end of the year, offering Texans help in home decorating and cuisine.

title: Jazz Guitar
description: Kenny Burrell, a guitarist, is leading his Jazz Guitar Band - three guitarists, plus bass and drums - and John Blake, a violinist, is leading a quartet tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: CALIFORNIA AGENCY ON COAST ASSAILED
description: The Commerce Department today accused the California Coastal Commission of not following a Federally approved management plan for the state's coast and threatened to withhold the commission's funds if it did not comply by Oct. 1.

title: INSIDE
description: Massachusetts Health Plan

title: Breezy Broadway
description: The thermometer was hitting 90 with some regularity, which undoubtedly fried the brain, which undoubtedly caused the spell of what was either idiocy or temporary insanity. Otherwise, how account for the decision to initiate an exercycle that had been used as a piece of sculpture and a clothes hanger for more than two years.

title: Marine Life Elsewhere
description: Although the New York Aquarium is the city's pre-eminent venue for creatures of the sea, it hardly has a monopoly on metropolitan New York's marine life. In fact, an unexpected array of habitats for sea lions and sharks, crabs and anemones can be found from City Island to Mystic, Conn.

title: Morgan Trade Kept On Books
description: Six weeks after Morgan Stanley & Company rankled investors by canceling a large trade the day after it crossed the tape, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the trade would stand in its records, even though no money changed hands and the trade is unlikely to ever take place.

title: Stage: Langella In 'Sherlock's Last'
description: ACCORDING to a line in ''Sherlock's Last Case,'' one characteristic of a ''great mind'' is the ability to ''change the ordinary into the extraordinary.'' That's elementary - but what kind of mind changes the extraordinary into the excruciating? One can use Holmesian deductive powers to answer that question - or simply report to the Nederlander Theater and watch such minds at work. In ''Sherlock's Last Case,'' the writer Charles Marowitz and accomplices have so completely diminished Victorian England's most beloved detective that one leaves the play wishing its title were a promise rather than merely an idle threat.

title: A.M.C. Incentives
description: The American Motors Corporation, now a part of the Chrysler Corporation, matched the sales incentive programs for light trucks offered by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. All the programs expire at the end of September. A.M.C.'s Jeep Comanche and two-door Cherokee models carry 1.9 percent financing for two-year loans, 3.9 percent for three-year loans, 4.9 percent for four-year loans and 8.9 percent for five-year loans. Buyers can choose rebates of $700 to $1,000 instead.

title: Voice That Crooned the Lullaby Sells Soap
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Bank in Settlement
description: Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. settled Federal charges today that the bank holding company had misrepresented its financial health in its 1984 annual report.

title: MARGARET MEAD FESTIVAL TO INCLUDE 50 FILMS
description: More than 50 films, many of them New York premieres, will be screened at the 11th margaret Mead Film Festival, which begins Sept. 14 at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. The international festival, which features films of anthropological and sociological impoortance, will run through Sept. 17, with an additional weekend of films on Sept. 19 and 20.

title: French Raise Bag With Jewels From Titanic
description: A French expedition has retrieved a valise containing jewels, coins and currency from the wreckage of the Titanic, a spokesman said today.

title: Reagan and the Russians: The Joke's on Them
description: While on vacation at his ranch near here, President Reagan is catching up on some favorite pastimes: riding horses, clearing brush and collecting jokes about the Russians.

title: Amateur Wins Met
description: Jim McGovern, a 22-year old senior at Old Dominion University, today became the fourth amateur to win the Met Open in its 72-year-history. Maintaining his poise against older professional golfers with winning records, McGovern beat the defender, David Glenz of Morris County Golf Club, by one shot.

title: Airy Music
description: There didn't used to be such a thing as cool concerts in summertime New York (there were Kool Jazz Festival concerts, but that's another story). Then somebody invented air-conditioning, and our musical life has been in a state of breezy evolution ever since. When Carnegie Hall completes its air-conditioning process by next summer and the New York International Festival of the Arts gets under way, New York music will become a seamless, yearlong flow, untroubled by mere climatic variation.

title: U.S. Delays Its Boesky Stock Sale
description: The new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, reversing a policy of his predecessor, said yesterday that he would put off selling the stock that Ivan F. Boesky gave up to settle insider trading charges.

title: Lyles Added to Jets' Woe List
description: This time, it happened because a teammate stepped on Lester Lyles's right heel in practice.

title: Adia Talks To Manpower
description: Adia S.A., a Swiss employment-services company, confirmed a report in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that its executives had met with Manpower Inc. to discuss a business arrangement that would help the Milwaukee company thwart a takeover bid by Blue Arrow P.L.C. of Britain.

title: At the Movies
description: Reading and Riding

title: U.S. REORGANIZING COMMAND IN GULF
description: The Defense Department is reorganizing its operations in the Persian Gulf in an effort to insure a centralized command in the region over the growing American forces there, Pentagon officials said today.

title: A.T.&T. Sets Atlanta Project
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would begin work in December on a $500 million development here. Its partner in the project will be the Landmarks Group, an Atlanta-based developer.

title: Dining Out Guide; Summery Italian
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. LUSARDI'S, 1494 Second Avenue, near 78th Street (249-2020) - **(Dec. 17, 1982) A stylish, modern version of the Italian trattoria, this pub-cafe-restaurant has beige walls and wood paneling. The kitchen is adept at turning out the light, herbaceous tomato sauces associated with Naples and the Abruzzi. Summer fare includes pappa al pomodoro, made of bread cubes, tomato sauce, basil, sage and garlic; carpaccio of beef with mushrooms as well as salmon carpaccio; penne, tubular pasta, with basil, tomatoes, carrots, celery and onion, and spaghetti with lemon peel, littleneck clams, garlic and parsley. Main dishes, $13 to $23. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 4 to 11 P.M. MARCELLO, 1354 First Avenue, near 73d Street (744-4400) - **(Feb. 7, 1986) The contemporary dining room of this East Side restaurant is done in shades of beige and rose, and the rear wall, near the kitchen, is covered with a floor-to-ceiling black-and-white photograph of Florence. Pastas are compelling starters, and a number of special summer dishes are also offered. You might choose a salad of thin French beans, beefsteak tomatoes, sliced boiled new potatoes and baby shrimp with garlic-scented mustard sauce and fresh oregano; grilled sliced eggplant, marinated with mint and garlic dressing served with crabmeat cocktail, or bow-tie pasta with a sauce of broccoli and escargot sauteed with olive, garlic and a touch of pesto sauce. Entrees $12.50 to $19.50. Fridays and Saturdays, 5 to midnight; Sundays, 5 to 11 P.M. ORSO, 322 West 46th Street (489-7212) - **(July 18, 1986) This bright and casual restaurant has a small bar with several tables up front and a step-down main dining room under an arching skylight with an open tile-and-steel kitchen in the rear. The menu is limited in size and emphasizes freshness. Pizzas, pastas and grilled entrees are featured. Good summer starters are sliced veal with tuna sauce; sliced tomato with mozzarella, olive oil and basil, and mixed seafood salad of scallops, octopus, calamari and shrimp with chopped tomato, onion and capers. Pasta options might include orecchiette, ear-shaped pasta, with mixed fresh herbs, black olives, chopped onion and tomato sauce, and fusilli with ricotta cheese, chopped tomato and basil. Entrees $15 to $18. Fridays noon to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 11:45 P.M.; closed Sundays during the summer. PRIMOLA, 1226 Second Avenue, near 64th Street (758-1775) - **(Feb. 20, 1987) One of the more spirited and alluring Italian restaurants on the East Side is Primola, with a dining area showcasing pale yellow walls decorated with watercolors and Italian poster art. The summer appetizer choices feature a cold buffet of fresh local vegetables that have been broiled, marinated or steamed. Available either as an appetizer or a main dish are cold sliced veal with mustard and mayonnaise sauce on a bed of radicchio, and beef carpaccio on arugula with Parmesan shavings. Pasta fanciers might choose linguini with pesto sauce or fedellini with a primavera of broccoli, zucchini, peas, tomatoes and mushroom in a light virgin olive oil and cheese sauce. Main-course offerings include cold poached salmon with a green sauce of mayonnaise, spinach and herbs. Dinner entrees $10 to $19.50. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays and Sundays, 5 P.M. to midnight. SISTINA, 1555 Second Avenue, near 81st Street (861-7660) - **(Nov. 16, 1984) Unstained oak walls, bent-cane chairs and rows of white-covered tables provide a trim and cheerful setting at this Upper East Side restaurant. Even the standards here have an inventive spark. Special summer appetizer choices are fresh anchovies, deboned and marinated with mint, olive oil and lemon; carpaccio of Norwegian salmon marinated with garlic, olive oil, lemon and fresh mint, and baby eggplants stuffed with goat cheese and baked with tomato and buffalo mozzarella. Warm-weather pasta options include ravioli stuffed with ricotta and spinach in a light sauce of butter and fresh sage, or ravioli made with cuttlefish ink and stuffed with seafood in a light tomato sauce, with small European clams and pink scallops. You might choose a main dish of pink snapper roasted on the bone and basted with balsamic vinegar, fresh mint and olive oil, or Norwegian salmon in white wine and puree of sun-dried tomatoes. Entrees $15 to $21. Fridays and Saturdays, 5 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays during the summer. What the stars mean, page C18.

title: Walesa Says Solidarity Will Take U.S. Money
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the banned Solidarity trade union, said today that the union would accept $1 million appropriated by the United States Congress but would spend the money only on medical care for workers.

title: 5 Swings, 5 Homers
description: Spiro T. Agnew was Vice President. That's how long ago it was that Lloyd McClendon had his greatest week in baseball.

title: FILM: 'DIRTY DANCING,' A CATSKILLS ROMANCE IN 1963
description: IN their time, almost all forms of popular American music and dancing, from the foxtrot and the tango through rock-and-roll and all of its variations, have scandalized the members of an older generation, whose own sexuality had earlier been liberated by tamer means. As music, lyrics and dance steps have become more and more sexually explicit, fathers and mothers from coast to coast have felt alienated, and worried that pop music was leading their children straight to hell. As it was with the bunny hug, danced to a ragtime tune in 1910, so is it today when Madonna sings ''Papa Don't Preach.''

title: Mastercard Bid
description: Mastercard International Inc. said it was negotiating to acquire Cirrus Systems Inc., a network of about 17,000 automatic teller machines. Banking sources said that Mastercard would pay about $38 million for Cirrus, which is owned by six banks. The combination of Cirrus Systems with Mastercard's Master Teller system would created a network of 27,000 teller machines. Visa U.S.A. Inc. recently affiliated with Plus System Inc., another network, which has 19,000 machines.

title: Film: 'The Big Easy,' Comedy About Police Case
description: REMY MCSWAIN (Dennis Quaid) is a tough, fast-talking New Orleans police detective who isn't above accepting free meals from all-too-obliging restaurants. They're the perks that go with the job. Anne Osborne (Ellen Barkin) is a pretty, sexually repressed assistant district attorney, assigned to investigate police corruption. Remy and Anne are made for each other, or would have been if ''The Big Easy'' were the sophisticated comedy it could have been.

title: Dow Soars To Record Of 2,706.79
description: Stock prices returned to record levels yesterday, building on the rally that began in late trading on Wednesday.

title: Fort of Runaway Slaves Spawns Masters of Ring
description: Jose Simanco's swollen foot was wrapped in medicinal herbs to cure a deep cut, and he grimaced as he hobbled over to his musical instrument, a crudely made sound box with little metal tongues that emit deep throbbing notes when plucked.

title: Health Care Workers Get Anti-AIDS Guide
description: The Centers for Disease Control recommended today that health care workers treat all patients as potentially infected with the AIDS virus. The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration is expected to use the recommendations as the basis for new regulations for medical facilities.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The British Government will sell its holding in the British Petroleum Company in late October for the equivalent of $12.1 billion, the Government's financial advisers said today.

title: Save the Elephants
description: Democrats are not customarily devoted to elephants, the favored symbol of the Republican Party since 1874, especially with a Presidential election coming up next year. But Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, a California Democrat, is making an exception.

title: Restaurants
description: ''WHAT'S the next big dining trend?'' is a question I am asked continually, the same way fashion writers are probably hounded by clotheshorses who can't wait to know whether ''free-flowing and easy'' or ''tapered and sexy'' will be the ''in'' look next season. My usual answer concerning restaurants is, ''What's left?''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Soviet Expels 2 Japanese as Spies; Tokyo Reacts by Ousting Russian
description: The Soviet Union today ordered two Japanese - a naval attache and a businessman - to leave the country. It was the first expulsion of Japanese by Moscow since World War II and the latest move in an exchange of spy charges and countercharges.

title: New Law Curbs Flights Over 3 National Parks
description: Tourist flights over the Grand Canyon and two other national parks will be sharply restricted under a law signed Wednesday by President Reagan.

title: Steel Jobs Slowly Rise
description: Jobs in the steel industry grew to 170,600 in June from 163,100 in May, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today, but was down from 186,000 in June 1986, before strikes began.

title: Advertising; Keiler Advertising Wins Konica Unit Account
description: Konica Business Machines U.S.A. , Windsor, Conn., a unit of the Konishiroku Photo Industry Company, Tokyo, has awarded Keiler Advertising, Farmington, Conn., its account, budgeted at $10 million.

title: Pawning Honor for the Contras
description: A startling historical thunderbolt has just dropped, almost as an afterthought to the Iran-contra investigation: the United States came close to using South Africa as a paymaster for the contra rebels in Nicaragua. Is there no end to the American honor that the Reagan Administration is willing to spend in this hapless cause?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * C3 Inc. of Reston, Va. said it had been awarded a $272 million contract to supply microcomputers for the Marine Corps.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page yesterday about government policy on family issues located the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute incorrectly. It is at the University of Minnesota.

title: Downtown Fun
description: The downtown fashion and club scene bubbled back to life this week when Susanne Bartsch began her Tuesday night club events at Savage West, a disco at 208 West 23d Street. Miss Bartsch has left the avant-garde SoHo fashion shop that bears her name, but avant-garde fashion followed her to the club to swirl and strut and glitter.

title: Javits Center Sued by Group Led by Farrakhan Over Rally
description: The Nation of Islam, the organization headed by the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, has sued the operators of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, asserting that they had reneged on an oral agreement to rent space to the group for a religious rally on Oct. 25.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kay Yow, the women's basketball coach at North Carolina State and for the United States women's team in the 1988 Olympic Games, underwent surgery Tuesday in Raleigh, N.C., for breast cancer. Mark Bockelman, the North Carolina State sports information director, said Yow ''should return to coaching and athletic activity in the very near future.'' . . . James Worthy, who averaged 19.4 points a game for Los Angeles last season and played all 82 regular-season games, has signed a multiyear extension of his contract with the Lakers. . . . A. J. Foyt has been fined $5,000 and placed on one year's probation for abusing a CART official, Dick Perry, after finishing seventh in the Quaker State 500 at Pocono International Raceway last week. Foyt was one of five drivers charged with an improper exit from the pits.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS BOYCOTT ON IRANIAN OIL
description: The Reagan Administration is studying whether to impose a boycott of oil trade with Iran, a trade that is now understood to be far greater than previously thought, officials said today.

title: TV Weekend; 'The Last Continent,' Antarctica Documentary
description: MOST of us, I suspect, still think of Antarctica as some faraway place having something to do with Adm. Richard Byrd, who in the 1920's established the first United States base there. But ''the kingdom at the end of the world,'' as it's sometimes called, is very much a major factor in the world's scientific and geopolitical concerns. This is the subject of ''Antarctica: The Last Continent,'' being broadcast tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Supplemental Draft Is Seen as Harmful
description: The National Football League's decision to conduct a draft for players who had lost their eligibilty for accepting money from agents was said yesterday to be harmful for college football because of the possibility that it could lead to an increase in rules violations.

title: Revolutionary Posters Here
description: In a political city like this, there are many ways to grab attention. Dan Walsh is trying it with what he calls oppositional posters, and for the time being he has apparently cornered the market.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Quantico, Va., on Wednesday about the Marine court-martial of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree misstated part of the background of John D. Barron, a prosecution witness. Mr. Barron, a senior editOr at The Reader's Digest, was not an employee of Government agencies for which he served as a lecturer and consultant on espionage trials. He served without compensation.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FAMILY TIES

title: Arlington Park Closing Until 1989
description: The Arlington Park race track will be closed next year to insure reconstruction of its fire-damaged grandstand and other facilities by the 1989 season, Richard L. Duchossois, owner of the track, announced today.

title: Advertising; From Grey, Glimpses Of New Car
description: IN its first commercial for Mitsubishi's brand-new Galant Sigma, Grey Advertising has avoided close-ups of the $20,000 car. Instead, the Galant Sigma races sleekly through a crowded tunnel, then swerves dramatically onto a surface that looks strikingly mirror-like.

title: Murder Trial Postponed
description: The murder trial of the man who set the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel here has been postponed until Nov. 9 to give the defense more preparation time, prosecutors said Wednesday.

title: A Huge Customs Scam Victimizes Uncle Sam
description: Nobody enjoys a good snapshot more than the people of Singapore. Last year alone, enough photo albums were imported into Singapore to supply 10 to every man, woman and child in that country. Singaporeans are not just camera happy; they must be ecstatic.

title: North Loses Walsh Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court today rejected Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's argument that the independent counsel investigating the Iran-contra affair is operating under an invalid Justice Department regulation.

title: Economic Scene; The Pressures On Inflation
description: OIL prices tumbled this week, pushed down by the market's pessimism about the world's ability to absorb current output levels of crude and refined products. In addition, world demand for commodities is far from booming. But within a pattern of reasonable balance, individual countries, whether developing or developed, are capable of generating inflation.

title: Maryland Biologists Seek Barrier Against Rabies
description: Using the benefits of a natural geographic barrier and an aggressive program of immunization, wildlife specialists here on the Delmarva Peninsula in eastern Maryland are making a stand against a rabies epidemic among raccoons and other wild animals.

title: English Riot Training Sends 20 to Hospital
description: An exercise designed to train the police in riot control here turned out to be too realistic. Twenty officers ended up in the hospital with sprains, cuts and bruises.

title: Thai Piracy of Software
description: The United States computer industry is pressing Thailand for greater protection from computer software piracy. ''Thailand should follow all other nations in the region - Korea, Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia - in granting copyright protection to software,'' Oliver Smoot, acting president of the Computer and Business Equipment Manufacturers Association, said in a statement. Charlotte LeGates, the group's communications director, estimated that piracy in Thailand costs American companies that create software $4 million to $8 million a year.

title: New Company Plans to Use Brooklyn Navy Yard for Ship Repairs
description: A new company has agreed to lease space in the Brooklyn Navy Yard for a ship repair business that it expects will grow to employ 450 people within two years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about the Board of Estimate's approval of a plan to build 11 shelters for the homeless in New York City misidentified the official who accused Mayor Koch of having ''bought off'' the support of two other board members. It was Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President. The report also misstated the vote of Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. Mr. Goldin, who voted against seven shelters for homeless families, voted to approve three others, for single adults; he voted against the fourth proposed shelter for single adults -at Commonwealth, St. Lawrence, Watson and Gleason Avenues in the Bronx.

title: Newsprint Producers On the Rise
description: As president of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation's paper division, Robert F. Bartlett spent years agonizing about the overcapacity and flat prices that troubled his company's newsprint operations.

title: For Aquino, Memories and Growing Uncertainties
description: As President Corazon C. Aquino visited the grave of her assassinated husband today, thousands of leftist protesters gathered outside her office to protest an increase in fuel prices, and newspapers raised questions about the pace of her Government.

title: Books of The Times; The Dark Side of Virtue
description: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO GLOOMY GUS OF THE CHICAGO BEARS? By Robert Coover. 154 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: COCA MINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company attributed the earnings in the latest periods to the sale of its stock in Equity Silver Mines Ltd.; sales resulted in earnings of $1,250,600, or 16 cents a share and $1,885,900, or 24 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Crash Survivor's Psychic Pain May Be the Hardest to Heal
description: Surgery has replaced her charred skin and time is repairing broken bones, but for the 4-year-old girl who alone survived the crash of Northwest Airlines Flight 255 there will be deeper injuries more resistant to healing.

title: Correction Officer Held in Drug Ring
description: A 28-year-old correction officer has been arrested on charges of smuggling drugs to inmates at the Morris County Jail, officials said.

title: Dance: The San Francisco Ballet
description: Helgi Tomasson and the San Francisco Ballet have been good for each other.

title: DOROTHY O. BRIDAHAM
description: Dorothy O. Bridaham, a former fine arts columnist of The Chicago Sun and The Denver Post, died of breast cancer on Aug. 6 at her home in Tacoma, Wash. She was 72 years old. Until April she lived in Denver, where she and her husband had a fine arts appraisal business.

title: The Race With Something Special
description: Today's $1 million Travers Stakes at Saratoga was won Thursday morning at 10:30 A.M., 55 hours before post time, when the names of all the best 3-year-olds in America were pulled from the entry box. Regardless of which one finishes first this afternoon, the race itself is a victory for the sport and everyone who follows it.

title:
Patents;
A Generating System To Reduce Acid Rain
description: LEAD: A power generation system patented this week by E. Stephen Miliaras, managing director of the Energotechnology Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., is expected to reduce acid rain and the emission of sulfur dioxide from coal-fired power plants.

title: Fed Voted in July Not to Alter Policy
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve voted at a meeting in July to leave monetary policy unchanged, but the officials indicated a willingness to tighten up on credit if inflation worsened or the dollar weakened, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Blue Arrow To Acquire Manpower
description: Manpower Inc., the world's largest temporary employment agency, today accepted a $1.33 billion offer to be acquired by Britain's Blue Arrow P.L.C., ending a two-and-a-half-week takeover battle.

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $408,000 and $485,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $264,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: ON A TAPE, BIAGGI AND ESPOSITO TALK ABOUT U.S. INQUIRY
