description: A Federal judge unsealed a transcript yesterday of a wiretapped conversation between Representative Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito that prosecutors contend show the two tried to obstruct justice.

title: HOMOSEXUIALS WIN CASE ON SECURITY
description: A Federal district judge here has ordered the Defense Department to discontinue its policy of conducting extensive investigations of homosexuals who seek jobs with military contractors requiring special security clearances.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Certainly the worst fears of inflation are out the window at this point.'' - Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers. [ 38:5. ]

title: Visa Granted to Cuban Official
description: The State Department granted a visa today to a senior member of the Cuban Government so he can attend the closing ceremonies of the Pan American Games Sunday night, when the Cuban flag will be raised to honor Havana, the host of the 1991 Pan American Games.

title: KEY RATES
TV: 'Operation X,' Comedy Sketches
description: For Teddy Dibble and Mitchell Kriegman, whose half-hour of comedy vignettes are scheduled to be seen on ''Operation X'' tomorrow at 11:30 P.M. as part of the ''Alive From Off Center'' series on Channel 13, this much can be said: They mean well.

title: CRS-SIRRINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes writeoffs of about $43 million related to restructuring costs. c-Net income The company said share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Aug. 27, 1987.

title: GATX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $2,200,000 and $3,500,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
YANKEES STILL GAIN AFTER GUIDRY'S LOSS
description: The evening seemed to deteriorate in sizable pieces for the Yankees. They lost their valued second baseman to an injury in the second inning, and they essentially lost their hope of beating the Oakland Athletics in the third.

title: KAPOK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $326,000 and $477,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of property. c-Net loss

title: Voicing Doubt, Son Gets 2d Autopsy on Hess
description: A second autopsy was performed today on Rudolf Hess as his son and his lawyer continued to express suspicion about the official account of the Nazi leader's death in an Allied prison.

title: Lilco Set Back in Bid To Recoup Damages
description: The Long Island Lighting Company was set back yesterday in its attempt to recover damages from defects in backup diesel generators at its Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Giants Get Reuschel
description: With three teams crowded atop the National League West, the San Francisco Giants reached into the cellar of the National League East yesterday in an effort to rule the roost alone and strengthen their pitching staff. In a two-for-one trade with the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Giants obtained the Pirates' right-handed ace, Rick Reuschel, in exchange for a reliever, Jeff Robinson, and a minor league starter, Scott Medvin.

title: GREINER ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
When Iranian Religion and Politics Become One
description: A young wounded war veteran stood near the front of the crowd under immense canopies at Teheran University this morning, beating the bent stumps of his elbows against his breast in rhythm with about 3,000 other men.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.D.I.C.'s Chief Proposes Eliminating Of Bank Laws
description: A top regulator today proposed ending almost all Federal banking laws that restrict the nation's bank holding companies.

title: Music: Mostly Mozart Chamber Concert
description: Thursday evening's chamber music program at the Mostly Mozart Festival ended with a superior performance of Mendelssohn's Octet. Given the proliferation of fine young chamber musicians these days, this score for eight string players has become almost a warhorse, so it takes something out of the ordinary to arrest one's attention - especially in a hall as large as Avery Fisher, far bigger than the sort of space in which, by rights, music like this should be heard.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Dr. Carlton Fredericks on July 31 incorrectly described the seizure of copies of one of Dr. Fredericks's books by the Federal Food and Drug Administration. Copies of the book, ''Eat, Live and Be Merry,'' were in sales kits for vitamins and minerals seized in 1961 by the agency at the Century Food Company, Varna, Ill.. The agency contended that the book was used to make false claims of the medical value of vitamins and food supplements. A judge deciding issues in the case said there was no allegation by the Government that Dr. Fredericks had authorized the company's use of his book.

title: WENDT-BRISTOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prince and Lloyd Webber Plan a Joint Production Company
description: Harold Prince and Andrew Lloyd Webber, two of the most powerful forces in the Broadway theater, have announced plans to form a theatrical production company that will produce their future collaborations and develop other plays and musicals.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Harness Racing Mack Lobell Sets World Record: Mack Lobell cut through a strong headwind in the stretch yesterday on his way to a world trotting record of 1:52 1/5 for the mile in the $110,000 Review Stakes at the Illinois State Fairgrounds in Springfield. The 3-year-old colt, who won the Hambletonian and the Yonkers Trot, made a detour from his pursuit of harness racing's Triple Crown to take a shot at the 1:53 2/5 standard set by Prakas at DuQuoin in 1985. (AP) Golf Inkster Ahead by a Shot: Juli Inkster shot a four-under-par 67 yesterday in the first round of the $225,000 Atlantic City Classic. The Ladies Professional Golf Association event is taking place at the 6,005-yard par-71 Marriott Seaview golf course in Galloway Township, N.J. Inkster's score tied the course tournament record and gave her a one-shot lead over Patty Jordan.(AP) Tennis Connors Survives: Fourth-seeded Jimmy Connors squeezed out a tough three-set victory last night in a heated match against Nduka Odizor of Nigeria to reach the semifinals of the $375,000 Association of Tennis Professionals Championship in Mason, Ohio. Connors's 6-1, 6-7, 6-3 victory lasted 2 hours 35 minutes and featured a game penalty against Odizor the second set. Connors advanced to the semifinals with second-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, third-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany, and eighth-seeded Anders Jarryd of Sweden.(AP) Evert Advances: Top-seeded Chris Evert allowed Helen Kelesi only two points in the first three games, and easily beat the Canadian, 6-2, 6-0, in the quarterfinals of the Player's Challenge tournament in Toronto. Evert will face No. 3-seeded Pam Shriver in a semifinal today. Shriver defeated Gabriela Sabatini, 6-2, 6-1. In the other semifinal, Zina Garrison will play Bettina Bunge.(AP) Horse Racing Chief of the Clan Wins: Chief of the Clan raced to a 6 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $55,300 New York Turf Writers Cup steeplechase at Saratoga. It was the third straight victory for the 4-year-old gelding, who covered the two and three-eighths miles in 4:20 2/5. (AP) Cycling Rider Out After Injury: Maria Canins, in second place of the Coors International Bicycle Classic, was injured yesterday at Tivoli Criterium in Denver, but her teammate, Genny Brunet, rallied in driving rain to finish first. Brunet, a Canadian who lives in Monument, Colo., won in 1 hour 16 minutes 23 seconds. It was the eighth stage of competition for the women. Canins, an Italian, suffered a broken collarbone after a crash on a straightaway. In the 17th stage for the men's division, Volker Diehl of West Germany earned his first victory in the competition.(AP)

title: MINER KILLED AND 20 HURT IN SOUTH AFRICAN STRIKE
description: One black miner was killed and 20 were wounded in a clash with security officials at a gold mine near here, the black miners' union said today. The death was the first attributed to strike violence since the miners walked out in a wage dispute 13 days ago.

title: BIOTECH RESEARCH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEAD: Caramoor Wrapup

title: ... Meanwhile, Fighting Intensified in the Biker-Pedestrian War
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHIQUES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $161,000 on the cancellation of a lease.

title: Warning on Replays
description: American League rules forbid a club from showing replays of controversial calls on giant video screens, and according to Bob Fishel, the league's executive vice president, the Toronto Blue Jays have violated the rule two or three times this year. If it keeps happening, he said, Bobby Brown, the league president, will pull the plug on the Blue Jay screen, as he has the authority to do.

title:
Patents;
New Form Of Braille On Tape
description: LEAD: IN Braille, letters are disclosed to the blind by raised dots. An invention for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration makes it possible to read Braille text from a magnetic tape without embossing the characters on paper. Patent 4,687,444 was granted this week to H. Douglas Garner, a staff scientist at the Langley Research Center in

title: CONSUMERS FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $75,000 and $133,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and a capital loss of $13,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $302,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes capital gains of $221,000 for the quarter and $272,000 for the 6 months.

title: Potential Acquirers Talk With Lamaur
description: Lamaur Inc. said that it had held preliminary discussions with several companies that have expressed an interest in acquiring all or part of the Minneapolis-based hair-care products company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Lamaur said it had provided confidential information to an unspecified number of companies but had not yet determined whether to pursue any transactions. Its stock jumped $1.75 a share today on the news, to $26.125.

title: Red Rodney
description: Red Rodney, a trumpeter who played with Charlie Parker, is leading a sextet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title:
Patents;
A Refrigerant to Cut Buildings' Power Costs
description: LEAD: A refrigerant patented this week by a New Jersey manufacturer and two scientists at the National Bureau of Standards in Gaithersburg, Md., is reported as promising great reduction in electricity costs for large buildings. The refrigerant gives compressors low-temperature capability. ''This is essential,'' the inventors say, ''since shortages of daytime electricity in the next few years threaten to close down large consumers in summer unless ice can be made at night.

title: A 'Middleman' Hired 4 Suspects To Kill Union Leader, Police Say
description: Four young men arrested late Thursday in the murder of the head of the New York City school custodians' union were hired to do the killing by a man who was found shot to death on Staten Island last Saturday, the police said.

title: Most Victims of Crash Are Identified
description: Lingering uncertainty for some families of 155 victims of the airliner crash last Sunday ended today with the release of a coroner's list of victims who have been identified.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 22, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Darling's Streak Comes to an End
description: Just when they were building some fantasies with their bats, the Mets got a shot of reality last night when the last-place San Diego Padres rose up to beat them, 6-2, ending Ron Darling's winning streak at six games.

title: Prosecutor to Assert Police Corruption on L.I.
description: A special prosecutor investigating accusations of police corruption in Suffolk County said today that he would convene a grand jury on Sept. 14 and present evidence of possible crimes by several high-ranking police and other public officials.

title: Vietnam Appears to Hinder an Emigration Accord
description: As American hopes of restarting a legal emigration process from Vietnam have been rising over the last month, Vietnamese officials here appear to be putting obstacles in the path of agreement.

title: Monarch Butterfly Is the Ideal National Symbol
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating on Train Charged
description: Officials eager to keep Miami's three-year-old commuter system spick-and-span have arrested a mother who allowed her children to eat canned sausages on a train after they missed dinner. The woman, 26-year-old Tobia Jinks, is to be arraigned next week on second-degree misdemeanor charges of eating on a train. ''The key is you don't let that start,'' said Sgt. John Carrel, head of Metrorail's police force. ''Otherwise it is New York - the toilet.''

title: August or No, Diners Rush Bellini and Bice
description: Fashionable New Yorkers are so fickle about restaurants that chic spots can seem to lose their cachet between the coffee and the check. But this summer Bice and Bellini, two new restaurants that have captured the attention of food aficionados, are being described as instant institutions.

title: 'Fatal Vision' Lawsuit Ends in a Mistrial
description: A Federal judge declared a mistrial today after jurors reported they were deadlocked over a suit brought by a convicted murderer against the author who wrote a book about him.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Wednesday about the United States arrival of the Soviet pianist Vladimir Feltsman imprecisely described the origin of a CBS recording of Chopin preludes played by Mr. Feltsman. A tape was smuggled out of the Soviet Union.

title: Two Iraqi Warplanes Bomb Border Settlement in Turkey
description: Two Iraqi warplanes bombed a Turkish settlement near the border today, apparently in error, and slightly wounded one person, the Foreign Ministry here said.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DYANSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company recently changed its name from Fine Art Acquisitions Ltd.

title: Giants Anxious About Nelson
description: Although the Giants seem to be thinking more about their ailing teammate, Karl Nelson, than about playing football, they will play a game Saturday night. They will meet the Cleveland Browns at 8 o'clock in Giants Stadium in the second of their four preseason games.

title: NEWS SUMMAARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 22, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/2-5 Sgt. Clayton Lonetree was convicted on all 13 counts of espionage by a court-martial jury after a trial that had lasted two weeks. He is the first United States marine to be tried for spying. Page 1 A U.N. meeting will be boycotted by the United States. The conference will discuss how money saved under future disarmament agreements could be used to stimulate economic development. 1 Nicaraguan rebel leaders pledged to accept the terms of a regional peace treaty signed by five Central American countries. They made the pledge at a meeting with the Salvadoran President, Jose Napoleon Duarte. 2 Iran is taking advantage of a lull in attacks on Persian Gulf shipping to increase oil exports and bolster its war-pressed economy, Western diplomats say. The Iranians are reportedly exporting more than 2 million barrels a day. 3 A second autopsy on Rudolf Hess was performed as his son and his lawyer continued to express suspicion about the official account of the Nazi leader's death in Spandau Prison. 5 In Tokyo, officials played down the diplomatic significance of the expulsion orders handed to two Japanese in Moscow. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone insisted that the expulsions were unjustified. 4 In the Philippines, the anniversary of the killing of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was the occasion for introspection over the nation's progress since his widow assumed the presidency 18 months ago. 4 In Zimbabwe, a house of Parliament voted to abolish the practice of reserving seats in Parliament for the country's tiny white minority. Officials sang and danced in the aisles when the vote was announced. 5 When Iranian religion and politics become one 3 Better Syria ties sought by U.S. 3 Dalat Journal 4 Vietnam appears to hinder emmigration accord 4 Miner killed, 20 hurt in South African strike 5 NATIONAL/6-8, 28, 33 In another sign of slowing inflation, the Labor Department reported that consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in July. It was the smallest monthly rise in the Consumer Price Index this year. 1 The U.S. economy grew modestly in the spring. The 2.3 percent annual rate was lower than the growth of the first quarter, the Government said. Analysts attributed the weaker second quarter to a disappointing trade performance in June. 35 In a comprehensive banking plan, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed eliminating almost all Federal banking laws that restrict the nation's bank holding companies. 1 The survivor of the airplane crash in Detroit, Cecilia Cichan, has become the focus of concern from relatives and physicians who worry as much about her emotional recovery as her physical convalescence. 1 Most victims of crash identified 7 Enforcement of a security regulation under which clearances would be revoked for any official who declined to sign a disputed pledge of secrecy was suspended by the Reagan Administration in a surprise move. 8 In Washington, a helicopter plunged into the Potomac River, killing three passengers and injuring the pilot. Witnesses said the aircraft was hovering above the water when it appeared to lose power. 7 A task force on pornography being run by the Justice Department is leading an effort to stem the distribution of obscene materials. But critics say that the wave of prosecution carries the threat of censorship. 6 Gary Hart is not reconsidering resuming his collapsed campaign, a senior aide to Mr. Hart said. But there were reports that supporters of Mr. Hart were promoting the idea of his re-entering the campaign. 7 In appeals for women's support, five Democratic Presidential hopefuls addressed or plan to address the National Women's Political Caucus. But the potential candidacy of Representative Patricia Schroeder dominated conversation. 6 A rabies epidemic among raccoons and other wild animals in eastern Maryland is being fought by wildlife specialists using the benefits of a natural geographic barrier and an program of immunization. 6 Museum planned for Titanic artifacts 8 Special security inquiry for homosexuals barred 8 REGIONAL/29-31 A transcript of a conversation between Representative Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito that was wiretapped was unsealed by a Federal judge. Prosecutors contend the conversation shows the two tried to obstruct justice. 1 Four Bronx youths arrested in the murder of the head of the New York City school custodians' union were hired to do the killing by another Bronx man who was found shot to death on Staten Island last Saturday, the police said. 1 The debate at the Century Club over whether to admit women is causing tempers to flare at the Manhattan club. The dispute is causing rifts among friends, and many members have threatened to resign. 1 Six people were shot in the head in a South Bronx apartment during a drug-related robbery, the police said. Three died at the scene, while three others, including a 13-year-old girl, were given a chance to survive. 31 Some service stations are cheating consumers by selling regular gasoline at premium prices in New York City, according to a report released by the Federal General Accounting Office. 29 A building's recovery in the Bronx is credited to the work of one woman, Ramona Munoz. ''If everybody fought like Mrs. Munoz fought,'' one nearby resident said, ''then maybe there wouldn't be any housing problem in New York City.'' 29 The Regency Theater will close before Sept. 3 to become a first-run house for the giant Cineplex Odeon Corporation. It is one of a dwindling number of film-revival houses long treasured by old-movie buffs. 9 Russians arrive for conference 29 Anatomy of shelters deal 29 Priest pleads not guilty in ticket theft case 30 New head of Probation Department named 31 Prosecutor to assert police corruption on L.I. 31 New company plans to use Brooklyn Navy Yard 31 Signature requirement in New York election law struck down 50

title: BETTER SYRIA TIES ARE SOUGHT BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration is engaged in an intensive effort to improve relations with Syria, officials said today, citing that nation's significant influence over events in the Middle East.

title: U.S. Callousness and Mozambique Massacres
description: News of two massacres in Mozambique in the last two months, in which more than 400 people were killed, seems to have made little impression on the American public. Had the incidents occurred in a refugee camp in Lebanon or a village in Central America, they surely would have received more attention.

title: D O C OPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: City and Foreign To Buy U.S. Firm
description: City and Foreign Holdings P.L.C., a language school and business services company, said it had agreed to acquire Alexander Proudfoot Company Worldwide Holdings, an American-based international management consulting firm, for an undisclosed amount. City and Foreign Holdings said the two companies would be merged to form Alexander & Proudfoot Company. Alexander Proudfoot, based in Palm Beach, Fla., would contribute the majority of the combination's earnings.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Iraq, Moscow Ally, Criticizes Soviet Gulf Policy
description: Iraq, a longtime ally of the Soviet Union, has attacked Moscow's policy on the Persian Gulf, calling its opposition to United Nations sanctions against Iran ''shortsighted.''

title: BOLT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results for year- ago periods include a charge of $5,758,000 from a writedown of assets.

title: Film: Anthony Newley In 'Garbage Pail Kids'
description: Where is Miss Manners when you need her? If only she'd been there to break up the big fight scene, when some vile children go on a rampage - one clears the room with nearly fatal flatulence, another vomits on her enemies.

title: Boxing Showdown Whose Time Is Up
description: ''Well,'' Michael Collins said, ''y'all ready for the showdown?''

title: Iran Said to Use Lull to Lift Oil Exports
description: Iran is taking advantage of a lull in attacks on Persian Gulf shipping to increase oil exports and bolster its war-pressed economy, Western diplomats say.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $13,737,000 of oil and gas properties. c-Includes a writedown of $31,921,000 and $49,926,000 of oil and gas properties for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a charge of $575,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: KOCH NAMES NEW HEAD OF PROBATION DEPARTMENT
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named Kevin Smyley, deputy commissioner for legal affairs at the Department of Sanitation, as the Commissioner of the Department of Probation.

title: Glenn Turner Sentenced
description: The founder of the ''Dare to be Great'' motivational program has been sentenced to seven years in prison for using an illegal pyramid scheme to bilk people out of thousands of dollars. Glenn W. Turner, 53 years old, was sentenced along with Edward G. Rechtor by Superior Court Judge Bernard J. Dougherty. Mr. Turner and Mr. Rechtor, who also received seven years, were convicted in July of 19 counts of conspiracy, fraud and promoting a pyramid scheme. Jurors found them not guilty of 27 counts of securities violations involving Challenge Inc., a motivational company.

title: U.S. WILL BOYCOTT A U.N CONFERENCE
description: A United Nations conference on disarmament and economic development will open in New York on Monday without the participation of the United States, which is boycotting the meeting.

title: Japanese Leaders Try to Play Down Expulsions by Moscow
description: Japanese leaders sought today to play down the diplomatic significance of expulsion orders handed to two Japanese in Moscow on Thursday.

title: Witness for Demjanjuk Is Said to Try Suicide
description: A psychologist from Texas tried to commit suicide last night after retracting her defense evidence at the trial of John Demjanjuk, who is accused of being a Nazi war criminal, the Israeli police saido=oday.

title: Hart Denies Bid to Resurrect Campaign
description: Gary Hart said categorically that he was not considering resurrecting his collapsed Presidential campaign, an aide said today. Political experts said any attempt to revive the campaign would thrust Mr. Hart into a political, legal, financial and public relations imbroglio.

title: Bad Loophole in the Pension Law
description: Should ailing businesses be allowed to dump their current pension liabilities on the Government - and then offer supplemental pension benefits to workers in return for cost-cutting labor concessions? That, incredibly, is what the bankrupt LTV Corporation hopes to do. The Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation is trying to persuade a court that Government payments should be reduced by the supplement LTV has agreed to pay.

title: ETZ LAVUD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in U.S. dollars at the June 30 exchange rate of 1.6060 Israeli Shekels per dollar.

title: Chiesa Succeeds Pitino
description: When Rick Pitino, the head coach who led the Providence College basketball team to the Final Four last spring, left to take over the Knicks, he had some parting advice for Providence: that it hire his associate coach, Gordon Chiesa, as his successor.

title: ... MEANWHILE, FIGHTING INTENSIFIED IN THE BIKER-PEDESTRIAN WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Home-Grown Chef Would Be a White House First
description: The 33-year-old Florida hotel chef who seems likely to be named executive chef at the White House is described by associates as an exceptionally well-organized cook with a flair for imaginative presentation and a style with classic roots.

title: Against Jets, Past Plays Part for Bucs
description: Vinny Testaverde used to dream about playing for the Jets, and Ray Perkins used to scheme of ways to beat them.

title: First-Run Films for Regency
description: The Regency Theater, one of a dwindling number of film revival houses, long treasured by old-movie buffs, is to close for renovations before Sept. 3, to become a first-run house for the Cineplex Odeon Corporation.

title: Hill Samuel Group Names New Chief
description: Hill Samuel Group P.L.C. said its non-executive director, David Davies, would replace Christopher Castleman as chief executive. Mr. Castleman resigned when merger talks between Hill Samuel and the Union Bank of Switzerland were announced July 9. The talks were called off earlier this week.

title: About New York; Europe Can Wait: Musician Adopts An S.R.O. Hotel
description: On his way to Germany from Australia to pursue a career as a classical guitarist, Lloyd Carew-Reid somehow landed at the Kenmore, a dismal single-room occupancy hotel on East 23d Street. His neighbors included many respectable people, low on cash like himself, as well as reputed drug dealers and prostitutes and one woman who seemed to think she was a rooster.

title: Consumer Index Climbed in July By Modest 0.2%
description: In another sign of slowing inflation, the Labor Department reported today that consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in July. It was the smallest monthly rise in the Consumer Price Index this year.

title: A Crisp or a Crumble? Well, If It's Good, Eat It
description: Old-fashioned American desserts have been christened, for reasons unknown, with some especially strange names. Trying to make sense out of them can be a challenge.

title: Growth in G.N.P. Down To 2.3% Rate in Quarter
description: The nation's economy grew at a modest annual rate of 2.3 percent in the spring, less than previously reported and considerably lower than the growth of the first quarter, the Government reported today.

title: AREA COSTS UNCHANGED
description: The cost of living did not change in New York and northeastern New Jersey last month, according to the regional commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Thomas Wirth, Sought The Legal Right to Die
description: Thomas Wirth, a New York City man who had urged doctors not to take extraordinary measures to prevent his death from AIDS, died Thursday at Bellevue Hospital from an AIDS-related brain infection. He was 47 years old.

title: Nicaragua Rebels Pledge to Accept Latin Peace Plan
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders pledged today to accept the terms of a new regional peace treaty signed by five Central American countries.

title: Not-Guilty Plea Made by Priest In Ticket Theft
description: A Roman Catholic priest arrested this week in connection with the theft in February of $1 million in Broadway theater tickets was freed yesterday on $2,500 bail after pleading not guilty to a felony charge of criminal possession of stolen property.

title: Music: Zorn And Berne Downtown
description: There is an old joke about people suddenly discovering with pride that all their lives they have been writing ''prose.'' Perhaps similarly, the raft of rock-jazz-vanguard fusion improvisers these days might be said to have been playing ''harmolodics'' unwittingly all along. The word is Ornette Coleman's never-too-clearly explained term for the basis of his own music.

title: FRANK BROGLIO
description: Frank Broglio, a former Long Island restaurant owner and a breeder of standardbreds, died Wednesday at Glen Cove Community Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Brookville, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: The Russians Hit Town For Talks and Ice Cream
description: The Russians landed yesterday. Among them were diplomats, scientists, actors, musicians - even the first woman in space.

title: Nuclear Plant Restarted
description: The Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear plant was restarted early today after a planned 10-day shutdown, entering a testing phase that will bring it up to 50 percent of capacity, officials of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said. In its previous testing phase the plant generated power for consumers for the first time. At the end of the current test, the plant on Lake Ontario will again produce electricity for the state power grid, the officials said.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,590,000 from early repayment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net income Share earnings are adjusted to reflect an increase of about 3,150,000 common shares resulting from a stock dividend of one share of a new class B common stock for each common shares, effectively a 2-for-1 stock split, paid Jan. 15, 1987. The company said the 1987 results include the operations of Keystone- Franklin Inc., acquired Dec. 30, 1986.; year-ago results include the operations of Learn Copper & Brass Inc., acquired Nov. 1, 1985, and Select-Line Industries Inc., acquired April 21, 1986.

title: Your Money; Convertible Mortgages
description: A NEW emphasis is being placed on convertible mortgages, a device that gives homeowners much greater flexibility in determining the cost of their loans.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,140,000 for both the quarter and 9 months; tax credits of $940,000 for the quarter and $3,470,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month is also after a loss from discontinued operations of $96,000 and a loss from the early extinguishment of debt of $1,502,000. c-Includes tax credits of $800,000 and $2,200,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and the 9-month also includes a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $424,000. Share earnings are after deduction of redeemable preferred stock dividends.

title: Letter: On Food Advertising; Health Claims Will Meet Strict Criteria
description: To the Editor:

title: Slow Codes, Show Codes and Death
description: New York recently became the first state to end the need for two deadly deceits in hospitals. One is the ''slow code,'' meaning medical resuscitation teams should move very slowly. The other is the ''show code,'' meaning resuscitation efforts should be faked, for the family's sake.

title: U.S. Drops Threat on Disputed Pledge of Secrecy
description: In a surprise move, the Reagan Administration today suspended a threat to revoke the security clearance of any official who declined to sign a disputed pledge of secrecy.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $969,000 and $1,945,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Airport Restrictions to Widen
description: Concerned about the threat of aerial collisions, the Transportation Department plans a sharp expansion of the number of airports with tightly restricted airspace, Government and industry sources said today.

title: U.S. Adamant in Indian's Case
description: The State Department said today that Leonard Peltier, an American Indian active in Indian causes, was a ''convicted criminal'' and criticized the Soviet Union for considering his request for political asylum.

title: Brooklyn Academy Post For Financier-Collector
description: Asher Edelman, a financier and art collector, has been recommended by a selection committee of the Brooklyn Academy of Music to become the new board chairman, pending formal election at the next full board meeting Oct. 6.

title: VOICEMAIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $7,011 from reduction of income taxes arising from deduction of prior year's accounting losses.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After an extraordinary credit of $607,000.

title: Cabdrivers, Neat and Not
description: Neatness began to count for New York City cabbies yesterday as the Taxi and Limousine Commission's new dress code took effect.

title: Circle Repertory Company Names Tanya Berezin Artistic Director
description: The board of directors of the Circle Repertory Company yesterday named Tanya Berezin artistic director, following a meeting Thursday. The appointment will take effect immediately, Max Weitzenhoffer, the board's president, said.

title: Position of Soviet Jews Is Being Distorted
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Ends Bad Week With Drop
description: The dollar slipped further yesterday, pushed down by a report of slower economic growth in the United States and a surprising statement by Japan's Minister of Finance.

title: Katherine Lynch, Ex-Official In New York City Schools
description: Katherine D. Lynch, a retired New York City school official and an aviator, died Tuesday at the Elihu White nursing home in Braintree, Mass., after a stroke. She was 85 years old and lived in Southbury, Mass.

title: Schroeder's Potential Candidacy Is Dominating Women's Political Caucus
description: Feminist testimonials were in the air today as the National Women's Political Caucus began its biennial convention here. Some of the strongest testimonials came from men.

title: ...MEANWHILE, FIGHTING INTENSIFIED IN THE BIKER-PEDESTRIAN WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Defeat for American Express
description: A mid-sized Indianapolis bank has won a contract to provide financial services to American military personnel in three European countries, defeating the American Express Company, which has handled the job for 40 years.

title: E&B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Koreans Win TV Franchise
description: The franchise for a new UHF television station covering northern New Jersey has been awarded to a group of Korean businessmen who said they could begin operations by early 1989.

title: Merc Offers Gold Proposals
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has proposed an extension of the trading hours in its gold futures contract and has introduced an incentive plan to promote liquidity in the contract.

title: Maurice Hopkins, 82, Dies; Led New York High Schools
description: Maurice D. Hopkins, a former assistant superintendent of schools in New York City, with responsibility for high schools, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Morris, N.Y. He was 82 years old and also lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Homeless, Politicians And a Deal
description: There comes a moment in any delicate negotiation when two parties realize they have the seeds of an accord. On Mayor Koch's highly disputed proposal to build 15 new shelters for the homeless, that moment came eight days ago.

title: Sonny Rollins
description: The tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins is leading a group that includes Monty Alexander on piano, Bob Cranshaw on bass and Marvin (Smitty) Smith on drums tomorrow on Musicruise (595-5272), a concert aboard the Hudson River Dayliner. The boat leaves Pier 81, at 41st Street and 12th Avenue, at 9 P.M. and returns at midnight; boarding begins at 8 P.M. Tickets are $20 in advance and $22.50 tomorrow, available through Ticketron (399-4444).

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $600,000. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: Small Loss for Fokker
description: Fokker, the Dutch plane maker, said that rising costs and delays on its new generation of F-100 and F-50 aircraft had caused a small loss for the first half of the year. Fokker, in debt to banks and the Dutch Government over financing the new airliners, Thursday reported a first-half loss of 3.4 million guilders, or $1.65 million, in contrast to a profit a year ago of 13.4 million guilders, or $6.5 million.

title: ... MEANWHILE, FIGHTING INTENSIFIED IN THE BIKER-PEDESTRIAN WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Quaker Oats Restructuring
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that it had reorganized its United States and Canadian grocery products businesses, which account for more than 60 percent of the packaged-food concern's revenues.

title: Cocaine Called Cause Of Death of an Actor
description: The death last month of a 31-year-old actor who had just learned he was to take over the lead in the Broadway production of ''Les Miserables'' was caused by a cocaine overdose, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Eddy Kirkland
description: Eddy Kirkland is to sing the blues tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a $1.5 million tax credit and $1.5 million in related interest income.

title: Eleanor W. Fowler Is Dead; A Labor and Peace Activist
description: Eleanor Woolley Fowler, a longtime peace activist and former leader in the labor movement, died Wednesday at her home in Lower Makefield, Pa., of complications of ovarian cancer. She was 79 years old.

title: Zimbabwe to Drop White-Only Posts
description: The lower house of Parliament voted today to abolish the practice of reserving seats for the country's tiny white minority.

title: Cheating on Regular Gas Prices Found at New York City Stations
description: Some New York City service stations are cheating consumers by selling regular gasoline at premium prices, according to a report released yesterday by the Federal General Accounting Office.

title: For the Slaying Suspects, Support From Neighbors
description: On Southern Boulevard in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, where decay and redevelopment exist side by side, relatives and friends of three of the four young men accused of murdering the head of the New York City school custodian's union refused to believe that the suspects could have been involved in such a crime.

title: CRAZY EDDIE GROUP ENDS PARTNERSHIP
description: Eddie Antar, the founder and chairman of Crazy Eddie Inc., and the First City Capital Corporation said yesterday that they had ended the partnership they formed to acquire the New York-based electronics retailer.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $10 million and $12 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and the 9-month also includes net from discontinued operations of $20 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4 million for the quarter and $12 million for the 9 months; and the 9-month also includes a gain of $66 million from the cumulative effect of a pension accounting change. The company said the latest third quarter includes aftertax gains of $6 million, or 15 cents a share, from partial liquidation of LIFO inventories.

title: Soviet Gives Exit Visas To Improve Its Image
description: To the Editor:

title: 2.71 GAIN PUTS DOW AT 2,709.50
description: The Dow Jones industrial average eked out a small increase yesterday to set another record, rising 2.71 points, to 2,709.50.

title: Pan American Games; U.S. and Cuba Gain Final in Baseball
description: Scott Livingstone hit for the cycle and drove in five runs, and Jim Abbott allowed only three hits in four and two-thirds innings of relief as the United States beat Canada, 7-6, tonight to set up a gold-medal game with Cuba in the Pan American Games baseball tournament.

title: GENERAL HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Israel Delays Plane Decision
description: Israel today delayed for a week a decision on whether to drop Israel's Lavi fighter plane project, officials said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres agreed to ask the Cabinet to decide the Lavi's fate Aug. 30, aides to Mr. Peres said. The American Ambassador, Thomas Pickering, met Mr. Shamir, but an embassy spokesman refused to confirm or deny a radio report that he once again urged Israel to scrap the United States-financed warplane. Washington, which will give $3 billion in aid this year, has urged Israel to invest in a less costly alternative, such as F-16's.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago second quarter net income brokeven.

title: Raiders Moving to Los Angeles Suburb
description: The Los Angeles Raiders, who left the city of Oakland for a home in Los Angeles, said today that they would leave Los Angeles for the suburban industrial hamlet of Irwindale.

title: United Parcel Agrees on Teamsters Contract
description: United Parcel Service and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced today that they had reached a contract agreement that would give 110,000 workers at United Parcels a 30-cent-an-hour wage increase and bonuses in each of the three years of the contract.

title: Court Bars Bid For Kenner
description: A Massachusetts court granted a preliminary injunction today barring New World Entertainment Ltd. and its subsidiaries from pursuing a hostile takeover bid for Kenner Parker Toys Inc. Justice John Forte of the

title: CITY OF MIMOSA, UNTOUCHED BY WAR
description: The church bells are first to greet the dawn as it seeps into the darkness of a wet and chilly morning in the Central Highlands. Hundreds of people respond to the call at a 5:15 mass in Dalat Cathedral and at smaller churches or the chapels of crumbling monasteries in the surrounding hills.

title: Port Authority Pay Called Too Generous
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is too generous with departing employees, paying an average of $2,500 more than necessary in unused vacation and leave time, according to an audit released yesterday by New York State Comtptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: Beaches Reopen After Bacteria Scare
description: Health officals, a day after closing the city's ocean beaches because of high fecal coliform bacteria levels in the water, reopened half of them yesterday.

title: ... MEANWHILE, FIGHTING INTENSIFIED IN THE BIKER-PEDESTRIAN WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Chad Says It Repelled A Large Libyan Raid
description: Chadian radio reported today that its troops had repelled four Libyan motorized columns advancing on its northern outpost of Aozou, and had shot down the largest number of Libyan aircraft in any battle since the Chadian-Libyan border war resumed in January.

title:
Patents;
Inventors' Convention
description: LEAD: The 16th annual Invention Convention, to be held in Los Angeles from Sept. 25 through 27, will have more than 500 exhibitors. The displays will range from toys to aircraft warning systems. For example, Joshua White, an 8-year-old from Portland, Ore., will show a dinosaur board game he invented.

title: Canada Cited On Potash
description: The Commerce Department issued a preliminary finding today that Canada was dumping potassium chloride, or potash, on the American market at less than fair value.

title: I'll Fight Jargon With Jargon
description: LEAD: Recently, I've become aware that I'm missing a lot and that each day I'm falling further behind. It's not that I don't understand the issues under discussion and am therefore overwhelmed by the enormity of the problems facing the world. They are, after all, merely updated versions of the same old issues that have always been around: plague, pestilence, famine, war, sex, drugs and rock and roll.

title: Ivory Coast Official Is Freed By Kidnappers After 4 Days
description: A wealthy Ivory Coast official, Aoussou Koffi, has been released unharmed by kidnappers after being held four days, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny said today.

title: Deficit Slows From '86 Pace
description: The Federal budget deficit grew to $141.7 billion at the end of July, substantially below last year's record level of red ink, the Government said today.

title: Helicopter Plunges Into Potomac, Killing 3 on a Photography Flight
description: A helicopter plunged into the Potomac River this morning, killing three passengers and seriously injuring the pilot.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Garfield Heard, an 11-year National Basketball Association veteran who played under John MacLeod at the University of Oklahoma and later with the Phoenix Suns, apparently impressed MacLeod, now the coach of the Dallas Mavericks. He has been named as a Mavericks assistant coach. . . . Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the Boston Red Sox pitcher, underwent shoulder surgery and should be fine by next spring, his surgeon said. . . . Bill Hanzlik, a forward for the Denver Nuggets, had surgery to repair a herniated disk and should be ready to open the season Nov. 6, the team said. . . . Pete Johnson, a former Ohio State fullback who later played for the Cincinnati Bengals and two other N.F.L. teams, pleaded not guilty in Columbus, Ohio, to a series of Federal cocaine charges that could lead to prison sentences of 65 years and $3 million in fines. . . . Aaron Emanuel, a running back at the University of Southern California, was found guilty of one of two counts of battery yesterday. The charges stemmed from fights five months apart involving two female classmates.

title: Victim Who Fought Job Bias Over AIDS Dies From the Illness
description: Todd Shuttleworth, who gained national attention by fighting to get his job back when he was dismissed after being stricken with AIDS, has died of complications from the disease. He was 34 years old.

title: Inside
description: Riders Again on Move

title: Molitor Extends Streak to 36 Games
description: Paul Molitor of the Milwaukee Brewers extended his hitting streak to 36 games tonight with a fourth-inning double in the 3-0 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: A Daring Idea on European Defense
description: European leaders, fretting over nuclear arms reductions and American constancy, have worked their way back to an old puzzle: how to strengthen Europe's commitment to its own security. It's a familiar and often fruitless activity. Yet some of the ideas now being discussed, particularly between Paris and Bonn, could yield a stronger alliance and deserve encouragement.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: 2 Holdouts Join Eagles
description: With the start of the National Football League season less than a month away, half the Philadelphia Eagles' four holdouts came into the fold yesterday. One, Mike Quick, the 28-year-old Pro Bowl wide receiver, had been seeking a renegotiated contract. The other, Jerome Brown, is a defensive tackle from the University of Miami who was a first-round draft pick.

title: Transamerica Deal
description: Transamerica Airlines has agreed to sell 11 Lockheed Hercules L-100-30 aircraft and additional equipment to the Southern Air Transport Company of Miami for $86.4 million. The airline, a unit of the San Francisco-based Transamerica Corporation, said it expected to realize an after-tax gain of $43 million on the sale. Southern Air has been operating the planes for the last year on a lease. The deal leaves Transamerica with a single plane. The unit announced plans to liquidate its operations last year.

title: Judicial Light in Emergency
description: A power failure forced the evacuation of more than 500 court and county employees from two Tarrant County buildings today, but a visiting judge used a flashlight to help a couple complete adoption of a 10-month-old girl. The judge, Eva Barnes, did not want the couple to have to make a second trip to Fort Worth from their home in central Texas, so in a first-floor courtroom she completed the process in 10 minutes with light from a window and a flashlight.

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Saxes at Fat Tuesday's
description: The tenor saxophonist Scott Hamilton is to lead a sextet, featuring Flip Phillips on tenor saxophone, tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M., plus midnight sets tonight and tomorrow; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: 3 Are Slain and 3 Are Hurt In a Robbery Tied to Drugs
description: Six people were shot in the head early yesterday in a South Bronx apartment during a drug-related robbery, the police said. Three died immediately, but three others, including a 13-year-old girl, were found alive.

title: NEW YORK WATERS - A CEMETERY FOR MARINE LIFE
description: LEAD: As commercial shellfishermen have known for some time, and scientists are just beginning to confirm, Long Island Sound suffered a major environmental disaster this summer.

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Friendly Matter: Male Club Faces Change
description: As the final hour approaches, tempers are flaring over whether to admit women to the Century Club, one of Manhattan's oldest and most exclusive all-male clubs.

title: Traditional Jazz
description: A festival of traditional jazz is to take place this weekend in Essex, Conn., at six locations near the Essex Steam Train. Performers between 6 P.M. today and 6 P.M. Sunday are to include the Louisiana Repertory Jazz Ensemble, Terry Waldo and the Gotham City Band, the New Leviathan Oriental Foxtrot Orchestra of New Orleans, Chicago Rhythm, Henry (Thins) Francis, the Red Rose Ragtime Band, the Original Salty Dogs and others; the number for information is (203) 767-0237. Complete festival passes cost $45; individual afternoon and evening tickets are also available at $12 and $15. The festival is to benefit the Hospice Council of Connecticut.

title: Ornette Coleman Music
description: John Zorn and Tim Berne on saxophones, Mark Dresser on bass and Bobby Previte on drums are to play music by Ornette Coleman tonight and tomorrow at at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Admission is $5.

title: Ethel W. Price Is Dead; Designed Custom Hats
description: Ethel Westheimer Price, known in the fashion world as ''Emme'' for her custom-made millinery, died as the result of internal hemorrhaging Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85 years old.

title: Official Plans Museum For Artifacts of Titanic
description: The president of an organization that is sponsoring a French expedition to salvage goods and valuables from the wreck of the Titanic said today that he hoped to set up a nonprofit foundation to administer the artifacts and to establish one or more museums to display them.

title: Breland Title Bout Today
description: Mark Breland, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, believes Marlon Starling, the top-ranked contender, is taking him lightly for their title fight Saturday, Breland's first defense. ''My advantage is my height and my reach -and my smarts,'' Breland said. ''He's an experienced fighter. But I think he's underestimating me by a lot of things they've been saying.''

title: Bridge:; Syndicated Columns Pass To a Younger Generation
description: There has been plenty of evidence to suggest that bridge columnists, particularly those who are syndicated, go on for virtually forever. But there seems to be a changing of the Old Guard, after more than 30 years of unchanged bylines.

title: Fitting Children's Shoes
description: WITH school about to begin, the prime season for buying children's shoes is in full swing. Millions of little feet are parading the aisles of shoe stores under the scrutiny of parents and salesmen. The latest sneakers, running shoes, loafers and party shoes look adorable, but do they fit?

title: Rule on Signatures Struck Down In New York State Election Law
description: A key provision of the New York State election law was ruled unconstitutional yesterday, as an appeals court reinstated one candidate for Bronx surrogate and paved the way for another to be returned to the Democratic primary ballot for the Sept. 15 election.

title: Faith Esham, Soprano, Communicates by Song
description: Even as a child back in Vanceburg, Ky., the soprano Faith Esham impressed listeners, but hardly for the qualities that later brought her international recognition.

title: ... MEANWHILE, FIGHTING INTENSIFIED IN THE BIKER-PEDESTRIAN WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: MARINE CONVICTED BY COURT-MARTIAL OF EMBASSY SPYING
description: A Marine Corps court-martial tonight found Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, the first marine to be tried for spying, guilty of all 13 charges against him.

title: Corporate Profits Up By 4.2%
description: After-tax corporate profits climbed 4.2 percent in the April-June quarter as American companies reaped benefits from the weaker dollar, the Government said today.

title: Justice Dept. Team Leading Broad Effort on Obscenity
description: One year after Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced the findings of his Commission on Pornography, a new Justice Department team is leading a nationwide effort to stem the distribution of obscene materials.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Fall
description: In the face of uninterested investors and continued weakness in the value of the dollar, prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined modestly yesterday.

title: Cajun Music
description: Beausoleil, a Cajun band from Louisiana, is to play two outdoor concerts this weekend. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., Celebrate Brooklyn (718-768-0699) is presenting Beausoleil at the Prospect Park Band Shell, near Prospect Park West and Ninth Street in Brooklyn; a $1 donation is requested. And on Sunday at 3 P.M., Summerstage (860-1335) is to present Beausoleil at the Central Park Band Shell, in the middle of the park near 72d Street; admission is free.

title: Hashish Seized in Soviet
description: Five tons of hashish worth $120 million have been seized in a joint Soviet-Canadian operation, the official Tass news agency said today. The agency said the hashish had been smuggled into the Soviet Union from Pakistan and was bound for Canada.

title: Shouting Into the Wind
description: A letter to the editor of The Washington Post recently criticized the men down there for wearing power neckties. Personally, I find it beguiling, and I sympathize with those men, although the letter writer's description of what a power necktie looks like was vague. Small brown figures on a yellow background, sort of, apparently.

title: On One Woman's Grit, a Building Revives
description: Along Spofford Avenue in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, there are two large prewar apartment buildings. One is abandoned, a shell of crumbled bricks and splintered plywood; the other is 62 families full, with about that many on a waiting list, and courtyards that are a jumble of children, dogs and bicycles.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The company said sales exclude leased departments, which were $5,335,000 and $9,999,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, compared with $4,994,000 for the year- ago quarter and $9,511,000 year-ago 6 months. The latest quarter and 6-month results contain LIFO provisions of $266,000 and $356,000, respectively.

title:
Patents;
Films on Windows To Control Light
description: LEAD: Thin films that can be applied to windows for control of daylight and sunlight have been produced by a method patented this week for the Department of Energy. C. Edwin Tracy and two other staff members of the Solar Energy Research Institute in Golden, Colo., were granted patent 4,687,560.

title: MUSICIAN'S RANGE IS HISTORIC
description: AFTER an hour with Ted Simons, a singer, composer and arranger, you will know, among other things, that ''Dixie'' was written in New York City and that ''Rockabye Baby, on the Treetop'' resulted from a desperate baby sitter's need to calm a frantic child in Winthrop, Mass., in the 1800's.

title:
TV VIEW;
THE F.C.C. DESIGNS A NEW TOASTER
description: LEAD: THE FEDERAL COMMUNICA-tions Commission's recent decision to abolish the Fairness Doctrine predictably drew mixed reactions:

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. We have a white plastic sink that has a yellow stain behind the faucet where water tends to collect. I have tried pure Clorox, a polishing compound and lots of rubbing, but nothing has worked. Do you have any suggestions? A. Most ''plastic'' sinks are made of fiberglass. It is possible the brown stain is actually rust and if so, a rust remover may be your best bet. If this doesn't work, try a cleanser called Zud (sold in many plumbing outlets, as well as in supermarkets). If even this fails, go to a marine supply store and buy a hull cleaner that is sold for removing rust and engine exhaust stains from Fiberglass hulls. These chemical cleaners should also work on your sink. Q. Our house is five years old. A professional termite inspection was done last year when we bought the house and indicated that we have no termite problem at present. I would like to treat my house against termites in the future and have read several articles about this. Can homeowners do a satisfactory job doing this themselves? A. In my opinion, no. Protecting against termites, or treating termites when they are found, is definitely a job for an experienced exterminator who is licensed to do this kind of work. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: Capone Image Backfires on Maryland
description: It seemed like a good idea to Maryland officials: Get maximum publicity for the state's new amnesty program for tax evaders and delinquent taxpayers through a hard-hitting advertising campaign.

title: Comparing Wealth As Money Fluctuates
description: THE United States no longer leads the world in per capita income, as measured in the dwindling dollar valuations of the last two years. But because the prices of food, clothes and other goods in the United States are low compared with other countries, Americans are still ahead in purchasing power.

title: Street Fashion; Now in the Mainstream: Cyclists' Garb
description: ONCE they were seen only on well-muscled young men who huffed and puffed aboard their racing cycles along switchback roads connecting Alpine villages. They still move in fast company, but not always on bicycle racers.

title: 'His Eminence and Hizzoner' to Write a Book
description: Mayor Koch and John Cardinal O'Connor, who were recently described by a mutual friend as ''the temporal and ecclesiastical Odd Couple,'' are collaborating on a book to be entitled ''His Eminence and Hizzoner.'' Each will argue his position on abortion, child care, homosexual rights and other issues on which church and state meet - sometimes head on.

title: Sewer System Intrudes On Burlington Beaches
description: Among the attractions of the City of Burlington are the lovely waters of Lake Champlain and the several miles of public beaches along the lake for swimming and boating.

title: INSTRUCTION
description: Cabinets DIY Video Corporation, 5250 Seventy-Seven Center Drive, Charlotte, N.C. 28210 35 minutes. $19.95.

title: A Money Manager on the Sidelines
description: FEW money managers have been more vocally skeptical during the last 1,000 or so points of the Dow Jones industrial average's ascent than Charles Allmon, president of the Growth Stock Outlook Trust. And today few managers are less apologetic for standing aside than Mr. Allmon, whose closed-end fund - like the private portfolios he manages - was recently sitting with about 70 percent of its assets in cash. One account, a long running portfolio that he tracks in a twice-monthly newsletter, was 80 percent in cash.

title: And if They Succeeded?
description: To the Editor:
