description: Did you borrow to buy a house since Aug. 16, 1986? Are you planning to contribute to a retirement account? Do you intend to deduct losses from an investment partnership this year? If so, Uncle Sam wants to know about it, all about it.

title: Young Voice in Africa: Sports and Clean Living
description: The young man in striped socks and jogging shorts with a referee's whistle around his neck looked familiar.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Downsizing Has Peaked

title: TROUBLED TIMES ALONG THE SHORE
description: THERE were no infestations of frogs or locusts, but the summer season at the Shore will long be remembered for the plagues visited upon it in 1987.

title: PRESSURED ON TRADE, JAPANESE TURN TO THE BUSINESS OF POLITICS
description: IN an era of spiraling American trade deficits and shrinking world markets, Japanese companies and agencies have marshaled some of Washington's best legal and consulting talent - at an estimated cost of $60 million last year - to represent their interests. Trade experts on both sides of the Pacific have doubts about how much bang for the yen is actually delivered by this lobbying armada. But its very existence is testimony to the Japanese determination to master the politics, players and protocol of the Washington trade establishment.

title: U.S. CONVOY BEGINS VOYAGE DOWN GULF
description: Four re-registered Kuwaiti tankers, including the mine-damaged Bridgeton, slipped away from Kuwait before dawn today under American naval escort, beginning their dangerous voyage back down the Persian Gulf.

title: Vermont's Few Blacks Finding Special Problems
description: Gus Gabriel, a student at St. Michael's College in Winooski, says he feels like he is ''constantly under a microscope.''

title: COLOMBIA'S DRUGS AND VIOLENT POLITICS MAKE MURDER A WAY OF LIFE
description: THE story headlined ''Sixteen Murders in Eight Hours in Medellin'' won little space in a leading newspaper here. The killings occurred separately, no one prominent was a victim and no common motive was apparent. ''That's about right,'' a Bogota resident said casually. ''It's usually around 20 murders every 24 hours there at weekends.''

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday on the incoming director of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center misidentified New York's oldest hospital. It is the 251-year-old Bellevue Hospital.

title: Books From The Times
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES COMPLETE GUIDE TO PERSONAL INVESTING. By Gary L. Klott. (Times Books, $22.50.) The investment world is a different and much bigger place in the wake of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Gary L. Klott, a business and financial reporter for The Times, outlines and explains more than 70 current individual investment options, their pros and cons, costs, risks and potential profits - all with an eye on the new tax picture. From annuities and antiques, to saving for college education or retirement, to vacation homes and venture capital, Mr. Klott offers tips for evaluating the field, plus a know-thyself category: ''What kind of individual is best suited to the investment''?

title: Librarians and Aborigines
description: To the Editor:

title: West Germany Arrests 78 In Protest Over Hess's Death
description: Right-wing extremists, some wearing clothing emblazoned with swastikas and others in Nazi uniforms unfurled Nazi banners and chanted ''Rudolf Hess!'' today in this Bavarian town, where the convicted war criminal, is to be buried next week.

title: A True Scoreboard Watcher Knows the Clues
description: AS a Mets season ticket holder, I'm the first to admit that Shea Stadium's bathrooms are fetid, the food rotten and comically expensive and the roar of airplanes overhead a nuisance.

title: NEIGHBORS ACT AS POND'S 'GUARDIAN'
description: LEAD: HOMEOWNERS who live around Little Fresh Pond in the Town of Southampton are giving new meaning to the old adage ''an ounce of prevention is worth a poununofofurur''

title: A MORASS FOR EMPLOYERS
description: LEAD: IN Montclair, a working mother fires her French housekeeper because the housekeeper does not have the proper papers. In Newark, a factory owner has so much trouble finding legal workers that he reduces production and contemplates building a plant in Mexico. In South Jersey, vegetable farmers turn away Hispanic-looking migrants, including Americans from Puerto

title: AIR SHOW ATTRACTS 400,000
description: ONCE a year, what is often called the biggest free show on the East Coast takes place at - and above - McGuire Air Force Base here.

title: AU PAIR PROGRAM A CULTURAL EXCHANGE
description: LEAD: FOR Paula J. Gamache and her husband, Serge Nivelle, a dual-career couple from Scarsdale, finding someone to care for their 6-year-old son, Alex, seemed at times like an impossible quest.

title: ART BORN IN THE FULLNESS OF AGE
description: THOUGH NOTHING IF NOT SPECIFIC, ''old-age art'' as a name lacks glamour. It makes us think of elderly persons pecking in dudgeon at a pre-electric typewriter, turning away in despair from an unfinished canvas or giving up on a commissioned concerto because they cannot think how to get beyond the opening tutti. That name is just too gloomy. ''How about coming round for some old-age art?'' is not an invitation by which courtship can be advanced.

title: CONSIDER DIVISION AND REPLANTING
description: DIG, divide and replant perennials that are well established and overgrown, especially astilbe, phlox, veronica and daylilies. If there are bare sections in the lawn, dig the earth carefully to a depth of a few inches, rake the soil smooth and broadcast quality grass seed; keep these sections moist until seed germination. Harvest tomatoes, sweet corn, squash and beans. Trim hedges. Mail nursery orders for hardy bulbs, perennials, dwarf conifers, azaleas and evergreens for planting next month. Torenia

title: Resurgence of Protozoa May Bear on AIDS and 'Fatigue Virus'
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTY GRANTED DELAY IN SUIT OVER LANDFILL
description: LEAD: THE Federal Government has agreed to a 45-day adjournment of a hearing scheduled for tomorrow on charges that the county should be held in contempt of a 1975 consent judgment for allowing a toxic leachate from the now-closed Croton Point landfill to discharge into a Hudson River swimming area and a nearby marsh.

title: Soviet Sends a 'Glasnost' Group to U.S. Meeting
description: The annual conference on United States-Soviet relations, overshadowed last year by the arrest of an American reporter, will be highlighted this year by a televised speech by President Reagan and the attendance of a Soviet delegation that reads like a Who's Who of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ''glasnost'' campaign.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: AN Ocean County environmental organization has hired four consultants to review a forthcoming feasibility study on how to clean up the Superfund site at the Ciba-Geigy Corporation's Toms River plant, and it is using the company's money to do it.

title: Blues: Buckwheat Zydeco
description: ACCORDION players call their instrument the ''squeeze box,'' and watching Stanley (Buckwheat) Dural play, one begins to understand just how appropriate the term is.

title: BETHANY HOLMES WEDS JOHN FRANK
description: At the First Parish Church in Portland, Me., Bethany Anne Holmes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Shepherd Holmes Jr. of Falmouth Foreside, Me., was married yesterday to John Lanier Frank, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Randolph Adams Frank of Washington. The Rev. Richard Hasty performed the Unitarian ceremony.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Film buffs have three nuggets in store this week: the broadcast premiere of Ingmar Bergman's ''Autumn Sonata'' (1978); a prime-time reprise of Alfred Hitchcock's dazzling Riviera bauble, ''To Catch a Thief'' (1955); and the seldom-shown ''On His Majesty's Secret Service'' (1969), the sixth James Bond thriller.

title: OUR COMPANIONS ON THIS PLANET
description: I read with great concern the article by Susan Merrill entitled ''Growing Complaints Cite Damage by Deer to Shrubs and Crops.''

title: W. DONALD GEORGEN
description: W. Donald Georgen, vice chairman of the board and senior partner of Touche Ross & Company, a major accounting concern, died Friday night at his home in Morristown, N.J., after a long illness. He was 58 years old. Mr. Georgen, who was born in Chicago, was awarded a bachelor's degree from the University of Notre Dame and received a juris doctor degree from Northwestern University.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The outlook for the economy is for slow growth, not fast growth and not no-growth, not a recession.''

title: STILL OF THE NIGHT
description: Sometimes there are nights when I cannot sleep, and I roam the house in search of something elusive. While the others sleep, it seems as if I am completely alone in the world. The darkness, broken only by my flashlight, seems unfamiliar and different.

title: LINCOLN MEETS THE PRESS
description: PICTURE THE EAST Room of the White House set up for a news conference, with the reporters of today's media - thrust back in time to the early 1860's - eager to fire newsmaking and potentially embarrassing questions at the President.

title: In Tiny Tobaccoville, a Giant Plant
description: IN the tiny town of Tobaccoville, N.C., down the road from where farmers stoop in the broiling sun to pluck leaves from tobacco plants, R. J. Reynolds employees are working in the climate-controlled environs of the world's most modern cigarette plant.

title: That '36 Arms Case
description: To the Editor:

title: ICE CREAMS IN SEASONAL FLAVORS
description: Near Amjo's Deli at the corner of Farragut Parkway and Green Street in Hastings is Amjo's Ice Cream and Stationery, under the same ownership - the name is derived from the initials of A Michael and Jorie's Original Store. At the ice-cream store, benches are moved inside or outside, depending on the weather, and the special flavors vary with the seasons, too - peach and fresh blueberry are a current possibility.

title: Librarians and Aborigines
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTER AND BIOGRAPHER
description: Joseph P. Lash, a newspaperman-turned-historian whose lifelong friendship with Eleanor Roosevelt became the basis of an acclaimed biography, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, where he was undergoing treatment for a heart ailment. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN his years as an alcoholic, then a recovering alcoholic doing 12th-step work, then a trade-union alcoholism counselor, Paul had been in and out of hospitals on the Island and elsewhere, but he had never spent any time in, visited anyone in or taken anyone to the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center.

title: How Justice Was Done In the Banking Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAPPED IN THE MUD WITH RED, MY HORSE
description: I WAS so excited. Don and I and our horses were off to Blydenburgh Park to my first Nassau-Suffolk Horsemen's Association event. At last I had my own horse, and trailering to this function inspired me with the exhilaration that comes from having a dream fulfilled.

title: Foreign Brains
description: To the Editor:

title: MISTAKEN IDENTITY
description: ITS ODD, SLIGHTLY OFF-CENTER peaked turret and weathered shingles make this building seem as though it were one of those whimsical English garden structures known as follies, mysteriously washed up on the Massachusetts shore. No clues reveal the real identity of the building. Indeed, even the keenest architectural eye would be hard pressed to know that part of it was originally a carriage house built in 1872 as part of an estate whose grand main house is still up the road.

title: IRAN-CONTRA INQUIRIES FIND MORE LEADS, MORE MYSTERIES
description: THERE are two parts of Wanda Palacio's story that provoke no argument. Her passport shows that she was in Baranquilla, Colombia, in the first week in October 1983. And records show that a plane owned by Southern Air Transport, an airline peripherally involved in resupplying the Nicaraguan contras, stopped at the airport several times during that period to be refueled. Everything else is in dispute.

title:
Headliners;
Terminal Favors
description: LEAD: Donald Harvey said that during four years in which he killed 24 people, mostly elderly or ill patients at a hospital where he worked as a nursing aide, he felt he was ''doing them a favor.'' Mr. Harvey, who is 35 years old, admitted the killings in an Ohio courtroom last week in order to avoid a similar fate himself.

title: Basket, Blanket, Berkshires
description: There is so much going on in the Berkshires that culture-hungry visitors can be as busy there as they would be at home. Happily, many of the area's attractions are outdoors and encourage picnicking. So, armed with a basket of provisions, visitors can satisfy two appetites at once. The following is one picknicker's itinerary. Clark Institute

title:
Headliners;
Addressees Well-Known
description: LEAD: Charles Merrill Mount has an abiding interest in other people's mail, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Mount, an art historian and portrait painter, was arrested in Washington last week for the second time this month on charges related to what the F.B.I. said was one of the largest known thefts of historic American documents.

title: CHEMICAL ACCIDENTS EXPLORED
description: LEAD: FEDERAL, state and local officials as well as industries are struggling to implement a complex portion of last year's Superfund reauthorization law that has nothing to do with cleaning up existing hazardous-waste sites.

title: >PAMELA SHELDON TO WED
description: Pamela Lynn Sheldon, an assistant vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and Matthew Tobin Panarese, a financial analyst for the Philadelphia National Bank, plan to be married in October. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Sheldon of Tempe, Ariz., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Panarese of Milton, Mass. Ms. Sheldon graduated from Stanford University. Her fiance is an alumnus of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: South Leads the Nation in Felony Conviction Rate
description: The South accounts for about a third of the crimes reported in the United States but also for nearly 60 percent of the felony convictions in state courts, the Justice Department says.

title: Youth in West Bank Is Shot
description: Israeli troops shot and wounded a Palestinian youth during disturbances in the town of Nablus in the occupied West Bank Friday, an army spokeswoman said today. The spokeswoman said the youth was slightly wounded when a soldier fired at a crowd that was throwing stones at an army post. He was taken to a local hospital for treatment.

title: Lion Happy to Leave
description: HE'S been a glum, standoffish presence in the Detroit Lion training camp, but now Demetrous Johnson, a safety who was the team's leading tackler last season, can be his old self again. Friday he was dismissed from the team by Coach Darryl Rogers, who said Johnson would be traded or waived tomorrow. Johnson, who had a running conflict with the defensive backfield coach, Willie Shaw, had been seeking a trade since the minicamp in May. ''I feel so relieved,'' Johnson said, ''I'm just happy to be getting out of here.''

title: HUNTINGTON WATERFRONT REPORT COMING OUT AT LAST
description: LEAD: SOMETIME next month, the fourth draft of Huntington's long awaited, much discussed waterfront revitalization report will be available for public scrutiny.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Harmonious Safari
description: LEAD: LAND OF THE TIGER A National Geographic Special. Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: Pop Music
description: Orchard Beach in the Bronx may not have palm trees or conch-fritter vendors. But Sunday from 1 to 9 P.M., it will have some of the best music north of Puerto Rico, in a free salsa concert headlined by Eddie Palmieri. Mr. Palmieri, a pianist, is one of the titans of salsa; his sets incoporate traditional Yoruba drumming, jazzy solos and Mr. Palmieri's salsa hits. The program also features the trumpeter Luis (Perico) Ortiz and his salsa band, with two first-rate guests - Yomo Toro, who has turned the mandolin-like Puerto Rican cuatro into an instrument capable of brilliant solos, and Dave Valentin, a flutist with a sultry tone and virtuosic technique.

title:
ART;
'PAINTERLY PANELS': HYBRID ART
description: LEAD: THERE are many painters for whom the conventional flat format of the canvas does not seem sufficient to contain their imagery, but who hold back from venturing into full three-dimensionality. What they create, in the form of painted reliefs, freestanding panels or shaped canvases, has a hybrid quality that incorporates painting's illusionistic image-making and sculpture's insistent physicality, pushing beyond the boundaries of either discipline.

title: EVELYN QUINTARD GETMAN WED TO JOHN SHERWIN 3D
description: Evelyn Quintard Getman and John Sherwin 3d were married yesterday at the Trinity Episcopal Church on the Green in New Haven by the Rev. Andrew E. Fiddler. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Hood Getman of New Haven. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwin Jr. of Waite Hill, Ohio.

title: A CHINESE PIONEER REVISITED
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Chinese food on Long Island meant sweet and sour pork, shrimp with lobster sauce and other standard Cantonese dishes. When Szechuan Royal in East Northport opened 12 years ago, it was a trailblazer into the spicy unknown of Sichuan cuisine.

title: Wilmington, Del.: Raceway's Bid For Mall Falters
description: JOHN A. ROLLINS SR., a millionaire businessman, is in a race with a national real-estate syndicate to see who will be the first to develop an upscale regional shopping center.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Inoculations At the 11th Hour

title: LESSONS ON UNDERWATER PATHOLOGY
description: THE waterway appears to be just another small creek flowing into the Pamlico River here. But, it is also the discharge point for as much as 60 million gallons a day of phosphate-laden water from an 80,000-acre phosphate mining and processing plant.

title: Steinbrenner and 'Star Quality'
description: THE SCRAP of paper in the hotel hallway was tiny, but not small enough to escape the owner's attention. George Steinbrenner stooped to pick it up, walked a few feet, and saw another scrap, equally small. He mumbled in exasperation at these cleaning errors as he bent to retrieve the second piece. He bobbled it for a second -Columbus for you! - then saw a third. He scooped it up, deposited all three in a waste can and continued, uninterrupted by dirt, to lunch.

title: >MS. MARSHALL PLANS TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burke Marshall of Newtown, Conn., and North Haven, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catie Marshall to Nelson Bakerman, the son of Barbara Bakerman of Keansburg, N.J., and Harvey Bakerman of Red Bank, N.J. The couple plan to marry in October. Ms. Marshall, assistant commissioner for public affairs in the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, graduated from the Milton Academy and Brown University. Her father is the Nicholas deB. Katzenbach Professor of Law at the Yale University Law School. He was assistant attorney general in charge of civil rights in the administrations of Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, and was vice president and general counsel of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: LISA GRIFFIN AND HARRY C. HAGERTY 3D ARE PLANNING TO BE MARRIED IN OCTOBER
description: Mary Elisabeth Griffin and Harry Coleman Hagerty 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hagerty Jr. of Rye, N.Y., plan to marry in October, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John T. Griffin of Oyster Harbors, Mass., and Jupiter Island, Fla., have announced.

title: Police Academy in Jersey Closes To Avoid Risk of Liability Suits
description: The Essex County police academy has been closed indefinitely because the association of police chiefs that runs it cannot afford liability insurance, according to the dean of the academy.

title: 18 Restaurants in New York Cited for Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 18 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Schroeder: At Ease With Femininity and Issues
description: It has been three years since Geraldine A. Ferraro, running for Vice President on the Democratic ticket, was presented with wrist corsages and quizzed about her cooking skills and introduced as ''most of all, a mother.''

title: Kipling's Sussex Retreat
description: What a splendid Victorian Rudyard Kipling was. When he was not in India gathering material to give the British pride in their greatest imperial holding there, he was elsewhere in the empire, even venturing to a former part of it and living for four years in Dummerston, Vt. But in the last three decades of his life, whenever he could, he went to that other great symbol of England, his country home.

title: Iran Sends Mixed Signals, Often on Purpose
description: IF Iran seems to speak to the world with conflicting voices, it may be because the Government here is being forced to respond simultaneously to pressures from many different quarters, both at home and abroad.

title: >BONNIE REICH IS MARRIED
description: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., Bonnie Ellen Reich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Raymond Reich of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to John Ansbro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Andrew Ansbro of New York. The Rev. John Ansbro performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass celebrated by the Rev. Andrew Ansbro; both are uncles of the bridegroom. The bride is a project coordinator for Herman Miller Inc., an office furniture manufacturer in New York. Mr. Ansbro expects to graduate in January from the Columbia University School of General Studies.

title: STATE OF THE SOUND: A SCIENTIST'S VIEW
description: THIS summer, Long Island Sound has seen thousands of fish and lobster die as a result of low oxygen conditions, particularly in the western end, and in some isolated eastern bays. Experts attribute much of the problem to the fact that there are 18 million people who live within 30 miles of the Sound and 44 sewage plants dumping 1.1 billion gallons of waste a day in the waterway. Seventy-five rivers and streams flow into the estuary, carrying manure and fertilizers from farms, lawn chemicals and other organic material.

title: Behind the Gulf Buildup: The Unforeseen Occurs
description: President Reagan decided in March to protect Kuwait's oil tankers in the Persian Gulf after being told by his senior Cabinet advisers that it could be done without any increase in America's naval forces there, according to Administration officials.

title: For Canada's Chief, 3-Year-Old Victory Turns Sour
description: Around the neo-Gothic buildings that house the Canadian Parliament there was more than the clammy 90-degree heat this week to furrow the brows of many of the legislators working their way through a summer session.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Swimming Record in Freestyle: Anke Moehring of East Germany set a world record yesterday in the women's 800-meter freestyle at the European Championships in Strasbourg, France, to lower the mark an American swimmer, Janet Evans, set July 27. Moehring, 17, finished in 8 minutes 19.53 seconds, almost three seconds under Evans's time. Moehring's performance highlighted the continued domination of the East German women and brought the world record total to five this week. Kristin Otto won her fifth gold medal when she led off the East German 400-meter medley relay. (AP) Tennis Clemson Student Top Amateur: Brian Page of Palos Hills, Ill., the favorite, rallied from a 3-5 deficit in the first set and beat second-seeded Eric Amend of Los Angeles, 7-6, 6-4, to win the men's singles final of the United States National Amateur championships at the Concord Hotel in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y. Page, a 21-year-old senior at Clemson, lost only one set in six matches.(AP) Track and Field Britons Lead in London: Steve Cram and Linford Christie, two of Britain's biggest medal hopes, posted impressive victories in London yesterday in the last international warm-up meet before the world championships in Rome. Greg Foster, America's 110-meter hurdles ace, also was defeated. Cram won the 1,000-meter event in two minutes, 17.15 seconds. (AP) Baseball Whalers Win Title: David DePaul and Dion Williams were named individual award winners, and the Whalers won the team championship yesterday as the Empire State League completed its first season on Long Island. DePaul, an outfielder, won the Roger Kahn rookie award, named for the son of the writer Roger Kahn. The younger Kahn died this summer. The Whalers beat the Diggers, 10-4, for the title. Williams hit .353 with 11 homers to win the most valuable player award.

title: What's Left Out, and Who
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock: Motley Crue With Whitesnake, at Garden
description: THE star of Motley Crue's show Thursday at Madison Square Garden was a machine - a lift that carried Tommy Lee's drum setup to the front of the stage, rocked it from side to side, then turned it in complete somersaults as the drummer pounded away. Pausing at various angles, the setup re-created the overhead and tilted-camera shots of rock videos; the crowd, cued by narration from Mr. Lee, roared at each realignment.

title: Music Boxes Contain Echoes of the Past
description: THOSE WHO ARE IN-volved in Victorian restoration and are striving for absolute authenticity in interior details may well look to antique music boxes. More than any velvet settee or lace curtains, the tinkling melodies from an antique music box recapture a tranquilizing sound from yesteryear.

title: Hospital Patient Becomes Its Patron
description: Benjamin Eisenstadt says he hates begging money for his favorite local charity, Maimonides Medical Center in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Aircraft Data for Public Debated in Industry
description: Airline officials say informing passengers about the mechanical and safety history of a type of aircraft or a specific plane, such as the Northwest Airlines jetliner that crashed in Detroit, could be misleading and might unduly alarm people.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RIDING THE DOLPHIN. By Amanda Thomas. (Peter Weed/Beaufort, $17.95.) What does life in the suburbs look like from the point of view of a 24-year-old schizophrenic photographer? The San Francisco Bay Area writer Amanda Thomas (a pseudonym) explores this question in her delightfully written and terribly clever first-person novel.

title: Streetscapes: East 92d Street Rowhouses; 19th Century Vestiges Topple to Meet School Needs
description: FROM the beginning, the proposal by the Nightingale-Bamford School to double its size with an 11-story addition on the south side of East 92d Street, off Fifth Avenue, has upset residents of the Upper East Side neighborhood. The dispute had its beginnings in 1974, when the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission excluded the Nightingale-Bamford site in a revised Carnegie Hill Historic District.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Trade-Up Buyers Spur Sales in Suffolk
description: LEAD: WHEN Thomas and Barbara Budd bought their first house 12 years ago, they settled for a 1,200-square-foot, no-frills ranch, built on a slab on a third-of-an-acre lot in a Mount Sinai development. The $42,000 price was all they could afford. Earlier this month, they entered into a contract to buy a $224,000, 2,070-square-foot Cape

title: THE NEW MOOD
description: It's not exactly a rerun of the mad, iconoclastic 1960's, but a new, adventurous spirit is abroad in the fashion world.

title: A LOOK AT KNEES
description: Women all over America are rediscovering their knees, and many don't like what they see. For after many comforting years when the knee and often even the lower leg were shrouded in billows of fabric, short skirts are again exposing what, for some, was best left unexposed.

title: Tying Knots In Delaware
description: LAST year, 5,484 couples were married in Delaware, or so they thought.

title: ANDRE ALSBERG HUNTER WEDS KELLY M. FOWLER
description: Kelly Marie Fowler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kirby Fowler of Flemington, N.J., and Andre Alsberg Hunter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan B. Hunter of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Chapel at Mount St. Mary Academy in Watchung, N.J. The Rev. John L. O'Connor, assisted by Rabbi Jonathan J. Prinz, performed the ceremony.

title: Crayfish, The Gem Of the Columbia
description: There's a little-known delicacy ambling about the Northwest's river and lake bottoms. Restaurantgoers in Portland, Ore., have known about it since at least 1892. Now Seattle seafood fans are catching on and devouring the Northwest crayfish with gusto.

title: Landing Gear Failures Strike Two Passenger Jets
description: A Trans World Airlines jetliner with its landing gear stuck was diverted today from a St. Louis airport to nearby Scott Air Force Base, where it landed safely on two of its three sets of wheels.

title: Georgia Captures Fugitive
description: Almost two years after she escaped from a Connecticut prison, a woman convicted of manslaughter is in the custody of Georgia officials. The woman, Diana Hamilton, 21 years old, of Norfolk, Conn., was charged with interstate flight and being a fugitive from justice after her capture Thursday, Gwinnett County sheriff's officials said.

title: North Korea Is Told of Loan Default
description: In the first formal loan default by any country since the international debt crisis began in August 1982, Western banks have notified North Korea that it is in default and that it could soon face legal proceedings to seize some of its property abroad, banking sources say.

title: ALICE P. ALBRIGHT IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Madeleine Korbel Albright of Washington and Joseph Medill Patterson Albright of Rome of the engagement of their daughter Alice Patterson Albright to Gregory Bigelow Bowes, the son of Judith G. Bowes of Chevy Chase, Md., and David B. Bowes of Washington. An October wedding is planned.

title: Alpine Voyaging From Lake to Lake
description: LEAD: Winding your way through Switzerland by ship? The suggestion, discovered in a brochure, that one could travel through the Alps and much of Europe's highest, craggiest and most breathtaking terrain by water struck me as rather implausible if not absurd. Until I took a closer look.

title: ACCESS CHANNEL IS PRESSED
description: LEAD: IN many communities, ''public access,'' which is required by the Federal Communications Commission, means that cable television companies must provide a channel that will allow the broadcasting of programming by local residents - anything from home videos to interview shows - free.

title: Manila Debates a Move to Bar Nuclear Arms
description: A nationwide debate over the presence of two bases vital to the United States has begun with the filing in the Senate of two bills that would bar nuclear weapons from the country.

title: VISIT BY SWEDE TO UNDERLINE BETTER U.S. TIES
description: A recent improvement in Sweden's political relations with the United States will be formally underlined early next month when Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson goes to Washington for the first state visit there by a Swedish Prime Minister in 26 years.

title: From Preschool to High School: What a New Schools Chancellor Can Do
description: The New York City Board of Education has just begun what is almost sure to be a controversial search for a new Schools Chancellor to replace Nathan Quinones.

title: Squeezing More Into the Package
description: HOW many cigarettes can you put into a pack? For years, the answer was 20.

title: NEW LIFE FOR PEEKSKILL INDUSTRIAL PARK
description: LEAD: THE former Standard Brands Plant at Charles Point in Peekskill once manufactured vodka, gin, yeast, vinegar and molasses in a sprawling complex of seven buildings. Founded at the turn of the century by Charles Fleischmann, it was considered the largest factory of its kind at the time.

title:
ANTIQUES;
18TH-CENTURY SKILLS AT JOCKEY HOLLOW
description: LEAD: THE natural beauty of the New Jersey countryside is nowhere more apparent than at Jockey Hollow in the Morristown National Historical Park.

title: Soviet Will Enter Horse in D.C. Race
description: A Soviet horse will race in the Washington D.C. International for the first time in 21 years at the 36th running of the event Oct. 31.

title: THE RED, WHITE AND BLUE IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: HOLLYWOOD GOES TO WAR How Politics, Profits, and Propaganda Shaped World War II Movies. By Clayton R. Koppes and Gregory D. Black. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: INTO EACH MIDLIFE SOME RAIN MUST FALL
description: 50 By Avery Corman. 254 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Defending Steeplechasing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Word From Our Sponsor
description: LINGUISTICALLY speaking (and that's still the preferred way), there is only one rule in advertising: There are no rules. ''We try harder,'' lacks parallelism. ''Nobody doesn't like Sara Lee,'' is a double negative. And ''Modess. Because. . . .'' Because . . . why? My friends didn't know. My mother wouldn't tell. My sister said, like Mount Everest, because it was there. The word ''creme'' on a product means there's no cream in it. ''Virtually,'' as in ''Virtually all our cars are tested,'' means in essence, not in fact. Even a casual ''Let's have lunch,'' said in passing on Mad Ave. means ''Definitely, let's not.''

title: ELIZABETH LEWIS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Elizabeth Perry Lewis, a daughter of Dr. John Leeman Lewis Jr. of New York and Jane Darling Lewis of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to William Elliott Matthews 5th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthews 4th of Birmingham, Ala. The Rev. Heidi Hudnut and the Rev. Dr. Robert S. Crutchfield performed the ceremony.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE VICE-CONSUL. By Marguerite Duras. Translated by Eileen Ellenbogen. (Pantheon, Cloth, $10.95; Paper, $6.95.) Marguerite Duras called this novel, published in France in 1966 and only now translated - competently - into English, her ''strongest and most violent joy.'' In it she has created characters whose emotional intensity far surpasses the events of their lives.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Cornfield's Future Debated in Fairlawn
description: LEAD: FOR nearly half a century, the 23-acre parcel of land in the 200-acre Fairlawn Industrial Park along Route 208 has remained untouched - a rare patch of farmland used as cornfields. The corn still stands high in what is now the park's last open tract, but its development appears certain.

title: SWEET ARE THE USES OF ANTHOLOGY
description: Every reader is an anthologist, but few carry the mania for selecting to the extreme of compiling a book. Memory keeps records for us, chooses this story and drops that one, builds odd manticores out of authors who happen to have met at our bedside. As readers, we change what writers write, cut it to fit our daily quotas, give it the tone of that particular moment in which something was read, mirror it in other texts of similar plot or style - in a word, make the writing ours. And because reading is a lonely vice, we frequently bring others into our reading; we nudge them to listen, to share our delight or disgust, to judge our selection. Every reader is an anthologist who breeds readers. When I was 10 or 11, and living in Buenos Aires, my eldest aunt, who late in life had adopted strict Edwardian manners, gave me her commonplace book. It was a scrapbook with fake white marble covers, and on the gray pages my aunt had copied out favorite passages from a long life of reading -mainly Spanish romantic poets and French novelists now mercifully forgotten, such as Jose de Espronceda and Anatole France. She had inscribed the names of the authors in her voluted handwriting, but to me the only author of this collection was my aunt. I could recognize, here and there, lines that she was Continued on page 22 fond of repeating, and certain words and phrases that had her intonation. ''He had never known desire except in the uttermost depths of love,'' my aunt's voice sang from the page. The line, used to describe one of my more colorful uncles, had thrilled me. When, years later, I came across these same words in France's romance ''The Gods Are Thirsty,'' they seemed unbearably trite.

title: Officials Agree On a New Road At Westway Site
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch said yesterday that they had agreed to proceed with the final design and construction of a six-lane highway and waterfront esplanade on the West Side of Manhattan as a replacement for the city's aborted Westway project.

title: A DEGREE OF DETACHMENT
description: Dr. Shragg's ''detachment,'' it seems to me, is simply one way of being appropriate with his patients. All too often, radiologists and other physician and nonphysician providers of technical components of medicine are entrapped by their ''attachment'' and thus reveal information to patients that, coming from them, is inappropriate and does not serve the patient. LESTER A. KLEIN, M.D. Boston

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: June 9 ended our fourth trip to and through the Soviet Union. Each trip confirms that the U.S.S.R. is not a service-oriented country. Intourist may rate hotels and services first class, deluxe, etc., but they are using perhaps Soviet standards, which are not strictly comparable to the United States or Britain. That's O.K. It is their right to run things the way they want and our option - the tourists who choose to go or not to go - so long as we all know the ground rules.

title: SMALL AIRFIELDS YIELD TO THE VALUE OF THEIR LAND
description: MANY of Connecticut's 18 privately owned commercial airstrips were started by World War II pilots returning home who wanted to continue flying as a hobby. Today, however, they are finding that hobby expensive. Their land, often hundreds of acres next to a major thoroughfare, has increased dramatically in value, to the point where it no longer makes economic sense for them to operate it as an airport.

title:
Headliners;
Tossed Out
description: LEAD: After he beat all but one of his competitors in the hammer throw at the Pan American Games, Bill Green of Torrance, Calif., was found to have had help. Officials of the Pan American Sports Organization stripped Green of his silver medal last week after he tested positive for one of the 3,700 substances banned by the International Olympic Committee.

title: 2 EVENTS TO MARK EQUALITY DAY
description: AT an undisclosed location, women in the county, including lawyers and secretaries, accountants and artists, have secretly been meeting weekly for seven years. The number keeps growing, but the purpose remains the same: peer support for women sexually abused by a family member.

title: British Stocks Recover a Bit
description: British stocks advanced Friday, but the gains were not enough to offset sharp declines earlier in the week caused by fears that inflation could be set off by free-spending, big-borrowing consumers.

title: Report Warns School Reforms May Fall Short
description: Recent efforts to improve the quality of American public elementary and secondary schools may fall short of the expectations of educators and political leaders, the Congressional Budget Office warned yesterday.

title: Rebecca Rozen Is Wed To Richard Kahlenberg
description: The marriage of Rebecca Ann Rozen, a daughter of Dr. Dinah Moche of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late I. Robert Rozen, to Richard Dawson Kahlenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Kahlenberg of Ridgewood, N.J., took place yesterday at the Thayer Hotel in West Point, N.Y. Joseph L. Thomson, a justice of the peace in Cornwall, N.Y., officiated.

title: Actors Need Not Apply?
description: Another actor for President?

title: Yen's Surge Helps Asians Lure Industry From Japan
description: The surge in the value of the Japanese yen is changing economies throughout Asia, altering longtime alliances and endowing new prosperity on nations from Taiwan to Thailand.

title: 13 Latin Nations End Meeting on Peace Pact
description: Foreign ministers from 13 Latin American countries ended their meeting here today after creating a commission to verify compliance with a Central American peace accord.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 20% Have Sought Aid on Drinking, Poll Says
description: One in five adult Americans reports having sought medical or other professional help for a drinking problem involving either himself or a member of his family, according to a Gallup Poll whose findings were issued yesterday.

title: Edberg Beats Becker in Final
description: Stefan Edberg of Sweden beat Boris Becker of West Germany, 6-4, 6-1, with a dazzling serve-and-volley display today to win the $375,000 Association of Tennis Professionals Championship.

title: Diane Smith, TV Anchor, Weds Thomas Woodruff
description: At the Inn at Long Shore in Westport, Conn., yesterday, Diane Marie Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas James Smith of Suffern, N.Y., became the bride of Thomas Charles Woodruff, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bernard Woodruff of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. Albert Ciarcia, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Razzmatazz The Cafe Versailles, at 151 East 50th Street, is a 1940's-style nightclub - complete with glittery showgirl revues and late-night dining and dancing. A new revue called ''High Energy'' opens at the club tonight.

title: Nicaraguan Hope Rises For Independent Press
description: Mechanics are oiling idle presses at La Prensa, the opposition newspaper, reflecting hopes that press freedom will soon be restored here under terms of a new Central American peace accord.

title: The Central American Peace Plea
description: The paradox of the peace plan agreed upon by the five Central American presidents is that it is both the best hope for peace in their region and the chimera the State Department suspects. Those who would sabotage the plan, chiefly Reagan Administration hard-liners and their apologists, continually forget whom the Nicaraguan revolution belongs to in the first place.

title: Lima Journal; Rising Beside the Garbage Mounds: Expectations
description: With its smoldering garbage, stray dogs, countless children and ever-present trucks taking Coca-Cola to corner stores, Villa el Salvador at first seems indistinguishable from the other shantytowns that surround Lima and most other Latin American cities.

title: Robins Has New Plan For Claims
description: The A. H. Robins Company, which has agreed to merge with Rorer Group Inc., said yesterday that it had filed a new reorganization plan to emerge from bankruptcy.

title: Business and the Law; States Protect Merger Targets
description: FACING an unfriendly takeover attempt from T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, and his Mesa Limited Partnership, executives of the Singer Company decided last week to do what any other beseiged warrior might do: seek a safe harbor.

title: Spain to Get 300 Dali Works
description: An Irish art collector said today that he was donating his collection of 300 works by the Surrealist painter Salvador Dali to the Spanish state.

title: Adventure In the Sun
description: BEFORE yesterday's game against the Padres, Dwight Gooden, in his three-and-a-half-year major league career, had a tremendous night-game record of 50 victories and 10 losses, but a relatively paltry 18-13 record for day games. In his previous two starts, both in daylight, he lost to the Cubs at Shea Stadium and then squandered a five-run lead for a no-decision against the Cubs in Chicago. Knock, knock. Who's there? It's me Doc, Davey. Davey? Davey who? Oh c'mon, Doc, You know. Davey, your manager. What is it? What do you want - at this hour? Do you know what time it is? Certainly. It's 10 in the morning. Just came by to remind you about the game we have this afternoon. You're pitching. Uh, this afternoon? Is it light out? Doc, you know it's light out at this hour. Will it be light out for the game, too? Doc! It's an afternoon game! Well, sometimes they get those eclipse things. Doc, open the door. Can't, Skip. Why not? Under the bed. What are you doing under the bed? I'm comfortable here, Skip. It's the way I like to work. You mean you work best under the bed? No, Skip. I work best in the dark. Count - I mean, Doc - don't be silly. Sure, in the old days there was a guy who even slept in a crypt until the sun went down, but. . . A crypt? No kidding. Never tried that. Is it comfortable? I don't think I'd trade it for my king-size mattress, Doc. Besides, scientists have discovered that a little sun is good for you. Vitamin C and all that. That's easy for you to say. You can always stay in the dark of the dugout. C'mon Doc, come out from under the bed. Skip? Yeah Doc, yeah? Good night.

title: They're More Efficient
description: To the Editor:

title: Re-Registered Ships Halfway Down Gulf Under Escort of U.S.
description: The latest American-escorted convoy of Kuwaiti tankers moved farther down the Persian Gulf tonight.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Iowa Newcomer Will Get a Chance
description: LEAD: HAYDEN FRY did not get the Iowa football team to where it is by fooling around with untried talent. But unless the Hawkeyes' coach changes his mind before Sunday, he will open the season in the Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium with a quarterback who is 12 passes removed from high school.

title: Walton Will Stay With Plans for Jets
description: Ken O'Brien and Mark Gastineau are having lackluster exhibition seasons: O'Brien has been unable to find his receivers, or has been pressured into releasing the ball too quickly. Gastineau, once the most-watched defensive end in the game, hasn't come within whispering distance of an opposing quarterback.

title: Backman, Johnson Talk
description: Wally Backman, an unhappy second baseman, and Dave Johnson, the Mets' manager, had what Backman described as ''a friendly talk'' before yesterday's game about the manager's strategy Saturday night.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BPT Associates, a joint venture of Bechtel Investments Inc. and Park Tower Realty, elected Donald R. Knab chief executive.

title: Christy L. McElhaney Marries Mark A. Sunshine
description: Christy Lee McElhaney, the daughter of Georgia Lee McElhaney of Shepherdstown, W. Va., and the late Dr. James McElhaney, was married yesterday to Mark Allen Sunshine, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Sunshine of Fairfield, Conn. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in Manhattan.

title: 3 Killed in Punjab Gunfight
description: Separatist gunmen shot dead a woman and the bodyguard of a police chief in the Sikh holy city of Amritsar today, the Press Trust of India reported. One gunman also died in the shootout.

title: Cuomo Calls for a 'New Realism' By U.S. in Relations With Soviet
description: Governor Cuomo called today for a ''new realism'' in American foreign policy and said that now was the time to bring about an end to the cold war.

title: In a Polish City, Jews Again Mourn
description: ''It was sunny, exactly like this, a beautiful day, maybe a little warmer,'' David Glenn said as crisp sunlight filtered down, mocking the darkness of the crimes committed here more than four decades ago.

title: Bangladesh Asking Flood Aid
description: Bangladesh is seeking emergency international aid for the victims of floods that have afflicted one-sixth of its 105 million people, Government officials said today.

title: Alana Ackler Is Bride Of Jack S. Abramowitz
description: At the Washington Hotel in Belle Harbor, Queens, Alana Ackler, a daughter of Raphael Ackler of Holon, Israel, and Marilyn Orenstein of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Jack Steven Abramowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Abramowitz of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Dr. Manfred Fulda officiated.

title: Atlantic City Opens Most of Beach Again
description: All but a block stretch of Atlantic City's beach was open for swimming yesterday, three days after high bacteria levels forced health officials to close the entire four-mile shoreline.

title:
Market Place;
Dow Looks Toward 3,000
description: LEAD: IT IS slowly dawning on investors, traders and analysts that the Dow Jones industrial average is nearing 3,000, a figure that - bull market or no bull market - has until recently seemed almost mythic.

title: Peter Orlov, Psychiatrist, Marries Peggy Ann Cohn
description: Peggy Ann Cohn, a daughter of Martin L. Cohn 3d of Deal, N.J., and the late Myra Stein Cohn, was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Andrew Orlov, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Orlov of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Phillip Hiat performed the ceremony at the Hollywood Golf Club in Deal.

title: TV: Tribute to Gershwin, on PBS
description: GEORGE GERSHWIN was born in Brooklyn in 1898, the second of four children born to an immigrant family named Gershowitz. He died of a brain tumor in 1937. His first published song, in 1916, was ''When You Want 'Em, You Can't Get 'Em.'' His last, completed by his older brother Ira, was ''Our Love Is Here to Stay.'' A prodigious composer, he turned out popular songs for stage and screen, more ambitious pieces for the concert hall, and the American folk opera ''Porgy and Bess.'' In the history of American music in this century, Gershwin is indisputably a giant.

title: Miriam Gruen Weds Jeffrey Kosowsky
description: At the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn, Miriam Aviva Gruen, the daughter of Dr. Rhoda Gruen and Dr. George E. Gruen of New York, and Jeffrey Joseph Kosowsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Kosowsky of Brookline, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Yitzhak I. Twersky officiated. Mrs. Kosowsky, a member of the class of '89 at the Harvard Law School, graduated summa cum laude from Barnard College. Her father is the director of Israel and Middle East affairs for the American Jewish Committee and an associate of the Columbia University Seminar on the Middle East. Her mother is assistant to the director of pharmacology and chemotherapy at Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. in Nutley, N.J.

title: The Dollar's Stumble: A Restrained Response
description: The dollar has taken another clobbering in the foreign exchange markets following the Government report a week ago of unexpected deterioration in the United States foreign trade accounts.

title: The U.S. Thumbs Its Nose
description: LEAD: Representatives of nations around the world will gather in New York City beginning today to discuss the relationship between reducing military spending and increasing funds for economic development. One country, the United States, will stage a lonely boycott of the United Nations-sponsored conference.

title: Battered American Boxers Assess Effort
description: After the boxers from Cuba completed their record-breaking business with their 10th gold medal of the Pan American Games, Roosevelt Sanders, the coach of the battered and exhausted United States team, said this was not the most overwhelming performance he had seen.

title: U.S. and Soviet Deny Planning September Meeting
description: American and Soviet officials said today that there were no plans for a summit meeting in September between Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and President Reagan.

title: T. D'Alesandro Jr., a Baltimore Mayor, Dies
description: Thomas D'Alesandro Jr., Mayor of Baltimore from 1947 to 1959 and an influence in Maryland and national Democratic politics for many years before that, died yesterday in his city's Mercy Hospital after a heart attack. He was 84 years old. The son of Italian immigrants, Mr. D'Alesandro was a lifelong resident and tireless, ribbon-cutting booster of Baltimore. He entered politics in 1927 as a member of the Maryland State Legislature and won his next 22 campaigns for the City Council, the House of Representatives and City Hall.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has an unseeded tennis player ever won the United States Open?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in The Living Section on Aug. 5 with an article on food costs nationwide omitted information on researchers' calculation of the market basket cost for New York City.

title: Democrats, in Iowa Debate, Make Reagan Their Target
description: Seven Democrats seeking their party's 1988 Presidential nomination spent two hours this afternoon debating economic issues, but they took sharper aim at the Reagan Administration than they did each other.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Personal Income ..... July Tuesday Durable Goods ..... July Wednesday Merchandise Trade Balance ..... Second Quarter Thursday None Friday None

title: Goodbye Gable: Regency Is Mourned
description: In New York City, things change so quickly that many people try to minimize their attachments. That way, if the Coliseum is razed or Times Square grows dark or the Museum of the American Indian goes to Texas, they will not be caught feeling as if all their old friends have moved to the suburbs.

title: Police Officer Shot On Lower East Side
description: A police officer was shot and wounded Saturday night on the roof of an abandoned building on the Lower East Side, the police said yesterday. The gunman escaped.

title: Cards Sweep Past Reds, 12-6
description: Tom Herr knocked in three runs and Ozzie Smith and Terry Pendleton drove in two each today as the St. Louis Cardinals routed the Cincinnati Reds, 12-6, to complete a three-game series sweep.

title: Scrap Deregulation and Merge All the Airlines
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FIRST LIGHT. By Charles Baxter. 286 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: They Take Shortcuts
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTHUR N. LEVIEN
description: Arthur N. Levien, a builder and co-developer of the 52-story Olympic Tower on Fifth Avenue, died of complications from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's Disease, Saturday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in Queens. He was 69 years old and lived in Aventura, Fla.

title: U.S. Is Exporting Antiabortion Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: 'No-Rejection' Ads Criticized
description: Insurance regulators across the country are moving to control controversial life insurance policies that they say are deluding thousands of elderly Americans yearly - the so-called ''low-cost'' policies that guarantee acceptance to anyone.

title: Sports World Specials; Stuffed Superstition
description: A rabbit's foot has long been considered a good luck charm, but when it comes to such superstitions, Val Skinner is a golfer who doesn't go in for halfway measures.

title: The Courtship Of a Consultant
description: Franklin Greer, a Democratic media consultant, returned from vacation last week to start work on an enviable decision: Before he left, three Presidential campaigns had approached his company, Greer & Associates, to discuss the 1988 race.

title: DESIGNING LIFE, BY THE RULES
description: ''I'm expressing civil disobedience. We can sit and talk about Dutch elm disease, or we can do something about it.'' So says Gary Strobel, a plant biologist at Montana State University, after injecting genetically altered bacteria into elm trees without Federal permission. The present rules, he says, are ''almost ludicrous.'' A pamphlet from the prestigious National Academy of Sciences comes close to saying the same thing.

title: Advertising; Arby's Account Given To Doner of Baltimore
description: After looking at reels from 75 agencies and visiting 11 of them, Arby's, the fast-food chain that has cornered the roast beef niche, chose W.B. Doner, Baltimore, on Friday to handle the $10 million account for its 1,700 restaurants. Doner's closest competitor was Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, New York.

title: Argentine Elections to Pose A Tough Test for Alfonsin
description: President Raul Alfonsin, still trying to ward off the effects of the military crisis in April, is fighting for the survival of some of his key policy goals in congressional and gubernatorial elections on Sept. 6.

title: 'PEOPLE BEGAN TO CRY,' THEN PLANE SKIDDED IN
description: Passengers fearing for their lives screamed, wept and prayed Saturday as a Trans World Airlines jetliner approached Scott Air Force Base for an emergency landing on only two of its three sets of wheels.

title: Dance: Prague Troupe
description: SUCH familiar subjects as disaffiliation, love and death informed the dances presented on Saturday night at the Gershwin Theater at Brooklyn College. What was remarkable about the program was that most of the dances were created by Czechoslovak choreographers for a Czechoslovak troupe - the Charles University Dance Company - and they were modern dance rather than traditional ballet or folk dance. This was not the most sophisticated modern dance, perhaps, but neither were the pieces presented by the Brooklyn Dance Theater on the shared program. But clearly modern dance is alive and well in Prague, where the venerable Charles University is based, and the skilled dancers have a freshness and winning modesty that made them standouts in this hectic New York dance year.

title: Rates Expected to Go Higher
description: Treasury bond yields are again flirting with 9 percent, and the mood of the credit markets is bleak.

title: Motown Executive Scouting Abroad
description: Lee Young Jr. has watched the repeated successes of American record companies that have signed foreign entertainers. So Mr. Young, who was named president last week of the music group of Motown Industries, says he will try to emulate them by adding to his company's roster of non-American performers.

title: F.A.A. Chief Says New Rule Isn't a Ban on Small Planes
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration said today that the proposal to extend tight restrictions to nine additional airports was not intended to keep major airports from being used by private pilots and small planes.

title: Yanks Win One From the Mound
description: It began to look like just another miserable day for the Yankees in the sixth inning. Rick Rhoden began his slow walk toward the mound, but he never threw a pitch. His shoulder, struck by a line drive last week in Seattle, had tightened.

title: Haig Criticizes Reagan And a Key G.O.P. Idea
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., whose long-shot Presidential campaign is still attracting relatively little attention, has stepped up his criticism of President Reagan, his rival Republican candidates and a nearly sacrosanct party position.

title: Metro Matters; After His Stroke, Koch Broadens Scope of Agenda
description: Considering the scandals that have haunted his administration, Mayor Koch probably wishes he could begin his third term all over again. Now the minor stroke he suffered might give him that chance.

title: Macy Planning to Open Three Specialty Stores
description: R. H. Macy & Company, which for years has resisted the industry trend of opening specialty stores, said that it would introduce three such stores in November.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Nicaragua Over the Years
description: Just 75 years ago, a Republican President was so vexed with Nicaragua that he asked a Marine hero to bring it true democracy. The hero was Major Smedley Butler, nicknamed ''Old Gimlet Eyes,'' who had twice daringly rescued wounded comrades during the Boxer Rebellion. Butler's forces landed on Aug. 16, 1912, along with this note from Washington:

title: Turmoil and a Scandal Take a Toll on Gandhi
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has survived his biggest political crisis since taking office in 1984, but he continues to be seen as an enigmatic politician whom many Indians do not trust or even know very well.

title: Iranian Voices Doubts On U.N. Cease-Fire Call
description: Iran's Deputy Foreign Minister for International Affairs expressed his Government's doubts today about whether Teheran would accept a United Nations resolution calling for a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Proper Use of Grants
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Hyman, a Lawyer, Is Married to David Fogel
description: Sharon Hyman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Avrum Hyman of Riverdale, the Bronx, and David J. Fogel, the son of Mrs. Aharon Fogel of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Fogel, were married yesterday at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt officiated, assisted by Cantor Zalman Baumgarten.

title: Ex-U.S. Banker, 82, Still Active Abroad
description: In one recent 24-hour period, George S. Moore conducted a round of business talks in Manhattan that included lunch and dinner, flew to Madrid for breakfast and lunch appointments, and by 4:30 P.M. was on a plane to his home here on the Costa del Sol for a dinner party.

title: Morris, Gibson Pace Tigers
description: Jack Morris pitched a five-hitter today and Kirk Gibson hit a three-run home run as the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-3.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 24, 1987
description: International

title: Hertz to Leave South Africa
description: The Hertz Corporation, the world's largest car rental company, said today that it would be ending its presence in South Africa during the next 18 months and merging its operation here with a local company, Imperial Car Rental. In a statement issued to the

title: Bridge: Book on Monks of St. Titus Is in English Comic Tradition
description: English writers on bridge have no peers when it comes to creating a cast of humorous characters involved in extraordinary events at the card table. Skid Simon began the trend 40 years ago with his famous foursome: Futile Willie, Mr. Smug, Mrs. Guggenheim and the Unlucky Expert.

title: IRVING G. THALBERG JR.
description: Irving G. Thalberg Jr., a philosophy professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago and the son of the late Irving Thalberg, the movie producer, died of cancer Friday at his home in Syracuse. He was 56 years old and also lived in Chicago and Aspen, Colo.

title: Brazil Upsets U.S. Men
description: During a news conference on Saturday, Denny Crum, the head coach of the United States men's basketball team, was discussing Brazil's team when he realized that he had forgotten the name of Brazil's best player. Finally, one of his players flipped through a roster and called out the name.

title: Film: 'Born in East L.A.,' Cheech Marin Comedy
description: CHEECH MARIN'S ''Born in East L.A.'' is enormously good-natured - exactly the wrong tone for a comedy that needs all the rambunctious lunacy it can get. Instead, this story of an American mistakenly deported to Mexico as an illegal alien is amiable and plodding, the very last things you'd expect from Cheech, with or without Chong.

title: MEASURE IS SOUGHT ON ROAD VIOLENCE
description: Gov. George Deukmejian has proposed a $29 million effort to fight freeway violence by adding 180 people to the California Highway Patrol and doubling the force's emergency overtime funds.

title: Advertising; Magazine To Pursue Teen-agers
description: ON the premise that teen-agers are more sophisticated than the magazines aimed at them, John Fairfax Ltd., Australia's powerful magazine company, is starting Sassy, the United States version of Dolly, its successful monthly for the teen-age market.

title: Advertising; Ayer Promotion
description: N.W. Ayer has put James P. Foley, 54, in charge of its Latin American and Asia/Pacific divisions. He will assume posts vacated two months ago by David J. Dodd, who went to Paris to look after the Ayer agencies in France, Italy and Spain.

title: Sports World Specials; Streak of Strikeouts
description: Nolan Ryan said he had not heard of Masaichi Kaneda, but then conceded he had hardly heard of Walter Johnson, either.

title: Canada Bank Expects Loss
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Canada's third-largest bank, said Friday that it would almost triple its reserves for doubtful third world loans.

title: Seoul Seeks Calm After Worker's Death
description: As mourners grieved beside the body of the first worker to be killed in the labor unrest that began sweeping the nation a month ago, South Korea's ruling party appealed for calm and expressed regret over the incident.

title: Acquisition by Armtek A Boon to Dayco Head
description: The purchase of the Dayco Corporation's automotive and industrial products division last year by the Armtek Corporation was a fortunate turn of events for Donald E. Ross.

title: Giants Troubled By Rash of Injuries
description: Last season, the Giants suffered few significant injuries en route to their victory in Super Bowl XXI. Now, with two exhibition games (both victories) gone and two to go, small injuries are creeping up.

title: Dr. Andrea Zuckerman Wed to a Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Andrea Leigh Zuckerman, a pediatric nephrologist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, and Dr. George Fulop, an assistant professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, were married yesterday at the Harvard Club of New York City by Rabbi Chaim Stern.

title: In August, Swedes Go a Little Wild With Louisiana Crayfish
description: After hours of drinking, eating and revelry, Swedish sobriety is long gone. Those who can walk unassisted will be bragging about it tomorrow. One celebrant, a high-ranking corporate executive, is temporarily missing, having wandered off into the woods in a muddled haze.

title: 'It's My World Too,' On Childrens' Disability
description: A LOCALLY produced documentary film pre-empts the usual television network summer fare tonight at 9 on WCBS, Channel 2. Deservedly so.

title: Alcala Captures Coors Bike Race
description: Raul Alcala of Mexico, representing the 7-Eleven team, won the Coors International Bicycle Classic today.

title: A Swedish Visit
description: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson of Sweden, who is scheduled to come to Washington in the second week of September at the invitation of President Reagan, will be the first Swedish head of government to pay an official visit to the White House in 26 years. The last one was Tage Erlander, who was received by President Kennedy in 1961.

title: Boxing; Breland Must Wait For Title Rematch
description: The reaction that Joe Fariello, the co-trainer, was anticipating finally came Saturday night, after Mark Breland had time to contemplate that he was no longer unbeaten and the World Boxing Association welterweight champion. It made Breland angry, Fariello said. It also prompted the 1984 Olympic gold-medal winner to make an unscheduled visit to the hotel where his successor, Marlon Starling, was staying.

title: Needed: A Quango for Education
description: It is not enough to throw money, managers, good intentions and good ideas at America's failed education system. What's needed is credible assessment of such intentions and such ideas and the way to get it is from a quango.

title: A Bear Puzzle With Too Many Pieces
description: THE after-dinner meetings had been brief. A benevolent coaching staff had imposed a 1 A.M. curfew, giving the Chicago Bears a generous amount of time to celebrate near-completion of three weeks of basic training in this quiet university town set among Wisconsin dairy farms.

title: DeBerg Watching A Familiar Story
description: Steve DeBerg said he had seen it before: the arrival of the National Football League's top draft pick, a quarterback. The crowd sensing a change in the franchise's fortunes, the electricity when the rookie took the field. A quick touchdown. Euphoria. They had seen the future quarterback, and he works.

title: U.S. NOW ENFORCING LAW ON EMPLOYERS OF ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Immigration officials have begun issuing citations to employers who continue to hire illegal aliens, ushering in the most lasting and difficult part of the nation's new immigration law.

title: HOUSE PANEL SAYS MX TESTS INDICATE SERIOUS PROBLEMS
description: Because of problems with the guidance system of the Air Force's MX missile, there are serious questions about whether MX's already deployed would work as planned, a Congressional committee charged in a report issued today.

title: King Gains Victory and Leads Earnings
description: Betsy King's golf clubs were sizzling hot in the bright Atlantic City sunshine today and she used them effectively to get to the top of the money list on the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour.

title: LITHUANIANS RALLY FOR STALIN VICTIMS
description: More than 500 Lithuanians gathered in the old quarter of this Baltic capital today to sing anthems of independence and to hear defiant speeches honoring ''the victims of Stalin.''

title: Delta Revises Its Discounts
description: Delta Air Lines said it would change its discount fare structure to allow customers to recover some of the cost of unused, discounted tickets.

title: Sharpening Shooting
description: YOU might consider enrolling in a shooting school if, when tramping through meadow, alder swamp or hardwood forest with shotgun in hand, you miss most of the quail, pheasant, woodcock or ruffed grouse that you or your dog locate.

title: Stage Was Filled By Cuba and U.S.
description: The 10th Pan American Games, which set records for most countries and athletes participating, closed tonight with a colorful, musical ceremony that, unlike the games themselves, was uninterrupted by political disturbance.

title: Authors Bring Their Verbs to Town To Plead for Relief From Restriction
description: By the thousands, letters have poured into Capitol Hill offices in recent weeks warning lawmakers of big troubles ahead for American writing.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Rowland Co., the U.S. public relations arm of Saatchi & Saatchi, has acquired Grody/Tellem Communications, a Los Angeles public relations firm.

title: A Girl Visting From Norway Is Missing From Hotel Room
description: A 17-year-old Norwegian girl who has been touring the United States with her 24-year-old sister, has been reported missing from her mid-Manhattan hotel, the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you want to have fun with your investments, I can't think of a better way.'' - Jay Acton, minor league baseball entrepreneur. [ A1:3. ]

title: Deadly Sleep On Highway Baffles Police
description: A stretch of the Atlantic City Expressway is known as the ''sleep zone'' these days, a name prompted by a mystifying series of fatal accidents involving drivers who dozed off at the wheel.

title: Far Away But Close To Home
description: THE job requires frequent travel.

title: Oarsman Killed By a Powerboat On Jamaica Bay
description: The operator of a 29-foot powerboat unknowingly ran over a fragile 12-foot racing shell in Jamaica Bay in the Gateway National Recreation Area yesterday afternoon, killing the lone oarsman in the tiny boat, officials said.

title: Travers Favorites Were Under Guard
description: The three favorites in the Travers Stakes on Saturday spent the hours before the race under guard because Saratoga Race Track officials had been alerted that one of them, Alysheba, might be given an illegal medication by his handlers.

title: Gooden Wins One on Bases
description: Dwight Gooden, who often pitches the Mets to victory, helped run them to a victory yesterday with an adventure that was questionable to some but not to the man who counts - his manager.

title: O'Neill Center: Where Musicals Are Nurtured
description: On stage is a musical about Lucy, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. She trades her wedding ring for a pistol and shoots the dog. She has taken up with Beau, the high school's star running back. Lucy's husband, Biff, the coach, plans to throttle Beau - when the season ends. Lucy, meanwhile, plans to kill herself as soon as she remembers how.

title: For 30 Families, Search For Homes on L.I. Ends
description: It was almost too good to be true, but Darrell Dabe, a Suffolk County police officer and father of three, spent much of Friday afternoon seeding the lawn in front of his house.

title: Dance: Modern Works By Georgia Stephens
description: THE world Georgia Stephens welcomed the audience into, in a program of her dances presented Friday in Dance Theater Workshop's summer Out-of-Towners festival, made no specific reference to Minneapolis, where the choreographer is based. And although Ms. Stephens made use of such currently popular accoutrements of dance as video and the spoken word, neither was this primarily the world of an experimentalist. Instead, the audience accompanied an engaging, inquiring spirit on an easygoing foray into the absurdities of everyday life.

title: Molitor Stretches Streak To 38
description: Paul Molitor of the Milwaukee Brewers extended his hitting streak to 38 games today with a single in the fifth inning against the Kansas City Royals. The streak is the seventh longest in major league history.

title: The Albanians
description: Sooner or later, Presidential election campaigns get around to the cultivation of ethnic groups. But among the current contenders, one Democrat and one Republican have started early in wooing a new category: the Albanian-American vote.

title: Embezzler Who Killed Secretary Dies in Louisiana's Electric
description: An accountant who raped and murdered his secretary because he feared she would expose his embezzlement of $84,000 was executed early today in Louisiana's electric chair.

title: Drugs Trace a Mayor's Rise and Fall
description: As the county prosecutor here a few years ago, Mike Roark was dubbed ''mad dog'' for the zeal he displayed in a crusade against local drug pushers and his penchant for wearing combat fatigues and carrying a revolver.

title: Move for Ambulances
description: To the Editor:

title: Mark Sidel Wed To Ms. Raymond
description: Margaret Raymond, a daughter of Mrs. Boris M. Raymond of New York and the late Mr. Raymond, was married yesterday to Mark Sidel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor W. Sidel of New York, at the Terrace Restaurant at Butler Hall in New York. Rabbi Joan Friedman officiated.

title: Entrepreneurs Scoring in the Bush Leagues
description: In professional baseball, the distance to the majors from the dusty benches of the Empire State League could be measured in light years.

title: Corrections
description: A Washington dispatch on Aug. 14 about the theft of documents from the Library of Congress included an incorrect description, from an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, of the availability of documents written by Abraham Lincoln. There are Lincoln documents in private hands that are occasionally offered for sale by dealers.

title: W. G. Obr, an Editor, Weds Robin E. Kaplan, a Banker
description: Robin Elisa Kaplan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kaplan of Brooklyn and Tamarac, Fla., was married yesterday to Warren Grant Obr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Obr of Mobridge, S.D. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony aboard the yacht Paco Rabanne in New York Harbor.

title: Dr. Gerald F. Jacobson, 65, Expert on Effects of Divorce
description: Dr. Gerald F. Jacobson, a pioneer in crisis intervention psychotherapy, died Saturday at St. John of God Nursing Home in Los Angeles, where he had been living for several months since suffering a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Sports World Specials; Channel Campaign
description: For someone who is planning to swim the English Channel to prove that epilepsy need not be a handicap, George Hauser has a problem. Precisely because epilepsy is a controlable disorder whose victims can usually lead perfectly normal lives, the 39-year-old Hauser, who experienced his first epileptic seizure after being hit in the head with a baseball at the age of 14, practically needs a doctor's certificate to prove he has it.

title: Pursuit of Women's Vote Taking a New Tack
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt's greeting to the National Women's Political Caucus was gender-neutral, a carefully calibrated gesture of respect. ''I'm very pleased to be here today with experienced, capable, successful, seasoned politicians,'' the Missouri Democrat said.

title: Advertising; Levine, Huntley Chosen By U.S. Health Care
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has won the $10 million account for U.S. Health Care. Of the 600 health maintenance organizations nationwide, U.S. Health Care is among the five largest, with $400 million in sales last year.

title: Dollar Lower in Tokyo
description: The Bank of Japan bought a large amount of dollars at just below 141 yen soon after the Tokyo market opened this morning. Currency dealers said the intervention seemed to be more aggressive than last week's, when the bank limited its purchases to small amounts. Several dealers said the latest purchase totaled more than $100 million. The buying helped to push the dollar back up above 141 yen, the dealers said. The dollar opened at 141.15 yen, then quickly fell below 141 before the Bank of Japan intervened.

title: Limpet Mines Are Removed From a P.L.O. Yacht in Malta
description: Soldiers in Valletta harbor removed two limpet mines from the hull of a yacht belonging to the Palestine Liberation Organization, authorities reported today.

title: Pat Yes, Gary No
description: ''Run, Pat, run,'' they were chanting at last week's National Women's Political Caucus in Portland, Ore., and that makes a lot of sense, maybe even for Representative Pat Schroeder of Colorado.

title: Advertising; Playboy Names Head Of Publishing Division
description: John A. Scott has been named to the new position of president of Playboy's publishing division and a corporate senior vice president.

title: 3 U.S. Gymnasts Win Gold Medals
description: The United States' grip on women's gymnastics in the Pan American Games was loosened slightly today in competition for medals in the four individual events.

title: In Britain, Memoir Stirs Doubt on Spy Agencies
description: At times, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's international legal vendetta against ''Spycatcher'' and the retired British agent who wrote it has seemed almost comical. But the ''Spycatcher'' affair has also opened up a serious political debate that goes beyond the immediate issue of whether the memoir can be published in this country.

title: Rock: Los Lobos, Tex-Mex and Blues
description: ''LA BAMBA,'' a glossy summer movie based on the short life of the 1950's rocker Ritchie Valens, has given Los Lobos a hit, and an anthem. The group could probably play Mr. Valens's insidiously infectious ''La Bamba'' all night long and keep audiences happy. Fortunately, they don't have to. Their own guitar-band rock-and-roll, rhythm-and-blues and Tex-Mex dance music are vital enough to keep audiences enthusiastic, as they proved Saturday night in a packed open-air concert at Pier 84. They saved ''La Bamba'' for an encore.

title: Catskill Bungalows: Rustic Goes Co-op
