description: Nudged by her happy memories of summers spent at Catskills bungalow colonies, Lillian Oberlander persuaded her friend Harry Geller to drive north from their Florida homes in June and spend the season here.

title: Iran Is Said to Block a Deal For Anglican Aide's Release
description: Iran has blocked a $5 million deal to free Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy who was kidnapped seven months ago, a senior Lebanese militia source said today.

title: INSIDE
description: A Test for Alfonsin

title: Tobacco's Road Through History
description: The smoking lamp is out, but tobacco in all its literary flavor permeates Room 324, on the north side of the New York Public Library. No matter that tobacco has now made it to the top of the most-unwanted list of undesirable flora, Room 324 maintains an objective balance, reflecting all observations available on the plant's role in human society.

title: San Diego Is Now A Boom Town For New Theater
description: San Diego is a theater town, and the city earned another gold star this month when the San Diego Repertory Theater's ''Holy Ghosts'' opened to good reviews in New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 24, 1987
description: International A2-9

title: 'Most Dangerous Game' Is Gaining as a Sport
description: After a day of rain that made the lush pine-crowned forests here feel like a steamy jungle, men hunted men, seeking the exhilaration that comes from shooting an enemy - with a paint ball.

title: Piniella Retracts Criticism
description: Lou Piniella, sounding almost apologetic, said today that he had erred last week when he made remarks that were construed as a criticism of his players.

title: Driver Relives Accident That Killed 2 in a Parade
description: The Rev. Etanislao Gonzales sat, head in hands, at his dining room table today, recalling how a pickup truck he was driving in a religious parade went out of control, killing two of his parishioners and injuring 29 others.

title: In Madrid, Fans Are for Fashion, Not Function
description: Elegantly dressed, the elderly woman sat alone at a table in the air-conditioned domed bar of the Palace Hotel, a glass of Jerez, or sherry, the national drink here, in one hand, a fan in the other. Occasionally, she would unfold it and flick her wrist for a few brisk waves of her own cooling air.

title: Four Treasury Auctions This Week
description: The Treasury has scheduled four auctions this week, starting with new three- and six-month bills today, followed by two-year notes on Wednesday and five-year notes on Thursday.

title: Mary McCarthy Reading
description: A reading by the author Mary McCarthy on Sept. 21 at 8 P.M. will open the 49th season of the Poetry Center at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Ms. McCarthy will read from her book ''How I Grew'' and other works. Others scheduled to appear during the season will be Anthony Burgess, Octavio Paz, Isabel Allende, Irina Ratushinskaya, Maya Angelou, Joan Didion, Susan Sontag and Tom Wolfe. Admission to each reading is $10; there is a series ticket for $80. Information: 966-1100.

title: Larry Morris, 63, Dies; A Times Photographer
description: Larry C. Morris, a New York Times photographer since 1950, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while playing volleyball at a swim club near his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: Beirut Bank Intervention
description: Lebanon's central bank stopped pricing the Lebanese pound Saturday in a bid to stop a runaway collapse. However, traders said the currency continued to fall in a market with little demand.

title: The News From Home
description: It's August in New York. And visitors from abroad -foreign residents, too - are hungry for hometown news, especially the sports scores. The political stuff can wait. Any morning after 9:30, when foreign papers arrive at news outlets, especially the Rizzoli bookstore on West 57th Street near Fifth Avenue, Europeans begin their day catching up with yesterday at home. Heads up for the Fifth Avenue traffic, folks. Now that you've found out who won, it's time for New York, New York.

title: Nelson Has Cancer; Prognosis Is Good
description: On Saturday night, after the Giants had beaten the Cleveland Browns in an exhibition game in Giants Stadium, they were told that one of their teammates, Karl Nelson, had Hodgkin's disease, a cancer of the lymph-node tissue.

title: Pamela Kochen Marries
description: Pamela Eve Kochen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Kochen of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Norbert Moise Baroukh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Baroukh of Kiron, Israel, were married yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi Samuel Weintraub. The bride, a graduate of the Masters School and Skidmore College, is a studio artist. The bridegroom is a graduate of the American International School in Israel and of Brandeis University. He is a sales executive in the apparel industry in New York.

title: Birth Control Ad: The Fight for TV Time
description: The television advertisement says: ''Four out of five young women who don't use birth control get pregnant before they want to. Birth control - from saying 'no' to taking the pill. You're too smart not to use it.'' The 30-second message is the introduction to a five-year campaign by the New York State Family Planning Media Consortium to reduce unintended pregnancies and abortions. The consortium comprises 18 agencies and institutions, including six branches of Planned Parenthood, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, several hospitals and health centers, and government agencies. The group is spending $700,000, mostly in state funds, for television and radio advertisements as well as posters. Stations Refuse to Broadcast Ads

title: U.S. May Cite Japan Trucks
description: The Reagan Administration and the Big Three American auto companies are considering the filing of ''dumping'' charges against Japanese compact truck makers, Commerce Department officials said Friday.

title: Florida To Review Tax on Ads
description: Gov. Bob Martinez, bowing to pressure from lawmakers and business interests, has called for a statewide referendum on Florida's controversial new tax on advertising and other services.

title: Many Are Trying to Save Brighton Beach Baths
description: To the Editor:

title: Joint Intelligence Panel: How Legislation Grew
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 24,1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: THE DANGERS OF DUMPING MEDICAL WASTE ARE UNDER SCRUTINY
description: About two years ago, people in the Westchester County hamlet of Cortlandt began complaining about odors from an old warehouse about 100 feet from a children's dance studio. When health inspectors responded, they were stunned by their discovery: about five tons of hospital and medical debris and trash, including surgically removed body parts and hypodermic needles.

title: Fixing Leaky Roof at Grand Central
description: Nothing is small at Grand Central Terminal - neither the problem (a leaky roof) nor the solution (more than one acre of new copper cladding).

title: 25 on L.I. Tied To a Drug Ring Run by Convict
description: A Long Island cocaine ring headed by a convicted drug dealer in a state prison was broken up over the weekend with the arrest of 25 people in Suffolk and Nassau Counties, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Canada Split on Drug Patents
description: An angry political confrontation has developed in Canada over a bill that would give foreign drug companies - many of them American - protection against widespread copying of their products by Canadian-based competitors.

title: Girl, 9, Loses Leg When Hit by Car
description: A 9-year-old girl lost her left leg after a car whose driver was charged with drunken driving hit her, her brother and their mother on a Brooklyn sidewalk, the police said yesterday.

title: No Arrests at Kongsberg
description: Employees of a Norwegian arms company who were involved in the illegal sale of sensitive technology to Moscow will not be prosecuted because of a statute of limitations, Defense Minister Johan Joergen Holst said today.

title: MORRIS ROSENBLUM
description: Morris Rosenblum, founder and chairman of the Excel Wood Products Company, one of the country's largest independent manufacturers of kitchen and bathroom cabinets, died of a heart attack on Aug. 17 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Farmingdale, N.J.

title: Molitor Honored Again
description: The Brewers' Paul Molitor, whose 38-game hitting streak is the longest in the American League since Joe DiMaggio's record 56-game string in 1941, has been named the league's player of the week for the second straight time. Molitor extended his streak by seven games, hitting .452 with four doubles and a home run, seven r.b.i. and seven runs scored. Milwaukee did not play yesterday. . . . The Houston Astros' Bill Doran, who hit .538 last week, was named National League Player of the Week. Doran had 14 hits in 26 times at bat, and hit safely in all seven Houston games. He hit two home runs, drove in nine runs, scored six runs and stole three bases.

title: Sybase President Gains The Confidence of Apple
description: Mark Hoffman, president of Sybase Inc., believes that future computing will consist of many high-powered work stations linked in networks, which would have the ability to gain access to large data bases. That belief gained a vote of confidence yesterday, when Apple Computer Inc. announced that it was making a minority investment in the Berkeley, Calif., software company.

title: J HIGBY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $58,733 and $71,588 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: ROBERT E. HALL
description: Robert E. Hall, former director of development and alumni affairs at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies, died of cancer Aug. 16 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 68 years old and lived in Georgetown.

title: Simon Investors To Buy Thrift Unit
description: An investor group headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Western Federal Savings and Loan Association for $145 million - its largest acquisition yet in the savings industry.

title: Jets Trying Rookie At Klecko's Spot
description: The Jets will start a new man at nose tackle against the Giants on Saturday night at Giants Stadium. He's Gerald Nichols, a blond, blue-eyed, 23-year-old who describes himself as a country boy and listens hard when Joe Klecko speaks.

title: HEALTHMATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTELLICORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $1,079,000 and $1,700,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for the latest periods include a charge of $1,730,000 associated with a corporate reorganization, including the writedown of certain computer assets. Results for the year-ago periods include a gain of $2,135,000, or 33 cents a share, on the sale of a 60 percent interest in Intelligentics Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1987
description: Markets

title: FAST-FOOD MERGER
description: Stuff-Yer-Face Inc., a fast-food chain, said today that it had agreed to merge with Tubby's Sub Shops, Inc. in a stock swap. Stuff-Yer-Face said Tubby's would take control of the company and probably change its name to Tubby's Inc.

title: 9.35% Notes Sold By Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.35 percent senior notes, maturing in 1994, at par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: GENERAL PARAMETRICS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE MARINES: AN UPDATE
description: Following are marines named in the investigations into espionage at the United States Embassy in Moscow, and their legal status. Cpl. Arnold Bracy: Originally accused of helping Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree let Soviet agents roam through sensitive sections of the embassy. He supplied information used against Sergeant Lonetree, but later said his incriminating statements were coerced by agents from the Naval Investigative Service.

title: Stone 'Tools' May Alter Early Human Record
description: A NEW discovery of what appear to be crude stone tools raises the possibility that human ancestors migrated out of Africa at least one million years earlier than previously thought. If true, this would sharply revise scientific understanding about the timing and reasons for one of the pivotal events in human evolution.

title: A Papuan Troupe At Festival
description: The Raun Raun Theater, one of the more exotic participants at Edinburgh's arts festival this month, is more than a source of entertainment for Papua New Guinea: it is an important source of education.

title: EDINER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lessons in Superpower Reciprocity
description: It did not take much to make Esther Coopersmith's day, just $15,000 from Armand Hammer, the industrialist who built a fortune out of his personal ties to the Kremlin. The $15,000 will help pay for a visit by about 50 Soviet officials to the White House, the Capitol, Ford's Theater and a swank Maryland shopping mall.

title: NATIONAL MEDIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Censors, Spies and Obscenity
description: The passion for freedom of the mind is strong and everlasting, which is fortunate, because so is the passion to squelch it.

title: Embattled Giant Of Psychology Speaks His Mind
description: B. F. Skinner is a creature of carefully shaped habit. At the age of 83, he has fashioned a schedule and environment for himself that is in perfect keeping with his theories of behavioral reinforcement.

title: Spiritual Pain: Ex-Priests Seek Return to Church
description: As a Roman Catholic priest, Michael T. Breslin spent each day for 14 years administering the sacraments and tending to the needs of the people of his Brooklyn parish. In the evening, he returned, alone, to the rectory. Now, he takes the subway to Manhattan to tend to his craft and pottery shop at South Street Seaport. At the end of the day, he returns to his wife and family.

title: Car Imports in Germany
description: Foreign car makers' share of the West German new-car market fell to 31.3 percent in the first seven months of this year, from 32.7 percent in the period a year ago, the Federal Motor Office said today. Foreign producers' sales rose to 85,421 in July, from 78,650 a year before, but were down to 553,752 cars during the seven-month period, from 561,436. Japan was the largest exporter to West Germany, holding its 14.7 percent share. The French car makers' share fell to 7.5 percent, from 8.2 percent, and Italy's share was unchanged at 4.8 percent.

title: DOWNEY DESIGNS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LONETREE IS GIVEN 30-YEAR SENTENCE IN EMBASSY SPYING
description: A jury of eight Marine Corps officers sentenced Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, the former Moscow Embassy security guard, to 30 years in prison today for spying for the Soviet Union.

title: A Golden Success For U.S. Athletes
description: By most every measurement, the 10th Pan American Games were an overwhelming triumph for American amateur athletics.

title: SUSPECT IN 'AIDS ROBBERIES' ARRESTED IN A BANK HOLDUP
description: New York City's most wanted bank robber, who held up 31 Manhattan banks by presenting tellers with notes saying he was ''dying of AIDS and had nothing to lose,'' was arrested yesterday during another robbery in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: S.I. Republicans Struggling Over Party Leadership
description: A struggle has erupted for the leadership of the Staten Island Republican organization, a fight that is tied to the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination next year.

title: U.S. Delays Phone Bids
description: The Federal Government has again delayed bidding for its multibillion-dollar telephone contract, following a report by the General Accounting Office that criticized the handling of the bidding process.

title: HEMACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Q&A
description: Q.How do city pigeons take care of their young? Although pigeons live on the ledge under my air-conditioner, there is no sign of nest-building or chicks. A. Urban pigeons don't necessarily build elaborate nests, or any nests at all, according to Michele Ball of the Audubon Society. ''Sometimes they just find a sheltered corner on someone's terrace,'' she said, adding that they are particularly partial to outdoor carpeting made to resemble grass. People seldom see signs of nesting, Ms. Ball said, because baby pigeons reach adult size very quickly, in about 10 days. A female pigeon can have two or three broods a year, usually of two chicks each. Q. Why are there so few thunderstorms early in the morning? A. Collisions of warm and cold air masses can produce thunderstorms at any time of day. Most common, however, are storms that occur when air warmed by the earth's heat rises to cooler altitudes, where moisture within it condenses to form clouds. The process creates ''a natural generator'' of lightning, according to Robert J. Banner, a climatologist at the National Weather Service. The tops of the clouds become positively charged with electricity, he said; their bases have a negative charge,and the earth under them has a positive charge.

title: Artful Compromise on Westway
description: A truce engineered by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch should end 15 years of delay that started when a dump truck fell through the rotting old elevated highway on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Our Towns; Corrupt Minds, Rebel Voices: It's Rock 'n' Roll
description: So what is wrong with watching a few guys, dressed like women, slinging guitars between their legs? Or Billy Idol trashing a church with a motorcycle? Or some corseted nymph ensconcing herself in black satin sheets? It's only rock-and-roll.

title: Bayard Rustin Is Dead at 75; Pacifist and a Rights Activist
description: Bayard Rustin, the pacifist and civil rights activist who was a chief organizer of the 1963 March on Washington and the 1964 New York school boycott, died early yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and was a longtime resident of the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

title: Osaka Brokers Held in Fraud
description: Police arrested five officials of an Osaka brokerage house today on charges of masterminding the country's biggest case of fraud involving overseas commodity markets.

title: CPT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes charges of $16,750,000 and $15,000,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Reagan Names Adoption Group
description: President Reagan, after moving to stop the use of Federal money for abortion counseling services, named a Federal task force today to encourage adoption as an ''alternative for pregnant women.''

title: TransAmerican Reorganization
description: A multimillion-dollar reorganization plan for the TransAmerican Natural Gas Corporation, one of the nation's largest independent gas production and pipeline companies, has been tentatively approved by a Houston bankruptcy judge. Federal Judge Manuel Leal's conditional confirmation came at the end of a hearing on Sunday, ending more than four years of proceedings in TransAmerican's second bankruptcy action.

title: Nonleaching Plastic
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Cameras in Space Stir U.S. Security Fears
description: CIVILIAN satellites that photograph the earth from hundreds of miles in space have become so powerful that decades-old divisions between space-based civil and military reconnaissance are blurring. Indeed, the Federal Government is now buying civilian photographs from space for use in military intelligence.

title: DISCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Genentech Seeks Action on T.P.A.
description: Genentech Inc. is seeking an injunction in an Osaka court to stop the Toyobo Company Ltd. from making, marketing and testing a drug that dissolves blood clots, a Toyobo spokesman said. Genentech, based in San Francisco, applied in April for Japanese patents for recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, which may help to prevent heart attacks. It is working with Mitsubishi Chemical Industries Ltd. and Kyowa Hakko Kogyo Co. Ltd. in developing T.P.A.

title: Does a Child Need A Computer at Home?
description: THE man in the checkout line was frustrated and confused.

title: Profile: Alicia Coro - A Matter of Politics and Linguistics
description: The newly appointed director of bilingual education at the Department of Education has been:

title: Selling the Sail In an Era of Power
description: With the approach of the 1987-88 boat show season, powerboat manufacturers are riding a wave of popularity that began four years ago. By contrast, the sailboat industry has fallen into a marketing trough.

title: COMVERSE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Toyota to Offer A Luxury Line
description: Toyota Motor Sales Inc., trying to shed its economy-car image and lure more affluent buyers, said today that it planned to set up a new dealer network called Lexus to sell a luxury car line in the United States by 1989.

title: Japan Bank Helps Cut Dollar Fall
description: After last week's sharp losses, the dollar slipped only fractionally yesterday against the yen and most other key currencies in sluggish trading. Intervention by the Bank of Japan, a wave of profit taking and developments in the Persian Gulf helped to buttress the currency.

title: Shifts Urged On Big Board
description: A special panel of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday recommended a number of changes in the way the Big Board operates, including modifications of its short sale rule.

title: Mining Is Still Key to South African Economy
description: By withholding their labor from South Africa's gold and coal mines, the members of the National Mineworkers' Union have focused their strength on a resource that has largely defined South Africa's place as a modern industrial state.

title: Tax Watch; Writers Upset On Accounting
description: AUTHORS, playwrights, screenwriters, songwriters and photographers are up in arms over an obscure accounting provision in the new tax law.

title: High OPEC Output Reduces Price of Oil To Four-Month Low
description: Crude oil prices tumbled yesterday to their lowest levels since April.

title: College Officials Petition N.F.L.
description: An association of college athletic directors today asked Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, to postpone the league's supplemental draft until a meeting can be held on the issue.

title: Texas Is Offering Notes Backed by 2 Big Banks
description: Texas, pressed by a weak economy that has led to large budget deficits, is turning to short-term financing in the tax-exempt note market with a one-year issue totaling $1.25 billion.

description: Valhi Inc., a diversified holding company controlled by Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, said it had submitted a sweetened $794 million merger proposal to the independent directors of NL Industries.

description: Net income represent net assets.

title: Toxic Leak Forces Evacuation
description: A truck carrying a caustic, flammable chemical overturned and began leaking today, prompting officials to order an evacuation in a five-block area of town, the authorities said. The truck was carrying ammonia nitrate when it overturned this afternoon at the intersection of state Routes 61 and 94, a fire department spokesman said. Ammonia nitrate can burn the eyes and skin.

title: Concert: Jessye Norman And Boston Symphony
description: It took a force of nature today to overshadow a rousing version of Schumann's Second Symphony, by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood. That force came in the person of Jessye Norman, who is, of course, no mere soprano.

title: AIDS Commission To Meet Next Month
description: President Reagan's commission on AIDS will meet in Washington on next month, the White House said today.

title: IRAN AND U.N. MEET ON GULF CEASE-FIRE
description: Iran's Deputy Foreign Minister met today with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to discuss the Security Council's call for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf, but officials close to the discussions reported little progress.

title: 20% of Condom Batches Fail
description: About one in five batches of latex condoms has failed water-leakage tests, according to a spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration. The Federal agency recently stepped up its testing of condoms after allowing manufacturers to advertise latex models as helpful in the prevention of AIDS.

title: Finally, the Right Stuff
description: PROGRAMS that turn a computer monitor into an airplane cockpit's instrument panel and window have long been popular with people attracted to flying but not to risking life, limb or savings. Indeed, one or two such simulators have occupied too much of the time of more than one corporate officer who should have been writing reports or recalculating spreadsheets. But existing flight simulators generally put you behind the controls of comparatively tame private planes (although this writer usually takes off right into Lake Michigan), in which it isn't easy to fantasize being Chuck Yeager.

title: Stephenville Journal; Faraway Amish Try to Keep Faith
description: There is still a need for a hitching post in front of the new Winn Dixie Supermarket on the main highway here. But it's not for the horses of the local ranchers. It's for the buggies of the local Amish.

title: In the Trenches in Iraq: Iran's Teen-Agers Dig In
description: In the trenches running along this ridge just inside Iraqi territory, Iranian soldiers, many in their teens, are digging into a position that only a few weeks ago was in Iraqi hands.

title: Right of School To Demand Use Of Texts Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that public school students can be required to read and discuss textbooks, even though the lessons may offend their religious beliefs.

title: Ban on Bikes Could Bring More Mopeds
description: When New York City officials announced a partial ban on bicycles in midtown Manhattan that went into effect yesterday, some of the city's bike messengers vowed to ignore the regulations, others planned alternative routes and still others purchased motor bikes.

title: Boeing Wins Missile Deal
description: The Army has selected the Boeing Company to produce a new truck-mounted version of its Stinger missile to help defend soldiers and tanks from aerial attack.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Iranian naval warship, this is U.S. Warship 37. I am at the head of a column of three ships transiting the Arabian Gulf.

Mine Union Leader Says Pretoria Politicizes Strike
description: The leader of the biggest wage strike in the country's history says he has a hard time finding the distinction between political and labor issues in South Africa.

title: Illnesses Puzzle Giants
description: In the last seven years, four men who have played pro football for the Giants in Giants Stadium have contracted cancer. Coincidence or not, some of the present Giants seemed concerned today. Others were not.

title: Massachusetts Issues Rules Barring Insurance Sex Bias
description: The Massachusetts Insurance Commissioner today issued regulations barring discrimination on the basis of sex for all forms of insurance, but the regulations face a court challenge.

Air Force Backs Its MX Program Against Critics
description: The Air Force today vigorously defended the MX missile and assailed a Congressional report that said there were serious concerns about whether MX's already deployed would work as planned.

title: Evans Leaving Simon & Schuster for Random House
description: Joni Evans, who has served as president of the trade division of Simon & Schuster for the last two years, will join Random House as president of ''a major new, as yet unnamed, publishing imprint,'' Random House announced yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
Grumman in China
description: The Grumman Corporation has been awarded contracts worth $245 million to update China's F-8 fighter aircraft as part of a program agreed to by China and the United States last year, The China Daily reported. Grumman has won two contracts for the building of a new nose cone for the planes in Bethpage, L.I., and a new tail in Shenyang, China, the newspaper said.

title: ASTROS TRIP UP CARDS
description: Bob Knepper pitched a seven-hitter for his first complete game of the season tonight as the Houston Astros won for the 10th time in 11 games, defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-2.

title: Theft of Infected Cats From U.S. Lab Spurs Alert
description: The Department of Agriculture issued a national alert today and called in the Federal Bureau of Investigation to look for 11 stolen cats infected with a parasite that can cause birth defects in humans.

title: Talks on Draft Constitution Intensifying in Seoul
description: Amid concern that the death of a shipyard worker over the weekend could become a political issue, members of the ruling and opposition parties are racing to conclude negotiations that will lead to the first direct presidential election here in 16 years.

description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $666,000 and $4,574,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and a loss of $522,000 from a recalculation of a previously reported tax effect for the quarter and a tax credit of $1,306,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $59,000 and $430,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: 'Music Man' at City Opera
description: The New York City Opera will continue its musical comedy series this season with a revival of ''The Music Man.'' Tony Roberts and Leigh Munro are scheduled to star in the Meredith Willson musical, which will begin performances Feb. 26. Tickets will go on sale Feb. 8.

title: New York Gets Tough On Window Guard Law
description: New York City is preparing criminal charges against 29 landlords and managing agents for either failing to install window guards or installing them improperly after children fell from windows in their buildings.

title: Access to Space Telescope
description: Not all the astronomers conducting investigations with the Hubble Space Telescope will be professionals. Amateur astronomers are being encouraged to submit proposals for using the huge telescope, which is to be placed into orbit soon after the space shuttles resume operations.

title: Stewart Lowers Speed And Is Rolling Again
description: The nickname fit: Smoke. It conjured an image of overpowering speed, of a fastball so imposing - so full of heat - it left hitters stunned. It fascinated fans. It flew through the air, leaving only curling trails of vapor.

title: Protecting Volunteers In AIDS Vaccine Test
description: INJECTIONS of the first experimental human AIDS vaccine in the United States this fall will be accompanied by what Federal health officials call ''unprecedented'' steps to protect the volunteers from possible discrimination.

title: Richard S. Harris, 59, Writer for New Yorker
description: Richard S. Harris, an author and former staff writer for The New Yorker magazine, died Sunday in a fall from his 12th-floor apartment on the Upper West Side. He was 59 years old.

title: U.S. Military Strength Rises
description: The active-duty strength of the nation's military services increased in July over the preceding month and the same period of a year ago, the Pentagon said today. As of July 31, the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force had 2,158,486 men and women on active duty, up 7,685 from June 30. The armed services reported strength of 2,150,310 on July 31, 1986, or 8,176 fewer than that reported today. It is not unusual for military strength to swing up and down on a monthly basis during the year, primarily because of differences in the flow of new recruits.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the growth of theater in San Diego misidentified the theater at which the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' is to open on Broadway in October. It is the Martin Beck.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $95,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Strike Halts Trains in Canada
description: Railroad workers across Canada went on strike today, shutting down freight and passenger service and prompting the Government to order an immediate return to the bargaining table to try to end the country's first rail strike in 14 years.

title: Pan Am Games Eye Problems
description: As Indianapolis said goodbye to the 10th Pan American Games Sunday night in the Hoosier Dome, a band played salsa music, athletes danced in conga lines and the flag of Cuba hung high above it all.

title: Resort Wear Rides the Tide Of Colorful, Playful Fashion
description: The resort collections are sizzling. Bright, stinging colors, original shapes and an inventive use of fabrics give life to clothes that in the past have often been nothing more than a retread of familiar, presumably successful, styles.

title: Atari to Acquire Electronics Retailer
description: The Atari Corporation, in a dramatic effort to increase distribution of its personal computers, is acquiring a consumer electronics chain.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MIXED-RACE LEADER BREAKS WITH BOTHA
description: The leader of the South African Parliament's chamber for people of mixed race quit the Cabinet today, declaring that President P. W. Botha was intolerant of other views.

title: Rig Count Up to 1,012
description: The number of oil rigs drilling in the United States jumped above 1,000 last week for the first time in 17 months, despite new volatility in world markets that has sent crude oil prices skidding nearly $4 a barrel in the last month. The latest weekly count, released today by Baker Hughes Inc., the Houston-based oilfield services company, showed 1,012 rigs were operating, up 14 from the previous week. A year ago, only 727 rigs were in use. The last time the United States rig count topped 1,000 was March 31, 1986, when 1,034 rigs were working.

title: NOT WHAT IT APPEARS
description: The invincible, to say nothing of the vincible, is always with us. It remains one of the delights and frustrations and agonies of life on this tilted planet.

title: RAGE IN JERUSALEM ON SABBATH FILMS
description: In the latest flare-up of the struggle between secular Israeli Jews and the very religious, 10,000 black-coated Orthodox demonstrators gathered at the Wailing Wall tonight to pray for an end to Friday-night films in Jerusalem, which they say are desecrating the Sabbath.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARY TODD LINCOLN. A Biography. By Jean H. Baker. Illustrated. 429 pages.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Friday misstated the effect of a strike on the International Paper Company's mill at Jay, Me. Although the United Paperworkers International Union has been striking since mid-June, the mill has continued operating.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Careers; Productive Ideas From Employees
description: INTRAPRENEURSHIP, the encouragement of productive ideas among employees, is coming to be depended on at a number of big companies. Top management realizes the need for more cooperation from lower levels of managers to improve productivity - and, hence, profits.

title: CONSUMMER SPENDING IS UP 0.9%
description: Consumer spending, bolstered by brisk auto sales and a heavy reliance on air-conditioning, soared nine-tenths of 1 percent in July for the second consecutive month, more than twice as fast as incomes grew, the Government reported today.

title: INTERNATIONAL AMERICAN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings reflect additional shares issued as of March 31, pursuant to an acquisition agreement.

title: Ranger-Islander Pacts
description: The Rangers have signed Jeff Jackson, a forward, and the Islanders have reached contract terms with Randy Boyd, a defenseman. Both players signed one-year pacts. Jackson, a left wing, was obtained last March from Toronto for Mark Osborne and had five goals and an assist in nine games with the Rangers. Boyd, who will be entering his third season with the Islanders, had 7 goals and 17 assists in 30 games with the team last season. He was recalled from the Springfield farm team in mid-February.

title: An Ascendant Conservative's Advice to Grim, Rejected Liberals
description: To the Editor:

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
School Board Is Assailed Over Nepotism
description: Despite almost a decade of warnings to the New York City Board of Education about the ''high incidence of nepotism'' among public school custodians, the board has failed to correct the abuses, New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: Pectin and Cholesterol
description: A study by scientists at the University of Florida has found new evidence that large daily doses of pectin can radically lower the blood levels of cholesterol, which has been linked to heart disease.

title: Plan to Widen Fire Dept. Role Angers High Police Officials
description: The Koch administration, attempting to settle a simmering dispute between New York City's Police and Fire Departments, has proposed that the main responsibility for handling certain disasters and emergencies be shifted from the police to the firefighters.

title: The Verity Hearings
description: The confirmation of President Reagan's nominee for Commerce Secretary, C. William Verity Jr., is shaping up as a more lively affair than anticipated.

title: Leadership For Schools
description: AMONG the nation's governors, education is no longer the overriding issue it was last year. New concerns, mainly economic problems and welfare reform, have moved to the head of the agenda.

title: Christmas Show Tickets
description: Tickets for the annual Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall go on sale tomorrow at the Radio City box office, 50th Street and Avenue of the Americas. Elves, carolers, members of the Rockettes and several snowmaking machines are to be on hand for the first day of sales. The show begins a two-month run Nov. 13. Tickets are $27 and $24. Information: 757-3100.

title: Surgery for Lawton
description: Brian Lawton, the Minnesota North Stars' center, returned to Minneapolis yesterday to undergo surgery on his right knee, which he injured while playing in Vienna for Team U.S.A. Lawton, 22 years old, tore cartilage in the knee during a game at the world championships shortly after the National Hockey League season ended, a spokeswoman for the North Stars said. The injury has continued to bother him, she said. Lawton should be skating within a week after tomorrow's surgery. Lawton, who lives in Cumberland, R.I., scored 21 goals and had 33 assists in 66 games last season.

title: Reunion in Coal Town Evokes Past
description: In the flower garden in front of the country home of Dr. Donald P. Vrabec sits a large lump of coal, a puzzlement to friends who visit.

title: INSIDE
description: Politics of Miners' Strike

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Return of the Beaver Yields New Opportunities for Study of a Builder
description: AFTER nearly being extirpated in the early 1800's by European trappers so that dandies abroad could don beaver hats, the beaver has gradually made a notable comeback - to the delight of many but to the consternation of some.

title: F. GEORGE du PONT
description: F. George du Pont, a retired executive vice president of the Remington Arms Company, died Saturday at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: More Can Fall Than the Dollar
description: U.S. Trade Gap in June Grew to $15.71 Billion. Like Beirut car bombings and defense contract overruns, big trade deficits have become routine; the bad news hardly registers, even when the dollar takes a nasty drop.

title: New Retreat for Theater Companies
description: In 1976 the Steppenwolf Theater company was little more than a gaggle of stagestruck suburban Chicago collegians, putting on plays in a church basement with furniture cadged from their parents' living rooms. But five years ago their production of Sam Shepard's ''True West'' brought national attention and established one company member, John Malkovich, as one of the most compelling young actors of the decade.

title: INSTITUTE OF CLINICAL PHARACOLOGY PLC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Shandwick P.L.C., a London public relations concern, has acquired Casey Communications Management, a public relations firm in Southfield, Mich.

title: Killings of Vietnamese Baffle California Police
description: Six years of efforts to solve a series of killings and arson fires involving Vietnamese refugees have had one main result: frustration for the law-enforcement authorities here.

title: GMI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: BROKERS SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Appeal by Caesars
description: Caesars World Inc. said it had petitioned the New Jersey Casino Control Commission to reconsider its refusal of the company's $960 million recapitalization plan, which was undertaken to defeat a takeover bid, since dropped, by Martin T. Sosnoff. The company said there was no guarantee that the commission would grant a rehearing on its denial of the plan, which included a one-time cash dividend of $26.25 a share.

title: Choices Made At Manpower
description: Manpower Inc. said today that five of its senior executives had signed employment agreements with Blue Arrow P.L.C. of Britain and that 22 other officials had reached severance agreements with Blue Arrow, which is acquiring Manpower for a sweetened offer of $1.33 billion.

title: PEGGY K. GLOVER
description: Peggy K. Glover, who worked in day care in East Harlem and the Bronx for more than 30 years, died Sunday at White Plains Hospital, after a brief illness. She was 67 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Graf Withdraws
description: Steffi Graf, ranked No. 1 in the world, will not play in the United Jersey Bank Classic tennis tournament at Mahwah, N.J., this week because of dental surgery. Graf, who had received an opening-round bye and had been scheduled to play her second-round match Thursday, underwent dental surgery in Florida last Thursday and Friday and had more surgery set for last night, according to the tournament spokesman, Jim Fuhse. Helena Sukova, who also received an opening-round bye, became the top-seeded player, and Zina Garrison is now seeded second. Tournament officials had moved Graf's starting time to Thursday from Tuesday in hopes she could compete but were informed Sunday night that the dental work was not complete because of an infection.

title: Chess: Gulko, First at Biel, Pulls Off Daring Speculative Sacrifice
description: Boris Gulko of the United States impressively won the elite, double-roundrobin Biel International Tournament in Switzerland. The former Soviet grandmaster tallied 9-5.

title: NOW, Criticizing Democrat Hopefuls, Plans Low Profile
description: Leaders of the National Organization for Women, dismayed over what they call a ''dull'' array of Democratic Presidential candidates, said today that they would not try to influence the party's choice for President.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1987
description: International A2-11, D20

title: Now We Need a Billboard Law for the Sky
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Makers Protest Tariff Ruling
description: A computer makers' trade group is challenging a Customs Service decision that could cost the companies millions of dollars a year in tariffs.

title: ERLICH BOBER FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $15,000 and $33,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the 9-month profit was attributable almost entirely to the gain on a sale of a building.

title: Blackstone Hires Shearson Officer
description: Roger C. Altman, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Carter Administration, said yesterday that he had left his position as a managing director of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and had joined the Blackstone Group, a private investment banking firm.

title: Jury Chosen in Biaggi Case as Defense Objects
description: Amid defense objections of bias, a jury was quickly selected yesterday for the Federal bribery trial of Representative Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader.

title: Reagan Said to Approve Missile Plan
description: President Reagan has approved the general elements of a new monitoring plan for a proposed treaty to ban American and Soviet medium-range and short-range nuclear missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: MAGMA POWER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $463,000 for the quarter and $470,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Viacom Unit Chairman
description: Viacom International named Henry S. Schleiff yesterday as chairman of its broadcast and entertainment groups. Mr. Schleiff, who has served as a senior vice president at Home Box Office since 1985, will manage Viacom's five television stations and nine radio stations, as well as its production and distribution work for television, motion pictures and video cassettes.

title: Son Helping to Update Crouse's 'Anything Goes'
description: Timothy Crouse's earliest memory of the musical ''Anything Goes'' is being told the story about how his father, Russel Crouse, who co-wrote the original script with Howard Lindsay, spent opening night in front of the Colonial theater in Boston, imploring his friends not to go in.

title: BEI HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,042,000 for the quarter and $2,591,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after tax credits of $1,970,000 and $2,401,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago losses were primarily the result of the one-time merger-related expenses of $1,700,000 and an $11,500,000 writedown in book value of certain real estate.

title: NEC Chip Seizure Is Sought by Intel
description: The Intel Corporation said it had asked the United States Customs Service to seize imported microprocessors made by NEC Electronics Inc., as well as any products containing the chips. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it had made the request because of delays involving a copyright infringement suit it filed against NEC about a year and a half ago. Intel has offered to post an indemnification bond on any parts detained until the trial ends.

title: New Music Scholarship In Ritchie Valens's Name
description: A music scholarship for Hispanic youths has been announced in the name of Ritchie Valens, whose brief rock-and-roll career is portrayed in the movie ''La Bamba.''

title: Heard These Two?
description: In the department of used jokes, somebody seems to have sold the same format to two contenders for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination: Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona.

title: New Forest Tools: Ping-Pong Balls
description: THE National Forest Service reports that it has successfully used common Ping-Pong balls filled with an incendiary chemical mixture to start a controlled forest fire in central Utah. A spokesman said the little chemical firebombs proved to be more effective than the jellied petroleum generally applied by spraying from helicopters, because the table-tennis balls started fires on the forest floor rather than in the treetops. The Ping-Pong bombs are also considerably cheaper than the napalm-type igniter jelly.

title: Bank of Boston's Auto Debt Issue
description: The Bank of Boston is offering $102 million of certificates backed by car loan receivables through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Bridge: In Casablanca, Relaxed Pace For an International Tourney
description: In a major American tournament most players are glued to the tables for eight hours each day. The experts who competed in the 1987 World Championships in Miami Beach complained bitterly when the total mounted to 10 or 11 hours, depriving them of the time usually available for swimming and socializing.

title: Empty Embassies
description: Diplomatic traffic has probably never been heavier in Central America, yet three out of the five U.S. embassies in the region lack ambassadors. Their absence is the more disabling since President Reagan's regional negotiator, Philip Habib, resigned. The result is that governments in the region either deal with interim charges or with Assistant Secretary Elliott Abrams, not known as a friend of negotiations with Managua.

title: Who Holds Key to Peace in Central America
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUNTAIN POWERBOAT INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dow Drops 12.43 to Close at 2,697.07
description: The stock market weakened yesterday, and major stock indexes pulled back from their record levels.

title: Advertising; Newsstand Catalogues Are Next
description: CATALOGUE promotion will pervade ever more of the nation this Christmas when 200 mail order catalogues are made available at 76,000 newsstands.

title: Nomura Move in Britain
description: The Nomura Securities Company Ltd. today became the first Japanese firm to make markets on the London Stock Exchange, as it began dealing in 10 leading British stocks. Nomura is entering a market in which the profits of longtime brokers have been squeezed by the so-called Big Bang deregulation last October. One firm has stopped market-making - the constant quoting of stock prices for instantaneous purchase or sale. Brokers said Nomura's huge base of Japanese clients gave it an edge in entering the London market.

title: TV Review; One Village In China'
description: ''ONE Village in China,'' a three-part series getting under way on public television - tonight at 9 P.M. on Channel 21 and 11 P.M. on Channel 13, and tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channel 31 - can claim an unusual and invaluable asset. At least two of the producers in the Long Bow Group, which produced the program, can speak Chinese, and they clearly know their subject. Carma Hinton, who introduces the programs, is an American born in Beijing in 1949. She spent her first 21 years in China. Richard Gordon, a photographer and cinematographer, has made seven trips to that country since 1975, and has worked in villages and in a Shanghai factory.

title: DRAFT REGISTRATIONB IS INDISPENSABLE
description: LEAD: Since the end of the Vietnam War, Congress and two Administrations have agreed that the demands of common sense and national security argue in favor of continued draft registration. Nevertheless, critics of the Selective Service System have little trouble gaining an audience for their argument that registration represents an intolerable abridgement of freedom.

title: Bryan Simpson, 84, Is Dead; Retired Appeals Court Judge
description: Bryan Simpson, who as a Federal district judge strongly enforced civil rights laws in the 1960's, died Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness, He was 84 years old.

title: AMERICAN EDUCATIONAL COMUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 25, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A Bull Market in Stock Splits
description: A record number of companies are expected to split their stock this year, yet another indication of the bull market's strength.

title: Japan's Plans On Research
description: Japan's Government will increase its spending on research in superconductivity next year while continuing to promote international cooperation, officials said today.

title: Who's Democratic
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Holds Key to Peace in Central America; Who Should Unite
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: CATHERINE ETTLINGER has replaced Karen Anderegg as editor in chief of Elle, the fashion magazine. John B. Evans, president of Murdoch Magazines, announced the appointment yesterday. Ms. Anderegg has become president of Clinique Laboratories.

title: Iran and the Saudis War With Fierce Words 881>
description: A fierce war of words, a religious struggle for the soul of Islam, is raging between Iran and Saudi Arabia over the violence at the annual pilgrimage to Mecca.

title: Gillette Rejects Revlon Bid
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that its board had rejected Revlon Group Inc.'s unsolicited $5.41 billion takeover offer and reiterated its intention for the company to remain independent.

title: Grand Auto Inc.
description: Grand Auto Inc., an auto parts retail chain based in Oakland, Calif., said it was discontinuing efforts to sell the company because it had received no proposals that its board felt were in the best interests of shareholders. The company also said Thomas F. Herman had been elected president, chief executive and a director. Mr. Herman, formery president of the automotive division of Lucky Stores Inc., succeeds John Goodsell, who resigned last week.

title: Soto Rejoins Reds
description: Mario Soto, who was hit hard in a minor league game Friday night for the Cincinnati Reds' Nashville farm team, probably will start a game for the Reds in the first week of September, according to Manager Pete Rose. Against Soto's wishes, team officials had considered keeping him in the minor leagues as he continues his attempt to regain the fastball he had before an August 1986 operation to repair his pitching shoulder. The right-hander, 3-2 this season, has spent much of this season on the disabled list. On Friday night, Soto pitched seven innings for the Nashville Sounds against the Louisville Cardinals, giving up eight runs on 10 hits. Despite that showing, Soto has rejoined the Reds, though he is still on the disabled list. ''We're looking for Mario to work on the side and have a good workout on Wednesday, and probably after that, I'll start him,'' Rose said. ''That should be somewhere around the first or second of September.''

title: Student-Exchange Groups Report Problems in Finding Host Families
description: International student-exchange programs in the United States are experiencing unprecedented difficulty this year finding American host families for high-school students from abroad.

title: SmithKline Bid
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the International Hydron Corporation for about $155 million and certain considerations. The National Patent Development Corporation owns about 90 percent of International Hydron, which makes contact lenses. Each public shareholder will receive about $10.35 a share. Allergan Inc., SmithKline's eye-care unit, will assume responsibility for Hydron's contact lens business.

title: Plea on Soviet Bankruptcies
description: Hundreds of Soviet companies that are losing money should be declared bankrupt as soon as possible to relieve the burden on healthy enterprises now subsidizing them, a top Soviet economist was quoted as saying today.

title: Kenner Parker's Injunction Upheld
description: A Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court judge denied a motion by New World Entertainment to remove an injunction blocking its bid for Kenner Parker Toys Inc. New World also said that a meeting with Kenner Parker officials, originally scheduled for Tuesday, had been canceled.

title: BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings results are adjusted to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid earlier this month. The company said results for the latest quarter includes an inventory writeoff of $533,000.

title: Tracing the 'Protocols of Zion' Farther Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Wayne Andrews, 73, Author And Professor of Art History
description: Wayne Andrews, an author and retired professor of art history at Wayne State University in Detroit, died of a heart attack on Aug. 17 while traveling in Paris. He was 73 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: U.S. Open Wild Cards
description: Ken Flach, the Davis Cup standout for the United States, and 15-year-old Michael Chang are among eight players to receive wild-card entries into the main draw of the United States Open. Flach, of Sebring, Fla., has a 7-0 record in Davis Cup doubles matches. Chang, who lives in La Costa, Calif., won the United States Tennis Association's Boys' 18 National Championship this summer. Other wild-card entries are Al Parker of Claxton, Ga.; Shelby Cannon of Gainesville, Fla.; Rich Leach of Laguna Beach, Calif.; Joey Rive of Lake Worth, Fla.; Todd Nelson of San Diego, Calif., and Andrew Burrow of South Africa. The Open runs from Sept. 1-13 at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: ASPEN RIBBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IRWIN MAGNETIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $124,000 and $494,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $343,000 for the quarter and $1,509,000 for the year.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $535,000 for the quarter and $2,038,000 for the year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page last Thursday about government policy on family issues misidentified a professor with the Hubert H. Humphrey Institute at the University of Minnesota. He is Harry Boyte.

title: On the Highway: A Blend of Progress and Tradition
description: The diners, motor inns and gas stations that front the Sunrise Highway here have an unlikely new neighbor: luxury town houses.

title: At Last, a Worker's Right to Know
description: A new ruling from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration grants workers in almost every major workplace a basic safeguard: the right to know what hazardous substances are present. The wonder is that it should have taken 17 years and a Federal court order to bring this about.

title: HEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest 9-month includes a gain of $441,000 from the sale of a former manufacturing facility.

title: Decline in Abortions Reported
description: Federal health officials have reported a decrease in the number of abortions in the United States for the first time since record-keeping began in 1969.

title: SUBWAYS ARE BETTER, TRANSIT SURVEY FINDS
description: New York City subways are cooler, cleaner, easier to get into and easier to see out of than a year ago, according to a report issued yesterday by the Transit Authority.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 12wks to July 26
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $726,000. The company said year-ago first quarter net excludes a gain of $5,736,000 from the secondary public offering of Sizzler common stock. The company changed its accounting periods from a calendar fiscal year ending April 30 to a 52-week fiscal year ending on the Sunday nearest April 30. Fiscal 1987 results have been adjusted accordingly.

title: Advertising; Agency Chosen By CBS Group
description: The CBS Broadcast Group has named Backer Spielvogel Bates as its first agency of record for the entertainment, news, sports and international divisions. The account, estimated at $50 million, encompasses the extensive daily program advertising nationwide. Ogilvy & Mather, SSC&B and

title: That Newsprint Tariff
description: Would a tariff on imported newpaper paper hinder the operation of a free press? Can First Amendment principles extend to the business operations of a newpaper as well as its editorial policy?

title: Aguilera Stellar In Comeback
description: The Mets reclaimed one of their memories of 1986 last night when Rick Aguilera made a smashing comeback after three months on the disabled list and pitched them to a 1-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: REPORT SAID TO FIND INEFFICIENCY AT NBC
description: A report commissioned by NBC from an independent management company has found that there are too many employees on the NBC news division payroll, their salaries are too high and their time is wasted too often, according to network officials familiar with the report.

title: DOCUGRAPHIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YANKS TOP ANGELS, 3-2, IN NINTH
description: For most of his 22 years in the major leagues, Don Sutton has been thrown under baseball's miscroscope for allegedly doctoring baseballs. Tonight, he might have been caught scuffing them in full view of a New York television audience.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BMG Music has promoted Pete Jones to president of its RCA/A&M/ Arista Distribution unit.

title: Ecuador Oil Shipments
description: Five months after earthquakes ruptured an important pipeline, Ecuador has resumed oil exports, the state oil company said, shipping 360,000 barrels to foreign customers on Sunday. While the ruptured pipeline was being repaired, Ecuador received oil loans from other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and managed to produce 50,000 barrels of oil a day - all of it used domestically. Oil provides about 65 percent of Ecuador's foreign income.

title: Summary of 13 Counts on Which Lonetree Was Convicted
description: Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree was sentenced to 30 years in prison today after being convicted on these 13 counts of espionage:

title: Mexico City Journal; And Where Are the Bureaucrats? Gone Fishing
description: Going on vacation is something workers everywhere eagerly look forward to. But according to a recent study, no one in Mexico does it better, or more often, than the country's two million bureaucrats, most of whom live and work here in the capital.

title: Emerson and Twain to Join Poets' Corner at Cathedral
description: Two giants of 19th-century American literature, Ralph Waldo Emerson and Mark Twain, will be inducted into the Poets' Corner in the arts bay of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, in a ceremony on Oct. 18 at the 7 P.M. vesper service. Two deceased writers are selected for the honor annually.

title: On Fire Safety
description: The International Association of Firefighters is seeking to draw a safety lesson from the fire last winter in a Puerto Rico hotel that killed 97 people.

title: Russians Say Western Radio Instigated Baltic Protests
description: The Soviet press has mounted an unusually bitter attack on Western radio stations for their role in publicizing nationalist demonstrations Sunday in the Soviet Baltic republics.

title: Lawyers Catch Merger Fever
description: The wave of mergers, acquisitions and buyouts that has swept through America's largest corporations has reached the country's leading corporate law firms.

title: Free T.W.A. Suspect, Beirut Hostage Asks
description: Kidnappers of two West German hostages in Lebanon issued a videotape of one of their captives today in which he called on Bonn to release a suspected Lebanese hijacker in exchange for their freedom.

title: Advertising; New Versions of Song For Hosiery Campaign
description: L'eggs pantyhose has reworked the lyrics of ''Legs,'' originally recorded by the rock group ZZ Top in 1984, for a new campaign for Sheer Energy and Sheer Elegance brands. Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton created an upbeat version of the song to promote Sheer Energy and a slower-moving tempo for the Sheer Elegance line.

title: George Lindsay, Ex-Publisher Of Stock Market Newsletter
description: George Lindsay, who for many years published a weekly newsletter that analyzed the stock market, died of a heart attack in his Greenwich Village apartment on Aug. 6. He was 79 years old.

title: HURCO COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JAMCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes a loss of $163,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. The company said the latest quarter loss consisted primarily of one-time non-cash charges, including $211,000 for miscellaneous items such as obsolete inventory and goodwill writeoffs; $587,000 expenses for anticipated losses on closed or subleased restaurant properties; and expense provisions of $599,000 for bad debts and settlement of litigation.

title: AMERICAN TELEMEDIA NETORK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OPTEK TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $132,000 for the quarter and $311,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $71,000 and $162,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Mary Dobkin Is Dead at 84; A Patron of Needy Children
description: Mary Dobkin, whose work kept thousands of children out of trouble and inspired a television movie about her life, died Saturday. She was 84 years old.

title: Carnival Ships
description: Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. said it had ordered two passenger ships from Finland's Wartsila Marine Industries in what it called the largest contract ever awarded for passenger ships. Carnival said it had signed a letter of agreement for the deal, worth about $400 million. The new vessels will be identical to a 70,000-ton ship, to be named Fantasy, that Wartsila is currently building for Carnival for about $200 million.

title: Suspect Gives Up in Shooting Of 6, 3 Fatally, in the Bronx
description: One of three suspects being sought for shooting six people in the head, three fatally, in a South Bronx apartment during a drug-related robbery last Friday, surrendered late Sunday in Harrisburg, Pa., officials said.

title: EX-JERSEYAN SEIZED IN FLORIDA WITH CAR OF MISSING WOMAN
description: An automobile belonging to a 25-year-old West Orange, N.J., woman who has been missing since she went to the Morris County Mall in Hanover, N.J., four days ago, was found yesterday in a restaurant parking lot in Palm Beach, Fla., officials said last night.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Net income

title: MICHAELS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes a $502,000 pretax gain from sale of investments.

title: Bonds Drop a Bit, Following Dollar
description: Bond prices continued to move in tandem with the dollar yesterday, dropping sharply in Tokyo overnight but then improving in London and stabilizing in New York. By the end of the trading day, prices were only slightly lower than last Friday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Upset in Gallant Man Stakes: Drachma and Crown the Leader, stablemates owned by Gail Beitz and trained by Larry Kelly, turned the featured race at Saratoga Race Track yesterday into an intramural contest by finishing first and second in the Gallant Man Stakes for 3-year-olds. The entry, dismissed as the fourth choice in a field of seven betting interests, also scored under substitute riders. At different points, Jacinto Vasquez had been named to ride on both horses, but he took the day off. Robbie Davis substituted on Drachma, who led all the way and scored by a nose over Crown the Leader, with Jean Cruguet riding. Major Beard was third at 13-1. Drachma, a son of Damascus and Ten Cents a Kiss, ran the one and an eighth miles on the grass in 1:49 4/5, and the winning entry returned $15.60, $12 and $7.20 for $2 across the board. Rowing American Wins Single-Sculls Heat: Anne Martin, competing in the women's lightweight single sculls, was the only American first-place finisher yesterday in the opening heats of the world rowing championships on Lake Bagsvaerd outside Copenhagen. In four heavyweight men's events yesterday, East Germany advanced its four with coxswain and its single- and double-sculls entries to Thursday's semifinals. Peter-Michael Kolbe of West Germany, the 1986 world champion, won his heat yesterday in the single sculls, as did Pertti Karppinen, the 1985 champion. Andy Sudduth of the United States finished second to Karppinen, but still advanced. (AP) Tennis Krishnan Defeats Maciel: Third-seeded Ramesh Krishnan, the No. 1 player on the Davis Cup team of India, defeated Francisco Maciel of Mexico, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in the opening round of the Nynex Open at the Rye Town Hilton Hotel in Rye Brook, N.Y. Thomas Muster of Austria, seeded fourth, scored a 3-6, 7-6, 6-3 victory over Christian Bergstrom of Sweden. (AP) Balestrat Advances in Mahwah: Dianne Balestrat defeated Hu Na, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the $150,000 United Jersey Bank Classic tournament in Mahwah, N.J. In other first-round matches, Nathalie Tauziat defeated Terry Phelps, 2-6, 7-5, 6-2; Sandra Cecchini edged Catherine Tanvier, 5-7, 6-4, 7-6, and Raffaella Reggi beat Tine Scheuer-Larson, 6-1, 6-2. Hockey Team U.S.A. Wins, 5-2: Phil Housley scored twice and John Vanbiesbrouck stopped 27 shots last night as Team U.S.A. scored a 5-2 Canada Cup exhibition victory over the United States Olympic team. The game, played at the Hartford Civic Center, was the final tune-up for Team U.S.A., which begins play Friday in the Canada Cup, a round-robin series involving six countries. Team U.S.A. jumped out to a 1-0 just 1 minute 9 seconds into the game when Pat LaFontaine snapped in a rebound from in close after the goaltender, Chris Terreri, had stopped Wayne Presley from about 12 feet.(AP)

title: Advertising; AC&R/DHB to Do Ads For Health Care Plan
description: Total Health, a managed health care plan in the New York metropolitan area, has awarded AC&R/DHB & Bess its $2 million budget. A television, radio and subway campaign is scheduled to start in the fall.

title: Mysterious Dances
description: Mysterious Dances

title: Uccel Purchaser Sets 300 Layoffs
description: Computer Associates International Inc., which completed its $830 million purchase of the Uccel Corporation last Wednesday, said 300 Uccel employees would be immediately laid off. The company said the job cuts, representing about 8 percent of the merged companies' work force, would primarily affect clerical and middle management positions.

title: WILLIAM W. KEELER
description: William W. Keeler, the former president and chief executive of the Phillips Petroleum Company and former chief of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma, died todayat the Heritage Manor Nursing Home here. He was 79 years old and had been in ill health for four years. .

title: Miller Quits as U.S.O.C. Chief
description: Less than six months before the start of the 1988 Olympics, the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee resigned his position today.

title: 73 Fishermen Rescued Near Coast of Florida
description: Rescuers picked up 73 abandoned lobstermen today after Bahamian authorities seized their mother ships, stranding the fishermen overnight in small boats until they made it to United States waters.

title: INTERFUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. NAVY ESCORT FIRES IN WARNING IN GULF ENCOUNTER
description: A United States Navy destroyer fired machine gun bursts across the bows of two small wooden sailing boats today as she helped bring four reregistered Kuwaiti tankers out of the Persian Gulf. They were the first shots fired by a Navy vessel since the gulf convoy mission began.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Fruehauf Corp., Detroit, said it had agreed to settle a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over its excise tax liability from October 1956 to 1965. Fruehauf agreed to an assessment of about $6.8 million of additional excise tax for that period, as well as a penalty of some $3.4 million and interest of about $9.9 million, for a total of $20.1 million.

title: Stephanos Sidarouss Dies; A Coptic Catholic Cardinal
description: Cardinal Stephanos Sidarouss, patriarch emeritus of the Coptic Catholic Church, died after an illness at age 83, a church spokesman said today.

title: Hess Is Buried Secretly by Family; Son Is Reported to Suffer Stroke
description: The family of Rudolf Hess announced today that Hitler's onetime deputy had already been buried in secret, apparently out of fear of neo-Nazi demonstrations and clashes with the police. The family would not disclose when or where the burial had taken place.

title: Brothers With AIDS Virus Return To Florida Classes Under Guard
description: Three brothers carrying the AIDS virus returned peacefully to their school under court order and police guard today despite a boycott by frightened parents that kept up to half the pupils at home.

title: Summer Antidote
description: It's fair season, a fact easily forgotten in the city. Across America, people park in grassy fields, get ink stamps on the backs of their hands and enter a world that hasn't changed much for decades.

title: Advertising; A 9-Page Soviet Ad In Wall Street Journal
description: The Soviet Union decided that one way to forge business ties with the United States would be to advertise its assets in a nine-page supplement, and it appeared in three regional editions of The Wall Street Journal yesterday. The ad, costing about $300,000, ran in the Eastern United States, European and Asian editions, with a combined circulation of 900,000, according to Donald Cates, managing director of Dow Jones International Marketing Services.

title: Seagram Names Official
description: Edward F. McDonnell has been named executive vice president, international, of the Seagram Company, the company said yesterday. Mr. McDonnell, 52 years old, is the president of Seagram International, which has affiliated companies in 25 countries. Since 1981, when the division was created, Seagram's sales have grown to $1.4 billion, from $870 million.

title: Economic Development: Engine of Democracy
description: There have been few times in our history when the word ''democracy'' has been so persistently, even extravagantly, a subject of public reference as in these last months.

title: A Reagan Message to Nicaragua Is Aired on Contra Radio Station
description: President Reagan told anti-Sandinista rebels tonight that the United States would continue to support them ''until the people of Nicaragua are guaranteed basic liberties.''

title: 100 Married Priests Meet
description: More than 100 married Roman Catholic priests began a weeklong congress today to press the Vatican to modify clerical celibacy regulations. The men, members of the International Federation of Married Catholic Priests representing the United States, Canada and Latin America, say there is no biblical basis for a celibate priesthood and are calling for optional celibacy.

title: A Professor Is Seeking Duro-Test
description: A member of the Yale University faculty who teaches business students how to spot undervalued companies has made an unsolicited $82 million takeover offer for the Duro-Test Corporation, a maker of long-lasting light bulbs.

title: State Lawyers Get Bond Role
description: New York State's own lawyers will begin issuing opinions about the tax-exempt status of bonds sold by state agencies, a budget official said yesterday.

title: For Koch and Cardinal, A Hit in the Making?
description: The joint book planned by Mayor Koch and John Cardinal O'Connor is literally an overnight hit. The morning after their project became public, the co-authors yesterday got a publisher, striking a deal that could yield $1 million to their chosen charities.

title: Market Place; Regional Bank Issues Favored
description: REGIONAL banks with no exposure to foreign loans are increasingly being recommended by analysts as many big money-center institutions and larger regionals continue to be battered by problems arising from their foreign lending.

title: New President For Shell Unit
description: The Shell Oil Company has named James R. Street president of the Shell Development Company, the corporation's research division.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: McRae at the Blue Note

title: EXPLOSION FORCES 400 TO EVACUATE BUILDING
description: About 400 people were evacuated from a medical research building in the Bronx yesterday after workers accidentally ignited volatile chemicals stored there, causing a small explosion and fire.

title: Dollar Moves Higher On Bullish Comments
description: The dollar rose on world currency markets yesterday, buoyed by supportive comments from Japanese, West German and United States officials.

title: Where to Sample the Varieties
description: FOLLOWING is a sampling of stores and markets in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut where shoppers can find fairly large selections of tomatoes. MANHATTAN Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street), 212-673-2600. Dean & DeLuca, 121 Prince Street (Greene Street), 212-431-1691. Greenmarkets in several locations offer some tomato varieties. (For information on the markets: 212-477-3220.) Here are three possibilities: Independence Plaza at Greenwich Avenue and Chambers Street (Wednesdays through Nov. 25 and Saturdays through Dec. 19); 102d Street and Amsterdam Avenue (Fridays through Dec. 18), and St. Mark's Church, 10th Street and Second Avenue (Tuesdays through Nov. 24). BROOKLYN Greenmarkets at Cadman Plaza West and Montague Street (Tuesdays through Dec. 22 and Saturdays year round), and at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues (Wednesdays through Nov. 25). DUTCHESS COUNTY Henry Dykeman's Farm Market, Route 22, Pawling, N.Y., 914-855-5166.

title: Mack vs. Chiles?
description: Republicans were stung by the defeat of Senator Paula Hawkins of Florida last year, but now they say they have a chance for a comeback in that state. The reason for their optimism is Representative Connie Mack, a conservative luminary in the party who says he is considering a challenge to Florida's senior Senator, Lawton Chiles, in 1988.

title: OPEC Head's Remarks Help Steady Oil Prices
description: Prices of crude oil held steady yesterday after OPEC's president offered hope that the group would soon restrain its output.

title: Runoff Cited in Pollution of the Hudson
description: Runoff from farms and roads causes more contamination of the Hudson River by such chemicals as lead and arsenic than do discharges from factories, according to a study to be released today by Inform, an environmental research group.

title: Advertising; Wall St. Still Sees Takeovers
description: THE price activity in advertising stocks has settled down, but takeover rumors seem to have a life of their own.

title: Neglecting the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Compassion Is the Key In Battle Against AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Disputes NBC Salary Figures
description: The union on strike against NBC said yesterday that salary figures in a study prepared for the network by an outside management consultant were ''grossly inflated.''

title: Moscow Journal; East Meets East in a Visitor From Constantinople
