description: The public perception of Jimmy Connors changed on the day he appeared with his first-born, Brett. With no other visible change but a child, Connors stopped being Terrible Little Jimbo and became A Dad.

title: SOVIET AIDE IS COOL TO REAGAN SPEECH
description: A senior Soviet official said today that he was disappointed by President Reagan's address on East-West relations and accused the United States of trying to ''walk away'' from its earlier proposals for a system of monitoring adherence to a treaty that would ban two types of nuclear missiles.

title: Coleman's Batting Propels Cardinals
description: Matt Nokes, a pinch-hitter, lined a two-run single with two outs in the ninth inning and Chet Lemon followed with his second homer of the game tonight, rallying the Detroit Tigers over the Minnesota Twins, 10-8.

title: Giants Break Up Training Camp
description: The Giants broke up their training camp at Pace University after this morning's practice, a session that again was not up to the standards of Bill Belichick, the team's defensive coordinator.

title: Post Office Takes a Tip From Dale Carnegie
description: The letter that arrives late or the check that never comes are easy sources of humor for comedians and cartoonists, and the United States Postal Service, aware that an impending rate increase may further diminish its popularity, is moving to improve its image.

title: Riding the North Wave
description: The newest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows why students of public opinion struggle to resist the pull of fad and fancy. Seven weeks ago, fervent boosters of the contra rebels were sure, like political surfers, that they had caught a wave. The Iran-contra hearings gave Oliver North a national audience for impassioned speeches about the Nicaraguan rebels, and support for American aid to them curled suddenly upward.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago 6-month net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: Civil Suit Is Filed By U.S. to Curb A Crime Family
description: The Federal Government, for the first time, has filed a civil racketeering suit against an organized-crime family to prevent it from enrolling new members and to stop it from reaping ''enormous financial windfalls'' through unlawful and even legal business activities.

title: Union Grove Journal; On Carnival Circuit, Fame of a Sort
description: Pops Preslar lit up a cigarette, leaned his tatooed arm against the amusement ride gate and flashed a cheerful, toothless grin.

title: Shareholders Fight Jim Walter Buyout
description: The Jim Walter Corporation said a shareholder suit in Florida charges that its directors and officers violated their fiduciary duties in accepting a $60-a-share, or $2.43 billion, friendly offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Jim Walter said the suit charged that its board ''unfairly favored Kohlberg, Kravis over the other bidders for reasons other than the objective merits of the offer.''

title: A Call for More Fire-Resistant Furniture
description: The union representing the nation's firefighters has called for tough new fire-resistance standards for furniture. ''Burning and smoldering upholstered furniture is the most frequent cause of death in fires in the United States,'' said John A. Gannon, president of the International Association of Fire Fighters. ''It is time to stop the killing.''

title: TENNIS LADY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $625,000 charge against the writedown of store assets.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $19,000. c-Net loss

title: BONN WOULD SCRAP A-MISSILES IN REPLY TO U.S.-SOVIET PACT
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that if the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to scrap all their medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles, West Germany would get rid of its Pershing 1A missiles.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Central Jersey Bancorp is offering $25 million of 7 5/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 at 100 through First Boston as sole underwriter. Noncallable for three years, the debentures are convertible into the company's common.

title: Carlucci Denies a Rift With Shultz on Policy
description: Frank C. Carlucci, the national security adviser, denied today that he and Secretary of State George P. Shultz are feuding. He said that they have ''long enjoyed a very good personal relationship,'' and that they have a ''very harmonious'' working relationship.

title: Thousands Protest Philippine Price Rise
description: Thousands of transport drivers, telephone operators, teachers, and government and factory workers stayed off the job today in a nationwide strike against fuel price increases, despite a last-minute attempt by President Corazon C. Aquino to defuse the protest.

title: PRIME MOTORS INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $641,000 and $3,330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net of $879,000 for the quarter and $3,579,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said the revenue results exclude revenue from discontinued operations.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FOR years, portable electric routers have been the darlings of woodworking professionals. Now routers are showing up in the workshops of amateurs, and with good reason. A router might be one of the most versatile power tools you can own.

title: PPG Selling Potash Unit
description: PPG Industries said it would sell its potash business to Sullivan & Proops of Chicago. Terms were not disclosed. PPG Industries said that potash, a key ingredient in fertilizer, accounted for less than $100 million of its 1986 total sales of $4.7 billion. PPG Industries is based in Pittsburgh.

title: Delta Engine Skids in a Test
description: NASA's troubled space program suffered another setback today when a solid rocket booster engine being tested for the Delta project skidded out of control, the space agency said. It was the third test for the rocket booster engine.

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said fiscal 1986 results have been restated to reflect United's policy, adopted during 1986, of valuing the current portfolio of marketable securities held by a wholly-owned subsidiary at market value.

title: AIR CRASH SURVIVOR LEARNS OF HER LOSS
description: Four-year-old Cecilia Cichan asked what ''never again'' meant after an aunt told her that her parents and brother had been in an accident and she would never see them again.

title: Welfare Costs: Spending Money To Save Money
description: Mayor Koch had been demanding it for months. William J. Grinker, the Mayor's Human Resources Administrator, responded by drafting a specific plan. Finally, on June 30, the Board of Estimate approved it: an imaginative jobs program to get up to 3,000 people off welfare without government subsidies.

title: TRITON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,999,000 for the quarter and $5,443,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,270,000 and $2,635,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the 6-months also includes a loss of $293,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A USEFUL ABOUT-FACE
description: President Reagan has decided to back away from his tough-guy demands for on-site verification of the proposed Soviet-American treaty banning medium- and short-range missiles. Arms control advocates, if tempted to laugh in derision, should stifle the impulse.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extrarodinary loss of $6,027,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary loss for both the quarter and 6 months of $6,209,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Caring for Books In a Home Library
description: LEAD: BOOKS are made mostly of organic products and are strongly affected by their surroundings. Whether they are bound in paper, cloth or leather, books that are not cared for deteriorate: covers discolor and leaves crumble.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend in May 1987, and a 2-for-1 stock split in July 1987.

title: Paint Jobs: Victorian Homes Burst Into Vivid Colors
description: IT'S hard to believe it now, but not long ago people traded in their glorious Victorian homes for boxes in the postwar suburbs. Even people who liked their Victorian homes masked the exterior architecture with white paint. Now that old houses have returned to fashion, people are discovering that the Victorians had a good sense of color. Cities are even requiring the use of historically accurate colors in historic districts, and new books are spreading the gospel and the how-to.

title: DIGITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $319,000 for the quarter and $600,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $140,000 and $867,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, the 9-month also includes income from discontinued operations of $483,000.

title: Physician Warns of a Generation of Fat Children
description: If Americans are trying to raise a generation of fat children unable and unwilling to exercise, they are ''off to a flying start,'' an American Academy of Pediatrics official says.

title: WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Worm and the Apple: Rest and Restoration; Discomfort Station
description: Often, the traveler's last impression of New York is of the rest room in the railroad station. If the traveler is female and the rest room is the one off Amtrak's waiting room in Penn Station, her farewell won't be pleasant.

title: Some Important Jets Get a Close Look
description: It looked like a free-agent tryout. In a sense it was.

title: DEALING WITH STAIRS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bork On the Presidency
description: The Iran-contra affair has just reminded us of a reality of modern American government: To a degree quite unforeseen by the Framers of the Constitution, the President has the initiative in our system. He acts; Congress reacts. Power is centered in the White House. So is the risk of its abuse. A Supreme Court nominee's approach to issues of Presidential power is therefore highly significant. Judge Robert Bork has made his exceptionally clear. He takes a sweeping view of what Presidents can do, beyond the control of Congress or the courts.

title: Tanzanians Kill 18 'Witches'
description: Eighteen elderly people suspected of practicing witchcraft in northern Tanzania have been killed by close relatives over the last two months, the official press agency Shihata said today.

title: UNCOVERING SECRETS OF THE PAST
description: WHEN it's time to paint a Victorian home, owners can restore the original paint scheme, select new colors from a historically apt palette or create an updated color scheme.

title: RECORDED BOOKS HELP MAKE THE EAR FASTER THAN THE EYE
description: Audio cassettes based on books are having an increasing impact on the entertainment and educational marketplace all over the country.

title: BANK BUILDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $371,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,084,000 and $1,124,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest third quarter includes an unusual pre-tax gain of about $3.8 million from the termination of a pension plan.

title: G&K SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
BANK OF MONTREAL (CALIFORNIA) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a special charge of $753 million for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The company said the bank took a $753 million special charge as part of its move to increase loan loss provisions to third world countries. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gillette Is Selling a Unit
description: Dickson Concepts Ltd., a local wholesaler and retailer of fashion products, watches and jewelery, agreed to acquire S. T. Dupont S.A. of France from the Gillette Company, Dickson's finance director, Joseph Wan, said today. Mr. Wan said the purchase of S. T. Dupont would complement the company's existing product lines. Its retail outlets may be integrated with S. T. Dupont's worldwide network. Industry sources said S. T. Dupont had annual sales of more than $500 million (Hong Kong), or about $64 million.

title: Offer by Company For Fermenta Fails
description: A bid to sell Sweden's scandal-plagued Fermenta A.B. to Trans-Resources Inc., a New York-based fertilizer and chemical company, collapsed late today after a major Fermenta shareholder refused to back the bid.

title: Lufthansa Weighs Bid For Hotels
description: Lufthansa, the West German national airline, is considering buying the Hilton International luxury hotel chain from the Allegis Corporation, Lufthansa said yesterday.

title: CAMERA PLATFORMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dealing With Stairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Missile Test a Success
description: A test of the Tomahawk cruise missile, loaded with small bombs dropped on multiple targets along a 500-mile path, was completed successfully on Tuesday, according to the Navy. Lieut. Cmdr. Don Lewis said today that the test marked a ''breakthrough'' in expanding the versatility of the missile, since it was the first time small bombs have been dropped from it.

title: DOOM DECLINED
description: To the Home Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 27, 1987
description: International A3-11

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Two Held in Abduction And Beating of Woman
description: A man and a woman were arrested on charges of abducting and beating a Stony Point woman who was found alive in a ditch 60 hours after having been dumped there, Rockland County officials said.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses of $1,581,000 and $3,608,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, on disposal of discontinued operations; and the year also includes a loss of $436,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Includes net of $12,000 for the quarter and a loss of $574,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: The company said the earnings increase resulted from the 15 percent sales gain and a reduction in the company's federal income tax rate, stemming from the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: Chairman For Filene's
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that Jerry M. Socol would become chairman and chief executive of its Filene's department store chain.

title: It Reconciles Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Andover May Bid Again for Concern
description: Andover Group, an investment firm based in suburban Washington, said that it might renew its efforts to seek control of HBO & Company. HBO is repurchasing six million of its 23.2 million shares. The program was announced after the company's investment adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, failed to find a buyer for the the Atlanta-based hospital computer equipment concern.

title: APPLIED DNA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Ethics Panel Is Scrutinizing New York City
description: The State Ethics Commission served subpoenas on New York City's Department of Personnel yesterday, seeking information about the appointments of up to 20 past and present city officials.

title: KEY RATES
Pitt Player Is Eligible
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Eligibility Committee voted today to restore the eligibility of Teryl Austin, the University of Pittsburgh defensive back who admitted taking money last year from Norby Walters, an agent, in violation of N.C.A.A. rules. Austin, a senior, must sit out

title: Free Device Offered To Block Out MTV
description: A Connecticut cable television company offered yesterday to provide, without charge to its subscribers, devices to block the reception of MTV, a cable channel that broadcasts rock music videos.

title: Anti-Drug Promotion By Procter & Gamble
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is joining the war against drugs in a September product promotion. The company plans to include anti-drug pledge cards in a coupon mailing to about 47 million households.

title: Split-Up Backed At Carter Hawley
description: Shareholders of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. have approved a restructuring, splitting the retailer into a specialty store company and a department store concern. The previously announced split was to fend off a hostile takeover attempt last year. It will cost about $88 million and will substantially change the ownership of Carter Hawley.

title: PHLCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said comparable results for year-ago periods weren't available; the company formerly known as Baldwin United Corp., emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings Nov. 13, 1986.

title: Battle Over Plant Closings
description: When House and Senate negotiators sit down in two weeks to work out their differences over trade legislation, they will first have to resolve one of the most bitter labor-management disputes to arise during the Reagan Administration.

title: Out of the Closets and Into Mini-Storage
description: LEAD: LAURA EDELSTEIN, a direct-mail sales executive who works out of her cramped studio apartment in Manhattan, wanted a place to store her files whenever she entertained.

title: Electronics Trade Deficit
description: The American Electronics Association said today that the American electronics trade deficit with Japan and the rest of the world narrowed to $5.3 billion in the first half of this year, from a deficit of $6.1 billion a year earlier.

title: DELTA WOODSIDE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: The company said latest quarter and year results include operations of the finished woven fabrics division, acquired from J.P. Stevens & Co. July 15, 1986. Year-ago share earnings aren't available; the company went public in February 1987.

title: Japan Stiffens Export Rules
description: Japan moved today to increase penalties for illegal exports to Communist countries. American anger continues over the Toshiba Machine Company's sales of advanced technology to the Soviet Union. In Washington, the Japanese

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Talking Deals: Raiders' Town: First and Long
description: WITH a signed agreement to build a 65,000-seat football stadium for the Los Angeles Raiders, Irwindale, Calif., stands to become the little town that landed a very big deal.

title: Rise in Fear of Flying Linked to Detroit Crash
description: Many people trying to overcome their fear of flying are suffering reversals as a result of the recent Northwest Airlines crash and other problems involving aircraft in the United States, some counselors say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are a family of very modest economic means, and I wasn't about to embark on a campaign that would have led us into a financial black hole.'' - Senator Paul Laxalt,withdrawing from Presidential race. [ A12:4. ]

title: Power Struggle in P.L.O. Unit
description: A power struggle has broken out among the senior commanders in southern Lebanon of Al Fatah, the faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization led by Yasir Arafat. One officer has been assassinated and a second was wounded in an attempt to kill him.

title: CH HEIST reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Dollar Dragged Down By Glum Trade Report
description: The dollar declined yesterday, pulled down by another discouraging report on the nation's trade picture.

title: ELEANOR JAMISON
description: Eleanor Poynter Jamison, a former Indiana newspaper publisher, died Tuesday. She was 86 years old.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,590,000 from early repayment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net income Share earnings are adjusted to reflect an increase of about 3,150,000 common shares resulting from a stock dividend of one share of a new class B common stock for each common shares, effectively a 2-for-1 stock split, paid Jan. 15, 1987. The company said the 1987 results include the operations of Keystone- Franklin Inc., acquired Dec. 30, 1986.; year-ago results include the operations of Learn Copper & Brass Inc., acquired Nov. 1, 1985, and Select-Line Industries Inc., acquired April 21, 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 27, 1987
description: Companies

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $969,000 and $1,945,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Drug Use Outlined
description: The former linebacker Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson says in his autobiography, ''Out of Control,'' that he used drugs while playing for four different National Football League teams and sniffed a cocaine-laced inhaler during Super Bowl XIII as a Dallas Cowboy.

title: Wallach's Resignation
description: E. Robert Wallach, a confidant of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d whose relationship with the Wedtech Corporation is under investigation, has quietly resigned as a United States representative to the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

title: 2 Northeast Banks Plan To Merge
description: The move toward giant regional banks continued yesterday when two companies in the Northeast - the Hartford National Corporation and the Shawmut Corporation of Boston - agreed to merge.

title: Shooting Victim May Lose Use of Eye
description: It was unclear yesterday whether a Brooklyn man who was shot in the right eye as he rode an elevated subway train early Tuesday would lose his sight in that eye, a spokeswoman for Bellevue Hospital Center said.

title: Recovery Effort Begun for Buick
description: The General Motors Corporation's troubled Buick Motor division has begun a wide-ranging effort to improve its image for building premium cars after a disappointing year for 1987 model sales. The major element in plans for a recovery in the 1988 model year will be the new front-wheel-drive Buick Regal, the first product from G. M.'s $5 billion program for a new family of sleekly styled mid-size cars, known internally as the ''GM10 project.'' The car replaces a rear-drive version of the Regal, whose sales have been steadily dropping since their 1983 peak. Buick, along with other G.M. divisions, has been stung by a steep drop in sales in 1987 as the company's share of the American market has been only about 37 percent, compared with about 43 percent a year ago.

title: LAWMAKERS FIGHT LIMIT ON RADIO STATION'S HOURS
description: When the sun goes down, WJDM-AM goes silent, and two New Jersey lawmakers want to change that.

title: Stripping Furniture Requires Patience
description: LEAD: NO matter how many pieces you have coped with and how adept you have become, stripping furniture is surprisingly messy. It takes patience and perseverance, as well as strict adherence to the instructions on the stripping product.

title: Trade Surplus Up in Bonn
description: West Germany's foreign trade surplus rose in July as exports did very well despite the growing strength of the mark against the dollar.

title: Accord Reached to Set Northeast's Milk Prices
description: Higher prices for consumers and a more stable supply of milk will be produced by an agreement between New York dealers and a new Northeast regional dairy cooperative on fluid milk prices, officials predicted today.

title: At Last, a Solution To the Deficit
description: I have learned one thing from watching the one-minute lessons on television about the Constitution. The Framers were great compromisers. They had strong views, but they were willing to bend when necessary to establish ''a more perfect Union'' or, as we say in our household, ''a more nearly perfect union.''

title: Mine Iranian Waters
description: The United States has three options in the Persian Gulf: clear out, retaliate against Iran or stand there and let the Iranians pummel us.

title: 'Stakeout' in First Place In Week's Ticket Sales
description: ''Stakeout,'' a Walt Disney detective thriller starring Richard Dreyfuss, was the No. 1 movie at the box office last weekend, with $5.5 million in ticket sales.

title: Kayaker Killed by Powerboat Is Identified as Brooklyn Man
description: The victim of a boating accident last Sunday in Jamaica Bay has been identified by the police as Rodd Kreitner, 34 years old, of 1355 East 21st Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Emery Refinancing
description: The Emery Air Freight Corporation said it agreed to refinance the $129.9 million of bank debt it took on when it bought the Purolator Courier Corporation. It said it would raise $95 million through asset sales and other means and would get $45 million of pension fund assets by creating an employee stock ownership plan. Last month, Emery said it was not in compliance with the debt agreement to buy Purolator Courier.

title: Poetry in Motion
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has lined up a new round of poetry posters for bus riders in 11 cities.

title: ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEMS (DANISH, CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hyundai Account
description: The newly established Central Region Hyundai Dealer Advertising Association has selected Backer Spielvogel Bates, Chicago, to handle its projected $12 million budget. The agency is already responsible for the Western, Southern and Eastern Hyundai dealer advertising associations.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I live in a large new apartment building and for four months a peculiar green stain has appeared in my bathtub the day after it is scrubbed clean. This is not mold or mildew; a plumber and a laboratory have agreed that it is from oxidation of the copper pipes. They say it should have cleared up by now. Do you agree, and can it be harmful to me? A.In a new building green stains in a sink or tub are often caused by oxidation of copper pipes, particularly from soldered joints. They usually clear up in a few months, but can last a year or more because too much flux was used in soldering. In most cases they do go away eventually.

title: Court Supports Stanford
description: Stanford University won a temporary restraining order today against the National Collegiate Athletic Association's mandatory drug-testing program.

title: The Exotic World Of Handcrafted Jewelry
description: ALL is not glitter, all is not gold at the many galleries that feature craft jewelry. Instead, artists are using nontraditional materials - old photographs, tree bark or flattened nails -to create bracelets, pins and earrings. Even necklaces are fashioned of exotic materials. Pier Voulkos's bright marbleized beads are made of oven-baked plastic. Tina Fang Holder links black and brass safety pins to form a Cleopatra-style collar.

title: Philips Industries
description: Philips Industries of Dayton, Ohio, a leading manufacturer of building components, has agreed to acquire the Dearborn Fabrication and Engineering Company of Detroit, a manufacturer of materials-handling equipment. The contract, which must be approved by Philips's board, Dearborn's shareholders and Federal regulators, is for an undisclosed sum that would be paid in cash and notes. A Philips spokesman said the acquisition of Dearborn, with expected sales of $40 million in 1987, would diversify the income of Philips, which had sales of $593 million in 1986.

title: Farm Bank Bonds
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks announced interest rates of 6.95 percent for a $785 million issue of three-month bonds and 7.20 percent for $1.472 billion of six-month bonds. Both issues are offered at a price of 100 through various banks and securities dealers.

title: SHAKESPEARE, THE FIRE ISLAND WAY
description: The sudden summer showers may have disappointed many a beach bum today, but the downpour failed to keep Fire Island fans from packing the fire house for the Annual Fair Harbor Shakespeare Festival's opening day performance of ''As You Like It.''

title: Sears Cable Move
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, continuing its push into electronic retailing, said that it had signed an agreement with a cable television shopping subsidiary of the J. C. Penney Company to market a broad range of home products. Sears joins 30 other retailers in offering products on the unit, including Marshall Field & Company, Penney's and Spiegel Inc. The Telaction Corporation, the Penney subsidiary, said that it would begin programming in the Chicago area by the end of 1987.

title: STUFF YER FACE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.M. PLANT CLOSING SHAKES OHIO TOWN
description: The last car rolled off the assembly line today at the 64-year-old General Motors Corporation plant that is by far the biggest employer in this town of 26,000 people in southwestern Ohio.

title: DEERE & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest 9-month reflects the virtual shutdown of its U.S. factories, which resulted in a $193 million loss in the first quarter. The company also said the latest 9-month loss was magnified by its inability to currently reorganize approximately $41 million of income tax benefits associated with tax loss carryforwards. The third quarter income was favorably affected by a $15 million tax benefit derived primarily from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Kohl's Proposal to Scrap Missiles Draws a Cautious Soviet Response
description: The Soviet Union, evidently caught unaware by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's offer to scrap West Germany's medium-range missiles and clear the way for a superpower arms accord, reacted guardedly tonight by stressing that the West German leader had imposed ''preconditions.''

title: Advertising; The Raisin War Is Met By Yawns
description: A $100 MILLION lawsuit filed by the Kellogg Company against the General Foods Corporation and Grey Advertising Inc., charging that General Foods is misrepresenting the raisins in its breakfast cereals, seems not to have aroused much support among agencies.

title: REPH in Default
description: The REPH Acquisition Company, which bought the Republic Health Corporation last August, said that it was in default under certain bank credit agreements and was open to possible foreclosure proceedings. The company said that an extension previously granted by its lenders expired Tuesday and had not been renewed. REPH, which operates 64 health-care facilities in 21 states, said that it was working with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation as financial advisers in an attempted recapitalization.

title: Burials for Slain Britons
description: The first of the victims of Britain's worst mass murder was buried in a village graveyard today near the town where a gunman, Michael Ryan, shot and killed 15 people and then took his own life. Eric Vardy, a 51-year-old deliveryman, died at the wheel of his vehicle. Other victims were to be buried later this week. An appeal fund to aid victims and their relatives topped $320,000, with Queen Elizabeth II reportedly among the donors. No date has been announced for Mr. Ryan's funeral.

title: Tax Burden Continues To Climb, Regan Says
description: Despite the $2.5 billion cut in state taxes adopted this year, the percentage of New Yorkers' income going to pay income taxes continues to climb, the State Comptroller said today.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes gains from insurance claim proceeds of $72,000 and $1,036,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and a tax benefit of $1,050,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Tax Law Penalizes Older Adults Living Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
The Worm and the Apple: Rest and Restoration; Refashioning an Avenue
description: In its heyday, Eastern Parkway was the Champs-Elysees of Brooklyn, an elegant, tree-lined thoroughfare leading straight to the Grand Army Plaza arch by Prospect Park. Now a thoughtful, $58 million renovation project aims to restore the faded grandeur of this 2.2-mile city landmark.

title: Prince Charming Candidate: So Far, a Democratic Fable
description: The vote for President, the experts say, is the most personal one cast. So it is only natural that Americans want to fall in love a little bit with the leader they send to the White House.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $141,000 and $131,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CHILI'S INC reports earnings for Revenue
Trade Deficit Set Record in 2d Quarter
description: The nation's trade deficit swelled to a record of $39.5 billion in this year's second quarter as a tide of imports overtook a smaller increase in exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NBC AND STRIKERS CONTINUE TALKS
description: Negotiators for NBC and the union representing striking producers, writers and technicians met separately with Federal mediators for six hours today with neither side reporting progress toward settlement of the two-month-old strike against the network.

title: Shipyard Strike Nears End in Korea
description: A long and bitter shipyard strike appeared settled today, raising hopes that the passions and political tensions that have surrounded a striker's death might ease.

title: HERS
description: ALL my friends have sat in the cavernous brown office, avoiding eye contact, waiting for their names to be called:

title: Before You Sign Papers For a Room or a Locker
description: THERE are many considerations in selecting a space at a mini-storage warehouse. Here is a checklist: Choosing a Company Mini-storage warehouses are listed in the Yellow Pages under ''Warehouses - Self-Storage.'' In New York City, the industry is competitive, but rents vary in Manhattan, depending on where the warehouse is, and they tend to be lower in the four other boroughs. A visit to the prospective warehouse is recommended before signing a rental agreement. Estimating Size

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transportation Bonds Offered in Connecticut
description: A $100 million issue of Connecticut transportation revenue bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 4.40 percent in 1988 to 6.50 percent in 1997 and 7.60 percent in 2007 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend, declared by the Board of Directors on August 25, 1987.

title: Reagan Predicts Agreement Soon On Missile Cuts
description: President Reagan, citing West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's decision today to dismantle 72 Pershing 1A missiles in West Germany, predicted that ''we can wrap up an agreement on intermediate-range nuclear missiles quickly.''

title: SMUCKER, J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The U.N. Today: Aug. 27, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Loophole in Florida Gun Law Permits Some Public Display
description: An inadvertent omission in Florida's new laws requiring licenses for concealed weapons allows people to carry weapons openly in public without a license, the Dade County state attorney said today.

title: Rolling Stone Raising Its Florida Cover Price
description: Rolling Stone magazine said it would raise its cover price 25 cents, in the state of Florida only, beginning with its next issue. That issue is dated Sept. 24, but goes on sale Sept. 8. Rolling Stone said the increase was to compensate for revenues it lost when advertisers withdrew ads to protest Florida's new 5 percent tax on advertising and other services.

title: Columbia and N.Y.U. Add Business Teachers
description: Two of New York's prominent business schools have gone outside the academic community to find teachers.

title: 'CURRENTS' EXAMINES RUSH TO SUE FOR LIBEL
description: INCREASINGLY, polls say, the press is perceived as powerful and arrogant, operating under few, if any, restraints. The perception may not be entirely accurate, but one consequence seems to be an increase in the number of libel suits by people who say the press has been unfair. ''Currents,'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight, examines the phenomenon.

title: Marbella Journal; You Can't See the Sea for the Construction Cranes
description: One block from the main street and a few steps from the beach in this resort city, construction cranes seem to outnumber tourists.

title: Many Teachers Fail State Certification Tests
description: Despite the low requirements for passing, 17 percent of prospective public school teachers are failing the certification exams that about half the states now require of those applying for classroom jobs, a Federal report said today.

title: The Pledge
description: It will be one huge Pledge of Allegiance on Sept. 16 as President Reagan joins Senator Robert C. Byrd, Speaker of the House Jim Wright and other Congressional leaders, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, Cabinet members and thousands of schoolchildren in a recitation on the west steps of the Capitol at 1:30 P.M.

title: Sony's Profit Drops 59.2%
description: The Sony Corporation said today that its earnings fell 59.2 percent in its fiscal first quarter, ended June 30, as the steep rise of the yen and intensifying competition cut into sales abroad.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
FARAH INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Unusual Sentence Stirs Legal Dispute
description: An unusual sentence imposed on a child molester by a state judge here has evoked comparisons to Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''The Scarlet Letter'' and created a legal controversy over creative jurisprudence.

title: Who's in Town in August?
description: On a hot August night, the massive old apartment buildings on Central Park West are eerily dark. Across the park, doormen stand idly under the awnings of Fifth Avenue. The residents are in the Hamptons, or Connecticut, or Maine - wherever the summer people go.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing 2 Long Shots Win at Saratoga: Wanderkin and G'Day Mate, a pair of low-weighted long shots, scored upset victories in different styles to win divisions of the featured West Point Handicap for New York-breds yesterday at Saratoga. Wanderkin, a 4-year-old gelding by Dewan, led all the way and widened his lead through the stretch to score by five lengths over Smoke the Queen, with Patchy Groundfog a head back in third. Wanderkin, owned by the Poma Stable and trained by Richard O'Connell, paid $16.20 for $2 to win and ran the mile and a sixteenth on the grass in 1:41 1/5 under Richard Migliore while carrying 109 pounds. In the second division, G'Day Mate, ridden by Frank Lovato Jr., came from last place along the rail to score by three-quarters of a length over Mugatea and My Man John. G'Day Mate, a 4-year-old son of Darby Creek Road owned by Carolyn Chernick and trained by Thomas Miles, paid $13.60 and was timed in 1:42. Golf Medalist in U.S. Amateur: Scott Gump, a former University of Miami star who arrived only 15 minutes before his tee time yesterday, shot a two-under-par 70 to earn medalist honors at the 87th United States Amateur golf championship in Jupiter, Fla. Gump finished with a 36-hole qualifying total of three-under-par 141. The format switches to match play today with 64 players remaining in contention. (AP) Rowing 15 U.S. Entrants Advance: The United States rowing team yesterday advanced 15 of its 21 entrants to the semifinal and final rounds of the world rowing championships on Lake Bagsvaerd in the suburbs of Copenhagen. The men's lightweight squad was able to advance its eight-oared and double sculls entry to the final Sunday, while its single sculler, Glenn Florio, of Rye, N.Y., will race today in a semifinal heat. Anne Martin, the favorite in the lightweight women's sculling event, will also race in a semifinal today. Tennis Maleeva Sisters Are Impressive: The Maleeva sisters of Bulgaria, Manuela and Katerina, each scored impressive second-round victories yesterday and led the advance into the quarterfinals of the $150,000 United Jersey Bank Classic women's tennis championships at Ramapo College in Mahwah, N.J. Manuela Maleeva, seeded third, dominated the baseline duels in a 75-minute match that saw the 20-year-old defeat Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-1, 6-4. Katerina Maleeva, 18, won a second-round match between unseeded players in downing Jo Durie of Britain, 6-2, 6-3, in 55 minutes. Top-seeded Helena Sukova advanced with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Beverly Bowes. (AP) Lundgren Upsets Chesnokov: Peter Lundgren of Sweden upset No. 2-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday to gain the quarterfinals of the Nynex Open at the Rye Town Hilton. In other play, Thomas Muster of Austria beat Carl Linberter of Australia, 7-6, 6-2; Marty Davis of Harbor Isle Bay, Calif., beat Jorge Lozano of Mexico 6-2, 6-4, and Martin Flur of Durham, N.C., beat Gilad Bloom of Israel, 7-6, 6-0. (AP) Lendl Wins Easily in Hamlet: Ivan Lendl crushed Jay Berger, 6-0, 6-2, in 79 minutes last night in the first round of the $150,000 Hamlet Challenge Cup tennis tournament at Jericho, L.I. (AP) Little League No-Hitter for Garcia: Aron Garcia threw a no-hitter, drilled a two-run homer and finished with four hits and three runs batted in yesterday as Irvine, Calif., beat Dover, N.H., 13-0, in the Little League World Series at Williamsport, Pa. Irvine was scheduled to play Chesterfield, Ind., today in the semifinals. In another game yesterday, Moca of the Dominican Republic defeated Glace Bay of Nova Scotia, 6-4, to gain a semifinal meeting with Hua Lian of Taiwan. (AP)

title: Reported Air Mishaps Proliferate After 2 Incidents
description: Reports of aviation accidents and emergencies have proliferated in the wake of the Northwest Airlines disaster near Detroit and the close brush between President Reagan's helicopter and a private plane in California. But aviation experts do not believe these incidents represent a sudden decline in the level of air safety.

title: Edwards's Decision Doesn't Please All
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth hired Harry Edwards ostensibly to help find former black players for management jobs in baseball, but the black sociology professor has created a confrontation with a black charitable organization that could culminate in a fight between the players and the commissioner.

title: FILM: 'BACKLASH,' FROM AUSTRALIA
description: ''Backlash'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 13. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway at 66th Street. THE Australian film ''Backlash'' begins with a brief, crude sequence in which a young aboriginal woman is attacked by her employer, an older white man whom she proceeds to murder and emasculate (we are later told) with a garden shears. How will the film, which is the second dramatic feature by Bill Bennett, make use of this episode? As it turns out, the focus shifts quickly from the murder to the man-and-woman police team assigned to escort the accused woman to her trial. Once these three begin their journey together, the film shifts gears entirely and becomes an odd hybrid, a whimsical, eccentric road movie with an element of mystery.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc., Roseland, N.J., a computing services company, named as a director Charles Lazarus, chairman and chief executive officer of Toys ''R'' Us Inc.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Uneasiness on Fed and Dollar
description: Uneasiness about the future of the dollar and the possibility of a credit-tightening move by the Federal Reserve caused Treasury notes and bond prices to decline modestly yesterday.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-Net income Sales represent company operations sales.

title: Leach Is Found
description: Rick Leach, the Toronto Blue Jays player who had been missing since Tuesday night, was located yesterday at a Seattle airport hotel.

title: Ecuador Debt Rise
description: Ecuador's foreign debt will grow to $8.4 billion by the end of this year, from $8.1 billion at the end of 1986, Finance Minister Rodrigo Espinosa said. Mr. Espinosa said Tuesday that the National Development Council calculations that Ecuador's debt already totaled $8.7 billion and would grow to $9.8 billion by the end of the year were ''mistaken figures.'' Ecuador would honor its debt obligations and talks with creditors would begin as soon as the country resumed direct exports of crude oil, he said.

title: Aims of South Africa Miners Are Anti-U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $692,900,000 charge for increased loan provisions on third world debt for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A CUP OF COFFEE WITH MY INTERROGATOR: The Prague Chronicles of Ludvik Vaculik. Translated by George Theiner. Introduction by Vaclav Havel. 127 pages. Readers International. $14.95.
description: THE community of writers who are barred from publishing in their own countries is, alas, flourishing. Some have chosen or been forced into exile; more remain in their homelands, risking their freedom by distributing their work through an underground or spiriting it abroad.

title: China-Japan Trade Falls
description: Business between China and its biggest trade partner, Japan, has been falling, The China Daily said today. Trade fell to $8.58 billion in the first seven months of 1987, compared with $9.49 billion in the comparable period last year, the paper said, quoting official statistics. The drop in world oil prices and high Japanese import duties had slowed normal growth in trade, the paper quoted a Government official as saying. Japan, China's biggest trading partner, now accounts for one-sixth of China's total imports and exports, compared with one-quarter a few years ago, the official said.

title: Exemptions On Notification
description: The Senate measure on plant closings includes a number of exemptions to the requirement for advance notice.

title: Mall for South Bronx: Hope and Disbelief
description: From a terrace on East 159th Street in the South Bronx, Gigi Semidey pointed down at a nine-acre sunken lot, empty except for abandoned cars and a stretch of telephone poles. The lot, several blocks east of Yankee Stadium and once a busy railroad yard, is commonly referred to by nearby residents as ''the hole.''

title: Frying Pan Chairs And Biscuit Tin Settees
description: TOM DIXON is a designer from London who makes furniture and furnishings from salvaged scrap metal or new found objects, like plumbing parts. ''Three years ago, when I first learned how to weld, I went to scrapyards to look for bits of metal to practice with and to play with,'' said the 27-year-old Mr. Dixon, above. ''I looked for Victorian cast iron from fireplaces, coal hole covers, steel rods - anything with a pattern on it or a strong shape - and made over 100 chairs, because everybody needs to sit down.''

title: Who's Got the Buttons?
description: BRIGHT colored children's buttons shaped like pencils, Art Deco buttons made of plaster, elephant buttons made of ivory and brass: all these and more can be found at Tender Buttons, 143 East 62d Street in Manhattan.

title: Rivers Swell as Rains Return to Chicago Area
description: Volunteers frantically filled sandbags today, and overflow sewage and storm water was dumped into Lake Michigan as more rain raised swollen waterways in already flooded areas.

title: Stung by Shore's Pollution, Jersey Legislators Plan Bills
description: The series of pollution problems that became an unwelcome part of many summer vacations on the Jersey Shore this year inspired a round of tough new legislative proposals today.

title: N.F.L. Will Start; Lockout Is Unlikely
description: The National Football League will start its season on time Sept. 13 -even if it has to do so without a new contract to replace the one that expires next Monday.

title: Dodger Blunders Help Mets Win
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers once again last night gave something back to the city that spawned them and they spurned.

title: Suit Against Bonanno Family Called Innovative Use of Law
description: The civil complaint announced yesterday by Federal prosecutors against reputed members of the Bonanno crime family represents a broad and innovative application of the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, commonly known by its initials, RICO.

title: JAZZ: MURRAY QUARTET
description: DAVID MURRAY, whose music for octet and big band is widely admired, has quietly been developing his quartet into a group that can express the entire range of his musical sensibilities.

title: BOMBARDIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $4,441,000 for the quarter and $8,940,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $1,333,000 and $2,216,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Calendar of Events; Crafts and Antiques
description: Crafts Festival Fordham University Plaza, 62d Street at Columbus Avenue; 212-677-4627.

title: President's Hearing Hasn't Deteriorated, A Checkup Indicates
description: President Reagan had a thorough ear checkup today, and his doctor found no deterioration in his hearing, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said.

title: SUIT FILED TO BAR 'DANCING FOR LIFE' BENEFIT TITLE
description: Dancing for Life Inc., the producing organization for an Oct. 5 benefit at the New York State Theater to raise money for AIDS care, research and education, is being sued by Vital Options, a Los Angeles-based organization helping young adults with cancer.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $143,000 and $704,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and the quarter also includes a gain of $215,000 from bankruptcy proceedings. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $2,852,000 in connection with bankruptcy proceedings and a tax credit of $335,000 for both the quarter and 9 months; and the 9-month also includes a gain of $1,236,396 from the sale of assets.

title: THT LLYOD'S reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1 million for inventory and receivable writedowns.

title: Fortunes Can Turn On Quiz-Show Test
description: ANDY WARHOL'S theory of fame did not account for television game shows. It might not be 15 minutes of fame to which every person is entitled, but a full half-hour, including commercials.

title: COMPLAINT BY U.S. OVER LATIN PANEL
description: The United States said today that the leftist Government of Nicaragua had appointed mostly supporters to a national reconciliation commission and it was only paying lip service to the Latin American peace accord that established the panel.

title: Japanese Told to Love New York, Cautiously
description: As the Japanese Government sees it, New York City is a dangerous place, filled with muggers, con artists, thieves and cheats waiting to take advantage of unsuspecting visitors from Japan.

title: Three Postal Unions Ratify New Contracts
description: Members of three unions representing more than 600,000 employees of the United States Postal Service have ratified new contracts providing a 7 percent raise and cost-of-living adjustments over the next 40 months.

title: Waitz Withdraws
description: Grete Waitz, who won the women's marathon in the first world track and field championships at Helsinki in 1983, said yesterday she would not defend her title in Rome on Saturday. Waitz, a co-favorite with Rosa Mota of Portugal and Lisa Martin of Australia, injured her right foot nine days ago during a training run near her home in Oslo. She said the injury had not responded to treatment. The women's marathon and the men's shot-put are the only finals scheduled for Saturday, when the eight-day world championships begin in Rome's Olympic Stadium.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,120,000. c-After tax credits of $689,000 and $367,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: INSIDE
description: Nationwide Filipino Protest

title: Of Moonlit Porches, Childhood Secrets
description: LEAD: LAST fall we sold the old place.

title: 2 Asleep in Prospect Park Are Set Afire
description: Two people suffered burns yesterday morning after being set on fire as they slept in Prospect Park in Brooklyn, and the police said they were searching for five teen-agers seen by a man who awoke as liquid was being poured on him.

title: Bridge; At Far East Championships, 'Worthless' Card Had Value
description: Early in a bridge lifetime, players learn the general principles of discarding: keep your honor card guarded, discard useless small cards and try to maintain a length to match dummy.

title: Of Science and Sabotage
description: Maintenance workers at the Beltsville Agricultural Research Center repaired fences this week, and painters prepared to cover the slogans - ''Stop the Slaughter'' - sprayed in black on the cream-colored walls of an animal containment building.

title: Eugene Matthews, 61, Court of Claims Judge
description: Eugene T. Matthews, a State Court of Claims judge and acting State Supreme Court justice, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Syosset, L.I. He was 61 years old and also lived in Astoria, Queens.

title: Yankees Acquire Gullickson
description: Shuffling their roster in an effort to get themselves moving toward the top of the division again, the Yankees made two trades yesterday. They swapped pitchers with the Cincinnati Reds, Dennis Rasmussen for Bill Gullickson, and acquired Jerry Royster, a utility player, from their favorite trading partner, the Chicago White Sox.

title: Revised Terms Set In Minstar Deal
description: Minstar Inc.'s majority-owned Genmar Industries plans to absorb Minstar in a revised transaction valued at about $540 million to Minstar shareholders. The financier Irwin L. Jacobs, chairman of both companies, said that each Minstar common share would be exchanged for a combination of 0.75 share of the newly formed Genmar Holdings and, at the shareholder's option, either $23.50 in cash, $23.50 in face value of Minstar senior notes or any combination of cash and notes totaling that amount.

title: DANCE: 4 NEW WORKS BY KEITH YOUNG TROUPE
description: THE New York dance world lost an exceptional full-time performer when Keith Young left the Twyla Tharp company two years ago to strike out on his own as a choreographer. Mr. Young did not dance nearly enough in a program by Keith Young Dance, on Tuesday at the Kitchen. But Mr. Young's choreography, though still developing, did bear the marks of his intelligence and warmth as a dancer.

title: HAPPINESS IS A BEAT, 3 CHORDS AND GIBBERISH
description: LAST Saturday at Pier 84, Los Lobos played a strong set for an appreciative audience, then left the stage without playing the one song everyone expected to hear. ''Come on,'' a fan sighed in mock exasperation. ''Give us 'La Bamba,' you guys.'' His tone of voice said it all: he knew they were going to come back out and do ''La Bamba,'' and of course they did.

title: 2 ARE BLOCKED IN BRONX RACE FOR SURROGATE
description: The New York State Court of Appeals yesterday removed two candidates for Bronx surrogate from the Democratic primary ballot, leaving Lee L. Holzman, now the chief law assistant in the court, as the unopposed Democratic candidate.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 28, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 3 Die Inspecting Oil Rig
description: Three men died Wednesday after they passed out inside an oxygen-depleted ballast tank they were inspecting on an offshore oil rig, and three others were injured trying to rescue them, officials said. The rig is listed as being operated by the Marine Drilling Company of Corpus Christi. The company did not respond to several requests for comment.

title: Nicaraguan Contras Ask Reagan For Escrow Fund Linked to Talks
description: Leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels today asked President Reagan to seek Congressional approval for renewed military and non-lethal aid for the guerrillas, but to hold the military aid in escrow unless the Nicaraguan Government fails to comply with terms of a peace plan now being negotiated.

title: SHEEPSHEAD BAY PROJECT REVIVED AFTER SETBACK
description: A waterfront project in Sheepshead Bay that was suspended last year when the developer was caught up in the New York City corruption scandals was revived yesterday with the announcement of a new design for the project and a new company to build it.

title: Doris B. Nathan Wed To Thomas Friedman
description: The marriage of Doris B. Nathan, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Fritz Nathan of New York, to Thomas C. Friedman, the son of Stanley Friedman of Miami and the late Mrs. Friedman, took place yesterday in Manhattan. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at the home of Susan Halpern, a friend of the couple.

title: UNITED ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for 12mo July 31
TURTLES AID FIGHT AGAINST L.I. DEVELOPMENT
description: Apparently impervious to the occasional but persistent mosquitoes, Larry Penny looked fondly out over a three-acre pond here.

title: Art: Gallery Presents Painters of Bloomsbury
description: MOVE over ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty'': here comes the real thing, ''Bloomsbury.'' The story of this group may be short on serious money, but it is loaded - perhaps overloaded - with sex and good, if sometimes esoteric, dialogue, and, as such, qualifies as grand soap opera (we're talking public television, of course).

title: U.S. Is Seeking to Expand Testing of Students, State by State
description: The Department of Education, in a move intended to increase the accountability of state and local education officials, has proposed expanding the nation's program for testing student performance.

title: THE ENIGMATIC LIFE AND VIOLENT DEATH OF IRWIN SCHIFF
description: To those seeking to decipher the mystery of his violent death, Irwin Schiff has bequeathed an even more haunting legacy -the mystery of his life.

title: Georg Wittig, 90, Dies; Winner of Nobel Prize
description: Dr. Georg Wittig, a winner of the Nobel Prize for chemistry, died Wednesday in Heidelberg, West Germany. He was 90 years old.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS EXPRESS OPTIMISM AQUINO CAN DEAL WITH THE REBELS
description: State Department officials said tonight that the latest coup attempt in the Philippines came at a time when the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino seemed to be more stable than it has been at any time in recent months.

title: Film: 'Maid to Order,' Starring Ally Sheedy
description: IN ''Maid to Order,'' Ally Sheedy plays the kind of girl who's waited all her life to be told to clean up her room. She's cast as Jessie Montgomery, a world-class brat who's turned from an heiress into a maid by her fairy godmother (Beverly D'Angelo), and who benefits immeasurably from this transformation. Story ideas don't get much older than this, but ''Maid to Order'' -which opens today at the Sutton and other theaters - is fun anyhow. Everyone involved radiates real enthusiasm, Amy Jones's direction is buoyant, and Ally Sheedy looks great in a uniform.

title: MYLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ex-Speaker O'Neill: A Salty Par for the Course
description: Tip O'Neill's golf swing is coming in these days. He smacks the ball 175 yards off the tee, hits 150-yard fairway woods, has a good short game and, if his putting improved, would shoot even lower than his present score, in the low 90's.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''WHO expected such big goings-on?'' a surprised and dressed-down Beverly Sills was asking Monday night outside the Baronet Theater on the Upper East Side. ''I thought Muffy and I were invited to a simple screening.''

title: MOLITOR REFLECTS ON STREAK
description: The day after he stopped Paul Molitor's hitting streak at 39 games, John Farrell, the Cleveland Indians' rookie pitcher, wanted more than just memories of what had been for him a fantastic week.

title: Chrysler Price Cut
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would cut the price of two car models by $1,369 in an effort to increase sales. The 1988 Plymouth Reliant and Dodge Aries, twins that are derived from the K-car family, would have a suggested base price of $6,995, compared with $8,364 for comparably equipped 1987 models. Gerald Greenwald, chairman of Chrysler Motors, compared the discounts to a similar discount offered a year ago for the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon. That offer produced an 86 percent increase in sales in four months over year-earlier figures.

title: City Opera: 'Desert Song' Cast Shifts
description: A CAST change Wednesday evening in the New York City Opera's production of ''The Desert Song'' at the New York State Theater placed different singers in four principal roles. Jane Thorngren made her City Opera debut as Margot Bonvalet, the love interest of both Capt. Paul Fontaine (Cris Groenendaal) and Pierre Birabeau (William Parcher). John Stewart was Sid El Kar, the Red Shadow's stalwart sidekick.

title: LOWE'S COS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Suit Challenges Crazy Eddie
description: Entertainment Marketing Inc., which has threatened a proxy fight for control of Crazy Eddie Inc., filed a lawsuit in Delaware State Court today asking that Crazy Eddie be forced to hold its annual meeting. A spokesman for Crazy

title: Shelly Belfer Marries Anthony Malkin
description: Rachelle Lisa Belfer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Belfer of New York, and Anthony Edward Malkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Malkin of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Film: John Sayles's 'Matewan'
description: TAKING as his source material an especially bitter and bloody confrontation between West Virginia coal miners and the company that owned their souls in 1920, John Sayles has made a film with the sweetness and simplicity of an Appalachian ballad.

title: Tokyo Imperial Palace Is Hit By Five Homemade Rockets
description: At least five homemade rockets were fired into the Imperial Palace complex in Tokyo today, the police said.

title: CROWLEY MILNER GRP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Giants' Backs Run Deep
description: The Giants have so many good running backs that they don't know how many to keep.

title: Soviet Reports Near-Collision
description: A Soviet airline pilot has reported that his plane nearly collided with an American jet fighter over New York City. An American official said today that there was no evidence of the incident but refused to discount it.

title: CSM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Quadrex President Takes Kidder Post
description: John M. Liftin, president of the Quadrex Securities Corporation, will be joining Kidder, Peabody & Company as senior vice president and general counsel. The position is particularly sensitive since Kidder was rocked by an embarrassing insider-trading scandal last year, not long after it was taken over by the General Electric Company.

title: Article 621487 -- No Title
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had awarded the American Telephone and Telegraph Company a $300 million contract to design and install a telephone network that would connect the company's 700 facilities around the nation into one of the largest private phone systems in the country.

title: HINTS PACT IS NEAR
description: The Soviet Union today welcomed the offer by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to dismantle 72 medium-range nuclear missiles in West Germany if Moscow and Washington agree to scrap all medium- and shorter-range rockets.

title: 'Reno and Yolanda,' Comedy, on CBS
description: ''Reno and Yolanda,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight, isn't much, but credit it with an original, or almost original, idea: the protagonists are a ballroom dance team in Atlantic City, giving lessons in a studio in the Four Aces Hotel. Astaire and Rogers, however, they are not. Indeed, except for a brief tango, they don't dance at all. That's too bad; Terpsichore might have helped. ''Reno and Yolanda'' is particularly limp.

title: Lazard Building a Fund For Takeover Defenses
description: Lazard Freres & Company is trying to raise $2 billion to make minority investments that would aid companies that might be a target of hostile takeovers.

title: Drugs-for-Guns Cycle Produces Bitter Ironies
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: THE darkened windows along a shabby stretch of Ninth Avenue belie the fantasy world that awaits within. You enter the dining room at Jezebel and find yourself in a vast and marvelously cluttered expanse, a cross between a leafy nightclub and a vintage clothing boutique.

title: No Clear Sailing
description: LEAD: eports of the death of a sculler whose 12-foot racing shell was run over on Sunday by a powerboat on Jamaica Bay prompted two personal reactions: sympathy for the athlete, who probably never knew what hit him, and surprise that such tragedies aren't happening almost routinely on America's bays, lakes and rivers.

title: Ivy League Notes
description: To the Editor:

title: Royals Dismiss Gardner
description: Billy Gardner, who was named to replace the ailing Dick Howser during spring training, was dismissed today as manager of the Kansas City Royals. He was replaced by John Wathan, manager of the Royals' Class AAA farm team at Omaha and a former Kansas City catcher.

title: New Face; Moving Up To 'Pretty' Roles: Jennifer Grey
description: For seven years Hollywood considered Jennifer Grey an ugly duckling. In July, it reclassified her as a swan.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 20,000 Dismissed at Mines; Pretoria Curbs Press Again
description: South Africa's largest mine owner dismissed 20,000 striking black miners today in response to the rejection Wednesday by leaders of 300,000 strikers of the employers' latest offer.

title: CUCOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago quarter and year losses includes non- recurring after-tax charges of $1,131,853, and 62 cents a share, respectively. The company did not report the full dollar figure for the prior year charge.

title: U.S. Calls For Mild Curbs for Gene Expert Who Defied Rules
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued mild sanctions today against a researcher who conducted unauthorized experiments with a genetically altered microbe.

title: FLOATING POINT SYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9-month losses include restructuring expenses of $8.1 million which primarily were related to the closure of the company's Ireland manufacturing facility.

title: J. David Case: Damages Set
description: A law firm that advised the now-collapsed investment firm of J. David & Company was ordered to pay five elderly investors nearly $1 million in actual and punitive damages.

title: SCAN-TRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bradley, in Soft Tones, Reproaches Russians
description: A speech on Soviet-American relations here today by Senator Bill Bradley, delivered in gentle tones but packed with stern criticism of many Soviet policies, left the Soviet listeners in his audience unsure how to respond.

title: CHARGES AGAINST RADIO 'PIRATES' ARE DROPPED
description: Federal authorities dropped charges yesterday against two men who had operated an unlicensed, ''pirate'' radio station broadcasting rock music from a ship four and a half miles off Long Beach, L.I.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SUMMERGARDEN FINALE Summergarden, the Museum of Modern Art's free outdoor concert series presented amid works by some of this century's greatest sculptors, ends its 12th summer season this weekend with performances tonight and tomorrow at 7:30. The program features the American premiere of Josef Matthias Hauer's 1936 work ''Dance Suite No. 2, Opus 71'' and John Cage's 1951 ''16 Dances.'' The pieces will be performed by past and present Juilliard School students, under the direction of Paul Zukofsky. The entrance to the museum's Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden is at 14 West 54th Street, and the garden's gates open at 6 P.M. Information: 708-9480. SNOW ON THE EAST RIVER

title: Senator Proxmire Bars Race in 1988
description: Senator William Proxmire, who gained renown as a critic of wasteful Government spending in his 30-year career, announced today that he would not seek office again in 1988.

title: EYE CARE CENTERS OF AMER INC reports earnings for Year to June 27
description: As reported, Sears, Roebuck & Co. has agreed to acquire the company.

title: Three Miles for Charity
description: Faster than a bill becoming law, quicker than a court ruling, swifter than an interagency memo, the three branches of Government are entering a foot race.

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Decision on Gross
description: A hearing on an appeal by Kevin Gross of a 10-day suspension for having sandpaper in his glove while pitching for Philadelphia was adjourned after four hours yesterday, and no decision was announced.

title: Problems Delay Test of Rocket For the Shuttle
description: A series of electronic problems and a leaky firehose forced postponement today of the first test firing of the space shuttle's redesigned booster rockets.

title: That North Video
description: How's this for a new title at the local video store? ''The Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North Slide Show.'' At public hearings on the Iran-contra affair, Colonel North was denied permission to show the Congressional committees the slides he had used to promote the Nicaraguan rebels at meetings with conservative donors.

title: Amateur Takes Lead in Women's Final
description: Kay Cockerill, an amateur, eagled the 16th hole with a 35-foot putt and birdied the 17th as she shot a three-under-par 69 today to take a one-shot lead in the first round of the World Championship of Women's Golf, which has a field of only 12 golfers.

title: 2 Groups in the Park
description: The Chelsea Percussion Ensemble and the Manhattan Marimba Quartet will perform music by Daniel Levitan, Larry Lockwood, Steven Reich, Villa-Lobos and others tomorrow afternoon at 3 P.M. at the Central Park Band Shell, near 72d Street. The concert is free. Information: 860-1335.

title: Economic Scene; Unique Asset: The U.S. Dollar
description: THE swelling of the United States trade deficit to an all-time high of $39.5 billion in the second quarter, after a first-quarter shortfall of $38.8 billion, has set off alarms that the Administration policy of cutting the dollar's value has failed.

title: MILTON BEARDS
description: Milton Beards, a retired importer of women's scarves and other fashion accessories, died Monday of a bacterial infection at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Korean Official Warns Against Leftist Unrest
description: Prime Minister Kim Chung Yul warned today that leftist forces were trying to use labor unrest to stage a violent revolution and said any attempt to disrupt national stability would be crushed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 28, 1987
description: International A2-9, A17

title: The Minds of Mario
description: Mario Cuomo certainly can make a beautiful speech. He did again the other day, talking about Soviet-American relations, a speech full of hope and emotions about the future, soaring above doubt and detail.

title: Jaffna Journal; Fight Is Over for Tigers, and the Dream Recedes
description: The downtown street bazaars here are teeming nowadays with crowds of shoppers, and the air rings constantly with loud bangs. For the first time in years, nobody jumps at the noise.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 28, 1987
description: Markets

title: Boxer Arrested
description: Mitch Green, the 30-year-old heavyweight who lost a bout to Mike Tyson last year, was arrested in Harlem last night and charged with driving without a valid license and with possession of a controlled substance, PCP, or angle dust. A police spokesman said Green was stopped at 124th Street and Seventh Avenue after he was seen driving while watching a small television set that was on the dashboard of his car. Records showed that his license had been suspended 54 times, the spokesman said.

title: Graffiti, Hirschfeld 5 and Czeslaw Slania
description: Horrified that there might be microscopic graffiti on postage stamps, the Bureau of Engraving announces sternly that it will review 500 issues of the last 10 years to look for secret signs on dies from which its stamps were printed. The practical effect will probably be as hard to see as the graffiti. Trying to stamp out this sort of thing is like trying to stamp out human nature.

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Fleshtones, the Lone Star Cafe, Fifth Avenue at 13th Street (242-1664). The Fleshtones never seem to play at anything less than peak intensity, which gives their shows a bracing rock-and-roll jolt that even their best recordings never quite deliver. They are playing their stylistically omnivorous, guitar-driven riff-rock tonight and tomorrow night, with shows beginning around 9:30 and 11:30. Admission is $12, with a minimum of two drinks or dinner at tables.

title: New Armour President
description: John R. Miller has been named president of the Armour Food Company, a unit of Conagra Inc. Conagra said that Mr. Miller has been president and chief executive of E. A. Miller Inc. since 1981. Armour is a processor, marketer and distributor of branded, processed meats including hot dogs, bacon, ham, sausage and lunch meat. E. A. Miller is a Conagra company, based in Hyrum, Utah, that produces premium boxed beef.

title: Koch Hurts Head in a Fall
description: With a red bump on his forehead, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he suffered the injury when he slipped on a rug in the bathroom in the dark and fell, hitting his head on the floor.

title: Back to New York
description: John H. Carley, one of a handful of New York lawyers who came to Washington to work for the Reagan Administration in 1981, is resigning as general counsel of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: 'HAMBURGER HILL,' ON A PLATOON IN VIETNAM
description: NO movie is simply what's on the screen. Much of what we see is what we bring into the theater. American critics saw ''Platoon'' as antiwar. When it was shown at Cannes last year, European critics, especially the French, read it as a glorification of American jingoism.

title: Appeals Court Voids Minnesota's Limits On Minors' Abortion
description: A Federal appeals court today struck down a Minnesota law that required women under 18 years old either to notify both parents or to obtain judicial approval before getting abortions.

title: IVY LEAGUE NOTES
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmental Groups Seek To Curb Offshore Oil Plan
description: Nine environmental groups filed a lawsuit today against the Interior Department's five-year plan for opening millions of acres of the outer continental shelf for oil and gas exploration.

title: Mets Counting on Pitchers, Ready or Not
description: Even Dwight Gooden admitted it yesterday before the Mets flew to San Francisco for their most dangerous trip of the season: When you restore three pitchers to your five-man rotation with only five weeks to go, there is no room for error.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: DOYERS STREET in Chinatown is a clogged little urban artery, barely more than an alley arching between Pell Street and Bowery, that you would never find unless highly motivated to do so. One reason to search it out is a humble subterranean restaurant at No. 11 that produces some of the most authentically delicious Vietnamese food I have found in New York City. Called Vietnam Restaurant, it is a clean and gregarious little place run by a friendly young crew of blue-jean-clad waiters.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Opinions differed on Liberace's musical talents, but the pianist and showman had few equals when it came to shopping.

title: M.T.A.'S STAFF URGES A BAN ON SMOKING ABOARD TRAINS
description: The staff of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has recommended that smoking be banned on all Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North commuter trains.

title: A GROUP LOVES NEW YORK, AND CLEANS IT
description: Along a stretch of the Long Island Rail Road in Brooklyn, nine young people toiled in a driving rain yesterday removing a varied collection of car parts, mattresses, tires and just plain trash from the tracks.

title: NEW GUY IN TOWN
description: No brass bands, no red carpets, no streams of confetti greeted Jerry Royster as he entered Yankee Stadium on the gray morning yesterday. He came in alone and quietly, as a veteran utility player might, and as one might expect Royster to do.

title: Ex-Air Force Sergeant Gets 5 Years for Spying
description: Allen John Davies, a former Air Force sergeant, was sentenced to five years in prison today for a bungled attempt to relay secret information about Warsaw Pact military preparedness to a man he thought was a Soviet agent.

title: Express Buses Are Manhattan's Big Polluters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Soviet Voice Of Innovation Comes to Force
description: Cloistered in a research institute in Siberia, a Soviet economist whose views were once considered too radical for public consumption has been openly challenging some of the fundamental principles on which Soviet society and the economy have been based for years.

title: Juror, After 3 1/2 Years, Sent Home as Biased
