description: A single-engine plane exploded over a residential area here yesterday, killing the pilot and showering dozens of homes with huge chunks of debris. No one on the ground was injured. The pilot, who has yet to be positively identified, had been flying alone from Teterboro Airport in New Jersey and was bound for Quebec, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Richard M. Montgomery, 75; Retired General of Air Force
description: Richard M. Montgomery, a retired lieutenant general of the Air Force who was a chief of staff of the Strategic Air Command in the 1950's, died at the Heritage Park Skilled Care Center in Bradenton, Fla., Thursday, of complications after neurosurgery. He was 75 years old.

title: N.F.L. Seeks More Talks
description: Fourteen days after their last meeting, the National Football League asked the Players Association yesterday to resume talks to replace the contract that expires on Monday. However, the head of the union, Gene Upshaw, is unlikely to respond until after a strike date is set at an association meeting on Monday.

title: Panel Urges Closer Look at Safety At Nuclear Plant in Washington
description: The Government might not be able to prevent a hydrogen explosion if a major accident occurs at a nuclear plant here that resembles the Soviet Union's Chernobyl reactor, according to a study made public Thursday.

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 8
description: b-Includes a special gain of $4,023,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Not the First Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Peter Vogel Is Dead; Pediatric Blood Expert
description: Dr. Peter Vogel, clinical professor of medicine emeritus at Mount Sinai Medical Center and a pioneer in hemolytic transfusions of the newborn to overcome the ''blue baby'' problem, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: I.B.M. ENDS INTEL FINANCIAL SUPPORT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation essentially ended its financial relationship with the Intel Corporation today, selling 5.9 million shares of stock in the company that it has held since late 1982.

title: CARTER, GLADMAN WAIT FOR ANSWERS
description: Whether Cris Carter and Charles Gladman will be playing college or professional football this season remained uncertain yesterday as lawyers and college officials discussed their options regarding the athletes' college eligibility.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11. 1. Militant animal-rights advocates stole animals, including 11 cats infected with a harmful parasite, from the Government's premier farm research center at Beltsville, Md. 2. That the Kuwaiti tankers could be protected without increasing the American naval presence in the gulf, which then numbered four vessels. 3. Mayor Koch said that he and John Cardinal O'Connor, his co-author of ''His Eminence and Hizzoner,'' would accept an offer to publish the book from the Hearst Corporation, which agreed to donate its profits from the venture to the charities that will also receive their royalties. 4. T. Allan McArtor, the new F.A.A. Administrator, called together some of the country's senior airline pilots to urge them to renew their commitment to ''vigilance in the cockpit'' against disastrous mistakes. 5. Because the President's influence on Capitol Hill has markedly declined, he may try to bypass Congress by shifting his focus from goals requiring legislation to goals that can be put into effect using regulations and executive orders. 6. The Brazilian men's basketball team upset the United States squad in the final, 120-115, marking only the second time the United States has failed to win the basketball gold since the games began in 1951. 7. President Kennedy was prepared to withdraw obsolete American missiles from Turkey in exchange for a Soviet pullout of its missiles from Cuba. 8. It enabled Federal prosecutors to apply the civil provisions of the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, known as RICO, directly against an organized-crime family. 9. Each nation held news conferences to promote its views. 10. They will be inducted into the Poets' Corner in the arts bay of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City. 11. The showing of films on Friday night, which Orthodox Jews consider a desecration of the Sabbath. 12. ''Light care'' patients are not profitable because, under a state plan, the more care a Medicaid patient requires, the larger the reimbursement the nursing home receives. 13. A warning sign that must be posted on the criminal's front door, saying in letters no less than three inches high, ''DANGEROUS SEX OFFENDER NO CHILDREN ALLOWED.'' 14. The Chancellor's proposal to dismantle 72 medium-range nuclear missiles in West Germany is contingent on an agreement by Moscow and Washington to scrap all their medium- and short-range nuclear missiles. 15. Federal appellate courts in Atlanta and Cincinnati ruled in favor of textbooks that the parents said had promoted godless, humanistic religion.

title: Koch Appoints His First Deputy To Succeed Him
description: Mayor Koch has decided to designate First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff to take over for him should a disability temporarily prevent him from performing his duties.

title: Rising Militancy Is Seen In Iran's Foreign Policy
description: Diplomats stationed in Iran say they detect an increasingly militant and confrontational foreign policy amid the often conflicting public pronouncements and actions of the Teheran leadership.

title: Saudis Pledge To Demolish Iran 'Monster'
description: The Saudi strategist, deeply knowledgeable about the affairs of the monarchy, showed a look of pure pleasure as he talked of the Iranian regime as a ''monster'' and of his own nation as at last shedding its image of being ''wimpy.''

title: 50 Lost in Ganges Sinking
description: More than 50 people were believed drowned when a boat sank in the Ganges River in the eastern Indian state of Bihar, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: SKYLINE CHILI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Bridge; Organizers of Split Regional Communicated From Afar
description: Communications are not usually a problem for tournament organizers, but the unusual Split Regional, in progress this weekend in Parsippany, N.J., and Albany, is an exception.

title: The Double Out
description: LEAD: You have probably heard of the Double Bind - that vise-like entrapment in adverse circumstances (a ''Catch-22'') - but have you heard of its opposite, the Double Out?

title: Corrections
description: A calendar of crafts and antiques shows in The Home Section on Thursday gave an incorrect address for Baldwin Studio Potters. It is at 534 La Guardia Place.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Grows
description: Japan's trade surplus climbed to $7.68 billion in July, from $6.88 billion in June, but the sudden jump did not budge economists from their optimism that the nation's trade figures were moving closer into balance.

title: John Huston, Film Director, Writer and Actor, Dies at 81
description: John Huston, the legendary director and scenarist who made such classic films as ''The Maltese Falcon,'' ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' ''The Asphalt Jungle'' and ''The African Queen,'' died yesterday in Middletown, R.I., at the age of 81. Associates said he had died in his sleep of complications from emphysema.

title: Rock: Roger Waters Sings of Political Despair
description: Roger Waters had a double agenda for his concert Wednesday at Madison Square Garden. He wanted to warn, in no uncertain terms, of the dangers of unbridled militarism and mindless consumption. And he wanted to reclaim an audience that's rightfully his: the fans of Pink Floyd, most of whose songs were written by Mr. Waters.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Epic Sues WHTZ-FM Over a Release Date
description: Radio Station WHTZ-FM, also known as Z-100, has been sued by Epic Records for playing a single from Michael Jackson's new album before the official debut date.

title: Loss at Toronto Bank
description: Toronto Dominion Bank has reported a third-quarter loss of $325.2 million (Canadian), or $247.1 million (American), primarily because of a large increase in reserves for possible losses on loans to third world countries. However, the bank, Canada's fifth largest ranked by assets, said it expected to report a profit for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 because of ''exceptionally strong'' growth in underlying earnings. Toronto Dominion said it took a one-time extraordinary charge of $475 million ($361 million) from an increase in reserves for third world loans to 40 percent, or $1.04 billion ($788 million), from 15 percent.

title: Trudeau Returns, and the Reception Is Mixed
description: ''Maybe I am passe,'' said Pierre Elliott Trudeau, an edge of sarcasm in his voice as he gazed across the hearing room at an old parliamentary foe. ''Maybe there is a new Canada now.''

title: Eruption That Destroyed Thera Left Crete's Civilization Intact; Theory Also Exploded
description: To the Editor:

title: FINDING A NURSING HOME: SOME GUIDELINES
description: Prospective patients and their families who are confronting the task of choosing the right nursing home face a maze of problems. In most cases they are reluctant to take the step, and frightened.

title: 16-Year-Old Charged In Her Mother's Death
description: A 16-year-old girl was arrested today, along with two other teen-agers, in connection with the slaying of the girl's 47-year-old mother, Joyce Aparo, the state police said.

title: Kodak-Fuji Rivalry Over Business Takes An Academic Turn
description: Like many American corporate giants, the Eastman Kodak Company battles its Japanese competitors in whatever marketplace they meet. Kodak recently carried that fight over to the university campus.

title: Koch Angered By Response To 2 Burnings
description: Comparing the burning of a young couple in Prospect Park to the Howard Beach assault, Mayor Koch expressed shock yesterday at ''the lack of outrage'' being voiced about the park attack by the city's religious and civic leaders.

title: FORMER AIDE TESTS PROSECUTOR LAW
description: The authority of the special prosecutor in the 1983 Environmental Protection Agency scandal has been challenged by a former Justice Department official, according to Federal sources.

title: ADT TAKES RAISED BID FROM HAWLEY OF BRITAIN
description: ADT Inc., the nation's leading supplier of fire and burglar alarms, yesterday accepted a $52-a-share takeover offer, worth $715 million, from Britain's Hawley Group Ltd.

title: Gale G. Moscow Wed To a Fellow Lawyer
description: Gale Gwiazdowski Moscow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Gwiazdowski of Norwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James R. Scala, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Scala of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Judge Phyllis Gangel Jacobs of New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony in her chambers in Manhattan.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THEODORE ISRAEL
description: Theodore Israel, a violist and music teacher, died of a ruptured aorta Thursday at New York Hospitaly. He was 60 years old and was a resident of Manhattan and Port Washington, L.I.

title: OPEC Sessions Put Off
description: Meetings of two OPEC committees that monitor world oil prices and the group's oil production have been put off for three days until Sept. 10, the OPEC press agency said today.

title: Reagan, Lobbying for Bork, Calls Judge Tough on Crime
description: President Reagan opened a lobbying effort today on behalf of the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, saying that Judge Bork would ''take a tough, clear-eyed look'' at crime issues.

title:
PATENTS;
I.B.M. Spelling Checker
description: LEAD: A typewriter spelling-verification system that notifies the operator immediately if a word is misspelled was patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation. The system has been incorporated in two typewriters, the Wheelwriter and the Quietwriter, made by I.B.M. in Lexington, Ky.

title: U.S. Cigarette Use Dips
description: Americans smoked 584 billion cigarettes last year, 1.7 percent fewer than in 1985 and a 9 percent drop from the historical high of 640 billion in 1981, the Agriculture Department said. At the same time, cigarette exports rose sharply, the department said. The department attributed the decline in consumption to prices driven higher by rising state and local taxes and manufacturers' costs, heightened anti-smoking campaigns and a tightening of smoking restrictions.

title: Congress Is Playing Games With the Civil Rights Commission
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch from Buenos Aires on Monday about the coming Argentine elections incorrectly named the last Argentine president from the Radical Party. The president was Dr. Arturo Illia, who was overthrown in a coup in 1966.

title: THE BIG GAME IS NOT SO BIG FOR GIANTS
description: Almost two decades ago, when the Giants represented the establishment and the Jets were brash intruders, the annual exhibition game between the teams captivated New York City and the suburbs. Now, for the Giants, the game Saturday night against the Jets is merely the third of four exhibition contests that prepare each team for the games that count.

title: Recalling the Early Days at the Schomburg Center, a Harlem Cultural Hub
description: Howard Dodson paused to find the right key before unlocking the door to a white, four-story stone building at 103 West 135th Street in Harlem. He walked quietly through a cluttered room, past dusty library carrels, empty shelves and similar reminders of the building's disuse.

title: Browns Sign 1, Drop 1
description: The Cleveland Browns said hello to one veteran and goodbye to another yesterday as the team finally came to terms with its Pro Bowl offensive tackle, Cody Risien, and waived Curtis Weathers, a linebacker.

title: A Latin Enclave
description: GOING TO MIAMI. Exiles, Tourists, and Refugees in the New America. By David Rieff. 230 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: TV: STRAVINSKY'S 'FLOOD,' ON 13
description: In 1959, when the Nielsens did not yet reign over all and things were different at the commercial networks, CBS commissioned Stravinsky to compose a piece for television. During a trip a year later to Venice, which had been overrun by a flood, the composer decided on his subject and, with the help of his assistant, Robert Craft, completed the work by March 1962.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $895,000, or 11 cents a share, on sale of land, for which no income taxes were provided because of capital loss offsets.

title: TOLL AT 19 KILLED, 249 HURT
description: In a day of street fighting and air attacks, forces loyal to the Government on Friday crushed the most serious assault yet on the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Major Events in Philippines Coup Attempt
description: The revolt by dissident soldiers against the Philippine Government began shortly after midnight Friday morning (shortly after noon Thursday, New York time) with raids on several targets. Here are the major events in the hours that followed.

title: Saying No to Bilingual Education
description: Members of the teachers' union in Los Angeles voted recently to seek abolition of so-called transitional bilingual education in the city's schools. The vote delighted supporters of California's strong English-first movement. Opponents, particularly Hispanic teachers, were distressed at what seemed like xenophobia on the part of the majority of teachers. In fact, the vote reflects a potentially healthy step forward in this complex debate.

title: 29 Accused of Welfare Fraud; 12 Are Government Workers
description: A welfare-fraud investigation has led to charges against 29 people, including 11 Federal employees and a state worker, for allegedly collecting welfare payments while holding full-time jobs.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Reebok Forecast Sends Stock Down
description: The stock of Reebok International Ltd. dropped sharply today after the athletic shoemaker said it would post only marginal profit increases in the third quarter because of production delays in South Korea. Reebok's shares closed down $1.375, to $21, on the New York Stock Exchange. Reebook said that about two-thirds of its shoe production comes from South Korea. ''As a result,'' it said, ''per-share earnings for the third quarter are expected to be only slightly higher'' than the 42 cents a share earned in last year's third quarter.

title: NEW YORK EXPANDS TREATMENT POLICY FOR THE HOMELESS
description: New York City will hospitalize mentally ill homeless people involuntarily if they are deemed ''incapable of taking care of themselves,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Whose Realism About the Russians?
description: This was a week in which a fall summit meeting looked likelier by the day, and it rang with speeches about U.S.-Soviet relations. Addressing Russians and Americans gathered in Chautauqua, Governor Cuomo of New York, President Reagan and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey gave the topic very different turns. Yet their speeches all made one compelling point.

title: Slum in Atlantic City Is Set for Renewal
description: After years of delay, city officials and residents of the blighted Northeast Inlet section believe the stage is finally set for redevelopment on the grand scale envisioned by the 1977 legislation permitting casinos to open here.

title: New Car for Ford
description: A two-door Ford coupe to be manufactured at the Mazda Motor Manufacturing Corporation's plant near Detroit will be called the Probe, officials for the Ford Motor Company said. The vehicle will be sold by Ford dealers beginning in the spring of 1988. The car was at one time seen as the replacement for Ford's Mustang, but there was resistance to giving the Mustang name to a car assembled in a Japanese-owned plant, The Detroit Free Press reported. The auto plant starts production of Mazda vehicles on Tuesday. About 60 percent of Mazda's production will be sold to Ford, which owns 25 percent of Mazda's stock.

title: LENDL, CASH LOSE IN OPEN WARM-UP
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and third-seeded Pat Cash were defeated in upsets today in the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Hamlet Challenge Cup.

title: SIGMA DESIGNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Cancer Study Annnounced For Stadium
description: State officials said today that they would commission a comprehensive environmental study of the Meadowlands sports complex and its surroundings in an effort to allay fears that there are cancer-causing elements in the area.

title: 24 Sea Otters Get New Home
description: Two dozen sea otters have arrived at their new home under a Federal program to re-establish the species in Southern California, officials say. The otters, captured earlier this week off California's central coast, were flown in a chartered cargo plane to San Nicolas Island on Thursday. They are the first of 70 that will be moved to the island, which is 75 miles southwest of Los Angeles, in an effort to establish a second otter colony in case an oil spill or disease wipes out the central population.

title: PARLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE LONG AND SHORT OF FURS
description: THE woman had a problem, one shared by many women who bought new fur coats last year. ''My mink coat is down to my ankles,'' she said. ''Now there's all this talk about short skirts. Do I have to cut thousands of dollars' worth of fur off the bottom of my coat?''

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,581,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,682,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $209,000 and $307,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Greece at Peace With Albania
description: Greece has lifted a technical state of war that has existed with Albania since 1945, a Government spokesman said today. Diplomatic relations between the two nations were established in 1971.

title: For Vietnam's Catholic Church, a Modest Revival
description: The clamor of a basketball match that shatters the afternoon calm of a cloister in St. Joseph's Seminary is, in a sense, the sound of a modest religious revival. The young men at play are student priests.

title: Patricia W. de Blank And John Klink Wed
description: The marriage of Patricia Wallace de Blank and John Michael Klink took place yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Montecito, Calif. Archbishop Renato Martino, permanent observer of the Holy See to the United Nations, and the Rev. James Burke performed the ceremony.

title: GUNNAR H. BERG
description: Gunnar H. Berg, a former national director of the Boy Scouts of America, died yesterday at Dover General Hospital, Dover, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Lake Telemark, N.J.

title: In Chinatown, Therapy Sessions Help Troubled Youths
description: Young Tai-Hong Lee was descending into mental illness when school officials referred him to the Chinatown Family Consultation Center three years ago. At home the muscular, hyperactive boy had thrown tantrums and kicked in doors. At school he had insulted students and staff with foul language.

title: GOODEN STRONG; JOHNSON HOMER IN 4-0 VICTORY
description: The Mets opened a nine-game trip to the West Coast tonight with a 4-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants, and did it with two smashing elements: a four-hit pitching performance by Dwight Gooden and a monster home run by Howard Johnson.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The reason why we are doing this is the sad plight of the soldiers and the policemen.''

title: A BLACK FIRM'S WALL ST. RISE
description: There's another Lazard in Wall Street these days.

title: Bond Prices Move Downward
description: The tenor of the Treasury market continued to be very negative yesterday, with bond prices falling half a point or more.

title: Posing as Officers, 2 Men Hold Up 9 Bars
description: Two men posing as police officers investigating a murder have held up nine neighborhood bars and their patrons in Manhattan and Queens since July, the police said yesterday.

title: Six Dead in Florida Accident
description: The wreckage of a school bus that carried 19 handicapped children and three adults and a truck loaded with tires yesterday in Bronson, Fla. The police said that five children and the bus driver were killed and at least 17 were injured, several seriously. Some of the victims were flown out by helicopter. (AP)

title:
PATENTS;
Boy From Brooklyn Honored as Inventor
description: LEAD: Michael Oliveras, a Brooklyn elementary school student, and his teacher, Carole Teller, were honored at a ceremony in New York City this week. Michael, the inventor of a swivel headrest, is the national fifth-grade winner in the Invent America program of the United States Patent Model Foundation.

title: ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 27
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9,905,100. c-Net income and after a loss of $1,935,500 from discontinued operations.

title: Fewer Dolphins Die Along Coast; Reason for the Change Is Unclear
description: The number of dead bottle-nosed dolphins washing ashore along the coast from New Jersey south to the Carolinas appears to be dwindling, but scientists are unsure whether the illness that has been ravaging the mammals has run its course.

title: INSIDE
description: Fundamentalists Press On Despite major setbacks in the courts this summer, the drive by fundamentalist Christians to shape public education is very much alive. Page 6.

title: BONANZA AT THE TOP OF DISNEY
description: The Walt Disney Company has proved a magic kingdom of incredible proportions for its chairman, Michael Eisner, and its president, Frank Wells.

title: JONES SPACELINK reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: Results are restated to reflect the acquisition in March of controlling interests in Jones Intercable Inc. and Jones Group Ltd.

title: Pact for Pankey
description: It took him 32 days to do it, but Irv Pankey, the offensive tackle who allowed just 3 1/2 quarterback sacks over his last two seasons with the Los Angeles Rams, finally got some satisfaction: a two-year contract worth an estimated $650,000. Pankey, a seven-year veteran, was not entirely thrilled with the negotiations, however. ''I'm happy about my contract,'' he said, ''but I'm upset I had to miss training camp.''

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Irving Stark, 92, Dies; Active in Philanthropy
description: Irving Stark, a retired businessman from East Norwalk, Conn., and founder of the Hazel E. Stark Center, home of the National Theater of the Deaf in Chester, Conn., died of a heart attack Sunday in the Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida. He was 92 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: NATO Picks German General
description: Lieut. Gen. Eberhard Eimler, chief of staff of the West German Air Force, has been appointed a NATO deputy supreme allied commander in Europe, the Western alliance announced today. He replaces Gen. Hans-Joachim Mack, also a West German, who is retiring.

title: PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to July 19
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $286,000. c-Net loss

title: Japan Conductor Effort
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that Japan would make an all-out effort in research on superconductivity, or the effort to develop materials that can conduct electricity with negligible loss of power.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Shift in Safety Strategy Gains at Nuclear Plants
description: Engineers and government officials are beginning to consider whether a nuclear power plant would be safer if its steel and concrete shell that is meant to bottle up radiation in an accident were vented instead.

title: 35.71 DROP PUTS DOW AT 2,639.35
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday for the third session in a row, moving in concert with the continued drop in bond prices. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 35.71 points, to 2,639.35, to end the week down 70.15 points, or 2.6 percent. It was the Dow's worst week in almost a year.

title: KEY RATES
Maurice Laporte, 86, Ex-French Communist
description: Maurice Laporte, a writer and a leader of the French Communist Party in the early 1920's, died of leukemia Wednesday at his home in Geneva. He was 86 years old.

title: Maintain the Bikeways We Already Have
description: I read, with interest, your article ''New Trailway Section Adds Another Link To County System'' [ Aug. 16 ] about the new bike trails in northern Westchester.

title: A SELECTIVE GUIDE: TELEVISION
description: New Network Series ''The 'Slap' Maxwell Story.'' Dabney Coleman, whose edgy portrayal of an egomaniacal TV talk-show host in ''Buffalo Bill'' won critical praise but marginal ratings, returns to weekly television as an egomaniacal sportswriter in this ABC series. ''Tour of Duty.'' CBS will try to turn the Vietnam War into a weekly entertainment, in an hour-long drama told from the grunt's point of view. Terence Knox stars as a platoon sergeant who cares. ''Hooperman.'' In this ABC comedy-drama series, John Ritter portrays a San Francisco police detective who becomes the owner of an apartment building when his landlord is murdered. From the creators of ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''L.A. Law.'' ''A Different World.'' NBC tries to exploit the overwhelming success of ''The Cosby Show'' with a spinoff starring Lisa Bonet as a Cosby kid in her first year of college. ''Frank's Place.'' A CBS series starring Tim Reid, who played Venus Flytrap in ''WKRP in Cincinnati.'' Here he takes on a more subdued role as a college professor who inherits a down-home Creole restaurant in New Orleans. ''Beauty and the Beast.'' An update of the fantasy classic, with Linda Hamilton as a career girl whose life is changed when she meets a nice monster who lives in the sewer system beneath New York City. Ron Perlman is the hirsute romantic lead in this CBS series. ''Dolly.'' ABC scraps its long-running (23 years) Sunday night movie for a try at the musical/variety format. Dolly Parton and guest stars. Mini-Series ''Napoleon and Josephine.'' A six-hour ABC soap opera with Armand Assante and Jacqueline Bisset as the Little Corporal and his wife. ''Echoes in the Darkness.'' Peter Coyote, Peter Boyle and Stockard Channing in a five-hour CBS adaptation of the Joseph Wambaugh book about murder in a Philadelphia suburb. ''Mario Puzo's 'The Fortunate Pilgrim.' '' A four-hour NBC rendition of the Puzo novel about a feisty immigrant and her family, with Sophia Loren and Edward James Olmos. ''James Clavell's 'Noble House.' '' Pierce Brosnan, Deborah Raffin and John Houseman are among the players in NBC's eight-hour mini-series set in contemporary Hong Kong. Television Movies ''Gunsmoke Revisited.'' James Arness and Amanda Blake portray Matt Dillon and Miss Kitty again, 12 years on. In this CBS movie, the retired marshall is a mountain trapper and Miss Kitty lives in New Orleans.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE U.S. OPEN, AND WHY?
description: Parity will play a deciding role in this year's United States Open. With much attention being focused on whether or not Ivan Lendl can win his third consecutive title, and whether John McEnroe can return to his old form, Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia will quietly rise to the occasion and win his first Grand Slam tournament. RODERICH E. SIEGMUND Brightwaters, L.I.

title: Mitchell-Lama
description: To the Editor:

title: Archivist Setting Records Straight
description: LEAD: YOUR baby pictures would not make it. But those of County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke would. That's a whimsical example from David W. Carmicheal, the County Archivist, of what qualifies for the County Archives, at 2199 Saw Mill River Road here.

title: Familiar and Unknown
description: The great strength of the new season is painting. It is not just that there are so many solid shows, particularly in New York and Washington, but that there are so many shows to capture the imagination.

title:
DINING OUT;
Seasonal Fare in Bedford Village
description: LEAD: ENTERING the reception area of Bistro 22 is as exciting as entering a theater lobby.

title: Present at the Misconception
description: THE TWILIGHT STRUGGLE Tales of the Cold War. By William Attwood. 433 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $20.

title: Applications to Medical Schools Are Falling
description: The number of applicants to medical schools is falling, possibly because students fear a glutted market and record debt upon graduation, medical officials say.

title: Perkin-Elmer Lays Off 89
description: Perkin-Elmer Corporation laid off 89 workers from its Optical Division plant here Friday, saying it was the last such action planned by the company, which has had about 300 layoffs in the last year. The company's director of public relations, Edward Bloch, said most of the workers were technicians, machinists and engineers. Earlier this month, the company said it would cut its worldwide force by 6 percent as part of a restructuring and, this week, it reported $18 million in losses over the last year. The division makes optical devices and other machinery for telescopes and space-based mechanisms.

title: The Soviet Union Introduces New Sheet
description: THE Soviet Union issued earlier this year a souvenir sheet and five stamps to celebrate the 117th anniversary of the birth of Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov, who assumed the pseudonym of Lenin. Lenin was a principal figure in the Soviet Revolution which culminated in the emergence of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic. The souvenir sheet, which contains five stamps, depicts paintings of Lenin by Soviet artists.

title: Chik ... Chek ... Chew
description: ALL the publicity about contaminated chicken earlier this summer got Charles Boggs's children and stepchildren so scared that they said they would never eat chicken again.

title: LENDL AT EASE WITH AMERICAN WAY AT U.S. OPEN
description: He studies the baseball box scores, watches hockey games on cable television in his Greenwich, Conn., house and enjoys spending his days off on a golf course in pursuit of par. Ivan Lendl has been studying to be an American since he moved to this country from Czechoslovakia in 1981, and is hoping to make it official some day. The United States Open, then, is his national tournament, and convenient to reach, too - only half an hour from home in a fast car.

title: Rich vs. Poor: Drug Patterns Are Diverging
description: Americans generally appear to be turning away from the use of illegal drugs, but, at the same time, the poor face mounting deaths and an ever bleaker future because of drug abuse, according to Government statistics and interviews with drug experts.

title: Cynthia A. Bogin Is Married to Kenneth Wornick
description: Cynthia Abigail Bogin, the daughter of Merle Golden Bogin of New York and Putnam Valley, N.Y., and Bruce Michael Bogin of Orlando, Fla., was married last night to Kenneth Wornick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Charles Wornick of Hillsborough, Calif., and Brewster, Mass. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: Data Update: August 30, 1987
HOOPLA
description: IT'S THE NATURE OF THE JOB that critics must greet the start of each new season in a state of almost mystical optimism - as if they had just arrived, at long last, at the gateway to the Promised Land. Maybe this will be the year, one traditionally postulates, when American theater (or dance or film or painting) will find its new O'Neill (or Balanchine or Welles or Pollock). Then again, maybe not. It can be exhausting, not to mention disappointing, to set one's cultural expectations too high before a single curtain has been raised. Art doesn't happen seasonally. Great art, which even in our time is not always preceded by the beating of the publicity tom-toms, has a way of turning up just at that moment when no one expects it. So please forgive this drama critic for not promising you that the 1987-88 season will ascend to the esthetic peaks. It could happen, but, if so, you didn't hear it here first.

title: KATHERINE PLACE WEDS
description: Katherine Patricia Place, a student at the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital School of Nursing, and Gary Richard Clark, an account executive at the New York investment banking firm of Blinder Robinson & Company, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Warren Skipp officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Curtis Place of Millbrook, and Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Clark of Glen Rock, N.J.

title: Elizabeth Wyman Becomes the Bride Of Donald Baron
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., Elizabeth Baldwin Wyman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hunt Wyman of Southport, was married yesterday to Donald Leighton Baron, a son of Mrs. Robert Quarterman of Dorchester, England, and Stanley C. Baron of Whitehouse, N.J. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund officiated.

title: In Search of the Perfect Angel
description: FIVE years ago, a young fashion designer named Rebecca Moses had an offer she couldn't refuse. ''You design,'' said Victor Coopersmith, a former Seventh Avenue salesman. ''In two to three years, we make you famous.''

title: Loft Residents Given Amnesty
description: EARLY in September, New York City will begin tacking red, black and white posters with an abstract expressionist design to buildings and kiosks in the artists' enclaves around Houston Street in Manhattan, with the warning: ''SoHo/NoHo Residents: Act Now. Don't Lose Your Loft!''

title: Drivers License Isn't Title to Road
description: Perhaps I was raised in a simpler time, but when I learned to drive, I was told that in residential neighborhoods there was no such thing as a speed limit. Rather, one drove defensively, as if a child could rush in front of the car at any moment. And when a child did appear, the driver's duty was to wait for him to move. As I remember it, the roads were posted with ''Children Playing'' signs instead of numerical speed limits. The idea was that a public roadway was just that: public. A driver's license entitled one to operate a motor vehicle, it did not convey title to the road.

title: AQUINO DEMANDING ARREST OF LEADERS IN MILITARY REVOLT
description: The leaders of an attempted coup were still at large today and the military remained on alert after Government forces put down the most serious armed challenge to the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I DIDN'T know what to expect the first time I drove through Cape May; maybe it's more accurate to say I harbored a set of images that proved to be dead wrong.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
AIDS Counseling
description: LEAD: COUNSELING for people with AIDS and their families and friends is now available through Westchester Jewish Community Services, a nonsectarian, nonprofit agency and licensed family mental-health clinic with main offices in Hartsdale.

title: VISION OF EDEN VOICES OF BABEL
description: WHEN THE CURTAIN IS RAISED on Maguy Marin'S ''Babel, Babel'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival in October, naked men and women will walk, run, embrace and frolic on a huge grass field - the park of Babel.

title: 30 GROUPS UNITE TO OPPOSE BORK
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT organizations opposed to the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the United States Supreme Court plan to spend the next month calling and writing the state's two United States Senators to urge them to vote against him.

title: DREAM CARS
description: Bill Boggs's article ''Finding the Fury'' (About Men, Aug. 2) brought back a fond memory. I was a college freshman, taking a Christmas vacation with my parents. My father, after struggling for years to build his business, was finally able to relax a bit and visit my older sister and brother in far-away Dallas and Los Angeles.

title: My 'L.I. Cottage' Isn't On L.I.
description: I HAVE a country house of my own.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN AT-HOME TESTING
description: THE industry had been around for years but it wasn't until earlier this decade that it really took off. Now at-home health testing has become a part of life for many Americans, who use store-bought kits to diagnose or monitor medical conditions ranging from diabetes to pregnancy.

title: Baltimore
description: Once upon a time, as many an old salt or traveling salesman could attest, Baltimore's downtown was festooned with strip joints and rotting wharves.

title: Ms. Rose to Wed Henry W. A. Jackson
description: The engagement of Virginia Oliver Rose to Henry William Arthur Jackson, a son of Mrs. Peter A. Jackson of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Jackson, has been announced by her parents, Virginia R. McElman of Belleaire, Fla., and Evans Rose of Sewickley Heights, Pa.

title: 70 Officers Investigate Idaho Gunfight Report
description: More than 70 heavily armed officers searched a wooded area today to investigate a report of a gunfight among motorcycle gang members, but found nothing. A man who reported seeing several bodies in the area was later charged with drug possession.

title: COMPANY MEETS CONCERN ON MTV
description: LEAD: GERY ALEXANDER of Clinton came home one day and saw his 5-year-old daughter mimicking a music program she was watching on television, a broadcast he considered to be ''obscene.''

title:
ABOUT MEN;
SURVIVOR'S DEBT
description: LEAD: FOR THE LAST FEW YEARS, I have been trying to figure out why I became obsessed with the idea of establishing an income source for charitable purposes. Why did I go into business because of certain feelings and not because of acquisitiveness or need? Most men don't act that way, I've been told, although in my case the work of two other men got me going.

title: ALABAMA, SOUTHERN CAL MAKE ACADEMICS A FIRST AND GOAL
description: THE problem, among all the problems, is that the spectacle will seem unchanged. The Million Dollar Band at the University of Alabama has not been devalued by inflation, and Traveler III, the great white Trojan horse at the University of Southern California, has never appeared more majestic.

title: A Seismograph in Poland
description: MOONRISE, MOONSET By Tadeusz Konwicki. Translated by Richard Lourie. 344 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: LAURA M. BRIGGS WEDS J. R. KNOWLES JR.
description: At the First Unitarian Church in Providence, R.I., Laura Manly Briggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Owen Briggs 3d of New York, and Jonathan Read Knowles Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Knowles of Rehoboth, Mass., were married yesterday by the Rev. Beth Ide.

title: A TINY COMPANY, A BIG AIDS HOPE
description: LEAD: IT is a small company on a quiet street in an industrial section of West Haven. It has fewer than 30 employees and no sign on its door, and it shares the building with an office furniture warehouse and helicopter parts supplier.

title: CAMBODIA MEETING SEEKS PACT
description: Representatives of the Soviet Union and the three Communist nations of Indochina met in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, this week and said they were beginning a new move to end the Cambodian conflict, the Phnom Penh press agency said today.

title: LANFORD WILSON COMES HOME
description: WHEN LANFORD WILSON BEGAN writing his newest play in the fall of 1985, he put a message to himself at the top of the first page.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Umberto D With Carlo Battisti. Directed by Vittorio De Sica. 1952. Video Yesteryear. 88 minutes. $29.95.

title: The Generation Gap: From Persephone to Portnoy
description: ''ONLY connect,'' said E. M. Forster, and what a world of human struggle, folly and failure are compressed into those two words. But for parents and children, in life and in literature, it is not the connecting but the separating that is the problem. Parents ''accept their obsolescence with the best grace they can muster,'' as Christopher Lasch puts it in ''Haven in a Heartless World.'' ''They do all they can to make it easy for the younger generation to surpass the older, while secretly dreading the rejection that follows.''

title: Quick Way to Diagnose Alzheimer's Outlined
description: A new, simple method of diagnosing Alzheimer's disease that is based on hesitations in speech was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association.

title: INSIDERS' FOCUS OF FALL FILMS
description: OF THE 200 OR MORE FILMS SCHEDULED to reach theaters during the next seven months, perhaps only some two dozen possess a special fascination for Hollywood insiders. Although the first concern of each studio executive, actor, producer and director is how his or her own film does at the box office, these two dozen or so films are bellwethers. As the history of sequels, prequels and clones repeatedly illustrates, this is an industry that feeds on its own successes. The men and women for whom movies are a job are as sensitive to fads and trends, unexpected box-office bonanzas and surprising failures as a bee is to the best and worst fields for clover.

title: Santa Fe
description: To the Editor: On June 7, hours before I was married, I spotted ''What's Doing in Santa Fe'' and immediately packed it, as my fiancee and I were leaving on our honeymoon to that city the next day. We enjoyed the many museums and art galleries mentioned and were particularly impressed with the city's combination of urban amentities nad suburban conveniences. We saw great art, shopped in elegant boutiques, ate in fine restaurants and never had a problem finding a parking space.

title: 4 Tenants Awarded $683,275 in Harassment Case
description: Four tenants of an Upper West Side building have been awarded $683,275 in a case in which their landlords were found guilty of harassment.

title: PRELUDE CAN HELP DRIVERS IN AND OUT OF TOUGH SPOTS
description: Unlike the complex hydraulic and electronic four-wheel steering systems being researched by many other manufacturers, Honda's unit is purely mechanical.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Los Angeles Playing Host to the World

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AN INFINITE NUMBER OF MONKEYS. By Les Roberts. (St. Martin's, $12.95.) What does a private eye novel need? A crime; a victim. Women - a few sexy, full blown; one fragile, resistant and adorable. Men -many, big and bad, some good but not heroic, an unfriendly police lieutenant. A couple of bodies no one will miss. Rich people. And a sophisticated, velvet-gloved, iron-fisted peg of a private eye who fits into any situational hole. In Les Roberts's pleasant if predictable first novel, set in contemporary Hollywood, they're all there. Also a professor who eats health foods, a black drug dealer-student and a wealthy publisher. Mr. Roberts's would-be victim is a Los Angeles author, Buck Weldon, who turns out best sellers about a stereotypical private eye. His trashy stories are, he says, a living. Someone wants him dead. He has two daughters. The sweet one is his secretary and lives at home; the other is a promiscuous addict supported by dad. Each has, or had, a worthless man who detests her father. Characters in Weldon's new novel resemble people in a high-level financial scam at a Hollywood studio. Stylistically, Mr. Roberts, a screenwriter, gets off slowly and unsteadily. He describes someone's Pepsodent teeth (in this Crest generation) and allows Saxon, the private investigator and part-time actor (he has one name), to fall for the novel's first good-looking woman. Mr. Roberts's strength lies in descriptions of places like Venture City in West Los Angeles and Palm Springs or in deft characterizations of people - a literary agent or a movie magnate dining out.

title: MARTHA STEWART, ON THE RUN
description: LEAD: NURTURING chickens, tending gardens, cooking up a storm, lecturing and writing - all are daily happenings in the life of Martha Stewart. But for the prolific author to whom many Americans have taken, it's a schedule she covets and loves. And it provides the basis of her books.

title:
ART;
Recent Work on East End
description: LEAD: DURING the height of the summer season, East End artists with substantial reputations often show their most recent work in local galleries. The current offering at the Vered Gallery in East Hampton, featuring Audrey Flack, Claus Hoie and Syd Solomon, is a case in point.

title: NUCLEAR BACKERS IGNORE REALITIES AND CRY WOLF
description: I strongly disagree with Herbert Jaffe's recent Opinion Page comment about the need for Shoreham [ ''Shoreham's Critics Ignore Realities'' ] . For him to espouse these views implies that he is ignoring the last 15 years of mistakes, mismanagement and special interests that have brought us to this point. I believe Lilco's board of directors, both past and present, are largely responsible for the problems and uncertainty that now face Long Island.

title: U.S. ADVANCES IN CANADA CUP
description: Led by Pat LaFontaine of the Islanders and John Vanbiesbrouck of the Rangers, Team USA defeated Team Finland, 4-1, Friday night in Hartford to start the round-robin competition in the six-team Canada Cup tournament.

title: TWO NEW MUSICCALS IN STATE STAGINGS
description: WITH the opening of two new American musicals in the next couple of weeks - one presented as a prospect for a national tour, the other already booked for Broadway - the state might be taking a major step toward saving our indigenous, endangered theater form.

title: Joyful Noises
description: Classical music lovers from Tokyo to Los Angeles to London welcome the fall season as the return of the riches that only a metropolis can offer. The traditional harbingers in Manhattan are the opening of the Metropolitan Opera -this year with Kiri Te Kanawa and Placido Domingo in Verdi's ''Otello'' on Sept. 21 - and the New York Philharmonic at its home base, Avery Fisher Hall, on Sept. 15. But one of the things that makes New York a world musical center is the steady parade of visitors to our major midtown halls. Like the Vienna Philharmonic with Leonard Bernstein at Carnegie Hall (Sept. 25), for instance. Or the United States debut of the Moscow Virtuosi, led by the brilliant violinist Vladimir Spivakov (Avery Fisher, Oct. 4), or the Central Philharmonic Orchestra of China (Avery Fisher, Oct. 11).

title: Vladimir Feltsman Recalls His Years as a Nonperson
description: VLADIMIR FELTSMAN, THE 35-year-old Russian pianist who arrived in New York on Aug. 18, considers himself a realist. Thus he was not altogether surprised at what happened when, eight years ago, he put in for an emigration visa.

title: Take a Quiz and Learn from Answers
description: WHEN I looked around the room on the first day of a summer photography workshop, which I recently taught in England, I could see thousands of dollars worth of gleaming cameras and lenses, most of which were of professional caliber. But how sophisticated were the participants who were toting them? Could they tell an ISO speed from an aperture? Did they think that reciprocity failure was a bad relationship between the subject and the photographer?

title: Patricia Holt, a Broker, Weds Jonathan Bauer
description: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church was the setting in New York yesterday for the wedding of Patricia Holt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Holt of New York, to Jonathan Scott Bauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Bauer of Glenview, Ill. Msgr. Henry Cauley performed the ceremony.

title: FROM VIETNAM TO WALL STREET
description: ALFRED HITCHCOCK ONCE SAID movies are like life with the boring bits cut out.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from two weeks in Spain, I would like to add my own word to your article ''What's Doing in Madrid'' (Travel, July 5). That word is nothing.

title: JOHNSON, LEWIS ONE STEO FROM SHOWDOWN IN 100
description: Even with Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson two steps closer to the men's 100-meter final Sunday, this was a day for Italians and Italy.

title: Apple Invades I.B.M.'s Domain
description: WALK into any major corporation and check the computers used there. The latest market surveys find that 85 percent of them are I.B.M. PC's or I.B.M. compatibles. That's hardly a surprise.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having difficulty removing nonskid decal strips from the bottom of my bathtub. The directions said to soak with detergent, then scrape with a razor blade, but this isn't working very well. What can you recommend? A. Try heating the decals with a hair dryer or heat lamp. This will soften the adhesive backing so that scraping with a razor blade will be easier. When scraping, hold the blade almost flat against the bottom of the tub to avoid scratching and move it back and forth as you push it forward under the decal. Q. Can I use Clorox and detergent on a blacktop driveway to get rid of a green mold that is spreading over the surface at a rapid rate? A. The green mold (moss) can be washed off with a solution of Clorox and water (one part Clorox to four parts water), but adding detergent does not really help much. You can also use one of the fungicide solutions sold in swimming-pool supply stores. Any of these should be kept off the lawn, or washed off with lots of water. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: Steps to Cut Air Traffic At Logan Are Decreed
description: The state transportation authorities, frustrated by what they call a lack of Federal leadership in reducing airport traffic, have announced steps to curb congestion at Logan Airport.

title: STREETSCAPES: THE MOUNT MORRIS BANK A Derelict Is Freshened Up, But Its Fate Is Still Uncertain
description: FOR over a decade, one of Harlem's greatest buildings has been derelict, a few dingy curtains blowing in its broken Queen Anne windows. This July it looked as if the old Mount Morris Bank at the northwest corner of 125th Street and Park Avenue was finally about to undergo restoration.

title: 4-IN-HAND DRIVERS TO VIE IN GLADSTONE
description: AN elite group of drivers will compete Sept. 11-13 in the sixth annual Gladstone Driving Event at Hamilton Farm, a ranch in Somerset County that is the home of the United States Equestrian Team Training Center.

title: Nancy C. Cox Married To Edward McSorley
description: At the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L.I., Nancy Caldwell Cox, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Graves Cox Jr. of Garden City, was married yesterday to Edward McSorley, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard McSorley of Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. Broesler performed the ceremony.

title: MS. SPEERS TO WED D. S. MCCORMICK
description: The Rev. and Mrs. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Center Sandwich, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Thacher Speers, to David Speir McCormick, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert V. McCormick of Madison, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Jody Tabner Wed To B. R. Thayer
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Glens Falls, N.Y., Jody Mary Tabner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Tabner of Latham, N.Y., and Bradley Raymond Thayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Norris Thayer of Beverly Hills, Calif., were married yesterday by the Rev. William D. Persell.

title: Poem Seeking Reward
description: To the Editor:

title: Tom Waits Distills a Vocabulary of the Psyche
description: ROILING MUSICAL TEXTURES that bubble up from the earth like warm mud, strains of European torch songs that bump elbows with plaintive Tex-Mex cowboy tunes, converging echoes of blues, jazz and mariachi: These are but a few of the elements to be savored on Tom Waits's new album, ''Franks Wild Years'' (Island 90572-1; all three formats).

title: Tracking Great Painters Within a Drive of Paris
description: On the top floor of the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, a cobalt blue sky daubed thickly on canvas by Vincent van Gogh blazes over a hilltop church with a V-shaped patch of grass in front. Twenty-five miles away, in Auvers-surOise, is that same church, still with the grass patch where the artist planted his easel 96 years ago.

title: VOICES FROM THE BARBIE TRIAL
description: Possibly, some of the most disturbing testimony comes from witnesses who felt incapable to speak of their ordeals. Apparently, some of the anguished secrets were kept for more than 40 years, until the trial in Lyon: ''The human mouth cannot express what we went through.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Aug. 9 incorrectly identified the law school of which Representative Robert G. Torricelli is a graduate. It is the Rutgers School of Law-Newark.

title: Japan by Rail
description: To the Editor: How right Patricia Langan is. Travel solo via the J.R. rail pass is loads of fun.

title: Left Behind
description: To the Editor: I have a steadily growing file of true-life stories to do with wives and absentee husbands, and when I read Bette-Jane Raphael's ''The One Who's Left Behind'' (Travel, July 19), my mind at once removed one of these anecdotes from the file.

title: BASEBALL BILL: OUT AT HOME
description: MOST New Jerseyans, according to recent polls, are enthusiastic and excited about the prospect of having a major league baseball team in our state. Everyone agrees it would provide a shot in the arm for the economy and allow all of us Jersey-boosters to wallow anew in state pride.

title: HARBOR ELEGANCE IN EAST HAMPTON
description: BEAUTY is what Wings Point Restaurant on Three Mile Harbor in East Hampton is all about. Esthetically speaking, there's no more lovely dining experience on Long Island.

title: Latin Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Lee Marvin Dies at 63

title: Bullfrog County, Nev., (Pop. 0) Fights Growth
description: When legislators formed this new county out of the bleak and hostile desert north of Las Vegas in June, they did not worry about soliciting the views of local residents. There are no residents.

title: Checking Out the Kids - and Yourself
description: WHEN talk of mandatory drug testing programs became widespread, pharmaceutical and lab companies scrambled to get in on the action. In one corporate drug-testing lab, an employee envisioned another side of the market.

title: Up the Gulf Without a Paddle of International Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Lee Marvin, Movie Tough Guy, Dies
description: Lee Marvin, who rebelled against a sheltered childhood to build an image as the consummate ''tough guy'' in the movies and in real life, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Tucson Medical Center in Arizona. He was 63 years old.

title: Ralph LaChance Wed to Ms. Kuhn
description: The marriage of Sarah Kuhn, a daughter of Kathryn M. Kuhn of Princeton, N.J., and Prof. Thomas S. Kuhn of Boston, to Ralph E. LaChance, a son of Mrs. Armand LaChance of Danielson, Conn., and the late Mr. LaChance, took place yesterday in Danvers, Mass. George Bach, a justice of the peace,performed the ceremony at the Glen Magna estate.

title: Beware the I.N.F. Risks
description: President Reagan's speech of Aug. 26, which put the arms control issue in the perspective of foreign policy as a whole, is being wrongly dismissed as a ritual gesture to placate his right wing. We should not allow the important message of the speech to be drowned in the cacophony of dispute over the details of the agreement on intermediate nuclear forces.

title: Squatters Celebrate Brooklyn Victory
description: It did not seem like much of a place for a party yesterday, this weedy lot at 412 Vermont Avenue in the heart of the East New York section of Brooklyn. Apart from the tall grass, there was literally nothing there, save the upside-down chassis of a long-defunct Ford Falcon, a kind of monument to urban decay.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: A COVEN OF WOMEN. By Jean Brody. (Atheneum, $16.95.) In Jean Brody's flawed but often intriguing second novel, eight related women contend with the choices, chances and limitations life offers them. The first and last chapters are told by Megan Austin, poet, awakening feminist, seeker. Megan inherits from her Aunt Vida a storage box containing her aunt's memories of seven ''dead people,'' she has ''collected'' and thereby kept ''alive.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having difficulty removing nonskid decal strips from the bottom of my bathtub. The directions said to soak with detergent, then scrape with a razor blade, but this isn't working very well. What can you recommend?

title: The Accuracy of the MX Questioned
description: FOR years, experts have debated where to put the MX, the 10-warhead long-range missile that the Reagan Administration has described as central in its nuclear arsenal. But recently, the debate has shifted to pressing questions about whether the MX can hit its targets.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE state Department of Environmental Protection, which has spent two years discovering wrong ways to find a site to store radium-contaminated soil, finally has a document that purports to explain the right way.

title: Aquino's Son Says Rebels Opened Fire as He Spoke
description: When the son of President Corazon C. Aquino approached his house at 2 A.M. Friday, he noticed that the street lights were out and soldiers were lying on the ground nearby.

title: FALL'S GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: IT IS A SECRET THAT CANNOT BE KEPT. Every least thing betrays it. The first hesitant downward drift of a leaf, for instance. The closing of the little seafood stalls, one by one, down by the beach. A publisher's fall catalogue in the mail. The highways along the Northeastern corridor, with a boat strapped on top of car after car and every one of them headed for home. Fliers from all over, promising us six great evenings in the theater for the price of five. And - unmistakable, this - the moment when all nature stops saying ''Come outdoors!'' and we start dreaming of indoors instead.

title: Emily E. Bannister Is Wed To Fellow M.B.A. Student
description: Emily Eleanor Bannister and Derek Kirby Rapp, M.B.A. candidates at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at St. John Chrysostom Roman Catholic Church in Wallingford, Pa., by Msgr. Frederick Stevenson.

title: >SHEILA PRIMPS IS BRIDE
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Theresa in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Sheila Marie Primps, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Byrd Primps of Ossining, N.Y., was married yesterday to Douglas Peter Sherwood, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Sherwood of White Plains. The Rev. Robert Dunn performed the ceremony. The bride is an account executive for the Softness Group in New York. Mr. Sherwood is an account manager for Apple Computer in New York.

title: Of Purple Calves And People
description: THEY were described as the highway equivalent of a message in a bottle: 20 purple calves made of plywood and placed at rest stops on interstate roads in northern Vermont. They bore signs inviting drivers to pick them up and take them to different destinations in the country.

title: Chinese Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: KATHERINE J. MCMILLAN WED TO NIGEL D. ADAM
description: Katherine Jane McMillan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward McMillan of Wenham, Mass., and Santa Barbara, Calif., was married yesterday to Nigel David Adam, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Adam of Ruckinge, Kent, England. The Rev. John Rogers performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Hamilton, Mass.

title: The Big Business of Build-It-Yourself Planes
description: FLYING has always been a big part of David L. Womeldorff's life. He was a flier in the Air Force for 11 years. He has owned his own airplane for 20 years. He is president of his local Bellevue, Wash. aerobatics club, which sponsors competitions for amateur aerobatics pilots. And he makes his living as an engineering design manager at the Boeing Military Airplane Company in Seattle.

title: SPECIAL TODAY: NEW SEASON/Magazine Part 2
description: * Previews of theater, art, dance, music, film, television, photography.

title: Clarification
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Five Stars For a Kitchen On Vacation
description: When we mention travel plans to friends, most assume we're mainly going to eat. ''Oh, you must try this enchanting little Italian place just off Union Square, so authentic and atmospheric,'' gushed one recent visitor to San Francisco. She didn't mention that noodles and cheese, described in italic script on a thick creamy menu as taliolini verdi, cost $22.50, a la carte.

title: School Allays Asbestos Fear
description: LEAD: AFTER a major fire last spring, unacceptable levels of asbestos and polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, were found at an Oceanside elementary school. Now, school officials, who have hired an asbestos removal company to clean the damaged area, are trying to allay parents' fears that their children may have been exposed to hazardous materials.

title: Bosworth's Big Game
description: AS a late-signing rookie linebacker he has had only two weeks of practice and is still somewhat at sea in the professional game. But Brian Bosworth, the former Oklahoma star, gave it the old college try Friday night as he helped the Seahawks beat the Detroit Lions, 38-10, in an exhibition game in the Seattle Kingdome.

title: Creating a Colonial Aura on the Cape
description: Most Massachusetts towns that cherish their distinctive colonial centers owe them to the esthetics of the Puritans who settled them hundreds of years ago. This Cape Cod community will have a colonial center because of a private developer who is spending $14 million.

title: For a Stealth Specialist, the Alekhine Defense
description: THERE are players who are not really happy unless they are fighting from a crouching position. These worthies get no special pleasure out of ramming a gigantic pawn center through the enemy lines. They are not inspired by anything as pedestrian as advantage in space.

title: Roster of Guest Performers for Fall
description: EARLY concert subscribers not only get preferred seating and pay discounted prices but also avoid the frustration of facing a ''sold out'' sign when renowned artists such as the Juilliard String Quartet, Claude Frank, Lilian Kallir, Michala Petri and Ahmad Jamal come to town. As it happens, all of those performers are listed on subscription series that get under way in September.

title: The Impressionists Saw Her as a Peer
description: AS OF NEXT SUNDAY, JUSTICE WILL BE done at the National Gallery of Art in Washington to Berthe Morisot (1841-1896), who is the least known, the least talked of and the least often looked at of the original group of French Impressionist painters.

title: Legends and Reunions
description: ''Autumn in New York - It's good to live it again,'' goes the lyric of the wistful Vernon Duke standard. Nowhere in the entertainment world do those words resonate more nostalgically than in pop music. While summer is the season of outdoor rock-and-roll, fall brings back to the city's concert halls, cabarets and jazz clubs those artists who are perennially popular.

title: Where Leonardo Lives On
description: Early in the autumn of 1516, Leonardo da Vinci left the papal court in Rome and set off on a mule across the Alps. Having outlived his great ptrons and protectors, he easily yielded to the entreaties of the young French King, Francois I, to come settle at the court in Amboise, ont he banks of the Loire River.

title: 200 Died in Massacre in Haiti
description: More than 200 people were killed and 100 wounded in a massacre on July 23 in the northwest farming town of Jean-Rabel, a commission investigating the incident said in a report published today.

title: THE NURSING CRISIS: ANOTHER VIEW
description: MUCH public attention has been focused recently on the critical shortage of nurses. It is felt no more acutely than by patients who are turned away from hospitals' doors or by physicians who are unable to gain hospital access for their patients. The vacancy rate for registered nurses in hospitals has more than doubled from 1985 to 1986, to 13.6 percent from 6.3 percent at a time when the Bureau of Labor forecasts a need for an additional 400,000 nurses by 1995.

title: THE TRIUMPH OF AMERICAN DIVAS
description: IT IS GETTING HARD TO remember that opera used to be an imported delicacy, that you had to send for European singers to get it done right. The Chicago Lyric Opera's nickname was ''La Scala West,'' and Chicago used to scoop New York on hot new singers from Italy. Now it scoops us on hot new singers from Connecticut. In fact, Italy now scoops us on hot new singers from Connecticut, or from Texas. American singers have permeated the European scene as never before.

title: VOICES FROM THE BARBIE TRIAL
description: Ted Morgan is short of the mark, I think, in stating that Klaus Barbie was ''comfortable inside a system where he could express, under orders, the pathology of his nature.''

title: Pop Music
description: S.O.B.'s, the night club and restaurant at 204 Varick Street in lower Manhattan, has done more than any other performance space in the city to popularize the full range of Brazilian vernacular music. The club's initials, with their peculiar connotations, stand for ''Sounds of Brazil.''

title: Restaurant Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: IRAN'S GUARDS TAKE THE LEAD IN THE MILITARY
description: Iran's Revolutionary Guards, once regarded as an undisciplined group that used suicide tactics and terrorism to supplement conventional military forces, are gaining such new power in the military establishment that they may now be its dominant component, diplomats from several nations here say.

title: Latin Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan Recovering From Headquarters Exodus
description: AFTER decades of defections to the suburbs, manufacturers are beginning to find compelling reasons for maintaining headquarters in Manhattan.

title: In 'Moves,' the Silence Remains Startling
description: JEROME ROBBINS'S ''MOVES'' WAS originally subtitled ''A Ballet in Silence About Relationships.'' Although that subtitle was later simplified to ''A Ballet in Silence,'' the work is still about relationships. Created in 1959 for Mr. Robbins's company Ballets U.S.A., it has been successfully revived by the Joffrey Ballet and by the New York City Ballet, which performed it this past season.

title: Hopes and Fears for a Superpower Treaty
description: IT was a typically languid August, and there was none of the electricity in the damp Washington air that usually marks historic moments, but there seems little doubt that such a juncture was reached last week. Suddenly, it became highly likely that the United States and the Soviet Union will agree before the year is out to destroy, for the first time, significant parts of their immense stockpiles of nuclear weapons.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: JAQUES PEPIN;
'A GOOD COOK HAS RAPPORT WITH FOOD'
description: LEAD: JACQUES PEPIN has been a chef to three French Presidents, including Charles de Gaulle, and at some of France and New York's best-known restaurants.

title: Paperback Best Sellers: August 30, 1987
description: Weeks On Fiction List 1 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) 2 Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, 7 $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians. 3 HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS, by Jackie Collins. 4 (Pocket, $4.95.) A top model's encounters with three of Los Angeles's most dynamic men. 4 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) A 8 rich orphan comes of age as she travels the world. 5 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Fawcett, $5.95.) 6 Four hundred years of history in fictional form. 6 THE UNWANTED, by John Saul. (Bantam, $4.50.) 5 A teen-age girl, lonely in a Cape Cod town, finds herself endowed with terrifying powers. 7 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom 68 Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 8 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. 9 (Bantam, $3.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 9 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. 8 (Pocket, $4.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 10 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Bantam, 1 $4.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenue in the world New York City police call home. 11 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence 10 Sanders. (Berkley, $4.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 12 * THE WILD BLUE, by Walter J. Boyne and Steven 4 L. Thompson. (Ivy/Ballantine, $4.95.) The lives of six American airmen, from the start of the Air Force to the coming of the space age. 13 TWILIGHT EYES, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, 1 $4.95.) While sought by police for murder, Slim MacKenzie stalks a force called the Others. 14 MURDER IN GEORGETOWN, by Margaret 10 Truman. (Fawcett, $4.50.) The mystery surrounding the death of a senator's daughter. 15 * THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. 1 (Avon, $4.95.) A woman's coming of age in 18th- century England and France. Weeks On Nonfiction List 1 HIS WAY, by Kitty Kelley. (Bantam, $4.95.) An 1 unauthorized biography of Frank Sinatra. 2 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. 201 (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 27 (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 4 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) 18 Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 5 * MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle 10 Barrows with William Novak. (Ivy/Ballantine, $4.95.) A member of one of America's oldest families tells of the world's oldest profession. 6 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. 43 (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 7 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T 17 ENOUGH, by Harold Kushner. (Pocket, $4.50.) A rabbion "the search for a life that matters." 8 "AND SO IT GOES," by Linda Ellerbee. (Berkley, 14 $4.50.) Television journalism as experienced by a veteran correspondent. 9 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A 21 HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological disabilities. 10 * JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES. (St. 17 Martin's, $4.95.) Fifty tales by the Yorkshire veterinarian. 11 * ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Ballantine, $4.95.) 14 Seventy-six days alone at sea on an inflatable raft. Weeks Advice, How-to and On Miscellaneous List 1 BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by 1 Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More Bloom County cartoon strips. 2 THE BOOK OF QUESTIONS, by Gregory Stock. 12 (Workman, $3.95.) Provocative and challenging questions to ask yourself in order to learn more about yourself. 3 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin 65 Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 4 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, 32 Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) The 1987 edition. 5 * CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. 20 (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents.

title: Paint Helps to Rescue Part of Newport's Past. . .
description: The new off-white paint on the exterior of Trinity Church may not match everyone's perception of how an 18th century Episcopal church should look, but the color is closer to historical accuracy than the more familiar pure white.

title:
MUSIC;
CHAMBER GROUP GETS NEW HEAD
description: LEAD: MARK LAYCOCK, a conductor and violist from Wayne, Pa., has been appointed music director of the Chamber Symphony of Princeton, succeeding Portia Sonnenfeld, who died June 8.

title: You Can Tell a Bookstore by Its Covers
description: CHARLES and Diane Newman bought a bookstore in 1977 and in 1987 they bought another one. By ignoring the dire predictions of those Cassandras who claim Americans won't buy books, the Newmans followed their instincts and reasoned that educated people would support a bookstore that stocked special-interest books and provided personal service. The Newmans, who grossed more than $900,000 last year, made Books 'n' Things, their Briarcliff Manor bookstore, into one of the most successful operations of its kind, before they ventured into Tarrytown last month with another branch.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FLIGHT FROM FIESTA. By Frank Waters. (Swallow/Ohio University, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.) Frank Waters's new novel, his first in nearly 20 years, tells of an unlikely friendship between a snotty little 10-year-old Anglo turista and an old, alcoholic Pueblo Indian. Set in Santa Fe in the 1950's during an annual fiesta, the plot has the economy and stateliness of a fable. Elsie, in rebellion from her materialistic parents, has a tantrum in the plaza and destroys the old Indian's pottery. Suddenly and mysteriously, she is moved by his ''massive dignity,'' his ''strange and compelling immobility.'' Inocencio, the Indian, is in turn drawn to Elsie by enigmatic tribal and paternal impulses and, with no words exchanged, no sense of logic or consequences, they take off on an odd and remarkable two-week odyssey through increasingly remote frontier towns, mountain areas, deserts and ancient Pueblo dwellings. During their adventures, the ''old, atavistic hate'' between Indian and white is purged, and a touching reconciliation takes place before the story's predictable, tragic conclusion. Inocencio is more a force of nature than a conventional character; muted and aloof, his unexpected outbursts of affection and joy make him thoroughly charming and lifelike. The real pleasure of ''Flight From Fiesta,'' however, is the evocation of the landscape, with its ''empty, illimitable sea of sage'' and the ''alien remoteness'' of dying frontier towns. Born in 1902, Mr. Waters, author of ''The Woman at Otowi Crossing'' and ''Book of the Hopi,'' is noted for the painterly eye he brings to the Southwest. Here, it remains as keen as ever. For all its allegorical bluntness and old-fashioned impulse to tell even after something has been vividly shown, ''Flight From Fiesta'' has an admirable authenticity and humaneness.

title: Up the Gulf Without a Paddle of International Law; Can't Trust Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Warplanes Resume Attacks On Iranian Shipping and Oilfields
description: Iraq broke a 45-day informal Persian Gulf cease-fire with Iran today by bombing Iranian offshore oil installations. An Iranian supertanker was left ablaze and another ship may have been damaged off the Iranian coast.

title: Victoria Hull Wed To Richard Sharp
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., Victoria Susan Hull, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd N. Hull of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Richard Simon Sharp, a son of Sir Eric and Lady Sharp of London and Stanmore, Middlesex, England. The Rev. Dr. Walter D. Wagoner performed the ceremony.

title: A Life Under Guard
description: LEAD: SIDE BY SIDE The Autobiography of Helen Joseph. Illustrated. 249 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: FERNANDEZ REINJURED AS METS LOSE, 9-1
description: Taking one disaster at a time, this is what happened to the Mets today in Candlestick Park:

title: Waterways Are Victims of Development
description: AS the open spaces of lower Westchester County disappear under developers' bulldozers, old-timers decry the loss of natural beauty; homeowners become plagued by displaced skunks, raccoons and squirrels, and motorists complain of jammed highways and byways. But one often-overlooked impact of development is the pressure it puts on Westchester's waterways.

title: BILL BRADLEY'S QUALIFICATIONS
description: If Senator Bill Bradley is the ''Democrats' best hope,'' as some would have us believe, the United States is in deep trouble.

title: Winning by a Nose
description: THE lineup for the Bermuda Bowl contest in Jamaica in October has crystallized as a result of the European championships which ended in Brighton, England, two weeks ago. The United States team will defend its title with the same six-man team that won in Sao Paulo, Brazil, two years ago. They will be exempt to the semifinal stage together with Sweden which won in Brighton.

title: The Americanization of Beneteau
description: WHEN Annette Beneteau Roux became chief executive officer of Beneteau, she was 22 years old and the company, which produced modest wooden fishing boats, was on the brink of going under.
