title: Lunch on Several Levels
description: WORKS OF GENIUS By Richard Marek. 290 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: Joyner-Kersee: Another View
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Economist or Mystic? Tune In, Around 1990, to Find Out
description: DALLAS

title: CARROLL D. FEARON
description: Carroll D. Fearon, former vice president in charge of personnel of the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of the Schrafft's restaurant chain, died at the North Broward Medical Center, Pompano Beach, Fla., on Aug. 18, after a brief illness. Mr. Fearon, who was 90 years old, lived in Pompano Beach and Thousand Island Park, N.Y.

title: Celia Cruz: Salsa Star, Expatriate, Whirlwind
description: HINTS OF CELIA CRUZ'S public persona showed through as she sat in her agent's office. The Cuban salsa singer's eyelids were brushed with cobalt; her lips matched her inchlong fingernails: apple red. A bulky gold earring dangled from her right ear.

title: For John Ritter, Playing The Comic Isn't Enough
description: FRED ASTAIRE HAD IT. CARY Grant had it. It is that rarest of on-screen attributes: the ability to break new ground, to grow artistically, while appearing to the public as effortlessly entertaining. For the past decade or so, Hollywood insiders have suspected that a man named John Ritter - primarily a commercial TV actor, of all things -has more than his share of it, too.

title: Is There a Foe in Your Faucet?
description: IN New York City, a family is concerned about stories of lead in old water pipes.

title: OCT. 17 WEDDING FOR BETSY WRIGHT
description: The engagement of Elisabeth Jane Wright to David Mark Hawkings Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hawkings of New York and Bay Head, N.J., has been announced by her mother, Cynthia Brannock Wright of Greenwich, Conn. The couple plan to marry Oct. 17.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: AN aircraft noise study will be undertaken in several northern and western counties to help aviation officials evaluate the impact of new jetliner routes on the quality of suburban life.

title: POSTINGS: A Bit of the Old World; Hillside Condos
description: Copley Court, a new condominium development in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was designed as a single grand structure draping over a hillside rather than as a series of clustered units for two reasons. The first is practical, stemming from an excessively rocky, densely wooded site. But the second has to do with ambiance. ''This town at one point was a playground for the wealthy of Manhattan, with lawn tennis and croquet,'' said Frederick L. Philopena, whose architectural firm Nadler Philopena & Associates of Mount Kisco, N.Y. designed the $14 million project. ''That was the feeling we tried to create. We wanted to bring back a little bit of the Old World.''

title: Seeking the Real Deadwood
description: It would have seemed more fitting, as we approached Deadwood on our tour of South Dakota, to arrive by stagecoach, covered wagon, mule or horseback, rathern than by automobile, the contemporary choice for overland travel.

title: Recent Sales
description: Amityville $175,000 50 Riverleigh Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; den, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. Bay Shore $110,000 112 Rhode Island Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Jericho $332,000 7 Warren Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; den, dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,700. Hauppauge $163,900 14 Del Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; basement, 1-car garage, new roof; taxes $2,800. Lake Grove $125,000 4 Connoly Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; dining room, den, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Wantagh $222,000 1635 Hanington Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; den, finished basement with bar, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. OTHER AREAS Avon, Conn. $410,000 23 Daventry Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; vaulted ceilings, elegant setting, 1 acre; taxes $4,065. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $337,500 68 Frame Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old clapboard ranch; eat-in kitchen, playroom, 1 acre; taxes $5,844. Hawthorne, N.J. $168,000 7 Coolidge Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; sun room, fireplace; taxes $1,518.

title: >Lauren Rouse Marries
description: Lauren Rouse, formerly a dancer with the Joffrey Ballet who will join the Fort Worth Ballet Company next month, and Andrew Leslie Drouin, the Dallas branch manager of Printers' Service, were married yesterday in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Cathedral in Houston. The Revs. Tarcisius Fischer and Denis Lynch performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Dolorosa Rouse of Chicago and Jack Rouse of Evanston, Ill., and Mary Kelly and Andre Drouin, both of Houston.

title: STRONG TIES
description: IT MAY BE THEIR low-key luxury, or a still more subtle allusion to the look of Britain's ruling class.

title: Going to Extremes for 'Animal Rights'
description: IT has been more than a century since a group of Victorian Englishmen founded the National Antivivisection Society and won passage of Britain's pioneering Cruelty to Animals Act of 1876. Now with laboratories in the United States maintaining an annual population of about 20 million ''guinea pigs'' - a diverse menagerie that actually includes dogs, frogs, cats, rats, monkeys, rabbits, goats, gerbils, chickens and armadillos - ''animal rights'' activists are becoming increasingly militant. Like the bombers of abortion clinics, they have adopted the rhetoric of national liberation movements and a conviction that their cause puts them above the law.

title: Masters and Innovators
description: The new season for photography starts off big, with reconsiderations of three Modernist masters. A selection of Henri Cartier-Bresson's early images that are illustrative of his ''decisive moments'' approach will be on view at the Museum of Modern Art (opening Sept. 10). Edward Weston's career will be surveyed at the Metropolitan (Sept. 11), in an exhibition organized by the Center for Creative Photography at the University of Arizona for last year's centennial of the photographer's birth. Besides the inevitable peppers and nudes, the show includes some little-known color work. The International Center of Photography's midtown gallery will present ''Andre Kertesz: Diary of Light, 1912-85'' (Sept. 18). The retrospective, planned before the photographer's death two years ago, will survey the whole of his lyrical oeuvre.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
HOW SWEET IT WAS -- AND IS
description: LEAD: A MAN came into the Rockville Centre supermarket, saw the display and gaped. A woman strolled by -and began feverishly piling the boxes into her cart: two, three . . . eight green-and-brown boxes. I walked over, took one look - and saliva cascaded down my blouse. Ebinger's was back. The Brooklyn bakery's products are popping up in Long Island groceries faster than you can say ''half-sizes'' - which is the second best news I could receive.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Debates Yield To Fun as U.S.-Soviet Meeting Ends
description: Under an opulent tent on the banks of Lake Chautauqua, a Soviet rocket scientist danced with the granddaughter of an American President and sang ''When the Saints Go Marching In'' with a five-piece country-rock band.

title: WHIMSY AND WOODCUTS IN S. NORWALK
description: LEAD: EVEN though there's corniness mixed in with the thought, James Grashow's exhibition at the John Cusano Fine Art gallery in South Norwalk arouses high-flown sentiments such as ''The Last Rose of Summer.'' After all, it's getting toward that time of year. But the viewer is finally faced with Mr. Grashow's own low-down title, ''Bugs, Plants & Stuff!

title: Yonkers Offers Four-Year Fiscal Plan
description: LEAD: THREE years after facing bankruptcy, Yonkers has put its finances in order and is well on its way to achieving long-term fiscal stability, city officials say.

title: Help for the Stretch
description: THE California Angels, in a move to strengthen the club for the American League West pennant run, acquired the veteran second baseman Johnny Ray from the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday. The Angels gave up a minor league infielder, Bill Merrifield, and a player to be named. Ray, 30 years old, entered the season with a .288 batting average in five-plus seasons with Pittsburgh. This season, he is hitting .273, with 54 runs batted in. The Angels demoted Mark McLemore to make room for Ray. . . . The Oakland Athletics acquired Rick Honeycutt, a left-handed pitcher, from the Dodgers for a player to be named. Honeycutt appeared in 27 games for the Dodgers this season, posting a 2-12 record and a 4.59 earned run average. . . . The Chicago White Sox gave Neil Allen, a pitcher, his release and activated Bob James, a relief pitcher, from the disabled list.

title: Filipino Links Singlaub to Revolt
description: Philippine senator said today that officials in his country were investigating whether recent trips there by Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, a retired United States Army officer who was involved in the private supply network for the Nicaraguan rebels, and other Americans prompted a coup attempt against the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: POSTINGS: Southold Affordables; Levitt Redux
description: Through a special zoning category meant to encourage affordable housing in Southold, L.I., Mooreland Development Corporation is moving ahead with 168 owner-occupied units.

title: Brunch: Bright Variations On a Favorite Theme
description: LEAD: IT seems that every eating spot capable of poaching an egg and splitting an English muffin or spreading cream cheese on a bagel is open for brunch these days. Anything goes; one can wear jogging gear and assemble an informal brunch in a corner of the local deli or glad rag-it at one of the county's big hotel dining rooms, where a dozen tables may sag with opulent displays.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in the Travel Advisory column Aug. 2 indexing comfort in various cities during August misidentified one. The comfort index of 4, which indicates substantial discomfort, was for Las Vegas, Nev., not Las Vegas, N.M.

title: BILL BRADLEY'S QUALIFICATIONS
description: I find it comforting to know that someday we may be offered a Presidential candidate who actually has intellectual capacities, but it is sad that ''Washington insiders'' believe this to be a negative factor in a future Bradley Presidential bid. STACEY M. HADASH West Caldwell, N.J.

title: More Phones, More Fairness
description: Cheers are in order for New York's Public Service Commission, which has just cut the price of no-frills phone service for welfare recipients. The initiative shows the commission's determination to make service affordable for 300,000 poor New Yorkers now without a phone.

title: Ripples of Change Flutter on Jamaica Bay
description: A PLAQUE at the end of the Canarsie Pier is inscribed with the words of Henry Meyer, a 19th-century developer: ''Jamaica Bay awaits the touch of the magic wand that will transform it into the Wonder Harbor of the World.''

title: Ornate Steins Brimming With History
description: CONNOISSEURS CLAIM that beer tastes better if drunk from a ceramic stein, since the vessel maintains a cool temperature and helps prevent the beer from going flat. Collectors of antique steins, however, may be content to drink from a frosty glass and keep their treasures on the shelf.

title: HISTORY AGAINST METS AND YANKS IN BIDS TO OVERTAKE LEADER
description: THE Mets and the Yankees have more than their inconsistent performances working against them in their efforts to win the division championships, the Mets for the second successive season and the Yankees for the first time in six seasons. As they head into the final five weeks of the season, the Mets and the Yankees, as well as other contenders not in first place, confront the overwhelming reality of history.

title: Our Japan Problem - and Japan's
description: LEAD: When members of Congress return to Washington in September, they will face several decisions that could determine the future of economic and strategic relations with our most important Pacific ally, Japan. We can only hope that a month's vacation has cooled the summer fires that were fanned by the Toshiba Machine Company's illegal $17 million sale of military technology to the Soviet

title: Authorities Act Against AIDS 'Cures'
description: Federal and state agencies have begun aggressive campaigns against manufacturers and distributors that promote as AIDS treatments everything from snake venom to algae, from swamp water to injections of hydrogen peroxide.

title: CRUSADER SWORD CAPTURES HOPEFUL STAKES BY A HALF LENGTH
description: Crusader Sword, nearly scratched because of a sloppy track, charged through the mud to outfinish Bill E. Shears and win the $174,300 Hopeful Stakes today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Study Says Unions Share New York's Economic Good Times
description: Organized labor is riding the crest of economic growth in New York State instead of being swept under by the changes in the state's economy, according to a new state report.

title: Networking
description: EMPIRE William S. Paley and the Making of CBS. By Lewis J. Paper. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: IN DEEP: Country Essays. By Maxine Kumin. (Viking, $16.95.) Maxine Kumin has left the city, fled the suburbs. Trading the interstates for the corrugated dirt roads of rural New Hampshire, she writes from her ''hardscrabble kingdom on a hill,'' a farm that she and her husband have worked for some 10 years.

title: Joan Prescott Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Prescott of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Joan Ellen Prescott to Dr. John Russel Torrisi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Torrisi of Scarsdale, N.Y. Ms. Prescott, a certified psychiatric nurse specialist, is a mental health liaison at the George Washington University Medical Center in Washington. Her fiance is a radiotherapist at Georgetown Hospital and an assistant professor of radiation medicine at the Georgetown University School of Medicine in Washington.

title: Dueling Typewriters
description: Mayor Koch and John Cardinal O'Connor agreed last week on a deal to publish a book setting forth their opposing views on issues such as abortion, child care and homosexuality. Somebody at the Hearst Corporation thinks the work will be a best-seller. The Mayor and the prelate had barely disclosed that they were collaborating on the project when Hearst called to offer a $200,000 advance for the right to publish it. The proceeds, which could go as high as $1 million, are to go to the authors' favorite charities. The Hearst offer was one that ''couldn't possibly be refused,'' said Mayor Koch. It included the rare offer by a publisher to forgo profits, contributing them instead to the charities selected by Mr. Koch and Cardinal O'Connor.

title: Everyone Sees Nathanael
description: RUMOR OF AN ELEPHANT By Alain Gerber. Translated by Jeremy Leggatt. 325 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $17.95.

title: Q & A
description: Winter Warmth

title: His Own Best Disciple
description: THE LIVES OF JEAN TOOMER A Hunger for Wholeness. By Cynthia Earl Kerman and Richard Eldridge. Illustrated. 411 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $29.95.

title: Epic Legends, American Accents
description: Though the British will be amply represented with plays, musicals (notably Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera'') and Peter Brook's epic nine-hour version of ''The Mahabharata,'' this would appear to be far more of an American season than those of recent years, with new plays expected from Lanford Wilson, August Wilson, David Mamet, Horton Foote, Terrence McNally, Beth Henley, Michael Weller, A. R. Gurney Jr., Israel Horovitz and Christopher Durang, as well as a new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine collaboration, the first since ''Sunday in the Park With George.'' From the Sondheim-Lapine ''Into the Woods'' to ''The Mahabharata,'' the season looks as if it may have more than a passing concern with myth, folklore and legend.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Milton Point Clam
description: LEAD: After years of invisibility, the symbol of Rye City's 65-member Milton Point Engine and Hose Company - a clam - has made its public debut.

title: Archie Campbell, 72, Is Dead; 'Opry' and 'Hee Haw' Comic
description: Archie Campbell, the cigar-puffing comedian who served up cornpone humor to ''Grand Ole Opry'' and ''Hee Haw'' television audiences for more than a quarter-century, died early today of complications of a heart attack he suffered June 15. He was 72 years old and lived in Bulls Gap, near here.

title: HISPANIC ARTISTS IN SHOW AT GALLERY IN DOVER
description: THE Blackwell Street Gallery, a cooperative at 32 West Blackwell Street here, gave carte blanche to Lou Martinez Piar when it invited him to organize its current exhibition.

title: Embassy Guard Gets 30 Years
description: CLAYTON J. LONETREE's lawyers said the former Marine sergeant had only wanted to become a double agent and infiltrate the K.G.B. But last week a jury of eight Marine Corps officers sentenced the former security guard at the Moscow Embassy to 30 years for spying for the Soviet Union.

title: Two More Miners Killed in South Africa
description: Two black miners were killed and 16 wounded in a clash Friday at a gold mine in eastern Transvaal province, police officials said today.

title: Charges of Misconduct Dropped Against Judge
description: A special State Supreme Court panel has dropped all misconduct charges against Associate Supreme Court Justice Ernest Gibson 3d.

title:
DINING OUT;
A DISCOVERY IN WALLINGTON
description: LEAD: ESSENCE is the kind of place that restaurant reviewers love to discover - the proverbial hole in the wall or, in this case, modest roadhouse serving creative, often first-rate, food at uninflated prices.

title: A Stop on the D Train: Sand, Sea and Handball
description: New York is a city of many wondrous things. It is a city where an all-Japanese band plays tangos and where Asian Indians run Mexican restaurants. And hard as it is to believe when the air smells of exhaust and the street tar bubbles in the heat, it is also a city with a seashore.

title: Argentina Has First Televised Political Debate
description: Argentina had its first televised debate between political candidates Thursday night, complete with makeup specialists and a talk-show director as moderator.

title: Harvard Tenure Battle Puts 'Critical Legal Studies' on Trial
description: A LONGSTANDING battle that has turned Harvard Law School into what departing professor David M. Trubek called ''the Beirut of legal education'' has flared again this summer because of a bitter tenure dispute. Members of a heterodox scholarly movement known as Critical Legal Studies contend that conservatives at Harvard blocked the tenure bids of two of their adherents, Clare Dalton and Mr. Trubek, because of their political views, an assertion that the school's dean denies.

title: Lawyer Sees Hope for Retrial in Atlanta Murders
description: Newly released police files on Wayne B. Williams contain information that had been denied to defense attorneys in his murder trial and could be grounds for a new trial, his attorney said today.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Jazz
description: LEAD: The Timeless All Stars, who are at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South) Tuesday through Sunday, weren't simply feeling their oats when they decided on a group name. They were recording for Timeless, a European jazz label, and decided to band together for occasional touring as well. But as it happens, '

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION;
description: THERE it was in a corner, staked out by the ski boots and Naugahyde sofas of a church thrift sale: A turquoise (only they called it ''acqua'' then) hand lawn mower, circa 1955. Between the sturdy black wheels hung big grass-stained blades that swirled around themselves like the stripes on a barber shop pole. I have a power mower but it keeps breaking down. I had had enough. Like Mary Ann, Mike Mulligan's outmoded steam shovel in the Virginia Burton children's story, this machine might work, felling the tallest grass in our Popperville with a steady click/swish of her blades.

title: Always in Love With Absolutes
description: WILL HERBERG From Right to Right. By Harry J. Ausmus. Foreword by Martin E. Marty. 275 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $29.95.

title: As the Trade Gap Closes, Beware Inflation
description: DESPITE the poor June trade figures reported earlier this month by the Commerce Department the United States economy is making a successful adjustment to the devaluation of the dollar.

title: DREAM CARS
description: I was very pleased to read Bill Boggs's article about his '56 Fury. Last year, I was fortunate enough to become the owner of a 1963 Mercury Monterey. The trunk could accommodate a Honda, there's enough chrome to dazzle even the most stalwart and, miraculously, the rear window still works.

title: San Diego Expected to Get Cup Series
description: The San Diego Yacht Club is expected to announce this week where it plans to stage the next America's Cup series. Sources close to the negotiations predict that the site will be San Diego.

title: Remember, Addiction Is an Illness
description: I am concerned about the Aug. 2 article by Bernard Mackler on the Opinion page 2 regarding ''excess'' [ ''We Live in a Society of Excess -Why?'' ] .

title: ALFRED PAVLIS WED TO DEIRDRE DALY
description: Deirdre Daly and Alfred U. Pavlis, assistant United States attorneys in Manhattan, were married yesterday at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Risk.

title:
INVESTING;
Jewelmasters: Prospects, Assets
description: LEAD: SINCE going public last year at $14.875 a share, jewelmasters Inc. has put precious little gold into investors' pockets. The shares, which trade on the American Stock Exchange, got as high as $16.50 in 1986, and then sagged to $6.875 last June. The stock was at about $8 last week. Jewelmasters runs leased jewelry counters in about 120 large stores, including ones owned by the Allied, Federated and

title: P. C. Hearn Wed To Suzette Scott
description: At the Point-O-Woods Church on Fire Island, Suzette Vreeland Scott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Spencer Scott Jr. of Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Christopher Hearn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hearn of Oyster Bay, L.I. Bishop John S. Spong of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Charles Ribaudo, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Sri Lanka Struggles to Overcome Centuries of Ethnic Ill Will
description: AS Sri Lanka struggles to pull itself together after four years of civil war, it is contending with an ancient contest between Sinhalese and Tamil claims of legitimacy, nurtured during thousands of years of racial, religious and ethnic conflict.

title: TASTEMAKERS
description: SMILE WHEN YOU CALL AN ART worldling a ''tastemaker.'' There's a disreputable tinge to the word, largely because it seems to suggest power used immodestly and also - well, a certain unserious trendiness. Those with enough clout to make or break taste tend to disclaim the role, and those who are their subjects have a natural reluctance to say so.

title: ANNE MCI. COVER WED TO TOWNSEND RAWLINS
description: The marriage of Anne McIntosh Cover, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. McIntosh Cover of Darien, Conn., to Townsend Gilbert Rawlins took place yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Margaret Minnick performed the ceremony.

title: NEW FACES FOR THE NEW SEASON
description: THEODORA SKIPITARES Puppeteer, age 40. Temperamental actors? This New York director has found a way around that problem. Most of her players are life-size puppets, like Marie Curie (behind screen). Those who missed her humorous look at science, ''Defenders of the Code,'' can see it next month at the Performing Garage. Beyond science? ''The History of Food,'' due next year. GERI ALLEN Jazz pianist, age 30. After creating a stir among the New York avant-garde with her virtuosity and versatility, Allen garnered fans from Paris to Tokyo. Her style encompasses African-derived rhythms and Thelonious Monk's lush harmonies. Her album ''In the Middle'' came out this summer; after a fall European tour, she'll return to the New York clubs. MILCHA SANCHEZ-SCOTT Playwright, age 32. This Bali-born writer (standing) arrived in Los Angeles by way of Colombia and Mexico. Her plays about domestic dynamics are infused with humor and the bizarre. ''Roosters,'' in which cockfighting is the family business, is being filmed for PBS's American Playhouse, and a new work, ''Evening Star,'' is to be staged in New York in the spring. SARAH JESSICA PARKER Actress, age 22. Natalie Wood and Elizabeth Taylor did it, but few others have made the transition from child star to successful adult actress. Parker, who starred on Broadway as Annie, seems poised to make that leap. Last year she played an independent young woman in NBC's acclaimed ''A Year in the Life.'' Now the mini-series is to be a series, featuring Parker. WES CHAPMAN Dancer, age 22. To stand out from a corps, a dancer must be able not only to execute the movements, but also to communicate through them. Last year, dancing with American Ballet Theater, Chapman made it look easy, particularly in the romantic ''Les Rendezvous.'' He'll return to Lincoln Center with ABT in the spring. MARILYN MIMS Opera singer, age 31. This soprano from Collins, Miss., walked away a winner of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions last year, a triumph that helped bring about her debut as Violetta in New York City Opera's ''Traviata.'' In January she'll have her debut with the Metropolitan Opera as Rosalinde in ''Die Fledermaus.'' JOHN HIATT Singer/songwriter, 35. With a new album out (''Bring the Family'') and a national tour this fall (he's at the Bottom Line tomorrow), this Nashville-based musician may get the recognition he deserves. Hiatt's quirky, heartfelt songs, sung in a soulful drawl, combine gospel emotionality with ironic literary edges: Elvis Presley meets Elvis Costello meets Randy Newman. KENT NAGANO Conductor, age 35. Two New York orchestras will follow the baton of this Californian in November: the Brooklyn Philharmonic at BAM's Next Wave Festival and the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center. The double debut reflects Nagano's successes in classical and contemporary repertory, including Robert Wilson's ''Salome'' at La Scala last season. ELLEN DRISCOLL Sculptor, age 34. The organic and the totemic, the flow of life and the rigid form. This New York-based sculptor (seated), winner of a 1987 Guggenheim Fellowship, melds the two in her work (''Sorrento,'' above, is an example), which can next be seen in the spring at the Damon Brandt Gallery. LAURIE METCALF Actress, age 32. She has lately been exploring venues beyond Chicago's Steppenwolf, the troupe in which she honed her considerable skills. Recently she played the earthy Liverpudlian of ''Educating Rita'' in New York. She's made some excursions to Hollywood, too, for this year's ''Making Mr. Right'' and for ''Stars and Bars,'' due out this winter. COURTNEY B. VANCE Actor, age 27. Sharing a stage with James Earl Jones is a formidable prospect. But Vance, in his Broadway debut as the son of Jones's character in August Wilson's ''Fences,'' collected a Tony nomination for the role. This fall, the Detroit-born graduate of Harvard and the Yale School of Drama can be seen in the film ''Hamburger Hill,'' as well as in ''Fences.'' ROB BESSERER Dancer, age 37. Media are frequently mixed in the arts, and Besserer, a dancer who can act (or an actor who can dance), finds plenty of projects that use both of his talents. Martha Clarke in particular has kept him busy, most recently in ''The Garden of Earthly Delights.'' Next March he'll do a turn with Lar Lubovitch's modern dance company.

title: Title Bout Put Off
description: The welterweight title fight between Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain and the challenger, Gene Hatcher of the United States, was postponed by rain today and rescheduled for Sunday.

title: YANKEES SALVAGE A SPLIT
description: The Yankees played a doubleheader last night and won one of the games, but they suffered a double blow nonetheless. They lost the first game and in the first game they lost Rick Rhoden, their No. 1 pitcher.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LIFE IN THE OCEAN

title: Giverny, as Monet Painted It and Lived It
description: It must often rain in Giverny, but somehow one doesn't expect it to. This large garden, and this pink house, will be associated for all time with Claude Monet, the Impressionist painter who is famous for his sunlight, his shimmering poplars, his bright flowers and iridescent sheets of water, for his blurry and brilliant palette - his contemporary critics said of him that he had ''invented light.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: HOMEPLACE. By Anne Rivers Siddons. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) ''Rich . . . deep and complicated'' is the way Anne Rivers Siddons describes how a beloved black maid in ''Homeplace'' felt and smelled to the young white girl she raised. The same words describe a good deal of this novel. In her dramatic story of a prodigal daughter's return to her family's home in Georgia, Mrs.

title: Bork And the Press
description: As law professor and judge, Robert H. Bork has criticized judges who in his view read the guarantees of the Constitution too expansively. On that ground he has denounced constitutional decisions going back 60 years.

title: Out of the Woods
description: The Environmental Protection Agency last week meted out its punishment of Dr. Gary Strobel, a plant pathologist who failed to get permission before conducting outdoor experiments with a genetically altered microbe.

title: HBO Turns To Vietnam's Trenches
description: AMERICAN TELEVISION AND THE VIETNAM War are once again prodding each other warily.

title: CARDS WIN FOURTH IN ROW, 4-2
description: Willie McGee and Lance Johnson drove in two runs each in a four-run first inning and a rookie left-hander, Joe Magrane, snapped a four-game personal losing streak as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Atlanta Braves today, 4-2.

title: Outdoors; New Edition of Book on Decoys Is Timely and Useful
description: THE new edition of William J. Mackey Jr.'s ''American Bird Decoys'' (E. P. Dutton) is both welcome and timely. Welcome because copies of this bellwether volume, first published in 1965, have become increasingly difficult to find, and timely because there has been an astonishing surge of interest in collecting these hunting artifacts, which were once prized only for their utilitarian function.

title: Cebu's Day of Insurgents: The Flag Was Inverted
description: Shortly after lunchtime last Friday, soldiers wearing inverted Philippine flag patches on their breast pockets clambered from a truck and took up positions around the provincial capital building in the center of Cebu City, the nation's second-largest city.

title: SUBSCRIBERS AVOID DISTRESS OF 'SOLD OUT'
description: CONCERT subscribers not only get the best seats and discounted prices, but they can also avoid the frustration of facing a ''sold out'' sign when stars like Luciano Pavarotti and Mikhail Baryshnikov come to town.

title: FOR NEW TEACHERS, EXCITEMENT IS INCREASING
description: LEAD: NO one is likely to be more excited about the opening of school than the new teacher who has his or her own class for the first time. Robin Chanley, a 22-year-old graduate of Misericordia College in Dallas, Pa., is typical.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WILDERNESS. By Liam O'Flaherty. (Dodd, Mead, $16.95.) Liam O'Flaherty, whose best known novel, ''The Informer,'' became an award-winning film in the 1930's, figured prominently in the 20th-century resurgence of Irish writing. Now, three years after his death, ''The Wilderness,'' an O'Flaherty novel serialized in a British magazine in 1927, is having its first American publication.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: LEAD: Sarah Vaughan: Live From Monterey Sony Video Software Company. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: SEASON PREVIEW: DANCECollaborations and Experiments
description: The new dance season promises some extravagant theatrical visions, many of them collaborations of choreographers, artists and composers. At a gala for the Martha Graham Dance Company (Oct. 6 at City Center), Mikhail Baryshnikov and Rudolf Nureyev are to appear together in ''Appalachian Spring'' and Ms. Graham will offer the premiere of a new work set to Stravinsky's ''Symphony in C.''

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: The Iliad Classic Books on Video. Best Film and Video. 40 minutes. $19.99.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE U.S. OPEN, AND WHY?
description: It is most likely that one will find Steffi Graf as one of two remaining competitors in the United States Open, held on hardcourts, a medium of grass and clay. This gives her an even chance against her opponent, whether it be Chris Evert, Martina Navratilova or Gabriela Sabatini. Graf is halfway to completing her best year in her career as a professional tennis player, so far. Her consistent and aggressive backcourt game is supplemented by a strong mental competiveness that will enable her to win the Open. DABNEY HO Queens

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HEARTSTONES. By Ruth Rendell. Illustrated by George Underwood. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Someone's been tapping that cask of amontillado again, and it isn't the Raven. Ruth Rendell, the British author of psychological suspense novels, has tried in ''Heartstones'' to combine the horror story and whodunit. The result, unfortunately, stays all too dead. Blond, anorexic, self-absorbed Elvira, the teen-age narrator, and her plump, dark sister, Spinny (for Despina), a compulsive eater, live near London with their fastidious father, Luke, a widower, in a 15th-century stone house facing the cathedral where he sometimes preaches. Not only the house but the characters are haunted. Spinny sees a cat that walks through doors; Elvira, when she isn't reading Poe by herself, or ''Medea'' in Greek with Luke, lavishes most of her thoughts on her father, whom she idolizes, perhaps for good reason: ''I have been told too often that [ mine ] is a beautiful face. If it is (as I have also often been told) a facsimile of Luke's it must be beautiful''; and Luke seems to reciprocate in an arctic way until he thaws over Mary Leonard, ''a distinguished medievalist'' - emphasis on the evil, it doesn't matter whose. As Elvira chills to her monotonous narrative, there is a death under mysterious circumstances and a suicide. The tantalizing aspect of this book in the Harper Short Novel Series is not the trick ending but the development of Elvira. By the end, the character is no longer a precious, unsympathetic twit but a young woman of some depth and insight. It's too bad she's walled in alive by ''Heartstones.''

title: Palestinian Journalist Dies of Wounds in London
description: Ali Naji Awad Adhami, a Palestinian cartoonist who was shot in the head while walking on a London street last month, died in Charing Cross Hospital today, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Aug. 15 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $605,000 2 Fifth Avenue (8th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, formal dining room, terrace; maintenance $1,400, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Bellmarc Realty) Murray Hill $220,000 155 East 38th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 835-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, remodeled kitchen and bath, washer/ dryer, hardwood floors; common charge $238, taxes $2,748 (Broker:

title: A PENTATHLON fOR RENAISSANCE PEOPLE
description: FIVE years ago, I thought ''triathlete'' meant someone who didn't excel at any particular sport but was willing to try them all anyway. Now I know better and even have friends who make daily sacrifices to qualify for the next swim-bike-run and the chance to compete against a thousand others afflicted with the same obsession.

title: PENN STATION: TALE OF TIRED AND TROUBLED
description: AT 11 o'clock on a recent summer night, a handful of commuters hurried down Seventh Avenue to Pennsylvania Station to catch the next train home to Long Island. At 35th Street, the clock over the station entrance came into view, a few bulbs out, but enough still burning to illuminate the time. As usual, it was about three minutes slow: often the difference between making and missing the train.

title: Opposition in Nicaragua Springs to Life - and Into Disunity
description: NICARAGUA'S 11 legal political parties, which range from extreme left to militant conservative, burst into activity last week as a result of the newly signed Central American peace accord. Most of their energy, however, was directed against each other. For the four other Central American countries who signed the agreement and for the United States, one of its most important stipulations is the call for free elections, to be held under international observation. The assumption is that the Sandinistas would lose at least some power in free elections in Nicaragua.

title: Living With Books, 15,000 of Them
description: IMAGINE living in a library.

title:
WINE;
Restaurants Vary on Proper Service
description: LEAD: RECENT excursions to area restaurants revealed a wide range in the quality of wine service offered. In general, the servers at most of the establishments visited were competent, avoiding much of the pretentiousness one can encounter at some Manhattan meccas of haute cuisine.

title: U.S. AGENT'S CASE STALLS IN MEXICO
description: One year ago this month, Victor Cortez, an agent with the United States Drug Enforcement Administration working out of the American Consulate in Guadalajara, was abducted, tortured and threatened with execution by Mexican state police officers.

title: SHARK REPORTS CLOSE BEACHES
description: HAVING done an extensive amount of scuba diving in areas such as the Caribbean and the Azores, Daniel Merritt of Stamford thinks he knows a shark when he sees one.

title: Amid Gulf Turmoil, Oil's Still a Bargain
description: Oil prices are defying normal trading patterns. With turmoil rampant in the Persian Gulf, oil would normally have gone through the roof as traders became nervous that shipments would be endangered or cut off. But OPEC, that group of bickering oil producers, apparently has been overproducing and ignoring price and quota agreements, and that has led to a glut on the market. Prices fell near $18.50 a barrel in spot trading, but were run back up above $19.50 a barrel in midweek by reports that OPEC was going to meet - even though past meetings have been generally ineffective - and by Saudi Arabian talk about getting tough with Iran, which could significantly affect oil shipments in the gulf.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Development Rides I-78 Into Washington
description: LEAD: OVER the last five years, New Jersey's unparalleled growth has pushed the developing suburbs close to the fringes of the state. Even so, the suburbs are still where most homeowners - in search of more house for the dollar - want to live.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having difficulty removing nonskid decal strips from the bottom of my bathtub. The directions said to soak with detergent, then scrape with a razor blade, but this isn't working very well. What can you recommend? A. Try heating the decals with a hair dryer or heat lamp. This will soften the adhesive backing so that scraping with a razor blade will be easier. When scraping, hold the blade almost flat against the bottom of the tub to avoid scratching and move it back and forth as you push it forward under the decal. Q. Can I use Clorox and detergent on a blacktop driveway to get rid of a green mold that is spreading over the surface at a rapid rate? A. The green mold (moss) can be washed off with a solution of Clorox and water (one part Clorox to four parts water), but adding detergent does not really help much. You can also use one of the fungicide solutions sold in swimming-pool supply stores. Any of these should be kept off the lawn, or washed off with lots of water. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: TRACEY L. WILLIS WED TO THOMAS R. GATES
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., Tracey Lee Willis, a daughter of Mrs. Charles Everett Willis Jr. of Locust Valley and the late Mr. Willis, was married yesterday to Thomas Reynolds Gates, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore Gates Jr. of Princeton, N.J.

title: To Squalor, With Love
description: WHATEVER happened to squalor? While re-reading ''Pere Goriot'' I was struck by the splendid description of squalor in the first chapter. You can feel Balzac's joy - it might be called the joy of description - as he goes through the Maison Vauquer, a boardinghouse for indigents, room by room. It's such vivid writing - and reading - that I found myself wondering about squalor. Though it played such an important part in the work of writers like Dickens and Dostoyevsky, Zola and Celine, squalor seems to be disappearing from fiction, except in the novels and stories of third world, Iron Curtain, or war-torn countries.

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: EARLY this summer, Dr. William G. Cahan, who is no slouch as a conversationalist, hit upon a hostess's dream - a topic that not only kept dinner parties humming but engaged the active interest of almost every guest. Politics entered into it, and even religion, two of the don'ts of social etiquette, and although there was always disagreement, and sometimes controversy, there was rarely anger. It was a perfect subject, serious but not heavy, intellectual but fun.

title: First Vermont Alien Amnesty
description: A native of Montreal has become the first person in Vermont to benefit from the new immigration law. June Mendell, 31 years old, who has lived in Vermont for 16 years, has received amnesty under the act, which allows people who entered the United States illegally to become citizens if they have lived in the country continuously since Jan. 1, 1982. ''This is the most exciting thing that's ever happened,'' said Ms. Mendell, who lives in Lake Elmore. She came to Vermont on a vacation and decided to stay.

title: BUCS SURPRISE REDSKINS, 17-10
description: Steve DeBerg flipped a 4-yard touchdown pass to James Wilder with 1 minute 43 seconds left in the game tonight to give the Tampa Bay Buccaneers a 17-10 exhibition victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: DEFENSIVE STANCE SPREADS TO OFF-THE-FIELD PROBLEMS
description: A dozen of the most successful coaches in the history of the game who are retired or working at another job recently expressed their views of the current state of college football. Some did not like what they saw. Earl (Red) Blaik, the 90-year-old former coach who led Army to consecutive national titles in 1944 and 1945, said, ''The amateur approach diminishes, the absolute lack of scholarship is apparent, and money dominates the moves.'' For coaches, he said, ''salaries are exorbitant.''

title: HONDA IS FIRST ON THE BLOCK TO FLAUNT 4-WHEEL STEERING
description: THE automobile is now 101 or 103 years old, depending on whether you are partial to the German Carl Benz or the Frenchman Edouard Delamare-Deboutteville, both of whom staked credible claim to the invention. No matter who or when, though, the time of the horseless carriage as a high-tech experiment has long since passed.

title: IMAGE AND IDEA
description: OUTSIDE THE LARGELY TRADITIONAL precincts of museums, photography appears to be headed back to the future. In today's vanguard downtown art scene, the medium is playing a role similar to the one it enjoyed in the late 60's and early 70's, when Conceptual art came into full bloom.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Even Out the Moisture Supply
description: LEAD: PLANTS perform best when provided with a uniformly adequate supply of moisture. This is evidenced through both maximum growth and top quality. Since nature's bounty often fails to provide moisture when it is most needed, we must rely on irrigation to supplement precipitation in attaining the desired growth and quality in our plants.

title: OcMober Wedding For Miss O'Leary
description: The engagement of Constance Ann O'Leary to Traugott Francis Keller 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keller 3d of Ridgefield, Conn., and New York, has been announced by the future bride's father, William John O'Leary of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MAKER OF DUNE: Insights of a Master of Science Fiction. By Frank Herbert. Edited by Tim O'Reilly. (Berkley, Paper, $7.95.) Frank Herbert was a country boy turned newspaperman who always aspired to be an author, but even he must have been amazed at how his modest science fiction career went high-frequency with ''Dune.

title: Susan Riordan, Architect, Weds
description: Susan Milligan Riordan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Nickerson Riordan of San Marino, Calif., and Quogue, L.I., and Donald Christopher Lisowy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Lisowy of Little Ferry, N.J., were married yesterday at the Quogue Chapel of the Westhampton (L.I.) Presbyterian Church in Quogue. The Rev. Charles M. Cary performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A video cassette review of ''The Little Foxes'' last Sunday incorrectly described the screenplay. It was written by Lillian Hellman, with additional scenes from Dorothy Parker, Alan Campbell and Arthur Kober.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Trying to Preserve Outdoor Heritage

title: Black Miners Reject Offer
description: In the third week of the nationwide strike of black miners in South Africa, both sides seemed to be holding fast. The 300,000 miners rejected an offer to end the strike, the costliest and most damaging in South African history. It has already severely disrupted production in at least half the country's gold mines and a fifth of its coal pits, and is estimated to be costing the companies between $10 million and $15 million a day.

title: COUPLE HELD IN WOMAN'S BEATING
description: A Rockland County couple were arrested Friday night and charged in connection with the abduction and beating of a Stony Point, N.Y., woman who was found in a ditch in New Jersey last week.

title: Kennedy's Men Relive the Cuban Missile Crisis
description: OUT IN THE TROPICAL night, a winter storm sweeps off the Caribbean, drenching the sea grapes and strangler figs along Hawk Channel, rattling the thatch palms and red mangroves that rim the terrace. Inside the old Florida resort hotel, three television sets glow in the dark, illuminating the sparkling napery of five tables strewn with half-nibbled strawberry shortcake, coffee-stained cups, burgundy in great balloon glasses. Around the tables, spectral figures hunch forward, absorbed by video images of a crisis that ended a quarter century before.

title: SOUND MOVES
description: MUSIC OF CONSCIENCE AND OF CALCULATION, music that honors formulas and that defies them, music steeped in history or blankly up to date, music with a strong regional flavor and music that's sleek and internationalist - all will show up in the coming season of pop, rock and jazz.

title: Becca Davies Plans to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Davies of New York and Redding Ridge, Conn., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Dorothy Rebecca Stewart Davies, to Jeremy Rafael Kramer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Kramer of West Hartford, Conn.

title: JERSEY OFFICIALS IRATE ON HOMELESS
description: Almost a year after New York City resumed placing homeless people in New Jersey hotels, opposition to the practice is rising in this Hudson County town and among county officials.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am having difficulty removing nonskid decal strips from the bottom of my bathtub. The directions said to soak with detergent, then scrape with a razor blade, but this isn't working very well. What can you recommend? A. Try heating the decals with a hair dryer or heat lamp. This will soften the adhesive backing so that scraping with a razor blade will be easier. When scraping, hold the blade almost flat against the bottom of the tub to avoid scratching and move it back and forth as you push it forward under the decal. Q. Can I use Clorox and detergent on a blacktop driveway to get rid of a green mold that is spreading over the surface at a rapid rate? A. The green mold (moss) can be washed off with a solution of Clorox and water (one part Clorox to four parts water), but adding detergent does not really help much. You can also use one of the fungicide solutions sold in swimming-pool supply stores. Any of these should be kept off the lawn, or washed off with lots of water. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE U.S. OPEN, AND WHY?
description: When it comes to the winner it is hard to go against Ivan Lendl and Steffi Graf. Both are now No. 1, dedicated and playing their best tennis. Lendl is also probably the best-conditioned player on the circuit.

title: Mideast Goes Back to the Old Ways of Hating
description: THE great 14th-century Arab historian Ibn Khaldun wrote that life is hard in this part of the world, especially in the desert, where people are dominated by the spirit of the clan and held together by asabiyya - a sense of mutual affection and, perhaps more important, a willingness to fight other clans, to die for each other.

title: A Consumer's Guide to Mental Health Treatment
description: A COUPLE OF GENERATIONS AGO, PSYCHOTHERAPY was an expensive, exotic cure indulged in by a tiny elite, and even as recently as the 1950's only one person in eight had sought it. But today, one American in three has been in psychotherapy, and in 1987, 15 million of us will make roughly 120 million visits to mental health professionals - nearly twice as many visits as to internists.

title: >A SLICE OF THE PAST IN NORTHVILLE
description: THERE'S been so much hoopla about Mary Dugan's restaurant in Northville, in the town of New Milford, ever since it opened last year that we braced ourselves for a letdown as we crossed the threshold.

title: Challenging the Law's Unstated Assumptions
description: In an article titled ''Some Realism About Critical Legal Studies,'' Richard Michael Fischl, an associate professor at the University of Miami School of Law, told how he uses Critical Legal Studies to encourage students to examine what he believes are the unstated assumptions that underlie American law. Following is an excerpt from the article, which appeared in the January issue of the University of Miami Law Review.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: GOSPEL IN PATERSON

title: G.E. Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: MUM AND MR. ARMITAGE. By Beryl Bainbridge. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) These are strange and demanding stories, not easily likable, about a world that is not easy to like. All the savagery, anomie and jarring discordancies that punctuated the British writer Beryl Bainbridge's first book, ''Harriet Said,'' and her subsequent novels and tightly controlled short stories, are concentrated in this selection of 12 stories, previously unpublished in this country.

title: Sidney Worthen Marries David Pearce
description: Sidney Worthen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Worthen of Glastonbury, Conn., was married yesterday in Wareham, Mass., to David Roberts Pearce, a son of Mrs. C. E. Phelps Compton of Monkton, Md., and the late David R. Pearce. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, senior minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, performed the ceremony at Sherburne House, the summer home of the bride's parents and her uncle, John S. Reidy of New York.

title: RECALLING QUAKERS' IMPACT ON L.I.
description: LEAD: IF a people's impact on an area was to be measured only in terms of numbers, then historically the Quakers should have been a religious footnote on Long Island. For despite reaching these shores early on - there was a Quaker among the first settlers in Southampton - the Friends were (and still are) never more than a minority.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error in the program, a review last Sunday of the Glimmerglass Opera Company's production of Benjamin Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' misidentified two members of the cast. Steven Tharp sang the part of Lysander and Kenneth Shaw was Theseus.

title: Gail Schmertz Is the Bride Of Bruce Kerner, a Lawyer
description: Gail Schmertz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Schmertz of Roslyn, L.I., was married at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center there last night to Bruce Kerner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Kerner of Dix Hills, L.I., and West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: House Hunting
description: IN the nation's capital the remarks must have sounded very near to treason, but Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins, said he wanted to find a new home for his National Football League team. Cooke took pains, to be sure, to make clear that he was not dissatisfied with Washington, the Redskins' home for 51 years, but that he was disenchanted with the confines of R.F.K. Stadium, where the team has played to sellout crowds since 1966. The stadium, which seats just over 55,000, is the third-smallest in the N.F.L.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Even Out the Moisture Supply
description: LEAD: PLANTS perform best when provided with a uniformly adequate supply of moisture. This is evidenced through both maximum growth and top quality. Since nature's bounty often fails to provide moisture when it is most needed, we must rely on irrigation to supplement precipitation in attaining the desired growth and quality in our plants.

title: Russian to Join Wife in U.S.
description: A Soviet man who has waited eight years to join his American wife in the United States said today he has been told he will be allowed to leave.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Up to 80 Percent Off On Outdoors Gear Eastern Mountain Sports in Ardsley, better known as EMS the Outdoors Specialists with 30 stores nationwide, has a stockroom inventory clearance with prices 20 to 70 percent off the usual retail charges through Labor Day, including 50 percent markdowns on winter of '86 clothing.

title: PUBLIC IS POLLED ON AIDS
description: While most Americans say AIDS victims ''should be treated with compassion,'' a third of the public says employers should be able to dismiss them for having the disease, a Gallup Poll has found.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a film distributor's change in plans, an article on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section about the film ''Coming Up Roses,'' and a listing in The Guide, section 2A, give outdated information on the film's opening date. The movie will open Sept. 11 at the 57th Street Playhouse.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Harrisburg, Pa.: Enhancing Strawberry Sq.
description: LEAD: COMMUNITY leaders here are hopeful that a $20.5 million expansion of a combined office building and shopping mall adjacent to the State Capitol complex will continue to revitalize downtown Harrisburg while drawing shoppers from the suburban malls.

title: Ospreys Have a Good Friend
description: The Birdman of Buzzard's Bay is busy building osprey nests at the southeastern tip of Massachusetts.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: LIVING WITH THE DEVALUED DOLLAR;
Surplus, Not Shortage, Is Now the Rule
description: LEAD: FIGHTING the last war is a favorite sport in business and financial circles, and today that war is the shortages and near-runaway inflation of the 1970's. The decline in the unemployment rate to 6 percent in July for the first time since 1979 has started yet another battle in that war - fear that the foreign trade balance will improve so rapidly that labor supplies and industrial capacity will be strained.

title: TEACHER BONUSES GET MIXED GRADES
description: LEAD: A NEW statewide program designed to attract and retain outstanding teachers by paying bonuses has drawn a generally favorable response on Long Island.

title: PROPOSALS ON OCEAN POLLUTION ABOUND
description: THE seemingly endless stream of ocean pollution that has fouled New Jersey's beaches this summer has produced a torrent of proposals to combat the problem.

title: Q&A
description: End of a Tax Break Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment and my building receives a tax abatement as part of the J-51-2.5 tax program. It expires in June 1990. Will my rent go up after the expiration date? . . . A. R., Manhattan Answer: The length of your rent-stabilization protection after the expiration of the tax benefits will depend on when you signed your first lease. If your first lease started after July 1, 1985, you lose your rent stabilization with the end of your lease after the building's tax benefits run out.

title: BEYOND HAPPILY EVER AFTER
description: INTO THE WOODS,'' SING THE CHARACTERS in the new musical by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine. ''You have to grope,/ but that's the way you learn to cope./ Into the woods to find there's hope/ of getting through the journey.''

title: WHO WILL WIN THE U.S. OPEN, AND WHY?
description: The odds would say Ivan Lendl, who is the two-time defending champion and currently ranked No. 1 on the A.T.P. computer. The die-hard American tennis fans would say John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors or Tim Mayotte. They are our three highest-ranked men and the only three Americans with a realistic chance to win it all. I, however, say that Stefan Edberg will be the 1987 United States Open men's singles champion.

title: The Value of Pythagoras in the Cockpit
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
Giants
description: LEAD: DON'T ask Phil Simms if the summer training camp is fun. Sure, there's lots of camaraderie, and three square meals a day and adoring fans around every corner - but fun? Not quite, according to the star quarterback of the football Giants.

title: CABLE
description: Ballet buffs have a triple-header treat in store this week: the Bolshoi Ballet's performance of ''The Golden Age'' a welcome reprise of ''The Turning Point,'' and a rare showing of Gene Kelly's ''Invitation to the Dance.''

title: Aging Gracefully (Thanks, Grandma)
description: THE first older people I knew well were my grandparents.

title: ENGLAND'S ENDLESS LOVE AFFAIR WITH FARCE
description: WHY IS NEXT SATURDAY A day that can scarcely be ignored by anyone with an interest in British taste, British audiences, indeed the British drama itself? Not because the National Theater will once again have sold every seat for its thrilling production of ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' nor because the public will be standing in line in case someone returns a ticket for Caryl Churchill's satiric ''Serious Money,'' nor because the scalpers will be out selling seats for ''Les Miserables'' and ''Phantom of the Opera.'' No, Sept. 5, 1987, is the date when the curtain will fall for the 6,761st and final time on the farce ''No Sex Please - We're British.''

title: Washington Feeling Insecure About Non-Secret Information
description: LEAKS of officially classified information are an age-old problem of government. But in the last few years, as computers have become ever more sophisticated and numerous, Federal officials have become increasingly concerned about unclassified data as well. They fear that foreign citizens might harm national security by extracting valuable scientific and technical information from the huge volume of unclassified material accessible in computers.

title: How About a Pair of Loudspeakers Priced at $65,000?
description: I PONDER THE RELATIONS BE-tween price and value after reading an advertisement from a company called Countess Mara, which informs me that it is possible to buy a necktie for $5,000. It is also possible to buy a pair of loudspeakers for $65,000. I can do without the necktie, but this I've got to hear.

title: Sailor, His Hope Fading, Is Plucked From Sound
description: LEAD: JOHN KANTOR of Westport remembers checking his watch as his 30-year-old, 30-foot Atlantic-class racing sailboat, Windsong, slipped beneath the waves. It was 8:58 A.M.

title: WENDY SCHAENEN, INTERNIST, MARRIES
description: Mr. Wendy Schaenen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Schaenen Jr. of Madison, N.J., and Dr. Anand S. Jagannath, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Yedatore Jagannath of Graniteville, S.I., were married yesterday at the Great Hall of Drew University in Madison by the Rev. Paul Ratzlaff, a Unitarian minister.

title: HEARTLAND ROCK: BRUCE'S CHILDREN
description: THE MUSIC IS BASIC - THREE CHORDS AND a back beat. The tone is earnest, plain-spoken, just folks. The verses are short stories, terse sketches of characters trying to get by. And the choruses, ready-made for sing-alongs, are about ''hard times.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Weightless Wordsman
description: Why is it, when Ronald Reagan speaks seriously and makes good sense on the most vital matters, his words no longer carry weight?

title: TOSHIBA COPIERS BANNED IN RETALIATION
description: The Suffolk County Legislature, quite familiar with challenging industries, moved into the less familiar area of foreign policy last week as it voted to remove Toshiba copiers from county offices.

title: Finding the Perfect 'A' Sparks A Pitched Battle
description: IN A DISORDERLY WORLD, THE scene is soothing, almost pastoral: the symphony orchestra, which has been indulging in seemingly random caterwauling and last-minute warming up, falls respectfully silent as all ears bend to the principal oboe's plaintive A. With the authority invested in him by his title of concertmaster, the principal violinist then picks up the tone and passes it to the orchestra. All is peace, unanimity and artistic solidarity. The conductor may now enter and the concert may begin.

title: Players in Manila
description: A group of National Basketball Association players on a tour of the Philippines were witnesses to the fighting in the Manila area.

title: SUSAN E. UTLEY, A STOCKBROKER, MARRIES TIMOTHY PROCTOR SCHIEFFELIN, A BANKER
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., Susan Elizabeth Utley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Dexter Utley 3d of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy Proctor Schieffelin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin 3d of Mount Kisco. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony.

title: Of Ivy and Success
description: COLLEGE COURSES for our time:

title: James Joyce to Rambo III
description: The new season promises to be less silly than most, with an emphasis on substantive social, historical and political subjects. ''Cry Freedom,'' Richard Attenborough's biographical film about the black South African leader Stephen Biko, will be Hollywood's first treatment of apartheid. Robert Redford has directed ''The Milagro Beanfield War,'' about a Chicano community's efforts to protect a tract of land from development.

title: Selling the Fizzle Instead of the Milk
description: WHEN you're producing milk and you're losing sales fast to soda manufacturers, what magic key might help reverse the trend?

title: President Has a Strategy for Ozone Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: PACKAGING BILL PUTS SUFFOLK IN LIMELIGHT
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature, long a bane to some businessmen and politicians, is at it again. Only a month after approving a far-reaching bill regulating video-display terminals, the Legislature is likely soon to become the first governmental body to outlaw plastics for many types of packaging.

title: In Newport, a Debutante Dances All Night
description: IF an indication was needed that old-style opulence is alive and well, the debutante party for Phyllis Trevor last Saturday in Newport should serve nicely. Miss Trevor, is the 17-year-old granddaughter of Eileen and John J. Slocum, whose mansion, complete with ballroom and ancestral portraits dating back to Miles Standish, was the scene of the bash. Five hundred guests began arriving shortly after 10:30 P.M., but before that, the debutante helped her mother, Marguerite, on with her long gloves, cousins hurried to get baskets of fresh flowers in place, and the two grandmothers, Eileen Slocum and Evelyn Trevor, conferred. After nearly two hours of receiving guests such as Noreen Drexel, Countess Anthony Szapary, and William and Eleanor Wood Prince, Miss Trevor took to the dance floor. As the ever-popular Lester Lanin and his orchestra pumped out the tunes, she swirled around the floor with her grandfathers, her dad and her brother. Later, the gloves came off and the Lester Lanin hats went on - as did the orchestra, until the wee hours. By then Miss Trevor needed dark glasses, but no encouragement to keep dancing.

title: Libya Reported to Retake a Key Chad Town
description: In Libya's first reported major victory this year in its war with Chad, Libyan troops have recaptured the northern Chadian town of Aozou from Chadian troops, the Agence France Presse news agency reported today.

title: Nakasone Says Law Permits Japan to Sweep Mines in Gulf
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has declared for the first time that Japan is permitted under its Constitution, which renounces war, to send minesweepers to the Persian Gulf.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Maplewood
description: LEAD: THE view of Maplewood from the raised platform of the N.J. Transit train station in the center of the township is of tall trees and winding roads, green lawns and clean shops and stately old homes set against South Mountain.

title: Tensions Rising Over Draft Charter in Brazil
description: Brazil's armed forces, in their most direct intervention in politics since civilian rule returned here 30 months ago, have strongly criticized the latest draft of a new constitution that is being prepared by a special assembly for a final vote later this year.

title: CHECKING COMPLAINTS ABOUT GARBAGE
description: I read with interest the article of Aug. 2 concerning the Brookhaven Town garbage hot line [ Long Island Journal ] .

title: MONEY IS KEY IN DEMOCRATS' STRUGGLE
description: MONEY and the ability to raise it is a critical issue in a struggle over the leadership of the Nassau Democratic Party that is being played out in the midst of the party's effort to win county and town offices.

title: Colors Go for a Walk
description: THE small tape decks and radios sold under the name Walkman by the Sony Corporation have been a fashionable way to listen to music ever since they were introduced in 1979. Now, Sony is turning them into colorful accessories.

title: East Germans and Rumanians Sharp
description: East Germany won two of the four heavyweight men's events and Rumania captured three gold medals in the women's races on the first day of the two-day world rowing championships on a wind-swept Lake Bagsvaerd course today.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE U.S. OPEN, AND WHY?
description: John McEnroe will win the 1987 United States Open.

title: A Commoner Who Ennobled Royal Subjects
description: THE LATEST TREASURE TO come the way of the Victoria and Albert Museum is an archive of photographs by Cecil Beaton, the fashion photographer, writer and bon vivant who died in 1980. Consisting of some 8,000 negatives and transparencies and more than 10,000 prints, the collection is as remarkable for its subject matter as for its author. For every one of the thousands of pictures in the archive portrays a member of Britain's royal family.

title: ATTACKS BY IRAQIS STIR U.S. CONCERNS
description: The attacks today on two Iranian merchant ships by Iraqi jets have raised concern among United States officials that the pace of Persian Gulf fighting could increase sharply.

title: Milk Dealers' Agreement Raises Concern Over Higher Prices
description: New York State officials said last week they will monitor an agreement raising wholesale milk prices to make sure it does not lead to unwarranted increases in prices to consumers.

title: Next Week; How Should College Eligibility Be Handled?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: NEW THREAT IS SEEN TO AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: THE state's supply of affordable housing, already short, could get even shorter if the owners off thousands of low-and moderate-income apartments decide over the next several years to remove them from the subsidized stock.

title: CRIME
description: The usual things happen in DEATH ON THE ROCKS by Michael Allegretto (Scribners, $15.95). In this first novel a wealthy man dies when his car goes off the road in the mountains near Denver. His wife hires a private eye to investigate; she insists that he was a careful driver who would never have lost control. Nor, she says, did he have any enemies. Jacob Lomax starts looking around. He unearths some unpleasant things in the dead man's background. Little by little he gets a good idea of what actually happened. There is a final shoot-out in which he takes on the killer.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ART IN A FIELD Upon arrival at ''Art Fest in a Field,'' to be held from 4 to 10 P.M. Saturday at an estate in North Salem, visitors will be encouraged to paint a picture, create a piece of pottery, sculpture or kibitz as professional artists demonstrate their skills.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The guys in Boston and the guys in Hartford got together, and they figured out a way to avoid the big bad wolves from New York.''

title: Call It What You Will, It Is Still Child Abuse
description: Unfortunately there is no law against parents who fail to instruct their children about safety on the roadway. There is a law, however, against parents who fail to provide adequate supervision for children too young to play by themselves in areas unprotected from traffic. I would hope that Catherine Henningsen had learned about, and acted on, this law by the time her story was published on the Aug. 16 Westchester Opinion page [ ''A Plea to Parents Who Let Children Play in the Streets'' ] .

title: NEW OSHA RULES GET MIXED RECEPTION HERE
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY labor leaders did not cheer as loudly as their counterparts in other states last week when the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) issued new regulations extending its hazard communication program to cover nonmanufacturing employees.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE ROAD TO TRINITY. By K. D. Nichols. (Morrow, $19.95.) Maj. Gen. K. D. Nichols rode shotgun through the planning, development, testing and use of the first atomic bombs, as well as the articulation of postwar nuclear strategy and the formation of the Atomic Energy Commission (of which he was the first general manager).

title: Outlook for Mozambique: A Drought and a Civil War
description: The rusty ferryboat, loaded with Red Cross supplies and too many passengers, made a serpentine course on what they call the River of Good Signs, chugging past flamingoes and pelicans and lone men in dugout canoes. The boat pulled up to a flat, muddy bank lined by a crowd of people suddenly gathered under the coconut palms.

title:
ANTIQUES;
EXPLORING THE BRANCHES OF FAMILY TREES
description: LEAD: LONG thought of as the exclusive preoccupation of those to whom a distinguished, or at least lengthy, lineage was already known, the study of genealogy has broadened considerably in the last decade to include anyone who is interested enough to explore the confusion of branches on a family trip.

title: Guide to Bangkok Restaurants
description: Americans visiting Thailand for the first time arrive with preconceived notions of how the food will taste: in a word, hot. So hot, in fact, that tourists generally avoid it, choosing instead to eat in their hotels, where the restaurants serve either Western food or some watered-down version of Thai cuisine. The slightly more adventuresome will venture to some other ethnic restaurant, say Chinese, where there will be no surprises.

title: Eileen Naughton Is Married to Craig Allen Chesley
description: Eileen Naughton, a daughter of Mrs. Patrick J. Naughton of White Plains and the late Mr. Naughton, was married yesterday to Craig Allen Chesley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Chesley of Farmingdale, N.J. The Rev. Carol Guilbert, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the White Plains home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Sherman.

title: In Meeting With Pope, Jews See Historic Opportunity to Improve Relations
description: One of the most remarkable meetings in the often troubled history of Catholic and Jewish relations is to take place Tuesday when a delegation of Jewish leaders meets with Pope John Paul II, a week before he travels to the United States for a nine-day visit.

title: Test of Shuttle Rocket Slated Today as Rehearsal Succeeds
description: The first full-scale test firing of the redesigned space shuttle booster rocket, postponed last week because of equipment failures, was set for Sunday after preliminary exercises ''went like clockwork'' today, officials said.

title: Hunters Are Offered Money for Not Killing
description: Three environmental groups have offered to reimburse eight elk hunters for the cost of their licenses if they agree not to kill animals from a small herd in northwestern Minnesota.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Grapes and Starling Wars ''FLOCK! FLOCK! Watch where they go,'' shouted Alex Hargrave, his lanky 6-foot, 6-inch frame almost leaping in the air with anticipation.

title: Transportation Chief Attacks Congress on Safety
description: Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Hanford Dole accused Congress today of budget decisions that endanger the safety of Americans traveling by both air and road.

title: Student Imbalance At Chapel Hill
description: ''ANY time you get over 50 percent, it's becoming more and more a girls' school,'' said one worried trustee said of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: HOME VIDEO: ART
description: Giotto and the Pre-Renaissance ''Museum Without Walls'' series. Narrated by Richard Basehart; produced by Lionella Torossi; directed by Luciano Emmer. Kartes Video Communications. 47 minutes. $14.95.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK'S CHANGING FACE STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: LEAD: IN the last quarter of the 17th century, Europeans settled here on the south bank of the Raritan River. The site - for more than 200 years the main highway between New York and Philadelphia - made this city a hub of commerce.

title: Soviet Afghan Veterans Find They Are the Forgotten Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Closing the Vulnerability Gap at Home
description: WHO pays when your house painter falls off his ladder and is seriously injured? When your babysitter slips on your newly waxed floor? Your dog bites a visitor?

title: Cathy Cramer, Law Student at N.Y.U., And Kenneth David Gibbs Are Wed
description: The marriage of Cathy Ann Cramer, a daughter of Susan H. Feer of New York and Robert S. Cramer of Washington, to Kenneth David Gibbs, the son of Bud H. Gibbs of New York and the late Patricia Kook Gibbs, took place last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin officiated. Ms. Cramer, who will retain her name, is a third-year student at the New York University School of Law. She graduated from the Riverdale Country School and cum laude from Harvard University. She was a youth policy analyst for former City Council President Carol Bellamy.

title: JOHN NICK JR. IS WED TO ALLYSON SACKMAN
description: The marriage of Allyson Theel Sackman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Sackman of Sands Point, L.I., to John Walters Nick Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nick of Sands Point, took place yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Msgr. Anthony Baretta performed the ceremony.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Olympic Series Is Released by South Korea
description: LEAD: SOUTH Korea has issued Series II of gold and silver coins to commemorate and finance the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul. The series dated 1987 comprises six coins, two in gold and four in silver. When completed, four series will include 24 coins, eight in gold and 16 in silver.

title: STATE CRITICIZED ON RIGHT-TO-KNOW ENFORCEMENT
description: LEAD: A COALITION of labor unions and environmental groups contended last week that the Department of Environmental Protection was not enforcing the state's right-to-know law.

title: Under Suspension
description: The Rev. Rose Mary Denman, a 40-year-old Methodist minister who says she was vehemently opposed to homosexuality until she recognized it in herself a few years ago, was hoping that members of a jury of fellow Methodist ministers would also be open-minded on the issue.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 34 in The New Season, part 2 of The Times Magazine today, about a film on Wall Street omitted the identification of the author, Steven Rattner. Mr. Rattner, formerly a correspondent for The Times, is now a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Chancey Greenleaf Bailey, a Banker, Is Engaged to William F. Schmick 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Bailey of Camden, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Chancey Greenleaf Bailey to William Frederick Schmick 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Schmick Jr. of Baltimore. The couple plan to marry Oct. 3.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: LEAD: Janet Baker: Full Circle Kultur. Mono (stereo compatible). Color. 75 minutes. $39.95.

title: At 71, Proxmire Calls It a Career
description: ALMOST everyone who thinks about such things assumed that Senator William Proxmire, the chamber's third most senior member, would seek one final term to cap the 30 years that began when he won a special election to succeed Joseph R. McCarthy. But last week, on the anniversary of his 1957 victory, the Wisconsin Democrat, who is 71, said he would step down in 1988 because he might not be so active through another six years.

title: Paint Helps to Rescue Part of Newport's Past. . .and a Beacon Is Guarded in Maine
description: To the people of this remote village on the easternmost tip of the United States, the lighthouse at West Quoddy Head means two things: it is a romantic symbol of a storied past dependent on the sea and it is hope for a future built on tourism.

title: When Is a Bad Road Good?
description: STRATEGY The Logic of War and Peace. By Edward N. Luttwak. 283 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $20.

title: CORRECTIONS
