description: An article Aug. 2 about Rheims, France, said incorrectly that its cathedral was painted in various lights by Monet. The paintings were of the cathedral in Rouen.

title: FROM TENTS TO BUNGALOWS TO CONDOMINIUMS
description: George Sigiel gets knocks on the door from people inquiring if his house is for sale. Never mind that it is a tiny house that these days, with its partly completed paint job, is half gold and half yellow. Appearance does not matter when your house fronts on Bantam Lake.

title: For Rustlers, Cactus Is the Big Cash Crop
description: THE Case of the Crested Saguaro was a natural for Arizona's cactus cops. When the rare 19-foot cactus disappeared recently, after serving for decades as a living monument in the town of Quartzite, the sleuths at the state's Commission of Agriculture and Horticulture figured that it would most likely be sold in Palm Springs, Calif., or Las Vegas - where the money was. Sure enough, the stolen succulent turned up at a nursery in Las Vegas, with a $15,000 price tag. With the help of the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, the poachers were traced, prosecuted, jailed and fined under Federal laws against transporting stolen property across state lines.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article last Sunday about the Charles Point industrial park in Peekskill incorrectly described the former Standard Brands Plant there. The original complex had 70 buildings.

title: Pewter and Bamboo of Kyoto
description: On Teramachi-dori, a street in central Kyoto, small, elegant shops and coffeehouses mark the strolling shopper's progress toward the Imperial Palace grounds. Antiques shops and purveyors of paper, tea, writing brushes and old books alternate with two-story residences. There, one will find Takano Take Kogei-ten, a shop specializing in items for the sado tea ceremony and goods made of a rare, smoke-stained bamboo. Nearby in a shop called Seikado, Yamanaka Genpei offers pewter vessels have long been used for offering sake to Shinto shrines and in the senchado is not the jade green tea in powdered form that is whisked to a froth in a small bowl in the better-known sado ceremony. Rather, whole green ta leaves are brewed in a small teapot, often made of pewter and served to guests in thimble-size cups carefully balanced on saucers also often made of pewter.

title: Compassion and Recklessness
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW CHILDREN'S WING BEING BUILT
description: THE Monmouth Museum has grown dramatically since it was founded in 1963. Last year 50,000 children and adults visited. The growing popularity has strained its facilities, but a new 5,800-square-foot children's wing is expected to solve the problem.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Bargain-House Dream Falters in Suffolk
description: LEAD: IT was mostly young first-time home buyers who earlier this year streamed into the Bay Coast Associates real-estate agency in Islip in response to advertisements promising new two- and three-bedroom modular houses in the Shirley-Mastic area for bargain prices of under $90,000 - about $10,000 less than similar houses.

title: DITKA AGREEGS TO 3-YEAR PACT
description: Mike Ditka, the Chicago Bears' coach, ended speculation he might leave the team after the 1987 season by announcing today that he had agreed to a new three-year contract.

title: ASSIGNMENT: COMEDY
description: JANUARY 1986: I HAVE RECENTLY fallen into the 1980's bad habit of not returning calls. And it's not because I'm arrogant.

title: Safer Skies
description: 'How do you stay professional? How do you stay vigilant? How do you maintain that razor's edge . . . [ and ] meet that challenge of routine after years and years? . . . The routine is the enemy.'

title: Musical Depicts Harlem of 1930's
description: A MUSICAL about Harlem in the 1930's, ''Little Ham,'' which has been in the works for more than three years, will go into a new developmental phase tomorrow night at the Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut.

title: A Shrub for Blossoms in August
description: SINCE they are providing spectacular bloom now, consider planting lily bulbs either in late fall or early next spring; they require well-drained soil and full sun; soggy ground rots bulbs, the chief reason for disappointment. Cut watersprouts, upright growing twigs, from dogwood trees. Gather seed pods from annuals and perennials. Plant early blooming fall bulbs such as autumn crocus and colchicums. Thin to a thumb-width apart rows of lettuce, chard and spinach. This is a good week to seed or sod a new lawn. A Worthy Shrub

title: Essence Preserved
description: PYGMALION Starring Leslie Howard, Wendy Hiller, Winifred Lawson. Directed by Anthony Asquith and Leslie Howard. Adapted by George Bernard Shaw from his play. Embassy Home Entertainment 96 minutes. $39.95.

title: Beautiful Charmer, Outdoor Pal
description: IMAGING AMERICAN WOMEN Idea and Ideals in Cultural History. By Martha Banta. Illustrated. 844 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $50.

title: A PRICELESS BUT FREE COLLECTION
description: ANTIQUES collectors are a breed unto themselves. Come the first balmy day, they are up and out scurrying the countryside for whatever it is that they collect. Up at the crack of dawn, map in hand, these hearty souls have the tenacity of an English bulldog and the motivational drive of a Vince Lombardi.

title: STEIN VS. KOCH IS LESS LIKELY TO BE FOUGHT
description: The conventional political wisdom is that City Council President Andrew J. Stein is itching to challenge Mayor Koch should he seek a fourth term.

title: Decades-Old Wreck Of Plane Discovered In Valley in Alaska
description: Army specialists will try to identify human remains found in airplane wreckage that lay undisturbed for decades in a remote valley on the Alaska Peninsula, officials say.

title: Luring People Back to Downtown
description: BEFORE the advent of home video and shopping-mall cinema, going out meant going downtown - to the Loop - where the blazing marquee of the Chicago Theater boasted the hottest names in show business. But gradually, as in other big cities, downtown became a district to skirt, not stroll. Fear of crime kept many city and suburban dwellers away, and so did the brand of entertainment - the hard-core pornographic films and the so-called ''action'' movies - being shown in the deteriorating old theaters.

title: Housing Officials' Choice: Asbestos Risk or Arrest
description: Environmental officials say it is dangerous to enter the basement of the old Gertz department store in Queens because of asbestos. But a Civil Court judge in Manhattan has ruled that it may be just as risky not to.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in some copies last Sunday of Joseph P. Lash incorrectly identified the author of the book ''Walter Lippmann and the American Century.'' The author was Ronald Steel, not Mr. Lash.

title: HELP FOR SICK CHILDREN'S FAMILIES
description: LEAD: EACH week a woman from the neighborhood comes and fills the cookie jar. Another keeps the house supplied with freshly cut flowers. A local gardener brings in his crop of tomatoes, and the women from the Homemakers Council are known to stock the freezers with homemade potpies and pans of baked ziti.

title: TANGLESIN THE ANTI-COPYING THICKET
description: A CONSIDERABLE NUM-ber of video fans acquire a second VCR specifically to engage in illegal pursuits.

title: POSTINGS: Century Conversion; New Attempt
description: Conversion attempts are rarely congenial affairs, but the one at the Century, the twin-towered Art Deco structure at 25 Central Park West, has been even more drawn-out and ugly than most. Over the last five years, the Attorney General's office rejected a preliminary offering plan because the sponsor, Century Apartments Associates, had failed to disclose about 140 building violations. In turn, the sponsor, whose principals include Daniele D. Bodini and Nathan Goldman, pressed a suit against the Attorney General's office that was later settled out of court. And the tenants sought, though unsuccessfully, a city administrator for the building.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want them arrested. It's not a question of forgiving. It was not only done against me but against the entire country. You saw how many innocent civilians were killed.''

title:
GARDENING;
How to Even Out the Moisture Supply
description: LEAD: PLANTS perform best when provided with a uniformly adequate supply of moisture. This is evidenced through both maximum growth and top quality. Since nature's bounty often fails to provide moisture when it is most needed, we must rely on irrigation to supplement precipitation in attaining the desired growth and quality in our plants.

title: U.S. Is Found Lagging on Identifying Waste Sites
description: At least 1,882 potentially hazardous waste sites have been found on Federal property but studies have been done on only half of them to determine whether it is necessary to clean them up, according to a Congressional report.

title: FOCUS: Philadelphia; Bargains In Homes Abound
description: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

title: Swatch Watch
description: To the Editor:

title: Groping for a New Order on Trade
description: FORTY-SIX years ago this month, on a warship in the North Atlantic, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill drew up a statement of eight common principles on which they based their hopes for mankind after World War II.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Western Growth

title: Left Behind
description: To the Editor: After reading ''The One Who's Left Behind,'' my wife said: ''Just think. While you're taking a trek out of Pokhara to get a view of Annapura and Dhaulagiri, I could stay home and read a book in bed or visit old friends. What a great ideal!''

title: Nofziger's Defense Attacks Prosecutor Over a Conflict
description: Lawyers for Lyn Nofziger, a former White House adviser charged with violations of Federal ethics laws, suggested today that the special prosecutor in the case might have to disqualify himself because of a serious conflict of interest involving his law firm.

title: CAN'T FOOL MOTHER NATURE
description: sym-bi-o-sis. (simbi osis) n. Biol. The consorting together, usually in mutually advantageous partnership, of dissimilar organisms, as of the algae and fungi in lichens. (Greek: syn: together; bios: life.) - Funk & Wagnalls Encyclopedic College Dictionary.

title: SUSAN LAMB HAS WEDDING
description: The marriage of Susan Condie Lamb, a daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Charles Anthony Lamb of Darien, Conn., to Christopher West Bartlett, a son of Bishop and Mrs. Allen Lyman Bartlett Jr. of Philadelphia, took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien. The bridegroom's father, the Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Walter H. Taylor, rector of St. Luke's.

title: Provincetown
description: To the Editor: William Longgood's article on Provincetown (Travel, June 21) refers to Beach Forest. This sounds like a forest on the beach.

title: GIANTS INTERCEPTED BY JETS
description: The Giants had won their last 14 games - nine regular-season and three playoff games last year and their first two games this preseason. They are the Super Bowl champions. They figured to beat the Jets tonight in their annual exhibition game.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 30, 1987
description: International 3-17 The military was on alert in Manila after the Philippines Government forces put down the most serious armed challenge to the presidency of .orazon C. Aquino. The leaders of the attempted coup were at large. Page 1 Iraq broke an informal cease-fire with Iran on attacks on Persian Gulf shipping with bombing runs on Iranian offshore oil installations that left an Iranian supertanker ablaze and another ship possibly damaged. 1 The attacks on the two ships have increased concern among Administration officials who said they feared an increased risk of a clash between Iran and the United States. 14 Mozambique is in desperate shape, in need of outside aid after being torn by the civil war. Officials stress that the war, combined with unusually dry conditions in the last several months, threatens millions of people. 1 A lawyer for Clayton Lonetree, the former Marine sergeant sentenced to prison for spying, said that the defense would seek to have the sentence set aside because prosecutors had falsely portrayed him as the first Marine convicted of spying. 7 Israeli riot police broke up protests at dusk by hundreds of black-garbed Orthodox Jews demonstrating against the showing of movies on Friday nights, and bursts of tear gas wafted through Jerusalem. 13 Japan could send minesweepers to the Persian Gulf under its Constitution, which renounces war, the Prime Minister declared. But he will not order such a mission because of a risk that they could become embroiled in combat. 16 A dead town is a monument to a disaster 3 2 more strikers killed in South Africa 3 Argentina has first televised debate 6 Weapon issue stirs doubts in Sri Lanka 11 Revolutionary Guards dominate Iran's military 15 Case stalled in Mexican beating of U.S. agent 17 National 20-27, 38-40, 43 Abortion-related activities by family planning clinics that receive Federal funds would be more tightly restricted under proposed rules announced by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. 1 A people-less county's high taxes were established by Nevada's Legislature to make the cost too exorbitant for the Federal Government to use it as a radioactive dump site. But some say the plan has backfired. 1 The home of boys infected with AIDS was destroyed by a suspicious fire, officials said. The boys' mother said that they would be withdrawn from school and that the family would leave DeSoto County, Fla. 1 Fraudulent treatments for AIDS are the subject of a campaign by Federal and state agencies. The Food and Drug Administration has already acted in a number of such cases and California has created a task force to handle the issue. 20 Lawyers for Lyn Nofziger, the former White House aide charged with violating ethics laws, suggested that the special prosecutor, James C. McKay, may have to disqualify himself because of a conflict of interest involving his law firm. 26 The Pope will meet Jewish leaders and thrash out such issues as the Holocaust, diplomatic recognition of Israel, and probably the event that sparked the meeting - the Pope's audience with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria. 20 Dole says budget cuts threaten travel safety 21 New method of diagnosing Alzheimer's disease is announced 24 Government called lax on identifying hazardous dumps 25 Lawyer sees hope for a retrial in Atlanta Murders 26 Regional 28-36, 41-44 The use of illegal drugs appears to be generally decreasing among Americans, but, at the same time, the poor face mounting deaths and an ever bleaker future because of drug abuse, according to government statistics and interviews. 1 The placement of homeless people from New York City in New Jersey hotels is facing rising opposition in North Bergen, N.J. Officials have drafted a letter threatening legal action if the practice is not stopped. 30 In a tenant harassment case, four tenants of an Upper West Side building have been awarded $683,275 from their landlords. Housing authorities found that the landlords had tried to drive tenants out of the building. 35 New York will watch milk prices in light of an agreement between milk dealers and a cooperative of milk farmers to raise wholesale prices. State officials fear unwarranted increases in retail milk prices. 33 A stepped-up police search in Newark for the youths who beat a South Korean official and a relative during a robbery this month was pledged by the Mayor Sharpe James. 36 As the Biaggi-Esposito trial opens tomorrow, the jury will have to prepare to decide whether Representative Mario Biaggi's acceptance of vacations from Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, constituted a bribe. 29 Stein-Koch race seems unlikely 31 Choice: Asbestos Risk or Arrest 34 Brooklyn squatters hold reunion 34 U.S.-Soviet meeting ends 34 Connecticut panel agrees on construction-safety changes 34

title: 'WEST SIDE STORY': STAGING AT ITS BEST
description: THE sharply snapping fingers of sauntering hoodlums set up a menacing rhythm as the Jets and the Sharks, the two street gangs of ''West Side Story,'' take over the Westbury Music Fair's center stage.

title: State of Ploy
description: THE HOTTEST WORD in diplomatic parlance is ploy. When President Reagan and Speaker of the House Jim Wright issued their short-lived peace plan for Central America, doves in the United States promptly dubbed it a mere ploy to help speed aid to the contras when the Sandinistas turned it down. A reporter asked Secretary of State George P. Shultz, ''Is it a ploy?'' Replied Mr. Shultz, in a verbal snippet that made a nice sound bite on all the news shows, ''It's not just a ploy, it's a serious effort.'' Soon afterward, when Central American presidents put their own plan forward, hawks here characterized Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega Saavedra's quick rhetorical acceptance of that as a ploy of his own.

title: T. A. NEVILLE WED TO DARCY PRIME, DOCTORAL STUDENT
description: Darcy Prime, the daughter of Ruth M. Prime of Lake Placid, N.Y., and Theodore F. Prime of Essex, N.Y., and Lake Placid, was married yesterday at her father's home in Lake Placid to Thomas Alexander Neville, a son of Emily Cheney Neville of Keene Valley, N.Y., and the late Glenn T. Neville. The Rev. Everett Gassett, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: LEBANON FOOD PROTESTS SPREAD
description: Protests over food prices spread today from the capital to other Lebanese towns as steel-helmeted Syrian soldiers with heavy machine guns continued to patrol the main shopping centers in mainly Moslem West Beirut to prevent further disturbances.

title: A Better Kind of Dust
description: EVELYN WAUGH The Early Years 1903-1939. By Martin Stannard. Illustrated. 537 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.

title: Talking Assessments; Don't Rely On a Tax 'Estimate'
description: WHEN someone is buying a home - a new condominium, single-family house or even a resale property -certain assumptions are made about the real-estate taxes that will be paid by the new owner.

title: Missiles of October, Then and Now
description: The Cuban missile crisis has become the textbook case of how to win and lose in the nuclear age. According to the lore, President Kennedy went eyeball-to-eyeball with Nikita Khrushchev, and the Soviet leader blinked and removed his missiles from Cuba. Twenty-five years later, the story of the crisis is not so simple and it teaches more than toughness.

title: SHOTS IN THE DARK
description: LEAD: IT'S ONE OF MY CHARACTER DEFECTS that I take everything personally, including this list I have just received anouncing the titles, stars and producers of all the new movies that will shortly be appearing at a selected theater near you and, presumably, me. The list is so fresh from the computer that the pages aren't even separated yet.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Did You Say Pig, or Fig? Children's books were never more judiciously read than when Katharine S. White reviewed them for The New Yorker. This is from ''Onward and Upward: A Biography of Katharine S. White'' (Harper & Row) by Linda H. Davis.

title: F. J. Pagnani Jr. Wed To Amy H. Springborn
description: At Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington, Conn., Amy Helen Springborn, a daughter of Helen Dillon of Greenwich, Conn., and Watch Hill, R.I., and Reynolds C. Springborn of New York, was married yesterday to Frederick J. Pagnani Jr., a son of Virginia Riley of Greenwich and Mr. Pagnani of Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Calvary's rectors, the Revs. Ellen and John Donnelly, who were assisted by Msgr. Thomas A. Guinan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: An American Director Offers A Quirky Welsh Lament
description: WHEN STEPHEN Bayly first gazed upon the cavernous Rex Cinema smack in the middle of Aberdare in South Wales, he saw it as a symbol of the impoverished community itself. ''When I arrived there in 1984,'' the director recalls, ''a miners' strike was on. Now the closing of the mines in Wales is symptomatic of the death of the towns. And somehow this empty, forlorn cinema sitting in the center of Aberdare made the whole thing bleaker still. It was as if in the midst of all this sadness, the town's machine for dreaming had been lost as well.''

title: Opening Statements Due in Biaggi Bribe Case
description: A few days after he was indicted on Federal bribery, fraud and conspiracy charges last March, Representative Mario Biaggi acknowledged to reporters that he had, as the Government contended, accepted a paid vacation from Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Himatsuri (Fire Festival) With Kinya Kitaoji. Directed by Mitsuo Yanagimachi. 1985. (Japanese, with English subtitles.) Lorimar Home Video. 120 minutes. $59.95.

title: Plucking Nostalgia From Defeat
description: Any people needs icons, legends, heroes, but never more than when defeated. As a present garish example, we need look no further than Rambo. The prostrate, despairing South after Appomattox exalted leaders like Lee, Davis and Jackson and rewrote parts so that cameo players would appear as stars, skirmishes as battles and defeats as victories. Southern artists churned out drawings from which printers (many of them in the North) made cards, posters - and money. In THE CONFEDERATE IMAGE: Prints of the Lost Cause (University of North Carolina, Cloth, $32.50; Paper, $14.95), Mark E. Neely Jr., Harold Holzer and Gabor S. Boritt collect and annotate much of this artistic output. The authors, who previously collaborated on ''The Lincoln Image: Abraham Lincoln and the Popular Print,'' often point out inaccuracies, such as a mythic meeting between Grant and Lee before the surrender and the ultimate ''Lost Cause'' depiction (in 1880) of the day in 1864 when Virginia Military Institute cadets, called from their books and drills, charged Union lines at New Market, Va. There are other battles - almost bloodless, of course - and contemporary inspirations, such as ''The Burial of Latane,'' a gentle and genteel, enormously popular 1862 depiction of the real-life interment of a Confederate cavalry captain whose mourners are mainly home-front women and sorrowing slaves. It is hard to remember that most Civil War antagonists thought of themselves more as citizens of Georgia or Massachusetts than as Americans. The best epitaph on that vision was perhaps that of a Virginian who rode with Jeb Stuart and Joe Johnston and remarked to his granddaughter many years later, ''I could not take up arms against my people, but I am very glad we still have a nation.'' This book is a well-researched and interesting sidelight into a world of illusion.

title: Georgine Maniscalchi Wed to John Edwards
description: At Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in New York, Georgine Frances Maniscalchi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Maniscalchi of Massapequa Park, L.I., was married yesterday to John Palmer Edwards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Knight Edwards of Providence and Saunderstown, R.I. The Rev. James Diamond, the bridegroom's brother-in-law, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Barbara Thrall.

title: Melissa Daly Plans to Wed Dwight F. Norrgard Oct. 10
description: The engagement of Mary Elizabeth Daly to Dwight Frederick Norrgard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Norrgard of Greenwich, Conn., and Brownsville, Vt., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Spencer Daly of Greenwich. The couple plan to marry Oct. 10.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bay View, Mich.; A Concession For Innkeepers
description: WHEN Patrick Barbour and Frank Shumway bought the 76-year-old Terrace Inn here last Dec. 15 they immediately began an extensive renovation coupled with an effort to stay open the year-round.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DECADE OF THE YEAR. By Ellis Weiner. (Dutton, $17.95.) Ellis Weiner and the 80's have agreed to disagree. This 60's-rooted acerbic sociopolitical humorist has collected a group of sharp, complex and well-observed humor pieces, many of which have been seen previously in the best printed neighborhoods.

title: Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $337,500 68 Frame Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old clapboard ranch; playroom, 1 acre; taxes $5,844. Hartsdale, N.Y. $310,000 8 Hood Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; family room, 2-car garage, cul de sac, walk to schools; taxes $5,929. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $138,000 2794 Hickory Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 53-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, brook, level .5 acre, walk to station; taxes $1,701. Avon, Conn. $410,000 23 Daventry Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; vaulted ceilings, 1 acre; taxes $4,065. Hartford, Conn. $175,500 75 North Beacon Street 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, turn-of-the-century colonial, built 1898, stained and leaded glass windows, fine woodwork detailing, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,267. New Canaan, Conn. $850,000 64 Cross Ridge Road 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; tennis court, 5-stall horse barn, 4.1 acres; taxes $4,803.

title: THE GENERATION TALENT FORGOT: A LONG ADULT MUSICAL CAREER
description: LAST week, as I discreetly dabbed at an emotional tear of joy at my sixth grader's violin concert and inwardly forgave him for getting a D in the subject I teach, I also reflected on my own long and ignorable adult musical career.

title: Referrals Grow to Meet Need
description: LEAD: ''THE services are here in Westchester; the problem is letting people know how to get to them,'' said Ann B. Spaeth, executive director of the Family Information and Referral Services Teams, known as First.

title: Grasping the Nation by the Scruff of Its Neck
description: FREEDOM SONG A Personal Story of the 1960s Civil Rights Movement. By Mary King. Illustrated. 592 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: HOW TO REPAIR METAL FASTENERS
description: STRIPPED or damaged threaded fasteners are a nuisance, especially when you encounter them on hard-to-replace appliance parts, cabinet hardware, furniture fasteners and other items for which substitutes are not likely to be found in hardware stores. There's a remedy, however. You can rethread existing fasteners or even make new ones yourself using taps and dies, precision hand tools for cutting threads in metal.

title: HOMEOWNER'S BLUES: WAITING FOR A CALL
description: SOMEWHERE back in the dark recesses of the 40's (and surely before), when decorum dictated that girls didn't phone boys for dates or for any reason, a common pastime for young females was ''waiting for the phone to ring.''

title: CONTRACT TALKS VARY WIDELY
description: LEAD: EXPERTS on school contract negotiations say there are few common denominators from district to district in New Jersey's current bargaining sessions, but concerns over retirement benefits and the effects of the Minimum Teacher Salary Law have created what may become trends.

title: Fundamentalists Lose on Texts
description: While they have been frustrated in their attempts to have prayer and creationism allowed in public schools, many fundamentalist Protestants feel that an enemy religion called secular humanism has been allowed to slip through the door. Through textbooks - the only publications that people can be legally required to read - schools are teaching a creed in which man, not God, is the center of all things, the fundamentalists believe. This, they say, violates freedom of religion, as surely as if students were forced to read the Bible or the Koran.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Even Out the Moisture Supply
description: LEAD: PLANTS perform best when provided with a uniformly adequate supply of moisture. This is evidenced through both maximum growth and top quality. Since nature's bounty often fails to provide moisture when it is most needed, we must rely on irrigation to supplement precipitation in attaining the desired growth and quality in our plants.

title: Weapon Issue Stirs Doubts In Sri Lanka
description: One month after a peace accord was reached in the Sri Lankan civil war, leaders of the most powerful Tamil guerrilla group say they have reluctantly surrendered all their weapons. But the statement is being met with skepticism in many quarters.

title: Connecticut Panel Will Urge Construction-Safety Changes
description: A panel reviewing a building collapse that killed 28 construction workers in Bridgeport has informally agreed to seek sweeping changes in the way Connecticut enforces building codes and construction safety.

title: POSTINGS: Brownstones; Sales Drop, Prices Rise
description: Sales of Manhattan brownstones dropped off considerably in the first half of the year, falling to 149 from the 199 recorded in the first six months of 1986 and even farther from the 341 in the second half of last year. At the same time, the average sale price of a brownstone - the term is used loosely for a town house of any material originally built as a single-family home - edged up by more than $200,000 this year to a two-year high of $837,000, according to a survey done by Douglas Elliman-Haldenstein, a Manhattan brokerage.

title: 2 FESTIVALS STRIVE FOR FRESHNESS
description: LEAD: HISTORY isn't the only thing that repeats itself; unless extraordinary measures are taken, performing arts festivals can face the perils of repetition, too. And as Labor Day weekend approaches, bringing with it the Nassau County Celebration of the Arts in Roslyn Harbor and the Jewish Arts Festival of Long Island in

title: Partners in Politics
description: A WOMAN OF EGYPT By Jehan Sadat. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: SCHOOLS TO BE FOCUS OF PROGRAM ON DRUGS
description: A NEW program by state and local police to educate pupils as young as kindergarteners about drugs will get under way this school year.

title: The Joys of Skiathos
description: LEAD: TALES FROM A GREEK ISLAND By Alexandros Papadiamantis. Translated by Elizabeth Constantinides. 176 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $16.95.

title: The Majestic Canada Goose Is Wearing Out Its Welcome
description: THE end of summer approaches, and wildlife officials are turning their thoughts to a resumption of the battle against one of suburban America's newest and most ardent admirers, the Canada goose. Strong and handsome, with their characteristic white ''chin strap'' markings, tens of thousands of these big birds have in a few recent years used the region's manicured lawns, artificial ponds, bird feeders and suburban antihunting ordinances to cease their normal migrations, multiply their numbers and acquire a reputation as dirty, aggressive pests.

title: 32 People Found Dead In South Korean Plant
description: Thirty-two people, some of them children and most of them bound and gagged, were found dead in a factory today, news reports said.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Burlingon, Vt.: Yielding To Developers
description: LEAD: RAPID development and soaring land values are helping to create a growing class of tenant farmers in the Champlain Valley.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: The Learning Tree With Kyle Johnson, Alex Clarke, Estelle Evans and Dana Elcar. Written and directed by Gordon Parks. 1969. Warner Home Video. 107 Minutes. $59.95.

title: BEARING WITNESS
description: IT IS AN AFTERNOON DURING THE trial of former Gestapo chief Klaus Barbie, accused of committing crimes against humanity in France during World War II. I have come to the courtroom in the company of Marcel Ophuls, the French-American film maker who is finishing his first major movie in a decade - a documentary entitled ''Hotel Terminus: The Life and Times of Klaus Barbie.''

title: October Wedding For Lynn Taylor
description: Capt. and Mrs. Allen J. Taylor of Governors Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Claire Taylor, to Jeffrey Pierce Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Alden Anderson Jr. of Fair Haven, N.J. The couple plan to marry Oct. 10.

title: TURKISH AND OTHER DELIGHTS
description: YOU MAY NOT HAVE NOTICED it, but quite a lot of New Yorkers are spoiled. ''What's new?'' they always ask. But when you tell them, they say ''I've seen it,'' ''I've heard it'' or ''I've read it.'' ''And besides,'' they say, ''it's flawed.''

title: Rock for the Record: Unsung Studio Bands
description: JOHN FOGERTY WAS remembering his 60's band Creedence Clearwater Revival the other day. ''We were pretty good,'' he allowed, ''but we weren't the greatest rock-and-roll band in the world.'' This raised the inevitable question: Who was? ''Booker T. and the M.G.'s,'' said Mr. Fogerty unhesitatingly.

title: The Stage Dining Table: Food for Thought
description: IT WAS A MOMENT I HAD BEEN subconsciously waiting for, and when it arrived, I was not surprised. It happened during the latest Neil Simon play, ''Broadway Bound.'' Early in the second act, the American playwrights' collective love affair with the dining table - that focal point of the Middle American home - comes to its sentimental apotheosis. Kate, the mother (played by Linda Lavin), defines for her son Eugene (Jonathan Silverman) her loving relationship with the dining-room table.

title: RAISES FOR TEACHERS START TO PAY OFF
description: WHEN schools in Sterling open tomorrow, students will see one of the major effects of the state's new Education Enhancement Act -there will be a permanent teacher in every classroom.

title: LONETREE DEFENSE CITES OTHER SPIES
description: A lawyer for Clayton J. Lonetree, the former Marine sergeant sentenced to 30 years in prison for spying while a member of the American Embassy guard in Moscow, said today that the defense would seek to have the sentence set aside on the ground that prosecutors had ''falsely and emotionally'' portrayed the defendant as the first marine ever convicted of spying.

title: Changes at General Foods Usher In a New Corporate Mood
description: LEAD: IN 1954 the General Foods Corporation moved its corporate headquarters from midtown Manhattan to White Plains. Other major companies followed, and their relocations helped the county weather the recessions of the late 1970's and early 1980's.

title: Film
description: Shorter days. Longer nights. Dipping temperatures.

title: A World In Miniature In Yorkshire
description: The fascination of craftsmanship on a miniature scale is universal, attracting the sophisticated and unsophisticated alike. The 1920's and 30's were a heyday for collecting miniature furniture in Britain and saw the formation of three principal assemblages: Queen Mary's Dolls' House at Windsor Castle, Titania's Palace at Wookey Hole in Somerset and the Carlisle Collection of Miniature Rooms at Nunnington Hall in Yorkshire.

title: Late Rains in India Ease a 2-Month Drought
description: Heavy rains lashed much of the drought-stricken areas of northern, western and central India Friday night and today, bringing relief and fresh hope to millions who had suffered in two months of drought.

title: STRANGE RETAINS 2-SHOT LEAD IN SERIES
description: Curtis Strange shot a 68 today and retained a two-stroke lead after the third round of the $800,000 World Series of Golf.

title: BIT OF OLD WEST CALLS THE EAST HOME
description: LEAD: EVERY Saturday night during the summer this Salem County community is transformed into Cowtown, an anomolous bit of the Wild West in the East.

title: Soviet Ethnic Minorities Take Glasnost Into the Streets
description: WHEN Mikhail S. Gorbachev called last February for ''a revolution of expectations'' in the Soviet Union, he probably did not have in mind the crowd that gathered here in Lithuania last Sunday to chant ''Freedom! Freedom! Freedom!'' and sing nostalgic songs of pre-Soviet independence.

title: PROSECUTOR'S OUSTER RAISES CONCERN
description: THE dismissal of a special prosecutor investigating accusations of police corruption in Suffolk County has touched off a debate about his future successor's ability to conduct a thorough and independent inquiry.

title: Talks With Lions
description: MY PRIDE AND JOY By George Adamson. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Christie's 'Indians': 10, 9 and So On
description: ''TEN little Indian boys going out to dine, one choked his little self and then there were nine,'' is the first verse of a Mother Goose rhyme as well as the indication of the first of several murders in Agatha Christie's thriller ''Ten Little Indians,'' now receiving a barely adequate staging at Theater Three.

title: DRUG-ABUSE ACTION IS NEEDED NOW
description: BEFORE last November's elections, when opinion polls showed that drug abuse was the nation's No. 1 concern, surpassing even fear of nuclear war, drug abuse emerged as one of the biggest issues throughout the country. Many politicians, including President Reagan, expressed their concerns about the poisonous influence of drugs on American society.

title: For the Patient Reader, Military Secrets Are Self-Revealing
description: FROM the wealth of authentic detail in his best-selling novels about superpower brinkmanship, many people assume that Tom Clancy must have served in the armed forces.

title: VOICES FROM THE BARBIE TRIAL
description: The Klaus Barbie trial was not carried out to determine the guilt or innocence of a man; he was certainly guilty (''Voices From the Barbie Trial,'' by Ted Morgan, Aug. 2). The real value of the trial, as Morgan reports, is the publicity given to the victims who have survived to tell their horrifying stories. Survivors such as Elie Wiesel, Pierre Durand and Serge Klarsfeld know, firsthand, what happened.

title: Gardens Rise Where Rubble Once Held Sway
description: ROSALIE ARCHER'S corn sways high as a man, while Lawrence Bailey's cabbages are the size of basketballs. On weekends and evenings these city farmers join their neighbors to pull weeds and harvest crops at a formerly rubble-strewn lot in downtown Yonkers that has been transformed into a community vegetable garden.

title: Toting Up the Victories - and Problems
description: TIME was when all eyes were on Scandinavia and its ''middle way''. Marquis Child's book on ''Sweden: The Middle Way'' was a best seller for some years after its publication in the 1930's.

title: New Clash in Jerusalem on Films on Sabbath
description: Israeli riot policemen broke up demonstrations at dusk today by hundreds of rigorously Orthodox Jews protesting the showing of movies on Friday nights. Bursts of tear gas fired by the police wafted through Jerusalem from the clashes.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: James Hoch Wed To Mary M. Camp
description: Mary Merwin Camp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Mattis Camp of Champaign, Ill., was married there yesterday to James Stevenson Hoch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Standley Howard Hoch of St. Louis. The Rev. Malcolm E. Nygren performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Not Just a Pretty Face
description: I LOOK DIVINE By Christopher Coe. 109 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $12.95.

title: Church Land Sold for High-Priced Condos
description: SOME of Westchester's most scenic sites, several overlooking the Hudson River where nuns and priests used to care for Roman Catholic orphans and troubled children, are now being developed for high-priced condominiums.

title: OSHA
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Orange, Mass.: Do-It-Yourself Home Builders
description: LEAD: THEY have worked on frigid winter nights and in the heat of summer to build a dream - their own home. Now, Ted Matteson and his wife, Terry, are on the threshold of realizing that dream.

title: Arts Are No Longer Only for Urbanites
description: IN the small towns and cities that have long played a cultural second fiddle to the major metropolitan centers, the arts have begun to flourish conspicuously.

title:
INVESTING;
Can Merck Continue Its Long Advance?
description: LEAD: IF the bull market of the 1980's could be represented by one stock, Merck would likely be it. Like the United States stock market early in this decade, Merck was considered boring and unattractive. But since August 1982, it has advanced more than 500 percent, making it the second-best performing component of the Dow Jones industrial average, behind F.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Svensson Surprises Leconte: Unseeded Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden scored his third straight upset in the $150,000 Hamlet Challenge Cup in Jericho, L.I., by beating seventh-seeded Henri Leconte of France, 6-3, 6-3, in a semifinal match yesterday. Eighth-seeded David Pate of Las Vegas, Nev., won the other semifinal, beating unseeded Paul Annacone of Bridgehampton, L.I., 7-6, 6-4. In previous rounds, the 20-year-old Svensson, who is ranked 25th in the world, eliminated Anders Jarryd of Sweden and Pat Cash of Australia. Leconte was unable to crack Svensson's service in the match and lost his three times. (AP) Lundgren Defeats Krishnan: Peter Lundgren of Sweden beat Ramesh Krishnan of India, 6-2, 7-5, yesterday to reach the finals of the Nynex Open in Rye Brook, N.Y. Lundgren will oppose John Ross of Gainesville, Fla., in the final. Ross, a former all-American at Southern Methodist, rallied for a 1-6, 6-2, 6-2 victory over Richard Matuszewski of Hopewell Junction, N.Y. The victory over Matuszewski enabled Ross to reach the final of a Grand Prix event for the first time.(AP) Hanika Advances: Sylvia Hanika of West Germany reached her second tournament final of the year with a 6-4, 2-6, 6-2 victory over Lori McNeil yesterday in the $150,000 United Jersey Bank Classic in Mahwah, N.J. Hanika, who was seeded sixth, needed 2 hours 4 minutes to defeat McNeil, who was seeded fourth. In the other semifinal, third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria defeated her younger sister, Katerina, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) HARNESS RACING Tabor Lobell Wins Challenge Cup: Tabor Lobell, a 25-1 shot driven by Buddy Gilmour, held off Callit of Sweden last night to capture the $100,000 Challenge Cup, a mile-and-a-quarter invitational trot at Roosevelt Raceway. The 4-year-old son of Speedy Crown-The-Pro raced third over most of the event, but caught Callit, winner of the International Trot last week, at the head of the stretch. The two went neck and neck to the finish, and Tabor Lobell won by a head, covering the course in 3:03 3/5. Whip It Wood, driven by John Patterson Jr., took third. Tabor Lobell's victory, only his second in 12 races, was worth $50,000 and pushed his career earnings to $199,095.

title: CLAMBAKES FOR THE YARD OR PARKING LOT
description: IT was time to start dinner, so Gene Goldsmith began hauling shovels, cinder blocks, seaweed, a 200-pound steel plate and other necessary items from a van.

title: Newark Intensifies Search in Assault on 2 Koreans
description: Mayor Sharpe James of Newark has pledged a stepped-up police search for the teen-agers who severely beat a South Korean official and a relative in a street robbery earlier this month. The Mayor compared the severity of the crime to last year's attack in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: West Side's New Road To Ornament Manhattan?
description: THE West Side waterfront, whose shabbiness somehow became all the more unattractive during the more than 15 years of controversy over Westway, is potentially a second Central Park. When Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced last weekend that they had agreed to proceed with a more modest West Side roadway and adjoining waterfront esplanade, they presented the city with an extraordinary opportunity to create in Manhattan, long walled off from the water by its own roads and maritime industries, one of the most magnificent big-city waterfronts in the world.

title: NUCLEAR BACKERS IGNORE REALITIES AND CRY WOLF
description: Herbert Jaffe tries to push for the opening of the Shoreham nuclear plant the same way Lilco has been doing for years. That is by blowing smoke and crying wolf at the door.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
GRAY CATBIRD
description: LEAD: Dumetella carolinensis Size: Eight to nine inches.

title: JUDGE DROPS SUITS OF MARSHALL ISLES
description: A Federal judge has dismissed the suits of Marshall Islanders seeking damages from nuclear tests after Government lawyers argued that the United States had already paid $150 million to the islanders to handle the claims.

title: MARTINI REDUX
description: AS SOON AS THE DESERTER Frederic Henry, the hero of ''A Farewell to Arms,'' concluded his ''separate peace,'' he celebrated his escape from the barbaric world of war with a fine meal. ''The sandwiches came and I ate three and drank a couple more martinis,'' he said. ''I had never tasted anything so cool and clean. They made me feel civilized.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TRAITORS AND HEROES: A Lawyer's Memoir. By Martin Garbus. (Atheneum, $19.95.) At the treason trial of 12 members of the African National Congress, a black Government witness suddenly breaks off his rehearsed testimony and tells the hushed spectators of police brutality and torture. No one interrupts, but immediately afterward, he disappears forever into South Africa's dark history.

title: BILL BRADLEY'S QUALIFICATIONS
description: In explaining why he is not running for the 1988 Democratic nomination for President, Bill Bradley says: ''Winning is not enough. We need to govern, too'' (''Why Bradley Isn't Running,'' by Randall Rothenberg, Aug. 2). Senator Bradley's decision, considering he has the political punch to make a strong run, shows a compelling thoughtfulness about what it means to function effectively as the nation's Chief Executive. There should be nothing ''potential'' about the ability to be President. There is no office for a Presidential trainee.

title: Japan by Rail
description: To the Editor: Patricia A. Langan's article ''A Pass to All Japan'' (Travel, June 28) was most informative. Having traveled extensively by railroad throughout Japan, I would like to share some further thoughts on the subject.

title:
RECORDINGS;
English Music-Tradition Individualized
description: LEAD: TRADITION, RATHER THAN IN-novation, has long played a dominant role in English music, and has served as a source for a distinctive national style. A full-textured choral tradition, stretching back as far as Dunstable and Tallis, received new impetus from the odes of Purcell and the oratorios of Handel; it was kept alive in the 19th century by countless cathedral choirs and amateur societies.

title: 13 Artists Awarded $15,000 State Grants
description: THIRTEEN New Jerseyans have been named ''distinguished artists'' and awarded fellowships of $15,000 each by the State Council on the Arts.

title: U.A.W. Sees a Danger From Supplies Abroad
description: Owen F. Bieber, the president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that the increasing reliance of American auto manufacturers on overseas suppliers was exposing the industry to greater risks and depriving Americans of jobs.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: She's Gotta Have It Written, edited and directed by Spike Lee. 1986. Key Video. 84 minutes. $79.98.

title: HOME VIDEO: DANCE
description: LEAD: Ailey Dances Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Kultur. 85 minutes. $39.95.

title: For Latins: Leadership Seminars
description: HISPANIC representation on state, county and municipal governmental bodies accounts for a little more than 1 percent of New Jersey's population of Hispanic descent, according to a nonprofit group here that is working to increase that proportion by reaching out to professionals.

title: Eagle Reportedly Seeks Drug Help
description: Alonzo Johnson, the Philadelphia Eagles' second-year linebacker, has left the team with the intention of entering a drug rehabilitation center, The Philadelphia Daily News reported today.

title: Disabled People: By Land, By Sea
description: Getting off the ground is difficult enough for the disabled traveler. But in fact, say experts in the field, getting around on the ground in this country is an even greater accomplishment. ''There are just not many cities that have extensive, accessible transportation systems,'' said Terry Moakley, director of barrier-free design for the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association.

title: CRISIS AT THE TOP FOR CENTURIES-OLD FARM By RALPH GINZBURG
description: WHAT appears to be Connecticut's oldest family-owned farm, passed on for 324 years from father to son, is facing a crisis: the only member of the younger generation willing to run it is a daughter.

title: Mayoral Campaign Grows Spirited
description: LEAD: ELECTION DAY could be tomorrow the way the race for mayor of New Rochelle has already heated up.

title: Corporate Naivte
description: The mortgage department of a large savings and loan orders one of its chief officers, 58 years old, to take early retirement or be dismissed. Discovering that he is being replaced by a younger man at a lower salary, the officer sues the bank, charging age discrimination. He also plans to sue for damages on the ground of emotional distress.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Newark Collaboration Group will accept applications through Friday from city residents for a free 14-week leadership training course conducted by the Coro Foundation to be held Sept. 28 through Jan. 28. Most sessions will be in the evening, but some, including a weekend retreat Oct. 9 through 11, will be during the day.

title: MS. LOOMIS WED TO J. E. NEUHAUS
description: Cynthia A. Loomis and Joseph E. Neuhaus, 1979 graduates of Dartmouth College, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gottfried Neuhaus, in Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Marilyn Batchelder, a Congregational minister, officiated.

title: For Llama Lovers
description: ALL ABOUT LLAMAS: LLAMA BASICS Taylor/Gavin Communications, Box 4323, Bozeman, Mont. 59772. 37 minutes. $39.95, plus $2 postage.

title: For John Ritter, Playing The Comic Isn't Enough
description: FRED ASTAIRE HAD IT. CARY Grant had it. It is that rarest of on-screen attributes: the ability to break new ground, to grow artistically, while appearing to the public as effortlessly entertaining. For the past decade or so, Hollywood insiders have suspected that a man named John Ritter - primarily a commercial TV actor, of all things -has more than his share of it, too.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Atlanta;
5-Tower Plaza For Buckhead
description: LEAD: BUCKHEAD, an affluent neighborhood six miles north of downtown that was annexed to this city in 1953, has always maintained an air of understated elegance.

title: In Politics, Money Is the Root of Campaigns
description: MONEY, or rather the lack of it, is being blamed for drying up several Presidential candidacies this year. But money problems are a result of a sputtering campaign at least as often as they are a cause, political analysts say.

title: Move to Cut Medicaid Spending on Drugs Is Called Harmful
description: Poor people with serious health problems may stop getting vital medicines if states try to limit the number of prescriptions they can receive under Medicaid, a new study says.

title: >Holland Sweet Is Wed
description: Holland Atherton Sweet, an assistant beauty and fitness editor at Vogue magazine, was married yesterday to Robert James Burt, president of Sports and Specialist Cars in Trenton. The Rev. William Zito performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Watertown, Conn. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Stedman G. Sweet of Watertown, and Mr. and Mrs. S. Charles Burt of Tunbridge Wells, Kent, England. The bridegroom's two previous marriages ended in divorce.

title: A View From Her Own Place
description: ADAM & EVE AND THE CITY Selected Nonfiction. By Francine du Plessix Gray. 396 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Instant Replay: A Nuisance
description: IT sounded like a terrific idea: instant replay to second-guess officials.

title: ARRESTS RISE FOR VIOLENCE IN THE HOME
description: LEAD: THE number of cases of domestic violence that have reached Connecticut courts has increased 99 percent in the first nine months of a new law that requires an arrest when a crime is committed in the home.

title: Actor's Condition Worsens
description: The actor Lorne Greene has developed pneumonia after undergoing abdominal surgery and his condition has deteriorated from fair to serious, a spokesman at St. John's Hospital here said today. Mr. Greene, the 72-year-old star of ''Bonanza'' and ''Battlestar Galactica,'' underwent surgery for a perforated ulcer on Aug. 19.

title: The Windfall Profits in Insider Flips
description: JAMES AND JOAN DRUKER purchased their Upper West Side apartment last April for $178,000. In June, they signed a sales contract to sell it at a $222,000 profit. Another couple, Eric and Carol Michaels, bought their Greenwich Village apartment in the early spring and sold it three months later, making $80,000.

title: A Daughter Lost to Faith
description: LOVINGKINDNESS By Anne Roiphe. 279 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: Prosecutors Sue the Bonannos
description: In an unprecedented use of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, Federal prosecutors last week filed a civil suit aimed at breaking up the Bonanno organized-crime family in much the same way the Government once used the Sherman Antitrust Act to break up the Standard Oil trust.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph in the Travel Advisory column July 19 accompanying an item about bonefishing on Christmas Island misstated the kind of fish shown. it was a golden trevally.

title: CITY LIFE VS. SUBURBAN SERENTIY
description: LIKE you, I have friends who have recently moved to the city. ''We're free!'' they proclaimed one day while visiting. ''You mean living in the suburbs was like being in prison?'' I asked. ''No, don't get us wrong,'' they replied. ''The suburbs are great while the kids are still - kids. But now they're out on their own, it's our turn to live a little.''

title: Sculptural Gateway to City Hall Is Rising in Mt. Vernon
description: THE thousands of Mount Vernon residents who enter their Colonial-style City Hall building each week have a surprise coming.

title: Publisher, Investigated by the Police, Is Outraged
description: The police in this small town investigated the publisher of a weekly newspaper as a possible child molester, according to the contents of a police file.

title: SON IN A BAND? COUNT YOUR (MIXED) BLESSINGS
description: MY son's rock group won the ''Battle of the Bands'' at the high school. For him, this signifies public recognition of talent and hard work. For me, this demonstrates that his chances of winning fame and fortune are now only slightly better than his being drafted as outfielder for the Yankees.

title: WISE UP TO REAL TV
description: O.K., SNOBS, LISTEN UP. Today, we want to talk to you about problems you people seem to be having with your personal viewing habits.

title: Dead Town Monument To Disaster
description: From a distance, the galvanized-steel roofs of this mountain village glint invitingly to the weary traveler. But upon arrival, it becomes painfully clear that Nios is an African ghost town.

title: The Vacation Plague
description: Six friends gathered recently in a house on the lip of the Atlantic. Waves slapped the shore; dune grass swayed in the breeze; a white-tailed doe and her two fawns nibbled the beach plums. Rarely had nature seemed more benign. But the people inside were less than enchanted. Five of the six were trying to outdo one another in describing symptoms of Lyme disease.

title: MCGWIRE'S 40th TOPS JAYS IN 10th
description: Mark McGwire led off the 10th inning with a home run, and Carney Lansford hit a homer in his fourth consecutive game, leading the Oakland Athletics to a 6-5 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays today.

title: How Zer-Zero Adds Up
description: THE formula for the United States-Soviet missile agreement that was suddenly at hand last week is known in Washington as global double zero.

title: SEASONING THE SEASON
description: The fervid pace of restaurant openings over the last five years has finally peaked, say restaurateurs. But try telling that to a casual stroller along Broadway, where the new options for theatergoers are nothing short of dramatic, or along Second Avenue in the 70's and 80's, where you pass one spiffy new pastel-splashed trattoria after another.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CASTLES IN THE SAND Once upon a time, Gerry Kirk and his partner in sand sculpturing, Todd Vander Pluym, built a 12-mile-long sand castle that covered six California beaches and won the pair the world record title for the largest and tallest sand castle. Since Sagaponack isn't exactly in California and Mr. Kirk is alone on this gig, today when he shows up at Peter's Pond to build his castles in the sand, he'll settle for a 15- to 20-foot-high structure, complete with turrets, towers, battlements and arched windows. He'll do all this from noon to 5 P.M. during a birthday party that Child Magazine is throwing for itself. There'll also be entertainment by Silly Billy the Clown; Wendy Brackman, who specializes in ''wacky hats'' and paper-plate costumes, and Compass Rose, a folk music group. Everything is free, but the Bridgehampton Child Care and Recreation Center will benefit from a raffle sale. FROM MOZART TO ROCK At Guild Hall's John Drew Theater this week, the beat goes from Beethoven and Mozart to rock-and-roll within six days. Today, the classics have it when Elmar Oliveira, the first American violinist to win a gold medal at the Tchaikovsky International Competition in Moscow, plays works by those masters and Ysaye and Saint-Saens. Accompanied by Robert McDonald at the piano, Mr. Oliveira performs at 6:30 P.M. On Saturday, in a concert that's become a traditional Labor Day weekend event, Lee Andrews and the Hearts, the Dubs and the Regents take the stage twice, at 7:30 and 10 P.M., to rock-and-roll across the venerable theater's stage. Guild Hall is on Main Street in East Hampton. For tickets call 324-4050. CYCLING CRAZE When it reached its first peak at the turn of the century, cycling was still considered a fad that would pass with time and the developing wisdom of its practitioners. The sport, or actually pastime, fooled everyone and has stayed around long eough to warrant a nostalgic, but scholarly, look back. That's what the Suffolk County Historical Society has done in ''The Cycling Craze 1890-1910,'' its current exhibition. With antique bicycles, bicycling memorabilia and photographs from the museum's extensive collections, the curators take a close look at the impact that the introduction of cycling had on social habits and transportation methods. For example, the show explores how the bicycle brought freedom and independence to more than just travel; it also affected how people dressed (it helped kill corsets and petticoats), and even how the sexes related to each other.

title: U.S. ISSUES LIMITS ON ABORTION AID BY FAMILY CLINICS
description: Proposed rules to prohibit abortion-related activities by family planning clinics that receive Federal funds were announced today by Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: DATA BANK: August 30, 1987

GARDENING;
The Lawn Routine Does Have Its Drawbacks
description: LEAD: IF anyone should care to remember, this past July was unusually hot and drenched with humidity. Garden chores were most unappealing.

title: Iowa and Tennessee Kick Off
description: Iowa wants to find its best quarterback and Tennessee needs to establish a defensive unit. Everyone will have a chance to play, say the coaches.

title: PATERSON, A FORGOTTEN MAN, REMEMBERED
description: LEAD: HE WAS a signer of the Constitution, a member of the first United States Senate, New Jersey's second Governor and a Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

title: 2 Setting the Stage At Dinner Theaters
description: JACK BELL said he had ''dreamed of producing musicals ever since I was a child,'' but his real inspiration came years later, in 1973, when he read an newspaper article about the popularity of dinner theaters.

title: Inquiry Finds No Wrongdoing In Pennsylvania Suicide Case
description: An investigation prompted by the public suicide of the state treasurer found no evidence to support his claim that a Federal lawyer had acted improperly in prosecuting him in a bribery-conspiracy case, the Justice Department announced Friday.

title: TIAWAN ROUTS IRVINE, 21-1, FOR TITLE
description: The Hua Lian team of Taiwan defeated the Irvine squad from California, 21-1, today to capture the Little League World Series championship with the most one-sided score in its 40-year history.

title: WALTON NOTES IMPROVEMENTS AFTER JETS MAKE ADJUSTMENTS
description: Joe Walton, asked recently to assess his team's first unsteady steps of the preseason, said that the Jets were still searching for a groove.

title: WHO WILL WIN THE U.S. OPEN, AND WHY?
description: Let's first eliminate who will not win: Jimmy Connors, Yannick Noah, Mats Wilander, John McEnroe, Boris Becker as well the usual surprising quarterfinalist.

title: In a Two-Crisis Week, Aquino Shows Her Nerve
description: IT was a week in which Corazon C. Aquino was again placed in her most compelling role, that of an earnest leader struggling against powerful odds.

title: CYCLE OF DRUG USE DEEPS GOING ROUND
description: WITH front-page headlines trumpeting the news of a drug scandal at the recent Pan American Games, and with persistent rumors that prominent United States track and field athletes tested positive for banned substances at our national championships, even the casual observer of sports is prompted to ask why.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: VEDI, by Ved Mehta. (Norton, $7.95.) In the third installment of Ved Mehta's family chronicle (''Daddyji'' and ''Mamaji'' are about his parents), the Indian writer turns more autobiographical and, using sounds, smells, tastes and textures, re-creates what he could not see: the Bombay slum school for the blind he attended as a child. The book's ''reliance on four strong senses plus the imagination'' renders the unseen ''almost palpable,'' Clark Blaise wrote in The Book Review in 1982.

title: SEAFOOD OF THE DESERT
description: THE SOUTHWESTERN region of the United States is vividly beautiful, spare, parched. So parched, it seems as though a strong wind would easily rearrange its sunset-hued desert landscape.

title: Family in AIDS Case Quits Florida Town After House Burns
description: As a result of a ''suspicious'' fire that destroyed their home Friday night, the parents of three young brothers infected with the AIDS virus said today that the family would leave this town in southern Florida.

title: ENCOUNTER WITH A MESSAGE OF PREJUDICE
description: ONE day last spring, my wife and I were strolling hand-in-hand along the New Haven shore. We are expecting our first child, and our thoughts were on life and love. Then we saw it: ''Nigger.''

title: VCR's Give Movies a Fresh Start
description: THIS IS WRITTEN IN PRAISE OF THE VIDEO cassette recorder, even as one attempts to deal with the sad news of the imminent demise of the Regency Theater, Manhattan's foremost film repertory house. The Regency has been sold to a giant exhibition combine and is due to be closed next week, remodeled and turned into yet another first-run theater on Manhattan's gentrified Upper West Side.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHY An overview of life in America in the 20th century and the progress of photography as an art and a historical record will be on display in a new exhibition called ''20th-Century Master American Photographs,'' opening Tuesday through Nov. 11 at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 1 Champion Plaza, Stamford.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hawthorne $168,000 7 Coolidge Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; sun room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace; taxes $1,518. Hewitt $162,000 176 Lakeshore Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old lakefront ranch; fireplace, full basement; taxes $1,993. Montville $350,000 14 Avalon Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; deck, wall-to-wall carpeting, central A/C and vacuum, 2-car garage; taxes $3,480. Morristown $229,900 30 Ershire Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old ranch; library, family room, porch, 1-car garage; taxes $2,970. Neptune $69,500 1712 Columbus Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; porch, patio, fenced yard; taxes $1,194. West Milford $203,900 196 Highcrest Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old contemporary; fireplace, family room, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,298.

title: Coping With Violence in Overcrowded Jails
description: OFFICIALS at the New York City Department of Correction expect 16,500 inmates to be packed into already overcrowded 11 city jails by October.

title: Hitting the Books
description: IN case anybody didn't get the message, Bob Wade, the Maryland basketball coach who took over from Lefty Driesell after the cocaine-induced death of Len Bias last year, apparently means business when he says that academics is at least as important as athletics. To help drive the point home, Wade has in effect suspended three of his players, including a starting guard, Keith Gatlin, from the team and ordered them to attend special tutoring sessions rather than practice or play.

title: TOMATOES, TOMATOES EVERYWHERE
description: THE undeniable appeal of fresh, vine-ripened tomatoes in season makes them a compelling choice for every summer meal. Some aficianadoes are content with slices adorned merely with salt and grindings of fresh pepper, a few sprigs of basil and a drizzle of fruity extra-virgin olive oil.

title: Harrison 'Rematch' In Supervisor Race
description: LEAD: The county telephone directory still lists John A. Passidomo as the Harrison Town Supervisor, a post he held for 19 years before resigning in 1983 to become the State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. But as he is once again the Democratic candidate for supervisor, Mr. Passidomo said, he will wait a bit before asking for the error to be corrected.

title: MYSTERIES FROM A NOVELIST NUN
description: PEERING OUT from behind the convent door, she makes you laugh right away as she thrusts out her chest to show off the message on her sweatshirt: ''I'd rather be writing my novel.'' Then she turns, in her patchwork slippers, and scuffles down the linoleum-tiled hallway to her office. It is there, across the bay from San Francisco, writing long-hand in a green Naugahyde easy chair, that she comes up with popular murder mysteries.

title: Hospitals Granted 30-Day Rate Rise
description: LEAD: STATE regulators have granted a 30-day, $9.5 million rate increase to hospitals across New Jersey to offset rises in nursing costs that hospital administrators have attributed to a ''critical'' shortage of registered nurses.

title: Giant Emotions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Cabinet of Curiosities Becomes a Museum
description: IN THIS ERA OF OVEREXPANDING museums, not only are the buildings themselves often losing their recognizable profiles, but the private collections that formed the institutions have long since merged their individual identities. Time was in earlier centuries when anyone of means who traveled to distant lands reurned with a few artifacts that were arranged systematically in a special room at home that reflected the emerging thirst for categorical knowledge. A gentleman's cabinet of curiosities is what these first museum-style rooms were called. Eventually, though, the articles dwindled as later generations sold them off.

title: Mini-Parade for North
description: To the Editor:

title: UCONN JOINS PROBE OF LAKES
description: SCIENTISTS and other staff members of the National Underseas Research Project of the University of Connecticut's Avery Point branch in Groton will be part of an American team traveling to Africa and Israel in the fall to demonstrate underwater robotics and probe the depths of ancient lakes.

title: In the Shadow Of the Acropolis, A Struggle Over Cultural Identity
description: EMBLEMS OF AN ATHENS summer: On a warm, Sunday evening, in an amphitheater 1,900 years old on the lea of the Acropolis, Vladimir Ashkenazy plays Schubert and Schumann. The brilliance billows through old stonework dusted by dusk sliding towards indigo night, and haunted by other, impenetrable gloamings from the past.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Orange, Mass.;
Do-It-Yourself Home Builders
description: LEAD: THEY have worked on frigid winter nights and in the heat of summer to build a dream - their own home. Now, Ted Matteson and his wife, Terry, are on the threshold of realizing that dream.

title: The First Sign of a Wimsey
description: ''I PARTICULARLY LIKE bus-shelter posters,'' Paul Davis says, ''because of the lighting and because they're placed where everybody passing by can see them.'' Davis, the art director for the New York Shakespeare Festival, is probably America's pre-eminent poster artist, and he's anticipating Sept. 15, when his latest work will be displayed at bus stops in New York and reproduced in newspapers in Boston, San Francisco and Los Angeles.

title: Up the Gulf Without a Paddle of International Law; Limits of Self-Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Local Color In Foliage Country
description: Every September and October, an army of leaf watchers invades New England, asking directions and wondering what they can do now that they've taken in the scenery.

title: Folk Festival Will Help the Homeless
description: From a modest beginning in 1981 as an outdoor entertainment for disadvantaged children, New York City's annual Folk Festival has grown into a week-long celebration that will be devoted this year to the theme, ''House the Homeless.''

title: Corinne Neale Is Wed To Patrick McCormick
description: Mary Corinne Neale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lewis Neale of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Patrick Thomas McCormick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald McCormick of Chappaqua, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua. Msgr. Robert F. Skelly performed the ceremony.

title: The Anti-Smoking Battle Goes Nowhere in Court
description: WILL the tobacco business go the way of the asbestos industry, driven into bankruptcy by an avalanche of lawsuits from those injured by its products? Not yet, anyway. Smokers' lawsuits have not so far extracted a cent in settlement, and last week the tobacco companies won their most significant legal victory yet.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: OPEN YOUR OWN BED AND BREAKFAST by Barbara Notarius. John Wiley & Sons Inc. 233 pages. $10.95.

title: 'Remaking Japan'
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael T. Harris Wed To Debra L. Leibowitz
description: Debra Lynn Leibowitz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold J. Leibowitz of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Thomas Harris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Robert Harris of New York. Rabbi Andre Ungar, assisted by Cantor Mark Biddleman, performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article in last Sunday's Arts and Leisure section about ''La Bamba'' inaccurately described Doug Sahm, a rock musician from Texas. Although Mr. Sahm has often performed in the ''Tex-Mex'' style and has used the name Doug Saldana, he is of German descent.

title: Pohl on Dollar Reserves
description: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, estimated that central banks bought up to $70 billion between the end of last year and May. Central banks used the intervention to shore up their currency reserves with cheap dollars, he said in an interview in the news magazine Der Spiegel to be published on Monday. Mr. Pohl said he expected the volatility of currency movements to ease in the next eight years.

title: Long-Range Rate Optimism
description: The steep rise in Treasury bond yields to well above 9 percent currently, from 7 1/2 percent in late March, has instilled the credit markets with pessimism and focused attention on reasons why rates might continue to rise.

title: Alvarado Journal; Spain Ahoy! Reborn Columbus Ship Heads Back
description: Moored amid the usual fishing skiffs, motorboats and trawlers at dockside here, one ship seems oddly out of place and time.

title: MINERS END STRIKE IN SOUTH AFRICA WITH NO WAGE GAIN
description: More than 250,000 black miners agreed today to end South Africa's largest and costliest strike after three weeks.

title: David Harlow, Lawyer, Weds Heather Zacker
description: Heather Beth Zacker and David Chasman Harlow, graduates of Brown University, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Judah in Ventnor, N.J., by the bridegroom's father, Rabbi Jules Harlow.

title: Window Guards Work
description: Strict enforcement of New York City's tough new window guard law is saving children's lives. Through July, there were 57 falls compared with 86 last year and the number of deaths dropped from 9 to 4. The Health Department merits praise for cracking down.

title: Metro Matters; Filtering the Dirt From the Energy Of Times Square
description: When the U.S.O. signed for new quarters last week, officials said they were relieved they could find a spot in Times Square. That's where military people come, said the center's director, Hazel Cathers, for the ''element of danger and excitement - it gets the adrenaline going.'' In fact, that's why tourists have been coming to Times Square for years.

title: Dr. Janet Fishman Marries Stephen A. Klausner
description: Dr. Janet Ellen Fishman, an assistant professor of sociology at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice of the City University of New York, was married yesterday to Stephen Allan Klausner, a senior vice president and an associate creative director at McCaffrey & McCall Inc., an advertising agency in New York. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the Tavern on the Green.

title: FLAWS CATCH UP WITH GIANTS
description: Super Bowl champions or not, the Giants are a football team with flaws. One major flaw is the secondary, and the problems there helped the Jets beat them Saturday night, 30-23, in their annual exhibition game at Giants Stadium.

title: BLACK CHILD'S SELF-VIEW IS STILL LOW, STUDY FINDS
description: The repeating of a landmark study shows that feelings of racial inferiority among young black children are as strong now as they were 40 years ago, researchers reported yesterday.

title: If You Didn't Notice
description: Unless you've been reading the papers closely, you may not have realized that after the national elopement with Lieut. Col. Oliver North and the contras, passions have cooled and the end of the affair is at hand.

title: Auto Exports Drop in Japan
description: Japan's exports of cars, trucks and buses dropped 6.2 percent in July from a year earlier, the sixth consecutive monthly decline, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said Friday.

title: Chiefs Swap Areas In Shawmut Merger
description: The day John LaWare of Boston's Shawmut Corporation met with Joel Alvord of the Hartford National Corporation to discuss the possible merger of their two banks, Mr. LaWare arrived before banking hours and entered the Hartford bank through the loading dock, rode up in the freight elevator and went through the back door of the executive offices.

title: TENNESSEE KICK EDGES IOWA
description: Phil Reich's 20-yard field goal, his third of the game, with three seconds remaining gave Tennessee the winning edge today in a 23-22 Kickoff Classic victory over Iowa.

title: FINDING SOLACE: PRAYERS ACCEPTING DIVORCE
description: When the United Church of Christ published the new edition of its ''Book of Worship'' in December, it introduced a section on prayers suitable for anyone going through a divorce.

title: Higher Prices Expected For Crude Oil Futures
description: Crude oil prices are expected to rise in the futures market this week, as concern grows among investors that the escalating war between Iran and Iraq could limit shipments of oil from the Persian Gulf.

title: Cases of Deficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubts on Intelligence Data: Iran Affair Renews the Issue
description: For most of President Reagan's tenure, the nation's intelligence agencies and some senior officials have fought with increasing bitterness over whether intelligence analyses prepared for the President were being distorted to support Administration policies.

title: Andretti Takes 200-Mile Race
description: Despite the lingering effects of a separated shoulder, Mario Andretti led from start to finish as he won a 200-mile Indy-car race at Road America today.

title: Raise Disabled Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Adidas Plans Pony Sale
description: The sporting goods manufacturer Adidas said Friday that it would sell its 80 percent stake in Pony Inc. to the Yarsel Investment Corporation of Taiwan for an undisclosed price. The Taiwan company already has the other 20 percent. Pony, which makes athletic shoes and apparel and is based in East Rutherford, N.J., posted sales of more than $100 million in 1986.

title: Triton Energy Stake Planned
description: New Zealand's busiest corporate investor, Ron Brierley, has notified the Triton Energy Corporation that he plans to increase his stake in the company to about 5 percent and might seek majority control, the Dallas-based oil and gas concern said Friday.

title: Iraqis Intensify Raids to Disrupt Iran Oil Traffic
description: Iraq, stepping up renewed attacks in the Persian Gulf, today bombed Iranian offshore oil sites for a second day, Baghdad communiques said.

title: ISRAEL OPENS TRIAL IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: The espionage trial of Mordechai Vanunu, the former nuclear technician who told a British newspaper what he said were details of Israel's nuclear weapons industry, began today in a Jerusalem courtroom behind closed doors and boarded windows.

title: Indiana Teen-ager With AIDS Ready to Start School Today
description: Ryan White begins classes Monday in a new school in a new town, where officials say he will be treated like just another student, not as the AIDS victim who once faced pickets and lawsuits.

title: Wasted Fuel Adds To Nicaragua Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Brand-Name Drugs Are Safer Than Generics
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMAN KILLS 3, THEN HERSELF
description: A woman who was described by friends as depressed and involved with drugs shot and killed a male companion, her sister and son before killing herself with a gunshot wound in the chest, the authorities say.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Construction SpendingJuly Leading IndicatorsJuly Wednesday None Thursday None Friday None

title: Good Skates
description: They may not play hockey the way God and Lord Stanley intended it to be played, but the way the Flying Fathers play it has been good enough to delight a generation of fans.

title: Tool Orders Dropped by 19.7% in July
