description: New orders for American-made machine tools plummeted 19.7 percent in July from the previous month's level, following strong increases in May and June, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Fellowships for Two
description: Two former Government insiders have been chosen as fellows of the Institute of Politics at the Kennedy School at Harvard for the coming fall term. Maxine Isaacs was Walter F. Mondale's press secretary when he ran for President in 1984 and an aide when he was Vice President. Jack Carlson was formerly an Assistant Secretary of the Interior and the chief economist for the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Baby Left on Convent Steps
description: The police were trying today to find the person who left a newborn baby wrapped in a towel on the doorsteps of a convent. The baby was found outside the St. Gregory convent at 9 A.M. Saturday after the police received a call about the infant, the police said. The infant was taken to United Hospital in Port Chester, where he was determined to be from 4- to 12-hours-old. His umbilical cord was cut and not tied or crimped. The baby was listed in fair condition today, the hospital said.

title: New Concern Raised By Waste-Dumping In Atlantic Off L.I.
description: Every working day, the barges laden with noxious wastes head for a spot in the Atlantic, 12 nautical miles off Long Island.

title: A Daily Closes in Puerto Rico
description: El Mundo, Puerto Rico's oldest daily newspaper, closed today after years of unprofitable operations and the collapse of efforts by the owners, the Angel Ramos Foundation Inc., to sell it.

title: Thousands in Poland Mark Solidarity's Birth
description: Solidarity supporters sang and prayed at masses here and in Gdansk today to mark the signing of accords that gave birth to their once independent trade union seven years ago Monday.

title: Dr. Vicki E. Jetter Is Married on L.I.
description: Dr. Vicki Ellin Jetter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Jetter of Oceanside, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Joseph Eichenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Eichenbaum of Lakewood, N.J. Rabbis Paul Z. Levovitz and Benjamin Blech and Cantor Joseph Malovany officiated at the Sands in Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: Israel Reports Killing 4 Guerrillas In a Battle in Southern Lebanon
description: Israeli soldiers killed four Lebanese Moslem guerrillas in a battle in southern Lebanon late Saturday night, according to the Israeli radio.

title: Don't Buy the S.D.I. Soap
description: LEAD: Having failed to gain credibility for its original vision of the Strategic Defense Initiative, the Administration now clings desperately to a new rationale for the program. The new marketing strategy says that initial deployment of S.D.I. would strengthen deterrence and deny the Soviet Union any hope of a successful first strike.

title: Filling the Nunn Vacuum
description: It isn't clear yet whether any Democrat will be able to fill the political vacuum left by Senator Sam Nunn's decision not to run for President, but it is clear that several would like to.

title: Lower Aluminum Price Seen in Rising Output
description: After six months of strong demand and surging prices for aluminum, there are signs that the industry may be headed for a return to worldwide overcapacity and weakening prices.

title: Lithuania Rights Unit Protests to Gorbachev
description: A group of Lithuanian human rights advocates sent a telegram to Mikhail S. Gorbachev today, saying the K.G.B. is harassing those who took part in a demonstration last week, a dissident reported.

title: People
description: * Susan Babbit Brenner has been promoted to senior vice president, research, at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: Reggie Jackson in the Ninth
description: ONE of baseball's great drawing cards -and the inspiration for a nutty chocolate bar (now extinct) - could be playing in his last regular-season games at Yankee Stadium this week.

title: STRANGE SETS MARK IN VICTORY
description: Curtis Strange established a PGA Tour single-season money-winning record today as he scored a relatively easy three-stroke victory in the N.E.C. World Series of Golf. Strange's third victory of the season was worth $144,000 from the $800,000 purse and pushed his earnings for the year to $697,385, surpassing the record of $653,296 earned by Greg Norman of Australia last year.

title: Bridge; Club managers Dominate Play in Open Pairs Event
description: The club management of New York City dominated the Flight A open pairs in the split regional championships Saturday. Arjun Ray of Manhattan, an assistant manager of the Cavendish Club of Manhattan, teamed with Jared Lillienstein of Flushing, Queens, an assistant manager of the Beverly Club, also of Manhattan, to take the title.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 31, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Year Later, California Town Remembers Jetliner Disaster
description: Residents of a neighborhood where a jetliner and a small plane collided and plunged to the gound a year ago, killing 82 people, joined in prayer today in remembrance of the tragedy.

title: British Report Of Boesky Aid
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York financier, has offered information to British authorities investigating a major takeover battle, The Observer reported today. Mr. Boesky faces sentencing Oct. 9 in the United States for illegal insider trading.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Wilson Sporting Goods Promotes Its President
description: LEAD: Glenn N. Rupp, president and chief operating officer of the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, has assumed the additional title of chief executive. He replaced John P. Murray, Wilson's 60-year-old chief executive, who has become the company's chairman.

title: Ojeda's Possible Dream
description: ''I remember the day a couple of months ago when I was swimming at a friend's house,'' Bob Ojeda was saying, ''and I went out into the backyard and picked up an old, beat-up baseball and threw it against the wall. That's how it started.''

title: Which War on Drugs?; Make a Dent by Making Choices
description: Whatever happened to the drug crisis? Last summer, it seized America's attention, stirring a lifeless political campaign. Then it passed on, eclipsed by AIDS, the Iran-contra scandal and air safety. Yet the need for coherent policy endures, beyond public relations spasms. Achieving such a policy requires refining outrage into a recognition that there is no simple answer, no single war; each drug poses its own issues.

title: Schools Faulted as Stressing Skills Over Ideas
description: Teachers and textbooks that emphasize skills over content are keeping American children ignorant of history and literature, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities said in a report issued today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 31, 1987
description: Companies

title: Scott A. Mandel Wed To Wendy Jill Balter
description: Wendy Jill Balter, a daughter of Norma Balter of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Lee Balter of Garrison, N.Y., was married yesterday at her father's home to Scott A. Mandel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Mandel of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi David Fass officiated.

title: BACK TO SCHOOL FOR PADDLING SKILLS
description: DONNA JACKSON waded precariously into Gillmore's Mistake, an easy Class 2 rapid on Wisconsin's Wolf river, and tossed herself onto her back in two-foot standing waves.

title: STAGE: POLISH CABARET
description: THE American musical-theater and cabaret worlds have nothing that quite resembles Piwnica pod Baranami, the 26-member Polish cabaret troupe that performed a two-and-a-half-hour show at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening. Part traveling circus, part variety show, part political cabaret, Piwnica pod Baranami (whose name means ''Cellar Under the Rams'') was established in a Cracow basement 30 years ago and since then has become something of a national institution.

title: L.I. Photon Soldiers Zap Foes for Fun
description: Stephen Glicker used to spend Friday nights at the movies with his girlfriend Cindy. That was before he became a swashbuckling Photon warrior.

title: Troop Carrier's Repair Backed by House Panel
description: The Army's plans to install a $43 part on the $1.5 million Bradley Fighting Vehicle should keep the amphibious troop carriers from sinking when they go into the water, a House Armed Services subcommittee said today.

title: Libyan Shows Outpost Chad Lost
description: The young Libyan colonel looked across the sandy waste stretching in every direction from this southern Libyan base and gave a stoic smile.

title: Project Irks Fishermen of Sheepshead Bay
description: The busiest time at Mike's Tackle Shop in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn is about 6 A.M. At that hour, the fishing boats start pulling out of the piers loaded with day passengers and their sandworms, everyone dreaming groggily of fluke.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carter Hawley Hale Stores, the Los Angeles department-store company, named as directors Caroline Leonetti Ahmanson, chairman of Caroline Leonetti Ltd., a woman's center for self-improvement; Myron Du Bain, chairman of SRI International, and Dennis C. Stanfill, president of Stanfill, Bowen & Co., a private investment firm.

title: Victory, and Not Cancer, Is Worry of Giant Fans
description: Fans and employees at Giants Stadium seemed more concerned with the point spread of the Jets-Giants game Saturday night than with any carcinogens that might lurk beneath the artificial turf.

title: SENDAK IN 'MON CHER PAPA'
description: MAURICE SENDAK, the renowned illustrator, is no stranger to television.

title: 1986 Talks By 2 Firms Questioned
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange have begun intensive investigations into the merger discussions late last year between the E. F. Hutton Group and the Shearson Lehman Brothers unit of the American Express Company, according to a number of Wall Street sources familiar with the inquiry.

title: Carburetor Chic
description: Does Montrachet goat cheese, straw and hay pasta, red onion soup and ragout of sea scallops and crayfish sound like the right food to accompany an excursion to a 500-mile stock-car race? The sport's traditional fans are quite happy to munch cold fried chicken and guzzle beer out of a can while they crowd into open grandstand seats to watch Richard Petty and Darrell Waltrip trade bumps at 200 miles an hour.

title: Land Is Winner In Show Jumpoff
description: Jay Land rode Leapy Lad to win the Hampton Classic Rose Jewelers Grand Prix jumping event in a jumpoff against the clock.

title: G.M., Ford Expect Incentives in 1988
description: Car and truck sales will continue at a brisk pace in 1988, according to officials of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the two largest American auto companies. But increasing competition will require the auto makers to use incentives and special marketing programs almost continuously to hold on to market share, company officials said here today.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Who was the last major league starter to win both games of a doubleheader with complete games?

title: DANCE: LLORY WILSON, FROM SEATTLE
description: THEY must be doing something right in Seattle, which has produced Mark Morris, the Pacific Northwest Ballet and now Llory Wilson. Her program on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, in Dance Theater Workshop's summer Out-of-Towners festival, had the independent spirit, simplicity and intelligence that seems to mark Seattle dance. The dances aren't easy to watch, in part because of their sometimes exasperating repetition. But Ms. Wilson zeros in unswervingly on a small, self-contained world that makes and needs to make no reference to anything outside it.

title: Poll Finds Democrats In Tight Race in Iowa
description: There is still no clear front-runner in Iowa among candidates vying for the Democratic Preridential nomination, although Representative Richard A. Gephardt seems to be leading, according to the latest Iowa Poll.

title: AN O'CASEY STAGES A BECKETT WORK
description: It takes some nerve for a shy, 16-year-old girl to tell Samuel Beckett that he ''ought to be more joyful,'' but that is what Shivaun O'Casey - the daughter of Sean O'Casey - said when she first met the author whose dramas about life's hopelessness and meaninglessness have become classics of 20th-century theater.

title: Kosar's Indoor Footage
description: Bernie Kosar, quarterback for the Cleveland Browns who was a recent Oval Office visitor, now has a videotape of that Presidential occasion recorded by a White House camera crew. But no, said Mark Weinberg of the White House press office, videotapes of Presidential greetings have not replaced the traditional photograph signed by the President. An in-house White House television crew is on hand to record the public activities of the Presidential day for archival and historical purposes and, from time to time, a White House visitor will be sent some footage of his meeting with the President.

title: Token Clerk Is Robbed After Death
description: A thief took advantage of a subway token clerk's fatal heart attack sometime around midnight Saturday by breaking into the token booth, reaching over the clerk's body and stealing more than $1,000 in cash, the police said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 31, 1987
description: International A2-6, A8-9

title: CASES OF DEFICIENCY
description: To the Editor:

title: Violent Death Halts Rap Musician's Rise
description: By age 25, Scott (La Rock) Sterling had achieved what many people only dream of.

title: BANKS FAILS TO REACH FINAL
description: Forlornly, Willie Banks walked away from the triple-jump area, trying to walk away from what had just happened.

title: Aquino Thanks Army for Backing Her
description: President Corazon C. Aquino thanked the armed forces today for defending her in a mutiny last week and all but dared the renegade officers to try again.

title: Advertising; Enquirer Promoting New Image
description: PEOPLE who look down their noses at The National Enquirer will find no friend in Patrick M. Linskey, the weekly publication's new publisher and executive vice president.

title: Justice Dept. Says Courts Can Cut Costs on Poor Defendants
description: Screening defendants to determine their ability to pay for a lawyer and requiring some to pay for part or all of their defense costs could reduce the financial burden on courts, the Justice Department said today.

title: Correction
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page last Monday about Presidential campaign consultants misidentified Daniel B. Payne. He is a Boston media consultant, not a member of the campaign staff of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachussetts.

title: Lee Marvin, Movie Tough Guy, Dies
description: Lee Marvin, who rebelled against a sheltered childhood to build an image as the consummate ''tough guy'' in the movies and in real life, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Tucson Medical Center in Arizona. He was 63 years old.

title: Business and the Law; Untested Issues On Smoking
description: AUGUST has been a difficult month for plaintiffs who have sued tobacco companies on health issues, but bigger battles lie ahead. Despite two recent decisions that have limited the ability of consumers to bring lawsuits against cigarette makers, more than 100 suits are pending, and many legal issues remain untested by the courts.

title: Boston Gunman Kills 5, Hurts 2 and Takes Own Life
description: A man opened fire with an automatic weapon in the Boston neighborhood of Dorchester today, killing four relatives and another woman and critically wounding two other relatives before taking his own life, the authorities said.

title: Key Witness in Presser Case Recants Payroll Statement
description: A key Government witness in the prosecution of Jackie L. Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and two co-defendants has recanted assertions that he was on the payroll of Mr. Presser's Local 507 in Cleveland without doing any work.

title: New Fairchild Tabloid
description: Fairchild Publications, a unit of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., has acquired the monthly Financial Services Times magazine from M& S Communications of Newton, Mass. Terms were not disclosed. Fairchild plans to combine the magazine with FP Week, a recently acquired biweekly. The new tabloid will be called Financial Services Week and will appear twice a month starting Oct. 5.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PETER THE GREAT. By Henri Troyat.

title: ONE WOMAN'S CHRONICLE OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS STRUGGLE
description: To this day, Mary King never leaves the house without her toothbrush.

title: Pilot Is Killed Upstate In Home-Built Copter
description: A home-built helicopter crashed in a farm field today shortly after taking off from the Rensselaer County Airport in Poestenkill, killing the pilot.

title: One-Person New York Subway Crew Is Feasible
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Sprinter Shatters 100-Meter Record
description: For all intents and purposes, the race was over before the first second ticked off the clock. Ben Johnson of Canada exploded out of the starting blocks and within a stride or two, he had a lead on Carl Lewis. Of such starts are world records made.

title: Foreign Concerns Cope With a Lower Dollar
description: Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, continues to attract growing numbers of upwardly mobile buyers. The company sold 3 percent more cars in the first half of the year than it did in the comparable 1986 period. But Volvo probably does not feel much like celebrating.

title: Dispute in the Pacific Adds Strains for France
description: France's already strained relations with Australia and New Zealand have been soured further by a dispute over the clubbing of independence demonstrators in New Caledonia, a French colony in the Pacific.

title: U.S. Booklet on AIDS Is Expected Out Soon
description: Nearly 7 million American households will soon receive a detailed Government booklet on AIDS in the wake of a dispute between the Reagan Administration and Congress over whether the pamphlets should be mass-mailed.

title: MASTERING THE FEAR OF WATER
description: THE relationship between people and water can be happy. However, some people go near the water but not in it, and for them the relationship is usually based on fear.

title: Court Interpreters Not Only for Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: A DREAM REALIZED, PAT CASH ADJUSTS TO PRESSURE OF SUCCESS
description: THERE was a vacant look in his eyes, as if Pat Cash had drawn the shade on his emotions. His voice was soft, his answers brief, lips barely moving, like a ventriloquist. But there was no puppet sitting alongside the winner and new Wimbledon champion, no alter ego named Crocodile Cash to offer a ''G'day, mate,'' that would allow the reporters to sample some of that Australian charm that is sweeping the world. That is what everyone expects, isn't it? That is the side of Cash that people want to see.

title: Abrams Seeks to Halt Child-Abuse Prevention Group Whose Members Are Armed
description: Charging that the Sullivan County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children is a ''sham'' whose only purpose is to make it easy for members to carry guns, the New York State Attorney General said yesterday that his office had filed a lawsuit to dissolve the group.

title: SMALL PRESSES FLOURISH
description: Publishers with names like Pharos Books, Hill & Company, Thunder's Mouth and Acropolis are still a long way from rivaling Random House and Simon & Schuster, but they and other small book publishers are beginning to make their presence felt in a big way. In fact, small presses will publish more books this year by name authors, and more books on important subjects, than at any time in recent years.

title: CARTER SLAM HELPS METS AND AGUILERA TOP GIANTS
description: Keith Hernandez, the captain and crossword-puzzle star of the Mets, reached for the precise word to describe a team that is five and a half games behind with 32 to play.

title: Sarah Tingley Baldwin Wed in Massachusetts
description: Sarah Tingley Baldwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Baldwin of Sandwich, Mass., was married yesterday to Fred Bruce Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Weiss of White Plains. Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony at the Methuen (Mass.) Memorial Music Hall.

title: India Shoes Gaining In the West
description: The way Ajit Kumar Sen, a senior Government official, tells it, when India began exporting shoes to the Soviet Union in the 1950's, neither side insisted on high standards of workmanship.

title: JETS FIND REASONS TO BELIEVE
description: In football legend, a play in the third exhibition game might become the rallying cry for a moribund team, the moment of truth that turns a team around.

title: MAYFAIR CAPTURES U.S. AMATEUR TITLE
description: Billy Mayfair of Arizona State defeated Eric Rebmann today, 4 and 3, to win the 87th United States Amateur golf championship.

title: MANUELA MALEEVA DEFEATS HANIKA
description: Sharing the rare joy of a tournament victory with family and close friends is difficult for most of the players on the tennis tour as they skip about the globe each week.

title: DAWSON'S 43D BEATS REDS' RASMUSSEN
description: Andre Dawson hit a two-run home run and a run-scoring single today as the Chicago Cubs beat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-1, to spoil Dennis Rasmussen's pitching debut with the Reds.

title: Bank in China Issuing Shares
description: A Chinese bank is issuing stock for the first time since the 1949 Communist takeover of China, the official New China News Agency said today. The Bank of Communications in Shanghai has started to issue $27 million worth of stock. The bank, which opened in

title: Translating Squash
description: Unlike most sports played in America, which undergo only minor rule changes for international competition, the game of squash racquets changes dramatically - from a fast-paced game played with a hard ball to the slower, more tactical international version played with a soft ball on a larger court.

title: Poll Finds Support for Tougher Back-to-Basics Approach in Schools
description: Americans overwhelmingly support tougher standards in the nation's public schools, including more emphasis on basic courses and less on electives, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Apparently, I trained to run pretty fast.'' - Ben Johnson of Canada,after setting a record for 100 meters. [ C6:1. ]

title: Israelis Decide Not to Construct Lavi Jet Fighter
description: After months of wrenching debate, the Israeli Cabinet voted today to halt development of the Lavi fighter jet, which was to be Israel's main advanced combat aircraft for the 1990's.

title: U.S. Men Slow
description: Lewis's second-place finish only underscored the growing concern over the showing here of the United States men. Today, several important competitors failed to advance, including Willie Banks and Charlie Simpkins in the triple jump and Johnny Gray, the American record holder, and Stanley Redwine in the 800 meters. In the javelin, the top American finisher was Tom Petranoff, who was fourth. Duncan Atwood, the only other American in the field, was 12th and last.

title: Tryart Seeks John Fairfax
description: Tryart Proprietary, owned by Sir Warwick Fairfax, said it would make a takeover bid for John Fairfax Ltd. to take it private and restructure the media group.

title: BOOKS: HEROIC DOCTOR
description: LEAD: WHO GOES FIRST? The Story of Self-Experimentation in Medicine. By Lawrence K. Altman, M.D. 430 pages. Random House. $22.50.

title: B.B.D.O. Wins Account For Pizza Hut
description: Pizza Hut chose Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn over Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton to handle its budget, estimated to be in the $25 million to $30 million range.

title: Restiveness in Manila: A Call for Strong Leadership
description: Eighteen months after ousting a man many called a dictator, many Filipinos are calling for strong leadership, which they complain President Corazon C. Aquino is not providing.

title: TAKING A CLOSE LOOK AT THE ART OF POST-MODERNIST ARCHITECTS
description: There is a touch of the fantastic about the series of rooms, filled with richly imagined visions of yet other rooms, as well as of buildings, bridges, cemeteries, streets, suburban homes and entire cities.

title: Market Place; MTM Seeking Hit on Wall St.
description: TELEVISION viewers know Mary Tyler Moore as the stay-at-home wife on the ''Dick Van Dyke Show'' and the all-American career woman in her own award-winning show.

title: CANADA DEFEATS FINLAND, 4-1
description: Kevin Dineen scored one goal and set up another as Team Canada posted a 4-1 victory over Finland tonight in Canada Cup play.

title: INSIDE
description: Sniper Kills 5 in Boston

title: New Jersey's Project
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. HEAVYWEIGHTS TRIUMPH
description: The United States won the gold medal in the glamour event of the regatta, the heavyweight men's eights, as the 1987 world rowing championships ended today.

title: STEFFI GRAF USES SINGLE-MINDED DRIVE TO CAPTURE NO. 1
description: TENNIS historians, like those who study the reigns of kings, emperors, presidents and dictators, derive an almost diabolical pleasure from chronicling the demise of the monarchs who rule the sport. That is especially true of those charting the women's circuit, which has been ruled since 1975 by Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert.

title: To Neighbors of Shunned Family, AIDS Fear Outweighs Sympathy
description: The day after Clifford and Louise Ray decided to quit this town, citing the suspicious fire that gutted their house Friday night, those who fought to keep the couple's children out of school are saying the battle was really not against the Ray family.

title: Black Men Fingerprinted After a Series of Rapes
description: After several elderly women were raped over the last four years, the police in this depressed steelmaking community outside Pittsburgh have resorted to voluntary fingerprinting of black male residents.

title: Honeyghan Wins In 40 Seconds
description: Lloyd Honeyghan knocked out Gene Hatcher 40 seconds into the first round today to retain his World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation welterweight titles.

title: Elizabeth Levine Wed To Robert W. Kennedy
description: Elizabeth Levine, the daughter of Dr. Stephen M. Levine and Dr. Rhea J. C. Levine of Haddonfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert William Kennedy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Kennedy of Melbourne, Australia. Rabbi Richard Address officiated at the Wharton Sinkler Estate in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia.

title: Police Baffled for Motive In Beating of a Woman
description: Cheryl Ickson never showed up on Aug. 23 for her job as a desk clerk at the motel her family owns and operates in Stony Point, N.Y.

title: Coup de Fusil Gets A Narrow Victory
description: Angel Cordero Jr.'s mount nosed out Jose Santos's to win today's John A. Morris Handicap at Saratoga, but it made little difference to anyone but those riders. The two were riding the entrymates Coup de Fusil and Clabber Girl, who finished a nose apart and six lengths ahead of the others as the 1-to-2 favorites in the Grade I race for older fillies.

title: Patent Extension Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Rowland Marries Dr. Paul J. Gagne
description: At Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, Conn., Elizabeth Ann Rowland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Rowland of Weston, was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Joseph Gagne, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Gagne of Leominster, Mass. The Rev. George Laedlein, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, officiated with the Rev. Charles Allen, a Roman Catholic priest who is the headmaster of the Fairfield (Conn.) Preparatory School.

title: Biden, Once the Field's Hot Democrat, Is Being Overtaken by Cooler Rivals
description: It was late at night and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. was saying goodbye to his New Hampshire campaign staff. In the weary quiet of a tiny airport in Keene, the Democratic Presidential candidate thanked his troops for doing ''a phenomenal job,'' then sought to rally their spirits for the days to come.

title: Washington Journal; On the Drug Patrol: Hands Tell It All
description: ''Watch the hands,'' Officer Freddy Lawson said, easing the unmarked car to a stop and pointing to a group of young people gathered on the corner half a block ahead.

title: REVAMPED ROCKET FOR SPACE VEHICLE PASSES A KEY TEST
description: A redesigned version of the shuttle booster rocket whose leaking seal led to the Challenger disaster was tested for the firrt time here today, filling a mountain valley with a roar that space agency officials said marked a major milestone for getting the shuttle flying again.

title: Kurds Kill 3 in Turkey
description: Separatist Kurdish guerrillas armed with guns and grenades killed a man and his two daughters in a raid on Caylidere village in southeast Turkey Saturday night, officials said today.

title: RANGERS HAND TIGERS VICTORY
description: Lou Whitaker scored four of Detroit's seven unearned runs today and Doyle Alexander pitched a three-hitter as the Tigers beat the Texas Rangers, 7-0, to maintain their one-game lead over Toronto in the American League East.

title: GULLICKSON'S STRONG START GIVES YANKS SOME RELIEF
description: Life in the big city. It can be a cruel experience.

title: Officials Report Drop In Violence in Schools
description: For the sixth consecutive year, reported incidents of violence and other rules infractions have declined in New York City's nearly 1,000 public schools, the city's top school officials said yesterday.

title: Lomas Broadens Its Horizons
description: For nearly 20 years, the Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation was the undisputed leader in the staid mortgage banking business.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 31, 1987: MONDAY Albertson's Inc. Watkins-Johnson Foxboro Co. TUESDAY Cummins Engine Premier Industrial WEDNESDAY Alaska Air Group Stanley Works Louisville Gas & Electric Starrett (LS) Pennwalt Corp. USF & G Corp. THURSDAY Atlantic City Elec Lucky Stores Brown Group SPS Technologies Engelhard Corp. Times-Mirror Co. Esselte Business Systs Washington Natl Corp. General Host

title: The Lure of the Bordeaux Chateaus
description: With his Yale degree, Levis blue jeans and stumbling French, Colin Ferenbach does not fit the image of a typical Bordeaux winegrower.

title: Declassified Cables Add to Doubts About U.S. Disclosures on 'Yellow Rain'
description: It was a frustrating two years for the official American team sent to investigate reports of chemical warfare described as ''yellow rain'' in Southeast Asia.

title: 2 HELD BY I.N.S. HURT IN ATTEMPT TO ESCAPE HOTEL
description: Two men from India being held by immigration authorities in a Kennedy International Airport hotel were injured after they tried to escape by tying their turbans, bed sheets and pillow cases together, lowering the makeshift rope from their fourth-floor hotel window and climbing down, the authorities said yesterday.

title: A FARM SYSTEM FOR SKIPPERS
description: According to Gary Jobson, who has won the last two Liberty Cups in New York Harbor, next month's fourth annual match-racing competition among eight of the world's best skippers and crews might also serve as a reunion for America's Cup sailors of the last decade and as a training ground for cup racers of 1991.

title: A Quirky Market for Autographs
description: An authentic Joe Biden, the experts say, is worth about $10. Same for Dick Gephardt and Michael Dukakis. Even a Gary Hart fetches only about $25 and the late Hubert H. Humphrey - well, you'd be lucky to get subway fare.

title: To Reporters: Quit South Africa
description: South Africa is winning the war of images, and that is changing the way the entire world looks at the human struggle in that faraway land. In the name of more accurate and sensitive coverage, perhaps the time has come for Western news organizations, specifically American network news operations, to say ''enough'' to the Government in Pretoria and to pick up our marbles and go home.

title: Judith A. Fried, an Editor Marries Douglas Conrad
description: At the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y., Judith Ann Fried, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Fried of New Rochelle, was married yesterday to Douglas Conrad, a son of Elaine Conrad of Port Washington, L.I., and Hallendale, Fla., and Paul Conrad of Bellmore, L.I., and Inverarry, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Melvin Sirner, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery, performed the ceremony.

title: Vietnam, Seeking Capital, Eases Rules
description: Vietnam, falling further and further behind its free-market Southeast Asian neighbors in development, is about to begin an ambitious two-track investment campaign.

title: Host Mothers and Den Mothers
description: More mothers working away from home means more worry about serious matters like latchkey children, but there are lesser victims, too. Consider the recent report that programs for foreign exchange students are having trouble finding host families. Little wonder; no one's home to help make the adjustments.

title: POP: MICHAEL JACKSON'S 'BAD,' FOLLOW-UP TO A BLOCKBUSTER
description: WHAT could Michael Jackson do to follow up the best-selling album to date? That's been the question since 1983, when sales of ''Thriller'' took off - and the answers in the last few years were peculiar indeed. Instead of recording, Mr. Jackson made a film for Disneyland; he had a cleft implanted in his chin; he offered a British hospital a million dollars to buy the remains of the Elephant Man. The wait between albums stretched to four and a half years. Today, two days after Mr. Jackson's 29th birthday, the long-delayed ''Bad'' (Epic EK 40600) arrives in record stores, and it's a gleaming, high-tech dance record that's just a little eccentric at the edges.

title: Jean Korelitz Is Wed to Paul Muldoon
description: Jean Hanff Korelitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burton I. Korelitz of New York and South Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Muldoon, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Muldoon of the Moy, County Armagh, Northern Ireland. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Michael A. Robinson at the Korelitzes' home in South Salem.

title: Arms Pact With U.S. Is Possible Despite Details, Soviet Aide Says
description: A Soviet official said today that there were still important details to be resolved in negotiations on reducing nuclear missiles in Europe, but he reaffirmed his country's optimism that an agreement with the United States could be achieved.

title: Treasury to Auction Bills This Week
description: Treasury auctions this week are confined to the bill sector, with today's auctions of new three- and six-month issues followed by tomorrow's one-year bill auction.

title: Blue Cross/Blue Shield Goes to Hal Riney
description: The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, Chicago, the national coordinating organization for 77 health plans across the country, has awarded Hal Riney & Partners/Chicago its $10 million budget.

title: Accounts
description: * Legg Mason, Baltimore, a brokerage firm, to VanSant Dugdale Advertising, Baltimore.

title: A Village Creates Housing for the Desperate Elderly
description: Strictly speaking, John McCann was never homeless. No one lives on the streets in this village in the northern foothills of the Adirondacks. But what he was living in, a rusting trailer with no indoor plumbing and little more heat, was less than a home.

title: Here Lies Free Trade. R.I.P.
description: LEAD: The failure of the nation's trade deficit to shrink has become a major embarrassment to the economics profession. According to conventional theory, the declining value of the dollar is supposed to make American goods cheaper and foreign goods more expensive, thereby enabling American producers to win back markets they lost when the dollar rose in the early 1980's.

title: Upscale Shopping Spree Daunts Visiting Russians
description: A group of visitors from the Soviet Union went to Bloomingdale's today, took a quick look around and asked for asylum - at Sears.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Remembering Gershwin The last New York concert appearance of George Gershwin, at Lewisohn Stadium on July 10, 1936, is to be recreated tonight at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, in an evening of nostalgia.
